[b"New York Today: The State of Our State - The New York Times\nSectionsSEARCHSkip to contentSkip to site indexNew YorkSubscribeLog InLog InToday\xe2\x80\x99s PaperNew York|New York Today: The State of Our StateAdvertisementSupported byNew York TodayNew York Today: The State of Our StateImageGov. Andrew M. Cuomo will address the state this afternoon from Albany.CreditCreditNathaniel Brooks for The New York TimesBy Alexandra S. LevineJan. 3, 2018Good morning on this (somewhat) warmer Wednesday.While many New Yorkers are still returning from holiday, city and state officials are already pounding the political pavement.Mayor Bill de Blasio was sworn into office for his second term on Monday, and today, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will deliver the annual State of the State address in Albany.The stakes are higher this year for the governor, a Democrat in his second term \xe2\x80\x94 he\xe2\x80\x99s up for re-election in November and may have presidential ambitions for 2020.Though Mr. Cuomo has been lauded for progressive victories \xe2\x80\x94 like tuition-free college, the legalization of same-sex marriage, a higher minimum wage and paid family leave \xe2\x80\x94 he has also faced troubles in office. He has been blamed (and blamed some more) for New York City\xe2\x80\x99s transit crisis. He has also been criticized for his response to sexual harassment allegations against one former senior aide, and for his ties to another aide who will go on trial this month to face corruption charges.In his speech this afternoon, Mr. Cuomo will lay out his vision for the state. A few of the plans he is expected to put forward:On SafetyHis gun-control proposal would take firearms out of the hands of New Yorkers who commit domestic violence crimes. One criminal justice proposal would outlaw \xe2\x80\x9csextortion\xe2\x80\x9d and revenge porn, and another would address workplace sexual harassment.On the EnvironmentSeveral environmental proposals would take action to protect New York\xe2\x80\x99s water, from the Hudson River and Long Island to Niagara Falls and our state lakes. Another plan would outline steps to fight climate change, and a separate land proposal would reduce the local property tax.On EducationHis \xe2\x80\x9cNo Student Goes Hungry\xe2\x80\x9d proposal would give students in kindergarten through college healthy meals at school. Another\nproposal would help students and graduates navigate loans and debt. He will also unveil plans to better prepare New Yorkers for the work force.The speech will begin at 1 p.m., and you can watch it online. (The live stream will appear on the website a few minutes before 1 p.m.)Here\xe2\x80\x99s what else is happening:WeatherAfter getting through days of single digits, today\xe2\x80\x99s high around 29 might feel comparatively bearable.It will stay sunny and bright until flurries begin this evening, leaving us with a windy, snow-shrouded Thursday.The weekend\xe2\x80\x99s looking clear, but even colder.In the News\xe2\x80\xa2 Transportation officials are left wondering if President Trump decided to block the plan to build an $11 billion rail tunnel under the Hudson River. [New York Times]ImageA portion of a new rail tunnel that will cross the Hudson River between New Jersey and Manhattan.CreditPhilip Montgomery for The New York Times\xe2\x80\xa2 Corey Johnson is expected to become the next speaker of the New York City Council, arguably the second-most influential political post in the city. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 In an unusual degree of consensus among the notoriously divided state Legislature, lawmakers propose legislation cracking down on sexual harassment. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 New York Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 best hope to challenge Governor Cuomo has backed out, leaving the party scrambling. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 A federal judge cleared the way for the $905 million sale of Starrett City, the nation\xe2\x80\x99s largest federally subsidized apartment complex. [New York Times]ImageShareholders tried to block the sale of Starrett City, the massive housing complex just off of the Belt Parkway near East New York. On Tuesday, a judge let it proceed.CreditJohnny Milano for The New York Times\xe2\x80\xa2 Mayor de Blasio announced a plan to protect pedestrians from truck attacks by installing 1,500 bollards around the city. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 City officials said they were taking the first step to shuttering Rikers Island by closing a facility that houses 600 men at the jail site this summer. [New York Post]\xe2\x80\xa2 What happened to Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s political clout? A look at how the king-making county lost its mojo. [The Bridge]\xe2\x80\xa2 An Upper West Side church once slated for a condo conversion will now be the new home of the Children\xe2\x80\x99s Museum of Manhattan. [Curbed]\xe2\x80\xa2 At MulchFest, you can bring your Christmas tree to a city park to be ground up into wood chips, which will be used to feed plants and trees on streets and in parks across the city. [Bklyner]\xe2\x80\xa2 After seeking help at a domestic violence shelter in 2012, a mother pushes forward to give her children a better life. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 Today\xe2\x80\x99s Metropolitan Diary: \xe2\x80\x9cWalking the Dog\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\xa2 For a global look at what\xe2\x80\x99s happening, see Your Morning Briefing.Coming Up Today\xe2\x80\xa2 Visit the Whimsical Winter Wonder photo shoot, where families can take pictures with Wanderlust the Unicorn, the Crescent Moon and other fantasy props, at Poe Park in the Bronx. 2:30 p.m. [Free]\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x80\x9cThe Power of Poop,\xe2\x80\x9d a talk by the gastroenterologist Ari Grinspan about gut health and the microbes in our intestines, at the American Museum of Natural History on the Upper West Side. 7 p.m. [Free]\xe2\x80\xa2 Celebrate the holiday season with a Tenet and Bach Vespers performance of hymns, carols and motets at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on the Upper West Side. 7:30 p.m. [Tickets start at $30]\xe2\x80\xa2 Grab a group of friends for \xe2\x80\x9cYellow Tape,\xe2\x80\x9d a bar trivia show focused on all-things true crime, unsolved mysteries and more, at Q.E.D. in Astoria, Queens. 9 p.m. [$7]\xe2\x80\xa2 Looking ahead: On Saturday, adults can see the still-festive Train Show after hours \xe2\x80\x94 with cocktails and live music \xe2\x80\x94 as part of \xe2\x80\x9cBar Car Nights\xe2\x80\x9d at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.\xe2\x80\xa2 Knicks at Wizards, 7 p.m. (MSG). Nets host Timberwolves, 7:30 p.m. (YES). Rangers host Blackhawks, 8 p.m. (NBCSN).\xe2\x80\xa2 Alternate-side parking remains in effect until Jan. 15.\xe2\x80\xa2 For more events, see The New York Times\xe2\x80\x99s Arts & Entertainment guide.And Finally...ImageYou have until the end of the month.CreditTimothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse \xe2\x80\x94 Getty ImagesIn December, New Yorkers were using LinkNYC stations to dial Santa at the North Pole.This month, they can use the sidewalk kiosks to sign up for health care coverage.LinkNYC, which offers free Wi-Fi connections and web browsing at thousands of city street corners, is working with GetCoveredNYC and the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications to create a health care enrollment app on tablets across the five boroughs. New Yorkers can use the app to explore insurance options, enroll and change existing plans.The open enrollment period for new health insurance plans ends Jan. 31.New York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.For updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.What would you like to see here to start your day? MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nDIGITAL STATES PERFORMANCE INSTITUTE\nTOP 25\nGOVTECH 100\nSEARCH\nCybersecurity\nGovTech Biz\nEmerging Tech\nCloud\nGov Experience\nMore\nBudget & Finance\nSmart City Procurement: Making the 100-Year Decisions\nPlanning for the future technology needs of a major city takes foresight, planning and the ability to spot an opportunity on the fly.\nby Stephen Goldsmith, Data-Smart City Solutions\n/\nJanuary 5, 2018\nShutterstock\nThis post originally appeared on\xc2\xa0Data-Smart City Solutions.\nCity officials face difficult challenges as they begin to weave a digital fabric through their streets and buildings. Not only do they need to confront questions of what pieces of infrastructure belong to that fabric -- whether street lights, broadband kiosks, parking meters or other fixtures -- but they must also consider compounding complexities such as the role of the private sector, liability issues and equity for underserved communities.\nCity procurement officials and program managers are on the front lines of these challenges. They should have a strong sense of which solutions to package together and be able to evaluate the blizzard of innovative vendor-based solutions. Crucially, they must avoid the obsolescence risk that new purchases can be quickly outdated or simply seen as faddish trends.\nAt the center of this storm -- in not one but two major cities -- is Miguel Gami\xc3\xb1o, the talented chief technology officer of New York City who I first met in his office while he was serving as San Francisco\'s CIO.\nAs we talked about his vision for the city, he filled his whiteboard with different options he might employ to fulfill his goal of bringing broadband to all city neighborhoods. Gami\xc3\xb1o brought that goal with him to New York, where he now works on the city\'s plan to achieve affordable high-performing broadband for all New Yorkers by 2025.\nIn a recent phone call, Gami\xc3\xb1o acknowledged to me the difficulty of making "hundred-year decisions often in the context of the current demands." To break down that task, we need to deconstruct the procurement challenges facing cities, starting with two primary considerations: setting the right interim goals and considering funding options.\nInterim goals:\xc2\xa0On the way to its long-term connectivity goals, a city will encounter a number of discrete opportunities that need to be prioritized. These may include community-level data dashboards, free street-level wireless hubs, improved emergency call services, smart parking meters, gunshot detectors, and noise and mobility sensors. These interim goals should prioritize not only critical new Internet-of-Things services but should also extend existing services such as community bulletin boards, 911 and 311 access, voter registration, job placement support, and housing and medical services.\nThe best procurement offices will consider ways to invite innovation and dynamic flexibility into the process. For instance, this past spring Pittsburgh issued a request for information to get help updating its 40,000 streetlights, many of which were still using conventional lightbulbs. Rather than focus the RFI on the light replacement alone, however, the city left the procurement process open to unconventional service providers that might integrate technology that could help the city monitor traffic conditions, air quality or gunshot noises, and even provide cellphone service. No project is too conventional to push toward the goal of universal connectivity.\nFunding options:\xc2\xa0Cities across the country are deciding whether to expand the scope of infrastructure spending from its more traditional role of funding streets and sewers to also include digital services and wireless access. They are also considering other revenue sources, such as advertising. In New York City, residents who could never afford data plans can now access street-level, high-speed wireless internet due to the advertising revenue sharing agreement the city worked out with the vendor for\xc2\xa0LinkNYC, the city\'s system of sidewalk broadband kiosks.\nOther cities more severely restrict advertising. While LED screens delivering ads may work for New York, Gami\xc3\xb1o says, the issue and the tradeoffs it presents remain the subject of debate in San Francisco. Those opposed to advertising often are motivated by a desire to protect the aesthetic character of neighborhoods. On the other hand, the revenues derived from advertising can provide resources to significantly improve the ability of a resident of an underserved area to access the benefits of the internet. Simply put, one person\'s aesthetics might be another\'s lifeline.\nAs cities continue to build out integrated, connected systems, they will face additional issues, among them design, the control of content delivered by devices occupying public spaces, and the use of public infrastructure for advanced cellular connectivity. A city official\'s job isn\'t to determine how to build one big digital system but rather to figure out how to define its elements. "I don\'t have to care so much about individual smart infrastructure like a smart lighting project or the smart trash can because other agencies will," Gami\xc3\xb1o says. "I have to care about helping those things interoperate with one another to exchange data and effect a smarter, seamless user experience to everyone in the public realm, to improve the way people experience New York City." He continues that work one day at a time, never losing sight of the bigger goals far down the road.\nRELATED\nTraverse City, Mich., OKs City-Owned Gigabit-Speed Network\nSan Diego, USMC Partner on Regional Smart City Initiatives\nIdaho Lawmaker Proposes Changes to IT Bid Posting Rules\nDISCUSS\nWe invite you to discuss and comment on this article using social media.\nMORE FROM Budget & Finance\nSPONSORED ARTICLES\nERP Modernization: How the Cloud Delivers Scalability, Security and Innovation\nThe Reality of the Local Government Cybersecurity Skill Gap\nGovernment No Longer Has to Choose Between Cybersecurity and Productivity\nNEWSLETTERS\nGovTech Today - Scientific American\nSkip to main contentSubscribeMenuScientific American Cart 0Sign In Email *:Password *:Forgot password?LoginNot yet registered?|Stay InformedSearchSubscribeCloseSearchCloseAdvanced SearchThe SciencesMindHealth TechSustainabilityEducationVideoPodcastsBlogsPublicationsSubscribeCurrent IssueCart0Sign InStay InformedShareLatestComputingNet Neutrality Loss Could Rekindle ISP Alternatives for Internet AccessThe FCC\xe2\x80\x99s decision to kill the 2015 Open Internet Order hands more control to large broadband providers, but internet users have other options for getting onlineBy Larry Greenemeier on January 8, 2018Share on FacebookShare on TwitterShare on RedditShare on LinkedInShare viaPrintNYC Mesh\xe2\x80\x99s community-owned and managed broadband network in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn is set to grow dramatically following the FCC\xe2\x80\x99s recent vote against regulating commercial ISPs. Credit: mromerorta PixabayAdvertisement\nEditor\xe2\x80\x99s Note (06/11/18):\xc2\xa0Scientific American\xc2\xa0is re-posting the following article, originally published January 8, 2018, now that the Federal Communications Commission\xe2\x80\x99s repeal of net neutrality rules has gone into effect. Many fear the Trump administration\xe2\x80\x99s December decision to\xc2\xa0kill the Open Internet Order\xc2\xa0could embolden broadband providers to manipulate how their customers access and use the internet, although it remains to be seen whether that will happen.\nThe Trump administration\xe2\x80\x99s recent decision to kill the Open Internet Order has a lot of net neutrality advocates fearing the worst. Foremost among those concerns: that last month\xe2\x80\x99s Federal Communications Commission vote might embolden broadband providers to manipulate how their customers access and use the internet. Although it remains to be seen whether that will happen, a small but growing number of users are taking matters into their own hands by exploring community- or municipal-owned, operated and funded internet access as a cheaper, faster and more neutral alternative to using large commercial internet service providers.\nNYC Mesh, which typically gets 20 requests per month for membership to its community-based network in New York City, has received connection inquiries from more than 200 people since the FCC\xe2\x80\x99s December 14 vote, says Brian Hall, a software consultant who helps manage the network. Self-organized, community-run systems including this one and Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s The Equitable Internet Initiative have for years offered alternatives to corporate ISPs such as Comcast and Time Warner Cable.\nThe community approach typically involves organizers renting internet access from a local data center, and installing rooftop antennas and wi-fi routers that together act as access point for nearby residents. Unlike a home or office router that provides wi-fi service for a dozen or so square meters, a community network can provide a wi-fi signal for several square kilometers. Residents connect to the access point by mounting their own antennas on their buildings\xe2\x80\x99 rooftops or outside their windows. These antennas receive the network\xe2\x80\x99s signal and send it through a cable to wi-fi routers located inside members\xe2\x80\x99 homes or offices. The setup is called a \xe2\x80\x9cmesh\xe2\x80\x9d network because any member can act as an access point, or node, for other members.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople are so used to ISPs that they think that\xe2\x80\x99s the only way to access the internet,\xe2\x80\x9d Hall says, adding ISPs have built their businesses by acting as gatekeepers between customers and the internet in order to extract as much money as possible. NYC Mesh pays about $1,000 per month to use the data center but does not charge members for access to the mesh network. The organization currently uses a grant from the Internet Society New York Chapter to pay the rent, and suggests members donate $20 per month to help cover ongoing rental and management costs.\nNYC Mesh has 70 wi-fi router nodes, many of which are connected to two "supernodes" that provide internet access at about 100 megabits per second, or Mbps\xe2\x80\x94more than twice as fast as the average commercial ISP connection\xe2\x80\x94throughout Lower Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn. The original supernode is run out of a Lower Manhattan data center. In that setup the group\xe2\x80\x99s antenna is mounted on the roof and their computer servers are a few floors below in what is known as the \xe2\x80\x9cradio room,\xe2\x80\x9d Hall says. The servers run software that manages the network. They are also linked via optical fiber cables to a \xe2\x80\x9cmeet-me room\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the location in a data center where networks interconnect directly with the internet backbone, without needing an ISP to serve as an intermediary.\nTo access one of the supernodes, a resident needs to get a wi-fi router node and install an antenna\xe2\x80\x94either on the roof of their building or in a window with an unobstructed line of sight to the supernode\xe2\x80\x99s transmitting antennas. Members whose view of the antennas is blocked by a building or bridge can connect to other NYC Mesh members\xe2\x80\x99 nodes. Residents can also access the network using the public LinkNYC kiosks that the city has installed throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re basically a wi-fi network,\xe2\x80\x9d Hall says.\nHall and others involved in NYC Mesh have recently been meeting to figure out how they can scale up the network to meet rising demand. One option is renting more antennas at supernode sites, and installing more large antennas atop tall buildings spread throughout the city and surrounding area. He estimates it would take between 20 and 50 supernodes to cover the city\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs.\nHours after the FCC vote Motherboard\xe2\x80\x94an online magazine that Vice Media launched in 2009\xe2\x80\x94announced plans to set up and operate its own community mesh network in Brooklyn, and to publish a how-to guide for others interested in doing the same thing in their own areas. The project is still in the early planning stages. \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of nonprofits and community groups and even just meet-up groups made of private citizens have built networks like this across the country,\xe2\x80\x9d Motherboard Editor in Chief Jason Koebler says. \xe2\x80\x9cEvery time we write about one of these community groups, people ask, \xe2\x80\x98What are the actual logistics of making something like this happen?\xe2\x80\x99 We don\xe2\x80\x99t have a good answer for them often, so we thought we\xe2\x80\x99d start from scratch.\xe2\x80\x9d\nPublic Broadband\nAnother approach, called municipal broadband or public broadband, offers residents internet access via a network supported by their city or town government\xe2\x80\x94often with outside help from tech companies or public utilities. This allows local governments to provide the service at low prices\xe2\x80\x94or for free. Starting in 2010 Google\xe2\x80\x99s Fiber division began offering broadband service directly to consumers. Within a few years the company was delivering high-quality internet access to nine U.S. locations\xe2\x80\x94including Kansas City, Austin and Atlanta. Unfortunately, a reorganization at Alphabet (Google\xe2\x80\x99s parent company) prompted the company to announce in October 2016 it would not extend its Fiber services beyond those locations it already served, plus three locations where fiber installation was already in progress and completed in 2017.*\nThe thinking behind publicly owned networks is that municipal governments have greater incentive than privately owned ISPs (which have little competition) to provide citizens, government agencies and local businesses with free or affordable high-speed internet access. Large ISPs, in an attempt to keep competition at bay, have lobbied hard\xe2\x80\x94and with some success\xe2\x80\x94to block or limit municipalities from offering broadband services. Several states, including Tennessee and Colorado, now have laws banning municipally run networks. Despite those restrictions, the city council in Fort Collins, Colo., voted on January 2 to move ahead with plans to build a public broadband network. In November an additional 19 cities and counties throughout the state approved financing to study the feasibility of their own municipal broadband projects.\nThe FCC\xe2\x80\x99s refusal to enforce net neutrality will \xe2\x80\x9ccatalyze\xe2\x80\x9d more city hall conversations about the best way to deliver broadband to both citizens and businesses, says Lev Gonick, Arizona State University\xe2\x80\x99s chief information officer and former CEO of the nonprofit broadband service provider OneCommunity. \xe2\x80\x9cAt a minimum, [municipal broadband] efforts put incumbent providers on notice that a city is looking for a competitive marketplace,\xe2\x80\x9d Gonick says.\nMunicipalities can fund the set up and management of public internet service in a few ways, such as issuing bonds or collaborating with local broadband providers. Publicly owned broadband networks have a mixed track record, however. Some municipal networks are owned by public utilities, such as Iowa\xe2\x80\x99s Cedar Falls Utilities or the Electric Power Board of Chattanooga, Tenn. These fiber networks deliver citywide gigabit-per-second speeds (a gigabit is one billion bits) that far surpass even the best ISP service in the U.S. The country\xe2\x80\x99s largest commercial ISPs offer average fixed (as opposed to mobile) broadband download speeds of about 64 Mbps whereas the average upload speed is under 23 Mbps, according to a report published last year by internet speed test company Ookla. (The FCC has for the past several years defined broadband as connection speeds of at least 25 Mbps for downloads and three Mbps for uploads.) There are, however, also many examples of failed municipal broadband projects, including iProvo in Utah and the City of Monticello in Minnesota. Mismanagement and high costs doomed both projects.\nWhether community- or municipal-run networks can handle a potential influx of tens of millions of disenchanted ISP subscribers is an open question. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not appropriate at this time to say that we have the solution to the problem that the FCC\xe2\x80\x99s decision has handed us,\xe2\x80\x9d says Nathan Schneider, a media studies scholar in residence at the University of Colorado Boulder. Still, these localized options are important at the very least for the pressure they put on ISPs to deliver good service at a reasonable price, Schneider says. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fundamental problem with the situation that we\xe2\x80\x99re in now is that [many] broadband providers are monopolies, but are not being recognized as such by the government,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we\xe2\x80\x99re going to do away with the principle of [net neutrality], on whose terms do we want to do that\xe2\x80\x94a big corporation or a company owned and operated by its customers?\xe2\x80\x9d\n*Correction (01/12/18): This paragraph was edited after posting. It originally referred to Google Fiber as a municipal-broadband subsidy program and referenced only nine of Google Fiber\xe2\x80\x99s 12 locations in the U.S.\nRights & Permissions\nABOUT THE AUTHOR(S)Larry GreenemeierLarry Greenemeier is the associate editor of technology for Scientific American, covering a variety of tech-related topics, including biotech, computers, military tech, nanotech and robots.Credit: Nick HigginsRecent ArticlesPhone Hacking Fears and FactsIKEA-Building Robot Conquers Touchy-Feely ChallengeHow Cryptojacking Can Corrupt the Internet of ThingsRead This NextComputingNew Net Neutrality Bill Has Glaring LoopholesDecember 20, 2017\n\xe2\x80\x94\nLarry GreenemeierPolicy & EthicsThe Downside of Net NeutralityDecember 13, 2017\n\xe2\x80\x94\nJeffrey Reed and Nishith TripathiComputingHow Washington Gridlock Delays High-Speed Broadband to Rural U.S.August 21, 2017\n\xe2\x80\x94\nLarry GreenemeierAdvertisement NewsletterGet smart. Live\nEntertainment\nJaneen Christoff\nJanuary 08, 2018\nPHOTO: Eat up with Restaurnat Week in New York City. (photo via Flickr/Mike Sinko)\nWHY IT RATES: NYC\xe2\x80\x99s Restaurant Week offers travelers a singular opportunity to enjoy unprecedented deals on dining\xe2\x80\x94Janeen Christoff, TravelPulse Senior WriterMORE Entertainment\nIsland H2O Live Water Park Opens in Florida\nLISTEN: Finding Facts Amid the Hype in Dominican Republic...\nDisney Raises Price for Annual Passes, Opens Booking for ...\nNYC & Company, the city\xe2\x80\x99s official destination marketing organization, today announced details for NYC Restaurant Week winter 2018 and opened reservations for booking:\xe2\x80\x94Dine over 17 days between January 22 through February 9, 2018\xe2\x80\x94Enjoy the option of more than 375 participating restaurants\xe2\x80\x94Receive three-course prix-fixe lunches for $29 and three-course prix-fixe dinners for $42\xe2\x80\x94Explore restaurants in 42 distinct neighborhoods, across all five boroughs\xe2\x80\x94Discover 31 individual cuisines\xe2\x80\x94View a full list of participants, browse menus and book tables now at NYCGo.com/restaurantweek.\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City is a world-class culinary destination and our NYC Restaurant Week program, which celebrated its 25th anniversary this past summer, exemplifies this ranking and welcomes all to come and experience it first-hand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred Dixon, president and CEO of NYC & Company.\xe2\x80\x9cWhether you\xe2\x80\x99re a visitor, meetings delegate or local resident, we invite diners to taste and explore New York City\xe2\x80\x99s incomparable restaurant scene across all five boroughs at a value this winter.\xe2\x80\x9dThis season features 32 new restaurant participants: Almond Flatiron, Antonucci Cafe, Astor Court, Augustine, Babu Ji, \xe2\x80\x98Cesca, Fusco, Il Cortile Restaurant, La Pecora Bianca Midtown, Legasea, Loring Place, Massoni, Maxwell\xe2\x80\x99s Chophouse, Momofuku Ma Peche, Momofuku Nishi, Nickel & Diner, One Dine, Ortzi, Osteria della Pace, Paowalla Restaurant, Quality Eats\xe2\x80\x93Upper East Side, Rice & Gold, San Carlo Osteria Piemonte, STK Rooftop, Suzuki, Tarallucci e Vino Upper West Side, The House in Gramercy Park, Tiny\xe2\x80\x99s & The Bar Upstairs, Tutto il Giorno, Vinateria, Yellow Magnolia Cafe and Yves.\xe2\x80\x9cNYC Restaurant Week was the first dining program of its kind, and provides the restaurant industry with the opportunity to showcase the quality and hospitality that our establishments are renowned for,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tracy Nieporent, partner and director of marketing for Myriad Restaurant Group and chairman of NYC & Company\xe2\x80\x99s Restaurant Committee.\xe2\x80\x9cThe dining community looks forward to welcoming patrons to experience and enjoy a variety of diverse restaurants across more than 40 neighborhoods this winter."Returning due to popular demand this season is the NYC Restaurant Week Tasting Series, which debuted this past summer. The ticketed events will highlight restaurants within cultural institutions and will offer exclusive tasting menus for guests.Ticket sales will benefit local charities City Harvest, Citymeals on Wheels and Food Bank NYC. Event details will be announced later this month.NYC Restaurant Week will be promoted through content on NYCgo.com, digital and print advertising, and with out-of-home advertising on NYC bus shelters, street pole banners, LinkNYC screens, NYC taxicabs, Toshiba Vision in Times Square and PATH trains and stations.Brand partners include booking partner OpenTable and culinary arts organization James Beard Foundation.NYC & Company\xe2\x80\x99s creative campaign for NYC Restaurant Week features new taglines such as \xe2\x80\x9cBeat the Cold in Warm Company,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBest Paired with Best Friends\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSome things are worth hailing a cab for,\xe2\x80\x9d to excite potential diners this winter.With American Express as a founding sponsor of NYC Restaurant Week, cardolders earn 5X Membership Rewards points per dollar spent during NYC Restaurant Week, up to 1,000 total points, from January 22, 2018, to February 9, 2018, by using your enrolled card at participating restaurants. Enrollment is required and is limited. To learn more, visit AmericanExpress.com/nycrestaurantweek.Diners can follow @nycgo and @nycrestaurantweek on Instagram and @nycgo on Facebook and Twitter for NYC Restaurant Week content. An Instagram photo contest will award four weekly winners, one each week of the program, with $250 in gift cards from participating restaurants by using the program hashtag #NYCRestaurantWeek.New Yorkers and visitors are also encouraged to seek out the ultimate-value week this winter, January 29 through February 4, when three of NYC & Company\xe2\x80\x99s signature programs align: NYC Restaurant Week, NYC Broadway Week and NYC Must-See Week.Hotel savings are also available as the winter season offers the most attractive hotel rates of the year, particularly on the evening of Super Bowl Sunday (February 4). For all there is to do in NYC this winter, visit NYCGo.com/winter.SOURCE: NYC & Company press release.\nFor more information on\nNew York City,\nNew York\nFor more Entertainment News\nMore by Janeen Christoff\nExplore Guanacaste, Costa Rica, With Lindblad Expeditions\nMSC Reveals More Details About Ocean Cay\nIsland H2O Live Water Park Opens in Florida\nDisney Raises Price for Annual Passes, Opens Booking for 2020 Vacation Packages\nUniversal Orlando Alters Operation Times for New Harry Potter Ride\nCountry Music Superstar Shania Twain Headlining Las Vegas Residency\ngallery icon\n20 Delicious Things to Eat at Disneyland\nComments\nYou may use your Facebook account to add a comment, subject to Facebook\'s Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. Galleries\nSNAPS\nSponsored Photo Galleries\nVideos\nMENU\nBreadcrumb\nHome\nPolitics\nJanuary 08, 2018 11:00 PM\nCommissioner in charge of city\'s tech and telephones is stepping down\nMatthew Flamm\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nEmail\nMore\nPrint\nDavid Kidd/"Government Technology"\nRoest had planned to retire after one term.\nThe unassuming chief of a city agency that did most of its work out of public view will announce Wednesday that she will leave her job later this month.\nAnne Roest, a longtime government official with a background as a computer programmer, has been commissioner of the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications since May 2014. Her departure is part of a reshuffling of the de Blasio administration that has been taking place over the past six months and includes the exit of two deputy mayors.\nIn an interview Tuesday, Roest, 58, said she had always planned to retire after serving one term, but had nonetheless delayed taking the step.\n"I have honestly been struggling with the decision," she said. "Everybody in City Hall knows I am loving my job."\nWhat tipped the balance was the strain of traveling to Vermont, where her partner lives. Roest will soon move there to live with him.\nWhen Roest started her tenure at DoITT, the agency was struggling to complete a modernization of its 911 system that was plagued with cost overruns and delays. She turned the project around by cutting ties with the outside consultants overseeing it and bringing the work in-house.\n"The city workforce put it back on schedule and on budget," she told Crain\'s. "It was in-sourcing on a grand scale."\nShe said she was also proud of making the agency more customer-centric\xe2\x80\x94the customers being the more than 100 city agencies that rely on the department for phone, internet and data services. Another high point was the conversion of pay phones into the LinkNYC Wi-Fi hubs, a project "born out of the brains" of the agency\'s franchise unit, she said.\nThe next commissioner will have to deal with one significant, unresolved issue of Roest\'s tenure: the city\'s effort to make Verizon\'s FiOS service available to every residence in the five boroughs.\n"It is frustrating that that promise was broken and we needed to sue," Roest said. Verizon says it has lived up to the terms of its franchise agreement.\nRoest said she does not know what she will do next.\n"I\'ve talked about everything from growing organic carrots to getting involved in local politics," she said. "I\'ll need to do something, but I need to get closer to home."\nIn a statement, Mayor Bill de Blasio said, "I want to thank Anne for her years of service and her tireless efforts to manage, maintain and streamline city technology and keep our data secure."\nRelated Articles\nBrooklyn lawmaker charged with fraud, obstruction of justice\nBiz leaders: Let nonunion contractors do subway projects\nVeteran congresswoman\'s challenger fills campaign coffers\nNonprofit in fraud case got nearly $200K from Brooklyn pol\nNYC sues, divests from oil firms over climate change\nView the discussion thread.\nGet our newsletters\nStaying current is easy with Crain\'s New York news delivered straight to your inbox, free of charge\nEmail Address\nCrain\'s Student Offer\nWe offer a discounted rate through Student Beans for students with a valid .edu email address. Commissioner\nimage/svg+xml\nCONTINUE TO SITE\nThis website uses cookies in order to offer you the most relevant information.\n\xc3\x83\xe2\x80\x94\nLearn More\nI Accept\nMAGAZINE\nNEWSLETTERS\nEVENTS\nPAPERS\nNAVIGATOR\nSECTIONS\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL EDUCATION\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL GOVERNMENT\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nDIGITAL STATES PERFORMANCE INSTITUTE\nTOP 25\nGOVTECH 100\nSEARCH\nCybersecurity\nGovTech Biz\nEmerging Tech\nCloud\nGov Experience\nMore\nPeople and Careers\nAnne Roest Retires, NYC Hires Atlanta CIO Samir Saini as IT Commissioner\nThe city is trading one Top 25 winner for another.\nby Ben Miller\n/\nJanuary 10, 2018\nSamir Saini\nDavid Kidd/Government Technology\nAfter a three-decade career in government, New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications Commissioner Anne Roest is retiring.\nTaking her place is Samir Saini, who has been Atlanta\xe2\x80\x99s chief information officer for three years. The city swore in a new mayor at the beginning of the year, an event which often prompts CIO departures. Though there is no exact date set for Roest to leave, Saini will start at DOITT at the end of January and Roest will stay on for a few weeks to help with the transition.\nBoth Saini and Roest received Top 25 awards from Government Technology in 2017.\nRELATEDAnne RoestAtlanta\xe2\x80\x99s Internal Platform Turns Public to Provide Real-Time Commuter Data Following Bridge CollapseNecessity Dictates One Rapidly Growing Jurisdiction\'s Smart City TransformationIn an email, Roest said the timing of the decision is personal \xe2\x80\x94 she\'s retiring so that she can move with her partner to Vermont, where she wants to spend more time at a home she purchased years ago.\n"It was a hard decision," Roest wrote.\nShe might not stay away from all work \xe2\x80\x94 she\'s "exploring opportunities" \xe2\x80\x94 but there\'s no job lined up for her.\nSaini started his government career in 2010 after beginning in the private sector, and quickly made a name for himself building out fiber connectivity and embracing data analytics. During his time in the city\xe2\x80\x99s IT office, Saini led efforts to gather more valuable traffic data in order to deal with mounting congestion problems, launched a smart city corridor, moved systems to the cloud and helped connect low-income housing residents to the Internet.\nRoest came to New York City in 2014 after more than 25 years working for New York state in various capacities, including public safety CIO.\nWhile managing the largest municipal IT office in the country, DOITT took on some ambitious work. It was under Roest that the city rolled out its fleet of more than 1,000 LinkNYC Internet-connected kiosks, with plans to eventually install 7,500. The department helped launch a city-specific Census data map, then it helped launch a new open data portal. She has also helped set up the first citywide Cyber Command center.\nPerhaps the largest single effort Saini will take on as he starts the new role is an effort to fully digitize the city\'s 911 system. The new system should be able to accept texts, photos, videos and social media as well as phone calls.\nRoest said some of the highlights of her career were the installation of the first LinkNYC kiosk and the opening of a 911 center in the Bronx, which she described as "an impossible project with an impossible timeline that an amazing interagency team delivered."\n"The best moments have been seeing the pride and ownership of the government works," she wrote. "I believe in the workforce, the mission, and the people in government who have never let me down. They work hard and smart and deliver."\nAs she leaves, Roest is urging government IT leaders not to let themselves fall behind on broader technological changes.\n"The most important thing in government IT right now is to learn how to change with the changing technology landscape," she wrote. "As the rate of change increases, it becomes harder for government to stay ahead. We have to keep our eye on the ball and embrace change as an enabler of great business solutions."\nIn a written statement, Saini said he\'s excited to start his new job and thanked Roest for building the team he\'ll be leading.\n"I look forward to building on the progress already made at DOITT to further strengthen and ensure the reliability and security of NYC systems and infrastructure," Saini wrote. "I\xe2\x80\x99m also thrilled about the opportunity to partner with New York City agencies to advance the use of innovative technologies that can improve quality of life for all New Yorkers.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn a simultaneous announcement, the city revealed that it has named Debbie Rosen chief of staff to First Deputy Mayor Dean Fuleihan. Per a mayoral executive order, the first deputy mayor oversees New York City Cyber Command.\nBen Miller\nAssociate Editor of GT Data and Business\nBen Miller is the associate editor of data and business for\xc2\xa0Government Technology. His reporting experience includes breaking news, business, community features and technical subjects. He holds a Bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degree in journalism from the Reynolds School of Journalism at the University of Nevada, Reno, and lives in Sacramento, Calif.\nRELATED\nAtlanta\'s New Tech Leader Is County School District CIO\nNYC to Set Up Real-Time Monitoring for Service Availability of Public Wi-Fi and Phone Call Kiosks\nAnne Roest\nDISCUSS\nWe invite you to discuss and comment on this article using social media.\nMORE FROM People and Careers\nPapers\nSPONSORED ARTICLES\nERP Modernization: How the Cloud Delivers Scalability, Security and Innovation\nThe Reality of the Local Government Cybersecurity Skill Gap\nGovernment No Longer Has to Choose Between Cybersecurity and Productivity\nNEWSLETTERS\nGovTech Today - Daily top stories\nFutureStructure - Weekly system engineering concepts\nPublic CIO - Weekly thought leadership\nNEWSLETTERS\nGOVTECH TODAY\nGOVTECH BIZ\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nPUBLIC CIO\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nK-12\nHIGHER EDUCATION\nSubscribe\nABOUT\nPRIVACY\nCONTACT\nADVERTISE\nGT Logo\n\xc2\xa9 2019 All rights reserved. e.Republic', b"New York IT Commissioner Anne Roest retires | StateScoop\nSubscribe\nAbout\nRSS\nBrought to you by\nSpecial Reports\nState\nCity\nCounty & Local\nWatch\nListen\nAttend\nContent Studio\nNew York IT Commissioner Anne Roest retires\nShare\nWritten by Jason Shueh\nJan 10, 2018 | STATESCOOP\nAfter nearly four years as New York City\xe2\x80\x99s IT commissioner and more than 35 years working in tech, Anne Roest is retiring.\nMayor Bill de Blasio made the announcement in a press release Wednesday, thanking Roest for her leadership while also naming her replacement \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Samir Saini, Atlanta\xe2\x80\x99s chief information officer. De Blasio commended Roest for her leadership at the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT), highlighting her efforts to improve emergency communications and cybersecurity.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to thank Anne for her years of service and her tireless efforts to manage, maintain and streamline city technology and keep our data secure,\xe2\x80\x9d de Blasio said.\nRoest played an integral part in the city\xe2\x80\x99s Emergency Communications Transformation Program, in\xc2\xa0which city IT\xc2\xa0partnered with police and fire departments to construct a state-of-the-art 911 dispatch and communications center and\xc2\xa0streamlined\xc2\xa0emergency communication systems across the city. The effort had been mired in delays and cost overruns before DoITT took over management of the dispatch centers in 2014. Roest formulated a plan and in May 2017, the $900 million, 550,000 square-foot facility opened its doors.\nRoest\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0contributions also included assisting with the\xc2\xa0hire of the city\xe2\x80\x99s first citywide information security officer and the launch of LinkNYC, a public-private partnership that is bringing the city\xc2\xa0free municipal Wi-Fi through a network of kiosks.\nPrior to joining the city in 2014, Roest served\xc2\xa0as the public safety chief information officer for New York state\xe2\x80\x99s Office of Information Technology Services, from 2012 to 2014. Before this, she was the state\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0deputy\xc2\xa0commissioner for IT\xc2\xa0at\xc2\xa0Criminal Justice Services, between 2005 and 2012, and the IT\xc2\xa0director at the state\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Taxation and Finance, from\xc2\xa01986 to 2005, according to LinkedIn.\nDe Blasio said that Saini, with his leadership of IT infrastructure and smart city projects in Atlanta,\xc2\xa0will build upon Roest\xe2\x80\x99s work.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m confident Samir Saini\xe2\x80\x99s impressive work in Atlanta makes him well-equipped to take on the crucial work of this agency, including continuing the modernization of our 911 system \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0which touches the lives of all New Yorkers,\xe2\x80\x9d de Blasio said.\nAs CIO of Atlanta Saini implemented a text-to-911 system, and also\xc2\xa0helped launch the city\xe2\x80\x99s Atlanta Smart Corridor to test Internet of Things solutions, autonomous vehicles and other emerging technologies. Saini also drove many civic tech projects, like the city\xe2\x80\x99s collaboration with Waze to alert drivers of traffic delays during the Interstate 85 fire and bridge collapse in 2017.\nIn an email to StateScoop, Saini expressed enthusiasm to take on the new role, thanking Roest for her dedication to DoITT and de Blasio for the opportunity to lead the department.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI look forward to building on the progress already made at DoITT to further strengthen and ensure the reliability and security of NYC systems and infrastructure.\xe2\x80\x9d Saini said.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m also thrilled about the opportunity to partner with New York City agencies to advance the use of innovative technologies that can improve quality of life for all New Yorkers.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAs described by the city,\xc2\xa0Saini \xe2\x80\x98s role\xc2\xa0will be a\xc2\xa0balance between innovation and support for the city\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0IT\xc2\xa0infrastructure.\nThe city\xe2\x80\x99s statement reads:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cHe will be responsible for maintaining the foundational\xc2\xa0IT infrastructure and systems that touch every aspect of city life \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0from public safety to human services, education and economic development \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0crossing the full spectrum of governmental operations.\xe2\x80\x9d\n-In this Story-\nAnne Roest, Careers & Elected Officials, Chief Information Officer (CIO), CIO appointment, Civic Tech, Cybersecurity, IT Infrastructure, Modernization, New York City, retirement, Samir Saini, Smart Cities, State & Local News, Tech News\nRelated news\nCity\nLos Angeles city controller updates online property map to boost housing, economy\nby Colin Wood challenge\nby Ryan Johnston \xe2\x80\xa2 6 hours ago\nAd Specs\nSponsor\nRSS\nPrivacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Scoop News Group\n|\nAll Rights Reserved\nSearch for:\nThe latest state and local government Learn more\nGOT IT!", b"Service design: How To Get People To Food bank \xe2\x80\x93 Muzli - Design InspirationHomepageSign inGet started\xf0\x9f\xa4\x98\xf0\x9f\x8f\xbbGet Muzli for Chrome\xe2\x9c\x8d\xf0\x9f\x8f\xbb Publish on MuzliService design: How To Get People To Food\xc2\xa0bankJohny VinoBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJan 10, 2018Service design for FoodBank for NYC on increasing Volunteer Registration via LinkNYCIntroduction and\xc2\xa0context:New York City, a home for 8.5 million people, has many people who yearn to serve the community. Hunger is a huge issue in NYC. 15% of NYC\xe2\x80\x99s 8.5 million population is hungry. Research shows that there is a decline in the number of New Yorker volunteers over a decade.The Food Bank of New York City is a charitable foundation striving to stop hunger. It needs volunteers to sustain the operation. The goal of our service is to connect volunteers accessing the opportunities easily.TeamI am pleased to team with exceptionally talented and supportive teammates.Arielle, JasonSponsorsLinkNYC, Foodbanks for NYCAdvising ProfessorMarshall SittenInitial AssumptionInitially, we presumed that food bank is in need of more food. So we started our research towards that.Field Research:In reality, they have ample food.Stakeholder research:We discussed with Chris, volunteer engagement associate of FBNYC. He told that they get more food but not more volunteers. Hence we shifted our gear more towards the volunteer experience.Problem:\xe2\x80\x9cHow can we inspire New Yorkers to engage in volunteer initiatives for the Food Bank of NYC\xc2\xa0?\xe2\x80\x9dWe decided to analyze the existing system of getting volunteering.Analyze Existing\xc2\xa0Service:Initially we analyzed the experience today,There are three things involved in this serviceSignup and registration processDoing the servicePost serviceThe tedious signup process leads 75% of the volunteers to drop the service. The CTA for registration is loaded with more amount of content. The navigation through several pages and more filtering options to find the best service is time-consuming.Signup and registration processOur survey results from the users list three things that people consider before volunteering.Whether1) It suits their schedule;2) Location is convenient;3) Evident and tangible impacts.As per research options presented on the website are not filling the needs of the user.2. Doing the serviceSince the management network is engaged in serving the food, they cannot endure and instruct the new volunteers.3. Post Service:The team cannot manage to acquire perceptions after every service instead it sends inappropriate mail.The main hindrances of Foodbank are listed.1. Profused sign-up process.2. Inept organization of on-site experience.3. No honors to the volunteers after the service.Week Signals\xc2\xa0found:When we worked towards resolving the tedious sign-up process, we noticed the weak central signal.Target Audience:An ad about the service would incline more bustling New Yorkers who have a giving heart and cares about the community towards volunteering.We produce two main things from our survey research: 1) people want volunteering to be convenient to their schedule; 2) people want to observe the results of their efforts.Our approaches to tackle the challenges:Initial Idea:For driving towards the solution, we captured all the weak signals and transformed into opportunities.With the idea of doing a public ad, we roamed around the city and obtained all the ad platforms. We decided to display the ads in\xc2\xa01. Bus stops,2. Phone booths,\xc2\xa03. Subways and\xc2\xa04. LinkNYC.Why LinkNYCThe primary reason for picking LINK NYC is it delivers content dynamically based on the location of the city.\xc2\xa0The four main reasons behind our selection:1. Since Kiosks are all over the city (1200), we can reach a significant number of users to acquire an accurate and fruitful outcome.2. LinkNYC is upheld by a prominent team of developers and data scientists. Hence we can measure the qualitative aspects of the data.\xc2\xa0An example of the former result analysis is attached.3. Link NYC is embedded with an internet-enabled tablet.\xc2\xa04. In future, we can utilize it for volunteer signup process.New Service\xc2\xa0Idea:Our initial service aims to incorporate easy-to-use technology, like QR codes and SMS so that New Yorkers can quickly engage with Food Bank collateral.Once they wish to engage with the service, they will be directly taken to the registration page and optimized for mobile.\xc2\xa01. Our version will filter only the nearby locations.2. We aim to intensify the onsite volunteer on-boarding process.3. After volunteering, our service will remind the impact through email..BluePrintThe line of interaction or elements that exist behind the scenes are outlined.Touch PointsLink Kiosk: SMS or QR codes to link new users.Mobile: Once a display is scanned, a New Yorker will be taken to the registration site.Email: A New Yorker will receive a confirmation email once signing up and a thank you email after the service with statistics.Food Bank NYC: The volunteer must be on-boarded and routed to the area to be serviced.Web: There is a robust web experience where users can investigate and sign up for the service.From: A guide to service blueprinting by Adaptive\xc2\xa0PathThe service proposal is a partnership between FB NYC and LINKNYC.FB NYC will be supplying all the API data to Link, which will host digital advertisements and Geo-targeted ads which ensure that pedestrians are perceiving opportunities close to them.Interested pedestrians can text the number on the ad or capture the QR code to go to a mobile optimized site for a quick sign up process. The users are invited with a confirmation email and a thank you email after their service.First PrototypeManifests the convenience.Ads display the closeness to volunteer opportunities.2. Registration optimized for those on-the-go.Able to register directly.3. Engage local Community.Showcasing the leader board on your street will motivate more people to volunteer.Co-DesignThe designers and product owners of LinkNYC are pleased to integrate this service with prompt feedbacks to improve.We attained warm synergies on our first prototype with short URLs or SMS than QR codes.Second round of prototype:Our second prototype maintains the credibility and text message option as most of the people wish to text. It\xe2\x80\x99s a double-sided platform that, once the person texts, we can also track him with texts.How does this achieve willingness-to-payEnticing our three players to pay for this service is important.New Yorkers who want to give back to the city with convenience.For Intersection with LinkNYC, they get more user attention and engagement with the kiosks.FB NYC gets many volunteers.What are the possible risks involved:What are incentives this three players will\xc2\xa0get1.New YorkersFeelings of fulfillment.2. LinkNYCLink achieves Reputation of socially conscious company.3. FoodbankThose in need get help more quickly.Execution planIdeal ProposalAccurate location and opportunities near them will be displayed.2. Data can be collected on how many volunteers served, signed up and volunteered from Link AI Analytics.MVP in 2 months using Excel uploadTesting the two engagement types: QR code, text for hyperlink test number of user engaging with KIOSK.2. No Analytics.Thanks for the 50 clap \xf0\x9f\x91\x8f\xf0\x9f\x8f\xbb if you enjoyed this article. This will tell me to write more of it! Also leave your valuable feedbacks to improveJohnyvino is the Product designer, building transformative experiences for mobile apps, SaaS, and enterprise software.You can connect with him on Dribbble, Behance and LinkedIn.LinknycService DesignCase StudyUrban PlanningFoodbanks734 claps1BlockedUnblockFollowFollowingJohny VinoSpecialized in humanizing User Experience. www.johnyvino.comFollowMuzli - Design InspirationAll the design inspiration you need.\nIt's like crack for designers. Learn moreGet updatesGet updates", b"Civic Tech: The City of Toronto must remain a public platform\nTorontoist has been acquired by Daily Hive Toronto - Your City. Now. Click here to learn more.\n2 Comments\nJanuary 10, 2018 at 1:52 pm\nnews\nCivic Tech: The City of Toronto must remain a public platform\nSidewalk Labs' ideas for Quayside are not intended to stay in Quayside.\nBy\nBianca Wylie\nPhoto courtesy of Sidewalk Labs.\nHeading into a year of public consultations on Sidewalk Labs in Toronto, Civic Tech brings you this first piece in a series that will explore a range of issues raised by residents concerned about the project.\nFor background, see this piece, and consider adding your questions to the ongoing community question document.\nIf you have an idea for this series or would like to contribute, please contact our editor.\nOur city cannot become a privatized digital platform\nIn the tech world, the word \xe2\x80\x9cplatform\xe2\x80\x9d is used to describe an interconnected set of products and services. Sidewalk Labs has not been shy about using the word to describe the way it sees cities.\nDan Doctoroff, chief executive of Sidewalk Labs, has likened the city to the operating system of a mobile phone, saying: \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cWhat made [the smartphone] ultimately magical is that it enabled millions of people around the world to use their imagination and skills to create apps that, in most cases, no one ever dreamed the platform would be used for and keep it fresh, changing, useful, and current.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTo keep with the analogy, Sidewalk Labs should never be our operating system. That\xe2\x80\x99s the role of government. If Sidewalk Labs wants to build some apps, they\xe2\x80\x99re welcome to do so. But these apps will need oversight, especially since they may seek to disrupt the delivery of public services.\nThe great and dangerous advantage of the technology sector is that it can go straight to market and its consumers via the internet. That can make tech products seem inevitable, instead of conditional on appropriate regulation. (Think of Uber\xe2\x80\x99s operating strategy.) As we move into a consultation on Sidewalk Labs, which will likely include some pilot projects, we must remember this: although consultation is a step in the right direction, it is not a substitute for policy or law. It\xe2\x80\x99s an input to both.\nBeware the blurring line between private and public sector language\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s Rohit Aggarwala, head of urban systems at Sidewalk Labs, quoted in a piece in Smithsonianmag.com about the project. It\xe2\x80\x99s an example of a communications strategy that makes Sidewalk Labs sound like the government, an issue that goes persistently unchecked in the press:\nAggarwala also offers assurances that the purpose of gathering so much data is not a commercial one. \xe2\x80\x9cThis isn\xe2\x80\x99t about trying to figure out how we make money from capturing all this information for advertisers. That\xe2\x80\x99s not our objective,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cOur objective is to build a great neighbourhood. The only reason we want to capture information is to provide better urban services.\nDan Doctoroff, CEO of Sidewalk Labs, doubled down on this line today in his\xc2\xa0Sidewalk Labs Reddit AMA. Of course the data collection is for commercial purposes \xe2\x80\x93\xc2\xa0it may not be for advertising, but for the provision of for-profit urban services. Sidewalk Labs is not the government, nor is it a philanthropic arm of Alphabet. It\xe2\x80\x99s a business. And its sister company, Google, recently received a\xc2\xa0$2.7-billion (U.S.) fine from the European Commission for anti-trust behaviour. (Google is appealing the decision.)\nAs you watch Sidewalk Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s communications, you\xe2\x80\x99ll see constant references to leading urban thinkers and theories. This is intended to instill trust and familiarity among the urbanites who are closely monitoring the project, and highlight the city-building aspect of the project while downplaying the tech-business side.\nAlphabet, the parent company of Sidewalk Labs, has a market capitalization of approximately $730 billion (U.S.). That is roughly half of Canada\xe2\x80\x99s GDP. For all the times Sidewalk Toronto references Jane Jacobs, don\xe2\x80\x99t forget this.\nDecision-making on data: Who\xe2\x80\x99s in the driver\xe2\x80\x99s seat?\nSidewalk Labs has said that it will make some of the data from this project available. The problem is that this is not, and never has been, Sidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99 decision to make.\nThere are three core outstanding questions to answer about the data from this and any other smart city project in Canada:\nWho can collect it?\nWho can use it?\nAnd under what terms?\nThere is a strong argument to be made that there is only one organization that can collect civic data, whether it\xe2\x80\x99s data from sensors monitoring the environment or from people moving in a public space\xe2\x80\x94the government.\nMita Williams, a librarian at the University of Windsor with a long-time interest in open data, put it this way in a recent tweet: \xe2\x80\x9cWe are forced to trade our personal data when we use services such as Facebook. But our cities cannot be treated as the same. Civic data should belong to the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFrom there, in terms of ownership, the list can expand beyond government. Individuals could also own it. Who can use it? Lots of people. It\xe2\x80\x99s here, at this stage, that we get into open data. Global corporations and small businesses alike can use it if, and only if, we all agree it should be open data in the first place.\nHaving public data collection and access to core information about our cities is a modern-day census, not one we should privatize in any circumstance. Teresa Scassa, Canada research chair in information law and policy at the University of Ottawa outlines some of the related issues in this recent piece on data ownership.\nCivic data provides critical information to government and residents, to researchers and non-profits and academics and the private sector. So yes, some of it should definitely be open, but determining these details is a task for the government, not Sidewalk Labs.\nSidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s insatiable ambition and the network effect\nAnother reason it\xe2\x80\x99s important to maintain government ownership and control over any platform in our city is a phenomenon known as a \xe2\x80\x9cnetwork effect.\xe2\x80\x9d A company\xe2\x80\x99s products become more powerful as the number of people using them grows.\nConsider Facebook: you use it because everyone else is using it.\nNetwork effects can lead to market domination and monopolies because of the power inherent from having many people use and rely on your product. And once a platform is embedded in society as a social norm, it\xe2\x80\x99s incredibly difficult to dislodge.\nSidewalk Labs has said that their appetite to move beyond the Quayside testing ground and into the rest of the city is \xe2\x80\x9cinsatiable.\xe2\x80\x9d Their model includes a suite of proprietary products that would use a digital platform. See: Waymo (autonomous vehicles), Flow (transportation planning), Waze (traffic data), Cityblock (social-service delivery), LinkNYC (public Wi-Fi), and Nest (thermostats, outdoor security cameras).\nWill Fleissig, chief executive of Waterfront Toronto, has said that \xe2\x80\x9cSidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s proposal stood out from more than a half-dozen submissions by demonstrating a plan that can take high-level conceptual ideas, piloting them and scaling them across a city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe ideas for Quayside are not intended to stay in Quayside. As such, Toronto must pay close attention to the core governance issues at the heart of this project. It\xe2\x80\x99s critical to ensure that what\xe2\x80\x99s public and vital to our city\xe2\x80\x99s operation stays under public control.\nThanks for reading this first instalment. Next up, Pam Sethi on health care.\nWe\xe2\x80\x99ll keep you posted on public consultation activities as we learn of them. For now, your best bet is to follow @waterfronttoronto and @sidewalktoronto on Twitter and consider signing up for both of their newsletters: \xc2\xa0Waterfront Toronto (left hand sidebar) and\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Sidewalk Toronto (scroll down, subscribe bottom right).\nOn December 20, 2017, Waterfront Toronto released the summary report from its first town hall meeting. We at Torontoist were happy to see the community list of questions included, as well as answers to several of them. As the process unfolds, we\xe2\x80\x99ll update the document with official answers. In addition, Patrick Connolly of Civic Tech Toronto has created a spreadsheet of press resources from the listing in the report.\nThe way this project plays out in the press matters. Technology has its own press. Urban planning has its own press. And business has its own press. Rarely does one publication or sub-section of a publication touch on all three specifics, so it can be difficult to assess the project through these three lenses simultaneously. Throughout this series, we\xe2\x80\x99ll be working to expand on some of the tech, business, and urban planning aspects as they relate to the project and its governance and politics.\nFiled under civic tech, network effect, Open Data, platforms, Quayside, sidewalk, Sidewalk Labs\nShare\n\xef\x82\x9a\n\xef\x82\x99\n\xef\x83\x95\n\xef\x83\x92\n\xef\x83\xa0\nReport error \xc2\xb7\nSend a tip\nComments\nSocial Media\nFollow @torontoist\nAbout Us\n\xc2\xa9 2019, Buzz Connected Media Inc. All rights reserved.", b"Sidewalk Labs' Toronto Project Stirs Up Privacy Debate | Civicist\nCivic Hall\nA New Home for Civic Tech\nAbout Us\nStaff + Board of Directors\nCivic Hall @ Union Square\nImpact Reports\nCode of Conduct\nOpportunities\nContact\nMembership\nPrograms + Projects\nThe Digital Learning Center\nCivicist\nForums @ Civic Hall\nEvents\nEvent Calendar\nSpace Rental\nMember\nLogin\nHome\nAbout Civic Hall\nImpact Reports\nIn the Press\nCode of Conduct\nCivic Hall @ Union Square\nBecome a Member\nEvent Calendar\nBook an Event\nOpportunities\nThe Digital Learning Center\nCivicist\nAbout Civicist\nSubscribe to First Post\nBooks\nCivic Tech in the Global South\nA Lever and a Place to Stand\nThe Big Disconnect\nWikiLeaks and the Age of Transparency\nTwitter\nFacebook\nInstagram\nCivicist Twitter\nRSS\nCivicist\nCivic Tech News & Analysis from Civic Hall\nInternet of ThingsSmart CitiesTransparency\nSidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99 Toronto Project Stirs Up Privacy Debate\nBy: John Lorinc\nJan 10, 2018\nQuayside, the waterfront area proposed to be redeveloped by Sidewalk Labs, and the eastern Port Lands in the middle distance. (Photo courtesy SidewalkToronto.ca)\nWhen Sidewalk Labs hosted a public forum in Toronto last November to gather feedback on its plan to build a data-driven innovation hub on a mostly derelict stretch of industrial waterfront, several participants posed tough questions about how the company, a subsidiary of Alphabet/Google, would address privacy issues\xe2\x80\x94questions that have yet to be answered some three months later.Sidewalk Labs (a Civic Hall member organization) was founded by former Bloomberg CEO and New York City deputy mayor Dan Doctoroff. The company launched its pitch in mid-October amidst an international media blitz that included promotional appearances by Canadian prime minister Justin Trudeau and former Google chairman Eric Schmidt. In particular, Sidewalk proposed to develop a green, affordable, and innovation-driven mixed-use waterfront community to be built using emerging data, mapping, and network technologies, such as the deployment of public data-gathering sensors and automated shuttle buses that would serve the area instead of private vehicles. Sidewalk also pledged to invest US$50 million in pilot projects in Toronto as they negotiate a final development agreement with local agencies over the coming year.The central premise of the firm\xe2\x80\x99s plan, now being evaluated by Waterfront Toronto, is to leverage data gathered in the public realm to achieve goals such as improving traffic flow, enabling autonomous vehicle movement, and reducing emissions on a 12-acre brownfields site known as Quayside that could become home to Google Canada\xe2\x80\x99s new headquarters, a cluster of tech companies, and other mixed-use buildings. Sidewalk and WT both talked initially about expanding the plan to a mostly fallow 800-acre swath of industrial Port Lands east of Quayside, but City of Toronto officials poured cold water on that goal in December.From the beginning, SWL has cast its plan as a kind of urban digital platform that will encourage third-party tech firms to \xe2\x80\x9cdesign city improvements\xe2\x80\x9d using data gathered from users of this new community\xe2\x80\x94a model not unlike the way Apple and Facebook encourage developers to create applications for their respective platforms.Sidewalk is no stranger to data and privacy issues. Their first venture\xe2\x80\x94through a company SWL has invested in (and shares New York office space with) called Intersection\xe2\x80\x94was turning hundreds of former payphone connection points in New York into free wifi-enabled LinkNYC wayfinding kiosks, with revenues generated by advertising. In late 2016, LinkNYC had to disable the web browsers following reports that they were being used to download porn.But concerns remain about LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s data gathering practices. According to this analysis by the Electronic Frontier Foundation, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy initially allowed them to retain significant user data and browsing histories. While they tightened up the privacy policies in 2017, EFF still has concerns about data breaches and the lack of public input into the governance of these kiosks, which will soon be outfitted with cameras and other sensors. As EFF\xe2\x80\x99s post noted, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is no means for New Yorkers to participate in decisions about how data from Link kiosks will be used, with whom it will be shared, for how long it will be retained, or whether the parameters under which it is initially collected might conceivably expand in the future.\xe2\x80\x9dWhile the initial Toronto pitch included a data privacy pledge that included hiring Ann Cavoukian, a former high-ranking Ontario government privacy official, to advise SWL on its practices, attendees at the forum nonetheless wanted to know more about safeguards and the company\xe2\x80\x99s accountability and transparency plans for its data-gathering operations.Indeed, as SWL itself has acknowledged, a good deal of the media coverage so far has focused on issues relating to privacy, intellectual property and the ultimate ownership of data gathered from the movement of people through the public spaces on the land it aims to develop. Some of the commentary, including a widely-read report in The Guardian, raised pointed concerns about what it described as \xe2\x80\x9cGoogle Urbanism.\xe2\x80\x9dWhile SWL\xe2\x80\x99s plan is geared at Toronto, the data governance issues resonate widely. The firm\xe2\x80\x99s pitch in Toronto could set precedents for how governments and public agencies elsewhere regulate these emerging technologies, including the troves of data they both consume and produce.Increasingly, as CityLab recently reported, some public agencies are raising questions about the ownership of the data of private mobility firms\xe2\x80\x94ridesharing companies in particular\xe2\x80\x94whose operations have triggered growing congestion and decreased transit usage in some jurisdictions.But several months into what was expected to be a swift year-long process to negotiate a formal development agreement, neither SWL, Waterfront Toronto, nor the company\xe2\x80\x99s privacy advisor have much to offer in the way of specifics about how they plan to deal with these data governance issues.Quayside (Photo courtesy Waterfront Toronto)In an email response, WT chief executive Will Fleissig said that the ultimate agreement \xe2\x80\x9cwill include provisions\xc2\xa0to ensure and enforce requirements regarding privacy considerations, as well as other critical issues relating to data governance and ownership.\xe2\x80\x9d Other government agencies, he added, may be involved. But Fleissig declined to say whether Cavoukian, as SWL\xe2\x80\x99s paid privacy advisor, will be required to report her findings or recommendations to Waterfront Toronto.Cavoukian, in an interview in late December, said she would be \xe2\x80\x9chappy\xe2\x80\x9d to report her eventual findings and recommendations to Waterfront Toronto, but the prospect hasn\xe2\x80\x99t arisen in the handful of meetings she has had so far.Nor has either body released the details, mandate, or membership of a pledge to establish a privacy advisory board, except to say that it will include government officials, academics, and community members. Asked if the group would meet in public and disclose its reports, Micah Lasher, a former Bloomberg administration political staffer who co-founded the lobbying powerhouse SDK Knickerbocker and now serves as Sidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s spokesperson, replied by email: \xe2\x80\x9cWe aim to make the process as transparent as possible. The Board is still in formation and its structure and protocols yet to be determined.\xe2\x80\x9dSuch hedges explain why some observers have questioned Sidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s public positioning. Writing in Torontoist last fall, open data activist and writer Bianca Wylie posed a series of hard-hitting questions for Sidewalk about issues such as the ownership of intellectual property developed on the project, public access to the data collected, security issues, and the intended beneficiaries. \xe2\x80\x9cWho is the user that Sidewalks Labs is ultimately serving?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. \xe2\x80\x9cCompanies that want to learn about how people interact with physical spaces? Real estate investors? Cities?\xe2\x80\x9dCavoukian\xe2\x80\x99s role, in particular, has drawn attention from Wylie and other critics who worry that her presence is more about public relations than oversight. She served for many years as the Ontario government\xe2\x80\x99s Information and Privacy Commissioner, a public official who administers the province\xe2\x80\x99s privacy laws, reports to the Ontario legislature, and is independent of the government of the day.Since her retirement, Cavoukian has held a position at Ryerson University, where she heads a \xe2\x80\x9cprivacy by design\xe2\x80\x9d think tank. Initially, SWL didn\xe2\x80\x99t publicly acknowledge that she was being paid for her advice (her unit at Ryerson provides certification services to companies and other organizations). \xe2\x80\x9cI am being paid but so what?\xe2\x80\x9d she said in an interview in late December. \xe2\x80\x9cI have no vested interest in this.\xe2\x80\x9dWhile Cavoukian will be delivering a consulting service and connecting SWL with tech firms that perform specific data-related tasks such as anonymizing large data sets, these tasks aren\xe2\x80\x99t the same as providing formal oversight.Indeed, the question of who or what will actually regulate the data-gathering envisioned by SWL remains largely unanswered.As the head of the IPCO, Cavoukian had legal authority to investigate government or other public agencies and was insulated from interference.She admits her current position with SWL has no such structural protections. She contends that as the former commissioner, her imprimatur not only carries weight but also puts pressure on SWL to own up to its promises. \xe2\x80\x9cOtherwise, there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing comparable to the IPCO [mandate].\xe2\x80\x9d Cavoukian also concedes that there\xe2\x80\x99s no way she could determine whether she was being given complete access to SWL\xe2\x80\x99s data systems in order to determine whether the company is living up to its public commitment to transparency. \xe2\x80\x9cHow would anyone prove that?\xe2\x80\x9dYet she says the eventual privacy advisory board that is established to oversee this venture should conduct its business in public. \xe2\x80\x9cI think that would make sense. I would imagine that those things should be made public.\xe2\x80\x9dAsked if SWL would agree to allow Waterfront Toronto or city officials to seek an independent evaluation of Sidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s proposed privacy policies, Lasher didn\xe2\x80\x99t offer a definitive answer: \xe2\x80\x9cWe would review any such proposal and react to its specifics, but we certainly aim to establish mechanisms that give Torontonians and their representatives in government confidence and clarity when it comes to all the work that happens as part of Sidewalk Toronto.\xe2\x80\x9dThis article has been updated to clarify the relationship between Sidewalk Labs and LinkNYC, and to include the fact that Sidewalk Labs is a member of Civic Hall.\nBy: John Lorinc\nJan 10, 2018\nShare\nShare on Twitter\nShare on Facebook\nShare by Email\nTopics\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Internet of ThingsSmart CitiesTransparency\nSponsors\nCraig Newmark Philanthropies\nMicrosoft\nLuminate\nGoogle\nSee all Sponsors, Partners, and Organizational\nMembers\nCivic Hall\n118 W22ND STREET, 12FL NEW YORK, NY 10011\nHours: Mon to Fri, 8:30 a.m. to 7 p.m.\ninfo@civichall.org\n@CivicHall on Twitter\nWhy privacy matters, Facebook's new currency, KidTube; and much more on the #FirstPost, a digest of news and analys\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/R4wqLyRXHU\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @EngineerEmily: A Timeline of Civic Tech Tells a Data-Driven Story of the Field https://t.co/Mgsg6HSpvv @CivicHall https://t.co/S2yvyCskaU\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @motaword: This month, MotaWord's content creator @marcosd attended New York Tech Meetup (powered by @CivicHall):\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/jhE4uLKjwq\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @booksoncallnyc: We\xe2\x80\x99re so pleased to be @CivicHall this evening, handling book sales for @josephmenn and \xe2\x80\x9cCult of the Dead Cow: How\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/Xrdyj0bndW\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @LeeTomson: Lunch and Learn with @PBProject in advance of their Forum @CivicHall on June 24!
