All Rights Reserved.\nContact\nData Use Policy\nTerms of Service\nPress Contact", b"What are those tall kiosks that have replaced pay phones in New York? - The New York Times\nSectionsSEARCHSkip to contentSkip to site indexNew YorkSubscribeLog InLog InToday\xe2\x80\x99s PaperNew York|What are those tall kiosks that have replaced pay phones in New York?AdvertisementSupported byF.Y.I.What are those tall kiosks that have replaced pay phones in New York?ImageSince the system launched in early 2016, around 1,250 Links have been erected throughout all five boroughs. The company is aiming for a total of 7,500 Links by 2026.CreditCreditCole Wilson for The New York TimesBy Keith WilliamsJan. 11, 2018Q. Tall kiosks labeled \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x9d are replacing phone booths, offering free Wi-Fi and nationwide phone calls. The thing is, I have never seen anybody using one. What gives?A. Compared with the pay phones they often replace, LinkNYC kiosks, known as Links, get plenty of use, even if no one is standing next to them.According to CityBridge, the consortium that operates LinkNYC, over 3.2 million people have registered for the system\xe2\x80\x99s Wi-Fi service, with 600,000 users each week. The Wi-Fi operates at gigabit speed, meaning it can be up to 100 times faster than cellular LTE networks. The range of a Link is about 150 feet in any direction.Links are a critical piece in the city\xe2\x80\x99s goal to bring broadband internet access to all New Yorkers, but the system\xe2\x80\x99s community-first approach provides other social benefits, as well.Each Link has an interactive screen, which offers everyday information you might expect, like weather, local maps, and transit updates, as well as a connection to the city\xe2\x80\x99s 311 service. Through a partnership with the software program Aunt Bertha, however, users can anonymously search for nonprofit and social services.Links also offer free phone calls anywhere in the country; the system registers around 200,000 calls each month. The number dialed most frequently? The state\xe2\x80\x99s hotline for its Electronic Benefits Transfer program, commonly known as food stamps.Since the system launched in early 2016, around 1,250 Links have been erected throughout all five boroughs. The company is aiming for a total of 7,500 Links by 2026, when its contract with the city is scheduled to expire.As the first system of its kind, LinkNYC has faced unforeseen difficulties. When the system was introduced, each Link offered an internet browser. But a slew of complaints of users camping out in front of the units and, in some cases, viewing inappropriate content, caused the system to remove that functionality.The system\xe2\x80\x99s biggest challenge is finding new locations, said Jen Hensley, the general manager of LinkNYC. The system is building a new fiber-optic network, but not every pay phone site is close enough to a manhole to connect to it.Links generate revenue through advertisements, which appear on the 55-inch screens on the sides of each kiosk. These ads are interspersed with in-house content like \xe2\x80\x9cNYC Fun Facts\xe2\x80\x9d and historical photos of nearby locations. LinkNYC and the city split the ad revenue equally, subject to an annual minimum.The idea is expanding to other cities: Links have begun appearing in the United Kingdom, and are set to arrive in Philadelphia this summer.The system is in a constant state of refinement, with temporary options ranging from time-sensitive to whimsical. Through Jan. 31, for example, users can browse and enroll in health care plans; in December, each Link offered a direct line to Santa\xe2\x80\x99s voice mail.EMAIL fyi@nytimes.com A version of this article appears in print on , on Page MB3 of the New York edition. Policy\nSubscribe\nNewsSportsLifeBusinessOpinionCalendarLetters to the EditorObituariesClassifieds\nCrews from the city of Tukwila install Wi-Fi hotspot equipment on a light pole on South 144th Street. Courtesy, city of Tukwila\nCity works to remove barriers to internet access\nRecently launched pilot program provides free Wi-Fi around South 144th Street.\nby Heidi JacobsTuesday, January 16, 2018 9:00amNews\nConnecting to the internet is becoming easier in Tukwila.\nOn Jan. 1, the city launched a Wi-Fi pilot that provides free internet access to anyone in the area of South 144th Street between Tukwila International Boulevard and Military Road South.\nTukwila Mayor Allan Ekberg asked Joseph Todd, the city\xe2\x80\x99s director of technology and innovation services, to find a way to provide internet access to city residents after seeing a need.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I walked the community for the mayor election, I talked to lots of residents,\xe2\x80\x9d Ekberg said. \xe2\x80\x9cOne of the things I recognized was the lack of internet access for a lot of our underprivileged youth.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThat gap in access impacts students\xe2\x80\x99 educational opportunities. The Tukwila School District has a one-to-one laptop program that provides a Chromebook for every student to take home.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose devices basically connect through the network,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hsian-Yu Kuo, the school district\xe2\x80\x99s director of information technology. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are pretty much not useful if you do not have an internet connection. Every student has one device, but we\xe2\x80\x99ve never sent them home. We can\xe2\x80\x99t send them home to students who can\xe2\x80\x99t use them, and not every student has internet access. We can\xe2\x80\x99t send them home because some student can do homework and some students can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBecause of this, the computers purchased by the district were not being used.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey had stacks and stacks of them sitting in the storage room,\xe2\x80\x9d Todd said. \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes they would use them in class, but the idea with one-to-one is that you need to be able to take them home.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTodd began researching ways to make internet access for all students a reality and came across LinkNYC, a program that provides free Wi-Fi to millions of users in New York City.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were taking all their old phone booths and creating them into Wi-Fi hotspots,\xe2\x80\x9d Todd said.\nWith an initial investment of $16,000 from the city\xe2\x80\x99s technology and innovation services general fund, Tukwila set up nine hotspots. The hotspots are on city infrastructure utility poles along South 144th Street.\nThe school district identified the area around South 144th Street as having the highest concentration of students without internet access, many living in apartments.\nWhile the area for the pilot program is small, it serves about 600 to 700 students.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a big deal,\xe2\x80\x9d Todd said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow you can go home with a Chromebook and have internet access. You don\xe2\x80\x99t have to be camping around Starbucks or the library to be able to get access to the internet.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe city sent out information to residents in the area of the pilot program with instructions of how to connect to the network. Anyone who is in the area of the pilot program can access the internet for free.\nTodd hopes to monetize the internet service through advertising.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThough the clicks we get the money back,\xe2\x80\x9d Todd said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will take that money from the clicks and use that to expand the service.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIf the program pays off, the revenue could be used to install more access points throughout the city, and it could eventually expand to all residential areas throughout the city, said Rachel Bianchi, the city\xe2\x80\x99s communications and government relations manager.\nIf service is expanded, the city\xe2\x80\x99s police and fire departments could also use the network, Todd said. Currently, public safety programs use cellular data devices to connect to the internet.\nThe city plans to monitor usage to see what sites are being visited and if students are using the connection for school.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur whole goal is to fundamentally change and improve the access for kids so they can use it for school,\xe2\x80\x9d Bianchi said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe want to make sure \xe2\x80\x93 as we are doing this \xe2\x80\x93 it is being used in the way that we think it is being used. Like any pilot program, you are going to establish the effectiveness of how many people are using it.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe city is also working with Verizon to provide MiFi devices to students in other areas of the city where the Wi-Fi is not available. MiFi devices provide internet connection using cellular data.\nThe school district has selected 100 students for an after-school program where the devices will be provided.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are looking at them as having the most need, so we are going to start with that,\xe2\x80\x9d Todd said.\nKuo said Foster High School is surveying students to see how many have internet access before it begins deploying the laptops.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we want to send them home, we want to make sure students have internet access,\xe2\x80\x9d Kuo said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t have students singled out because they don\xe2\x80\x99t have internet.\xe2\x80\x9d\n==\nHow to connect\nAnyone in the area of South 144th Street between Tukwila International Boulevard and Military Road South can connect to the internet through free hotspots.\nTo connect:\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Go to the Wi-Fi settings on any device and join the SSID Tukwila Community WiFi.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Once connected, read and accept the terms to the user license agreement.\nFor questions or feedback, contact wifi@tukwilawa.gov.\nLearn more about the future of IT in Tukwila at futureit.tukwilawa.gov.\nThe city of Tukwila recently launched a pilot program that provides free Wi-Fi access along South 144th Street between Tukwila International Boulevard and Military Road South. Courtesy, city of Tukwila\nPrevious\nFirst students enroll in Impact Puget Sound Elementary\nNext\nSaguil takes on new role as school resource officer at Foster High School\nThis Week's AdsView NY\nUpper West Side, NY\nUpper East Side, NY\nMidtown Manhattan, NY\nHarlem, NY\nAstoria-Long Island City, NY\nChelsea, NY\nGramercy-Murray Hill, NY\nWest Village, NY\nEast Village, NY\nState Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\nhealth & fitness\nRegister For Health Care At LinkNYC Kiosks\nNew Yorkers can sign up for insurance until Jan. 31.\nBy Noah Manskar, Patch Staff\nJan 17, 2018 4:18 pm ET | Updated Jan 17, 2018 4:22 pm ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nNEW YORK, NY \xe2\x80\x94 New Yorkers can sign up for health care on the street for the next two weeks. The city\'s LinkNYC internet kiosks will connect directly to the state insurance marketplace until the open enrollment period closes Jan. 31, city officials said Wednesday. A special app will connect LinkNYC users to the New York State of Health marketplace, where they can enroll in a new insurance plan or change their existing plan, officials said. The 1,200 kiosks across the five boroughs will also display public service announcements encouraging city residents to get covered if they aren\'t already. The city started installing the kiosks in 2016 to provide free wireless internet. "LinkNYC\'s superfast, free Wi-Fi is already a tremendously valuable resource for New Yorkers \xe2\x80\x94 and giving our neighbors the opportunity to get healthcare coverage right there at a Link kiosk only deepens that," Anne Roest, the outgoing commissioner of the city Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, said in a statement. The initiative is part of the city\'s efforts to connect New Yorkers with publicly funded health insurance through the state marketplace.\nIt comes after President Donald Trump reportedly cut the federal advertising budget to promote health insurance supported by the Affordable Care Act, the landmark health care law championed by his predecesesor, Barack Obama.\nThe city Department of Health also provides in-person counseling to help enroll people in health policies. (Lead image: A man uses a LinkNYC kiosk in August 2016. Payphone Parts on eBay\nPayphone Industry Links\nLinkNYC by the Numbers\nTablets Down\nPhones Down\nWiFi Down\nSearch\nThe Payphone Project: "The best \xe2\x80\x94 and most entertaining \xe2\x80\x94 website that tracks the de-evolution of payphones and phone booths" AT&T\nHome\nLatest\nDaily Payphone\nIn Movies and on TV\nThen and Now\nPayphone Pictures & Sounds\nSounds\nPayphone Confidential\nNo Dial Tone at Grand Central TerminalInbound Calls Now Allowed to Australia\xe2\x80\x99s Telstra PayphonesThe \xe2\x80\x9cWE NEED MORE PAY PHONES\xe2\x80\x9d Vandal(s) Never Stop(s)To Whoever Gets the Job of Franchise Inspector at DoITT\nPhotos\nAfrica\nAntarctica\nAsia\nAustralia, New Zealand, Oceania\nEurope\nSouth & Central America\nNorth America\nNumbers\nUSPS Mailbox Locator\nAbout\nContact\nFAQs\nGothamist: LinkNYC/Mr. Softee Mystery Solved\nPayphone Project on \xe2\x80\x9cCBS Sunday Morning\xe2\x80\x9d\nNew York Times\n\xe2\x80\x9cHang Up\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 Payphone Documentary by Hugo Massa\nHuffington Post Interview\nLA Times\nSt. Pete Times\nLike On Facebook\nFollow on Twitter\nPayphones on Soundcloud\nPayphones & Parts\nPayphones and Payphone Parts on eBay\nPayphone Industry Links\nLinkNYC by the Numbers\nTablets Down\nPhones Down\nWiFi Down\nSearch\nLink.NYC\nTwo Years of LinkNYC\nthe payphone project\nJanuary 17, 2018\n|\nIt has been a couple of years since CityBridge commenced its raid of New York City\xe2\x80\x99s sidewalks with its so-called \xe2\x80\x9cpayphone of the future\xe2\x80\x9d, the 10-foot tall electronic billboard monoliths known as LinkNYC.\nThe LinkNYC platform is, first and foremost, an advertising platform.\nBut the kiosks also offer a number of public amenities, such as free phone calls within the U.S., MTA transit updates, maps to tell you where you are, the time of day, etc. LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s signature feature would seem to be its blazing fast free Wi-Fi. In my admittedly limited experience (with a less than bleeding edge tablet) it was not especially fast, nor was it reliable. I have not made use of the Wi-Fi since early in 2016, soon after the kiosks first appeared on Third Avenue in Manhattan. I do not intend to make future use of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s free Wi-Fi.\nI wanted to be a fan of LinkNYC. Really, I did. But I have come to loath these things. This loss of sympathy does not exactly compare to LBJ losing Cronkite but given my connection to the world of payphones and my personal connection to the livelihoods wiped out by the LinkNYC monopoly it is enduring enough of an issue for me that I thought I should write about it again. I did not think I would.\nMany of the LinkNYC kiosks simply Do Not Work\xe2\x84\xa2. In their uselessness they lurk ugly as hell, ingrown toenails on the city\xe2\x80\x99s streets. Countless kiosks, once erected, stand idle for months. This useless slab has inhabited its spot (COMING SOON!) since October but I have seen other LinkNYC middle fingers stand dark like this for far longer.\nInactive LinkNYC Kiosk\nCityBridge has claimed the kiosks are maintained twice a week. Maybe I do not understand what \xe2\x80\x9cmaintenance\xe2\x80\x9d means but if it includes making sure the kiosks are in proper working order then I find it hard to believe these things are checked in on twice weekly. If so then they are not being maintained very well. I and others on social media have seen screens, reserved for advertisements and twee factoids, instead pouring oceans of Linux text matter 24 hours a day for weeks on end.\nAnother #LinkNYC endless bootup lightshow, this with a subtle seasonal Christmasy color splotches. pic.twitter.com/cUH1QG7ATE\n\xe2\x80\x94 Payphone Project (@payphonenews) November 28, 2017\nAnother glitch I have not noticed lately but which was showing up all over town for a couple of months was this seizure-inducing spectacle that looked like something from a discotech lightshow gone wrong. Imagine living with this right outside your living room window:\nAnother #LinkNYC psychedelic lightshow. pic.twitter.com/fjLzwdCmYX\n\xe2\x80\x94 Payphone Project (@payphonenews) October 25, 2017\nAny time I see one of these bugged out LinkNYC advertising panels all I can think is this is such an obvious thing to have not happen, and that the network must be designed so the kiosks cannot be remotely rebooted or even monitored for functionality.\nOther lasting problems with the kiosks include touchscreens that don\xe2\x80\x99t work, calls that never connect, screeching sounds inexplicably blaring from the loudspeakers, advertising screens that show no ads, etc. If you are sitting in your Hudson Yards CityBridge offices you know exactly what I am talking about.\nI could go on but enough about LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s rinky-dink hardware and software. What about LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s feel-good Smart City amenities and social services that are alleged to level the playing field between the rich who created these things and the poor who cannot access the Internet at anything but GIGABIT speeds?\nAt present CityBridge claims New Yorkers can register for health insurance at the New York State of Health website \xe2\x80\x9cright here\xe2\x80\x9d, meaning at a LinkNYC kiosk.\nThat is not true.\nForget about the logistics of navigating the famously recalcitrant New York State of Health website through a small tablet screen without a physical keyboard on a city sidewalk in the cold of January. Even if using the New York State of Health website was practical it would be impossible to register anew entirely from a LinkNYC kiosk. Registration requires one to create an account and validate it using an e-mail address. Assuming a LinkNYC user even has an e-mail account it would be impossible for them to access it from the kiosk. Did product planners at CityBridge imagine users would create their New York State of Health account at one device and resume their registration at a LinkNYC kiosk? Why would anyone would do that? It could be possible to use kiosks for this if you already have an account from previous years at the New York State of Health. But the registration process also requires users to upload tax returns and documents for proof of income. Has quantum computing evolved to a point where this is possible from a LinkNYC kiosk? CityBridge product management in its condescending wealth would not know having never seen anything more than their link to the New York State of Health website.\nYES, with a laptop or a tablet it should be possible to connect to the health exchange through LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Wi-Fi. But that is not the claim being made by CityBridge. Theirs is a cynical pronouncement few would question but which others hail as a signature achievement \xe2\x80\x94 a Smart City initiative making social services available to all. In fact it does no such thing. This digital divide remains unbridged. The only way to register for health insurance through a LinkNYC kiosk would be over the phone. That being the case you\xe2\x80\x99d have better luck using one of the old payphones these kiosks replaced. Smart City indeed.\n54\nLinkNYC: Sign up for Health Care? Not So Much.\nOne clue as to why CityBridge gets away with claiming it is possible to register for health insurance from their kiosks comes from a piece of typically soft media coverage, the likes of which LinkNYC seems amazingly capable of nurturing. The New York Times reported CityBridge \xe2\x80\x9cis working with GetCoveredNYC and the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications to create a health care enrollment app on tablets across the five boroughs.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSo, they are \xe2\x80\x9cworking\xe2\x80\x9d on an app. Seriously? With zero revenue to be made from such an app, and with time running out before the registration deadline arrives, I do not think such a product will make it to LinkNYC kiosks any time soon.\nHaving fibbed about the ability to register from a kiosk at the present time I suspect that this app CityBridge refers to Does Not Exist\xe2\x84\xa2. It is vaporware.\nThe NYC.gov website, to its credit, does not mention LinkNYC as an option for registering at the New York State of Health, probably because the city knows it cannot be done.\nBut about a week after the previous reference the Times repeated the claim that registering for health insurance is possible through the kiosks, this time in a Q & A piece that almost looks like it could have been asked and answered by CityBridge itself.\nThis little bit of public relations gawkery, catering to the self-satisfied Smart City meme that LinkNYC kiosks are designed with community-first thinking, is emblematic of the flat out lies underlining the program. One early promise of LinkNYC was that the city would be blanketed with free Wi-Fi in every road and alleyway. To fulfill that promise, and to comply with zoning requirements, residential neighborhoods would be populated with advertising-free kiosks. That pledge might have been an intentional fabrication merely meant to grease the wheels of getting CityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s monopoly franchise approved but those advertising-free units will almost certainly never appear.\nSo what about the free phone calls, weather snapshots, and transit updates? I found no issues with the transit data, which come from the MTA website. The HTML forms interface is clumsy to me and the typeface is tiny, but it works.\nWeather snapshots are erratic, with reported current temperatures varying so widely from one kiosk to another that you might think climate change is a little too real. Three kiosks in a row last week showed temperatures at 40\xc2\xba, 60\xc2\xba, and 72\xc2\xba. On a very cold day in December I saw one kiosk report a balmy 49\xc2\xba. A couple of days ago, when it should have been too cold for me to care what LinkNYC thought the temperature was, this kiosk cheerily said I was out and about on a beautiful 82\xc2\xba afternoon.\nLinkNYC Weather Snapshot, Completely Wrong\nI might have never noticed it before but recently other LinkNYC kiosks have borked one feature for which I had come to think they were actually reliable: The time of day. On December 24 at about 2:30pm this kiosk claimed it was 8:04am on January 2, 2009.\nLinkNYC: The Time of Day\nWhat of the free phone calls, a marquee feature which accounts for LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s tagline as the \xe2\x80\x9cpayphone of the future\xe2\x80\x9d?\nCall quality from LinkNYC kiosks was always bad but it has actually gotten worse in recent months. This seems to be a deliberate choice of the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 maintainers. Most LinkNYC kiosks I encounter lately are set so the sound volume of the phone calls can only be turned up half way. It did not used to be like this. With any level of street noise (duh) this low-volume \xe2\x80\x9cfeature\xe2\x80\x9d makes it almost impossible to hear whoever you have called (assuming the call you made even went through). This half-way volume limitation is supposed to be LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cafter dark\xe2\x80\x9d mode, a concessionary setting begrudgingly made by CityBridge so that phone calls made at night would not disturb the sleep of people unfortunate enough to have a kiosk outside their bedroom window.\nAs of a couple of months ago I find that more and more kiosks are set to after dark mode all day long, not just at night, while others are set so that full volume on the loudspeakers can be reached 24/7. There does not seem to be a pattern or logic behind which ones are set to night mode and which ones are not.\nLast year I discovered that successfully making phone calls from these kiosks was essentially a hit-or-miss affair, with calls connecting only about half the time. That ratio seems to have improved a bit, but that might be because network availability improved after CityBridge dropped its maximum call time on some kiosks from 4 hours to 55 minutes, and it only applies to kiosks where the tablet device works in the first place. Many of the tablet screens are dark, dangling like bats-by-their-balls in \xe2\x80\x9cHang Tight\xe2\x80\x9d mode, or otherwise dysfunctional. One kiosk in my neighborhood looked like this for weeks, maybe even months. I know of other kiosk tablets that I don\xe2\x80\x99t think ever worked.\nBlinkNYC Kiosk\nI could go on with these observations but don\xe2\x80\x99t worry, I won\xe2\x80\x99t, though I have plenty more where this came from. These complaints might seem petty. I hear tech trolls, DoITT, and even CityBridge waking from its corporate slumber telling me to SHUT UP\xe2\x80\xa6 But given the propaganda we\xe2\x80\x99ve been fed about these things equalizing information and broadband access for all I do not understand how CityBridge, with its resources and municipal privilege, gets away with delivering such a half-assed product as LinkNYC.\nWhat to make of the fibs? Should we believe anything CityBridge says about LinkNYC? The claim that you can register for health insurance from any LinkNYC kiosk: That\xe2\x80\x99s not true. What of the early claim that purely residential areas would be given advertising-free kiosks? That appears to have never been true, though this apparent canard might reflect nothing more than bad or overly-ambitious planning. Claims that each LinkNYC kiosk is maintained twice weekly seem absurd given the state of disrepair in which so many of them languish. I suspect other fabrications inhabit the LinkNYC program but will let them pass for now. The bridge rots from the bottom. If\nCityBridge can get away with all these little lies they will move on to bigger ones \xe2\x80\x94 if they haven\xe2\x80\x99t already.\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve never gotten past the tasteless way CityBridge addressed, or rather did not address their encampments that plagued the kiosks and turned some neighborhoods into toilets for the first 7 months of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s existence. Sycophantic press coverage suggested the company dealt with the matter swiftly but that is simply not true.\nThe poor and disenfranchised who gravitated to LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Internet web browser (formerly on the kiosks) were nothing but pawns in an arrogant, for-profit game of Smart City brinkmanship played by tech overlords who have done nothing to prove they have any business using a city\xe2\x80\x99s streets and its people as their beta testing sandbox.\nI used to watch some of the people sitting at the kiosks, grooving to YouTube music videos, watching full length movies while the so-called \xe2\x80\x9crest of us\xe2\x80\x9d passed them by.\nThey were every bit a part of this town as the rest of us.\nThat was probably the first time a lot of those folks ever had regular access to the Internet, only to have the amenity sternly revoked with a condescending announcement that it was their fault for using the kiosks as their personal entertainment centers.\nThere could be blame to go all around but this was an inevitable result of bad planning and CityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s prolonged indifference to their money-making consequences.\nSure, I could complain to 311, DoITT, or LinkNYC itself. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve found 311 to almost always be a waste of time and those other routes are futile. I had made comments to LinkNYC on Twitter but I\xe2\x80\x99ve either been ignored or asked to take it to Direct Messaging (no thanks). A Facebook posting I made regarding the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s poor phone call quality was deleted by whoever manages the LinkNYC page, an admittedly petty incident which nevertheless teed me off enough to decide I should not reach out to them anymore. There are other ways for me to waste my time.\nI could align with some of the anti-tech and anti-surveillance activists. They want me to. I\xe2\x80\x99ve considered it. I have met with them. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what value one such as I could bring to something like that. I am not an activist-minded soul to begin with but even if I was I don\xe2\x80\x99t think my voice and relatively respected reputation in the realm of public telephony would land on anything but deaf ears at DoITT or anywhere else of relevance.\nThis story will, I know, be read and summarily waved away and ignored by CityBridge and all involved. (I have access_logs!)\nThis Smart City stampede cannot be stopped, no matter its unproven track record or, in the case of LinkNYC, obvious dysfunction. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know about other programs but the LinkNYC initiative in particular is simply not one of those things where the public\xe2\x80\x99s input matters. Money is being made so SHUT UP.\nMy interest in these kiosks makes sense given their connection to the world of public pay telephones. But it as a niche interest. Many New Yorkers do not know or do not care that these things exist. I\xe2\x80\x99m starting to think I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t care, either.\nShare this:Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)MoreClick to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window)Click to share on Tumblr (Opens in new window)\nRelated\npreviously\xc2\xab Payphones Seen in Woody Allen\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cManhattan\xe2\x80\x9d\nnextPayphones of \xe2\x80\x9cCat People\xe2\x80\x9d (1982) \xc2\xbb\n2 thoughts on \xe2\x80\x9cTwo Years of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x9d\nSteven\nSeptember 14, 2018 at 12:40 pm \xc2\xb7 Edit\nAt first there were just a few, now they are on almost every street corner. I have never seen anyone using one, have you? The other day, out of curiosity, I tried to look up where to vote in primaries, but the station did not work. They are also massive eyesores. And the last thing we need is to have more screens flashing the 24/7 news cycle at us while we are walking down the street. I would think it is also extremely expensive to build and install them, and then you need people to program for them, maintenance, etc. Aren\xe2\x80\x99t there much better ways to spend our NYC tax dollars?\nReply\nthe payphone project\nSeptember 14, 2018 at 12:52 pm \xc2\xb7 Edit\nI see people using them but not very often. The program is said to be 100% funded by advertising revenues, with zero tax dollars, though I\xe2\x80\x99ve long been a little suspicious of that claim being 100% true. I agree about the screens being blighted eyesores, and the quantity of these things is ludicrous. There are not even 2,000 of them on the streets yet, we are supposed to get 10,000!\nReply\nPost Comment Cancel reply\nComment\nName *\nEmail *\nWebsite\nNotify me of follow-up comments by email. Here\xe2\x80\x99s why | World Economic Forum\nAgenda\nInitiatives\nReports\nEvents\nAbout\nAbout\nOur Mission\nLeadership and Governance\nOur Members and Partners\nCommunities\nCentre for the Fourth Industrial Revolution\nOur Impact\nHistory\nCentre for Cybersecurity\nKlaus Schwab\nPictures\nMedia\nContact Us\nMapping Global Transformations\nCareers\nWorld Economic Forum LLC\nCode of Conduct\nWorld Economic Forum Privacy Policy\nSustainability\nEnglish\nEnglish\nEnglish\nEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nFran\xc3\xa7ais\n\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe6\x97\xa5\xe6\x9c\xac\xe8\xaa\x9e\nLogin to TopLink\nWe use cookies to improve your experience on our website. By using our website you consent to all cookies in accordance with our updated Cookie Notice.\nI accept\nAgenda\nInitiatives\nReports\nEvents\nAbout\nEnglish\nEnglish\nEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nFran\xc3\xa7ais\n\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe6\x97\xa5\xe6\x9c\xac\xe8\xaa\x9e\nTopLink\nGlobal Agenda\nTechnological Transformation\nEmerging Technologies\nUnited States\nA quarter of urban Americans don't have broadband access. Here\xe2\x80\x99s why\nNew York, home to over 8.5 million people, has roughly 1.6 million residents who lack broadband connectivity.\nImage: REUTERS/Ints Kalnins\n18 Jan 2018\nRob Smith\nFormative Content\nNew Report: Are we saving enough for retirement?\nRead more\nMost Popular\nHow the digital economy is shaping a new BangladeshAzaz Zaman 19 Jun 2019\nDavid Attenborough\xe2\x80\x99s worried about this ocean threat - and it\xe2\x80\x99s not plasticEmma\nCharlton 18 Jun 2019\nGlobots and telemigrants: The new language of the future of workEshe Nelson \xc2\xb7 Quartz 19 Jun 2019\nMore on the agenda\nExplore context\nTechnological Transformation\nExplore the latest strategic trends, research and analysis\nThe United States is home to many of the world\xe2\x80\x99s biggest tech companies including Apple, Amazon, Google and Facebook.\nYet almost a quarter (23%) of urban Americans \xe2\x80\x93 nearly 62 million citizens \xe2\x80\x93 do not have access to broadband.\nThis is a similar proportion to Russia, where almost 24% of the urban population lack broadband access.\nImage: Statista\nThe chief barriers to connectivity are quality of internet and affordability. A lack of IT literacy also poses a concern.\nThat is according to a report by IHS Markit and the Wireless Broadband Alliance (WBA), which identified what percentage of people from urban areas in eight countries lacked access to broadband.\nThe report also analyzed connectivity in five cities, including in London where just 7%, or 625,000 of almost 8.8 million residents, are without broadband.\nIn New York, the most densely populated city in the US and home to over 8.5 million people, roughly 1.6 million residents lack broadband connectivity, as the table below demonstrates.\nImage: IHS Markit and the Wireless Broadband Alliance (WBA)\nCity connections\nTo tackle this, New York is focusing on providing people with IT and technology skills, as well as providing improved internet access throughout the city.\nFor example, the OneNYC initiative, launched by mayor Bill de Blasio in 2015, aims to provide every resident and business in New York with access to adequate and affordable broadband by 2025.\nLast year, the project helped provide free Wi-Fi to around 3,500 residents, and offered dedicated support for senior citizens as well as for young people and their families.\nAnother project launched by the de Blasio administration, called LinkNYC, included repurposing New York\xe2\x80\x99s payphone infrastructure with free Wi-Fi. According to LinkNYC, at least 7,500 payphone kiosks will be installed in the city by 2025, providing superfast broadband for residents.\nClosing the digital divide\nThe report also highlights the digital divide among those from rural areas, where the average proportion of unconnected people across the eight nations analyzed is 44%.\nIn addition to lower rates of connectivity, rural populations often have to contend with less reliable and slower internet than those living in towns and cities.\nIn the US alone, well over 16 million residents from rural areas lack broadband, which is equivalent to 28% of the rural population, as the table below highlights.\nImage: IHS Markit and the Wireless Broadband Alliance (WBA)\nSocial change organization Connect Americans Now (CAN) is trying to tackle this issue, promising to bring reliable and affordable broadband to all Americans living in rural areas by 2022.\nAccording to CAN, the most effective way to improve connectivity is via a combination of wired and wireless technologies, and by leveraging a range of bandwidths, such as the 700 MHz frequency range. The group claims this would enable wireless signals to travel over hills and through buildings and trees.\nChallenges in rural America, however, are far less pronounced than in other nations, particularly in India where 87% of the rural population lacks broadband access.\nFortunately for its citizens, India has developed plans at a country-wide level to expand digitization and develop \xe2\x80\x9csmart cities\xe2\x80\x9d.\nIts Smart Cities Mission and Challenge project includes retrofitting and redeveloping existing areas to improve communications infrastructure and broadband connectivity.\nHowever, it is the UK and Germany that lead the charge in terms of rural connectivity. Almost 90% of residents in rural Britain have access to broadband, while in Germany around 82% of the rural population is connected.\nImage: IHS Markit and the Wireless Broadband Alliance (WBA)\nHave you read?\nThese are the most (and least) expensive countries for broadband\nThe plan to get 100 million more Indians online by 2018\nSpace could be the final frontier for the world's digital divide\nTo have your say on this topic, submit a question to be answered at Davos by a global leader.\nShare\nWritten by\nRob Smith, Formative Content\nThe views expressed in this article are those of the author alone and not the World Economic Forum.\nNew Report: Are we saving enough for retirement?\nRead more\nExplore context\nTechnological Transformation\nExplore the latest strategic trends, research and analysis\nSubscribe for updates\nA weekly update of what\xe2\x80\x99s on the Global Agenda\nFeatured:\nTechnological Transformation\nView all\nFiguring out Blockchain's most useful open\nToggle navigation\nFood\nchennai\nsouth indianasiancontinentalmediterraneanmulti cuisineworld cuisine\nbengaluru\nsouth indianasiancontinentalmediterraneanmulti cuisineworld York City\xe2\x80\x99s signature dining program,\xc2\xa0NYC Restaurant Week\xc2\xa0returns\nPublished: \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa018th\nJanuary 2018 12:00 PM\n0\nShare Via Email\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City is a world-class culinary destination and our NYC Restaurant Week program, which celebrated its 25th anniversary this past summer, exemplifies this ranking and welcomes all to come and experience it first-hand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fred Dixon, president and CEO of NYC & Company. \xe2\x80\x9cWhether you\xe2\x80\x99re a visitor, meetings delegate or local resident, we invite diners to taste and explore New York City\xe2\x80\x99s incomparable restaurant scene across all five boroughs at a value this winter.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cNYC Restaurant Week was the first dining program of its kind, and provides the restaurant industry with the opportunity to showcase the quality and hospitality that our establishments are renowned for,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tracy Nieporent, partner and director of marketing for Myriad Restaurant Group and chairman of NYC & Company\xe2\x80\x99s Restaurant Committee. \xe2\x80\x9cThe dining community looks forward to welcoming patrons to experience and enjoy a variety of diverse restaurants across more than 40 neighborhoods this winter.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThis season features\xc2\xa032 new restaurant participants: Almond Flatiron, Antonucci Cafe, Astor Court, Augustine, Babu Ji, \xe2\x80\x98Cesca, Fusco, Il Cortile Restaurant, La Pecora Bianca Midtown, Legasea, Loring Place, Massoni, Maxwell\xe2\x80\x99s Chophouse, Momofuku Ma Peche, Momofuku Nishi, Nickel & Diner, One Dine, Ortzi, Osteriadella Pace, Paowalla Restaurant, Quality Eats\xe2\x80\x93Upper East Side, Rice & Gold, San Carlo OsteriaPiemonte, STK Rooftop, Suzuki, Tarallucci e Vino Upper West Side, The House in Gramercy Park, Tiny\xe2\x80\x99s& The Bar Upstairs, Tuttoil Giorno, Vinateria, Yellow Magnolia Caf\xc3\xa9, and Yves.\nReturning due to popular demand this season is the\xc2\xa0NYC Restaurant Week Tasting Series\xc2\xa0which debuted this past summer. The ticketed events will highlight restaurants within cultural institutions and will offer exclusive tasting menus for guests. Ticket sales will benefit local charities City Harvest, Citymeals on Wheels and Food Bank NYC. Event details will be announced later this month.\nNYC Restaurant Week will be promoted through content on NYCgo.com; digital and print advertising, including with media partner\xc2\xa0Time Out New York; and with out-of-home advertising on NYC bus shelters; street pole banners; LinkNYC screens; NYC taxicabs; Toshiba Vision in Times Square; and PATH trains and stations. Brand partners include booking partner OpenTable and culinary arts organization James Beard Foundation. NYC & Company\xe2\x80\x99s creative campaign for NYC Restaurant Week features new taglines to excite potential diners this winter, including \xe2\x80\x9cBeat the Cold in Warm Company,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBest Paired with Best Friends\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSome things are worth hailing a cab for.\xe2\x80\x9d\nO\nP\nE\nN\nComments\nChennaiBengaluruKochiKolkataCoimbatoreHyderabadChennaiBengaluruKochiKolkataCoimbatoreHyderabad\nFacebook\nTweets by TheIndulgeMag\nFOLLOW US\nCopyright - Mascali\nPublished : January 18, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nMore\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsapp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\nWith the deadline for health care open enrollment on Jan. 31, New York City launched a LinkNYC app to sign up for coverage. (Getty)\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nWith the open enrollment deadline looming, New York City is looking to make it easy for residents to sign up for health care.\nOn Wednesday, the city launched its Healthcare Open Enrollment app on the more than 1,100 LinkNYC kiosks in all five boroughs. Public service announcements will also air on the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s digital displays to remind New Yorkers that the deadline to enroll for health-care coverage is Wednesday, Jan. 31.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s superfast, free Wi-Fi is already a tremendously valuable resource for New Yorkers \xe2\x80\x94 and giving our neighbors the opportunity to get healthcare coverage right there at a Link kiosk only deepens that,\xe2\x80\x9d Anne Roest, commissioner of the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, said in a statement.\nRecommended Slideshows\n40 PicturesPHOTOS: Blues dump Bruins to win Stanley Cup after agonizing 52-year wait40 Pictures\n8 PicturesPHOTOS: This Pakistani waiter looks just like Peter Dinklage8 Pictures\n36 PicturesAll of these celebrities have had their nudes leaked36 PicturesMore picture galleries\n16 PicturesThese photos of Trump and Ivanka will make you deeply uncomfortable\n16 Pictures\n4 PicturesCuba Gooding Jr. charged in Manhattan groping incident, police say4 Pictures\n2 Pictures4 fun things to do in the Lehigh Valley2 Pictures\nThrough the LinkNYC kiosks, residents will be able to review their health care marketplace options, enroll for coverage and review or change their existing plans.\nAs part of #GetCoveredNYC, the city also offers free, in-person assistance in getting health insurance coverage through the New York State of Health Marketplace. New Yorkers can visit nyc.gov/aca, call 311 or text \xe2\x80\x9cCoveredNYC\xe2\x80\x9d to 877-877 to find a nearby counselor.\nAdditionally, Certified Application Counselors (CAC) are also available Monday through Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. in each borough to help explain enrollment options. Though walk-ins are welcome at some locations, appointments are encouraged. Interpretation services are offered as well.\nTags:HealthNew York City\nLoading...\nLatest From ...\nNews\nShare Now\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsApp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\nTrump's East Village NYC.\nSaturday, January 20, 2018\nPrepping for another LinkNYC kiosk on 3rd Avenue\nA payphone-removing crew was out this morning, prepping to take away the phones on the east side of Appreciating what\'s here while it\'s still here. Remembering what\'s no longer here. Grieve\'s ProfileCreate Your Badge\nSubscribe To\nPosts\nAtom\nPosts\nComments\nAtom\nComments', b'\xc2\xbfCu\xc3\xa1les son las ciudades m\xc3\xa1s tecnol\xc3\xb3gicas del mundo? - Expreso\n)\n\xef\x80\x8d \xef\x82\x9a\xef\x82\x99\xef\x85\xaa\xef\x82\x9e \xef\x80\x82 ExpresoSecciones Victoria Sur Frontera Mante Veracruz Texas Seguridad Deportes M\xc3\xa9xico Mundo Opinion Espect\xc3\xa1culos Tecnolog\xc3\xada Redes Sociales \xc2\xa1No te lo pierdas!MultimediaImpresosClasificados \xef\x83\x89\xef\x82\x9a\xef\x82\x99\xef\x85\xaa\xef\x82\x9e 21 de Junio, 2019 \xef\x80\x82Secciones Victoria Sur Frontera Mante Veracruz Texas Seguridad Deportes M\xc3\xa9xico Mundo Opinion Espect\xc3\xa1culos Tecnolog\xc3\xada Redes Sociales \xc2\xa1No te lo pierdas!MultimediaImpresosClasificados\nEn riesgo de despido 700 trabajadores de saludAeropuerto de Tampico se suma a las acciones de limpieza emprendidas por Chucho NaderBenefician a 47 productores del campo de Ciudad VictoriaOperan delegaciones con funcionarios administrativos: SEPCiclistas han sido responsables en 20 accidentes, de 35 ocurridos\n\xc2\xa1No te lo pierdas! Est\xc3\xa1s en: Expreso > \xc2\xa1No te lo pierdas! > \xc2\xbfCu\xc3\xa1les son las ciudades m\xc3\xa1s tecnol\xc3\xb3gicas del mundo?\xc2\xbfCu\xc3\xa1les son las ciudades m\xc3\xa1s tecnol\xc3\xb3gicas del mundo?Las ciudades que florecer\xc3\xa1n en el futuro son aquellas dise\xc3\xb1adas a partir de las tecnolog\xc3\xadas de alto nivel \xef\x80\x97 7:11 PM / 24 de enero, 2018\n/ Agencias \xef\x83\xa6 Comentarios \xef\x80\x83 \xef\x88\xb2 Comparte \xef\x82\x9a Comparte \xef\x82\x99 Comparte M\xc3\x89XICO.FLa mayor\xc3\xada de la poblaci\xc3\xb3n a nivel mundial vive en centros urbanos, ciudades que o bien nacieron hace muchos a\xc3\xb1os y que fueron creadas recientemente para satisfacer una necesidad. De acuerdo con la Organizaci\xc3\xb3n Mundial de la Salud, en menos de 35 a\xc3\xb1os dos tercios de las personas en todo el mundo vivir\xc3\xa1n en ciudades.De acuerdo con Business Insider, las ciudades que florecer\xc3\xa1n en el futuro son aquellas que est\xc3\xa9n dise\xc3\xb1adas a partir de las m\xc3\xa1s recientes tecnolog\xc3\xadas de alto nivel, lo que le dar\xc3\xa1 a sus habitantes la oportunidad y las herramientas para desarrollar nuevas innovacionesBusiness Insider consult\xc3\xb3 a la empresa de investigaci\xc3\xb3n especializada en ciudades innovadoras 2thinknow para clasificar a las ciudades de acuerdo con su nivel de adopci\xc3\xb3n, desarrollo y utilizaci\xc3\xb3n de las tecnolog\xc3\xadas de alto nivel. La firma eligi\xc3\xb3 10 factores relacionados con el avance tecnol\xc3\xb3gico incluyendo el n\xc3\xbamero de patentes presentadas per c\xc3\xa1pita, las startups, los capitalistas de riesgo tecnol\xc3\xb3gicos, el ranking en otros reportes sobre innovaci\xc3\xb3n y el nivel de uso de los tel\xc3\xa9fonos inteligentes compar\xc3\xa1ndolos y elaborando a partir de esta comparaci\xc3\xb3n una clasificaci\xc3\xb3n de las 25 ciudades m\xc3\xa1s tecnol\xc3\xb3gicas del mundo.1. San Francisco, California A todas las ciudades de la lista les gustar\xc3\xada tener su propio Silicon Valley. Desafortunadamente, Silicon Valley s\xc3\xb3lo hay uno y se encuentra en San Francisco. Ubicada en la costa este de Estados Unidos, en el estado de California, San Francisco es el epicentro de la actividad tecnol\xc3\xb3gica en el mundo, de acuerdo con Business Insider y 2thinknow, sobre todo porque Silicon Valley se las lleva todas en pr\xc3\xa1cticamente todas las categor\xc3\xadas porque la cadena de suministro de la innovaci\xc3\xb3n ha hecho su hogar all\xc3\xad .2. Nueva York, Nueva York De acuerdo con Business Insider, Nueva York es una ciudad especial cuando se trata de su infraestructura tecnol\xc3\xb3gica, en algunos casos es sumamente progresista y en otros, es incre\xc3\xadblemente progresista. En Nueva York existen alrededor de 7,000 empresas tecnol\xc3\xb3gicas de este nivel que brindan empleo a m\xc3\xa1s de 100,000 personas. De acuerdo con 2thinknow, Nueva York tambi\xc3\xa9n integra la tecnolog\xc3\xada a las calles de la urbe con la red de wifi gratuito LinkNYC que cuenta con m\xc3\xa1s de 500 puntos de conexi\xc3\xb3n en la zona de Manhattan.3. Londres, Inglaterra El Crossrail ha convertido a la capital de Inglaterra en el lugar ideal para usar el transporte p\xc3\xbablico y esto es justamente lo que coloca a esta ciudad en los primeros tres lugares de la lista. De acuerdo con Business Insider, en el 2018, ser\xc3\xa1n inauguradas 10 nuevas l\xc3\xadneas de tren que conectar\xc3\xa1n 30 estaciones ya existentes. Adem\xc3\xa1s, la capital londinense cuenta con m\xc3\xa1s start-ups que cualquier otra ciudad del mundo y seg\xc3\xban 2thinknow, hay estimaciones de que en la pr\xc3\xb3xima d\xc3\xa9cada se crear\xc3\xa1n 11,000 trabajos relacionados con la tecnolog\xc3\xada.. Los Angeles, California La Corporaci\xc3\xb3n de Desarrollo Econ\xc3\xb3mico de los Angeles, California, indic\xc3\xb3 en un informe del 2014 que la ciudad tiene m\xc3\xa1s empleos en el sector de alta tecnolog\xc3\xada que cualquier otra en Estados Unidos. Adem\xc3\xa1s, el informe indica que la generaci\xc3\xb3n de riqueza gracias a la inversi\xc3\xb3n en tecnolog\xc3\xada ronda los 58,000 millones de d\xc3\xb3lares y de acuerdo con 2thinknow, tanto las startups como el capital que ha entrado a la ciudad juegan un papel sumamente importante en el sector tecnol\xc3\xb3gico de alto nivel de Los Angeles.5. Se\xc3\xbal, Corea del Sur Seg\xc3\xban Business Insider, Se\xc3\xbal ha sido llamada la ciudad del futuro. El dise\xc3\xb1o de la ciudad hace que \xc3\xa9sta compita directamente con otras urbes de esta lista, como Nueva York. De acuerdo con 2thinknow, en la capital de Corea se archivan m\xc3\xa1s patentes que en cualquier otra metr\xc3\xb3poli en el mundo. La LTE es un est\xc3\xa1ndar de comunicaciones en todo el mundo que justamente dio inicio en esta ciudad oriental, lo mismo que la tendencia a consumir productos v\xc3\xada digital.6. Taipei, Taiw\xc3\xa1n Taipei es la capital del dise\xc3\xb1o industrial. De acuerdo con 2thinknow, la ciudad ha sido la meca del dise\xc3\xb1o de productos industriales desde hace varios a\xc3\xb1os, sobre todo cuando se trata de hardware para las computadoras. \xc3\x89sta es la raz\xc3\xb3n de que compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xadas como Asus, Gigabyte y Acer llamen su hogar a esta urbe.7. Boston, Massachusetts De universidades como Harvard, Tufts y Northeastern han salido tecnolog\xc3\xadas de alto nivel, sobre todo en los campos de la biotecnolog\xc3\xada y la rob\xc3\xb3tica. Compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xadas como Facebook, que tiene sus oficinas centrales en California, han fundado oficinas de investigaci\xc3\xb3n y desarrollo (I+D), y otras muchas peque\xc3\xb1as empresas y laboratorios de innovaci\xc3\xb3n han logrado establecerse en esta ciudad que cuenta con varios inversionistas de capital de riesgo, como Ventures Bater\xc3\xada, Venture Atlas, Bessemer Venture Partners, Matrix Venture Partners.8. Singapur, Singapur Singapur es un hervidero de tecnolog\xc3\xada. La cantidad de programadores y de inversionistas de capital de riesgo hacen que la ciudad est\xc3\xa9 en constante transformaci\xc3\xb3n, con infraestructura y tecnolog\xc3\xada de alto nivel, que incluye la construcci\xc3\xb3n de un bosque en el centro de un edificio, adem\xc3\xa1s de que la ciudad ha hecho una alianza con el MIT para desplazar la utilizaci\xc3\xb3n del autom\xc3\xb3vil e impulsar el uso del transporte p\xc3\xbablico.9. Toronto, Canad\xc3\xa1 Seg\xc3\xban Business Insider, Toronto da cabida a un tercio de todas las empresas tecnol\xc3\xb3gicas de Canad\xc3\xa1. Esto significa que de cada tres empresas tecnol\xc3\xb3gicas, una se encuentra en esta urbe. La mayor\xc3\xada de estas empresas no cuentan con m\xc3\xa1s de 50 empleados, lo que implica que se trata de compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xadas j\xc3\xb3venes que actualmente representan una ganancia anual de 52,000 millones de d\xc3\xb3lares y que en el futuro pueden valer mucho m\xc3\xa1s.10. Chicago, Illinois La zona del medio este de Estados Unidos, compuesta por estados como Kansas, Wisconsin, Indiana e Illinois no es el \xc3\xa1rea que se espera que aparezca en esta lista, pero la ciudad de Chicago, en Illinois est\xc3\xa1 demostrando lo contrario, de acuerdo con Business Insider. De acuerdo con un informe reciente, Illinois es uno de los cinco estados en todo el pa\xc3\xads con el mayor n\xc3\xbamero de empleos de alta tecnolog\xc3\xada. Adem\xc3\xa1s, de acuerdo con el Brookings Institute, Chicago es un centro neur\xc3\xa1lgico de la planificaci\xc3\xb3n urbana, que ha sido impulsado principalmente por City Digital, dise\xc3\xb1ada para resolver problemas relacionados con la transferencia de energ\xc3\xada y el transporte .11. Dallas-Fort Worth, Texas 12. Tokyo, Jap\xc3\xb3n 13. Estocolmo, Suiza 14. Vancouver, Canad\xc3\xa1 15. Amsterdam, Holanda 16. Beijing, China 17. Shanghai, China 18. Montreal, Canad\xc3\xa1 19. Bangalore, India 20. Shenzhen, China 21. Berlin, Alemania 22. Hong Kong, China 23. Copenhage, Dinamarca 24. Barcelona, Espa\xc3\xb1a 25. Washington, DCCON INFORMACION DE EL ECONOMISTA. \xc2\xa1No te lo pierdas!\n\xc2\xbfCu\xc3\xa1ndo inicia el solsticio de verano y por qu\xc3\xa9 es el d\xc3\xada m\xc3\xa1s largo del a\xc3\xb1o?Iniciar\xc3\xa1 en punto de las 10:55 horas del 21 de junio, momento en el...\nTribunal reconoce el derecho a volar de las aves; prohibe enjaularlasLa ONG People for Animals (PETA), asegura que las aves, por naturaleza tienen derecho...\nVer pel\xc3\xadculas de terror en pareja ayuda a fortalece la relaci\xc3\xb3nVivir situaciones estresantes en compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xada del ser amado fortalece la confianza y lazos amorosos...\nPerro muerde diploma de reci\xc3\xa9n graduada (VIDEO)El bulldog, de nombre Tarz\xc3\xa1n, mordi\xc3\xb3 la carpeta verde pensando que era comida. Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\nseasonal & holidays\nPost Your Valentine On LinkNYC Kiosks Once Famous For Public Porn\nYou can declare your love on the devices where shady characters once watched porn in public.\nBy Noah Manskar, Patch Staff\nJan 25, 2018 4:18 pm ET | Updated Jan 26, 2018 8:36 am ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nNEW YORK, NY \xe2\x80\x94 The city wants New Yorkers to declare their love \xe2\x80\x94 or even pop the question \xe2\x80\x94 on the kiosks that were once infamous for public porn-watching.\nTo celebrate Valentine\'s Day, anyone who posts a cute photo to Instagram and tags it with #LinkLoveNYC could have the picture projected on the sides of more than 1,200 LinkNYC kiosks across city on Feb. 14. Link, the company behind the kiosks, is even offering to help New Yorkers "set up a special proposal" using the screens. But anyone popping the question might have to shuffle around other people charging their phones or making phone calls. "LinkNYC\'s digital displays feature fun facts about New York City, historic photos, important PSAs, and advertising that keeps our services free for all," Link President Jen Hensley said in a statement. "This Valentine\'s Day, you can use it to tell someone you love them \xe2\x80\x94 and even propose." The attempt at romance is Link\'s latest holiday-themed display on the kiosks, which had internet browsers until people reportedly spent hours camped out next to them playing music or watching smutty videos. The kiosks still allow free phone calls, maps and wireless internet connections. The company thinks it\'s solved that problem \xe2\x80\x94 loitering complaints dropped by 96 percent "immediately" after the web browsers were pulled in September 2016, a Link spokesman said.\nLink staff will review every tagged Instagram photo to make sure it\'s not too risque before putting it goes on the screens, the spokesman said. But every appropriate picture will likely be featured. Link will ask users for permission before broadcasting their photos, the company says.\nAnyone who wants to take the next step and propose with the LinkNYC screens should email hello@link.nyc. (Lead image: A LinkNYC kiosk is pictured in Manhattan in August 2016. Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images)Subscribe\nBack to the New York City Patch\nMore from New York CityUp next on New York City Patch\nLegal E-Bikes Won\'t Be Allowed In NYC Bike Lanes, De Blasio Says 3h\nLandfill Art: Sanitation Worker Displays Items Plucked From Trash 4h\nThis Dream Pillow Makes Bedtime Fun For Kids 4d\nRead more local news from New York City\nWhat are Featured Events?\nFeatured Events are paid listings by users and receive priority placement on Patch, on our social pages and in our daily newsletters. Us\nEat & Drink\nReal Estate\nEvents\nCalendar\nLinkNYC Boosts Local Businesses With Free Advertising\nBy Paul Stremple -\nJanuary 26, 2018 1\nFacebook\nTwitter\nPinterest\nWhatsApp\nLinkedin\nReddIt\nEmail\nPrint\nLocal business owners celebrate advertising on LinkNYC kiosks along the Graham Avenue BID (Via NYCDoITT)\nWILLIAMSBURG \xe2\x80\x93 LinkNYC kiosks have been popping up across the five boroughs for the last few years, replacing outdated phone booths with free calling and phone charging while showing big, glowing ads. Now, they\xe2\x80\x99re opening up that advertising space to local businesses\xe2\x80\x94for free.\nThe LinkLocal program launched last year as part of an effort to give a leg up to small businesses, said Kate Blumm, Assistant Commissioner for Communications at the NYC Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t have a strict code, but go on instinct,\xe2\x80\x9d said Blumm, describing\xc2\xa0which local businesses qualify for free ads. \xe2\x80\x9cMom and pop, new and longstanding independent businesses that don\xe2\x80\x99t have big advertising budgets.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBklyner reporting is supported by our subscribers and:\nBusinesses are able to fill out a short online questionnaire through City Bridge, Link\xe2\x80\x99s sponsoring partner, which asks the name of the company and what exactly they\xe2\x80\x99re advertising, before creating ads for the company.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s shockingly easy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Blumm. With advertisers like Poland Spring and Jet Blue able to purchase plenty of ad space on Link kiosks, Blumm said the purpose of the program is to make sure local businesses are as visible as possible.\nThe ads run on area Links for one month, said Blumm, but business have opportunities to sign up again through different local promotions.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt felt too good to be true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Betty Cooney, executive director of the Graham BID, which has 8 Link kiosks on its stretch of Graham Avenue in Williamsburg.\nAs far as the efficacy of the ads go? Time will tell.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re in a holding pattern,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cooney. It is often difficult to judge the response to online advertising,\xc2\xa0she added, since customers aren\xe2\x80\x99t walking in with physical flyers or coupons. \xe2\x80\x9cBut from what I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard, businesses feel they\xe2\x80\x99re getting a good return.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCooney said she finds the 9-foot tall glowing kiosks \xe2\x80\x9creassuring,\xe2\x80\x9d and said that their visibility in the evening, when everything is closed, makes pedestrians feel less alone. They remind her of the old red emergency boxes on street corners, she said. Link kiosks have a button that can be used to call 911 in an emergency.\nLast September, DNA Info reported that in North Brooklyn, LinkNYC kiosks were being used to arrange for drug sales, but on Graham Avenue, Cooney said that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been the case.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the BID managers meeting, some worried about abuse [of the kiosks],\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cBut that\xe2\x80\x99s the exception to the rule. The plusses outweigh the negatives.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLink kiosks aren\xe2\x80\x99t just for advertising businesses, though, said Blumm. 5% of their ad space is reserved for New York City PSAs, from emergency preparedness notes from the Office of Emergency Management to reminders to sign up for healthcare via the Get Covered New York campaign. New Yorkers can actually use the kiosks to sign up for healthcare right on the street, Blumm said.\nAdditionally, the kiosks advertise local interest: reminders about Community Board meetings and information about how to find polling places. In June, during Caribbean Heritage Month, one campaign raised awareness of the contributions made by Caribbean-Americans.\nNever miss the day\'s stories!\nLeave this field empty if you\'re human: This page is available to subscribers. \xd7\x94\xd7\xa7\xd7\xa8\xd7\x99\xd7\x90\xd7\x94 \xd7\xaa\xd7\xa4\xd7\xa8\xd7\x99\xd7\x98 \xd7\xa0\xd7\x92\xd7\x99\xd7\xa9\xd7\x95\xd7\xaa\xd7\xa0\xd7\x99\xd7\x95\xd7\x95\xd7\x98\xd7\xa9\xd7\xaa\xd7\xa4\xd7\x95 \xd7\x91\xd7\xa4\xd7\x99\xd7\x99\xd7\xa1\xd7\x91\xd7\x95\xd7\xa7 Urban Living\nFebruary 2, 2018\nby Joseph Darius Jaafari\nNationSwell Logotype\nMenu\nWatch\nDiscover\nxClose\nFocus Areas\nOpportunity Divide\nGovernance\nEnvironment\nMoving America Forward\nNational Service\nCouncil\nxClose\nNationSwell Council is a diverse community of accomplished professionals who are passionate about service.\nLearn more\nCouncil News\nJoin\nNominate\nSummit Talent (beta)\nSearch\nSearch for:\nWelcome to the Future of Urban Living\nShare\nFacebook\nTwitter\nSeattle has used data analysis to design its streets in a way that promotes walking, biking and riding public transportation.\nPhoto by Kenny Hung Photography/Getty Images\nSmart cities can make life better for residents, but with progress comes a new set of problems.\nWhat might a city look like in the future if a tech company had a say in it? How can cities harness all the data at their disposal \xe2\x80\x94 on things like traffic, crime, health and income \xe2\x80\x94 and use it to eliminate the most common woes of urban living? At its core, the goal of a smart city is to improve the quality of life for its residents, by providing them good jobs, a clean environment and safe, sustainable infrastructure.\nBut as cities race to implement technology that can respond to the needs of its citizens, concerns over things like privacy, ownership and the energy needed to power millions of data-collecting sensors have increased right along with it.\nEverything Is Connected\nThough the term \xe2\x80\x9csmart city\xe2\x80\x9d is relatively new, the concept of cities using data to inform policies isn\xe2\x80\x99t. More than a decade ago, for example, Seattle passed an\xc2\xa0ordinance that instructed its department of transportation to conduct a\xc2\xa0data analysis of city streets, taking into account traffic patterns, speed limits and collision history with the goal of encouraging residents to walk, bike and ride public transit more often.\nMore recently in 2015, the U.S. Department of Transportation launched the\xc2\xa0Smart City Challenge. A total of 78 mid-size cities responded, presenting ideas for revolutionizing their highways, roads and public-transit systems through the use of data, applications and other technology. (The winner: Columbus, Ohio.)\nBesides easing the burdens of city life for residents, technology plays a major role in keeping them safe, too, especially as America\xe2\x80\x99s infrastructure rating\xc2\xa0continues its steady decline across the board.\nIn September 2016, a team of engineers from Michigan State University and Washington University in St. Louis put self-monitoring\xc2\xa0stress sensors on the Mackinac Bridge \xe2\x80\x94 one of the longest suspension bridges in the U.S. \xe2\x80\x94 to log information on wear and tear, and send alerts when maintenance or repairs are needed.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese sensors are going to continuously monitor the health of the structure, and if something goes wrong, then it\xe2\x80\x99s going to report that to the cloud,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0said Shantanu Chakrabartty, one of the sensors\xe2\x80\x99 developers. \xe2\x80\x9cIf something happens, you can go back and see that a certain part of the structure experienced abnormal levels of strain, and then according to that, you can schedule your emergency response and your maintenance.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMichigan\xe2\x80\x99s Mackinac Bridge features self-monitoring sensors that measure wear and tear and increase safety.Photo by Jim Feng/Getty Images\nA New Model Emerges\nHalf the fun of envisioning a smart city isn\xe2\x80\x99t just the nifty gadgets that make roads more stable, water cleaner or traffic lighter. What\xe2\x80\x99s most exciting for many engineers and developers is the idea of making a city responsive to the people who live there.\nAn example is New York\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC program, which is replacing thousands of pay phones around the city with kiosks that provide free Wi-Fi, phone calls, device-charging stations and touchscreen tablets that connect residents and tourists to city services and maps.\nA more futuristic example is Sidewalk Toronto \xe2\x80\x94 a partnership between Sidewalk Labs, an Alphabet company, and Waterfront Toronto, a local organization charged with the revitalization of the city\xe2\x80\x99s waterfront. The goal: Design an entirely new neighborhood on the city\xe2\x80\x99s east side that will include sustainably built homes, roads designed for self-driving cars and green spaces that can adapt to how people act within them. (\xe2\x80\x9cNobody\xe2\x80\x99s using that bench? Let\xe2\x80\x99s try moving it to a sunnier area then.\xe2\x80\x9d) If a tech company took over urban planning, this is what it might look like.\nPrivate-Public Partnerships Put to the Test\nBut despite the competing interests of the private sector, which looks for ways to monetize its efforts, and the public sector, whose goal is to provide free services, there is the sense that tech companies will eventually be viewed as trustworthy gatekeepers of data \xe2\x80\x94 so long as they provide benefits to the city.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a change in outlook,\xe2\x80\x9d Roman Serdar Mendle, smart cities program manager at the International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives,\xc2\xa0said a brief. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the past, those concerned with sustainable cities saw the private sector as bad, and governments and NGOs as the ones that were fighting the good fight. Now companies are seen as the solutions providers.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAnd then there is the confusion about who actually owns the data being harvested: the outside companies hired to collect it through sensors and other means, or the local officials who rely on it to make their cities smarter.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re in the learning business, that is wholly true,\xe2\x80\x9d says Tracey Cook, executive director for \xc2\xa0Municipal Licensing & Standards for the City of Toronto. By regulating Uber, for example, the city was able to gather data on every single trip that occured, down to where people were getting picked up and dropped off, \xe2\x80\x9cwithin inches.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThat information could inform the city\xe2\x80\x99s future endeavors with Sidewalk Toronto, for example.\nAs cities become more reliant on the private sector to fill gaps that government can\xe2\x80\x99t, the way forward, it seems, is two-fold: Cities will continue to use the data it collects on its citizens with the goal of improving their lives, and then partner with for-profit companies to ease concerns on privacy.\nA New York City resident uses a LinkNYC kiosk to access free Wi-Fi, calling and other digital services.Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images\nThe Future Is (Almost) Imminent\nAt first blush, smart cities sound like the ultimate solution for bridging the opportunity divide by giving people in all neighborhoods equal access to technology, creating a sort of digital utopia. But a backlash is brewing, not only over reasons of privacy but also over resources. The more a city relies on the Internet of Things \xe2\x80\x94 an interconnected network of devices that communicate with each other \xe2\x80\x94 the more energy is needed to power said \xe2\x80\x9cthings.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCurrently, 7 percent of the world\xe2\x80\x99s internet is used by the information technology sector, with that percentage expected to triple within the next two years. Annual Bitcoin transactions, for example, consume as much energy as the entire country of Iraq, according to the Bitcoin Energy Index.\nAs more and more people flock to urban areas, a partnership between tech companies and the services people use every day in a city \xe2\x80\x94 be it public buses or green spaces \xe2\x80\x94 is warranted. But given the privacy and environmental concerns that have yet to be addressed, the full-on smart city still has its obstacles.\nShare\nFacebook\nTwitter\ndata-driven solution smart city smart infrastructure Sustainable Cities Technology\nComments\nGet the best of NationSwell in your inbox.\nYou Might Like\nMaking Government Work\nJuly 21, 2014\nThese Solar-Powered Roads Transmit Helpful Information onto Your Windshield\nMaking Government Work\nMarch 20, 2014\nHow an Innovative Parking Program May Cut Downtown Traffic by One Third\nMaking Government Work\nJune 23, 2014\nD.C., New York City and Boston Named Tops for Foot Traffic\nNationswell champions solutions to America\xe2\x80\x99s problems and supports the people making them happen\nHome\nStudio\nCouncil\nTeam\nCareers\nTerms of Service\nPrivacy Policy\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nCreated with Sketch.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nGet the best of NationSwell in your inbox.\nAll content copyright \xc2\xa92019 NationSwell. All rights reserved.', b"NBC Will Show Winter Olympics Content on 4,000 Outdoor Displays in 3 U.S. Cities \xe2\x80\x93 Adweek\nNEWSAgenciesBrand MarketingCreativityDigitalInside the BrandProgrammaticTV / VideoFEATUREDAd of the DayCannes LionsThe Creative 100Grad GuideOp-EdsPartner ExpertsSponsoredEVENTSFEATUREDNexTechJuly 24-25, 2019New York, NYCOMING SOONAdweek Abroad in CannesBrandweekProject IsaacConstellation AwardsView All EventsWEBINARSFEATUREDStop Client Churn In Its TracksThu., June 27, 2019\n1 PM ETCOMING SOONWhy Customer Privacy MattersAddress the Pain Points of TV AdvertisingView All WebinarsCONNECTMedia KitEditorial CalendarAgency MembershipsGroup SubscriptionsNewslettersContact UsADVERTISE WITH USBrand AwarenessThought LeadershipLead GenerationSponsoredPartner ExpertsADWEEK NETWORKAgencySpySocial Pro Daily\xe2\x80\x8bTVNewserTVSpyADWEEK JOBSFind a JobPost a JobCURRENT OFFERUnlimited Job Postings My Account Log Out Sign In Subscribe\nEmerging TechNBC Will Show Winter Olympics Content on 4,000 Outdoor Displays in 3 U.S. CitiesIntersection brings the games to New York, Chicago and PhiladelphiaBy Marty Swant|February 6, 2018\nA mock-up of a LinkNYC kiosk that will display Winter Olympics content. They will begin showing content on Thursday.IntersectionShareBy Marty Swant|February 6, 2018\nShareOlympics fans in New York, Chicago and Philadelphia will soon have a way to catch up with the 2018 Winter Olympics without looking down at their phones during their commute.Later this week, NBC Olympics will begin showcasing content from\xc2\xa0Pyeongchang, South Korea\xe2\x80\x94videos and visuals such as highlights, summaries, previews, medal counts and athlete bios\xe2\x80\x94on digital displays on streets and in mass transit systems in those three cities. Through a partnership with Intersection, a New York-based smart cities and media company, NBC hopes to broaden its Olympics footprint while reminding people to watch the games on TV or on NBC\xe2\x80\x99s mobile app.According to\xc2\xa0NBC Olympics President Gary Zenkel, the goal is to reach viewers beyond their usual consumption habits. Since there is a 14-hour time difference between the East Coast and South Korea, Zenkel said he hopes it will also provide ongoing content even though the games are half a world away. That means having highlights from the night before during the morning commute in the U.S. to show people what happened while they were still sleeping.\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a real-time presence of Olympic content that\xe2\x80\x99s accompanying people who are either heading to work or doing what they do as they maneuver the streets of New York, Philly and Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d he told Adweek during an interview from South Korea.Starting Thursday, around 4,000 digital displays will begin showing Olympics content for about three to six minutes every hour. The New York City monoliths stand 9.5 feet tall, and have 55-inch display screens. Zenkel said the goal is to increase the \xe2\x80\x9cappetite\xe2\x80\x9d for Olympics content.The idea came about a couple of months ago after Zenkel noticed the LinkNYC stands around New York. Soon after that, Zenkel ran into Intersection chief revenue officer Marta Martinez and decided to contact her later to learn more about the displays.\xe2\x80\x9cI saw these kiosks popping up on what felt like at least every city block and in some cases corners and was intrigued,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Zenkel said.This is the first major content play for Intersection, which has digital display partnerships with a number of major cities in the U.S. Screens can show all kinds of content, including ads like Apple\xe2\x80\x99s Shark Tank-style show, \xe2\x80\x9cPlanet of the Apps,\xe2\x80\x9d as well as offer free Wi-Fi. Other Intersection markets include Dallas, San Francisco, Seattle, Minneapolis and most recently Los Angeles.The Olympics content will be displayed across the 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks in New York; on digital panels and displays in the Chicago Transit Authority system; and on bus shelters, urban panels and other displays in Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s mass transit system and streets.\xe2\x80\x9cIt ties back to our core mission, which is to improve [the] daily life of cities through technology,\xe2\x80\x9d said Intersection CEO Ari Buchalter. \xe2\x80\x9cI think a big part of that is around delivering unique and powerful content experiences in the public space, in particular those that are sort of human-scale, look-up experiences as opposed to the content that people often consume on their mobile phones.\xe2\x80\x9dThe initial plan late last year was to find advertisers among NBC\xe2\x80\x99s existing content sponsors. However, Zenkel said the plan came together just before the games were set to begin, and the two companies decided not to exchange any money\xe2\x80\x94unless they\xe2\x80\x99re able to find an advertiser at the last minute.\xe2\x80\x9cThe Olympics is a uniquely massive event,\xe2\x80\x9d Zenkel said. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think anyone who walks down the street seeing some great Olympic content is going to say, \xe2\x80\x98Hmm, how did this end up here?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9dBuchalter said Intersection is also in talks to bring other types of content to public spaces. That might include news, social media, local info or cultural content. Buchalter said revenue agreements depend on each contract. However, the share with LinkNYC, a joint partnership with New York City, is split in half.\xe2\x80\x9cIf you only see an ad, then you eventually become blind to that space,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. America set to feature Australia and QatarJune 17 2019\n4Report: North Carolina FC up MLS bid with US$1.9bn stadium site plansJune 19 2019\n5Zion Williamson suing to end deal with marketing agencyJune 17 2019\nBrought to you by the\nNBC to deliver PyeongChang 2018 content to city commutersUS network to distribute Games coverage on urban screens and major transport networks.Posted: February 6 2018By: Michael Long\nUS broadcaster NBC Sports Group has announced that it will deliver exclusive content from the upcoming PyeongChang Winter Olympics to urban screens in\xc2\xa0three major cities and transport networks in the United States.NBC Olympics, the network\xe2\x80\x99s dedicated Olympics division, will work with Intersection, a smart cities technology and media company, to produce and distribute the specially created content, which\xc2\xa0will include morning highlights, primetime previews, athlete profiles, medal counts and real-time alerts.Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s network spans thousands of screens across the LinkNYC transport network in New York City; digital urban panels and platform displays in the Chicago Transit Authority; and digital bus shelters and other street displays in Philadelphia.\xe2\x80\x9cWhether walking the streets of New York, riding the Chicago L, or waiting in Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s 30th Street Station, Olympics fans in these three cities will be surrounded by the excitement of the Winter Games,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gary Zenkel, the president of NBC Olympics.\xe2\x80\x9cEmerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media.\xe2\x80\x9dNBC confirms live VR coverage for PyeongChang 2018The forthcoming Games in PyeongChang, South Korea begin this week -\xc2\xa0with the opening ceremony scheduled for Friday -\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0conclude on 25th February. NBC owns the rights to the event as part of a 12-year, US$7.65 billion deal that runs until 2032.Headquartered in Manhattan, New York, Intersection specialises in providing technology, connectivity infrastructure and content experiences to\xc2\xa0cities, public transport systems, airports and other real estate developments around the world.\xe2\x80\x9cOur content partnership reflects a new approach to storytelling in cities using one of the most inspiring and unifying global events,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ari Buchalter, the chief executive of Intersection.\xe2\x80\x9cWith thousands of digital screens across our cities and transit hubs, our partnership allows us to bring NBC\xe2\x80\x99s coverage of the Winter Games to fans in entirely new ways, and create unique content and advertising experiences for consumers.\xe2\x80\x9d\nPosted in: Media Rights, SmartSeries, Olympics, Paralympics, North America\nLatest News\nTop Story: Granada return to La Liga with Nike kit deal\nDivision 1 F\xc3\xa9minine finds first title sponsor in Arkema\nLyon creates production company to manage new music festival\nUSOC rebrands as US Olympic & Paralympic Committee\nDAZN app nets 950% year-on-year revenue growth\nNew Fiorentina owner targets stadium upgrade\nFIFA 19 esports series scores 61m total global views\nEurosport Events on board for World Touring Car Cup\xe2\x80\x99s electric series\nDignitas opens esports content production hub near Prudential Center\nReport: Ferrari, Ducati could axe Mission Winnow logos for remaining season\nRays to explore Tampa Bay and Montreal home game split\nF1 subsidy cuts could see Mexico GP scrapped after 2019\nLoad comments\nPlease enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.\nblog comments powered by
