By continuing to use this site, you are agreeing to the use of these cookies.Read our Privacy Policy.\nContinueContinue\n\xc3\x97', b'DailyDOOH\n\xc2\xbb Blog Archive\n\xc2\xbb Winter Olympics Content to be Featured Across New York City, Chicago and Philadelphia\n48\nBroadSign Digital Signage Software\nDailyDOOH\nDigital Out of Home \xe2\x80\x93 Insight, Knowledge, Opinion\n\xc2\xab Vector Media Acquires Direct Media USA\nWinter Olympics Content to be Featured Across New York City, Chicago and Philadelphia\nAdrian J Cotterill, Editor-in-Chief NBC Olympics, a division of the NBC Sports Group, has partnered with Intersection, a smart cities technology and media company, to feature exclusive PyeongChang Olympics content across thousands of digital screens in New York City, Chicago and Philadelphia during its production of the XXIII Olympic Winter Games, which take place in PyeongChang, South Korea, from February 8 \xe2\x80\x93 February 25.\nGary Zenkel, President, NBC Olympics said \xe2\x80\x9cWhether walking the streets of New York, riding the Chicago L, or waiting in Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s 30th Street Station, Olympics fans in these three cities will be surrounded by the excitement of the Winter Games. Emerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe custom content, specifically created for Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s urban network of digital screens, will keep people up-to-date on the PyeongChang Olympics beginning Feb. 9 and continuing until the conclusion of the Games on Feb. 25. The program will feature morning highlights, primetime previews, an Opening Ceremony teaser, medal counts, real-time alerts, athlete profiles and more, spanning thousands of screens across the LinkNYC network in New York City; digital urban panels and platform displays in the Chicago Transit Authority; and digital bus shelters, urban panels and platform displays throughout SEPTA, PATCO and the streets of Philadelphia.\nAri Buchalter, CEO of Intersection \xe2\x80\x9cOur content partnership reflects a new approach to storytelling in cities using one of the most inspiring and unifying global events,\xe2\x80\x9d said With thousands of digital screens across our cities and transit hubs, our partnership allows us to bring NBC\xe2\x80\x99s coverage of the Winter Games to fans in entirely new ways, and create unique content and advertising experiences for consumers.\xe2\x80\x9d\nPrint This Post\nTweet\nThis entry was posted\non Wednesday, February 7th, 2018 at 08:58 @415\nand is filed Every appropriate picture will likely be featured. of ServicePrivacy PolicyVisit our partner siteWATCH LIVENews 4 NY at 5The latest local news, weather and investigative stories impacting your community.New Yorkers Can Display Their Loved Ones on Thousands of Screens This Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s Day By\nSander SiegelPublished Feb 7, 2018 at 12:31 PM NEWSLETTERS Receive the latest local\nupdates in your inboxEmailPrivacy policy | More NewslettersPexelsWhat to KnowThis year, New Yorkers can submit photographs of their loved ones to be displayed on thousands of screens across the five boroughsLinkNYC, the city-wide project of Wi-Fi kiosks that replaced most payphones beginning in 2014, teamed up with NYC for the projectBy using the hashtag #LinkLoveNYC, New Yorkers can submit photos of their loved ones to be featured on LinkNYC kiosks across NYCThis Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s Day, New Yorkers will have a way to declare their love other than a fancy bouquet (but those are great, too, of course).This year, New Yorkers can submit photographs of their loved ones to be displayed on thousands of screens across the five boroughs.LinkNYC, the city-wide project of Wi-Fi kiosks that replaced most of the NYC\xe2\x80\x99s payphones beginning in 2014, has teamed up with the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) to promote the unique Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s Day present.By using the hashtag #LinkLoveNYC, New Yorkers can submit photos of their loved ones to be featured on LinkNYC kiosks from Riverdale to SoHo, and Flushing to FiDi.Top Tri-State News PhotosBeth Elwood\xe2\x80\x9cWe are thrilled to add this fun feature to Link kiosks across the five boroughs this Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s Day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne Roest, Commissioner of DoITT.Launched by Mayor de Blasio, the project has created a numbered 1,280 kiosks across NYC, with thousands more to set to be constructed over the next few years.Get the latest from NBC 4 New York anywhere, anytimeDownload the App\nAvailable for IOS and AndroidFollow NBC New York Leave Comments New York LiveNewsWeatherInvestigationsEntertainmentTrafficContact UsCommunityContestsConnect With UsWNBC Public Inspection city\nVegan Dominican food comes to the South Bronx\nHealth Pulse Extra\nSubscribe to Health Pulse\nHealth Pulse Pro Corporate Membership\nPhoto Galleries\nSNAPS\nSponsored Photo Galleries\nVideos\nMENU\nBreadcrumb\nHome\nTechnology\nFebruary 06, 2018 11:00 PM\nThe Winter Olympics is coming to LinkNYC\nMatthew Flamm\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nEmail\nMore\nPrint\nIntersection\nIn a first for the digital billboard industry, highlights from the Winter Olympics will appear on the more than 1,500 Wi-Fi hubs that are replacing pay phone kiosks citywide as part of the LinkNYC network.\nFrom Feb. 9 through the closing ceremony Feb. 25, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s digital screens will post morning highlights, prime-time previews, medal counts and athlete profiles from the games in Pyeongchang, South Korea, throughout the day.\nFor NBC, which has never distributed its Olympic programming via the out-of-home advertising space, the deal marks the latest effort to extend the games\xe2\x80\x99 reach across an increasingly fragmented audience. LinkNYC, meanwhile, gets to showcase new programming and collect data on how audiences on the street interact with the content.\nFrom there, LinkNYC can develop a more tailored pitch for advertisers that might range from the store right beside the kiosk to a national brand looking to do a citywide takeover.\nThe product of a public-private partnership, LinkNYC has an\xc2\xa0ad revenue-sharing arrangement\xc2\xa0with the city that requires it to deliver $500 million during the first 12 years of the agreement. The deal with NBC\xe2\x80\x99s Olympics division will also bring the customized content to digital networks in Chicago and Philadelphia operated by Intersection.\nAccording to Intersection CEO Ari Buchalter, there will be more programming partnerships of this kind.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re talking to a large number of folks that have unique and engaging content, whether that\xe2\x80\x99s news, entertainment, sports or local stories, so we can test and experiment [and see] what content people want to experience in that setting,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd then we can see what is the best way\xe2\x80\x9d for advertisers to sponsor the content people want to see and develop strategies related to it.\nNBC\xe2\x80\x99s programming also could reintroduce LinkNYC to New Yorkers who know of it chiefly as the Wi-Fi hub that, for a period in 2016, attracted users who watched pornography on its interactive tablet. The company solved that problem by disabling the tablet\xe2\x80\x99s web browser.\nRelated Articles\nHBO surpasses 5 million U.S. online subscribers\nPrince's former manager Londell McMillan explains Jay-Z's beef with him\nDolan, Garden keeping WNBA's Liberty for now\nUnlimited-movie deal could be too good to survive\nSale of Harvey Weinstein's company up in air after lawsuit\nFilm and TV parking workers vote to unionize\nA relaunch for Gothamist, but not for DNAinfo\nView the discussion thread.\nGet our newsletters\nStaying current is easy with Crain's New York news delivered straight to your inbox, free of charge\nEmail Address\nCrain's Student Offer\nWe offer a discounted rate through Student Beans for students with a valid .edu email address. coverage on LinkNYC kiosks\nGet morning highlights, medal counts, primetime previews, schedules, real-time alerts and more right from the more than 1,300 LinkNYCs across the city.\nBy Nikki M. Mascali\nPublished : February 07, 2018\nUpdated\n:\nFebruary 07, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nMore\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsapp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\n1/2\nNBC Olympics partnered with smart cities tech and media company Intersection to broadcast exclusive Olympic content across the more than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks across the city. (Provided)\n1/2\nNBC Olympics partnered with smart cities tech and media company Intersection to broadcast exclusive Olympic content across the more than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks across the city. (Provided)\n2/2\nAbove is NBC's primetime studio for the PyeongChang Games. (NBC Sports Group)\n2/2\nAbove is NBC's primetime studio for the PyeongChang Games. (NBC Sports Group)\nBack to top\n1/2\nNBC Olympics partnered with smart cities tech and media company Intersection to broadcast exclusive Olympic content across the more than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks across the city. (Provided)\n1/2\nNBC Olympics partnered with smart cities tech and media company Intersection to broadcast exclusive Olympic content across the more than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks across the city. (Provided)\n2/2\nAbove is NBC's primetime studio for the PyeongChang Games. (NBC Sports Group)\n2/2\nAbove is NBC's primetime studio for the PyeongChang Games. (NBC Sports Group)\nBack to top\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re worried about missing even a single minute of the upcoming PyeongChang Olympics, you\xe2\x80\x99ll only have to find the nearest LinkNYC kiosk to see the latest highlights.\nNBC Olympics, a division of NBC Sports Group, partnered with smart cities tech and media company Intersection to broadcast exclusive Olympic content on the more than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks across the city.\nNBC\xe2\x80\x99s digital-based content for the Olympic Winter Games, which take place in PyeongChang, South Korea, Feb. 9 through Feb. 25, will include morning highlights, medal counts, primetime previews, schedules, real-time alerts and more.\nRecommended Slideshows\n40 PicturesPHOTOS: Blues dump Bruins to win Stanley Cup after agonizing 52-year wait40 Pictures\n8 PicturesPHOTOS: This Pakistani waiter looks just like Peter Dinklage8 Pictures\n36 PicturesAll of these celebrities have had their nudes leaked36 PicturesMore picture galleries\n16 PicturesThese photos of Trump and Ivanka will make you deeply uncomfortable\n16 Pictures\n4 PicturesCuba Gooding Jr. charged in Manhattan groping incident, police say4 Pictures\n2 Pictures4 fun things to do in the Lehigh Valley2 Pictures\nThe Olympics coverage isn\xe2\x80\x99t just relegated to New York City, though. Chicago residents will be able to see the content on digital urban panels and platform displays in the Chicago Transit Authority, and Philadelphians can see it on digital bus shelters, urban panels and platform displays throughout SEPTA, PATCO and city streets.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether walking the streets of New York, riding the Chicago L or waiting in Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s 30th Street Station, Olympics fans in these three cities will be surrounded by the excitement of the Winter Games,\xe2\x80\x9d Gary Zenkel, president of NBC Olympics, said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cEmerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWe're thrilled to partner with @NBCOlympics to bring the Winter Olympics to Chicago, Philadelphia, and New York City! Info\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nGet Tickets\nSee All Places\nNearby Places\nCentral Park, NY\nUpper West Side, NY\nUpper East Side, NY\nMidtown Manhattan, NY\nHarlem, NY\nAstoria-Long Island City, NY\nChelsea, NY\nGramercy-Murray Hill, NY\nWest Village, NY\nEast Village, NY\nState Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\nsports\nWatch 2018 Winter Olympics On NYC Streets\nLinkNYC kiosks will broadcast highlights, athlete profiles and other features from the PyongChang games.\nBy Noah Manskar, Patch Staff\nFeb 7, 2018 5:45 pm ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nNEW YORK, NY \xe2\x80\x94 Why watch the 2018 Winter Olympics indoors when you can see them outside, in the actual winter? The city\'s LinkNYC kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 known for providing free WiFi and, previously, unsavory entertainment \xe2\x80\x94 will screen videos fresh from the games in PyeongChang, South Korea, which start Friday. NBC Olympics and Intersection, a technology and media company, will broadcast a special package of Olympics-themed features to New York\'s more than 1,200 Link screens, as well as displays in Chicago and Philadelphia. The kiosks will show highlights from the games each morning, previews of events during primetime, athlete profiles, medal counts and other videos showcasing the world\'s favorite winter sports.\nThe goal is to get some of America\'s urbanites to watch the Olympics in "entirely new ways," said Intersection\'s CEO, Ari Buchalter. That means New Yorkers could catch up on curling while walking to the subway or learn about your favorite bobsledder while getting a bagel. "Emerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media," Gary Zenkel, the president of NBC Olympics, said in a statement.\nEighteen athletes from New York State will be part of the U.S. team at this year\'s Olympics. Coincidentally, the LinkNYC kiosks will be plastered with cute couple photos on Valentine\'s Day, about five days after the opening ceremonies. (Lead image: Moguls skier Joon Seo Myung of South Korea in action during training session ahead of the PyeongChang 2018 Winter Olympic Games on Feb. 7, in Pyeongchang-gun, South Korea. Photo by David Ramos/Getty Images)Subscribe\nBack to the New York City Patch\nMore from New York CityUp next on New York City Patch\nLegal E-Bikes Won\'t Be Allowed In NYC Bike Lanes, De Blasio Says 3h\nLandfill Art: Sanitation Worker Displays Items Plucked From Trash 4h\nThis Dream Pillow Makes Bedtime Fun For Kids 4d\nRead more local news from New York City\nWhat are Featured Events?\nFeatured Events are paid listings by users and receive priority placement on Patch, on our social pages and in our daily newsletters. The program will feature morning highlights, primetime previews, an opening ceremony teaser, medal counts, real-time alerts, athlete profiles and more, spanning thousands of screens across the LinkNYC network in New York City. The screens include digital urban panels and platform displays in the Chicago Transit Authority; and digital bus shelters, urban panels and platform displays throughout SEPTA, PATCO and the streets of Philadelphia.\xc2\xa0"Whether walking the streets of New York, riding the Chicago L, or waiting in Philadelphia\'s 30th Street Station, Olympics fans in these three cities will be surrounded by the excitement of the Winter Games,\xe2\x80\x9d Gary Zenkel, president of NBC Olympics, said in the press release. "Emerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media.""Our content partnership reflects a new approach to storytelling in cities using one of the most inspiring and unifying global events,"\xc2\xa0said Ari Buchalter, CEO of Intersection. "With thousands of digital screens across our cities and transit hubs, our partnership allows us to bring NBC\'s coverage of the winter games to fans in entirely new ways, and create unique content and advertising experiences for consumers."Topics: Interactive / Touchscreen, Outdoor KiosksCompanies: IntersectionSponsored Links:Related ContentKiosk Marketplace editor reviews 39 kiosk companies at National Restaurant ShowTaco Bell to install self-order kiosks in all stores in 2019 under its All Access initiativeSquare integration with Kiosk Pro app enables self-service for iPadsTaco Bell, Bell Canada Smart City Kiosks grab Elevate AwardsLatest ContentState-of-the-art testing: the first line of defense against fraudstersTexas Dairy Queen franchisee pioneers self-order kioskCashierless stores? Your keyword is highlighted, other text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.\nCopyright \xc2\xa91999 - 2019\nTVEyes, Inc.\nAll rights reserved.\nQuestions, comments, or suggestions? Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b'NBC to stream Olympics coverage on digital screens in 3 cities\n| Smart Cities Dive\nCONTINUE TO SITE \xe2\x9e\x9e\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nEnergy & Utilities\nTransportation\nBuildings & Infrastructure\nEnvironment\nResilience\nGovernance\nTech & Data\nAn article from\nBrief\nNBC to stream Olympics coverage on digital screens in 3 cities\nAuthor\nBy\nKristin Musulin\n@kristinmusulin\nPublished\nFeb. 8, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nDive Brief:\nNBC Olympics has partnered with Intersection to develop custom content from the XXIII Olympic Winter Games and display it across Intersection\'s urban network of digital screens in New York City, Chicago and Philadelphia, according to an emailed press statement.\nThe content will include morning highlights, primetime previews, an Opening Ceremony teaser, medal counts, real-time alerts and athlete profiles. It will be streamed across the LinkNYC network in New York; digital urban panels and platform displays in Chicago; and displays on streets and transit platforms in Philadelphia.\nThe events, which take place this year in PyeongChang, South Korea, begin on Feb. 9 and conclude on Feb. 25.\nDive Insight:\nIntersection, a company that prides itself on "delivering connectivity, information and content that elevate the urban experience," made a splash in the smart cities world when it partnered with Qualcomm and CIVIQ Smartscapes to roll-out the LinkNYC network in 2016. The kiosks offer a variety of services including high-speed Wi-Fi, device charging and a touch screen tablet for access to maps and direction, and their popularity in the city sparked the company\'s spin-off collaborations with Philadelphia, Seattle and the U.K.\nKey Features\nFree Wi-Fi\nEvery Link is equipped with free, gigabit Wi-Fi, allowing access to high-speed services - about 100 times faster than basic public Wi-Fi.\nDirections\nA touch screen tablet allows users to access city services and maps, and provides step-by-step directions to destinations or cross streets.\nFree Calls\nThe touch screen tablet is equipped with a microphone, tactile keypad and Vonage app, allowing users to make free calls anywhere in the U.S.\nEmergency Calls\nA red button below the tablet allows users to instantly connect with 911 in the case of an emergency.\nUSB Ports\nTwo USB ports, connected directly to power sources, allow users to charge devices without the risk of data exchange with the kiosk.\nAd Space\nEach Link has two 55" high-def digital screens, allowing for public service announcement and advertising opportunities.\nUntil now, the digital screens that hug the sides of the 10-foot kiosks were mainly used for advertising purposes, or in some cases, to show historic photos from the city\'s digital archives. With the NBC partnership, Intersection is unlocking the full potential of its kiosks and digital platforms by truly bridging a digital divide and allowing folks who may not have cable access to indulge in the worldwide events. "Our content partnership reflects a new approach to storytelling in cities," said Ari Buchalter, CEO of Intersection, in a press statement.\nIf the 17-day custom content coverage is deemed successful, Intersection will likely be approached by other networks that wish to leverage the opportunity to expose their content to a more inclusive audience. The "digital storytelling" concept could be expanded to other companies\' or cities\' digital screens as well, including subway kiosks and billboards.\nRecommended Reading:\nDigital Signage Connection\nNBC Olympics Partners with Intersection to Deliver Custom Content of the Pyeongchang Olympic Winter Games\nAdWeek\nNBC Will Show Winter Olympics Content on 4,000 Outdoor Displays in 3 U.S. Cities\nFollow\nKristin Musulin\non\nTwitter\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nTech & Data\nTop image credit:\nWikimedia Commons\nGet the Newsletter\nSubscribe to Smart Cities Dive to get the must-read news & insights in your inbox.\nEmail:\nSmart Cities Dive\nTopics covered: energy, green building, transportation, waste solutions, connectivity, policy and more.\nDaily\nSign up\nA valid email address is required.\nPlease select at least one newsletter.\nBy signing up you agree to our privacy policy. You can opt out anytime.', b'Cheddar afternoon business report for Feb. 8, 2018\nHomeCreate AccountLog InGoHomeWeatherTop StoriesPower & PoliticsNumbers & LinksNews 12 Talks New Jersey podcastFeaturesSportsHealth MattersNews 12 VarsitySports ScoresEducation MattersU.S. & World NewsBusinessEntertainment Cheddar Business UpdateLotterySend Us PhotosTrafficCrimeFood & FunRoad Trip: Vote on the Top 12 places to visit in New JerseyNew Jersey Birthday SmilesVideos\nCheddar afternoon business report for Feb. 8, 2018\nPosted:\nThursday, February 8, 2018 3:35 PM EST\nUpdated:\nThursday, February 15, 2018 3:35 PM EST\nNEW YORK -\nTwitter reported its first-ever profit on Thursday morning.The social media platform brought in $732 million in revenues, nearly $50 million more than expected. Monthly active users did fall short of expectations, though, coming in 2 million less than estimated at about 330 million.The Winter Olympics are finally here. NBC will have 1,800 hours of event coverage over the next two weeks, but unlike the Super Bowl, NBC is not giving it away for free. If you have cable, you can stream all the events on NBC\'s sports app. But if you\'re a cord-cutter, NBC has partnered with tech company Intersection and will provide Olympic highlights on platform displays, LinkNYC Wi-Fi networks and other transit hubs across New York City, Chicago and Philadelphia.Amazon will start delivering Whole Foods on its fastest service, Prime Now. Shoppers in four cities -- Austin, Dallas, Virginia Beach and Cincinnati -- will be able to get their groceries within two hours of purchase. Amazon purchased Whole Foods last June, but this is the first time the brick-and-mortar store and e-commerce giant are merging operations.\nCan\'t Find Something?GoHomeWeatherTop StoriesTrafficCrimeFood & FunVideos\nAll content \xc2\xa9 Copyright 2000 - 2018 Frankly Media and . All Rights Reserved. Technical.ly Brooklyn\nCommunitiesBrooklynBaltimoreDCDelawarePhillyAll CitiesChoose your topicBusinessDevAccessMediaCivicSciencesCreativeFor EmployersCommunitiesPost a JobBecome a Talent ProAdvertiseMore InformationAbout Technical.lySubscribeOur ImpactBecome a MemberEthics\nBrooklynBaltimoreDCDelawarePhillyAll Cities\nNews\nJobs\nEvents\nLogin For EmployersJobsCompaniesEventsNews\nCivicFeb. 9, 2018 11:46 amIn Park Slope they\xe2\x80\x99ve turned the LinkNYC kiosks into bus countdown clocks Councilman Brad Lander saw a good opportunity to use the existing kiosks for an additional use.In Park Slope they\xe2\x80\x99ve turned the LinkNYC kiosks into bus countdown clocks\nBy Tyler Woods\xc2\xa0/ contributor Join 30,000+ readers who receive daily email updates from Technical.ly\nAdvertisement TOP ARTICLES A LinkNYC kiosk in Park Slope where you can check when the next bus comes.(Photo via Twitter/@bradlander)Could the WiFi kiosks that continue to dot the city double as bus countdown clocks?Down in Park Slope a trial is underway to do just that, led by City Councilman Brad Lander.\xe2\x80\x9cThe Links [LinkNYC kiosks] came to Park Slope over the last year and so many of them are located close to bus stops and they have all kinds of fun facts,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0the councilman said by phone Thursday.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cA lightbulb came on: Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it be a great idea if they had a bus countdown?\xe2\x80\x9dThanks @LinkNYC for acting on my suggestion to use Link kiosks as bus-countdown clocks \xe2\x80\xa6 and piloting it in our district. B63-riders, did you see/try this? Any feedback? We\xe2\x80\x99re working w/ @LinkNYC & @NYCDoITT @NYC_DOT @MTA to make it easier, more useful & eventually citywide. pic.twitter.com/ruJEepdiYC\xe2\x80\x94 Brad Lander (@bradlander) February 7, 2018So\xc2\xa0Lander, who represents Park Slope, Gowanus, Carroll Gardens and Borough Park, said his office has been working with\xc2\xa0Department of Transportation and the Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications. Along the B63 bus route in Park Slope, bus riders can head to the kiosks and check when the next bus is due to arrive. Lander said the feature has been added to about 20 kiosks along the route on 5th Avenue.Lander said he\xe2\x80\x99s been trying to get bus countdown clocks installed in Park Slope for the last five years, but that it\xe2\x80\x99s a complicated and expensive process, with the price for each countdown clock at about $35,000. The LinkNYC kiosks seemed like they could be a quick fix for getting that functionality.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve gotten decent feedback,\xe2\x80\x9d Lander said. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope we could get to the point where nearly all Links that are close to buses or to the subway could act as countdown clocks.\xe2\x80\x9d AdvertisementFor now, the countdowns are only visible on the console of the kiosks. Lander would like to see countdowns displayed periodically on the side of the kiosks, available for all to see. He\xe2\x80\x99s working on that.\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a million logistical reason why it isn\xe2\x80\x99t as easy as it would seem,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained.\n-30-\nJOIN THE COMMUNITY, BECOME A MEMBER\nAlready a member? Get self-driving cars off the road now\nCivicBrooklyn councilman proposes law banning after-work emailing\nSPONSOREDBrooklynExplore how diverse teams build dynamic products with Dev Bootcamp\nSign-up for daily news updates from Technical.ly Brooklyn\nCitiesNetworkPhillyBaltimoreBrooklynDelawareWashington D.C.TopicsBusinessAccessCivicCreativeDevMediaSciencesServicesFind JobsSearch DirectoryBrandAbout Technical.lyAdvertisingEthicsContactWrite for UsEditorial Calendar Published by\nV. 3.4.0 February 10, 2019 \xc2\xa0 / \xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa9 2019 Technically Media Inc. \xc2\xa0All Rights Reserved.\nDo NOT follow this link or you will be banned from the site!", b"New Web Portal NYCHOPE Offers Resources for Domestic Violence Survivors | BK Reader\nNeighborhoodsBedford StuyvesantBrownsvilleBushwickCrown HeightsEast New YorkFlatbushFort Greene / Clinton HillProspect HeightsNewsArts & EntertainmentBusiness & InnovationHealth & WellnessLifestyle & CultureNon-Profit & CommunityPolicy & GovernmentFeaturesBlack History MonthCommunity HealthGentrification in BrooklynLocal VoicesAboutAbout UsOur TeamAdvertise with UsWrite For UsContact\nNo Result\nView All Result\nNeighborhoodsBedford StuyvesantBrownsvilleBushwickCrown HeightsEast New YorkFlatbushFort Greene / Clinton HillProspect HeightsNewsArts & EntertainmentBusiness & InnovationHealth & WellnessLifestyle & CultureNon-Profit & CommunityPolicy & GovernmentFeaturesBlack History MonthCommunity HealthGentrification in BrooklynLocal VoicesAboutAbout UsOur TeamAdvertise with UsWrite For UsContact\nNo Result\nView All Result\nNo Result\nView All Result New Web Portal NYCHOPE Offers Resources for Domestic Violence Survivors\nby\nAndrea Leonhardt February 9, 2018 in\nCommunity Health Page, Community Health Slideshow, Featured News, Health & Wellness, Latest News, Policy & Government\nPhoto credit: NYC.gov Share on FacebookShare on Twitter\nNYCHOPE offers a directory of local services; information about signs of abuse; and a guide about how to help a person experiencing abuse \xe2\x80\x93 easily and safely accessible from any smartphone, tablet or computer.Photo credit: NYC.govAccording to the CDC, one in four women and one in seven men will experience severe physical violence by an intimate partner in their lifetime. And: Annually, more than 80,000 phone calls are placed to the NYC domestic violence hotline, according to officials.In an effort to combat and shed light on the issue of domestic violence, First Lady Chirlane McCray announced on Thursday the launch of NYCHOPE, a web portal that provides resources and information to survivors, and tips for others who want to help someone experiencing domestic violence.\xc2\xa0Its launch is also accompanied by a domestic violence awareness campaign \xe2\x80\x93 \xe2\x80\x9cWe Understand\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 developed with advocates and survivors to speak to the complexities of abuse, as well as the availability of support and services in NYC.\xe2\x80\x9cIt is time to stop asking survivors of domestic violence why they stay and start asking what more can we do to support them and their families,\xe2\x80\x9d said McCray, co-chair of the Domestic Violence Task Force. \xe2\x80\x9cThe innovative NYCHOPE portal and \xe2\x80\x98We Understand\xe2\x80\x99 ad campaign will help educate New Yorkers about the complexities of intimate partner violence and make it easier for survivors to access the services they need for safety and heal from trauma.\xe2\x80\x9dThe ad new campaign \xe2\x80\x9cWe Understand\xe2\x80\x9d aims to connect survivors and their loved ones to the web portal NYCHOPE, a centralized information and service hub that allows survivors to access information and services from any computer, smartphone or tablet. \xe2\x80\x9cWe Understand\xe2\x80\x9d includes ads and promotional spots which will run for 12 weeks through the first week of April 2018. Ads will be displayed in bus shelters, subways, the Staten Island Ferry and on social media platforms; promotional spots will run on 103.5 KTU FM and Power 105.1 FM, as well as on LinkNYC kiosks across the city.NYCHOPE offers features such as a resource directory of local services; information about signs of abuse; and a guide about how to help a person experiencing abuse. The portal includes tech safety tips and a quick-escape feature for users to ensure their safety while accessing the platform. NYCHOPE also provides information about the city\xe2\x80\x99s five Family Justice Centers, which serve as one-stop service centers for victims of domestic violence, elder abuse and sex trafficking, and connect them to services in their language, regardless of immigration status, income, sex, gender identity or sexual orientation.The web portal was designed and developed by the NYC Department of Information Technology and Telecommunication (DoITT) and students at Cornell Tech. During the 2016-2017 school year, the students interviewed over 100 domestic violence survivors to assess how technology can support their needs for information and access to resources.\xe2\x80\x9cI encourage victims of domestic violence to take advantage of the assistance available from city and state agencies,\xe2\x80\x9d said State Senator Roxanne Persaud. \xe2\x80\x9cSurvivors need to be encouraged to seek help, and offered information and support as they endeavor to disengage themselves from this vicious cycle of domestic abuse.\xe2\x80\x9dFor information, support and help, New Yorkers can also contact the city\xe2\x80\x99s Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-621-HOPE, which is available 24/7 and provides safety planning, referrals, and connections to emergency housing for victims of domestic violence.Tags: bk reader ShareTweetSend\nDid you enjoy this story? Here are the weirdest, most interesting events Manhattan has to offer.\nBy Ciara McCarthy, Patch Staff\nFeb 10, 2018 7:00 am ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nTRIBECA, NY \xe2\x80\x94 No matter what you\'re looking for this weekend, Manhattan has something to offer, from Winter Olympics screenings to a Justin Timberlake pop-up shop to New York Fashion Week.Here\'s Patch\'s guide to the most interesting events, exhibits and things to do in the city.New York Fashion WeekWhen: Feb. 8-14Where: Various locations in ManhattanWhat: The newest designs from the country\'s most high-profile designers will descend on New York for a week of catwalks and intimidating fashion. If NYFW feels a little out of your league, Patch broke down the best and most interesting looks here. You can find the full lineup of designers and shows here.Visit Justin Timberlake\'s Pop-Up ShopWhen: Feb. 9-11Where: 138 Wooster St., SohoWhat: Justin Timberlake is opening an NYC pop-up shop on Friday fresh off his Super Bowl performance. The pop-up shop will feature merchandise that accompanies Timberlake\'s newest album "Man of the Woods," which also inspired the pop star\'s camo-and-bandana ensemble at the Super Bowl on Sunday. Timberlake posted on Instagram that the pop-up shop would be open Friday through Sunday with an item to match every song on the album. Photos of the merch that Timberlake has posted on Instagram include sunglasses, jackets and a Moleskine notebook made specially for the album. You can read more here.Watch the 2018 Winter OlympicsWhen: Feb. 9-25Where: LinkNYC kiosks throughout New York CityWhat: The Winter Games are being screened straight from PyeongChang, South Korea on LinkNYC kiosks throughout the city. The kiosks will include a special package of highlights from the games each morning, plus athlete profiles, medal count updates, and more. You can find all the details here.Tell Me: Women Filmmakers, Women\'s StoriesWhen: Feb. 2 - 11Where: The Metrograph movie theater, 7 Ludlow St.\nWhat: The Metrograph is launching a film festival that focuses exclusively on female filmmakers and women\'s stories. The indie film theater will be screening dozens of films throughout over 10 days, focusing on varying aspects of the female experience. You can see the full lineup of films here.Image credit: Slaven Vlasic/Getty Images. Image caption: Models walk the runway for PRISCAVera during New York Fashion Week presented by Made at Gallery II at Spring Studios on February 9, 2018 in New York City. Park-Flatbush, NY\nBrooklyn Heights-DUMBO, NY\nBed-Stuy, NY\nSunset Park, NY\nState Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\ntraffic & transit\nBus Countdown Clocks Added To LinkNYC Kiosks In Park Slope\nInformation on when the B63 would arrive was added to LinkNYC kiosks around Park Slope, Councilman Brad Lander announced.\nBy Nicholas Rizzi, Patch Staff\nFeb 12, 2018 4:17 pm ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nPARK SLOPE, NY \xe2\x80\x94 Residents can now find out when their bus will arrive using LinkNYC\'s internet kiosks around Park Slope under a new pilot program by the city, Councilman Brad Lander announced. Real-time countdown clocks of buses were added to to the public Wi-Fi hubs along the B63 route in the neighborhood with plans to extend it to all LinkNYC spots around the city if successful, Lander announced on Twitter. As part of the pilot, nearly 20 LinkNYC hubs on Fifth Avenue had the bus information added to them last week, Technica.ly reported. Spokespeople for LinkNYC and Lander did not respond to a request for comment on this article. Lander previously called on the city to add the data to LinkNYC in September as a way to increase the coverage of bus countdown clocks around Park Slope without costing the city money. "Many places the Links are currently are nearby or on the same block or in a location that\'s on the way \xe2\x80\x94 that\'s very convenient to bus riders," Lander previously told Patch.\n"Surely, when the next bus is coming is as valuable to New Yorkers as when the next community board meeting is. I hope Link will work with New York City to make this happen."\nThe LinkNYC replaced pay phones in every borough in the city to offer free Wi-Fi, USB charging, phone calls and a large tablet with maps and directions. The devices originally had the ability to browse the web but it was disabled in 2016 after residents complained people watched porn on them. Image: Spencer Platt/Getty ImagesSubscribe\nBack to the Park Slope Patch\nMore from Park SlopeUp next on Park Slope Patch\nNYC Weather Forecast: Sunny Weekend Ahead 8h\nIron Chef Morimoto\'s Ramen Might Be Coming To Park Slope 1d\nThis Dream Pillow Makes Bedtime Fun For Kids 4d\nRead more local news from Park Slope\nWhat are Featured Events?\nFeatured Events are paid listings by users and receive priority placement on Patch, on our social pages and in our daily newsletters. You\'re now signed up for local updates.\nDaily Newsletter The latest Park Slope news delivered to your inbox every morning.\nBreaking News Alerts Real-time updates on breaking stories in Park Slope.\nLet\'s go!\nNot in Park Slope?', b'Creative IT Leaders Make Citywide Wi-Fi an Affordable Reality | StateTech Magazine\nSkip to main content\nBecome a StateTech Insider\nSign up today to receive premium content!\nSign Up\nMENU\nLog in\nMobile menu\nTopics\nStates\nTips & Tactics\nVoices\nFeatures\nVideo\nIT Blogs\nMore\nNews\nEvents\nWhite Papers\nMust Read IT Blogs\nCITizen\nSmart Cities\nAbout Insider\nSearch\nSearch\nMain menu\nTopics\nStates\nTips & Tactics\nVoices\nFeatures\nVideo\nIT Blogs\nMore\nNews\nEvents\nWhite Papers\nMust Read IT Blogs\nCITizen\nSmart Cities\nAbout Insider\nSearch\nEnergy & Utilities\nEnterprise\nFinancial Services\nLegal\nManufacturing\nNonprofit\nRetail\nSmall Business\nSports & Entertainment\nStartups\nTrending Now\nEnterprise\nWhat Is IoT\xe2\x80\x99s New Security Threat? It\xe2\x80\x99s Called Hajime.\nBusiness Intelligence\nCloud\nData Center\nDigital Workspace\nHardware\nInternet\nManagement\nNetworking\nSecurity\nSoftware\nTrending Now\nPublic Safety\nDispatch Centers Upgrade 911 Systems in the Face of Cyberthreats\nCloud\n3 Benefits of Effective Government Cloud Management\nNetworking\nSmart Cities 3.0: 5G, Edge Computing and Citizen Engagement\n30 Must-Read State and Local IT Blogs 2018\nOct 31 2018\nFollow these blogs to stay current on the latest news and trends for state government, smart cities, first responders, public libraries, courts and more.\nStateTech Magazine\nCurrent Issue | Archive\nStateTech E-Newsletter\nCurrent Issue | Archive\nTwitter\nfeed\nHome\xc2\xbbInternet\nInternet\nCreative IT Leaders Make Citywide Wi-Fi an Affordable Reality\nNew York, Philadelphia and Portland take advantage of existing infrastructure to close the digital divide for all residents.\nby\nHouston Thomas III\nIn his role as Senior Business Development Strategist and Public Safety Senior Strategist, Houston Thomas III manages the architect and engineering process for large-scale integration projects involving public safety agencies. He provides subject matter expertise to CDW\xe2\x80\xa2G law enforcement customers with respect to digital intelligence and evidence management.\nWi-Fi and broadband internet access are integral to being an active and engaged citizen in today\'s world. Often, however, municipal internet projects are deployed in downtowns or affluent city centers while less economically developed areas are left behind, furthering the digital divide and isolating the advantages of technology to small sections of a city.\nTo close this gap, several cities have launched projects aimed at offering free, secure Wi-Fi across all regions of their city.\nSan Francisco announced in October its plans to offer residents 1-gigabit connections as part of a citywide $1.5 billion project.\n"Bridging the digital divide is right for our residents and right for the future of our city," San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee said in a statement to SFGate.\nSIGN UP: Get more news from the StateTech newsletter in your inbox every two weeks!\nNew York Swaps Phone Booths with Hotspots\nBut not all cities can afford to build out Wi-Fi across the city from the ground up. For this reason, many cities are thinking creatively and launching projects that take advantage of upgrades to existing citywide infrastructure to outfit all areas of a region with Wi-Fi availability.\nIn New York City, officials took advantage of a project to remove outdated phone booths and replaced them with more than 900 Wi-Fi kiosks throughout the city. Each kiosk is outfitted with tablets, charging ports and displays with relevant information for residents alongside a Wi-Fi connection that residents, tourists and passersby can access.\nIt wasn\'t a breeze to get the project off the ground, however, Jeff Merritt, former director of innovation for the city, said at the 2017 Smart Cities Week conference.\n"When we came into office this project was dead," said Merritt. "Folks wanted to get rid of street clutter. Pay phones were an eyesore. There was an adverse reaction to the idea of putting digital advertisement on city streets. I think that we did the hard work of recognizing the opportunity that exists there."\nMerritt and his team moved quickly to get contracts in place that would replace the outdated infrastructure with strategically advantageous Wi-Fi kiosks and ended up with "something that far exceeded anything we could have ever come up with on our own," said Merritt. Now, the city plans to implement more than 7,500 kiosks as part of the project, but officials aren\'t being na\xc3\xafve about the need to update the newest infrastructure to meet future needs.\n"It requires us to think differently about hardware and infrastructure and think about it in a way that is modular and flexible," said Merritt. "We recognize that many of the components of LinkNYC will be outdated in a very short amount of time so the [kiosks] are built in a way that the actual individual module \xe2\x80\xa6 can easily be swapped in and out."\nPortland Upgrades Lamp Posts for Wi-Fi Access\nLamp posts aren\'t just for light anymore, at least not in Portland, Maine. In a bid to upgrade the city\'s lighting infrastructure, roll out connected technologies and, ultimately, save taxpayer dollars, the city council approved an $8.5 million project to revamp its streetlights downtown with LED lighting, Wi-Fi and other technologies. The move will ultimately generate $1 million in cost avoidance annually, the Portland Press Herald reports.\n"The bottom line here is there is literally nothing but upside to what is being proposed here," city councilor Justin Costa told the Herald.\nPhiladelphia Capitalizes on Failed Wi-Fi Projects\nCurrently ranked as America\'s poorest big city, Philadelphia officials believe that smart city projects, including a citywide Wi-Fi deployment, will be able to move the needle on its poverty rate by improving digital citizenship and opening the door to greater opportunity.\nIn order to make citywide Wi-Fi possible, officials are making use of existing human and technological infrastructure from a failed Wi-Fi project as a stepping stone to the new deployment.\n"It\'s a failed initiative by any standard, but some things came out of it that are pretty interesting," Andrew Buss, the deputy CIO for innovation management within Philadelphia\'s Office of Innovation and Technology, said at an event earlier this year. "Because everyone was so in to Wireless Philadelphia for that period of time, what ends up happening is we created all these really active communities around the topic of broadband \xe2\x80\x94 very committed people, community organizations, individuals, people who are excited about the issue."\nWireless Philadelphia was launched in 2004 and abandoned in 2008 when Earthlink dropped the project and it became clear that the underlying technology to achieve citywide goals simply weren\'t mature enough yet.\n"Wireless Philadelphia, in a way, was ahead of its time. The technology issues were not worked out," Buss said. "The technology changed faster than the city could implement the program, frankly, and that was a big challenge."\nWith new technology available, however, the new network should have no trouble keeping up.\nThis article is part of StateTech\'s CITizen blog series. Please join the discussion on Twitter by using the #StateLocalIT hashtag.\ntawanlubfah/Getty Images\nMore On\nDigital Citizenship\nInvestment\nIT Governance\nWi-Fi\nRelated Articles\nInternet\n3 Tips to Configure State Services for Accessibility Compliance\nInternet\nWhich States Receive Top Marks for the Best Websites?\nInternet\nChattanooga\'s Broadband Investment Opens the Door to Telehealth\nFeb\n13\n2018\nSponsors\nLatest Articles\nSmart Cities Council Winners Ready for the Future\nLos Angeles Wants Tech to Liberate Police Officers from Administration\nGeorgia Telemedicine Initiative Bolsters Health in Rural Areas\nHow State and Local Agencies Can Turn to Self-Scanning Tools for Cybersecurity\nNetworking\nRisk vs. Reward with Internet of Things Deployments\nData Center\nDisaster-Ready State and City IT Systems Weather the Storm\nAdvertisement\nTrending Now\nDispatch Centers Upgrade 911 Systems in the Face of Cyberthreats\n3 Benefits of Effective Government Cloud Management\nSmart Cities 3.0: 5G, Edge Computing and Citizen Engagement\nHow to Help Your Local Agency Block Malware That Can Cause Data Breaches\nRegister\nStateTech\nTechnology Solutions That Drive Government\nAbout Us\nContact Us\nPrivacy\nTerms & Conditions\nSite Map\nStateTech:\nCDW:\nVisit Some Of Our Other Technology Websites:\nBizTech\nEdTech\nFedTech\nHealthTech\nExperts Who Get IT\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s Next for Smart City IoT? Milwaukee Avenue, Vernon Hills, IL 60061', b'LinkNYC invites Valentine\'s Day marriage proposals, love Instagrams | Kiosk MarketplaceTest LinkCONTINUE TO SITE \xc2\xbb or wait 15 seconds\xc3\x97Toggle navigation\nTOPICS ATM Installation / DeploymentBill Payment KiosksCannabis KiosksCustomer ExperienceCustom KiosksDigital SignageDisplay TechnologyDVD KiosksEmployee Self-ServiceEV Charging KiosksFull Service / Turnkey ProviderGovernmentHardwareHealthcare / HospitalsHotelsICX SummitInteractive / TouchscreenKiosk BrandingKiosk DesignKiosk EnclosuresKiosk PrintersManufacturersNetworking / ConnectivityOutdoor KiosksPhoto KiosksRepair / ServiceRestaurantsRetailSelf-CheckoutSoftwareTransportation / TravelTrends / StatisticsVending KiosksWayfinding / InformationView all Topic Centers \xc2\xbbSUPPLIERS Companies by NameCompanies by CategoryProducts & ServicesRequest Information from SuppliersPROJECT HELPRESOURCESNEWSWEBINARSEVENTS View Industry Event Calendar >>MORE VideosWebinarsEventsPodcastsPhotosArticlesVideosBlogsPress ReleasesJob ListingsMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggers\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nLinkNYC invites Valentine\'s Day marriage proposals, love InstagramsFeb. 13, 2018 | by Elliot MarasPhoto courtesy of Link,Looking to pop the big question on Valentine\'s Day? If you happen to be in New York City, you can catch your beloved\'s attention as they approach one of LinkNYC\'s Wi-Fi kiosks.For the second straight year, Link, which operates the LinkNYC Wi-Fi kiosks, has invited the marriage minded to post their proposals on the city\'s 1,280 LinkNYC kiosks for all passersby to see."We expect more proposals this year than last year," Ruth Fasoldt, Link\'s director of external affairs, told Kiosk Marketplace. Last year saw two marriage proposals on Link. So far this year, five are planned and more are expected.\xc2\xa0Tag Instagram love notesResidents who are not in\xc2\xa0marriage mode but feeling\xc2\xa0nonetheless amorous can tag their Valentine\'s Day entreaties on Instagram for a chance to be featured on the 55-inch digital displays throughout the city\'s five boroughs.Link will review every tagged Instagram photo to make sure it\'s not too risque before putting it on the screens. Every appropriate picture will likely be featured. Link will ask users for permission before posting their photos.Link has promoted the Valentine\'s Day campaign on the kiosks and through social media.Over 500 posts already"I\'ve just been so delighted to see all the different ways that love wins across New York City," said Kate Blumm, assistant commissioner for communications and external affairs for the city\'s department of information technology and telecommunications, noting that as of Tuesday afternoon (the day before Valentine\'s Day) there were more than 500 posts."It\'s everything from casual snapshots to more formal wedding pictures," she said. The city has promoted the campaign on\xc2\xa0its own social media channels.Blumm said the Valentine\'s Day promotion brings "community value" to residents."It enhances civic pride," she said. "It makes people feel a personal connection to the program. It makes it (the kiosk) less a hunk of metal and more of a community asset and something that they can have a human connection to.""We want to make sure that Links are bringing community value to the corners that they\'re on, and the more that people can see themselves reflected in the Links, the more valuable we think they\'ll be to New Yorkers," she added.More activities plannedLink is also celebrating Black History Month this month in New York City in partnership with a non-profit called Global Kids. Illustrations by students of famous black figures in science are being displayed on Links citywide."That\'s a very specific New York City, New Yorker driven way to commemorate Black History Month," Blumm said. "That\'s the kind of stuff we\'re going to continue to deepen over the course of the year.""The benefit to the city for Links in general is really vast," Blumm said. "We\'re replacing pay phones which have special places in the city\'s history but certainly are outdated in terms of their utility to New Yorkers.""We\'re going to continue to highlight the people, places and things that are special to New York City in particular," she said.Link kiosks allow residents to make domestic phone calls for free as well as provide access to city services. Residents were able to enroll in healthcare coverage up through the Jan. 31 enrollment deadline.Long-term benefits to accrue"Link is going above and beyond a traditional communications structure," Blumm said. "Not only is it at no cost to taxpayers, but the city of New York and the people of New York are guaranteed a minimum of $500 million over the life of the Link franchise."The revenue, generated by paid advertising, is paid to the city annually and will support city services. The kiosks have two panels that run digital advertising.Since New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 3.2 million people have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service.\xc2\xa0"They are certainly a flagship smart city innovation," Blumm said of the Link kiosks."The community engagement part of Link will always be important," Fastold said. The campaigns will always be tailored to the particular community being served. Outside of New York City, Link operates in the United Kingdom and will be operating in Philadelphia.Link has also done Instagram campaigns for other events, such as Fashion Week and Halloween.\xc2\xa0Topics: Advertising, Customer Experience, Government, Networking / Connectivity, Outdoor Kiosks, Wayfinding / Information Elliot MarasElliot Maras is the editor of KioskMarketplace.com and FoodTruckOperator.com.Sponsored Links:Related ContentKiosk Marketplace editor reviews 39 kiosk companies at National Restaurant ShowTaco Bell to install self-order kiosks in all stores in 2019 under its All Access initiativeSquare integration with Kiosk Pro app enables self-service for iPadsTaco Bell, Bell Canada Smart City Kiosks grab Elevate AwardsLatest ContentState-of-the-art testing: the first line of defense against fraudstersTexas Dairy Queen franchisee pioneers self-order kioskCashierless stores? Pyle Illustrations | Untapped Cities\nTOURS\nPUBLIC TOURS\nPRIVATE TOURS\nINSIDERS EVENTS\nGIFT CARDS\nINSIDERS\nINSIDERS EVENTS\nBECOME AN INSIDER\nINSIDERS LOGIN\nINSIDERS ACCOUNT\nSECRETS OF NYC\nTHINGS TO DO\nTHINGS TO DO IN NYC\nNYC GETAWAYS\nTOPICS\nBEHIND THE SCENES\nARCHITECTURE\nARTS & CULTURE\nTRANSIT\nLinkNYC Kiosks Teach NYC Etiquette With Nathan W. Pyle Illustrations\nNicole Saraniero\n02/15/2018\nArts & Culture, New York, News\nLinkNYC Kiosks\xc2\xa0are teaching New York City\xc2\xa0residents and tourists how to be a little more considerate. The digital displays around the five boroughs are currently featuring the\xc2\xa0work of illustrator and T-shirt designer,\xc2\xa0Nathan W. Pyle. He\xe2\x80\x99s the author of\xc2\xa0NYC Basic Tips and Etiquette, a book of illustrations depicting the \xe2\x80\x9cunique habits and unspoken customs New Yorkers follow to make life bearable.\xe2\x80\x9d\nPyle, originally from Ohio, uses his black and white drawings to share helpful tips that he has learned through his own experiences of living in New York City. His illustrations cover all facets of city life, from how to deal with pole-hogs on the subway to how to photograph skyscrapers with your phone. The book also answers \xe2\x80\x9cburning questions\xe2\x80\x9d like: how do I hail a cab? What is a bodega?\xc2\xa0and most humorously, Do we need be touching right now? See below for a sampling of Pyle\xe2\x80\x99s work:\nAll images courtesy Harper Collins\nIn addition to these hilarious tidbits of advice, some of our favorite LinkNYC displays include fun facts about New York City, as well as historical photos of neighborhoods. That\xe2\x80\x99s how we learned that 15,152 life forms have been identified on the subway\xc2\xa0and that New Yorkers bite 10 times more people than sharks do worldwide. Next time you pass by a LinkNYC display, make sure to keep your eyes peeled, and you may just learn something new about our city.\nYou can see more of Nathan W. Pyle\xe2\x80\x99s work on his Instagram. Next, check out the Judgmental Map of NYC.\nLinkNYC\nRead More\nUntapped Cities Partners with LinkNYC to Power NYC Facts Series!\n06/18/2019\nDiscover NYC\xe2\x80\x99s Never Built Architecture on the LinkNYC Kiosks\n07/13/2018\n54 LinkNYC Fun Facts You Probably Didn\xe2\x80\x99t Know About NYC\n12/06/2017\nLeave a Reply\nCancel reply\nYour email address will not be published. The content will run from Feb. 9 until the end of he XXIII Olympic Winter Games on Feb. 25, according to a press release.The displays will showcase morning highlights, opening ceremony teasers, medal counts, athlete profiles and previews. Intersection will run the content on the LinkNYC network in New York City, digital panels in the Chicago Transit Authority and displays in SETP, PATCO and throughout the rest of Philadelphia."Whether walking the streets of New York, riding the Chicago L, or waiting in Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s 30th Street Station, Olympics fans in these three cities will be surrounded by the excitement of the Winter Games," Gary Zenkel, president, NBC Olympics, said in the release. "Emerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media."Topics: Digital Signage, Display Technology, Interactive / Touchscreen, TechnologySponsored Links:Related ContentUrban Air CEO: Retail success is all about loving the customerGetting customers to return: Customer experience success storiesBrick-and-mortar retail isn\'t dead, it\'s just evolvingWhat revived legacy retail brands need to do to surviveLatest ContentCreating an experience beyond shoppingFor high-velocity retail business, mind the data gapCashierless stores? 22\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n17\xc2\xb0C\n4\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n18\xc2\xb0C\n6\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n17\xc2\xb0C\n4\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n17\xc2\xb0C\n3\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n17\xc2\xb0C\n6\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n14\xc2\xb0C\n6\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n18\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n15\xc2\xb0C\n12\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n17\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n16\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n19\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n17\xc2\xb0C\n8\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n19\xc2\xb0C\n5\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n19\xc2\xb0C\n6\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n19\xc2\xb0C\n7\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n19\xc2\xb0C\n5\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n19\xc2\xb0C\n4\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n17\xc2\xb0C\n8\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n20\xc2\xb0C\n3\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n19\xc2\xb0C\n4\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n17\xc2\xb0C\n2\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n17\xc2\xb0C\n1\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n19\xc2\xb0C\n1\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n17\xc2\xb0C\n6\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n25\xc2\xb0C\n13\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n24\xc2\xb0C\n14\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n22\xc2\xb0C\n15\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n22\xc2\xb0C\n15\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n20\xc2\xb0C\n15\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n19\xc2\xb0C\n15\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n24\xc2\xb0C\n15\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n19\xc2\xb0C\n13\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n15\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n16\xc2\xb0C\n10\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n16\xc2\xb0C\n12\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n18\xc2\xb0C\n12\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n20\xc2\xb0C\n9\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n14\xc2\xb0C\n10\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n16\xc2\xb0C\n8\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n17\xc2\xb0C\n5\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n18\xc2\xb0C\n10\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n18\xc2\xb0C\n7\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n19\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n14\xc2\xb0C\n12\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n15\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n15\xc2\xb0C\n10\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n17\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n17\xc2\xb0C\n11\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n19\xc2\xb0C\n4\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n20\xc2\xb0C\n5\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n21\xc2\xb0C\n8\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n19\xc2\xb0C\n5\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n20\xc2\xb0C\n4\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n18\xc2\xb0C\n9\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n17\xc2\xb0C\n0\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n16\xc2\xb0C\n3\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n13\xc2\xb0C\n0\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n14\xc2\xb0C\n0\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n15\xc2\xb0C\n0\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n17\xc2\xb0C\n4\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n22\xc2\xb0C\n5\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n23\xc2\xb0C\n6\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n23\xc2\xb0C\n6\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n20\xc2\xb0C\n5\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n20\xc2\xb0C\n7\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n18\xc2\xb0C\n9\xc2\xb0C\nFri\n23\xc2\xb0C\n15\xc2\xb0C\nSat\n16\xc2\xb0C\n12\xc2\xb0C\nSun\n14\xc2\xb0C\n8\xc2\xb0C\nMon\n15\xc2\xb0C\n7\xc2\xb0C\nTue\n15\xc2\xb0C\n9\xc2\xb0C\nWed\n18\xc2\xb0C\n9\xc2\xb0C\nGo\nCape Town partners with New York to boost tourism\nCape Town Tourism has partnered with New York City\xe2\x80\x99s official destination marketing organisation, NYC & Company, to co-market the two cities.\nFILE: Picture: Pixabay.com.\nCape Town Tourism\nNew York City\nLinkNYC\nEmail\nPrint\nTweet\nShare\nKevin\xc2\xa0Brandt\n|\xc2\xa0489 days ago\nCAPE TOWN - From February, New Yorkers will be encouraged to visit Cape Town as a tourism destination as President Cyril Ramaphosa eyes major growth in the sector.Cape Town Tourism has partnered with New York City\xe2\x80\x99s official destination marketing organisation, NYC & Company, to co-market the two cities.Tourism contributes around R15 billion to Cape Town\xe2\x80\x99s economy and sustains 700,000 jobs nationally, a number Ramaphosa believes can be doubled.As part of the agreement between the two tourism promotion bodies, Cape Town\xe2\x80\x99s many attractions will appear on 62 bus shelters and over 1,000 outdoor LinkNYC kiosks across New York\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs.Cape Town Tourism CEO Enver Duminy explains how New York City will be promoted locally.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re going to be wrapping up one of our mobile information centres, which will go to all key events across Cape Town to share New York's appeal. A digital billboard will be installed in town to screen campaigns.\xe2\x80\x9dHe says Cape Town will benefit from exposure to New York City\xe2\x80\x99s nine million residents and 60 million annual visitors.President Ramaphosa in his State of the Nation Address said the government will enhance support for destination marketing in key tourism markets, to further grow this top performing sector.\nTimeline\nRise in cruise ships docking in CT beneficial for local economy, says MEC\n57 days ago\nNew York hotels offer free rooms to furloughed US govt workers\n153 days ago\nNumber of visitors to CT expected to increase\n188 days ago\nWesgro: CT secures business events worth R1 billion\n191 days ago\nMore in Lifestyle\nIndonesian YouTube stars get chance for university place\n4 hours ago\nPenelope Cruz is 'angry' about the 'taboo' surrounding menopause\n5 hours ago\nDame Judi Dench slams 'cruel' dog meat festival\n6 hours ago\n19 dummies found in dog\xe2\x80\x99s stomach\n6 hours ago\nTiffany Haddish slams anti-abortion laws\n9 hours ago\nSteve Hofmeyr's recent controversies\n11 hours ago\nComments\nEWN welcomes all comments that are constructive, contribute to discussions in a meaningful manner and take stories forward.\nHowever, we will NOT condone the following:\n- Racism (including offensive comments based on ethnicity and nationality)\n- Sexism\n- Homophobia\n- Religious intolerance\n- Cyber bullying\n- Hate speech\n- Derogatory language\n- Comments inciting violence.\nWe ask that your comments remain relevant to the articles they appear on and do not include general banter or conversation as this dilutes the effectiveness of the comments section.\nWe strive to make the EWN community a safe and welcoming space for all.\nEWN reserves the right to: 1) remove any comments that do not follow the above guidelines; Gardens\nEastern Brooklyn\nBrownsville\nCanarsie\nCypress Hills\nEast New York\nNorthern Brooklyn\nBushwick\nGreenpoint\nWilliamsburg\nBed Stuy\nNorth Western Brooklyn\nBoerum Hill\nDowntown Brooklyn\nPark Slope\nProspect Heights\nRed Hook\nSouth Slope\nClinton Hill\nCarroll Gardens\nCobble Hill\nDUMBO\nFort Greene\nGowanus\nWindsor Terrace\nSouthern Brooklyn\nBergen Beach\nConey Island\nGravesend\nBrighton Beach\nMarine Park\nMidwood\nMill Basin\nSheepshead Bay\nWestern Brooklyn\nBath Beach\nBay Ridge\nBensonhurst\nBorough Park\nDyker Heights\nSunset Park\nSubscribe\nAbout Us\nEat & Drink\nReal Estate\nEvents\nCalendar\nBus Time Clocks Come To Bensonhurst\xe2\x80\x99s B8 Line\nBy Paul Stremple -\nFebruary 21, 2018 1\nFacebook\nTwitter\nPinterest\nWhatsApp\nLinkedin\nReddIt\nEmail\nPrint\nPassengers wait for the B8 bus at 18th Avenue and New Utrecht (Via\xc2\xa0Carmen Molina Tamacas)\nNew Bus Time clocks have made their way onto the B8 bus route down 18th Avenue, with 5 of the LED signs giving passengers a heads up on when the next bus is due.\nThe five clocks run along 18th Avenue, using real-time GPS monitoring to let commuters know how much time is left until the next bus\xe2\x80\x94a system already in place with the Bus Time app. Now, commuters without smartphones can reap the benefits as well.\nEach route for the stop is listed with a separate countdown, and blank spaces allow for additional bus routes to be listed in the future.\nBklyner reporting is supported by our subscribers and:\nA closeup of a new Bus Time pole sign in Bensonhurst (via\xc2\xa0Carmen Molina Tamacas)\nThe project had $100,000 allocated from Councilmember Mark Treyger\xe2\x80\x99s District 47 during Participatory Budgeting, leading to the installation of 5 clocks\xe2\x80\x94about $20,000 each.\nThe NYC Department of Transportation was on track to install twenty-eight of the Bus Time pole signs by the end of\xc2\xa02017, on bus routes in Park Slope, Carroll Gardens, Kensington, Bensonhurst, Sheepshead Bay, Coney Island and Brighton Beach, according to the DOT.\nPiloted in Staten Island and Manhattan in 2013-2014, the program has had positive results, said a DOT spokesperson.\nThe DOT has said further expansion in Brooklyn will happen through funding provided by local elected officials, though the cost may prove to be prohibitive in some communities. In District 30, Councilmember Brad Lander has pushed for collaboration between the city and LinkNYC, with the goal of using the large advertising and communications kiosks to display wait times for nearby bus routes.\nLast fall, Lander put the price point of the clocks at about $35,000, and when one factors in the roughly 15,000 bus stops in Brooklyn, full coverage doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem likely anytime soon. Still, a handful of Bensonshursts commuters are now able to reap the benefits of more timely information.\nNever miss the day\'s stories!\nLeave this field empty if you\'re human: This page is available to subscribers. Welcome to NYC! pic.twitter.com/oKm3pD5GJz\xe2\x80\x94 NYC IT & Telecomm (@NYCDoITT) February 5, 2018Brooklyn startup Remesh adds Noele Emmons and Emma Borochoff as sales and marketing directors.The market research startup uses artificial intelligence to innovate in the field. Last year it raised $2.2 million and earlier this month it announced five new hires, including these two at the director level.Borochoff comes to the company after nearly six years at digital events company Bizzabo, where she rose from a community manager to its brand and communications director.Emmons, who\xe2\x80\x99s based in Seattle, is a sales veteran, having been at the director level at two previous companies out on the West Coast.We are growing our Remesh family and times could not be more exciting! https://t.co/16S987dfHJ #mrx #insights @researchlive #marketresearch Advertisement\xe2\x80\x94 Remesh (@teamremesh) February 14, 2018Chris Giliberti announced as head of Gimlet Pictures.Giliberti was an internal promotion at Gimlet when it launched its film and television arm last month, Gimlet Pictures.This year,\xc2\xa0Amazon Video\xc2\xa0will premiere a show called\xc2\xa0Homecoming, based off the Gimlet podcast of the same name, which will star\xc2\xa0Julia Roberts. Another upcoming show based on a Gimlet podcast will be\xc2\xa0Alex, Inc., set to air on\xc2\xa0ABC\xc2\xa0and starring and directed by\xc2\xa0Zach Braff. Rights Reserved.\nDo NOT follow this link or you will be banned from the site!", b'The Free Wi-Fi Payphone Replacements of New York Cityairport_transferbarbathtubbusiness_facilitieschild_activitieschildcareconnecting_roomcribsfree_wifigymhot_tubinternetkitchennon_smokingpetpoolresturantski_in_outski_shuttleski_storagesmoking_areaspastarSectionsSeriesHungerlustLocationsEuropeNorth AmericaAfricaAsiaSouth AmericaMiddle EastAntarcticaCentral AmericaPacificCaribbeanWishlistsNorth AmericaUSANew YorkTechThe Free Wi-Fi Payphone Replacements of New York CityLinkNYC kiosks are funded by advertising | \xc2\xa9 LinkNYC Peter WardTech EditorUpdated: 22 February 2018 Save to wishlistSave to Wishlist Payphones became so obsolete so quickly that we rarely pay any attention to the few that are left. In New York, it\xe2\x80\x99s even possible to overlook the fact that many have been replaced by Wi-Fi capable, phone charging, tablet-wielding kiosks all over the city. LinkNYC is a network of slim, tall booths that offer a number of services to visitors and residents of New York. Perhaps the most useful is free, fast WI-Fi access, that lets you stay connected free of charge when you\xe2\x80\x99re out and about in the city. The Links also provide free domestic phone calls, maps, directions, a USB port for charging, and a 911 button for emergencies. The project to install the network has been ambitious. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen LinkNYC is fully built out it\xe2\x80\x99s going to be the largest, fastest municipal Wi-Fi network anywhere in the world. So we definitely have a go big or go home mentality. It\xe2\x80\x99s an incredible resource both for New Yorkers and visitors, at no cost to the taxpayer,\xe2\x80\x9d says Kate Blumm, Assistant Commissioner, Communications & External Affairs at NYC Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications, in an interview.Phones can be charged at the stations\xc2\xa9 LinkNYCThe reason there\xe2\x80\x99s no cost to New York\xe2\x80\x99s residents is that the whole network is funded by advertising. The Link kiosks have two digital screens on either side, which can display advertising, among other things. They\xe2\x80\x99re provided by the City of New York and a New York-based consortium called CityBridge that includes chip maker Qualcomm and Intersection, a company funded by Google\xe2\x80\x99s parent firm Alphabet. \xe2\x80\x9cOld payphones had static advertisements on three sides, and our new Links have digital advertising on two sides, and we split the revenue 50-50 [with the city,]\xe2\x80\x9d says Ruth Fasoldt, Director of External Affairs at LinkNYC. \xe2\x80\x9cOur 50% also pays for the entire project, and we also use the 55-inch screens for other things beyond advertising. We have content up there that can be useful for residents and visitors alike, subway updates, weather updates, fun facts about New York City, and we\xe2\x80\x99re growing that content all the time.\xe2\x80\x9dThe program, which started rolling out in 2016, hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been without its controversies. There was a problem with users accessing pornographic content on the browser later that year, which was fixed by limiting the sites accessible via the kiosk. And there have also been privacy concerns raised, particularly as the booths have forward-facing cameras. Citizens opposed to the cameras began putting post-it notes on the cameras, only for them to be taken down. The New York Civil Liberties Union has also complained about the LinkNYC network, saying in a letter to New York Mayor Bill de Blasio: \xe2\x80\x9cthe NYCLU remains concerned about the vast amount of private information retained by the LinkNYC system and the lack of robust language in the privacy policy protecting users against unwarranted government surveillance.\xe2\x80\x9dLinkNYC has been operational since 2016\xc2\xa9 LinkNYCBut despite these concerns, the project has aimed to bring connectivity to every New York resident and visitor. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Mayor has said publicly and is 100% right\xe2\x80\x94the internet is like water in 21st-century New York City,\xe2\x80\x9d explains Blumm. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not a luxury, and not just access to internet, access to high speed internet. Adults need it to look for jobs, and to manage their resources, kids need it as part of their education. Every New Yorker and visitor deserves the right to have it.\xe2\x80\x9dIn order to make the kiosks more visible to busy New Yorkers, several campaigns have been launched to attract attention. One of the more recent examples was on Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s Day, when people were encouraged to tag photos of them and their Valentine on Instagram, to be in the running to be featured on the side of a Link kiosk. There were also plans to arrange for visitors and residents who intended to propose to do so via a message on the side of a Link. Aside from these types of campaigns, the main goal for LinkNYC in the future is to expand the network. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re still in the third year of an eight-year rollout. It will keep growing. You\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to walk pretty much the whole of Manhattan while being connected to this Wi-Fi the whole time. We have 1,300 links that are live across the five boroughs so far, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll have thousands more. We\xe2\x80\x99re already up to 3.3 million devices having connected, which is larger than Chicago. It\xe2\x80\x99s really exciting to see where we\xe2\x80\x99re going,\xe2\x80\x9d says Fasoldt. On the show: Denver airport, Verizon, Omnicom, LinkNYC, O2\xe2\x80\x99s Weve, Placecast gets acquired by Ericsson, Radius8, Selfridges.\n&lt;span data-mce-type=\xe2\x80\x9dbookmark\xe2\x80\x9d style=\xe2\x80\x9ddisplay: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;\xe2\x80\x9d class=\xe2\x80\x9dmce_SELRES_start\xe2\x80\x9d&gt;\xef\xbb\xbf&lt;/span&gt;&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;span data-mce-type=\xe2\x80\x9dbookmark\xe2\x80\x9d style=\xe2\x80\x9ddisplay: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;\xe2\x80\x9d class=\xe2\x80\x9dmce_SELRES_start\xe2\x80\x9d&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;\xef\xbb\xbf&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;/span&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;\nTags:\nEricsson Omnicom Placecast Radius8 Selfridges Verizon\n0\nshares\nPrevious Post\nUnderstanding the Proxies That Can Undermine Location Data\nFebruary 23, 2018\nNext Post\nHow Local Healthcare Providers Can Imitate Advances in Retail to Boost Efficiency\nFebruary 23, 2018\nLeave a Reply Cancel reply\nYour email address will not be published.
