Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b'Llega la modernidad a los tel\xc3\xa9fonos p\xc3\xbablicos, solo conservar\xc3\xa1n cuatro de las antiguas cabinas telef\xc3\xb3nicas\nNueva York\nNueva York\nToggle navigation\nLog In\nEn Vivo\n\xc3\x9aLTIMAS NOTICIAS\nTitulares\nPol\xc3\xadtica\nSeguridad P\xc3\xbablica\nEducaci\xc3\xb3n\nSalud\nEntretenimiento\nVivienda\nEL TIEMPO\nEl Tiempo en el 1\nRadar Interactivo\nEl Blog del Tiempo\nTR\xc3\x81NSITO\nNoticias de Tr\xc3\xa1nsito\nMapa del Tr\xc3\xa1fico\nPROGRAMAS\nPura Pol\xc3\xadtica\nNueva York Por la Ma\xc3\xb1ana\nMartes de "Migra"\nSi usted viera lo que Viera\nCOMUNIDAD+CONDADOS\nManhattan\nBrooklyn\nEl Bronx\nQueens\nStaten Island\nGente\nCalendario Comunitario\nOrgullo Latino\nPuerto Rico Al D\xc3\xada\nEl Estudiante Destacado\nNUESTROS PERIODISTAS\n\xc3\x9aLTIMAS NOTICIAS\nTitulares\nPol\xc3\xadtica\nSeguridad P\xc3\xbablica\nEducaci\xc3\xb3n\nSalud\nEntretenimiento\nVivienda\nEL TIEMPO\nEl Tiempo en el 1\nRadar Interactivo\nEl Blog del Tiempo\nTR\xc3\x81NSITO\nNoticias de Tr\xc3\xa1nsito\nMapa del Tr\xc3\xa1fico\nPROGRAMAS\nPura Pol\xc3\xadtica\nNueva York Por la Ma\xc3\xb1ana\nMartes de "Migra"\nSi usted viera lo que Viera\nCOMUNIDAD+CONDADOS\nManhattan\nBrooklyn\nEl Bronx\nQueens\nStaten Island\nGente\nCalendario Comunitario\nOrgullo Latino\nPuerto Rico Al D\xc3\xada\nEl Estudiante Destacado\nNUESTROS PERIODISTAS\nALERTA DEL TIEMPOVer lista completa de alertas\nLlega la modernidad a los tel\xc3\xa9fonos p\xc3\xbablicos, solo conservar\xc3\xa1n cuatro de las antiguas cabinas telef\xc3\xb3nicas\nBy\nNY1 Noticias\nPUBLISHED 12:36 PM ET Feb. 26, 2018\nPUBLISHED February 26, 2018 @12:36 PM\nSHARE\nUn nuevo plan, llamado LinkNYC, busca reemplazar los tel\xc3\xa9fonos p\xc3\xbablicos de la ciudad por al menos 7 Mil 500 kioscos de Wi-Fi.\nPero la empresa ha decidido conservar cuatro cabinas telef\xc3\xb3nicas ubicadas en la Avenida West End por su gran valor hist\xc3\xb3rico.\nLas autoridades dicen que la labor de reparar estos cub\xc3\xadculos no ha sido f\xc3\xa1cil, ya que no muchas empresas los siguen fabricando.\nLos nuevos kioscos ofrecen servicios de internet de alta velocidad a lo largo de los cinco condados, seg\xc3\xban Intersection, la compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xada de tecnolog\xc3\xada encargada de instalarlos.\nIntersection incluso tuvo que contactarse con una empresa en Canad\xc3\xa1 para poder renovar las cabinas.\nLas nuevas casetas cuentan con tabletas y teclados que permiten que los usuarios hagan llamadas dom\xc3\xa9sticas gratis.\nAdem\xc3\xa1s, los transe\xc3\xbantes tambi\xc3\xa9n pueden encontrar cargadores para USB, pantallas con avisos comerciales y un bot\xc3\xb3n de emergencia para llamar al 911.\nLa empresa de tecnolog\xc3\xada dice que para el 2020 estar\xc3\xa1n instalados cerca de 4 Mil de estos kioscos.\nREAD MORE\nYOU MIGHT ALSO LIKE\nLatest News\nCAMBIO DE REGI\xc3\x93N\nCONTACTOS\nACERCA DE NOSOTROS\nRSS\nPREGUNTAS Y RESPUESTAS\nMAPA DEL SITIO\nEMPLEOS\nT\xc3\x89RMINOS DE USO\nPRIVACIDAD\nCERTIFICACIONES\nAn\xc3\xbanciese con nosotros\n\xc2\xa9 1999-2019 Charter Communications. All Rights Reserved. Reproduction in whole or in part without permission is prohibited.', b'Riding Along With a Night Stringer, Chasing Car Crashes for Local NewsThe A.V. ClubDeadspinGizmodoJalopnikJezebelKotakuLifehackerSplinterThe TakeoutThe RootThe OnionClickholeThe InventorynullRiding Along With a Night Stringer, Chasing Car Crashes for Local NewsBryan Menegus3/01/18 11:20amFiled to: StringersFiled to: StringersStringersCitizen AppLocal NewsWhatsAppNight shiftRide along8312EditEmbiggenSend to EditorsPromoteShare to KinjaToggle Conversation toolsChange in-article videoGo to permalinkPhoto:\nBryan Menegus (Gizmodo)The engines are already pulling away by the time we get to a reported dryer fire. There won\xe2\x80\x99t be any footage of flames lapping up from the basement or smoke inhalation victims being wheeled into ambulances through the drizzling gloom\xe2\x80\x94not tonight anyway. The rain makes shootings unlikely too, in Adam\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, but there might be car crashes, and if they\xe2\x80\x99re bad enough those can sell.Thirty-two, but with the short-cropped hair and stubble mustache of a fresh police recruit, Adam is what\xe2\x80\x99s known in local news as a stringer: the photographers and videographers that cruise the city documenting accidents, crimes, disasters of all sizes in the hopes of selling their footage to media outlets faster than their competitors. His black tactical jacket and safety vest are partly inspired by a former obsession with airsoft guns, while the big velcro PRESS patches adorning them are ripped from the playbook of Scott Lane, the LA stringer documented in the Netflix series Shot in the Dark. (Of the three companies featured in a show described by reviewers as \xe2\x80\x9csleazy\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9ctasteless\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9cundiluted rubbernecking\xe2\x80\x9d, Lane\xe2\x80\x99s LoudLabs is presented as the most morally bankrupt.) New York City doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have any stringer companies yet, but that\xe2\x80\x99s what Adam\xe2\x80\x94who asked us not to use his last name in this article and goes by the moniker Adam West on social media\xe2\x80\x94has been working on for the past two months with NYC911News.AdvertisementInside his dark grey Ford Fusion is a utility belt of tools: two smartphones clipped above the car\xe2\x80\x99s sat-nav and three dispatch radios running up to an antenna jutting out of the sunroof to increase their range, tuned to the frequencies of the FDNY, NYPD Special Operations Division (SOD), and the third swapping constantly to local precincts, the codes for which Adam has memorized. One phone displays incidents reported to the Citizen app while the other chirps out Twitter alerts from select accounts and tips through a Whatsapp group run by a Daily News photographer. The effect is overwhelming. Driving most days for Uber, Lyft, Juno, and Via, he\xe2\x80\x99s grown used to being the servant of many masters. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen we decide to go to a [stringer] job we\xe2\x80\x99re assuming the risk that we may not get paid. Whereas when I answer an Uber job and I press \xe2\x80\x98accept trip\xe2\x80\x99 I know I\xe2\x80\x99m getting something. There\xe2\x80\x99s no guarantee of how much, but there\xe2\x80\x99s a guarantee of something,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. With its gadgets and metal push bumpers, passengers routinely mistake his Fusion for a cop car. The only difference with riders in his car is that Adam sends the audio from SOD into an Secret Service-style earpiece, filming between trips if proximity and opportunity align.Parked outside a McDonalds in Gowanus where he\xe2\x80\x99s just devoured a cheeseless triple cheeseburger, one of his three radios crackles and Adam mentally decodes: precinct, location, accident type, working the calculus of its value to New York TV and digital media by instinct. A car has struck a tree in Elmhurst and it might be a pinjob\xe2\x80\x94the sort of crash where people are trapped inside the vehicle. That could sell. We beeline for the BQE, only slowing down to scope out two stalled vehicles in front of the Kosciuszko bridge. A car behind us honks and Adam half-jokes, \xe2\x80\x9cHe must not know what I do.\xe2\x80\x9dAdvertisementCar collided with tree in Elmhurst.Photo:\nBryan Menegus (Gizmodo)At 98th and 23rd the front end of the white Nissan is mutilated. Adam pulls his camera and shoulder rig out of the trunk and goes to film. No pin, and no passengers. An eyewitness claims two people fled the car on foot after it crashed, but neither he nor the cops seem to know why. Adam shoots 30 seconds of footage from a few angles and we find another staging area to idle in\xe2\x80\x94someplace near a highway and a Link NYC public wi-fi terminal so he can upload the footage to Google Drive. We end up in front of the Quays, a local Irish bar in Astoria.AdvertisementAll the footage from an event becomes a package, and a good package can net $100 to $300 per hit. Get a few outlets to buy it and that can easily become $1,000 per job. The ruined Nissan probably won\xe2\x80\x99t sell, but Adam uploads it anyway, shooting an email off to New York 1, CBS, Pix 11, and a dozen other stations, agonizing over whether midnight should be referred to as Saturday night or Sunday morning. Certain events are more likely to be bought than others. Pinjobs and overturned vehicles, water main breaks, fires, slashing victims, pedestrians struck cars or trains, suicidal individuals on ledges (before or after jumping), people who have barricaded themselves inside structures, preferably with hostages. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s just another guy shot in the Bronx, it\xe2\x80\x99s not gonna make the news. If it\xe2\x80\x99s a teenager, if it\xe2\x80\x99s a child, if it\xe2\x80\x99s a baby shot, that kind of stuff\xe2\x80\x94or multiple people shot,\xe2\x80\x9d he says, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what they want.\xe2\x80\x9d Still, most happenings are ordinary and not worth the gas to film. A collision can be a simple fender-bender. A severed limb can mean a finger. Despite the idiom, where there\xe2\x80\x99s smoke, there is not necessarily fire. Reports of burglars breaking in through the roof of an apartment building turn out to be the sound of rain.AdvertisementThe radio crackles again. It\xe2\x80\x99s too far, so he records the string of information as a voice message when the SOD dispatcher repeats it, passing the tip to the 10 or so members of the NYC911News Whatsapp group, who, like Adam, all have some secondary line of work: a DJ, a real estate agent, a bike messenger, and a conservationist to name a few. There\xe2\x80\x99s strength in numbers. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s say I\xe2\x80\x99m in Bay Ridge and my guy\xe2\x80\x99s in the Bronx and there\xe2\x80\x99s a 2-alarm fire. By the time I get to that 2-alarm fire, that fire\xe2\x80\x99s gonna be out,\xe2\x80\x9d he explains. \xe2\x80\x9cHe can get there, catch the flames, catch the victims being loaded on the ambulance. And if that sells for say, 500 bucks? Multiple stations? At least I\xe2\x80\x99m getting a quarter of that, whereas [if] he was a random stringer, I\xe2\x80\x99d be getting nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d In exchange for his cut, Adam handles pitching, vendor accounts, and the other nuts and bolts of NYC911News.As small a community as New York City stringers are, a young and informal an operation like NYC911News is still vulnerable. \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of these guys, I notice, are older. When they get a solid staff job at a newspaper like the Daily News or the New York Post they stick with it and they do not quit,\xe2\x80\x9d he tells me, \xe2\x80\x9cThe young guys you might see might be Stringr app users, they might be new grads working at NY1 or channel 12.\xe2\x80\x9d While he feels photographers are different enough from videographers like himself, app-based paid platforms like Stringr and unpaid ones like Citizen eat away at his profits. \xe2\x80\x9cAt some point I would tell people \xe2\x80\x98Hey is that Citizen? Can you stop filming? You\xe2\x80\x99re costing me money,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d though his new approach is to try to recruit videographers using these apps with the promise of better pay. At some point during the evening it becomes clear he uses Stringr too\xe2\x80\x94but passes on the job because it\xe2\x80\x99s in Jersey City.AdvertisementMan being arrested outside the Buccaneer Diner.Photo:\nBryan Menegus (Gizmodo)After a false start chasing a reported assault on the Grand Central Parkway, Adam hears a local precinct responding to an unconfirmed fight: ten people brawling with knives. We arrive at 93rd and Astoria Boulevard in time to watch over a dozen officers lead a single angry man out of the 24-hour Buccaneer Diner into one of the eight cars that responded to the call, no knives in sight. \xe2\x80\x9cI love these perp walks,\xe2\x80\x9d Adam laughs, reviewing the footage. It probably won\xe2\x80\x99t sell either but, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s probably gonna make good social media stuff.\xe2\x80\x9d Whether or not news outlets buy his footage, he can still make a little extra by uploading it to YouTube. His most successful stringer clip\xe2\x80\x94HUGE VIOLENT Fight! Brooklyn halal food cart attacked! Feat. on Pix11 & NYPost\xe2\x80\x94is riddled with comments attributing the violent behavior to the attackers\xe2\x80\x99 race, though the commenters are undecided on what race that might be.AdvertisementMuch of his expertise with \xe2\x80\x9cbuffing\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94listening in on scanners\xe2\x80\x94comes from years as an EMT for an ambulance company in his neighborhood of Bay Ridge, eavesdropping on 911 reports to swoop in before city ambulances arrive. It\xe2\x80\x99s a controversial practice, but contained at least the veneer of assisting people in need. \xe2\x80\x9cIn EMS we had a cool phrase: \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything bad to happen to you, but I want to be there when it does.\xe2\x80\x99 What do we say? We don\xe2\x80\x99t have a cool saying like that,\xe2\x80\x9d he tells me in a moment of reflection. \xe2\x80\x9cComing from EMS to this job is very almost\xe2\x80\xa6 awkward. As an EMT, I work with fire, I work with police, we work together. There\xe2\x80\x99s that camaraderie. Bond. Whatever. Now I go to this job, now I\xe2\x80\x99m like, the schmuck with the camera trying to film the victim.\xe2\x80\x9d On the rare occasion he works EMS these days, the promising calamities that come over dispatch get passed to his Whatsapp groups.Police ESU responding to crashed vehicle near FDR Drive.Photo:\nBryan Menegus (Gizmodo)AdvertisementBy 4am the rain is starting to pick up, and exhausted drivers start making mistakes. There\xe2\x80\x99s been a crash on the onramp to the southbound FDR. An Emergency Service Unit is looping chains under the rear axle of a van, preparing to pull it off the concrete barricade its beached itself onto. The passengers are nowhere in sight. Documenting even this bloodless wreckage feels grotesque but I\xe2\x80\x99m beginning to understand why adrenaline junkies like Adam are drawn to it.By five, the night is looking like a washout. Before we head back to Brooklyn where Adam would drop me and my soggy gear off on his way down to Bay Ridge, we idle near a 7-11, waiting\nfor jobs from the now-dwindling radio messages. AdvertisementAdam dabs some hand sanitizer into his palms, tucks into a prepackaged croissant and a coffee, and plays me some of the clips he\xe2\x80\x99s shot. A massive car collision. Then a woman being carried out of a ruined cab. Then a three-alarm fire where firefighters slice into the security gates of a building with massive saws\xe2\x80\x94he caught that one at the tail end of an overnight shift on the way home and shot for close to an hour without a smoke mask. He perks up at the sound of sirens behind us. The ambulance passes with the words \xe2\x80\x9csenior care.\xe2\x80\x9d Old people dying isn\xe2\x80\x99t news, it\xe2\x80\x99s just life. He goes back to his croissant and coffee.Share This StoryRecommended StoriesAmazon&aposs Last MileSome Crypto-Capitalists Just Want to See the World BurnThe Untold Story of Napoleon Hill, the Greatest Self-Help Scammer of All TimeThe Survivors of the Coming Apocalypse Just Wanna Have Fun72 Hours in Model Horse MeccaThe Last of the Iron LungsAbout the authorBryan MenegusBryan MenegusSenior reporter. We are working to restore service.', b'More LinkNYC Kiosks Installed in LIC, Activation in Coming Weeks | LIC Post\nContact\nastoriapostflushingpostforesthillspostgreenpointpostjacksonheightspostridgewoodpostsunnysidepost\nlicpost\nSERVING LONG ISLAND CITY\nMenu\nHome\nAbout\nContact\nAdvertise\nEvents\nastoriapostflushingpostforesthillspostgreenpointpostjacksonheightspostridgewoodpostsunnysidepost\nYou are reading\nMore LinkNYC Kiosks Installed in LIC, Activation in Coming Weeks\nvia LinkNYC\nMarch 5, 2018 By Nathaly Pesantez\nAdditional LinkNYC kiosks have recently been installed in Hunters Point and Court Square.\nVernon Boulevard will see two kiosks come online in the coming weeks, with one installed mid block between 48th and 49th Avenues, and another between 47th Road and 48th Ave. The boulevard only had one LinkNYC kiosk installed prior to the additions.\nAnother kiosk will come online by the intersection of Jackson and 48th Avenues. The kiosk is one of several along Jackson Avenue, the majority of which are in the Court Square and Queens Plaza areas.\nAnother two kiosks were installed on 11th Street, the first two on that strip. One of the kiosks is on 45th Avenue, across the street from John F. Murray Playground. The other is on 44th Drive.\nA spokesperson for LinkNYC said the new kiosks were installed about a month ago, and should go live in weeks time.\nLinkNYC launched in 2016 as a way to replace obsolete phone booths with a free, public Wi-Fi network. The kiosks also allow users to make free phone calls, charge their phones, and access maps and city services. Roughly 1,400 kiosks are active citywide, with the first batch of 11 kiosks installed through Long Island City last year.\nVisit LinkNYC for a map of the kiosks citywide.\nemail the author: [email\xc2\xa0protected]\n13 Comments\nGreg Thrasher March 25th, 2018\nI love the entire enterprise\xe2\x80\xa6.Extremely functional and the potential is unlimited.\nReply\nso frustrating March 9th, 2018\nyet another addition that is spending tax dollars on \xe2\x80\x9cinnovation\xe2\x80\x9d before spending tax dollars to fix what we already have. bonus, this innovation attracts perverts! Ribbon\nJune 17, 2019\xc2\xa0By Meghan SackmanElected officials cut the ribbon on William Cullen Bryant High School\xe2\x80\x99s new $3.3 million sports field on Friday.\nRead More\n2\nCourt Square for\nClose\nArrow_Path\nFastestMobileNetworks\nUpdateFirefox\nFacebookLibra\n5G\nPrimeDay\nNews & Analysis/\nT-Mobile\'s LAA Creates Screaming Fast Speeds in NYC\nPiping LTE over new channels results in download speeds over 500Mbps in our testing.\nBy\nSascha Segan\nMarch 5, 2018 11:14AM EST\nMarch 5, 2018\nPCMag reviews products independently, but we may earn affiliate commissions from buying links on this page. Terms of use.\nT-Mobile is now boosting LTE download speeds to over 500Mbps by using Licensed Assisted Access (LAA) in New York City, according to Milan Milanovic, Technical Evangelist for Ookla.\nThis is the first time we\'ve actually been able to see and test commercial LAA in the US. The technology, which we\'ve heard a lot about for a year now, pipes 4G LTE signals over unused 5GHz Wi-Fi channels to widen a carrier\'s available bandwidth. For carriers other than Sprint, LAA will be critical to achieving gigabit LTE speeds, because they don\'t have enough contiguous licensed spectrum to achieve those speeds.\nWireless carriers hate referring to these channels as Wi-Fi spectrum, because it implies that Wi-Fi has preferred usage of the 5GHz band when it\'s actually open to everyone. But Wi-Fi is the predominant use for it right now.\nAT&T is working with LAA in Indianapolis and Austin, and Verizon is probably "deploying but being stealthy," Milanovic said.\nAt a cell site at 45th St. and Third Avenue in Manhattan, T-Mobile is combining 20MHz of its Band 4 spectrum with 60MHz of LAA spectrum. Phones connect to the cell site and send data up using the 1700MHz/2100Mhz Band 4 spectrum, and then get downloaded data via a combination of Band 4 and LAA.\nThose speeds are insane. In 13 tests, we got an average of 503Mbps down and 42.7Mbps up. Just to compare, in Ookla\'s Speedtest Intelligence database, the top 10 percent of T-Mobile download speeds in that ZIP code are only around 70Mbps down.\nLAA-capable phones can get up to ten 100Mbps download streams on this cell site, with four on the licensed spectrum (4x4 MIMO) and two on each of three channels of LAA spectrum, Milanovic said.\nOther users on this cell site will do well, but not as well as LAA users, Milanovic notes. The site is also equipped with T-Mobile\'s workhorse Band 2 and the low-frequency Band 12, which penetrates inside buildings.\nLAA is only a solution for dense urban areas, though. This cell site has a coverage diameter of about four blocks (a bit over 1,000 feet), which is considered pretty good for LAA. That\'s a little better than what the coverage probably would be if the site was sending down 5GHz Wi-Fi, and it\'s a little better than New York\'s LinkNYC public Wi-Fi posts.\nRelated\nExclusive: Qualcomm\'s iPhone X Still Outpaces Intel\'s\nExclusive: Qualcomm\'s iPhone X Still Outpaces Intel\'s\nA nearby LinkNYC post doesn\'t appear to be interfering with the T-Mobile signal, Milanovic said. That\'s good news, because one of the concerns about LAA is whether or not it will coexist well with powerful public Wi-Fi.\nYou\'ll need the right phone to hit these speeds, and that\'s not an iPhone. Currently, LAA is supported by T-Mobile\'s Samsung Galaxy S8, Note 8, Galaxy S8 Active, Galaxy S9/S9+, LG V30, and the unlocked Huawei Mate 10 Pro. We\'ll make sure to test LAA when we go on the road with our Fastest Mobile Networks drive tests this spring.\nDisclosure: Ookla and PCMag share a parent company, Ziff Davis.\nTop\nRecommended\nRead More\nLyft Partners With Allscripts to Help Patients Get a Ride to the Doctor\nNews & Analysis\nLyft Partners With Allscripts to Help Patients Get a Ride to the Doctor\nSkyroam Wants to Be Your Global ISP\nNews & Analysis Skyroam Wants to Be Your Global ISP\nAbout the Author\nSascha Segan\nLead Analyst, Mobile\nTwitter\nEmail\nPCMag.com\'s lead mobile analyst, Sascha Segan, has reviewed hundreds of smartphones, tablets and other gadgets in more than 13 years with PCMag. He\'s the head of our Fastest Mobile Networks project, hosts our One Cool Thing daily Web show, and writes opinions on tech and society.\nSegan is also a multiple award-winning travel writer. The partnership will allow MCNY to highlight its current exhibit, Beyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics.\nStarting today, the city\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC kiosks will feature images of notable women from MCNY\xe2\x80\x99s exhibit, across all five boroughs. The partnership will last through the end of the month, and highlight the roles of women both well known and others whose work has not attracted mainstream attention prior to the exhibit.\nJust some of the women that will be featured in this digital exhibit include Verina Morton Jones, a physician and leader of the Equal Suffrage League, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, one of the leading figures of the early women\xe2\x80\x99s suffrage movement, and Mabel Lee, one of the lesser known activists of the movement.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe perfect match between Link\xe2\x80\x99s platform and our content will bring the story of women\xe2\x80\x99s activism in New York to life in unprecedented ways and make the inspiring history of Beyond Suffrage accessible for even more New Yorkers, tourists, and visitors,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president of the MCNY, Whitney Donhauser, in a statement.\nNext Up In\nNYC Museums\nAmerican Museum of Natural History finally breaks ground on long-planned expansion\nWorld Trade Center memorial for those with 9/11-related illnesses debuts in lower Manhattan\nBrooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s cash-strapped Weeksville Heritage Center surpasses fundraising Mascali\nPublished : March 08, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nMore\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsapp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\n1/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n1/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n2/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n2/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n3/3\nThe initiative is in conjunction with the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s current exhibit, \xe2\x80\x98Beyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics.\xe2\x80\x99 (MCNY)\n3/3\nThe initiative is in conjunction with the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s current exhibit, \xe2\x80\x98Beyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics.\xe2\x80\x99 (MCNY)\nBack to top\n1/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n1/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n2/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n2/3\nStarting on International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day and running throughout the rest of Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, LinkNYC will honor city\xe2\x80\x99s trailblazing women political activists. (MCNY)\n3/3\nThe initiative is in conjunction with the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s current exhibit, \xe2\x80\x98Beyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics.\xe2\x80\x99 (MCNY)\n3/3\nThe initiative is in conjunction with the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s current exhibit, \xe2\x80\x98Beyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics.\xe2\x80\x99 (MCNY)\nBack to top\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nFor more than a century, International Women\xe2\x80\x99s Day has celebrated the social, economic, cultural and political achievements of women across the globe. And starting today through the rest of the month, some of New York City\xe2\x80\x99s most trailblazing female political activists will be honored at LinkNYC kiosks across the city.\nThe initiative is a collaboration between LinkNYC, the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) and the Museum of the City of New York and not only commemorates this year\'s IWD, but also March being Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month.\nThe women featured on the LinkNYC kiosks are included in the museum\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBeyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics\xe2\x80\x9d exhibit, which runs through Aug. 5.\nRecommended Slideshows\n40 PicturesPHOTOS: Blues dump Bruins to win Stanley Cup after agonizing 52-year wait40 Pictures\n8 PicturesPHOTOS: This Pakistani waiter looks just like Peter Dinklage8 Pictures\n36 PicturesAll of these celebrities have had their nudes leaked36 PicturesMore picture galleries\n16 PicturesThese photos of Trump and Ivanka will make you deeply uncomfortable\n16 Pictures\n4 PicturesCuba Gooding Jr. charged in Manhattan groping incident, police say4 Pictures\n2 Pictures4 fun things to do in the Lehigh Valley2 Pictures\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuring Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month, we are proud to shine a light on prominent women who have positively impacted New York City and the entire nation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jen Hensley, president of LinkNYC. \xe2\x80\x9cUsing Link\xe2\x80\x99s platform of digital displays throughout the five boroughs, we hope New Yorkers and visitors who walk by Links will get a window into the well-known and unsung heroes who have paved the way for women today.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAmong those heroes are Alva Belmont, founder of the Political Equality Association in New York, journalist and civic activist Bessye Bearden, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, who was a drafter of the Declaration of Sentiments, suffrage leader Mabel Lee and Sarah J.S. Tompkins Garnet, who founded the Equal Suffrage League in Brooklyn.\nThe museum\xe2\x80\x99s exhibit features photos, audio materials, garments and more to tell the stories of the city\xe2\x80\x99s female activists, and DoITTT Commissioner Samir Saini hopes that its partnership with LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x9cwill inspire activism among all the people \xe2\x80\x94 male and female \xe2\x80\x94 of our city today,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\nWhitney Donhauser, president of the Museum of City of New York, called the collaboration a "perfect match" that "will bring the story of women\xe2\x80\x99s activism in New York to life in unprecedented ways and make the inspiring history of \xe2\x80\x98Beyond Suffrage\xe2\x80\x99 accessible for even more New Yorkers, tourists and visitors.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMore than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks can be found across the five boroughs, and thousands more will be deployed in the coming years.\nTags:WomenWomen\'s History MonthNew York City\nLoading...\nLatest From YorkSubscribeLog InLog InToday\xe2\x80\x99s PaperNew York|New York Today: Overlooked Women in Our CityAdvertisementSupported byNew York TodayNew York Today: Overlooked Women in Our CityImageThe photographer Diane Arbus in New York in the 1960s.CreditCreditRoz Kelly/Michael Ochs Archives, via Getty ImagesBy Jonathan\nWolfe and Alexandra S. LevineMarch 12, 2018Updated, 7:35 a.m.Good morning on this spotty Monday.The New York Times, as part of a new project called Overlooked, has published obituaries for 15 extraordinary women who were not given one at the time of their deaths.Among the first group of women are a few whose remarkable accomplishments took place here in New York.Diane Arbus, a photographer, grew up in luxurious uptown apartments, but she sought inspiration among the city\xe2\x80\x99s outcasts and eccentrics. Her photographs like \xe2\x80\x9cA Jewish giant at home with his parents, in the Bronx, N.Y., 1970\xe2\x80\x9d; \xe2\x80\x9cA young man in curlers at home on West 20th Street, N.Y.C.\xe2\x80\x9d; and \xe2\x80\x9cGirl with a cigar in Washington Square Park, N.Y.C.\xe2\x80\x9d are debated among photographers as both sublime and exploitative. She influenced generations of photographers and artists including Stanley Kubrick, who adapted her image of twins in his film \xe2\x80\x9cThe Shining.\xe2\x80\x9dThe transgender pioneer, prostitute and drag queen Marsha P. Johnson moved to New York with $15 and a bag of clothes, where she created her alternate persona, Black Marsha. She played important roles in the gay liberation movement and the Stonewall uprising, and she was a fixture of gay life in Greenwich Village, where she was known as the mayor of Christopher Street.Nella Larsen, a writer, became a star of the Harlem Renaissance with her novels \xe2\x80\x9cQuicksand\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cPassing.\xe2\x80\x9d Forgotten for years, she was rediscovered in the late 20th century and is now taught in literature classes across the country.Emily Warren Roebling oversaw the construction of the Brooklyn Bridge. After her husband (and the bridge\xe2\x80\x99s chief engineer) fell ill, she taught herself engineering and took over his duties.What is definitively known about Mary Ewing Outerbridge is that she set up the nation\xe2\x80\x99s first tennis courts, on Staten Island. What we think we know about Ms. Outerbridge is that she played the first game of tennis in the United States, against her sister Laura. What is still unknown is who, exactly, won that match.The Overlooked project will continue to add overdue obituaries to The Times\xe2\x80\x99s pages each week. But New York has more extraordinary women in its history than could fit into a newspaper.Some of them will be featured on LinkNYC kiosks this month, including Mable Lee, a jazz tap dancer and singer; Sarah J. S. Tompkins Garnet, the first African-American female principal of a New York public school; and Verina Morton Jones, the first woman licensed to practice medicine in Mississippi.And to learn about women who wielded political influence in the city, visit the exhibition \xe2\x80\x9cBeyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics\xe2\x80\x9d at the Museum of the City of New York.Here\xe2\x80\x99s what else is happening:WeatherToday will be mediocre at best.It\xe2\x80\x99s going to be a cold and cloudy Monday, with a high around 40. There\xe2\x80\x99s a chance of rain this afternoon, but we\xe2\x80\x99re likely to get snow overnight.A winter weather advisory goes into effect at 8 p.m.: Two to four inches of snow are expected, and Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s commute could be slippery.Keep springing forward.In the News\xe2\x80\xa2 A commuter helicopter crashed into the East River on Sunday, killing five of the people on board. [New York Times]ImageMembers of the New York Fire Department at the East River after a helicopter crashed into the water off Manhattan on Sunday. Five people were killed.CreditJeenah Moon for The New York Times\xe2\x80\xa2 Ronald L. Rice, a Democrat representing Newark in the New Jersey Senate, believes efforts to legalize marijuana would create more problems than it would solve in black neighborhoods, a stance at odds with his party. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 Two New York assemblywomen have written a letter professing solidarity with women who have been victims of sexual assault. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 About 500 students from the five boroughs gathered to give history-themed performances at the annual New York City History Day Competition. [New York Times]ImageKayla Noseworthy, an eighth grader from Michael J. Petrides School on Staten Island, and classmates presented \xe2\x80\x9cThe Constitutional Convention of 1787\xe2\x80\x9d at the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s annual History Day Competition.CreditMichelle V. Agins/The New York Times\xe2\x80\xa2 Jurors in the corruption trial of Joseph Percoco, a former top aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, appear to have resumed their deliberations, despite declaring deadlock last week. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 A peek at Lalo\xe2\x80\x99s Barber Shop, where Bushwick residents have been going to get a haircut, relax and chat for 40 years. [Bushwick Daily]\xe2\x80\xa2 An upstate county claims New York City is \xe2\x80\x9cdumping\xe2\x80\x9d homeless people in their community. [WTEN]\xe2\x80\xa2 A series of conversations about segregation in the city and how it impacts residents\xe2\x80\x99 access to opportunities gets started this summer. [AM New York]\xe2\x80\xa2 Today\xe2\x80\x99s Metropolitan Diary: \xe2\x80\x9cFourth Car From the Back\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\xa2 For a global look at what\xe2\x80\x99s happening, see Your Morning Briefing.Coming Up Today\xe2\x80\xa2 The \xe2\x80\x9cUnseen Oceans\xe2\x80\x9d exhibition opens at the American Museum of Natural History on the Upper West Side. Times vary. [$23]\xe2\x80\xa2 A March for Safe Streets, organized after two children were killed at a Brooklyn intersection last week, begins at Ninth Street and Prospect Park West at 6 p.m. [Free]\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x80\x9cEverything Is Hallucinated,\xe2\x80\x9d in which a science lecture meets a comedy show to explore how reality is not always what it seems, at Caveat on the Lower East Side. 7 p.m. [$15]\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x80\x9cMothers of the Movements,\xe2\x80\x9d a series celebrating black female pioneers in the civil rights and Black Arts movements, at the National Black Theater in Harlem. 7:30 p.m. [$15 suggested donation]\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x80\x9cIn Your Face New York,\xe2\x80\x9d a musical, comedy and spoken word show with prominent actors, writers and musicians at Merkin Concert Hall on the Upper West Side. 7:30 p.m. [Tickets start at $25]\xe2\x80\xa2 Rangers host Hurricanes, 7 p.m. (MSG).\xe2\x80\xa2 Alternate-side parking remains in effect until March 29.\xe2\x80\xa2 For more events, see The New York Times\xe2\x80\x99s Arts & Entertainment guide.And Finally \xe2\x80\xa6ImageJuliette Gordon Low, standing center, with a group of female activists.CreditHulton-Deutsch Collection/Corbis via Getty ImagesOne woman who won\xe2\x80\x99t be featured in the Overlooked series is Juliette Gordon Low, as she was the subject of a Times obituary \xe2\x80\x94 albeit a short one \xe2\x80\x94 at the time of her death.Ms. Low, who founded the Girl Scouts of America on this day in 1912, was from Georgia, but her activism made waves \xe2\x80\x94 and continues to do so \xe2\x80\x94 in New York and around the world.The city\xe2\x80\x99s first troop was established in Manhattan in 1913; the other boroughs founded troops a few years later.When women won the right to vote in 1920, local Girl Scouts \xe2\x80\x94 despite being too young to cast ballots \xe2\x80\x94 helped work the polls across New York. Soon after, during the Great Depression, the group held its inaugural citywide cookie sale. And today, a century later, nearly 28,000 young female leaders in New York continue their training in business ethics, environmental conservation, scientific research and more.Ms. Low now figures in a debate to wipe the name of former Gov. Eugene Talmadge of Georgia, a segregationist with white supremacist views, off a bridge in Savannah: Girl Scouts there are rallying to replace his name with Ms. Low\xe2\x80\x99s.New York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.For updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.What would you like to see here to start your day? Post a comment, email us at nytoday@nytimes.com, or reach us via Twitter using #NYToday. Follow the New York Today columnists, Alexandra Levine and Jonathan Wolfe, on Twitter.You can find the latest New York Today at nytoday.com.AdvertisementSite IndexGo to Home Page \xc2\xbbnewshome pageworldU.S.politicsElection 2020New Yorkbusinesstechscienceclimatesportsobituariesthe upshottoday's papercorrectionsopiniontoday's opinionop-ed columnistseditorialsop-ed Contributorsletterssunday reviewvideo: opinionartstoday's artsart & designbooksdancemoviesmusicPop Culturetelevisiontheaterwatchingvideo: artslivingautomobilesCookingcrosswordeducationfoodhealthjobsmagazineparentingreal estatestylet magazinetravellovelistings & moreReader CenterWirecutterLive EventsThe Learning Networktools & servicesN.Y.C. events guidemultimediaphotographyvideoNewslettersNYT storetimes journeysmanage my accountnewshome pageworldU.S.politicsElection 2020New Yorkbusinesstechscienceclimatesportsobituariesthe upshottoday's papercorrectionsopiniontoday's opinionop-ed columnistseditorialsop-ed Contributorsletterssunday reviewvideo: opinionartstoday's artsart & designbooksdancemoviesmusicPop Culturetelevisiontheaterwatchingvideo: artslivingautomobilesCookingcrosswordeducationfoodhealthjobsmagazineparentingreal estatestylet magazinetravellovemoreReader CenterWirecutterLive EventsThe Learning Networktools & servicesN.Y.C. events guidemultimediaphotographyvideoNewslettersNYT storetimes journeysmanage my accountSubscribehome deliverydigital subscriptionsCrosswordCookingemail newsletterscorporate subscriptionseducation ratemobile applicationsreplica editionSite Information Navigation\xc2\xa9\xc2\xa02019\xc2\xa0The New York Times CompanyContact UsWork with usAdvertiseYour Ad ChoicesPrivacyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapHelpHelpSubscriptions", b'Intersection, a smart city ad platform, unveiling new subway screens in Chicago - Curbed\nSkip to main content\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nSubscribe\nLog In or Sign Up\nLog In\nSign Up\nCities\nTopics\nHandbook\nShopping\nPodcast\nMore\nCities\nAtlanta\nAustin\nBoston\nChicago\nDetroit\nLos Angeles\nNew Orleans\nNew York\nPhiladelphia\nSan Francisco\nSeattle\nWashington DC\nTopics\nNews\nArchitecture\nHome Tech\nCampers and RVs\nInterior Design\nHouse Calls\nFor Sale\nLongform\nMaps\nHandbook\nShopping\nPodcast\n\xe2\x9c\x95\nFiled under:\nNews\nIntersection, a smart city ad platform, unveiling new subway screens in Chicago\nNew content platform allows for more real-time transit, and advertising, opportunities\nBy\nPatrick Sisson\nMar 14, 2018,\n6:36pm EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nIntersection, a smart city ad platform, unveiling new subway screens in Chicago\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nIntersection\nIntersection, the New York City-based advertising firm responsible for the LinkNYC kiosks and free Wi-Fi service, will begin upgrading its transit display and advertising platforms, starting in Chicago.\nThe company\xe2\x80\x99s new IxNConnect system provides additional real-time information management for city transit system, including improved train departure and arrival times, service updates, and the ability to better tailor emergency messages. It also works with touch-screens and interactive kiosks, and will also enable more location- and time-specific ads, allowing advertisers to send specific messages to a line, station, and individual display.\nIntersection will upgrade its system in Chicago and add 138 new screens to Chicago Transit Authority (CTA) stations over the next two years, eventually hitting a total of 400 displays across the city.\nThe company, which has contracts with Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco, and Dallas,\nwill expand the new IxNConnect system to Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s SEPTA and New Jersey Transit next.\nThis roll out shows the importance of these public-private partnerships for funding technological upgrades for U.S. mass transit systems, as well as the increased market for contextual, location-aware advertising.\nIntersection is backed in part by an investment from Google\xe2\x80\x99s Sidewalk Labs, the smart city firm set to help create a new neighborhood in Toronto to serve as a test-bed for new technology. The company believes that more context-specific ads can help \xe2\x80\x9credeem the credibility\xe2\x80\x9d of outdoor urban advertising.\nThe CTA has been an Intersection partner since 2010. According to Mike Gwinn, director of revenue and fare systems at the CTA, IxNConnect will allow CTA operators to target alerts and emergency messages to individual screens and stations, as opposed to sending messages to an entire route.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrands want to be relevant, and real-time transit information gets commuters to pay attention and look up,\xe2\x80\x9d says Scott Goldsmith, president of cities and transit at Intersection,\nGoldsmith says it\xe2\x80\x99s all about generating more advertising revenue for transit authorities, by helping deliver more real-time advertising opportunities for brands. For example, a previous Intersection campaign in New York allowed MillerCoors to display beer ads to subway riders facing a train delay, and point to bars near the closest station.\nNext Up In\nNews\nOur cities are getting hotter\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s killing people\nCities\xe2\x80\x99 climate plans are wildly underestimating emissions, and what to do about it\nWill this PoMo wonderland in San Diego be saved?\nNew affordable housing bill aims to add 1.9M units nationwide in the next decade\nAir pollution\xe2\x80\x99s invisible toll on our cities\nStar Wars land: An inside look at Disneyland\xe2\x80\x99s immersive new world\nMost Read\nAmazon is selling a $1,200 geodesic dome kit for your backyard\nThe Garden Dome Igloo is a 12-foot dome kit that can work as a backyard retreat, glamping tent, or kids play area.\nDo you hear marbles rolling in your apartment? Sites\nWeb Adv.\nSections\nPrime Times\nHome & Garden\nBanking & Finance\nHealth & Fitness\nSchool Spotlight\nCelebration\nFall Guide\nAnniversary\nSpring Guide\nDigital Edition\nSouth Edition\nSpecial Sections\nPage One\nSports\nHome\nEditions\nNorth/Northeast Queens News\nCB 7 OKs a pair of Flushing buildings\nProjects are in LGA flight path; board also hears that LinkNYC coming its way\nStoryComments\nPrint\nCreate a hardcopy of this page\nFont Size:\nDefault font size\nLarger font size\nPrevious\nNext\nPHOTO BY RYAN BRADY\nCB 7 OKs a pair of Flushing buildings 1\nLand use attorney Eric Palatnik speaking to members of Community Board 7 at Monday\xe2\x80\x99s meeting.\nPosted: Thursday, March 15, 2018 10:30 am\nCB 7 OKs a pair of Flushing buildings\nby Ryan Brady, Associate Editor\nQueens Chronicle\n|\n0\xc2\xa0comments\nCommunity Board 7 approved two applications on Monday for mixed-use projects on 35th Avenue by Farrington Street in Flushing.\nWhile the plans for the buildings are consistent with the zoning code, the developers are required to get permits from the Board of Standards and Appeals because of the nearby airport.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s in the flight path of LaGuardia Airport,\xe2\x80\x9d said land use attorney Eric Palatnik, counsel for the project\xe2\x80\x99s developers.\nThe BSA has to issue permits for the locations \xe2\x80\x9cto make sure that the height has been vetted with the FAA,\xe2\x80\x9d Palatnik said. The Federal Aviation Administration has issued a determination of no hazard for both of the locations.\nOne of the developments, at 134-37 35 Ave., will rise 211 feet above sea level, around 188 feet above the ground, according to the attorney. The 16-story building will feature residential units, a hotel and a community facility.\nThe other project okayed by CB 7 is the 15-story development at 134-03 35 Ave. The building will be 177 feet above grade or 209 above sea level, Palatnik said. It\xe2\x80\x99ll also feature residential and hotel space.\nAfter stamping its approval on the two projects, the board learned that LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x94 the wireless internet station program that has sidewalk kiosks in much of the city already, replacing pay phone booths \xe2\x80\x94 has some plans for Community District 7.\nRuth Fasoldt, director of external affairs for Intersection \xe2\x80\x94 the company that is installing the LinkNYC Wi-Fi hotspots \xe2\x80\x94 gave the board a presentation.\nThe public Wi-Fi system already has kiosks in parts of Queens and is expanding to the advisory council\xe2\x80\x99s area. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are coming down Northern Boulevard, that is how we are getting to your community board,\xe2\x80\x9d Fasoldt said, adding that kiosks on Main Street and Kissena Boulevard are also planned.\nMembers of the board were given a packet with information in the presentation, as well as a list of sites proposed for kiosk installations where there aren\xe2\x80\x99t pay phones.\nThe list includes sites in Flushing on Main Street, College Point Boulevard, Sanford and Franklin avenues, as well as 33-01 126 St. in Willets Point.\nNo board members said that they were opposed to the LinkNYC rollout in Community District 7, but board Chairman Gene Kelty said he didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the proposed locations for Main Street, given how busy the commercial strip is with pedestrian traffic.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to see people being impeded,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\nMore about Government\nYour primer for the Queens DA race 1\nNY makes two major transportation moves 1\nARTICLE: Hotels for sale spark shelter concerns\nComing through: lane on Fresh Pond 2\nAn unlikely race for a seat on the bench 1\nMore about Economy\nARTICLE: Create one now.", b"The Facts Behind the New York City Facts \xe2\x80\x93 Next City\nInspiring Better Cities\nMenu\nSign Up\nTwitter\nFacebook\nLinkedIn\nRSS\nsearch\nLatest News\nBecome a Member\nLogin\nFAQ\nFeatures\nLatest Feature\nEbooks\nTopics\nTechCultureEconomicsHousingTransportation & InfrastructureEnergy & Environment\nVanguard\nHost Vanguard\nSponsor Vanguard\nApply for Vanguard\nVanguards\nEvents\nJobs\nPost a Job Listing\nFind a Job\nTwitter\nFacebook\nLinkedIn\nRSS\nAbout Next City\nContact\nAdvertise\nPitch a Story\nNewsletter\nPress Room\nMeet the Experts\n\xc3\x97\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nThe Facts Behind the New York City Facts\nSamantha Maldonado \xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0 March 19, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nA LinkNYC Kiosk on the street in Queens (Credit:\xc2\xa0DanTD)\nBerry Villegas walks his dog at least twice a day, once in the morning and once at night. Along the way, Villegas scopes out the silver LinkNYC kiosks. These 10-foot-tall, silver monoliths have replaced sidewalk payphones in more than 1,300 locations throughout the five boroughs. The kiosks provide free WiFi and calling functions and allow users to charge their phones.\nRelated Stories\nVoter Advocates Say There\xe2\x80\x99s a Way to Increase TurnoutThese Winning Designs Rethink NYC MediansBoulder City Council Votes to Fund Citywide Broadband NetworkExperimental Theater Pushes Boundaries to Preserve Itself\nVillegas looks to the gleaming, 55-inch screens on either side of the kiosks, seeking new additions to a series of numbered New York City facts, rotating among the paid advertisements, event listings, weather updates and transit alerts. If Villegas, 44, comes across a fact that strikes his fancy, he posts a picture of it on Instagram.\nHis family and friends back in Florida, where he lived before moving to the city in June, now know that there is a superhero supply store in Brooklyn (fact number 139), that New York City gets 15 times more snow than the South Pole each year (fact number 206) and that Martin Hildebrandt opened the United States\xe2\x80\x99 first tattoo business in New York City in 1870 (fact number 304).\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose are just things that stop you in your tracks and you go, huh, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know that,\xe2\x80\x9d Villegas says. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nice to not just see someone selling me a phone plan or a movie trailer. It\xe2\x80\x99s nice to see just facts.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s the intention of Amanda Giddon, the woman behind the facts. Giddon works at Intersection, the company that manages the LinkNYC kiosks (soon to expand the network to Philadelphia). In addition to their primary functions, the kiosks host advertising and more than 50 other content campaigns, such as news headlines, information on how to sign up for health insurance, a series of comics, and the facts. The ads are on track to generate half a billion dollars in revenue over the next 12 years \xe2\x80\x94 enough to cover the cost of the LinkNYC kiosk services.\nGiddon, 24, grew up in the New York suburbs, and still remembers the sense of awe she felt every time she rode the train thirty minutes into the city \xe2\x80\x94 a feeling she still experiences.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThrough this work, I\xe2\x80\x99ve definitely re-connected with the city in a new way,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. Her interest in historical New York led her to recently pick up Jennifer Egan\xe2\x80\x99s novel \xe2\x80\x9cManhattan Beach.\xe2\x80\x9d She is eager to try Enoteca Maria, an Italian restaurant in Staten Island that features the cooking of a different grandmother each night. She heard about the restaurant during her fact research.\nGiddon kicked off the NYC Facts campaign in early 2017, right when she started at Intersection. Before then, she\xe2\x80\x99d been working in digital media for almost two years, after graduating from Duke University in 2015.\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy goal with this campaign is to really make New Yorkers feel like tourists and tourists like New Yorkers,\xe2\x80\x9d Giddon says. \xe2\x80\x9cThe strategy is making [LinkNYC kiosks] a beloved member of the community and making life more enjoyable as people navigate the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAs of this writing, Giddon has curated 349 facts and rolls out new ones on a weekly basis. The Intersection communications team gives the facts a quick review before the they go live. What makes a good fact? \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s something that can surprise and delight even the most seasoned New Yorker who\xe2\x80\x99s lived decades in the city,\xe2\x80\x9d says Giddon, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd also can arm consumers with things they want to share with their friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIt can be a challenge, especially if you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to surprise long-time New Yorkers. Giddon spends a few hours a week fact-hunting, which gives her an opportunity to follow her curiosity. From perusing Broadway.org, she learned that only five of the 40 Broadway theaters are actually on Broadway. According to data from Grow NYC, Greenmarket farmers travel an average of 90 miles between their farm and the city. She found that New Yorkers bite 10 times more people than sharks do worldwide while reading a Time magazine article. When FiveThirtyEight published a report on elevators in New York, the fact that 18 percent of the city\xe2\x80\x99s adult population could be riding in elevators at a time caught Giddon\xe2\x80\x99s eye.\nA partnership with the National History Museum\xe2\x80\x99s StarTalk Radio resulted in a series of celestial-themed facts. Giddon also worked with the Department of Records to create a series of historical photos displayed on kiosks in the neighborhoods where the photos were originally taken. Her plan to attend the Women\xe2\x80\x99s March inspired a group of facts about women\xe2\x80\x99s history and the suffrage movement in New York, all on display during the event.\nGiddon keeps track of her facts on a spreadsheet and estimates that about two-thirds of the facts in her collection haven\xe2\x80\x99t been published. Sometimes coworkers and friends will suggest facts to include, but Giddon must verify the facts before publishing them. Giddon finds the facts about firsts, such as the origins of the first cappuccino or Manhattan cocktail, to be the most difficult to pin down.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople feel so strongly about New York culture and history that I make it my duty to make sure we\xe2\x80\x99re putting the right stuff out there,\xe2\x80\x9d Giddon says with a laugh, adding, \xe2\x80\x9cIf something is wrong, we totally will get called out on it.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBecome A Next City Member Today\nSign-up for our newsletters\nSign Up\nSamantha Maldonado is\xc2\xa0a multimedia journalist based in New York City. She's\xc2\xa0interested in stories about cities, health, and culture. Read more of her work at\xc2\xa0samanthamaldonado.com.\nTags:\nnew york city,\xc2\xa0internet access\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\n0 Comments\nJoin the Conversation\nPlease enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.\nMost Popular\nThe Case to Repair, and Not to Replace\nA Worker Cooperative and a Community Land Trust Bought a Building Together\nNew York Could Be First State to Decriminalize Sex Work\nStrategies for Increasing Park Funding for Low-Income Communities: Upcoming Report Sponsored\nJob Board\nView all jobs\nLike what you\xe2\x80\x99re reading? Sign up for our weekly or daily newsletter!\nSign Up\n\xc3\x97\nGet our newsletters\nSign Up\nAbout Next City\nNews\nContact\nPrivacy\nTerms\nBecome a Member\nAdvertise\nPost a Job Listing\nFind A Job\nPitch a Story\nEbooks\nEvents\nVanguard\nLogin / Become A Member\nTwitter\nFacebook\nLinkedIn\nRSS\nSearch nextcity.org\nsearch", b'Wi-Fi may be coming to a NYC streetlight near you - Curbed NY\nSkip to main content\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nNew York\nSubscribe\nLog In or Sign Up\nLog In\nSign Up\nCities\nTopics\nNeighborhoods\nMore\nCities\nAtlanta\nAustin\nBoston\nChicago\nCurbed.com\nDetroit\nLos Angeles\nNew Orleans\nNew York\nPhiladelphia\nSan Francisco\nSeattle\nWashington DC\nTopics\nFor Sale in New York\nFor Rent in New York\nDevelopment\nNews\nHouse Calls\nArchitecture\nMaps\nTransportation\nAffordable Housing\nCelebrity Homes\nNeighborhoods\n\xe2\x9c\x95\nFiled under:\nBrooklyn\nNews\nWi-Fi may be coming to a NYC streetlight near you\nNew,\n1\ncomment\nThe city\xe2\x80\x99s next push to bring affordable, high-speed internet to NYC by 2025\nBy\nZoe Rosenberg@zoe_rosenberg\nMar 19, 2018, 10:00am EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nWi-Fi may be coming to a NYC streetlight near you\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nThe de Blasio administration is in the early phases of exploring how it can turn some of the city\xe2\x80\x99s 250,000-plus streetlights into high-speed public Wi-Fi hotspots, the New York Post reports. The move would advance Mayor de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s goal of bringing \xe2\x80\x9caffordable, reliable, high-speed\xe2\x80\x9d internet to the city by 2025.\nThe initiative is hardly out of the gate: The city has yet to determine if the plan would actually work, let alone how much it would cost to implement. The concept is similar to the LinkNYC kiosks that brought free Wi-Fi and public charging outlets to city sidewalks.\nIn November 2017, the mayor issued a request for information to internet service providers and related fields seeking ideas on how access to high-speed, affordable internet can be increased in the coming decade. It\xe2\x80\x99s unclear whether the idea to harness the city\xe2\x80\x99s streetlights is related, but Curbed has reached out to City Hall for clarification.\nThis wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the first time the city\xe2\x80\x99s streetlights have been used for telecom equipment. About 6,400 poles are already used or reserved by private companies, and a few streetlights throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn are already rigged up with free city Wi-Fi.\nThe move to diversify access to high-speed public Wi-Fi would be one more step in the city\xe2\x80\x99s agenda to combat the grip a select few telecom companies have on the city\xe2\x80\x99s access to Wi-Fi. A source of the Post\xe2\x80\x99s said the city is hoping the Wi-Fi will compete with Verizon, who Mayor de Blasio has had a long-standing beef with. (City Hall vehemently denies this.)\nIn de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s days as public advocate, he accused Verizon of making its FiOS network unobtainable to low-income communities, and last year the administration sued Verizon for failing to meet its promise to provide FiOS to all NYC households.\nCity wants to turn streetlights into high-speed Wi-Fi hotspots [NYP]\nNew York City Wants New Ideas on Providing Internet Access [WSJ]\nNext Up In\nNews\nNew York Botanical Garden\xe2\x80\x99s stinky corpse flower will bloom soon\nDigital billboards should be banned from NYC waterways: lawmakers\nNew York lawmakers vote to legalize e-bikes, e-scooters\nInfamous landlord to pay $3M in tenant harassment settlement\nNotorious B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x99s childhood home now a $4,000/month rental\nBrooklyn lawmaker wants to resurrect Triboro rail line\nMost Read\nNotorious B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x99s childhood home now a $4,000/month rental\nThe apartment where the late rapper grew up is up for grabs\nWhat $1M buys in NYC right now\nFive apartments, five NYC neighborhoods\nSign up for the\nCurbed NY Newsletter\nEmail (required)\nSubscribe\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy and European users agree to the data transfer policy.\nThis Article has a component height of 8. The sidebar size is short.\nLoading comments...\nThe Latest\nNew York Botanical Garden\xe2\x80\x99s stinky corpse flower will bloom soon\nThe flower, whose stench is similar to that of "rotting meat," will bloom sometime this month\nBy\nAmy Plitt\n1\ncomment\n/\nnew\nWhat $1M buys in NYC right now\nFive apartments, five NYC neighborhoods\nBy\nAmy Plitt\n4\ncomments\n/\nnew\n14th Street busway will \xe2\x80\x98threaten the wellbeing\xe2\x80\x99 of residents: lawsuit\nThe suit ironically uses environmental law to argue against the busway\nBy\nCaroline Spivack\n1\ncomment\n/\nnew\nDigital billboards should be banned from NYC waterways: lawmakers\nState lawmakers passed a bill that would prohibit the use of these ads in New York waterways\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n11\ncomments\n/\nnew\nLovely Ditmas Park townhouse with a huge pool asks $2M\nThe landmarked Brooklyn home has a ton of "old world charm."\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n3\ncomments\n/\nnew\nBig reveal: $675K for a bright East Village 1BR\nDid you guess the correct asking price?\nBy\nAmy Plitt\n4\ncomments\n/\nnew\nChorus\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nGDPR Commitment\nCommunications Preferences\nContact\nSend Us a Tip\nCommunity Guidelines\nMasthead\nAbout Curbed\nEditorial Ethics and Guidelines\nAll Systems Operational\nCheck out our status page for more details.\nVox Media\nAdvertise with us\nJobs @ Vox Media\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Vox Media, Inc. All Rights Reserved\nNew York\ntweet\nshare', b"NYC\xe2\x80\x99s streetlights may transform into Wi-Fi hotspots\nGo to the content\nGo to the footer\nClose\nNew York\nChange city\nNew York\n(en)\nEnglish\nEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nPopular cities\nLondon\nNew York\nParis\nChicago\nLos Angeles\nLisbon\nHong Kong\nSydney\nMelbourne\nPorto\nSingapore\nBarcelona\nMadrid\nGirona\nBrowse all cities\nTickets\nEvents\nThings to Do\nTime Out Market\nRestaurants\nBars\nMovies\nTheater\nKids\nArt\nNews\nAttractions\nVideo\nHotels\nTravel\nMusic\nTO Book\nClasses\nMuseums\nShopping\nNightlife\nComedy\nDance\nLGBT\nSex & Dating\nBooks\nCity Guide\nNeighborhoods\nMagazine\nSweepstakes\nVenue Rental\nTime Out New York\nNew York\nEnglish\nEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nPopular cities\nLondon\nNew York\nParis\nChicago\nLos Angeles\nLisbon\nHong Kong\nSydney\nMelbourne\nPorto\nSingapore\nBarcelona\nMadrid\nGirona\nBrowse all cities\nSubscribe\nLove Time Out?\nGet the best of your city in our newsletter, as often as you like\nD\xc3\xa9j\xc3\xa0 vu! Look out for your first newsletter in your inbox soon!\nMy Account\nMy Profile\nSign out\nMy Account\nSearch\nicon-search\nTickets\nEvents\nThings to Do\nTime Out Market\nRestaurants\nBars\nMovies\nTheater\nKids\nArt\nNews\nAttractions\nVideo\nHotels\nTravel\nMusic\nTO Book\nClasses\nMuseums\nShopping\nNightlife\nComedy\nDance\nLGBT\nSex & Dating\nBooks\nCity Guide\nNeighborhoods\nMagazine\nSweepstakes\nVenue Rental\nMore\nWorldwide\nicon-chevron-right\nNorth America\nicon-chevron-right\nUnited States\nicon-chevron-right\nNew York State\nicon-chevron-right\nNew York\nicon-chevron-right\nNYC\xe2\x80\x99s streetlights may transform into Wi-Fi hotspots\nNews\n/ City Life\nNYC\xe2\x80\x99s streetlights may transform into Wi-Fi hotspots\nShare\nTweet\nBy Clayton Guse\nPosted: Tuesday March 20 2018, 5:52pm\nPhotograph: Pixabay\nThe way that New Yorkers connect to the internet within the five boroughs is poised to get a major shake-up in the coming years.\nThe\xc2\xa0New York Post reports that\xc2\xa0Mayor Bill de Blasio's office is working to roll out Wi-Fi hotspots across the city\xe2\x80\x99s network of streetlights. The concept is part of the administration\xe2\x80\x99s push to give every city resident access to affordable high-speed internet, and it would theoretically compete with the likes of Verizon and Spectrum.\nThe streetlight initiative follows up on\xc2\xa0the relatively new LinkNYC kiosks, which allow members of the public free access to\xc2\xa0Wi-Fi, phone charging ports and the ability to make phone calls on a speakerphone loud enough to wake up an entire block. It is unclear whether or not the expanded\xc2\xa0Wi-Fi will be free for all, but it comes in a period when New York is seeing a rapid expansion of its wireless services in public spaces.\xc2\xa0Earlier this month, a pair of companies, Transit Wireless and\xc2\xa0Alcatel-Lucent, were recognized in the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s Genius Transit Challenge for their plans to\xc2\xa0install an LTE network throughout the subway system\xe2\x80\x94not just at platforms.\nThe technology required to bring\xc2\xa0Wi-Fi to streetlights is nothing new. Companies have been\xc2\xa0producing concepts for streetlights as part of the Internet of Things for years.\xc2\xa0But\xc2\xa0the backing of De Blasio to roll out a public\xc2\xa0Wi-Fi option in New York could be a game changer not only for the city but for the country as a whole.\nThe city is already working to phase out its old high-pressure sodium lamps (which give off that iconic orange glow) for brighter, whiter LED lights. Throw\xc2\xa0free or\xc2\xa0cheap wireless internet into the mix, and you could see New Yorkers\xc2\xa0get more excited about new\xc2\xa0streetlights than they\xe2\x80\x99ve been in decades.\nSign up to receive great Time Out deals in your inbox each day.\nAdvertising\nAdvertising\nShare\nTweet\nStaff writer\nBy Clayton Guse\nClayton is a digital editor for\xc2\xa0Time Out New York. He has an overwhelming love for south-facing windows and bicycles. Follow him on Twitter @ClaytonGuse.\nComments\n0 comments\n&nbsp\nGet\nLivefyre\nFAQ\nSign in\n+ Follow\nPost comment\nLink\nNewest | Oldest\nMost recent posts\nEverything you need to know about the Coney Island Mermaid Parade tomorrow\nChloe Coscarelli and Tom Colicchio's vegan pop-up Supernatural is back\nThis immersive outdoor jungle installation is coming to MoMA PS1 this summer\nBook the ultimate 4th of July party with a killer view of the fireworks\nTurk's Inn midwest supper club is revived as Bushwick restaurant and music venue\nLove Time Out?\nSign up and get the best of your city in our newsletter, as often as you like\nD\xc3\xa9j\xc3\xa0 vu! Look out for your first newsletter in your inbox soon!\nClose", b"New York City to use streetlights as WiFi hotspots? - Technical.ly Brooklyn\nCommunitiesBrooklynBaltimoreDCDelawarePhillyAll CitiesChoose your topicBusinessDevAccessMediaCivicSciencesCreativeFor EmployersCommunitiesPost a JobBecome a Talent ProAdvertiseMore InformationAbout Technical.lySubscribeOur ImpactBecome a MemberEthics\nBrooklynBaltimoreDCDelawarePhillyAll Cities\nNews\nJobs\nEvents\nLogin For EmployersJobsCompaniesEventsNews\nCivicMar. 20, 2018 12:46 pmNew York City to use streetlights as WiFi hotspots? The proposal was floated in the Post this week. It would be an interesting idea, taking the infrastructure of the 20th century and using it for the 21st.New York City to use streetlights as WiFi hotspots?\nBy Tyler Woods\xc2\xa0/ contributor Join 30,000+ readers who receive daily email updates from Technical.ly\nAdvertisement TOP ARTICLES A streetlight in Sunset Park.(Photo by Flickr user Michael Fleshman, used under a Creative Commons license)The New York Post reported this week that the city is considering plans to light the city with WiFi by retrofitting streetlights as wireless hotspots.The plan is according to unnamed sources by the Post, which\xe2\x80\xa6okay\xe2\x80\xa6but it was not met with an outright denial from the city. Reporter Anna Sanders writes that the city \xe2\x80\x9cwants to turn streetlights into high-speed public Wi-Fi hotspots as part of a plan to boost Internet access across all five boroughs.\xe2\x80\x9dIt would be an interesting idea! Using existing infrastructure for new technologies makes a lot more sense than trying to build a completely new one. We reported on something similar\xc2\xa0last month down in Park Slope, where Councilman Brad Lander has convinced the city and LinkNYC to use the WiFi kiosks planted all over the city to also show the waiting time for buses along the B63 route.NYC wants to turn streetlights into public WiFi hotspots. Exclusive from me: https://t.co/jaEmsbJDG3\xe2\x80\x94 Anna Sanders (@AnnaESanders) March 18, 2018The idea of using streetlights could also work for deploying 5G technology in the city. One of 5G\xe2\x80\x99s biggest challenges is how comparatively weak the signals are. Even though they are capable of transmitting way more data, they can\xe2\x80\x99t go through thick walls and geographical features the way the sturdier, current 4G cellular and WiFi wavelengths do.One idea is to simply broadcast from more places in dense cities, essentially flooding dense places with signals to overcome their weaknesses. Perhaps this could be a method for that. There has even been talk of the government building a 5G network, the merits of which we reported on last month, as a means of overcoming the difficulties of having private corporations do it. AdvertisementOutgoing New York CTO Miguel Gamino didn\xe2\x80\x99t respond to an immediate request for confirmation of this story, but we\xe2\x80\x99ll add that if he does.What would be the challenges such an idea would face? Presumably there would be a bit of regulatory red tape to get though, plus the question of cutting up the sidewalk for trenches if that\xe2\x80\x99s needed to connect the poles, plus questions of legality and rights.The Post article is well worth a full read. Read the full story\nCompanies:\nCity of New York -30-\nJOIN THE COMMUNITY, BECOME A MEMBER\nAlready a member? Sign in here\nAdvertisement BusinessDog Parker is no more. Meet DogSpot and its national expansion plans\nCivicBus countdown clocks to arrive soon at more LinkNYC kiosks\nCivicBrooklyn councilman proposes law banning after-work emailing\nSPONSOREDBrooklynYou can win up to $360,000 at the WeWork Creator Awards\nBrooklyn Partners Coffee (formerly Toby's Estate) Marketing and Events Project Manager Apply Now\nBaltimore, MD 21201 14 West Senior Software Engineer (Java + Apache Spark) Apply Now See more jobs from the Technical.ly Community\nSee all jobs\nCivicBeing involved in your community has never been easier thanks to this new site\nCivicNew York to boycott ISPs that don\xe2\x80\x99t adhere to net neutrality, de Blasio announces at SXSW\nCivicBrooklyn Councilman Rafael Espinal comes out in favor of electric bikes\nSPONSOREDBrooklynExplore how diverse teams build dynamic products with Dev Bootcamp\nSign-up for daily news updates from Technical.ly Brooklyn\nCitiesNetworkPhillyBaltimoreBrooklynDelawareWashington D.C.TopicsBusinessAccessCivicCreativeDevMediaSciencesServicesFind JobsSearch DirectoryBrandAbout Technical.lyAdvertisingEthicsContactWrite for UsEditorial Calendar Published by\nV. 3.4.0 February 10, 2019 \xc2\xa0 / \xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa9 2019 Technically Media Inc. \xc2\xa0All Rights Reserved.\nDo NOT follow this link or you will be banned from the site!", b'City May Turn Streetlights into High-Speed WiFi Hotspots - The Jewish Voice\nNew York\nIsrael\nNews\nNews\nInternational\nNational\nPolitics\nSpecial Features\nBusiness\nReal Estate\nLifestyle\nEntertainment\nFashion\nTravel\nJewcy News\nHealth\nEducation\nArts & Culture\nOpinion\nJV Editorial\nOp-Ed\nTorah\nHolidays\nJewish Features\nParsha\nDonate & Support Connect with us\nThe Jewish Voice\nThe Jewish Voice\nCity May Turn Streetlights\ninto High-Speed WiFi Hotspots\nDonate & Support\nNew York\nIsrael\nNews\nNews\nInternational\nNational\nPolitics\nSpecial Features\nBusiness\nReal Estate\nLifestyle\nEntertainment\nFashion\nTravel\nJewcy News\nHealth\nEducation\nArts & Culture\nOpinion\nJV Editorial\nOp-Ed\nTorah\nHolidays\nJewish Features\nParsha\nNew York City News\nCity May Turn Streetlights\ninto High-Speed WiFi Hotspots\nPublished 1 year ago on 03/21/2018\nBy Rachel Shapiro\nShare\nTweet\nAs part of a plan to increase access to the Internet throughout the five boroughs, the city is thinking of making streetlights double as high-speed public Wi-Fi hotspots, according the The Post\xe2\x80\x99s sources.\nThis is a similar idea to LinkNYC, which are former phone booths around the city that have been converted into free Wi-Fi and cell phone charging stations.\nWhether or not the service from the light poles will be free is not clear. It is also too soon to say what the cost of such an endeavor would mean to taxpayers, as the concept is merely in the preplanning stages and officials are still trying to determine if it would even be possible. If it does go through, the service would be part of a bigger push by Mayor Bill de Blasio, for every city business and resident to have \xe2\x80\x9caffordable, reliable, high-speed\xe2\x80\x9d Internet service by 2025.\nThis plan, if it happens, would take advantage of one of the city\xe2\x80\x99s most widespread and virtually otherwise untapped resources.\nCity spokeswoman Kate Blumm said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe humble light pole is actually one of the city\xe2\x80\x99s most crucial pieces of public infrastructure. We\xe2\x80\x99re continuing to explore how this basic street furniture will be part of our 21st-century city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOver 250,000 streetlights exist across the city\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs, of which approximately 6,400 are already being used or reserved by private companies for telecom equipment that expands cellular and Web service.\nIn certain Brooklyn and Manhattan neighborhoods, free city Wi-Fi is already installed on many light poles. However, those are only on a small scale and developed independently.\nThe Post reports, \xe2\x80\x9cStreetlights could also be a big moneymaker for the city. Communications companies eagerly put up a few hundred bucks a month to use a single pole already. But proposed federal regulation might hinder the city\xe2\x80\x99s scheme. The Federal Communications Commission has proposed measures that would limit how much control the city has over the streetlights, including the price companies pay to use them. Still, the city believes streetlight Wi-Fi could provide competition for traditional cable and internet providers like Spectrum and Optimum. Ultramodern high-speed 5G service might also be offered from the poles, bypassing companies like AT&T and Verizon. The city particularly hopes to compete with Verizon, said a well-placed source familiar with the project.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBack in 2013, while serving as a public advocate, de Blasio accused Verizon of not bringing its fiber-optic FiOS service to low-income communities. Verizon was actually sued by the city last year for its failure to fulfill its promise to offer all households FiOs service. The litigations are still ongoing, with Verizon insisting it met the requirements set forth by the city contract by running fiber cable by every residence, it just hasn\xe2\x80\x99t connected the cables to each individual home.\nBy Rachel Shapiro\nBy: Rachel Shapiro\nDonate & Support\nClick to comment\nLeave a Reply Cancel reply\nYour email address will not be published.
