Resource Center\nThe 5G Exchange\nAutomation Exchange\nWhite Papers\nUpcoming Webinars\nWebinar Archives\n5G Webinars\nLiveLearning Webinars\nTopics / Smart Cities\nWatch Out Telcos, There\'s a New Muni Broadband Wave on the Horizon\nNews AnalysisMari Silbey, Senior Editor, Cable/Video3/30/2018Comment (4)Login100%0%\nTweet\nAsk most cable and telecom network operators about municipal broadband and there\'s a fair amount of eye rolling, usually followed by references to failed projects that cost taxpayers money and never delivered results. But despite industry skepticism -- and often outright antagonism -- a new crop of city executives is re-examining their role in broadband deployments.\nWhy? First, the national discussion around smart cities has evolved. It\'s not just about putting sensors on street lights and adding cameras to intersections anymore. There is growing recognition that network infrastructure is critical for enabling smart city initiatives at scale, and with that understanding has come the logical deduction that owning and/or controlling network assets is valuable.\n"Infrastructure is the yellow brick road" for smart cities, says David Graham, deputy COO for the city of San Diego, who spoke this week at the Smart Cities Connect Conference & Expo in Kansas City.\nAnd for the first time at this annual event, that sentiment was echoed by a significant number of city and technology leaders now working to implement smart city strategies.\nSecond, while most cities recognize that they can\'t do everything on their own, they\'re also becoming more aware of where they do have leverage with the private sector, as well as the potential consequences of not setting ground rules with partners today before the Internet of Things takes over.\nA good example of this is the city of San Francisco. Mayor Mark Farrell has announced a new "Fiber for SF" initiative with the goal of getting fiber broadband to every home and business, and making free WiFi available in public spaces. According to Farrell, a team of folks from the city has been working behind the scenes on this project for four years, and after much research, he and his cohorts have decided that they want to create a public/private partnership\nto achieve their aims. However, a key tenet of that partnership will be that the city must own its network infrastructure.\n"This is really what people wanted: publicly owned from day one; [an] open access network," says Farrell. And, "We want net neutrality back. We want consumer privacy protections."\nFarrell says the plan is to sign a contract with a partner to run lit and dark fiber network services in the city for 15 years, all with provisions in place related to net neutrality, privacy, security and equity. That partner will build and operate a gigabit-speed fiber network, and then lease it out to retail service providers, earning a guaranteed percentage of the revenue generated.\nSo far, the city of San Francisco has released a Request for Qualifications regarding the project, and it is right now processing responses to that RFQ from potential partners. The hope is that the city will be able to draft a concrete proposal in the near future that it can put to voters for budget approval in November. If approval is granted, the city will then move to a Request for Proposal (RFP) process.\n"In terms of owning the asset itself... to me it\'s critically important that the public owns it, especially as you think about the revenue opportunities down the road," says Farrell.\nBut he adds, "To be clear, we\'re going to have a large opposition campaign from the telcos... And we\'re ready for it."\nPictured from left to right: IDC VP Ruthbea Yesner, Kansas City CIO Bob Bennett, New York CIO Samir Saini, San Diego Deputy COO David Graham and Aurora CIO Michael Pegues\nAnother example of network infrastructure leadership is coming from New York City. While CTO Miguel Gami\xc3\xb1o, who has helped manage several projects including the LinkNYC kiosk rollout, is getting ready to leave his position, Samir Saini, the former CIO of Atlanta, has just relocated to New York as DoITT Commissioner and CIO.\nSaini not only brings a wealth of expertise with him, but he\'s also gaining authority in his new NYC role with direct oversight of the city\'s telecom franchise agreements. Those franchise agreements are where the rubber meets the road for network infrastructure, and Saini is clear that he will pursue arrangements designed to make sure all of the city\'s residents benefit over the long term.\n"The infrastructure stuff is not sexy, but it is really important," says Saini. "And I think the core foundational component to any city being a smart city, and however you want to define that, is a connected city. So it\'s that basic foundational broadband access for everybody in your city. It\'s the equitable and affordable distribution of high-speed broadband on every street, in every home, in every public facility across our cities."\nYou\'re invited to attend Light Reading\xc2\x92s Big Communications Event\n-- the ONE event that delivers fresh perspective on the rapid transformation of the telecom industry and the road ahead. We\'ll see you May 14-16 in Austin -- communications service providers get in free!\nIn the latest wave of municipal interest in broadband network infrastructure, there is general consensus that cities and commercial operators are going to have to find new ways to partner. While a few communities are taking broadband entirely into their own hands, most are actively seeking help from the private sector, recognizing that particularly as the smart city movement gains momentum, local governments aren\'t best suited to handle the complexity of network operations and the rapid pace of technology change.\nNetwork operators also seem to be coming to terms with the idea that they have to court communities if they want to form successful partnerships and put themselves in a position to make serious money from smart cities.\nAt the Smart Cities Connect event, service providers showed up in force this year, with AT&T Inc.\n(NYSE: T) and Sprint Corp.\n(NYSE: S) acting as sponsors, and Charter Communications Inc. , Cox Communications Inc.\nand Verizon Communications Inc.\n(NYSE: VZ) all making the rounds at panels and keynote sessions. These operators want to open a dialog with cities, and in many cases have already begun that process.\nAs the conversation continues, they\'ll just have to make sure not to underestimate the will of the current class of city leaders, or how informed and strategic about network infrastructure they are starting to become.\nRelated posts:\nComcast, Cox Go Big on IoT, Smart Cities\nLas Vegas Bets on a New Network Edge\nPole Control Fight Gets Net Neutrality Nasty\nAT&T\'s Smart City Ambitions Take Root\nVerizon Takes \'One Fiber\' to More Cities\n\xe2\x80\x94 Mari Silbey, Senior Editor, Light Reading\nLike what we have to say? Click here to sign up to our daily newsletter\n(4) \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0Comment \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0Print \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0RSS\nComments\nNewest First \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Oldest First \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Threaded View\nADD A COMMENT\n[close this box]\nLogin50%50%\nkq4ym,\nUser Rank: Light Sabre4/15/2018 | 4:00:54 PM\nRe: Interesting stuff\nWhile it\'s probably mostly true that "owning and/or controlling network assets is valuable," and therefore the municipalities would love to control those assets, I would guess in the long run, corporate entities will actually end up with those assets. Due to the lack of expertise at the city or town level, and the capital needed to provide the services, it would almost seem a given that plan is not going to work in many cases.\nReply \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Post Message \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Messages List \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Start a Board\nLogin50%50%\nJoe Stanganelli,\nUser Rank: Light Sabre3/30/2018 | 5:46:36 PM\nRe: Interesting stuff\n> "Breaking apart bundles of fiber is exactly what the Trump DoJ required CenturyLink to do when it merged with Level3."You mean selling them off, right (like the interests in Idaho, for example)? I remember reading a lot about that as part of the deal.In other words, to clarify: You surely don\'t mean literal, physical breaking apart of the fiber? (That would be nuts, IMHO.)\nReply \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Post Message \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Messages List \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Start a Board\nLogin50%50%\nJoe Stanganelli,\nUser Rank: Light Sabre3/30/2018 | 5:43:53 PM\n"We want Net Neutrality back."\nUnfortunately, Farrell either doesn\'t seem to realize or is ignoring that you can\'t have real Net Neutrality and a sustainable and reliable Smart Cities and commercial IoT infrastructure. Certain traffic must be prioritized. Otherwise you\'ve got critical infrastructure facing downtime, drones crashing, and other catastrophes while Johnny Hipster tries re-binging Black Mirror.\nReply \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Post Message \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Messages List \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Start a Board\nLogin50%50%\nClifton K Morris,\nUser Rank: Light Sabre3/30/2018 | 3:10:44 PM\nInteresting stuff\nWhen it comes to smart cities, there definitely quite a few out there. However, how about \xc2\x93smart states\xc2\x93. For example, in this world community of Delta-Montrose,\nin rural Colorado, a broadband network award was awarded to a smaller start up.\nWhen the local ILEC, Centurylink, found out about this, they made a tender offer to buy the company out including the award and funding using \xc2\x93First Right Of Refusal\xc2\x94\nWhen legislatures found out about this award and subsequent change of hands of lining CenturyLink\xc2\x92s pocketbooks (funds were likely used to finance additional mergers), State Legislature passed a bill that requires FROR-based transactions to provide similar services at a lower price to the customer.\nThis change to FROR helps to ensure that good-faith negotiations occur and funding made available goes to ensure the services which people make taxpayer dollars available to purchase actually become available.\nChanges like these can also enable and allow Verizon or AT&T to build high speed data networks in areas where a local incumbent Baby Bell struggled to gain approvals or simply didn\xc2\x92t want to build because it had negotiated to a clause which allows it to still accept municipal broadband funding but offset the affected population of customers in another area.\nSee:\nhttps://durangoherald.com/articles/215479-colorado-rural-broadband-gets-help-on-two-fronts-general-assembly-and-congress Building broadband infrastructure can be relatively easier if cities and towns build their own fiber in the right-of-way, then lease it to carriers on a per-fiber optic strand basis instead of wholesale-selling of right-of-way rights to the highest bidder.\nBreaking apart bundles of fiber is exactly what the Trump DoJ required CenturyLink to do when it merged with Level3.\nIt\xc2\x92s a solution that solves many issues if cities and municipalities also look to installing their own bundles of 24,46,or even 128 strands as part of any upgrade or new roads or transportation project.\nIndeed, it was the DoJ realized the existing business model which included exclusive, in perpetuity sale of right-of-way rights instead of individual fiber strands placed companies at a disadvantage in the long term. Instead, new taxpayer-funded fiber should be laid whenever roads are expanded, paved, or large road infrastructure projects occur.\nThen from there, with inexpensive solutions from BaiCells things become easier and manageable.\nToday\xc2\x92s BaiCells even has a solar-powered LTE base station with a range between 8-10 miles that can run for 24-48hours (at full load) with only 4 hours of of sun to charge the battery.\nOf course, BaiCells could be mounted on a light pole, but solar is free and requires less electrical engineering work. Low-voltage solutions require one less sign-off.See:\nhttps://na.baicells.com/2017/10/30/baicells-technologies-releases-first-solar-powered-small-cells-product/\nReply \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Post Message \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Messages List \xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0 Start a Board\nEducational Resources\nsponsor supplied content\nOperator Strategies for 5G Transport: 2019 Heavy Reading Survey\nHeavy Reading White Paper and Verizon Case Study:\nTDM-to-IP/MPLS Migration with Circuit Emulation (CEM)\neBook: Building the World\xc2\x92s First Fully Virtualized Network - All rights reserved.', b'NYC announces cybersecurity initiative to protect mobile devices\n| Smart Cities Dive\nCONTINUE TO SITE \xe2\x9e\x9e\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nEnergy & Utilities\nTransportation\nBuildings & Infrastructure\nEnvironment\nResilience\nGovernance\nTech & Data\nAn article from\nBrief\nNYC announces cybersecurity initiative to protect mobile devices\nAuthor\nBy\nKristin Musulin\n@kristinmusulin\nPublished\nApril 2, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nDive Brief:\nNew York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced last week\xc2\xa0the launch of NYC Secure, the city\'s first-ever cybersecurity initiative, aimed to "defend New Yorkers from malicious cyber activity on mobile devices, across public Wi-Fi networks, and beyond," according to a statement. NYC Cyber Command will oversee the initiative.\nAs part of the program, the city will launch a free smartphone protection app \xe2\x80\x94 available to all New Yorkers in summer of 2018 \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0that will send warnings to users when malicious activity is detected on the device, as well as recommendations for self-protection, such as disconnecting from a dangerous Wi-Fi network.\nThe city will also add technology to its public Wi-Fi networks to boost security by protecting users from downloading ransomware or accessing phishing websites. These security measures will be added by the end of the year, and will also be deployed across the city\'s LinkNYC network.\nDive Insight:\nThe city\'s focus on mobile devices is driven by the increased use of smartphones and Wi-Fi enabled applications across the nation. The city reports that, in early 2017, mobile phones accounted for 50% of web traffic and by 2020, 30% of all cyberattacks will be mobile-based, according to Gartner.\xc2\xa0"The amount of personal information available and easily stolen from our smart phones \xe2\x80\x94 which we are all entirely dependent on \xe2\x80\x94 is staggering and requires robust security measures," said New York State Senator Brad Hoylman in a statement commending Mayor de Blasio on the effort.\nHolyman was joined by officials from various levels of government, as well as private sector companies such as McAfee, JPMorgan Chase, Palo Alto Networks,\xc2\xa0CrowdStrike and F-Secure, to praise de Blasio\'s actions on information security standards.\nThis announcement comes just days after Atlanta fell victim to a ransomware attack that caused outages across a number of city departments, and Baltimore fell victim to a hack that shut down the city\'s 911 dispatch system. Both attacks raised overall concerns about the vulnerabilities of cities\' operational and emergency systems, and brought into question some cities\' current measures to combat cyberattacks.\xc2\xa0By being proactive on cybersecurity, New York City \xe2\x80\x94 which is often the target of attacks, both physical and cyber \xe2\x80\x94 is demonstrating the various ways it can increase resident protection.\n"It\xe2\x80\x99s our job in government to make sure that people are safe online. It\xe2\x80\x99s a new reality,\xe2\x80\x9d de Blasio told Reuters. And while many cities have not yet faced this reality head-on, it is crucial that cybersecurity becomes more of a priority in all local governments for the sake of public trust, data protection and operational efficiency.\nRecommended Reading:\nReuters\nNew York offers free cyber security tools to public to deter hackers\nSmart Cities Dive\nInside the mind of Silicon Valley\'s chief privacy officer\nFollow\nKristin Musulin\non\nTwitter\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nGovernance\nTech & Data\nTop image credit:\nOffice of the Mayor\nGet the Newsletter\nSubscribe to Smart Cities Dive to get the must-read news & insights in your inbox.\nEmail:\nSmart Cities Dive\nTopics covered: energy, green building, transportation, waste solutions, connectivity, policy and more.\nDaily\nSign up\nA valid email address is required.\nPlease select at least one newsletter.\nBy signing up you agree to our privacy policy. You can opt out anytime.', b'Olympic Tech Spotlight - Sound & Video Contractor\nProducts\nMarkets\nStaging\nThe Wire\nResources\nPodcasts\nNeed to Know\nEvents\nNewsletters\nSubscribe\nAV-iQ\nAbout Us\nContact Us\nAdvertise\nPrivacy\nTerms of Use\nAd Choices\nSubscriptions\nPrivacy Settings\nProducts\nMarkets\nStaging\nThe Wire\nResources\nPodcasts\nNeed to Know\nEvents\nNewsletters\nSubscribe\nYour browser is out-of-date!\nUpdate your browser to view this website correctly. Update my browser now\n\xc3\x97\nProducts\nMarkets\nStaging\nThe Wire\nResources\nPodcasts\nNeed to Know\nEvents\nNewsletters\nSubscribe\nHome\n\xe2\x80\xba\nMarkets\nOlympic Tech Spotlight\nCynthia Wisehart \xe2\x8b\x85\nApr 3, 2018\nTo prepare for the 2018 Winter Olympics, South Korea built six new venues and refurbished six others in three different areas in the province: PyeongChang, an area known for winter sports and home to the Olympic Stadium; Jeongseon, a former mining area home to the downhill skiing courses; and Gangneung, a resort town and bustling port city home to the ice skating, speed skating, and hockey arenas.\nOne of the largest AV (and broadcast) suppliers for the sprawling games was of course Panasonic, which reports supplying a total of 1640 square meters of LED display in the competition venues, in addition to approximately 80 PT-RZ31K high-brightness compact 30,000 lumens projectors for the opening and closing ceremonies, 154 other projectors, 1079 security cameras, 20 camera recorders, 16 multi-format live switchers, and audio systems for 10 venues.\nBut alongside the large-scale anchor vendors, there were dozens of other technology suppliers whose products served as infrastructure and playback and solved problems or enhanced the guest experience for those who made the trip to South Korea. Here are just a few examples of the Olympics\xe2\x80\x99 technology moments, gathered from my inbox. \xe2\x80\x93Cynthia Wisehart\nEAW Adaptive System\nThe Medals Plaza stage within the PyeongChang Olympic Plaza hosted cultural performances and video displays of the competition during the day and Olympic medal ceremonies in the evening. Playback for these important events at this iconic location was reinforced by an Eastern Acoustic Works (EAW) Adaptive System provided by Seoul-based Dasan SR.\nThe one-floor Medal Plaza \xe2\x80\x93 at 1,267 square meters in size \xe2\x80\x93 features a wide, domed stage and an audience area wider than it is deep. The challenge, EAW says, was to blanket the outdoor area with clean, high-quality sound while providing the flexibility required for the different forms of entertainment.\nTo accomplish this, Dasan SR specified left-right columns of four Anna modules hung above the stage video screens (covered by scrim to match the dome). Large scaffolding towers were erected further left and right of the stage for the main PA, which was made up of 20 Anya modules. Two columns of five Anya modules hang in each scaffold.\nA combination of twelve Otto subwoofers \xe2\x80\x93 ground stacked 2 x 3 \xe2\x80\x93 located under each Anya array along with four SB1002 subs placed under the stage provide the low end that the programming demands. Six KF730 enclosures were placed along the lip of the stage for front fill while 16\xc2\xa0MicroWedge stage monitors were on hand for the artists.\nK-ARRAY Python\nGangneung Ice Arena served as the venue for both the figure skating and short track speed skating competitions. The arena houses two 60m x 30m ice rinks for competition and training respectively, and has a seating capacity of 12,000.\nBecause the arena reaches four floors aboveground in height, Olympic organizers needed an audio system that was precise and powerful for both the audience and the figure skaters performing to music.\nOrganizers asked South Korean distributors, Soundus to supply an audio design and specification that would provide the necessary breadth and accuracy. Their design included K-Array PythonKP52 line arrays, chosen for clarity and definition and an ability to provide continuous, even coverage that reaches the last bleacher in the stands.\nEquipped with Pure Array Technology (PAT), the Python has no crossover points in the voice range and no reflex ports. Only the closely-spaced, full-range 3\xe2\x80\x9d identical sound sources are responsible for the Python\xe2\x80\x99s true line array characteristics. It claims a perfect phase response both in the near and in the far fields and as a compact column it provided the necessary uniformity for the stadium seating in the arena.\nA total of 56 Python line arrays were installed horizontally throughout the bleachers to successfully provide accurate audio without obstructing the view of the competitions.\nClear-Com Communications\nSometimes technology that defines guest experience is invisible to the guests themselves. Proper communications during Olympics venue operations are of paramount importance to everyone involved.\nAt the 2018 PyeongChang Olympics, the team at The P.A. People and OneUp Solutions ensured that the Clear-Com systems in use kept a large portion of key venue personnel in touch before, during, and after events.\nThe Clear-Com system is used for the sports A/V presentation in the venue. Timing and results all link back to Olympics Broadcasting Service (the host broadcaster which supplies images and sounds to all the partner broadcast organizations) and into the actual sport federation itself, says Scott Davidson, senior systems engineer, Event Communications, The P.A. People. \xe2\x80\x9cWe also have three venues here that are fiber-trunked together, and that provides some real good flexibility to join the three systems together while also giving autonomy.\xe2\x80\x9d\nChris Dodds, managing director, The P.A. People, notes that every system has three major components: the Matrix, the Partyline, and the FreeSpeak devices. \xe2\x80\x9cTo our knowledge,\xe2\x80\x9d he adds, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is the first time that serious quantities of full-duplex comms have been used for an Olympics.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAt each of 15 locations, a mix of Clear-Com intercom systems are deployed, including the Eclipse HX matrix system as a central system, FOR-22 module cards for two-way radio interfacing, LQ-R4W8 IP interface for eight rings of audio interface to HelixNet, HelixNet Digital Partyline Main Stations, and a FreeSpeak II Base Station or E-QUE card.\nField equipment used by the operators includes 400 FreeSpeak II wireless intercom beltpacks and headsets (for mobile users), 115 FreeSpeak II transceivers and 30 splitters, 180 V-Series Lever keypanels, 440 HelixNet digital beltpacks, 100 CC110 lightweight headsets, 100 CC200 lightweight headsets, 500 CC300 headsets, and 300 CC400 headsets.\nSydney-based The P.A. People has the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest Clear-Com rental inventory and worked with Korea-based OneUp Solutions on the project. The systems are not cookie-cutter and require different quantities of certain elements (particularly at the endpoints), and Davidson says the flexibility of the system and the HelixNet beltpacks has been good for all involved.\nAll of the endpoints are IP-capable, so the system can depoly using network switches for all elements. HelixNet adds to that versatility because uniquely every channel of the Partyline system can share one cable and select the required channels at the beltpack.\nLeyard TWS Series\nFor NBC Olympics, a division of the NBC Sports Group, Leyard supplied three TWS Series LED video walls for the dramatic set within the International Broadcast Center.\nThe Leyard video walls include a 43-foot wide by 13-foot tall video wall comprised of 196 displays, a 16-foot wide by 8-foot tall video wall comprised of 36 displays, and three 4-foot wide by 7-foot tall video walls in an athlete interview area.\nThe walls uniquely integrated with the scenic design that soon became familiar to Olympic viewers at home, and of course to all the athletes summoned there for interviews.\nStateside Olympics AV\nBeyond the guests who enjoyed the 2018 Winter Olympics in person, and the millions who tuned in via television and internet, Olympic distribution got a new audience and a new twist with the first-ever public DOOH network featuring Olympics content.\nNBC Olympics partnered with smart cities technology pioneers and media company Intersection to show exclusive content of the PyeongChang Olympics across four thousand large format digital screens in public places in the U.S. throughout the winter games. This is the first time the official Olympics broadcaster is cutting content specifically for the digital out-of-home medium. The Olympics content was seen in New York City, Chicago and Philadelphia during its production of the XXIII Olympic Winter Games.\nLynkNYC, the public screen-based system in New York City\xe2\x80\x93the largest and fastest free public Wi-Fi network in the world according to Intersection\xe2\x80\x94was part of the program. LinkNYC was one of the first smart cities networks based on interactive screens in the U.S., It has always had a substantial public access component that went beyond a passive \xe2\x80\x9cdigital signage\xe2\x80\x9d model and towards more civic engagement especially for demographics with less mobile internet access.\nThe custom content for the 2018 Winter Games, specifically created for Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s urban network of digital screens, will keep people up-to-date on the PyeongChang Olympics. The program will feature morning highlights, primetime previews, an Opening Ceremony teaser, medal counts, real-time alerts, athlete profiles and more, spanning thousands of screens across the LinkNYC network in New York City; digital urban panels and platform displays in the Chicago Transit Authority; and digital bus shelters, urban panels and platform displays throughout SEPTA, PATCO and the streets of Philadelphia.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether walking the streets of New York, riding the Chicago L, or waiting in Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s 30th Street Station, Olympics fans in these three cities will be surrounded by the excitement of the Winter Games,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gary Zenkel, President, NBC Olympics. \xe2\x80\x9cEmerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur content partnership reflects a new approach to storytelling in cities using one of the most inspiring and unifying global events,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ari Buchalter, CEO of Intersection. \xe2\x80\x9cWith thousands of digital screens across our cities and transit hubs, our partnership allows us to bring NBC\xe2\x80\x99s coverage of the Winter Games to fans in entirely new ways, and create unique content and advertising experiences for consumers.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93David Keene\nFeatured Articles\nNews\nAudinate Unveils Revolutionary New Dante-As-Software Products for Manufacturers and Developers\nSVC Event\nTraining Track: Intro to AV Industry Training\nRelated\nThe Wire\nMorris Light & Sound uses new SL-Series for two main stages at CMA Fest\n\xe2\x80\x94Supports five stages with d&b loudspeakers\xe2\x80\x94 ASHEVILLE, NC 6.20.19\xe2\x80\x94Every year for 48 years, CMA Fest draws hundreds of thousands of country music fans and this year did not miss...\nThe Wire\nPassaic County Technical Institute Upgrades Studio with JVC CONNECTED CAM Cameras\nWAYNE, NJ (June 20, 2019) \xe2\x80\x93 JVC Professional Video, a division of JVCKENWOOD USA Corporation, today announced Passaic County Technical Institute, a vocational high school in Wayne, upgraded its...\nThe Wire\nAVL Integration Firm Clair Solutions Builds Out the Woodward Theatre at the Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame & Museum\nOWENSBORO, KENTUCKY:\xc2\xa0As an institution, the Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame and Museum is over 25 years old, but the building it\xe2\x80\x99s housed in is brand new. It overlooks the...\nThe Wire\nBenQ Wins Double Awards from Commercial Integrator\nCompany Took Home CI\xe2\x80\x99s 2019 Best Conference/Classroom Projector and Best K-12 Project COSTA MESA, Calif. \xe2\x80\x94 June 13, 2019 \xe2\x80\x94 BenQ, an internationally renowned provider of visual display solutions,...\nThe Wire\nWorldStage Goes Full Circle for \xe2\x80\x9cblu Marble\xe2\x80\x9d Art Installation in Manhattan\nDrawing on a long history of working with leading multimedia artists, WorldStage provided AV technical support for Chilean artist and activist Sebastian ErraZuriz and his latest ground-breaking installation, titled...\nThe Wire\nSHARC Turns to Symetrix to Refresh Its Audio System\nSunriver, OR\xe2\x80\x94June 2019\xe2\x80\xa6 At the end of the 1960s, Sunriver, Oregon, was constructed as a planned community 20 miles southwest of the city of Bend. The 2010 census shows...\nFrom The Wire\nSony AI-Based Edge Analytics Appliance and Midsize Laser Projectors Awarded InfoComm \xe2\x80\x9cBest of Show\xe2\x80\x9d Honors\n2 hours ago\nAnalog Way appoints Demetrio Faroldi as EMEA Sales Director\n10 hours ago\nYamaha STAGEPAS 1K Offers Enhanced Portability and Power With Remote Editing App for All-in-One PA System\n16 hours ago\nWomen in Consumer Technology Hosts 11th Annual CEDIA Expo Luncheon With Keynote Speaker Sam Horn\n1 day ago\nAbout Us\nContact Us\nAdvertise\nAd Choices\nTerms of Use\nTags\nSubscriptions\nPrivacy\nPrivacy Settings\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Sound & Video Contractor is part of Future plc, an international media group and leading digital publisher. Visit our corporate site.\nClose', b'Mozilla provides $280K in funding for cities\' gigabit projects\n| Smart Cities Dive\nCONTINUE TO SITE \xe2\x9e\x9e\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nEnergy & Utilities\nTransportation\nBuildings & Infrastructure\nEnvironment\nResilience\nGovernance\nTech & Data\nAn article from\nBrief\nMozilla provides $280K in funding for cities\' gigabit projects\nAuthor\nBy\nKatie Pyzyk\n@_PyintheSky\nPublished\nApril 3, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nDive Brief:\nMozilla has announced the winners of 14 grants\xc2\xa0in its Mozilla Gigabit Community Fund Program. The funding will be distributed to projects in Austin;\xc2\xa0Chattanooga, TN; Eugene, OR; Kansas City, MO; and Lafayette, LA.\nThe projects all use high-speed internet of at least 1 gigabit per second to improve education and teacher training in the winning cities.\nThe grants range from $10,000 to $30,000 each, for a total of $280,000 for this round of funding. Mozilla has now awarded $1.2 million in grants through its six-year gigabit program.\nDive Insight:\nAs more cities become gigabit communities \xe2\x80\x94 including recently-added Las Vegas, San Francisco,\xc2\xa0Lexington, KY and Colorado Springs, CO \xe2\x80\x94 there\'s a push to find new uses for the super-fast service. Although service providers often tout lightning fast download speeds that allow users to download 90-minute movies in 30 seconds, the average user doesn\'t fully comprehend the potential of a service that offers speeds up to 1,000 megabits per second. New York provides free gigabit Wi-Fi from its LinkNYC interactive kiosks, but again, the average user hasn\'t been properly informed of the potential such service holds beyond the "cool" factor of exceptional speed.\nThe Mozilla Gigabit Community Fund Program broke through that barrier and funded the development of projects that help communities with the ultra-fast internet service. This round of funding focused on education, both for enhancing student education and teacher training.\nEducation is an area that perennially struggles to secure adequate funding just for daily activities, much less innovation and technological advances. School systems are increasingly relying on partnerships to fill the gaps, such as with the partnership between Chicago and Apple to provide nearly 500,000 students with coding classes.\nA number of the 14 projects that received grants centered on virtual reality (VR). Many people who hear that term automatically think of video games and might not understand what that has to do with education, but the project developers found ways to make it incredibly relevant. They use VR on the gigabit service to provide students, often underserved students in low-income communities, with alternative education methods and opportunities they otherwise would not have. Plus, gamifying learning can be successful in making the information more comprehensive, which helps it stick with students better.\nA project in Lafayette and Chattanooga allows middle and high school students to take virtual reality field trips to solar energy plants, while another in Lafayette teaches students about broadcast and livestream technologies they can use as community journalists. A project in Eugene empowers at-risk students to be environmental watchdogs by using Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to track wetland restoration initiatives, and another environmental project uses VR to show students in Lafayette the impact of coastal erosion and climate change, especially the effects on a displaced Native American tribe. A project in Lafayette and Kansas City uses internet-connected emerging technologies such as robotic puppets and 3-D printing to teach history.\nThe funding doesn\'t stop at projects for students, though; it also extends to teachers, who are sometimes a forgotten group in the education sphere. Without their own training in emerging fields and technologies, teachers can\'t adequately educate students. One of the newly-funded projects in Lafayette trains elementary and middle school teachers about cloud-based programming and connected robotics, and one in Eugene will provide teachers at low-income schools with VR and video game development training. Another project in Eugene uses VR training to help teachers eliminate their unconscious biases, which could mitigate disproportionate suspensions and expulsions for minority students.\nThese programs and others are helping entrepreneurs to get more exposure for their technological advances and the benefits of gigabit internet service. They also help to bridge the digital divide that holds back low-income and minority residents from experiencing the same benefits of technology as more well-off segments of communities, which is a major concern as cities become increasingly connected.\nRecommended Reading:\nVentureBeat\nMozilla awards final grants from its $1.2 million Community Gigabit Fund\nFollow\nKatie Pyzyk\non\nTwitter\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nTech & Data\nTop image credit:\nRyan McKnight (Industry Dive)\nGet the Newsletter\nSubscribe to Smart Cities Dive to get the must-read news & insights in your inbox.\nEmail:\nSmart Cities Dive\nTopics covered: energy, green building, transportation, waste solutions, connectivity, policy and more.\nDaily\nSign up\nA valid email address is required.\nPlease select at least one newsletter.\nBy signing up you agree to our privacy policy. You can opt out anytime.', b"New York City street light Wi-Fi: Is it feasible? | Wi-Fi NOW Events\nWi-Fi NOW EventsAbout usAbout Wi-Fi NOWMANIFESTOOur ratingsOur credentialsMeet the teamContact usEventsCurrent EventsDownload Show GuideBuy Wi-Fi NOW presentations & videos2019 Washington DC2019 Shanghai2018 Johannesburg2018 Berlin2018 San FranciscoPrevious EventsExpoAwardsAbout awardsThe AwardsWhy enter?How to enterJudgesHall of FameSelection criteriaMediaNewsTVNew York City street light Wi-Fi: Is it feasible? [Analysis] by Claus Hetting | April 3, 2018By Claus Hetting, Wi-Fi NOW CEO & ChairmanIs New York street light Wi-Fi feasible? That is the looming question after the New York Post & others\xc2\xa0broke this story on New York City\xe2\x80\x99s desire to embark on yet another massive public Wi-Fi project. Here\xe2\x80\x99s our non-exhaustive take on this complex \xe2\x80\x93 but fascinating \xe2\x80\x93 subject.Even with the world\xe2\x80\x99s no. 1 city Wi-Fi flagship project \xe2\x80\x93 LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x93 expanding as planned, New York City wants more Wi-Fi. The latest idea is to equip some 250,000 street lights across all five boroughs with Wi-Fi in an attempt to expand the availability of affordable Internet access in New York.If the project happens, the new Wi-Fi service would be part of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s ambitious plan to push for \xe2\x80\x9cevery city resident and business to have affordable, reliable, high-speed Internet service by 2025,\xe2\x80\x9d the New York Post reports.The technical pieces already existThe idea may not be as far-fetched as it sounds. Swapping out old street lights for more energy-efficient LED-based units that include Wi-Fi APs is a fairly well-know concept, with companies like Wi-Fiber, Soluxio, Citintelly, and\xc2\xa0Ventev leading the way. Thus far nothing on the scale of New York City has been deployed. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean it can\xe2\x80\x99t be done.Ventev has developed as series of concealed antenna solutions for outdoor lighting that might be just what cities are looking for. Powering the APs should be straight-forward although backhaul \xe2\x80\x93 as always \xe2\x80\x93 is more tricky. Some kind of mesh network for backhaul seems an obvious choice. Maybe the time has come for using 60 GHz (aka WiGig) radios or something akin to Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Terragraph.Security is always an issue in Wi-Fi and there would be two ways of dealing with that: Either allow users to access the service via a connectivity app only or insist on using 802.11X/EAP including certificates for authentication. Either is possible although using a connectivity app might be the less costly and more user-friendly option.The timing could be just about rightThe timing could be just about right for a project of this kind given that the next major Wi-Fi standard is expected to hit the markets in earnest some time next year.The 802.11ax standard comes with at least two new features useful for outdoor dense city Wi-Fi deployments: Much longer range and much better performance in high-density environments.Add to this that the FCC within the foreseeable future may release a lot more spectrum for Wi-Fi in the 6 GHz band\xc2\xa0and that the new 802.11ax is already defined for use with this new spectrum. The Wi-Fi industry is also well on its way to introducing mobility (handoff), which means that the Wi-Fi experience should feel a lot more like what many consumers are used to with cellular.The key: Attracting partnersIn the end what would make or break such a project is the existence (or not) of a harmonious trifecta of money, city politics, and \xe2\x80\x93 well \xe2\x80\x93 even federal politics on regulating telco access to city infrastructure, such as light poles. The first question is of course who or what is going to pay for it.\xc2\xa0 A public-private partnership model may be the way to go, says one expert.\xe2\x80\x9cA large city like New York would be able to attract interest in a public-private partnership to fund and operate such a network,\xe2\x80\x9d says David Witkowski, Executive Director at Joint Venture Silicon Valley and co-author of the \xe2\x80\x98Public Wi-Fi Supercluster Blueprint\xe2\x80\x99 report. The report is \xe2\x80\x98how-to guide\xe2\x80\x99 on how to make free public Wi-Fi happen.Witkowski refers to the complex corporate and partnership structure of LinkNYC as an example of how a major public-private partnership model can be put together. \xe2\x80\x9cThe success of any such project will depend on wether Mayor de Blasio will be able to attract the right companies to make the level of investment required,\xe2\x80\x9d Witkowski says./Claus.\nWi-Fi Industry NewsJune 20, 2019 [Regulation & Policy]Europe\xe2\x80\x99s process to release 6 GHz spectrum to Wi-Fi on track, expert saysJune 18, 2019 [Breaking News]Emergency \xe2\x80\x98Ducklink\xe2\x80\x99 Wi-Fi to save lives during disastersJune 17, 2019 [Breaking News]Facebook takes on leadership role to improve Wi-FiJune 16, 2019 [News Exclusive]South Africa: Vast Networks\xe2\x80\x99 Wi-Fi offload trial with Vodacom \xe2\x80\x98faster than cellular\xe2\x80\x99June 13, 2019 [Breaking News]World\xe2\x80\x99s biggest Wi-Fi 6 trial tees off at US Open with Cisco & USGAJune 12, 2019 [Weekly News Brief]Wi-Fi news roundup: Aruba, Marvell, Quantenna, Newracom, and moreJune 12, 2019 [Breaking News]Greece to start building nationwide free public Wi-Fi networkMay 30, 2019 [Breaking News]Cuba to legalise private Wi-Fi networks by end JulyMay 30, 2019 [Breaking News]Wi-Fi 6 enters steep growth phase far outpacing 5G, says Contact: Tlf: +45 25341705 / Claus HettingFor questions or comments, please contact Chief Administrator charlotte@wifinowevents.com\nTerms of Purchase - Privacy Statement - Terms of Service", b"MTA bus times will display on LinkNYC kiosks | am New York\nMenu\nLATEST PAPER\nSEARCH\nNews\nPolitics\nThings To Do\nEAT & DRINK\nEntertainment\nReal Estate\nTransit\nOpinion\nLATEST PAPER\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nHome\nNews\nPolitics\nElections\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nPets\nSecrets of NY\nReal Estate\nCity Living\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nStaten Island\nTransit\nSports\nOpinion\nJim Marguiles\nCartoon roundup\nWeather\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nTransit\nMTA bus times will display on LinkNYC kiosks\nTwenty-nine Park Slope kiosks have already been updated with bus arrival information as part of a citywide rollout over the next several weeks.\nLinkNYC kiosks around the city will be updated to include bus arrival times over the next few weeks.\nPhoto Credit: Colter Hettich\nBy Vincent Barone vin.barone@amny.com\n@vinbarone\nUpdated April 4, 2018 4:18 PM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nYour bus may be late, and now it\xe2\x80\x99s easier to find out.\nMTA bus arrival times are coming to LinkNYC kiosks, the city announced Wednesday.\nTwenty-nine of the sidewalk kiosks, or \xe2\x80\x9cLinks,\xe2\x80\x9d in Park Slope were adjusted Wednesday to feature real-time bus arrival information for nearby stops. The Park Slope updates are part of a citywide rollout over the next several weeks.\nThe first few kiosks were located in the district of Councilman Brad Lander, who had pushed the city to update the kiosks primarily as a means to give New Yorkers access to free Wi-Fi and phone calls.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ... bus clocks we\xe2\x80\x99ve installed in our district and across the city prove that knowing when the next bus is coming is a real quality-of-life improvement for NYC\xe2\x80\x99s bus riders,\xe2\x80\x9d Lander said in a statement.\nThe kiosks, which also display subway service statuses, will offer bus arrival times for stops within walking distance \xe2\x80\x94 roughly a three-tenths-of-a-mile radius. While the MTA and third parties offer the same data through apps and text-based services, advocates said having the information on the kiosks helps modernize a bus service that has been steadily losing ridership in recent years.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCity buses need deep interventions before they will function adequately, and part of the path to turning around our failing bus service is to get more information into the hands of bus riders, in as many ways as possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said John Raskin, executive director of Riders Alliance, in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cAdding bus arrival times to LinkNYC kiosks is a smart and creative way to help bus riders save time, and it will help make the bus a more modern, convenient option for New Yorkers to choose.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSince LinkNYC launched in 2016, more than 1,700 Links have been installed across the five boroughs. More than 3.6 million gigabytes of data has been used \xe2\x80\x94 the equivalent of sending 36 billion emails, the city points out. LinkNYC once also offered web access, but the city pulled the plug on the feature months after the launch due to complaints that users were monopolizing kiosks to visit illicit sites.\nEat it. Drink it. Do it. Tackle the city, with our help.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\nBy Vincent Barone vin.barone@amny.com\n@vinbarone\nVin has been covering transportation at amNewYork since 2016. He first landed on the beat at his hometown newspaper, the Staten Island Advance, in 2014.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. Photo: Wikimedia Commons\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nNext time you need to know when your bus will arrive, you can look to some LinkNYC kiosks.\nCity Council Member Brad Lander, who represents Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s 39th District (covering Carroll Gardens, Gowanus, Park Slope and more) announced on Wednesday the launch of a bus time arrival pilot program for 29 Links within those areas.\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s 55-inch screens in those Brooklyn neighborhoods will now show arrival info for buses that are a short walk away from a particular kiosk.\nRecommended Slideshows\n40 PicturesPHOTOS: Blues dump Bruins to win Stanley Cup after agonizing 52-year wait40 Pictures\n8 PicturesPHOTOS: This Pakistani waiter looks just like Peter Dinklage8 Pictures\n36 PicturesAll of these celebrities have had their nudes leaked36 PicturesMore picture galleries\n16 PicturesThese photos of Trump and Ivanka will make you deeply uncomfortable\n16 Pictures\n4 PicturesCuba Gooding Jr. charged in Manhattan groping incident, police say4 Pictures\n2 Pictures4 fun things to do in the Lehigh Valley2 Pictures\nIn the coming weeks, the same bus arrival time feature will launch on Links throughout all five boroughs.\nThe pilot is a collaboration between LinkNYC, the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications and Lander.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98real-time passenger information\xe2\x80\x99 bus clocks we\xe2\x80\x99ve installed in our district and across the city prove that knowing when the next bus is coming is a real quality-of-life improvement for NYC\xe2\x80\x99s bus riders,\xe2\x80\x9d Lander said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, thanks to LinkNYC and DoITT, riders will have access to that information on thousands of LinkNYC consoles along bus routes citywide, within just a couple of weeks.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThere are more than 1,700 LinkNYC kiosks across the city, which already show subway status updates, weather, sports scores, information about community meetings, street closures and more.Related ArticlesBrooklyn goes 'Beyond The Streets'PHOTOS: Violet Chachki talks NYC Pride, kink and modern LGBTQ cultureHouse of Love is the progressive sex party that only Brooklyn could host\nTo city leaders, incorporating real-time data on buses is a logical next step and also a necessity for residents.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCity buses need deep interventions before they will function adequately, and part of the path to turning around our failing bus service is to get more information into the hands of bus riders, in as many ways as possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said John Raskin, executive director of the Riders Alliance, in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cAdding bus arrival times to LinkNYC kiosks is a smart and creative way to help bus riders save time, and it will help make the bus a more modern, convenient option for New Yorkers to choose.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTags:New York target for spoofing attacks\n1h ago\nView\nA new tool detects deepfakes with 96 percent accuracy\n1h ago\nView\nNew York Senate passes ban on Elon Musk\'s Not-A-Flamethrower\n2h ago\nView\nImage credit: John Taggart/Bloomberg via Getty Images\nsave\nSave\nshare\nNew York City\'s WiFi kiosks now offer real-time bus arrivals\nKnow at a glance when to rush to your stop.\nJon Fingas, @jonfingas\n04.04.18\nin Transportation\nComments\n182\nShares\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nSave\nSponsored Links\nJohn Taggart/Bloomberg via Getty Images\nNumerous cities display real-time bus arrivals on public screens, but New York City? Not so much -- you\'ll probably have to pull out your phone to know if you have a chance of making your ride. That shouldn\'t be a problem before long, as the city has launched a pilot program that puts real-time bus info on LinkNYC\'s gigabit WiFi kiosks. Visit one of 29 kiosks in Brooklyn\'s City Council District 39 and you can see arrival times for nearby stops at a glance, letting you know when you need to hustle.\nThe two plan to bring arrivals to kiosks in every borough in the "coming weeks."LinkNYC\'s stations were initially focused on plain internet access, phone charging and other fundamentals, but they\'ve gradually rolled in features like social service access and even messages to Santa. Bus data is just a logical extension of that strategy -- the kiosks are quickly becoming catch-alls for any info that might be helpful when you\'re navigating the sidewalks.\nSource:\nNYC DoITT\nIn this article:\nbus,\ngear,\ninternet,\nkiosk,\nlinknyc,\nmasstransit,\nNewYorkCity,\nnyc,\nPublicTransportation,\ntransportation\nAll products recommended by Engadget are selected by our editorial team, independent of our parent company. Conditt,\n2h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\nMore Stories\nFrom around the web\nAbout\nAbout Engadget\nAbout Our Ads\nAdvertise\nBrand Kit\nBuyers Guide\nContact Us\nRSS Feed\nSections\nReviews\nGear\nGaming\nEntertainment\nTomorrow\nThe Buyer\'s Guide\nVideo\nPodcasts\nDeals\nContribute\nComment Guidelines\nSend us a tip!\nSupport\nInternational\n\xe7\xb9\x81\xe9\xab\x94\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe7\xae\x80\xe4\xbd\x93\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe6\x97\xa5\xe6\x9c\xac\xe7\x89\x88\nJoin Our Newsletter\nSubscribe\nFollow Us\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Verizon Media. All rights reserved.\nAbout Verizon Media\nReprints and Permissions\nSuggestions\nPrivacy Policy (Updated)\nTerms of Service (Updated)\nTrademarks\nAdvertise\nPage 1Page 1ear iconeye iconFill 23text filevr', b'Bus countdown clocks coming to some LinkNYC kiosks - Curbed NY\nSkip to main content\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nNew York\nSubscribe\nLog In or Sign Up\nLog In\nSign Up\nCities\nTopics\nNeighborhoods\nMore\nCities\nAtlanta\nAustin\nBoston\nChicago\nCurbed.com\nDetroit\nLos Angeles\nNew Orleans\nNew York\nPhiladelphia\nSan Francisco\nSeattle\nWashington DC\nTopics\nFor Sale in New York\nFor Rent in New York\nDevelopment\nNews\nHouse Calls\nArchitecture\nMaps\nTransportation\nAffordable Housing\nCelebrity Homes\nNeighborhoods\n\xe2\x9c\x95\nFiled under:\nNYC Transportation\nBus countdown clocks coming to some LinkNYC kiosks\nNew,\n2\ncomments\nThe feature launched today on 29 kiosks in Brooklyn\nBy\nZoe Rosenberg@zoe_rosenberg\nUpdated\nApr\n4, 2018,\n4:45pm EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nBus countdown clocks coming to some LinkNYC kiosks\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nSome of New York\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC kiosks will act as de facto countdown clocks for the city\xe2\x80\x99s bus system. As of today, 29 Link kiosks in Brooklyn began displaying realtime information for busses up to one-third of a mile from their location, Crain\xe2\x80\x99s reports. The development is just the beginning of a larger rollout of the countdown display across some of the city\xe2\x80\x99s 1,550-plus kiosks.\nWhile the countdown clock function was always intended to come to the kiosks, it got a boost from Brooklyn City Council member Brad Lander who Crain\xe2\x80\x99s says began asking LinkNYC to post bus arrival information last September. \xe2\x80\x9cTo me, it is one element of the overall bus turnaround effort,\xe2\x80\x9d Lander said. \xe2\x80\x9cGood service and good information together will increase ridership.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe rollout comes at a crucial time for New York City transit, as riders across the city will be called to rely more heavily on alternate modes of public transportation given the impending L-train shutdown and other subway fixes that may see some lines close for weekends at a time.\nLinkNYC kiosks will continue to provide services including charging outlets, fast WiFi, and free access to features like maps and domestic phone calls. The bus information will display between advertisements and other public notices.\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrategically, what\xe2\x80\x99s going on is this vision we have around transforming the Link from being just the means by which we get high-speed public Wi-Fi to really being a digital public service assistant,\xe2\x80\x9d said Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications Commissioner Samir Saini.\nLinkNYC kiosks to double as bus countdown clocks [Crain\xe2\x80\x99s]\nLinkNYC pulls the plug on web browsing at its kiosks [Curbed]\nNext Up In\nNYC Transportation\n14th Street busway will \xe2\x80\x98threaten the wellbeing\xe2\x80\x99 of residents: lawsuit\nNew York lawmakers vote to legalize e-bikes, e-scooters\nBrooklyn lawmaker wants to resurrect Triboro rail line\nStaten Island to get modernized bus fleet this year\nMTA wants vendors to transform vacant storefronts at major subway hubs\nAmbitious bill to overhaul NYC streets would require billions in funding, DOT says\nMost Read\nNotorious B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x99s childhood home now a $4,000/month rental\nThe apartment where the late rapper grew up is up for grabs\nWhat $1M buys in NYC right now\nFive apartments, five NYC neighborhoods\nSign up for the\nCurbed NY Newsletter\nEmail (required)\nSubscribe\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy and European users agree to the data transfer policy.\nThis Article has a component height of 5. The sidebar size is short.\nLoading comments...\nThe Latest\nNew York Botanical Garden\xe2\x80\x99s stinky corpse flower will bloom soon\nThe flower, whose stench is similar to that of "rotting meat," will bloom sometime this month\nBy\nAmy Plitt\n1\ncomment\n/\nnew\nWhat $1M buys in NYC right now\nFive apartments, five NYC neighborhoods\nBy\nAmy Plitt\n4\ncomments\n/\nnew\n14th Street busway will \xe2\x80\x98threaten the wellbeing\xe2\x80\x99 of residents: lawsuit\nThe suit ironically uses environmental law to argue against the busway\nBy\nCaroline Spivack\n1\ncomment\n/\nnew\nDigital billboards should be banned from NYC waterways: lawmakers\nState lawmakers passed a bill that would prohibit the use of these ads in New York waterways\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n11\ncomments\n/\nnew\nLovely Ditmas Park townhouse with a huge pool asks $2M\nThe landmarked Brooklyn home has a ton of "old world charm."\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n3\ncomments\n/\nnew\nBig reveal: $675K for a bright East Village 1BR\nDid you guess the correct asking price?\nBy\nAmy Plitt\n4\ncomments\n/\nnew\nChorus\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nGDPR Commitment\nCommunications Preferences\nContact\nSend Us a Tip\nCommunity Guidelines\nMasthead\nAbout Curbed\nEditorial Ethics and Guidelines\nAll Systems Operational\nCheck out our status page for more details.\nVox Media\nAdvertise with us\nJobs @ Vox Media\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Vox Media, Inc. Resource Center\nThe 5G Exchange\nAutomation Exchange\nWhite Papers\nUpcoming Webinars\nWebinar Archives\n5G Webinars\nLiveLearning Webinars\nTopics / Smart Cities\nLinkNYC Pilots Real-Time Sharing of Bus Data\nNews Wire FeedLight Reading4/4/2018Comment (0)Login50%50%\nTweet\nBROOKLYN -- The New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT), LinkNYC and City Council Member Brad Lander announced today the launch of a bus time arrival pilot program across 29 Links in Brooklyn City Council District 39. Using bus time data, arrival information for buses within a short walking distance of Links will be broadcast on the 55-inch digital displays on the sides of Link kiosks. LinkNYC will launch bus arrival time network-wide throughout all five boroughs in the coming weeks.\n\xc2\x93From voter registration to healthcare enrollment, and now with real-time bus information on Brooklyn kiosks, LinkNYC has once again proven to be more than just fast and free Wi-Fi,\xc2\x94 said Samir Saini, Commissioner of the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. \xc2\x93I am proud to be a part of this expansive initiative where we can leverage technology to enhance public services\xc2\x97this is what keeps New York City on the leading edge of urban innovation. We thank Council Member Lander for working with us and look forward to expanding this service to bring value to New Yorkers in all five boroughs.\xc2\x94\n\xc2\x93We thank Council Member Lander for his advocacy around the need for real-time bus information on Links, which we will roll out network-wide in the coming weeks,\xc2\x94 said Jen Hensley, President of Link. \xc2\x93LinkNYC isn\xc2\x92t just the world\xc2\x92s largest, fastest free Wi-Fi network, it\xc2\x92s a platform to make life in New York City easier through delivering relevant local content and information.\xc2\x94\n\xc2\x93I want to thank LinkNYC and the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) for their openness to using the City\xc2\x92s technology and resources to rapidly expand access to real-time bus arrival information, citywide,\xc2\x94 says Council Member Brad Lander. \xc2\x93The \xc2\x91real-time passenger information\xc2\x92 (RTPI) bus clocks we\xc2\x92ve installed in our district and across the City prove that knowing when the next bus is coming is a real quality-of-life improvement for NYC\xc2\x92s bus riders. Now, thanks to LinkNYC and DoITT, riders will have access to that information on thousands of LinkNYC consoles along bus routes citywide, within just a couple of weeks.\xc2\x94\nLinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\xc2\x92s payphones to build the world\xc2\x92s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,700 Links are installed across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next few years.\nLinkNYC\nLike what we have to say? this box]', b"City Council program lets you choose what public projects to fund in your neighborhood | am New York\nMenu\nLATEST PAPER\nSEARCH\nNews\nPolitics\nThings To Do\nEAT & DRINK\nEntertainment\nReal Estate\nTransit\nOpinion\nLATEST PAPER\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nHome\nNews\nPolitics\nElections\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nPets\nSecrets of NY\nReal Estate\nCity Living\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nStaten Island\nTransit\nSports\nOpinion\nJim Marguiles\nCartoon roundup\nWeather\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nNews\nCity Council program lets you choose what public projects to fund in your neighborhood\nNew Yorkers voted on how to spend over $40 million on public projects in 2016.\nA Participatory Budgeting poll worker explains voting to a resident in Bushwick, Brooklyn.\nPhoto Credit: Official NYC Council Photo by William Alatriste\nBy Lauren Cook lauren.cook@amny.com\n@L_Cook865\nUpdated April 13, 2018 4:53 PM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nThat park near your apartment in need of a little TLC; a city-owned vacant lot that would be perfect for a community garden; an intersection that could benefit from public safety improvements \xe2\x80\x94 if you\xe2\x80\x99ve ever had an idea on how to improve the city, there\xe2\x80\x99s a program that wants your input.\nParticipatory Budgeting New York City (PBNYC) gives residents in certain City Council districts a chance to decide how to spend millions of dollars on public projects around the city.\nAnyone can propose a project during the yearlong process, which culminates with a week of open voting on which ideas should get funding.\nNow in its seventh year, PBNYC has launched\xc2\xa0a partnership with LinkNYC kiosks, bringing the project proposals to the streets of New York City and giving residents easier access to voting.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is real grass roots democracy in action,\xe2\x80\x9d said Council Speaker Corey Johnson. \xe2\x80\x9cParticipatory Budgeting is also bringing the community together; it\xe2\x80\x99s really about you. You get to come together, meet your neighbors, and make your community a better place.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe city also lowered the voting age to 11 years old, giving more New Yorkers a say in how taxpayer dollars are spent.\nOn Friday, Mayor Bill de Blasio cast his vote for projects at the 39th council district office in Brooklyn.\nLast year, residents voted on where more than $40 million in funding should be spent in participating districts. Previous PBNYC projects that received funding include: transforming an empty lot in Hell\xe2\x80\x99s Kitchen into a public park; the creation of a STEM lab at the Young Women\xe2\x80\x99s Leadership School in Astoria; and the installation of sidewalk extensions and a way-finding station at a three-way intersection in Borough Park.\nGet Breaking News emails\nThe latest about your city, as it happens.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\nOver $30 million in funding is available for public projects this year. Voting on this year\xe2\x80\x99s projects began April 7 and ends\xc2\xa0on Sunday.\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s what you need to know about the Participatory Budgeting process.\nHow it works\nEach year, members of the City Council have the option of joining in the PBNYC process by pledging a minimum of $1 million from their budget.\nCommunity members can submit project ideas online and volunteers, called Budget Delegates, will help develop those ideas into proposals that then go onto a voting ballot.\nResidents in participating districts are given a week to vote on all the proposals in their district.\nVoters can choose up to five PBNYC projects in their district. The projects with the most votes will receive funding from the council member representing that district until the full amount of PBNYC funding they allocated is used up.\nWhat kind of projects can be proposed\nFrom parks and housing to sanitation and schools, there are a wide variety of proposal categories that qualify for PBNYC funding. However, the funding can only be used on proposals for physical infrastructure projects, like renovating a public library meeting room. The money can\xe2\x80\x99t be used for proposals that involve improving services, such as adding more staff to a city resource program.\nYou can submit your idea online via the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s website, however, this year\xe2\x80\x99s PBNYC proposal cycle has already closed.\nBelow is a list of project categories that are eligible for funding:\nParks and recreation Sanitation Transit and transportation Housing Environment Schools and education Public health Youth Streets and sidewalks Seniors Public safety Culture and community facilities\nCouncil districts participating this year\nThere are 27 council districts, representing parts of each borough, that have finalized ballots for this year\xe2\x80\x99s PBNYC vote. The following districts are participating this year: 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 15, 16, 17, 19, 22, 26, 27, 29, 31, 33, 34, 35, 36, 38, 39, 40, 44, 45, 47, 49.\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re unsure what district you live in, you can find out by visiting the City Council PBNYC website.\nWhat projects are being proposed in which districts this year\nNow that you know whether your council member is participating, you can find out what projects are being proposed in your neighborhood online via the City Council PBNYC website. Clicking on your council member\xe2\x80\x99s name will bring you to a page that lists the proposed projects, with a description and funding amount for each.\nWhen and how you can vote\nVoting is open to all New Yorkers 11 years old or older\xc2\xa0who live in a participating council district. Each district lists several locations where you can vote in person or you can vote online.\nVoting for this year\xe2\x80\x99s PBNYC projects began Saturday, April 7, and will end on Sunday, April 15. In order to vote, you will need to sign an affidavit that confirms your residency and age.\nHow to get involved in PBNYC\nThe City Council welcomes volunteers interested in getting involved in the PBNYC process beyond proposals and voting.\nCommunity members can become a volunteer Budget Delegate or poll worker, join a district committee or PBNYC citywide committee and participate in a working group that provides input on initiatives that impact PBNYC.\nBy Lauren Cook lauren.cook@amny.com\n@L_Cook865\nLauren joined amNY.com as a news editor in 2016. Previously, she worked as a web producer at CBS New York and News 12.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. Learn more and share your input.\nMost popular\nWhat to know before watching the Central Park 5 series 'Mrs. Maisel' giving out free Midge-approved lunches MTA touts 7 train performance as it fights for funding Senate, Assembly pass\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill A look at where the Central Park 5 are now\nTop News stories\nHere's what's in the NY\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill\nYour guide to next week's primary elections\nHALT solitary confinement fails, but lawmakers strike a deal\nSenate, Assembly pass\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill\nWatch the Democratic presidential debates at these parties\nMan who spray-painted\xc2\xa0anti-Muslim messages\xc2\xa0arrested: Cops\nNews photos & videos\nDon't just march, celebrate at these Pride parties\nStonewall's resident bartender Tree recalls riots ahead of 50th anniversary\nHow does a guide dog train in NYC?\nCentral Park puts finishing touches on Belvedere Castle\nThe best places to view the July Fourth fireworks\nSee scenes from this year's Puerto Rican Day Parade\nQuick Links\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s paper\nNewsletters\nSecrets of New York\nEvents this week\nWeekend Best Bets\nStaff & Bios\nSitemap\nPartners\nNewsday\nNews 12\nNewsday Homes\nNewsday Jobs\nNewsday Connect\nHometown Shopper\nNews12 Varsity\nSections\nNews\nTransit\nPolitics\nElections\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nContact us | Jobs at amnewyork | PRIVACY\nPOLICY | TERMS OF SERVICE\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\n240 W 35TH ST., 9TH FLOOR NY, NY 10001 646.293.9499 FAX: 212.239.2828 | Newsday. All rights reserved.", b"City Council program lets you choose what public projects to fund in your neighborhood | am New York\nMenu\nLATEST PAPER\nSEARCH\nNews\nPolitics\nThings To Do\nEAT & DRINK\nEntertainment\nReal Estate\nTransit\nOpinion\nLATEST PAPER\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nHome\nNews\nPolitics\nElections\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nPets\nSecrets of NY\nReal Estate\nCity Living\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nStaten Island\nTransit\nSports\nOpinion\nJim Marguiles\nCartoon roundup\nWeather\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nNews\nCity Council program lets you choose what public projects to fund in your neighborhood\nNew Yorkers voted on how to spend over $40 million on public projects in 2016.\nA Participatory Budgeting poll worker explains voting to a resident in Bushwick, Brooklyn.\nPhoto Credit: Official NYC Council Photo by William Alatriste\nBy Lauren Cook lauren.cook@amny.com\n@L_Cook865\nUpdated April 13, 2018 4:53 PM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nThat park near your apartment in need of a little TLC; a city-owned vacant lot that would be perfect for a community garden; an intersection that could benefit from public safety improvements \xe2\x80\x94 if you\xe2\x80\x99ve ever had an idea on how to improve the city, there\xe2\x80\x99s a program that wants your input.\nParticipatory Budgeting New York City (PBNYC) gives residents in certain City Council districts a chance to decide how to spend millions of dollars on public projects around the city.\nAnyone can propose a project during the yearlong process, which culminates with a week of open voting on which ideas should get funding.\nNow in its seventh year, PBNYC has launched\xc2\xa0a partnership with LinkNYC kiosks, bringing the project proposals to the streets of New York City and giving residents easier access to voting.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is real grass roots democracy in action,\xe2\x80\x9d said Council Speaker Corey Johnson. \xe2\x80\x9cParticipatory Budgeting is also bringing the community together; it\xe2\x80\x99s really about you. You get to come together, meet your neighbors, and make your community a better place.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe city also lowered the voting age to 11 years old, giving more New Yorkers a say in how taxpayer dollars are spent.\nOn Friday, Mayor Bill de Blasio cast his vote for projects at the 39th council district office in Brooklyn.\nLast year, residents voted on where more than $40 million in funding should be spent in participating districts. Previous PBNYC projects that received funding include: transforming an empty lot in Hell\xe2\x80\x99s Kitchen into a public park; the creation of a STEM lab at the Young Women\xe2\x80\x99s Leadership School in Astoria; and the installation of sidewalk extensions and a way-finding station at a three-way intersection in Borough Park.\nGet Breaking News emails\nThe latest about your city, as it happens.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\nOver $30 million in funding is available for public projects this year. Voting on this year\xe2\x80\x99s projects began April 7 and ends\xc2\xa0on Sunday.\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s what you need to know about the Participatory Budgeting process.\nHow it works\nEach year, members of the City Council have the option of joining in the PBNYC process by pledging a minimum of $1 million from their budget.\nCommunity members can submit project ideas online and volunteers, called Budget Delegates, will help develop those ideas into proposals that then go onto a voting ballot.\nResidents in participating districts are given a week to vote on all the proposals in their district.\nVoters can choose up to five PBNYC projects in their district. The projects with the most votes will receive funding from the council member representing that district until the full amount of PBNYC funding they allocated is used up.\nWhat kind of projects can be proposed\nFrom parks and housing to sanitation and schools, there are a wide variety of proposal categories that qualify for PBNYC funding. However, the funding can only be used on proposals for physical infrastructure projects, like renovating a public library meeting room. The money can\xe2\x80\x99t be used for proposals that involve improving services, such as adding more staff to a city resource program.\nYou can submit your idea online via the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s website, however, this year\xe2\x80\x99s PBNYC proposal cycle has already closed.\nBelow is a list of project categories that are eligible for funding:\nParks and recreation Sanitation Transit and transportation Housing Environment Schools and education Public health Youth Streets and sidewalks Seniors Public safety Culture and community facilities\nCouncil districts participating this year\nThere are 27 council districts, representing parts of each borough, that have finalized ballots for this year\xe2\x80\x99s PBNYC vote. The following districts are participating this year: 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 15, 16, 17, 19, 22, 26, 27, 29, 31, 33, 34, 35, 36, 38, 39, 40, 44, 45, 47, 49.\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re unsure what district you live in, you can find out by visiting the City Council PBNYC website.\nWhat projects are being proposed in which districts this year\nNow that you know whether your council member is participating, you can find out what projects are being proposed in your neighborhood online via the City Council PBNYC website. Clicking on your council member\xe2\x80\x99s name will bring you to a page that lists the proposed projects, with a description and funding amount for each.\nWhen and how you can vote\nVoting is open to all New Yorkers 11 years old or older\xc2\xa0who live in a participating council district. Each district lists several locations where you can vote in person or you can vote online.\nVoting for this year\xe2\x80\x99s PBNYC projects began Saturday, April 7, and will end on Sunday, April 15. In order to vote, you will need to sign an affidavit that confirms your residency and age.\nHow to get involved in PBNYC\nThe City Council welcomes volunteers interested in getting involved in the PBNYC process beyond proposals and voting.\nCommunity members can become a volunteer Budget Delegate or poll worker, join a district committee or PBNYC citywide committee and participate in a working group that provides input on initiatives that impact PBNYC.\nBy Lauren Cook lauren.cook@amny.com\n@L_Cook865\nLauren joined amNY.com as a news editor in 2016. Previously, she worked as a web producer at CBS New York and News 12.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. Learn more and share your input.\nMost popular\nWhat to know before watching the Central Park 5 series 'Mrs. Maisel' giving out free Midge-approved lunches MTA touts 7 train performance as it fights for funding Senate, Assembly pass\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill A look at where the Central Park 5 are now\nTop News stories\nHere's what's in the NY\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill\nYour guide to next week's primary elections\nHALT solitary confinement fails, but lawmakers strike a deal\nSenate, Assembly pass\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill\nWatch the Democratic presidential debates at these parties\nMan who spray-painted\xc2\xa0anti-Muslim messages\xc2\xa0arrested: Cops\nNews photos & videos\nDon't just march, celebrate at these Pride parties\nStonewall's resident bartender Tree recalls riots ahead of 50th anniversary\nHow does a guide dog train in NYC?\nCentral Park puts finishing touches on Belvedere Castle\nThe best places to view the July Fourth fireworks\nSee scenes from this year's Puerto Rican Day Parade\nQuick Links\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s paper\nNewsletters\nSecrets of New York\nEvents this week\nWeekend Best Bets\nStaff & Bios\nSitemap\nPartners\nNewsday\nNews 12\nNewsday Homes\nNewsday Jobs\nNewsday Connect\nHometown Shopper\nNews12 Varsity\nSections\nNews\nTransit\nPolitics\nElections\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nContact us | Jobs at amnewyork | PRIVACY\nPOLICY | TERMS OF SERVICE\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\n240 W 35TH ST., 9TH FLOOR NY, NY 10001 646.293.9499 FAX: 212.239.2828 | Newsday. (Courtesy: Intersection)\nBy Karen Yi | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com\nNewark will be the fourth city in the world -- and the first in New Jersey -- to provide high-speed wifi "Link" kiosks that will allow pedestrians to charge their phones, make a call or download music and movies, free of charge.The multi-million dollar investment in the city by\xc2\xa0Intersection, a New York-based technology company, comes at an exciting time for Newark,\xc2\xa0which was recently named a\xc2\xa0finalist\xc2\xa0for Amazon\'s second headquarters.\n"Newark is here, we are on the map," Aisha Glover, president of the Newark Community Economic Development Corporation (NCEDC) said\xc2\xa0during\xc2\xa0a Wednesday press conference at NJIT. "We are claiming our space. We certainly feel like this is our moment."The city will also host this year\'s VOICE Technology Summit, the largest voice technology conference that gathers 1,500 developers and designers. The summit is sponsored by Amazon Alexa."The idea that this city is\xc2\xa0on its way to be a tech hub is outstanding,"\xc2\xa0NJIT President Joel Bloom said. The college will host the three-day conference July 24-26.Dan Doctoroff, chairman of Intersection, echoed those sentiments and said the company was betting on Newark. Intersection will install 45 LinkNWK sidewalk kiosks by the end of the year -- at no cost to the city.Many\xc2\xa0of the kiosks will be\xc2\xa0installed in the downtown corridor (along Broad and Market streets and Irvine Turner and Martin Luther King Blvds) with at least two kiosks in the each ward, including in major commercial corridors like Ferry Street, Clinton Avenue and Bloomfield Avenue.\nDoctoroff declined to detail the company\'s investment except to say it was "several million dollars." Intersection makes its money through\xc2\xa0ads on the digital screens and some of that revenue will also be shared with NCEDC and the city. A minority investor in Intersection is Sidewalk Labs, which was created by Alphabet, the parent company of Google.LinkNWK will let passersby make calls anywhere in the U.S., charge their devices and provide free high-speed\xc2\xa0wifi connected to Newark Fiber -- the city\'s public-private gigabit data network. The 55-inch\xc2\xa0digital screens on each side will also improve city communications and help inform residents of garbage pick-up days, parking rules and relate other important messages.\nLinkNYC kiosk.\nIntersection already operates 1,600 Link kiosks in New York City, London and Philadelphia. And it\'s not without its kinks. When the program first rolled out in New York in 2016, there were\xc2\xa0reports that people were using the devices to watch pornography.Doctoroff said\xc2\xa0Intersection\xc2\xa0learned from operating two years in New York City\xc2\xa0and would apply those lesson in Newark, including turning off the internet browser and having a robust privacy policy.\nThe bigger goal, he said, was to help cities grow by improving connectivity and communication. And Newark, he said, was finally\xc2\xa0growing as a tech hub."We are looking for places where we can grow and utilize assets that are in the ground," said Doctoroff, a former deputy mayor in New York City who noted that he was born in Newark. "This is Newark\'s time."Karen Yi may be reached at\xc2\xa0kyi@njadvancemedia.com. Follow her\xc2\xa0on Twitter at\xc2\xa0@karen_yi\xc2\xa0or on\xc2\xa0Facebook.\nView Comments\nFooter Navigation\nDisclaimer\nRegistration on or use of this site constitutes acceptance of our User Agreement and Privacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 New Jersey On-Line LLC.
