The Jazz Bee\nAll Programs A-Z\nMusic\nJazz Night in America\nThe Checkout\nRhythm Revue\nRadar\nTake Five\nPerformances and Interviews\nDeep Dive\nNews\nWBGO Newsroom\nNPR News\nWBGO Journal\nNewark Today\nAsk Governor Murphy\nSportsjam\nSubmit a News Tip\nListen & Connect\nHow to listen online\nMobile Apps\nRadio Coverage Map / Reception\nJazz E-News\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nCalendars & Events\nMusic Calendar\nArts Calendar\nWBGO Travel & Events\nWBGO Day Trips to Newport Jazz Festival\nWBGO Weekend Trip to Newport Jazz Festival\nSupport\nContribute Now\nMembership Benefits\nJazz Leadership Society\nVolunteer\nDonate a Vehicle\nLegacy Giving\nUnderwriting Opportunities\nAbout\nContact Us\nStaff\nBoard of Trustees\nCommunity Advisory Board\nEmployment and Internships\nMedia Fellowship Program\nReports & Public File\nPress\nSearch\nNewark Link Kiosks, Amazon Conference Signal Growing Tech Industry\nBy Ang Santos\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nApr 4,\n2018\nTwitterFacebookGoogle+Email\nListen\nListening...\n/ 0:42\nThe City of Newark will install high-speed Wi-Fi kiosks on city streets by the end of the year.\nWBGO\xe2\x80\x99s Ang Santos reports.\nThe initial installment of 45 Link kiosks will be in the busiest parts of the city. Credit Ang Santos / WBGO\nLink London, Link NYC, now Link Newark.\xc2\xa0 The free Wi-Fi, phone call, device charging kiosks are a quality of life change for residents and visitors says Dan Doctoroff of Intersection, the company that supplies the technology. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople saving money on their data plans as they go down to the corner and download movies.\xc2\xa0 While waiting for the bus they download their music.\xc2\xa0 It\xe2\x80\x99s really saved tens of millions of dollars for people on their data plans,\xe2\x80\x9d Doctoroff said. Newark Mayor Ras Baraka says Link will be placed in every one of the city\xe2\x80\x99s five wards. \xe2\x80\x9cSo that our community can actually engage in these kiosks that will give them the opportunity to have free Wi-Fi, interact and engage with city services, and many other things at the same time. \xc2\xa0That\xe2\x80\x99s the true definition to me of what a smart city starts to look like,\xe2\x80\x9d Baraka said. The initial installment of 45 kiosks will be in the busiest parts of the city.\nListen\nListening...\n/ 0:44\nThe city of Newark is hosting a three-day summit sponsored by Amazon Alexa on language processing technology. WBGO\xe2\x80\x99s Ang Santos reports.\nMayor Ras Baraka is pushing to bring longterm technology investments to Newark. Credit Ang Santos / WBGO\nThe city had another big technology related announcement.\xc2\xa0 The \xe2\x80\x98VOICE\xe2\x80\x99 conference is being held at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in late July.\xc2\xa0 Pete Erickson of the software development company Modev says the summit will bring together the brightest minds in voice development technology. \xe2\x80\x9cJuly 24 through 26, it\xe2\x80\x99s going to be a three-day summit.\xc2\xa0 It will include a lot of deep dive workshops like hands on how to do things," said Erickson. \xc2\xa0"We\xe2\x80\x99re going to have maybe a dozen people from the Amazon team giving courses and classes on how to build Alexa skills, but then a lot of other things around natural language generation.\xe2\x80\x9d The conference is separate from Newark\xe2\x80\x99s bid to bring Amazon\xe2\x80\x99s second headquarters to the city, but Aisha Glover of the Newark Community Economic Development Corporation says they\xe2\x80\x99ll use is as leverage. \xe2\x80\x9cThat recognition of the amazing hub that Newark is for technology," Glover said. \xc2\xa0"Then of course the talent piece.\xc2\xa0 The fact that we are here at NJIT and right across the street from Rutgers definitely speaks to our assets.\xe2\x80\x9d Paid registration is required for the \xe2\x80\x98VOICE\xe2\x80\x99 summit.\xc2\xa0 The first 500 tickets are being offered at a special discounted rate. Tags:\xc2\xa0NewarkNew Jersey Institute of TechnologyRas BarakaMayor Ras BarakaTwitterFacebookGoogle+EmailView the discussion thread.\nRelated Content\nNJIT Opens New Biomedical Research Center\nBy Ang Santos\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nSep 21,\n2017\nAng Santos / WBGO\nThe NJIT science building is situated with the latest research technology in the biomedical field.\xc2\xa0 The 21 million dollar project was partially funded by the Building Our Future Bond Act signed by Governor Chris Christie.\n\xc2\xa9 2019 WBGO\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Service\nWBGO Public Files', b'TVEyes Media Monitoring Suite - [Transcript]\nLog In >\nTranscript\nLog In\nTranscript Log In\nNews 12 Bronx\xc2\xa0-\xc2\xa0New York, NY\n4/4/2018 7:31:33 PM: ......\nCopyright \xc2\xa91999 - 2019\nTVEyes, Inc.\nAll rights reserved.\nQuestions, comments, or suggestions? Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b"New York Today: More Snow on the Way - The New York Times\nSectionsSEARCHSkip to contentSkip to site indexNew YorkSubscribeLog InLog InToday\xe2\x80\x99s PaperNew York|New York Today: More Snow on the WayAdvertisementSupported byNew York TodayNew York Today: More Snow on the WayImageIt pains us to write this, but there\xe2\x80\x99s more snow in the forecast.CreditCreditSam Hodgson for The New York TimesBy Jonathan WolfeApril 5, 2018Updated, 10:03 a.m.Good morning on this in-between Thursday.First a four\xe2\x80\x99easter. Now a snowgie.Think of yourself this morning as in the middle of a snow sandwich. After five and a half inches fell on Monday, we\xe2\x80\x99re expecting more snow tomorrow and through the weekend \xe2\x80\x94 which is looking extra chilly to boot, with temperatures about 20 degrees below normal.We\xe2\x80\x99re currently keeping our eye on three systems that may make a mess of the city.The first arrives tonight and could drop around an inch of snow during tomorrow morning\xe2\x80\x99s commute, before turning to rain.On Saturday, expect the opposite, said Faye Morrone, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service \xe2\x80\x94 rain in the morning, snow during the day, then more rain at night. The high on Saturday is a wintry 39, well below the average of 58.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty cold start to the month,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Morrone said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd that looks to continue through the weekend and into next week.\xe2\x80\x9dDaily lows should stay in the 30s until next Thursday.And the climatological crystal ball is predicting a possible nor\xe2\x80\x99easter on Monday, though it\xe2\x80\x99s too early to know with any certainty, Ms. Morrone told us.While we wait to find out, put on a mitten and pat yourself on your back: You\xe2\x80\x99ve now trudged through 40.9 inches of snow this winter and spring, nearly 16 inches more than the average snow season.This April has already landed among the city\xe2\x80\x99s top 10 snowiest (at No. 8), and it\xe2\x80\x99s only the first week.\xe2\x80\x9cAny snow that we pick up in these next three chances would only bump that up,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Morrone said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe definitely seem to be in a pattern where the temperatures are cold enough to support those chances.\xe2\x80\x9dBut this is April, after all, the month that makes meteorologists look foolish, so expect plenty of chance.No curveballs today, though. It\xe2\x80\x99s sunny with a high near 49.Here\xe2\x80\x99s what else is happening:In the News\xe2\x80\xa2 The Independent Democratic Conference is no more. The group of renegade Democrats in the State Senate who for years had aligned themselves with Republicans have agreed to rejoin the fold. [New York Times]ImageAfter years of infighting, they\xe2\x80\x99ve struck a deal to unite.CreditChristopher Lee for The New York Times\xe2\x80\xa2 Homelessness is rising, not just in the city but throughout the state. A coalition is calling for more help. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 A judge criticized an officer who was found guilty of perjury, but saved his harshest words for the prosecutors in the case. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 Five New York state senators will not be getting their stipends this week, and they have the state comptroller to thank. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 The police shot and killed a man in Brooklyn while responding to reports of a man with a weapon. [New York Times]ImageInvestigators at the scene of a police-involved shooting in Brooklyn.CreditJohn Taggart for The New York Times\xe2\x80\xa2 Meet the next generation of tutors: They can help you with your math homework as well as your emotional issues. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 The New York City Housing Authority has had a rough time in recent weeks, and now so are its playgrounds. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 Is SoHa a cool new title for South Harlem, or an indication of gentrification? [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 The New York Philharmonic is channeling the vast universe. [New York Times]\xe2\x80\xa2 New York City transportation outside Manhattan will receive $50 million annually, after Queens legislators reached an agreement with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. [Queens Tribune]\xe2\x80\xa2 The body of an unidentified man was pulled from the Gowanus Canal, badly decomposed and with duct tape covering his mouth. [Brooklyn Paper]\xe2\x80\xa2 Police freed up the bike lanes in Times Square briefly, only to block them off again. [Streetsblog NYC]\xe2\x80\xa2 Today\xe2\x80\x99s Metropolitan Diary: \xe2\x80\x9cA Mostly Quiet Car\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\xa2 For a global look at what\xe2\x80\x99s happening, see Your Morning Briefing.Coming Up Today\xe2\x80\xa2 The Photography Show, a showcase of photography from the 19th century to today, at Pier 94 in Midtown Manhattan. Noon to 8 p.m. [$30]\xe2\x80\xa2 The Fusion Film Festival presents discussions, screenings and classes from women in film, television and new media at New York University Cantor Film Center and Tisch Theater in Greenwich Village. Various times. [Free]\xe2\x80\xa2 Learn how to play the Dan Tranh, a 16-string Vietnamese zither, at Poe Park Visitor Center in the Bronx. 3:30 p.m. [Free]\xe2\x80\xa2 A screening of the documentary \xe2\x80\x9cThe Green Book Chronicles,\xe2\x80\x9d about the history of the travel guide \xe2\x80\x9cThe Negro Motorist Green Book,\xe2\x80\x9d at the Museum of Art and Design in Columbus Circle. 6:30 p.m. [$10]\xe2\x80\xa2 The comedian Chris Gethard performs at the Brick in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. 8 p.m. [$10]\xe2\x80\xa2 Mets at Nationals, 1:05 p.m. (SNY). Yankees host Orioles, 6:35 p.m. (WPIX). Islanders host Rangers, 7 p.m. (MSG, MS+2). Devils at Maple Leafs, 7 p.m. (MSG+). Nets at Bucks, 8 p.m. (YES).\xe2\x80\xa2 Alternate-side parking remains in effect until Thursday.\xe2\x80\xa2 For more events, see The New York Times\xe2\x80\x99s Arts & Entertainment guide.And Finally \xe2\x80\xa6ImageHeads up.CreditJulia Gillard for The New York TimesAs the days get longer, we\xe2\x80\x99ve been getting around town more by bike and bus.Maybe you are, too.With all the attention on our crumbling subway system and congestion pricing for cars, it would be easy to miss recent developments in biking and bus travel in the city. But it\xe2\x80\x99s been a big week for aboveground commuting.Here are a few things you should know.\xe2\x80\xa2 You will soon be able to see the arrival time of your bus. The city announced yesterday that a Brooklyn pilot program that displayed countdown clocks on LinkNYC kiosks will be expanded to the five boroughs in the coming weeks.\xe2\x80\xa2 Dockless bike sharing may be coming to your neighborhood.\xe2\x80\xa2 Electric and pedal-assist bikes may soon be legal. City Hall announced on Tuesday that the mayor plans to change city law to allow them explicitly.\xe2\x80\xa2 Cyclists will be given a seven- to 11-second head start before cars at 50 intersections around the city as part of a pilot program.\xe2\x80\xa2 And Citi Bike is offering $3 single rides all month.If you do travel by subway, here\xe2\x80\x99s one way to make your time underground more pleasant: Talk to a stranger. A recent study found it could make commuting more enjoyable.New York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.For updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.What would you like to see here to start your day? d\xe7\xba\xa6\n\xe7\xba\xbd\xe7\xba\xa6\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe6\xb8\xb8\n\xe7\xba\xbd\xe7\xba\xa6\xe5\xae\xa2\xe6\xaf\x8f\xe6\x97\xa5\xe8\xa1\x97\xe6\x8b\x8d\n\xe6\x8e\x88\xe6\x9d\x83\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe8\xae\xb8\xe5\x8f\xaf\n\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8a\xa1\xe6\x9d\xa1\xe6\xac\xbe\n\xe5\xb9\xbf\xe5\x91\x8a\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8a\xa1\n\xe6\x8d\x90\xe5\x8a\xa9\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\xba\xaa\xe5\x85\x83\nCopyright\xc2\xa9 \xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\xba\xaa\xe5\x85\x83\n\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8cookies\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe4\xba\x86\xe8\xa7\xa3\xe6\x82\xa8\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xbd\x91\xe7\xab\x99\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\x96\x84\xe6\x82\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7\xe4\xbd\x93\xe9\xaa\x8c\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\xbf\x99\xe5\x8c\x85\xe6\x8b\xac\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe6\x80\xa7\xe5\x8c\x96\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\xb9\xbf\xe5\x91\x8a\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\x8b\xa5\xe6\x82\xa8\xe7\xbb\xa7\xe7\xbb\xad\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xbd\x91\xe7\xab\x99\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8d\xb3\xe8\xa1\xa8\xe7\xa4\xba\xe6\x82\xa8\xe5\x90\x8c\xe6\x84\x8f\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8cookies\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x96\xb0\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x9a\x90\xe7\xa7\x81\xe6\x94\xbf\xe7\xad\x96\xef\xbc\x88Privace Policy\xef\xbc\x89\xe5\x92\x8c\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x9d\xa1\xe6\xac\xbe\xe3\x80\x82\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe6\x88\x91\xe5\x90\x8c\xe6\x84\x8f\xc3\x97', b"New York adds bus info to LinkNYC kiosks, starting in Brooklyn | StateScoop\nSubscribe\nAbout\nRSS\nBrought to you by\nSpecial Reports\nState\nCity\nCounty & Local\nWatch\nListen\nAttend\nContent Studio\nNew York adds bus info to LinkNYC kiosks, starting in Brooklyn\nShare\nWritten by Benjamin Freed\nApr 5, 2018 | STATESCOOP\nSince early 2016, New York City has installed about 1,700 LinkNYC kiosks\xc2\xa0offering free Wi-Fi, mobile-device charging stations, and access to city services where now-antiquated phone booths once stood. As of this week, 29 kiosks in Brooklyn will now display real-time\xc2\xa0bus schedules, city officials announced Wednesday, with the updates spreading to the rest of the city not long after.\nThe bus-information upgrade was announced by LinkNYC, which is privately operated and managed by the Citybridge consortium;\xc2\xa0the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of\xc2\xa0Information Technology and Telecommunications;\xc2\xa0and City Council member Brad Lander, who\xc2\xa0represents neighborhoods like Park Slope and Cobble Hill. The initial 29\xc2\xa0kiosks getting the bus information are all in\xc2\xa0Lander\xe2\x80\x99s district.\nKiosks will show pedestrians which bus lines they\xe2\x80\x99re on, and how many stops away the nearest bus is, with the relevant information being dowloaded from the Metropolitan Transit Authority. The arrival times will be shown on the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 55-inch digital screens. Citybridge, a group\xc2\xa0of advertising and communications companies, also sells ads on the displays.\nCity officials boast of LinkNYC having one of the quickest internet connections in New York, with the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 broadcasting gigabit-speed Wi-Fi that\xe2\x80\x99s 100 times faster than typical public wireless and 40 times faster than the average home connection, according to the service\xe2\x80\x99s website.\nThe\xc2\xa0Android tablet computers implanted in each kiosk already allowed users to access city maps and social services. The kiosks also support phones that offer free domestic phone calls. Along with the free wireless internet and device charging, city officials estimate LinkNYC has already been used 3.5 million times since the first kiosks were installed, with Wi-Fi users going through more than 3,625 terabytes of data. CIVIQ, which\xc2\xa0manufactures the kiosks,\xc2\xa0has also\xc2\xa0deployed them in\xc2\xa0London, and similar\xc2\xa0systems are being planned in Chicago and Miami.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom voter registration to healthcare enrollment, and now with real-time bus information on Brooklyn kiosks, LinkNYC has once again proven to be more than just fast and free Wi-Fi,\xe2\x80\x9d DoITT Commissioner Samir Saini says in a press release.\nLander may have more of a rooting interest in getting the real-time bus information on the kiosks. Many of his\xc2\xa0constituents might soon be familiarizing themselves with their local bus schedules in preparation for next year\xe2\x80\x99s scheduled shutdown of the subway\xe2\x80\x99s L train, a vital link for Brooklynites headed into Manhattan.\nCity officials do not expect the Brooklyn pilot to last more than a few weeks before the real-time bus information spreads to the rest of the kiosk network. The pilot is mostly to make sure the bus schedules are functioning properly and meeting user-experience requirements. LinkNYC also\xc2\xa0plans to collect direct\xc2\xa0feedback from users who are frequent bus passengers.\n-In this Story-\nCivic Tech, Digital Services, LinkNYC, New York, New York City, Samir Saini, State & Local News, States, Tech News, Transportation\nRelated news\nCity\nLos Angeles city controller updates online property map to boost housing, economy\nby Colin Wood \xe2\x80\xa2 2 hours ago\nCity\n'Bootcamp' program aims to boost New York City's cybersecurity workforce\nby Benjamin Freed \xe2\x80\xa2 6 hours ago\nCity\nDetroit kicks off Ford-backed transportation challenge\nby Ryan Johnston \xe2\x80\xa2 6 hours ago\nAd Specs\nSponsor\nRSS\nPrivacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Scoop News Group\n|\nAll Rights Reserved\nSearch for:\nThe latest state and local government tech news, delivered straight to your inbox.\nSign up for our daily newsletter.\nPrivacy Policy\nWe use cookies to provide you with the best experience across all Scoop News Group websites. Learn more\nGOT IT!", b'LinkNYC Kiosks to Display Real Time Bus Info | Bowery Boogie\nAdvertisement\nBowery Boogie\nBowery Boogie\nToggle navigation\nHome\nShop\nCategories\nFood\nReal Estate\nTransportation\nCrime\nMusic\nArt\nTV/Film\nFashion\nPhotos\nHistory\nStreets\nBowery\nOrchard Street\nLudlow Street\nDelancey Street\nRivington Street\nHouston Street\nClinton Street\nGrand Street\nAllen Street\nEssex Street\nBroome Street\nStanton Street\nHester Street\nCanal Street\nEldridge Street\nChrystie Street\nNorfolk Street\nSuffolk Street\nSpring Street\nDaily Newsletter\nMore\nContact Us\nLinkNYC Kiosks to Display Real Time Bus Info\nShare\nShare\nTweet\nPosted on: April 6th, 2018 at 5:12 am\t\tby Holly\nDelancey Street, September 2017\nThose annoying LinkNYC kiosks that have taken over the sidewalk may soon get slightly more useful.\nIn a few weeks,\xc2\xa0the citywide eyesores will display bus timetables, up to one-third of a mile away. The countdowns will naturally be squeezed between advertisements and other public information that cycles through the screens. The commuting inclusion was spearheaded by Brooklyn\xc2\xa0Councilman Brad Lander, who has been pushing for this addition since September 2017.\nA LinkNYC spokesperson had stated that a countdown was \xe2\x80\x9con the roadmap\xe2\x80\x9d of future programming endeavours, but the councilman\xe2\x80\x99s proactive interest sped up the launch.\nThe Link network is a public-private partnership that relies on advertising revenue to provide free services such as wi-fi, domestic phone capability, two USB charging ports, mapping services, neighborhood history,\xc2\xa0and at one time, porn.\nOf course, there\xe2\x80\x99s always the less landscape-invasive option of using the MTA Bus Time App\xc2\xa0instead, presumably where LinkNYC is pulling its data from in the first place. If that\xe2\x80\x99s the case, you\xe2\x80\x99re still at the mercy of mediocrity.\n[h/t Crains New York]\nShare\nShare\nTweet\nTagsBus LinkNYC\nStreetsDelancey Street\nAdvertisement\nAdvertisement\nStay Connected:\nRecent Stories\nTV/Film Art Pigeon of Elizabeth Street Garden Stars in Next Season of HBO\xe2\x80\x99s The DeuceWhen both sides of the street are lined with 1970s gas-guzzlers, it could only mean one thing. John Vasilopoulos, who lost the Cup & Saucer exactly two years ago, [\xe2\x80\xa6]\nTransportation DOT Pitches New Delancey Street Safety Upgrades (Again)It\xe2\x80\x99s back to the drawing board. (Published Friday, April 6, 2018)Friday, April 6, 2018\xc2\xa0Congrats, you've made it to Friday! You may want to grab a small umbrella before you head out the door today. We're looking at a few pop-up rain showers as the temps rise into the 50s in the city. As always, get the latest forecast at nbcnewyork.com/weather.1.\xc2\xa0Majority of NYC Public Housing Playgrounds Not Maintained: AuditIf you are planning to visit a New York City playground, you may want to think twice.\xc2\xa0It\nturns out 70 percent of public playgrounds managed by the housing\nauthority haven't been properly maintained. A city audit found jagged\nedges on slides and detached ladders among other dangers.\xc2\xa0But the worst of it? Some playground inspection reports were left blank or altered and some were never even done.\xc2\xa0Read more\xc2\xa0here.2. LinkNYC Kiosks to Show Bus Arrivial Time InfoAttention New York City bus commuters. Tracking your transportation is about to get much easier.\xc2\xa0A\npilot program is set to kick off that will show commuters when the next\nbus will arrive thanks to the colorful LinkNYC kiosks we see all over\nthe place. Bus info will launch first in Brooklyn.\xc2\xa0Commuters can now get free WiFi, subway, bus info, and New York City fun facts all while standing on the street corner.\xc2\xa0Read more here.3.\xc2\xa08-Year Plan to Put an End to Train PainHow long do you think it will take to end the train pain and have a fully modernized subway system in New York City?Well, according to Gov. Cuomo, it's eight years.\xc2\xa0For subway riders, it may seem like light years away, but the original estimate was 40 years to replace signals.\xc2\xa0Get more here.For the latest entertainment news and things to do, tune in to New York Live, Monday through Friday at 11:30 a.m. on NBC 4 New York.\xc2\xa0Get the latest from NBC 4 New York anywhere, anytimeDownload the App\nAvailable for IOS and AndroidFollow NBC New York Leave Comments New York LiveNewsWeatherInvestigationsEntertainmentTrafficContact UsCommunityContestsConnect With UsWNBC Public Inspection FileEmploymentSend FeedbackTerms of servicePrivacy policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 NBCUniversal Media, LLC. All rights reserved.\nAdChoicesAdvertise with us", b"Bus countdown clocks to arrive soon at more LinkNYC kiosks - Technical.ly Brooklyn\nCommunitiesBrooklynBaltimoreDCDelawarePhillyAll CitiesChoose your topicBusinessDevAccessMediaCivicSciencesCreativeFor EmployersCommunitiesPost a JobBecome a Talent ProAdvertiseMore InformationAbout Technical.lySubscribeOur ImpactBecome a MemberEthics\nBrooklynBaltimoreDCDelawarePhillyAll Cities\nNews\nJobs\nEvents\nLogin For EmployersJobsCompaniesEventsNews\nCivicApr. 6, 2018 7:40 amBus countdown clocks to arrive soon at more LinkNYC kiosks A pilot project in Councilman Brad Lander's district will expand to the rest of the city.Bus countdown clocks to arrive soon at more LinkNYC kiosks\nBy Tyler Woods\xc2\xa0/ contributor Join 30,000+ readers who receive daily email updates from Technical.ly\nAdvertisement TOP ARTICLES A LinkNYC kiosk with bus countdown clock.(Photo via DOITT/Facebook)LinkNYC kiosks across the five boroughs will show countdown clocks for nearby buses, thanks to a multi-party agreement between city departments, projects and a councilman.Twenty-nine kiosks will show the countdown clocks as part of their screen displays in Brad Lander\xe2\x80\x99s District 39, to be followed by kiosks in districts in all five boroughs in the coming weeks, the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of\xc2\xa0Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) announced Wednesday.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a modest but meaningful improvement,\xe2\x80\x9d Lander,\xc2\xa0who represents Park Slope, Gowanus, Carroll Gardens and Borough Park, told Technical.ly by phone Thursday. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a lot easier to be a bus rider if you know when the bus is coming.\xe2\x80\x9dThrilled to help @LinkNYC kiosks become bus countdown clocks! Big thanks to @LinkNYC & @NYCDoITT for making it happen & @CMPeterKoo @CIO_Saini @JenMarieHensley @noneck @PkSLCivCouncil for joining us. Makes taking the bus a little bit better! https://t.co/ZY624f7Yhw pic.twitter.com/G1oCIdyWoq\xe2\x80\x94 Brad Lander (@bradlander) April 4, 2018Lander told Technical.ly in February about a pilot of the idea in his district. He said the idea for bus countdown clocks came out of participatory budgeting suggestions in years past but that it\xe2\x80\x99s a complicated and expensive process, with the price for each standalone countdown clock at about $35,000. The LinkNYC kiosks seemed like they could be a quick fix for getting that functionality. AdvertisementThe LinkNYC kiosks, which provide free WiFi for nearby users, are paid for primarily by the ads that appear on the screens on the sides of them. There is some time set aside for use of those screens by the city on some of the kiosks, but Lander said that, along with DoITT, the parties agreed to post the countdowns in place of some ad time and without compensation from the city.\xe2\x80\x9cThe nice thing was that Link agreed this would be valuable content to provide. Obviously, they want these things to be valuable things to look at, so they\xe2\x80\x99re putting it up in \xe2\x80\x98their\xe2\x80\x99 time,\xe2\x80\x9d Lander explained. \xe2\x80\x9cIf they don\xe2\x80\x99t become things people want to look at, that will be self-defeating because no one will be looking at them. If it helps New Yorkers, they\xe2\x80\x99ll be looking at the Links, thus making the ad space more valuable.\xe2\x80\x9dLander said he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t immediately have any other ideas for using technology to improve city life, but noted that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t have this idea in the first place exactly, either.\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think the answer is that elected officials will have great tech ideas for how to improve the city, but that we have a lot of people with ideas, such as how to make it a little easier to wait for the bus. I\xe2\x80\x99m looking forward to a lot more of those ideas,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.From where we sit, there\xe2\x80\x99s no shortage of ideas for civic tech. The pain point often occurs where implementation with government departments and organizations. That Lander was able to actually get several parties to sit down and agree to this and implement it in a pretty quick time period might be the most innovative part of this whole project.\n-30-\nJOIN THE COMMUNITY, BECOME A MEMBER\nAlready a member? Get self-driving cars off the road now\nCivicBrooklyn councilman proposes law banning after-work emailing\nCivicNYC tech advocacy group urges full speed ahead on autonomous cars\nSPONSOREDBrooklynExplore how diverse teams build dynamic products with Dev Bootcamp\nSign-up for daily news updates from Technical.ly Brooklyn\nCitiesNetworkPhillyBaltimoreBrooklynDelawareWashington D.C.TopicsBusinessAccessCivicCreativeDevMediaSciencesServicesFind JobsSearch DirectoryBrandAbout Technical.lyAdvertisingEthicsContactWrite for UsEditorial Calendar Published by\nV. 3.4.0 February 10, 2019 \xc2\xa0 / \xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa9 2019 Technically Media Inc. \xc2\xa0All Rights Reserved.\nDo NOT follow this link or you will be banned from the site!", b'Link kiosks expand offerings in Newark, NJ and NYC\n| Smart Cities Dive\nCONTINUE TO SITE \xe2\x9e\x9e\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nEnergy & Utilities\nTransportation\nBuildings & Infrastructure\nEnvironment\nResilience\nGovernance\nTech & Data\nAn article from\nBrief\nLink kiosks expand offerings in Newark, NJ and NYC\nAuthor\nBy\nChris Teale\n@chris_teale\nPublished\nApril 6, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nDive Brief:\nHigh-speed "Link"\xc2\xa0kiosks, developed by Intersection,\xc2\xa0will soon be installed in downtown Newark, NJ, according to NJ.com. The kiosks have Wi-Fi connectivity and allow users to charge their phones, make calls and download music or movies for free.\nMeanwhile, State Scoop reports\xc2\xa0that the LinkNYC service in New York City will add bus arrival times to 29 kiosks in Brooklyn, with the service set to expand to the rest of the 1,700 kiosks in the city\xe2\x80\x99s other boroughs soon.\nThe kiosks will show users nearby bus lines and how far away the next bus is, using information downloaded from the city\xe2\x80\x99s Metropolitan Transit Authority. Transit officials told StateScoop the Brooklyn pilot should last "[no] more than a few weeks"\xc2\xa0before it spreads elsewhere in the city.\nDive Insight:\nThe use of the Link Wi-Fi kiosks\xc2\xa0has been expanding across several cities in recent years as they look to reduce the "digital divide"\xc2\xa0and make the internet accessible for all residents. In addition, the initiative has generated millions of dollars in revenue for New York City through advertising and has created new jobs, while others report that retail business near the kiosks has experienced an uptick.\nThe kiosks could be even more effective in Newark, as Fierce Telecom reports they will run over the Newark Fiber network, offering high speeds on the city\xe2\x80\x99s public-private gigabit data network already linked to several other buildings. Intersection, one of the companies behind the LinkNWK kiosks, will install 45 by the end of the year at no cost to the city.\nInstallation is set to be largely focused in Newark\xe2\x80\x99s downtown corridor, and comes with the city a finalist for Amazon\xe2\x80\x99s HQ2\xc2\xa0and looking to flex its muscles as a leading place for new technological innovations. Not only should this help the city move toward that goal, it will also provide an opportunity for all residents to be involved in this revolution. "Newark is here, we are on the map," Aisha Glover, president of the Newark Community Economic Development Corporation (NCEDC) reportedly said during a Wednesday press conference at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.\nNew York\xe2\x80\x99s push to add bus schedules to its LinkNYC kiosks represents another step forward, too. More and more, cities are pushing to standardize arrival time information for public transportation, including for the blind like in Austin\xc2\xa0or in cities like Chicago, which provides service updates and emergency messages. "From voter registration to healthcare enrollment, and now with real-time bus information on Brooklyn kiosks, LinkNYC has once again proven to be more than just fast and free Wi-Fi," Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications Commissioner Samir Saini said in a statement, per StateScoop.\nRecommended Reading:\nState Scoop\nNew York adds bus info to LinkNYC kiosks, starting in Brooklyn\nNJ.com\nSoon you can charge your phone, make calls for free around this N.J. city\nFierce Telecom\nNewark Fiber\xe2\x80\x99s gigabit network becomes engine for LinkNWK smart city initiative\nFollow\nChris Teale\non\nTwitter\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nTransportation\nTop image credit:\nWikimedia Commons\nGet the Newsletter\nSubscribe to Smart Cities Dive to get the must-read news & insights in your inbox.\nEmail:\nSmart Cities Dive\nTopics covered: energy, green building, transportation, waste solutions, connectivity, policy and more.\nDaily\nSign up\nA valid email address is required.\nPlease select at least one newsletter.\nBy signing up you agree to our privacy policy. You can opt out anytime.', b"LinkNWK lands on New Jersey sidewalks -- GCN\nThe Technology that Drives Government IT\nAI & AutomationCybersecurityCloud & InfrastructureData & AnalyticsSmart Cities & IoTEmerging TechState & LocalMoreEventsResourcesNewslettersContactAdvertiseReprintsList Rental\nLinkNWK lands on New Jersey sidewalks\nBy Matt LeonardApr 06, 2018\nNewark, N.J., will be installing 45 kiosks that provide free gigabit Wi-Fi, mobile-device charging and other services on sidewalks across the city.\nContracting with Intersection, one of the companies behind similar programs in New York, Philadelphia and London, the LinkNWK kiosks will run on Newark Fiber, the city\xe2\x80\x99s public\xe2\x80\x93private gigabit data network.\nIn New York, the rectangular kiosks feature advertising and information on city services as well as charging stations, real-time local information on city streets, an integrated tablet to provide access to selected websites and a phone allowing free calls to all 50 states and Washington, D.C.\nLike LinkNYC, the project is being funded at \xe2\x80\x9cno cost to taxpayers,\xe2\x80\x9d according to Intersection, which says advertising will also cover costs associated with repairing and upgrading the system. There could also be additional revenue to put toward future smart city projects, Intersection predicted.\nNew York City has connected more than 1,700 LinkNYC kiosks since 2016, but it has ambitions of reaching 7,500 kiosks by 2020 in its effort to build citywide free Wi-Fi network. On April 4 the city launched a pilot project to add bus arrival times for stops near kiosk locations.\nAbout the Author\nMatt Leonard is a former reporter for GCN.\nE-Mail this page\nPrintable There are now over 100 of the kiosks on the UWS, as seen on this map.\nLinkNYC hotspots provide free wi-fi and calling stations and offer information and device charging. They\xe2\x80\x99re going to have bus arrival times too. Some have raised concerns about the data that these kiosks are collecting. And some Upper West Siders blocked cameras on the kiosks with yellow Post-its.\nAt a community board meeting scheduled for Tuesday, April 10 at 7 p.m. at 250 #est 87th Street, the city and CityBridge will be discussing putting new kiosks at the following locations:\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 2 Columbus Avenue (West 59th- 60th Streets)\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 111 West 60 Street (Columbus Avenue)\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 40 Columbus Avenue (N/W/C of West 61st Street)\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 322 Columbus Avenue (West 75th\xe2\x80\x9376th Streets)\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 100 West 77th Street (Amsterdam \xe2\x80\x93 Columbus Avenues)\nNEWS | 60 comments | permalink\ndannyboy says:\nApril 7, 2018 at 9:27 am\nNIMBY\nyourneighbor says:\nApril 7, 2018 at 9:30 am\nLooking at the linked citywide map, there are close to 2000 of these kiosks throughout the city.\nQuite noticeable is the lack of kiosks in low income neighborhoods \xe2\x80\x93 the places where residents most likely have the least access to the internet.\nIsn\xe2\x80\x99t the company that owns the city issued franchise required to serve all classes of citizens in NYC or did NYC just do a money grab and leave that out of the contract?\ndannyboy says:\nApril 7, 2018 at 2:35 pm\nNYC just did a money grab and leave that out of the contract.\nnycissues.org says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 12:27 pm\nAreas not served on the UWS are high income districts.\nCentral Park West\nWest End Ave\nRiverside Drive\ndannyboy says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 8:25 am\nshhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh!\nCarlos says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 9:20 am\nMy guess is that those avenues are zoned to exclude anything commercial and these are considered commercial. service that off. They are just as dangerous to you as using any APPLE or Google product. Using an Apple product including the cloud allow them to search your usage and/or computer at any time. Google has in there term of use for Gmail, google doc\xe2\x80\x99s etc that you give them permission to access any and everything on your computer. This means they have all over your contacts, emails, sites you view etc. By using their services you are also giving them the ability to share your information with 3rd parties. This is why when you and a friend are texting/emailing about a trip to Europe and then you suddenly start getting adds about travel to Europe. The Kiosks use the same type of what\xe2\x80\x99s called a \xe2\x80\x9cnegative consent agreement/letter\xe2\x80\x9d, it says \xe2\x80\x9cthat by continuing to use their service you agree to let them do this\xe2\x80\x9d. If you connect once to their service say at 96 & B\xe2\x80\x99way and a week later you go by their Kiosk on 86 & Lex the system with quire your phone and download any new info on your phone, this is done to \xe2\x80\x9csynch up\xe2\x80\x9d your acct with them and it is done with out any notification to you.\nIndependent says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 4:47 pm\n[To replace previous]\n@ Robert, #12:\nAs the saying goes,\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re not paying for the product, then you are the product.\nThis would apply to \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d services, such as those offered by Google and LinkNYC. The cost \xe2\x80\x94 at a minimum\xe2\x80\x94 is allowing and enabling the provider (and often any number of third-parties as well) to monitor, track and profile one\xe2\x80\x99s usage. (And, in all-too-many cases at least, to go on to sell said data to the highest bidder as well. Note that I am not making any accusations in this regard concerning either of the two aforementioned companies.)\nWith Apple, in contrast, the user actually purchases the products and services in-question by paying a fee (and by no means a discounted or bargain one). Granted, even the latter is by no means without its own privacy concerns. Nonetheless, there is a fundamental difference between the two business models and the distinction must be made.\nCarlos says:\nApril 8, 2018 at 7:29 am\nAs I understand it, their business model is to make money by selling ads on the kiosks but most of the time when I walk by I see marginally interesting trivia rather than ads so I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how well that is working out for them.\nAnd I agree with others above that I find their wifi to be spotty at best.\nm.pipik says:\nApril 8, 2018 at 12:41 pm\nI want to add my expereinces to the others. The only people I have seen use these are addicts.\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen anyone who might live or work in the area using one.\n@yourneighbor is right, why aren\xe2\x80\x99t these in areas where people don\xe2\x80\x99t have much access to the internet?\nSo much for the liberal concept of equal access by our very \xe2\x80\x9cliberal\xe2\x80\x9d Mayor.\nThis contract definitely needs to be investigated for kickbacks. But whom do we trust to do it right?\ndannyboy says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 3:14 pm\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe only people I have seen use these are addicts.\xe2\x80\x9d\nyou sure of that?\nBruce Bernstein says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 5:54 pm\nDannyboy is right. How does M.pipik know if the person using the kiosk is \xe2\x80\x9can addict\xe2\x80\x9d?\nor maybe he means \xe2\x80\x9caddicted to the Internet.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMTS says:\nApril 8, 2018 at 3:01 pm\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve lived for 13 years in what\xe2\x80\x99s recently become a gentrified area.\nTwo LinkNYC kiosks were installed on my block a couple of years ago.\nDuring that time I\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen anyone use them other than strung-out semi-homeless looking individuals who yell frantically into the machine at all hours having conversations that clearly sound like they\xe2\x80\x99re between an addict and their dealer.\nNo shiny happy folks charge their phone or use the map function or make calls.\nDoubtful anyone\xe2\x80\x99s using the wifi either, since there are 2 nice public parks very close-by with free wifi, as well as numerous establishments where the purchase of a cup of coffee will get you free wifi.\nThe kiosks (in my \xe2\x80\x98hood, anyway) are basically a free phone for druggies\xe2\x80\x93 who are attracted to the block by the presence of the kiosks.\nNot sure why they don\xe2\x80\x99t just apply for an \xe2\x80\x9cObama-phone\xe2\x80\x9d, unless they\xe2\x80\x99re looking to remain untraceable.\nThen again, with the built-in camera on the kiosks that stores data\xe2\x80\x93 and the facial recognition tech used by law enforcement\xe2\x80\x93 it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be hard to identify anyone using them.\nWho knows? Maybe that\xe2\x80\x99s why they\xe2\x80\x99re there in the first place.\nSmile!! You\xe2\x80\x99re on Kandid Kiosk!\nhttps://www.link.nyc/faq.html#devices\ndannyboy says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 3:17 pm\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuring that time I\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen anyone use them other than strung-out semi-homeless looking individuals who yell frantically into the machine at all hours having conversations that clearly sound like they\xe2\x80\x99re between an addict and their dealer\xe2\x80\xa6\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe kiosks (in my \xe2\x80\x98hood, anyway) are basically a free phone for druggies\xe2\x80\x93 who are attracted to the block by the presence of the kiosks.\xe2\x80\x9d\nYou see what you expect to see.\nBruce Bernstein says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 5:58 pm\nMTS said:\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuring that time I\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen anyone use them other than strung-out semi-homeless looking individuals who yell frantically into the machine at all hours having conversations that clearly sound like they\xe2\x80\x99re between an addict and their dealer.\xe2\x80\x9d\nhow could MTS know this in the 10 seconds (or less) it takes him to walk past the kiosk?\nperhaps the kiosk user always screaming, \xe2\x80\x9cI need the heroin NOW!!\xe2\x80\x9d\nor maybe MTS just has a fertile imagination.\nLeon says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 9:22 am\nDoes dannyboy = Bruce Bernstein? Or do they just have a mutual admiration society the likes of Trump and Putin? Inquiring minds want to know\xe2\x80\xa6\nBruce Bernstein says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 3:11 pm\nresponse to Leon:\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve got a problem with progressives expressing their opinions? maybe you\xe2\x80\x99re an ideological prisoner of Fox News.\nJane says:\nApril 8, 2018 at 3:55 pm\nWhen I look out my window, I can see 3 kiosks on the street in front of my building. Why they need to be in a 1-block radius is beyond me.\nfrancesca says:\nApril 8, 2018 at 7:40 pm\nEgads!\nAlready tripping over too big recycling cans, bicycle racks, postal boxes, fire hydrants, Instacart delivery depots and kiosks that are mainly occupied on a per diem basis by homeless people.\nRehetoru al question:\ndoes any government official EVER look carefully at the state of our sidewalks?\ndannyboy says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 3:19 pm\n\xe2\x80\x9cmainly occupied on a per diem basis by homeless people.\xe2\x80\x9d\nbecause they\xe2\x80\x99re homeless.\nUWSer says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 10:55 am\nGoogle. The kiosks are owned by Google.\nAs the Village Voice put it in 2016\xe2\x80\xa6\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat LinkNYC is, ultimately, underwritten by Google should tell you a lot about why New York got so very lucky as to receive an unprecedentedly fast network of citywide public Wi-Fi \xe2\x80\x94 for \xe2\x80\x98free.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\nfrom https://www.villagevoice.com/2016/07/06/google-is-transforming-nycs-payphones-into-a-personalized-propaganda-engine/\nMark Moore says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 10:55 am\nThese are surveillance towers. They have cameras that are hard to spot, plus wifi and bluetooth tracking. They have microphones that might be on, might be off at any given time, who knows. All owned by a consortium of faceless corporations led by Google that we have no control over. Take them away please.\nThese people are right:\nhttp://rethinklink.nyc/\nnycissues.org says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 12:52 pm\nYou should be more afraid of your cell phone tracking you than phone kiosks.\nCato says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 7:05 pm\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s not a competition.\nYou should be afraid of both.\nAs well as of Alexa, Cortana, Siri and all the other microphones you have set to be on, permanently.\nOf course they\xe2\x80\x99re just for your convenience, only when you want them, right?\nRiiiiiiight\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\xa6\nLegacy American says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 1:09 pm\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should be more afraid of your cell phone tracking you than phone kiosks.\xe2\x80\x9d\nDo you know that he (Mark Moore) /isn\xe2\x80\x99t/? Or even that he /owns/ or /uses/ a cell phone at all?\nJimbo says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 11:45 am\nThe UWS already fought against digital billboards in our neighborhoods. Where is CB 7? Where is Rosenthal?\nThis is a money grab bu DiBlasio who is very busy selling my eyes.\nYarnguy says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 12:35 pm\nI see so much native advertising on these things, I wonder if they\xe2\x80\x99re doing what they are meant to do\xe2\x80\xa6 and who\xe2\x80\x99s covering the cost?\nUWS_lifer says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 6:10 pm\nI think you answered your own question. The advertising pays for it.\ndannyboy says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 8:36 am\nCarlos says:\nApril 8, 2018 at 7:29 am\nAs I understand it, their business model is to make money by selling ads on the kiosks but most of the time when I walk by I see marginally interesting trivia rather than ads so I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how well that is working out for them.\nFollow the money.\nScopamici.\nTrombamici \xf0\x9f\x98\x82\xf0\x9f\x98\x82\nCato says:\nApril 9, 2018 at 7:06 pm\n:who\xe2\x80\x99s covering the cost?\nWhy, you are, of course.\nDrMMM says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 1:32 am\nSomebody please educate me.\nAnd I\xe2\x80\x99m not being sarcastic.\nWhat in the world are the actual, needed, unable-to-get-elsewhere (i.e. home, work, Starbucks/other widely available indoor public spaces) services available at these kiosks?\nI walk by them daily and wonder to myself why anyone would stand there, out on the street, doing anything on any sort of device for any reason.\nWhat am I missing?\ndannyboy says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 8:39 am\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I missing?\xe2\x80\x9d\nservices people areunable-to-get-elsewhere: (not in their home, work, or Starbucks).\nOur community is not all of one economic class\nJuan says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 9:27 am\nOn a nice day, if I need to do something on my phone and it would be easier to do it on wifi, I would prefer to do it standing outside next to one of these kiosks than fighting the coffee-obsessed masses in Starbucks.\nAlso, I believe they are paying a fee to the city for the right to exist, so there is also that benefit.\nI\xe2\x80\x99m not a huge fan of them either, and I\xe2\x80\x99m not arguing that the benefits outweigh the costs, but there is some benefit to them.\nRK says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 5:13 pm\nThe kiosks provide free wifi. Crappy free wifi is better than no wifi. Ask anyone with a small data plan. Plus, all the best cities are doing it.\nThe tablet part of it is some sort of attempt at an urban perquisite, coupled with an opportunity to advertise in the public square, which helps defray the cost of the wifi. And it impresses the tourists, which counts for something I guess. Sorta like the big touchscreen thingies in the subway.\nB.B. says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 7:13 pm\nPublic libraries have limited hours and or also limit amount of time one person can hog \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d computer/Wifi connections.\nStarbucks and other places that offer \xe2\x80\x9cfree WiFi\xe2\x80\x9d are increasingly making it \xe2\x80\x9cahem\xe2\x80\x9d uncomfortable for the homeless and or others who aren\xe2\x80\x99t paying customers to lounge around all day using the service. That and in case you\xe2\x80\x99ve not noticed Starbucks is actually opening smaller stores, which again discourages lounging about.\nThen there is the obvious (again), Starbucks and other retail/commercial places close at some point. So if you want \xe2\x80\x9cfree Wifi\xe2\x80\x9d at 1AM you need to make other arrangements.\nMany poor to low income persons have limited data plans. They use \xe2\x80\x9cfree Wifi\xe2\x80\x9d as a supplement.\nNone of this even touches tourists and other visitors to NYC\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\xa6\nNearly every other world class city in Europe, Asia or whatever has some sort of free WiFi. NYC\xe2\x80\x99s limited offerings are rather puny by some standards.\nHave to say since the porn was removed things do seem to have quieted down. Yes, you still see homeless or other persons tethered to a kiosk while huddled under blankets, but that is becoming less of an issue.\nRK says:\nApril 10, 2018 at 1:53 pm\nI\xe2\x80\x99m writing this while sitting at an AWS Machine Learning seminar discussing automated sentiment analysis and face recognition. No joke.\nMost of your technology usage is underwritten by advertising. Without this advertising, you would have to pay for services such as Google Search, free email, Facebook, Twitter, etc. If we had to pay for services, these services would not have reached the critical mass to break out of the geek-and-enthusiast niche and would not be as useful as they are now. So if you use Google, and don\xe2\x80\x99t want to pay for the hundreds of thousands of CPUs used to complete your queries in a fraction of a second using data and technology the scale of which was unthinkable even 10 years ago, please stop complaining about advertising.\nIf you have to consume advertising, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you want it to be something you\xe2\x80\x99re interested in rather than random stuff? And don\xe2\x80\x99t you think the advertisers would rather people interested in their product be the ones viewing the ads? Yes? Then it\xe2\x80\x99s a win-win-win. You get use of an unprecedented amount of intellectual capital created by some of the brightest minds in the world, hosted on a staggeringly large hardware platform, delivered via a simple user interface that even whiny UWS geriatrics can use, for free. Advertisers get to focus their ad dollars on people who are interested in them. You only need to get exposed to advertising of interest to you. Please point out the evil here.\nThis is not the Gestapo tracking your every move. No black helicopters. No evil scheme to\xe2\x80\xa6 well\xe2\x80\xa6 do something evil. No fevered Hollywood plots. Just more efficient commerce and a more advanced society.\nOh, and stop complaining about the cameras in the Link pillars. That battle was lost long ago. Next time you go outside, look up and around and I\xe2\x80\x99ll bet you see at least one camera. Color, hi-def and night-vision equipped. Ever notice how crimes on the news often have surveillance footage? Not coincidence.\ndannyboy says:\nApril 11, 2018 at 7:43 am\nSteve Wozniak drops Facebook: \xe2\x80\x9cThe profits are all based on the user\xe2\x80\x99s info\xe2\x80\x9d.\nWozniak adjusted his profile on Facebook before deactivating his account and said he was shocked to see the extent of the platform\xe2\x80\x99s data collection. His announcement comes as Facebook is under fire for its potential mishandling of user data with Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm.\nIndependent says:\nApril 11, 2018 at 2:44 pm\n@RK, #23:\n1.) What about cases, e.g. an ISP, where the provider of a paid product or service, already profiting amply from the full, market rate (often inflated) fees they charge, seeks to profit further at the expense of their customers by extensively and often invasively tracking, collecting and profiling their usage and then packaging and selling said data to the highest bidder?\n2.) Not everyone considers the technological advances you cite to have proven, on balance, to be a net /positive/ for society.\nTechnology is, or at least was, supposed to serve man. I am hardly the first nor the only one to contend that today, the reality is at least as often the reverse.\n3). The cameras are another matter. There is no reasonable expectation of privacy in a PUBLIC place such as the sidewalks of NYC.[1]\n[1] http://www.krages.com/ThePhotographersRight.pdf\nhttp://lindsaydobsonphotography.com/blog/photographing-people-and-children-in-public-places/\nhttps://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/3559975/There-is-no-law-against-photographing-children.html\nIndependent says:\nApril 12, 2018 at 12:10 am\n[to replace previous]\nSome additional points:\n1.) Using any public wireless network subjects one to both privacy as well as security risks.\n2.) I was going to ask whether there is any reason to think that whatever tracking and profiling is done by the operators of the LinkNYC kiosks, CityBridge, is\nany worse than that done by one\xe2\x80\x99s ISP or telecom provider.*\n(*NOTE: I have no affiliation with or connection to either the author of the linked article or to the site where it appears.)\nThen I read the following in the privacy policy at the LinkNYC web site:\nWe will not store your browsing history or track the websites you visit when you use your personal device to access the Services.\nAre there /any/ ISPs or telecom providers that even make a comparable claim?\n3.) RK, in Comment #23, contends that the type of tracking and profiling under discussion here (i.e., that done legally by a recognized commercial entity, in this case CityBridge) is harmless and even desirable. Even if one were to accept his arguments (and, certainly, many do /not/), what assurance does one have that the data in-question, once collected, will only be used for such purposes as outlined by RK or in the relevant terms of service?\nSuch data, which can be highly revealing and personal, can be abused in any number of ways by any number of entities. Even if one were to trust all of the authorized, original collectors of the data, what about the risk of it being stolen by rogue entities? The seemingly countless number of such instances that have been reported to-date and continue to be reported regularly would suggest that this threat remains all-too-real.\nSIGN UP FOR THE RAG\nExtra, Extra!\nUPPER WEST SIDE BLOGS\nOut Walking the DogCentral Park BloggerCity Girl WritesBeccaramaCreative DelitesFood and ThingsUpper West Side StyleMeatballs and MilkshakesTracy's New York LifeGotham Girl ChroniclesAverage JoelleWest Side WordsBloomingdale History BlogLOCAL RESOURCES\nRiverside Park ConservancyOne Stop Senior ServicesCentral Park ConservancyCommunity Board 7West End Preservation SocietyLandmark WestLivable West SideNY Historical SocietyEducation Council District 3Campaign Against HungerGale BrewerLinda RosenthalNeighborhood In The NinetiesHelen RosenthalBloomingdale Neighborhood HistoryCITY NEWS\nNew York TimesNew York Daily NewsGothamistNew York PostCity LimitsOTHER FAVORITES\nFriends of BowneNew Haven IndependentThe Lo-DownCurbedBrickUndergroundNabeWiseVanishing New YorkNew York HyperlocalEaterUntapped CitiesHumans of New Yorkfloat fixExplore Your Favorite Subject20th precinct\namerican museum of natural history\nanimals\nart\nbicycling\nbulletin\ncentral park\nclosings\ncolumns\ncommunity board 7\ncrash\ncrime\ndevelopment\ndogs\nevents\nfdny\nfire\nfood\nfree\ngale brewer\nhealth violations\nhelen rosenthal\nhistory\nhudson river\njcc\nlincoln center\nmorning bulletin\nmovies\nnypd\nopenings\npedestrian safety\nphotography\nphotos\npolitics\npublic schools\nreal estate\nrestaurants\nretail\nriverside park\nsilver stars fitness\nsnow\nsponsored\nsubway\nupper west side\nuws\nWEST SIDE RAG\nAbout\nContact Us\nSite Map\nCopyright 2011-2019 West Side Rag. Terms and conditions.", b"Inwood Residents Decide How to Spend $1 Million in Their Community\nMenu\nTop Menu\nHarlem World Magazine\nHarlem World Magazine is the #1 source in the world for living your best life and style in Harlem.\nMenu\nPrimary menu\nHome\nBeauty\nBooks\nCalendar\nCelebrity\nEducation\nEvents\nFilm\nHistory\nMusic\nReal Estate\nArchitecture\nSports\nStyle\nContributors\nCassandra\nCC Minton\nClaude Jay\nDiane Alford\nDontre Conerly\nEartha Watts-Hicks\nHosea Johnson\nKyle Fraser\nLil Nickelson\nMarc Rasbury\nMichael Andre Adams\xe2\x80\x99\nNicky Mayers\nReggie Jones\nRudy Collins\nSeitu Oronde\nTod Roulette\nUdo Salters\nWalter Rutledge\nYolande Brener\nFood\nArt\nReal Estate\nLife\nStyle\nSign-Up\nPartners\nAtlanta\nHampton\xe2\x80\x99s\nLos Angeles\nWashington DC\nAbout Us\nAdvertising Services\nCalendar\nPodcast\nSubmit A Story\nTips\nHarlem World Advisory Board\nHarlem Media Group\nThe Best\nThe Best On A Budget\nThe Best Culture & Attractions\nThe Best Food\nThe Best For Kids\nThe Best Nightlife\nThe Best Pet Services\nThe Best Places To Stay\nThe Best Shopping\nThe Best Wellness\nShop\nThe Harlem World Collection\nDonate\nSecondary menu\nPost navigation\n\xe2\x86\x90 Previous\nNext \xe2\x86\x92\nInwood Residents Decide How to Spend $1 Million in Their Community\nPosted on 04/07/2018\nby\nHarlem World Magazine\n\xe2\x80\x94\nLeave a reply\nCouncil Member Ydanis Rodriguez joined by community leaders and District 10 residents kicked off the start of Participatory Budget Vote Week at the Inwood Greenmarket that will run through Sunday, April 15th.Residents as young as 11 years old or in the 6th grade can vote for the first time.\nEach voter can select up to five projects. There are eleven items on the ballot this year:\nDistrict Libraries Technology Upgrades \xe2\x80\x93 $200,000\nPS 173 Auditorium Technology Upgrade \xe2\x80\x93 $150,000\nPS 48 Playground Renovation \xe2\x80\x93 $500,000\nGeorge Washington High School Weight Training \xe2\x80\x93 $80,000\nSound System for WHEELS Auditorium \xe2\x80\x93 $150,000\nDyckman Houses Building #4 Playground Renovation \xe2\x80\x93 $500,000\nDyckman Houses Building #3 Playground Renovation \xe2\x80\x93 $500,000\nDyckman Houses New Park Game Tables \xe2\x80\x93 $350,000\nDyckman Houses Community Center Outside Drainage \xe2\x80\x93 $500,000\nDyckman Houses Community Center ADA Ramp \xe2\x80\x93 $850,000\nNorthern Basketball court Wallenberg Playground \xe2\x80\x93 $535,000\nThere are three ways to vote: (1) in person at a\xc2\xa0pop up site\xc2\xa0or Monday through Friday at the Council District Office at 618 West 177th Street; (2) online at\xc2\xa0pbnyc.org/vote; or (3)\xc2\xa0visit a LinkNYC kiosk\xc2\xa0in District 10 along St. Nicholas Avenue or any of the five boroughs.\nDistrict 10 has taken part in this process since 2014. Last year the winning projects totaled over $1.1 million: laptops for low-income students at P.S. M293 Salome Urena Campus, science carts for P.S. 178, street trees and tree guards in Washington Heights and Inwood, air conditioner for Castle Bridge & P.S. 128, and bus countdown clocks with live timing of bus arrivals district-wide.\n\xe2\x80\x9cParticipatory Budgeting allows everyone as young as 11 years old or in 6th grade to take part in this democratic process. It empowers the community to determine how to best use capital resources available to us and teaches young people the importance of civic engagement,\xe2\x80\x9d said Council Member Ydanis Rodriguez. \xe2\x80\x9cVoting has become much more accessible with the many options we now have. I invite everyone to vote between April 7th and April 15th, let their voice be heard, and their friends, family and neighbors to take part in this global initiative.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cParticipatory budgeting is one if the best ways to get our community involved in our democratic process. What better way can there be than allowing the community decide the projects they would like to fund in their neighborhoods. Thank you Councilman Rodriguez for organizing this effort. I am sure wonderful community improvement projects will result from this process,\xe2\x80\x9d said Senator Marisol Alcantara.\n\xe2\x80\x9cParticipatory budgeting serves the community with a great opportunity to vote on projects based on priority as considered by residents. For a whole week the community can select their preferred projects to be funded. I commend Council member Ydanis Rodriguez for encouraging residents of district 10 to be proactive in their vote so that the 1 million dollar in capital funds are allocated in projects where the need for upgrade and improvement is vital,\xe2\x80\x9dsaid Assemblywoman Carmen De La Rosa.\nTo learn more about Participatory Budgeting in New York City, visit\xc2\xa0pbnyc.org. Go to\xc2\xa0participatorybudgeting.org/pbps-story\xc2\xa0to learn about how it started in Porto Alegre, Brazil in 1989.\nSign-Up for Constant Contact e-mail marketing!\nHarlem World Magazine, relies on its readers for support. You can help us by supporting us today! Your contribution supports more local, Harlem coverage from Harlem World. Thank you!\nThis entry was posted in Harlem, Inwood, politics and tagged Inwood, Inwood Greenmarket, Participatory Budget Vote Week, Ydanis Rodriguez by Harlem World Magazine. Heights\nDitmas Park\nFlatbush\nKensington\nProspect Lefferts Gardens\nEastern Brooklyn\nBrownsville\nCanarsie\nCypress Hills\nEast New York\nNorthern Brooklyn\nBushwick\nGreenpoint\nWilliamsburg\nBed Stuy\nNorth Western Brooklyn\nBoerum Hill\nDowntown Brooklyn\nPark Slope\nProspect Heights\nRed Hook\nSouth Slope\nClinton Hill\nCarroll Gardens\nCobble Hill\nDUMBO\nFort Greene\nGowanus\nWindsor Park\nDyker Heights\nSunset Park\nSubscribe\nAbout Us\nEat & Drink\nReal Estate\nEvents\nCalendar\nParticipatory Budgeting \xe2\x80\x93 Cast Your Vote This Week At LinkNYC Kiosks\nBy Zainab Iqbal -\nApril 9, 2018 0\nFacebook\nTwitter\nPinterest\nWhatsApp\nLinkedin\nReddIt\nEmail\nPrint\nPhoto via NYC Council Speaker Corey Johnson\nPROSPECT HEIGHTS \xe2\x80\x93 Voting kicked off this past Saturday and you have all week (until April 15) to vote for the projects you want to see completed as part of the Participatory Budgeting (PB) process.\nPB is a democratic process where several council members \xe2\x80\x94 this year in Brooklyn it\xe2\x80\x99s Levin, Reynoso, Cumbo, Cornegy, Menchaca, Lander, Eugene, Williams, Treyger, and Yeger\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 allocate at least $1 million from their budgets to give residents in their districts a direct say what the money is spent on.\nToday\'s the first day of @PB_NYC open voting period at #Brooklyn Borough Hall. Come by anytime from 9AM to 5PM thru Fri, April 13th. You can also vote online at https://t.co/2hV6gRX0ko or at a @LinkNYC kiosk. Make your voice heard on what projects get funding in your area. #PBNYC\n\xe2\x80\x94 Eric Adams (@BPEricAdams) April 9, 2018\nYou can vote at any Link kiosk, at a voting site, or online. Voting at Link kiosks is new this year, and is a collaboration among LinkNYC, NYC Council, and the NYC Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (NYC DoITT).\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe always envisioned Link as a platform for civic engagement and are thrilled to support the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s Participatory Budgeting efforts this year, providing another way for New Yorkers to vote for projects that will directly improve their quality of life,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jen Hensley, president of LinkNYC said.\n.@PB_NYC voting is going strong! We kicked it off in @bradlander\'s district over the weekend.\nThrough Sunday, you can vote to determine how $1 million is spent in your community.\nGo to https://t.co/RTgRcHBm8F to learn more and vote online, or find an in-person vote location! pic.twitter.com/RQLaAUkgZx\n\xe2\x80\x94 NYC Council Speaker Corey Johnson (@NYCSpeakerCoJo) April 9, 2018\nAt the kick-off, NYC DoITT Commissioner Samir Saini was also there encouraging people to take advantage of Link kiosks across the city.\nStopped by grand army plaza today to support the City Council #PBNYC kickoff! New Yorkers can now use @LinkNYC to vote for the neighborhood projects that matter the most to them. pic.twitter.com/z2LbpjFhi3\n\xe2\x80\x94 Samir Saini (@CIO_Saini) April 7, 2018\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re honored to work with the Council to put democracy at New Yorkers\xe2\x80\x99 fingertips. This year, more than 1,500 Link kiosks present that many more opportunities for residents to vote for the neighborhood projects that matter the most to them. I look forward to introducing New Yorkers to even more ways the Link platform can be used to foster civic innovation within our great city,\xe2\x80\x9d Commissioner Saini said.\nYou can vote at any Link kiosk, at a voting site, or online.\nNever miss the day\'s stories!\nLeave this field empty if you\'re human: This page is available to subscribers. Entertainment\nLegal\nPolitics\nCity\nNational\nState\nBusiness\nSports\nCyclones\nIslanders\nNets\nHistory\nNeighborhoods\nCentral Brooklyn Jazz Festival To Include Over 500 Artists\nMarch 22, 2012 Brooklyn Eagle Staff\nBROOKLYN \xe2\x80\x94 From March 30 until April 30, the Central Brooklyn Jazz Consortium (CBJC) will present the 13th Annual Central Brooklyn Jazz Festival. More than 500 artists will be performing in 40 events at venues from Coney Island to Williamsburg in Brooklyn.\nBrooklyn jazz has a rich past, and its legacy is celebrated every April. Clarence Mosley Jr., chairman of the consortium, says, \xe2\x80\x9cCBJC enters its 13th season in presenting the African-American art form jazz to the under-served populations of Brooklyn. We continue to recognize the contributions and creativity of the jazz community of Brooklyn, past and present.\xe2\x80\x9d\nInternationally recognized musicians will perform in community centers, clubs, colleges and cultural and faith-based institutions. The jazz festival is accessible to all, with 85 percent of the events free or at a cost of less than $20.\nFor information, contact CBJC at (718) 773-2252 or [email\xc2\xa0protected]\nAmong others, performers this year will include Bilal Sunni Ali, Kenyatta Beasley, Gloria Cooper, Steve Cromity, Bob Cunningham, Lou Donaldson and Eric Frazier.\nSHARE ARTICLE:\nLeave a Comment\nRelated Articles\nMore enforcement cameras coming to Brooklyn bus lanes\nJune 21 |\nScott Enman\nFBI agent was on the phone with his wife when he was shot in the back\nJune 21 |\nNoah Goldberg\nFront-runners for City Council seat get a boost\nJune 21 |\nPaula Katinas\nBay Ridge is getting a new bike lane network after all\nJune 21 |\nMeaghan McGoldrick\nBrooklyn Today\nJune 21, 2019Jun 21, 2019 | Rain, 75\xc2\xb0 F\nDaily Top Brooklyn News\nFollow\n@bkeagle\nContribute\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nTerms & Conditions\nContact Us\nThe Brooklyn Daily Eagle and brooklyneagle.com cover Brooklyn 24/7 online and five days a week in print with the motto, \xe2\x80\x9cAll Brooklyn All the Time.\xe2\x80\x9d With a history dating back to 1841, the Eagle is New York City\xe2\x80\x99s only daily devoted exclusively to Brooklyn.\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Everything Brooklyn Media\nDAILY TOP BROOKLYN NEWS\nNews for those who live, work and play in Brooklyn and beyond\nLeave this field empty if you're human:", b'Access to participatory budgeting now available via Link kiosks - The Brooklyn Home Reporter\nNews\nEvents\nNeighborhoods\nBath Beach\nBay Ridge\nBensonhurst\nCarroll Gardens\nConey Island\nDowntown Brooklyn\nDumbo\nDyker Heights\nGowanus\nGravesend\nPark Slope\nRed Hook\nSheepshead Bay\nSunset Park\nDigital Editions\nAdvertise\nJoin our email newsletter to get Local Brooklyn News, Events & Offers in your inbox.\nLearn More\nBrooklyn Reporter\nBrooklyn Reporter\nNews\nEvents\nNeighborhoods\nBath Beach\nBay Ridge\nBensonhurst\nCarroll Gardens\nConey Island\nDowntown Brooklyn\nDumbo\nDyker Heights\nGowanus\nGravesend\nPark Slope\nRed Hook\nSheepshead Bay\nSunset Park\nDigital Editions\nAdvertise\nThe structure of other researchers\xe2\x80\x99 ideas p buy cheap research papers. They analyze the order custom research papers cheap research papers is paramount, we urge students to find cheap research papers with your disposal all year long, you have at.\nPolitics Access to participatory budgeting now available via Link kiosks\nBy\nMeaghan McGoldrick\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nApril 10, 2018 @ 11:54 am\nPhoto via Flickr/LinkNYC\nA Link kiosk in New York City.\nParticipatory budgeting just got easier for some.\nThe New York City Council together with the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) and LinkNYC announced on Monday, April 9 the launch citywide of participatory budgeting on Link kiosks \xe2\x80\x93 the first-of-its-kind communications network which replaced city payphones and offered free Wi-Fi starting in early 2016.\nThrough participatory budgeting, New Yorkers in participating City Council districts can now decide how to spend $1 million of the public budget. Community members can propose and vote on projects like improvements to schools, parks, libraries and more, via the Link system.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC once again demonstrates that technology is a powerful tool for public good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Samir Saini, commissioner of DoITT. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re honored to work with the Council to put democracy at New Yorkers\xe2\x80\x99 fingertips. This year, more than 1,500 Link kiosks present that many more opportunities for residents to vote for the neighborhood projects that matter the most to them. I look forward to introducing New Yorkers to even more ways the Link platform can be used to foster civic innovation within our great city.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Participatory Budgeting, Link is helping to bring the democratic process to the streets,\xe2\x80\x9d agreed Jen Hensley, president of Link. \xe2\x80\x9cWe always envisioned Link as a platform for civic engagement and are thrilled to support the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s Participatory Budgeting efforts this year, providing another way for New Yorkers to vote for projects that will directly improve their quality of life.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMore than 1,700 Links are installed across the five boroughs, with thousands more coming over the next few years. Participatory budget voting is open now through Sunday, April 15.\nTo find a Link near you, visit\xc2\xa0https://www.link.nyc/find-a-link.html.\nTags:boroughwideCity CouncilGovernmentlinklink City, NY\nGramercy-Murray Hill, NY\nWest Village, NY\nHoboken, NJ\nState Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\ncommunity corner\nMore LinkNYC Kiosks May Come To Upper West Side\nThe city has five new Upper West Side locations in mind for LinkNYC Kiosks.\nBy Brendan Krisel, Patch Staff\nApr 10, 2018 2:52 pm ET | Updated Apr 10, 2018 2:53 pm ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nUPPER WEST SIDE, NY \xe2\x80\x94 The Upper West Side may get new LinkNYC kiosks at five new locations, according to a Community Board 7 agenda. The city Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications and Citybridge \xe2\x80\x94 the organization that will install new LinkNYC kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 are applying to continue deployment of the multi-use terminals on the Upper West Side. The targeted locations are: 2 Columbus Avenue between West 59th and 60th streets;111 West 60 Street on the corner of Columbus Avenue;40 Columbus Avenue near West 61st Street;322 Columbus Avenue between West 75th and 76th streets;100 West 77th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus avenues.Thousands of LinkNYC kiosks have been installed across New York City, many of them on the Upper West Side, in a venture to replace outdated payphones. The terminals provide free wi-fi access, phone charging and assistance with directions. The terminals have also been deployed for more creative uses such as sending Valentines Day messages and functioning as bus countdown clocks.\nWhile the kiosks have their uses, there has been some negative backlash. Some people simply don't like how they look, and internet browsing was removed from the terminals because some New Yorkers were using them to watch porn in public. CONVENTIONS\nf\nl\ni\nBlogs\nNews\nResources\nCareer\nEvents\nSupplied Content\nfind facilities \xc2\xbb\nCut through the clutter. Know it all.\nMeeting News\nHome / News\nIndustry Associations\nEmpire State Building Goes Blue Tonight for Global Meetings Industry Day, April 12\nshare\nshare\nby Sarah J.F. Braley |\nApril 11, 2018\nAs the meetings industry prepares to celebrate itself tomorrow for Global Meetings Industry Day, aiming to remind the world of the positive impact of face-to-face gatherings, New York City will glow blue tonight, April 11.\nThe Jacob K. Javits Convention Center of New York\'s glass-enclosed 15-story Crystal Palace, which is available to event managers seeking a customized lighting sequence, will turn blue for GMID. The new Pier 17\xc2\xa0-- a four-story mall opening this summer in the Seaport District with several dining options and an iPic theater -- also will participate. The Empire State Building, One Bryant Park, 4 Times Square\xc2\xa0and One World Trade Center\xc2\xa0will sport blue lights, as well.\nOn Thursday, Global Meetings Industry Day itself, more than 2,100 LinkNYC screens citywide will rotate displays of NYC & Co.\'s "Make it NYC" meetings slogan, along with MMBC and GMID logos, and in the afternoon, Vornado Realty Trust\'s Times Square billboard on the New York Marriott Marquis will display the same signs.\n"The third annual lighting of the skyline in blue on GMID eve is a unique tribute to the power of meetings," said Jerry Cito, senior vice president of convention development for NYC & Co., the city\'s convention and visitors bureau. "As both a founder of and current executive team member of MMBC, and the SVP of Convention Development here, I couldn\'t be prouder to sell NYC in this exciting time of development. With the opening of the Cornell Tech campus, the ongoing expansion of the Javits Center and numerous boutique meeting spaces emerging throughout the City, there will be added capacity for meetings delegates in 2018 and beyond. Ultimately, this will bolster spending across the five boroughs."\nMore than 100 events celebrating GMID will take place around the world tomorrow, including NYC & Co.\'s Tristate Meeting Planner event at the NFL Experience Times Square. The following is just a sampling of what\'s in store (all times are local).\nUNITED STATES\n\xe2\x80\xa2 MPI Chicago Area Chapter\'s Industry Xchange 2018\xc2\xa0will begin at 4 p.m. at the city\'s new Wintrust Arena, in collaboration with the Association Forum, the Catering Executives Club of America, EDPA Midwest, IAEE Midwestern Chapter, ILEA Chicago Chapter, PCMA\'s Greater Midwest Chapter and SITE Chicago.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 The Meetings Industry Council of Colorado\xc2\xa0will hold a celebration starting at 1 p.m. at the Colorado State Capitol for a talk with an elected official followed by a tour of the renovated Capitol and a reception at the Sheraton Denver Downtown.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 In Washington, D.C., the PCMA Capital and MPI-Potomac chapters will converge for an afternoon of education, networking and advocacy [https://capital.pcma.org/event/global-meetings-industry-day-gmid/], beginning at 3:30 p.m. at the Grand Hyatt.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 A Bowling, Trivia Night and Global Meetings Industry Day Celebration\xc2\xa0takes place in Scottsdale, Ariz., hosted by the MPI Arizona Sunbelt Chapter beginning at 6 p.m. at BowlMor Scottsdale.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Cvent\'s Regional Leadership Summit\xc2\xa0will be held at the W Hotel in Los Angeles starting at 8 a.m., a gathering of industry leaders, practitioners and experts to discuss key trends \xc2\xa0shaping the industry.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 A conglomeration of industry organizations (PCMA Southeast, IAEE Southeast, MPI Georgia, GSAE, SITE and SPIN) will get together at Live! at the Battery Atlanta for GMID Spring Training at 3:30 p.m. The interactive event will explore the latest technology and industry trends.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 SITE Florida & Caribbean Chapter, Sustainable Events Network Florida & Caribbean, SKAL, Greater Miami and the Beaches Hotel Association, International Live Events Association, HSMAI South Florida will hold a session on "Blockchain Disruption in Travel"\xc2\xa0at 3:30 p.m. at the Faena Hotel Miami Beach.\nINTERNATIONAL\n\xe2\x80\xa2 "The Value of Events in the Marketing Mix" is the topic being discussed in Leusden, the Netherlands, at 2:15 p.m., sponsored by the MPI the Netherlands Chapter and hosted by AFAS Software, one of the largest Dutch Software companies.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Positive Impact Events in Manchester, England, is hosting\xc2\xa0a webcast at 4 p.m. on how collaboration can build a more powerful and sustainable event industry.\n\xe2\x80\xa2 In Warsaw, Poland, the faculty of Tourism and Recreation at University of Physical Education is hosting Student Event Day, providing a series of brief lectures about the meetings industry, beginning at 10 a.m.\nClose\nPlease enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.\ncomments powered by Disqus\nNewsletters\nMeeting News\nAssociation News\nSportsTravel\nHot Idea of the Day\nTech Insider\nSign Up for More ENLs\nMost Popular\nmost read\nmost shared\nHow Attrition Has Changed and What It Means for Meetings\nTSA Allows Flyers to Travel With Drug Derived From Marijuana\nThe Coolest Ice Cubes Ever\nCan Americans Still Go to Cuba?
