Tech! Action! PB voting is underway - The Villager | The Villager\nContact Us\nDigital Editions\nHome Delivery\nHome\nNews\nPolice & Fire\nPolitics\nOpinion\nArts & Entertainment\nReal Estate\nDining & Nightlife\nKids & Education\nRSS for Entries\nLights! Tech! Action! PB voting is underway\nApril 12, 2018 |\nFiled under: News |\nPosted by: manhattannews\nBY SAM BLEIBERG |\xc2\xa0Upgrades to parks and green spaces, new tech for libraries and schools, improved public safety and better bus stop info all have a place among the worthy projects vying for Council District 3 residents\xe2\x80\x99 support this week, as part of the annual Participatory Budgeting process. The program allows locals, age 11 and up, to cast their vote for up to five of 11 ballot items. The top vote-getter will be fully funded, with other projects also getting funding until the allocated $1 million in discretionary cash has been fully distributed.\nMaury Schott, left, and Brooke Schooley think historic lighting would make Seventh Ave. South more neighborhood-like and \xe2\x80\x9cless like a highway.\xe2\x80\x9d Photo by Sam Bleiberg\nResidents of District 3 (Village / Chelsea / Hell\xe2\x80\x99s Kitchen) can vote online (pbnyc2018.d21.me) anywhere, including at several area polling sites, as well as at City Council Speaker Corey Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s district office and, for the first time, at LinkNYC sidewalk kiosks. Voting closes Sat., April 15. Traditional (non-online) voting can also be done at the poll sites and Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s office.\n\xe2\x80\x9cParticipatory Budgeting is democracy in action,\xe2\x80\x9d Johnson said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt gives every constituent an opportunity to take part in the budget process.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe process started at last Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s Project Expo at P.S. 41, on W. 11th St., where residents heard from project sponsors.\nJone Noveck pitched a proposal for tree guards.\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost of the trees they plant now have a poor likelihood of survival,\xe2\x80\x9d the local resident said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe may replace a tree two or three times. This would save taxpayers money.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe Seventh Ave. South Alliance is proposing the installation of historic streetlights, which they say would make the street more welcoming for residents and visitors alike.\n\xe2\x80\x9cA couple of these intersections at one point were gauged among the most dangerous in the city,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alliance member Brooke Schooley. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can provide an aesthetic feature like historic lights that can make it feel like more of a neighborhood and less like a highway.\xe2\x80\x9d The Landmarks Preservation Commission has O.K.\xe2\x80\x99d the light poles as appropriate for wide avenues in the Greenwich Village Historic District.\nEngaging youth is a goal of the City Council. This year, the \xe2\x80\x9cPB\xe2\x80\x9d voting age has been lowered from 14 to 11.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSometimes students have to go home and might not have computers or Internet connection there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ashley, a High School of Fashion Industries student. \xe2\x80\x9cThey might have to go to libraries and waste time trying to figure out how to get things done. If it\xe2\x80\x99s at school, it\xe2\x80\x99s easily approachable.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe spend most of our time on computers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malachi, a student at Quest to Learn. \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes there are problems with the Wi-Fi, or our project can get deleted. If this is done properly that won\xe2\x80\x99t happen.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAudrey Henningham, a volunteer in Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s district office, advocated for a project to upgrade technology in libraries. She said the printers in the four local libraries are often out of order and the letters worn off many keyboards.\nAmong the projects are: $250,000 for real-time rider information at key bus stops district-wide; $250,000 for historic street lighting on Seventh Ave. South between Commerce, Carmine and Clarkson Sts.; $242,000 for 200 tree guards district-wide; $500,000 for a new fitness center for special-needs students at P.S. M721, Manhattan Occupational Training Center, at 250 W. Houston St.; $350,000 for tech upgrades for the district\xe2\x80\x99s public schools; $200,000 for tech upgrades \xe2\x80\x94 including new desktop computers, printers and more \xe2\x80\x94 at District 3 libraries. Other projects are in Chelsea and Hell\xe2\x80\x99s Kitchen.\nVillage poll sites include the L.G.B.T. Center, at 208 W. 13th St., and Greenwich House, at 27 Barrow St., 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Sat., April 14, and Sun., April 15. There is also voting at Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s district office, at 224 W. 30th St., Suite 1206, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., from Mon., April 9 through Fri., April 13.\nLeave a Reply Cancel reply\nYour email address will not be published. sick hoax: \'Baby\' believed dead inside Crocheron Park in Bayside turns out to be lifelike doll left by prankster\nJune 18, 2019\nA sick hoax: \xe2\x80\x98Baby\xe2\x80\x99 believed dead inside Crocheron Park in Bayside turns out to be lifelike doll left by prankster\nJune 18, 2019\nRego Park\'s Shalimar Diner spared the wrecking ball, will be moved to Long Island with assist from a 1986 Met\nJune 20, 2019\nReopening Rockaway branch is no path to the future\nJanuary 01, 2016\nMan with head trauma found dead on an Astoria street: NYPD\nMay 10, 2019\nHomeless complaints and moto stunts hit nerve in Ridgewood-based 104th Precinct\nMay 22, 2019\nDevelopers get $30 million loan to build 17-story residential tower on site of Flushing\'s RKO Keith\'s Theater\nMay 20, 2019\nWomen\'s March leader endorses Tiffany Cab\xc3\xa1n for DA, citing stance on justice reform\nMay 17, 2019\nAs construction on Station Square in Forest Hills nears completion, neighborhood corporation tests a new plan restricting traffic\nMay 15, 2019\nJun\n21\nEvents\nQueens Jazz Orchestra: It Ain\'t Over Yet\n12:00 AM\nmore\nadd\nFacebookTwitteremail\nFacebookTwitteremail\nQueens residents vote on projects during Participatory Budgeting Week\nPhoto by Nat Valentine\nCouncilman I. Daneek Miller\xe2\x80\x99s office is participating in Participatory Budget Week.\n[email\xc2\xa0protected]\n/\nThursday, April 12, 2018\n/\n12:00 AM\nBy Naeisha Rose\nResidents throughout Queens, including those in District 27 who are represented by City Councilman I. Daneek Miller (D-St. Albans), have until Sunday to make sure their voices are heard for their area\xe2\x80\x99s Participatory Budgeting Week.\nParticipatory budgeting allows residents to vote on which infrastructure projects will be funded by their Council member\xe2\x80\x99s budget allocation by up to $1 million.\nVoting kicked off Saturday and residents in District 27, which covers Jamaica, St. Albans, Hollis, Cambria Heights, Queens Village, Addisleigh Park and Springfield Gardens, have a chance to participate at different locations.\nBallots will be available in English, Bengali, Creole and Spanish, and if individuals want to show their support for the initiative WHAT INITIATIVE \xe2\x80\x93 EXPLAIN -on social media. they can use the hashtag #PB27 and #PBNYC.\nIn District 27 constituents can vote Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Miller\xe2\x80\x99s office, which is located at 172-12 Linden Blvd. in St. Albans. Other locations will be open on different days.\nResidents as young as 11 years old will be eligible to participate by visiting their local polling site, by completing an online ballot or using a LinkNYC kiosk.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC once again demonstrates that technology is a powerful tool for public good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Samir Saini, commissioner of the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re honored to work with the Council to put democracy at New Yorkers\xe2\x80\x99 fingertips. This year, more than 1,500 Link kiosks present that many more opportunities for residents to vote for the neighborhood projects that matter the most to them. I look forward to introducing New Yorkers to even more ways the Link platform can be used to foster civic innovation within our great city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTo learn more about the process Queens residents can visit www.council.nyc.gov/pb/.\nSome of the other sites in District 27 include PS 360 in St. Albans (Tuesday), Cambria Heights Library (Wednesday), Alpha Phi Alpha Senior Center (Thursday), PS 176 in Cambria Heights (Friday) and Roy Wilkins Recreation Center (Saturday) in St. Albans.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are very excited to engage all facets of our community, and empower citizens in this manner, including those previously disenfranchised,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miller. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is an opportunity to give all individuals, especially our young people, a chance to become stakeholders, and have a voice in the enhancement of our community\xe2\x80\x99s capital investments. There is no greater vehicle galvanizing local communities today than participatory budgeting.\xe2\x80\x9d\nReach reporter Naeisha Rose by e-mail at nrose@cnglocal.com or by phone at (718) 260\xe2\x80\x934573.\nTopics:\nDistrict 27\nGovernment\nparticipatory budgeting\nShare this story\nFacebookTwitteremail\nRelated Stories\nAdams makes history to take Wills seat, Miller re-elected\nGreen Party\xe2\x80\x99s Francois runs grassroots campaign for Council seat\nPopular Stories\nFlushing man wins $5,000,000 on \'Set for Life\' scratch-off ticket\nRobbers slash Rego Park candy store employee in the neck during armed robbery: cops\nThief drugged man\'s drink and stole his valuables while he slept in Queens home: cops\nAbout Schneps Communications, 2018\nMasthead\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Service\nQUEENS COURIER\nRIDGEWOOD TIMES\nBORO MAGAZINE\nLIC MAGAZINE\nSend Invite\n\xc3\x97\nSubject: Subject line is fixed\nAn invitation to join the QNS community.\n(optional) Customize the text of the\ninvitation.\nThe message will also contain a custom footer containing links to accept\nthe invitation or opt out of further email invitations from this site.\nYou have been invited by Queens Courier Staff to join the QNS community.\nVisit Queens Courier Staff\'s profile at qns.com/members/admin/.\n\xc3\x97\nCreate an Account\nForgot Password\nor\nLog in with\nCreate New Event\n\xc3\x97\nx\nUpload\nImproper image submitted. Queens Chronicle: Eastern/Southeast Queens News\nClose\nHome\nSubscribe\nContact Us\nOur Newspaper\nJune 21, 2019\nWelcome!\nLogin|Signup\nLogin|My Dashboard|Register\nLogout|My Dashboard\nQueens Chronicle\nAdvanced Search\n78\xc2\xb0\nPartly Cloudy\nNews\nGov't & Politics\nEducation\nTransportation\nEconomic\nEnvironment\nHealth\nCrime\nEditions\nSouth Queens\nCentral/Mid Queens\nEastern/Southeast Queens\nNorth/Northeast Queens\nWestern Queens\nQueenswide\nOpinion\nEditorials\nLetters to the Editor\nColumns\nSports Beat\nqboro: Arts\nStories\nCommunity Calendar\nOnline Calendar\nI Have Often Walked\nRestaurant Reviews\nPhotos\nEvent Photo Galleries\nNews Photo Galleries\nSchool News\nClassifieds\nAbout Us\nAbout Us\nContacts\nMedia Kit\nAdvertisers\nClassified & Services\nDisplay Adv.\nAdv. Calendar\nMap\nCirc. & Demographics\nDistrib. Sites\nWeb Adv.\nSections\nPrime Times\nHome & Garden\nBanking & Finance\nHealth & Fitness\nSchool Spotlight\nCelebration\nFall Guide\nAnniversary\nSpring Guide\nDigital Edition\nSouth Edition\nSpecial Sections\nPage One\nSports\nHome\nEditions\nEastern/Southeast Queens News\nSpend the city\xe2\x80\x99s money\nStoryComments\nPrint\nCreate a hardcopy of this page\nFont Size:\nDefault font size\nLarger font size\nPosted: Thursday, April 12, 2018 10:30 am\nSpend the city\xe2\x80\x99s money\n0\xc2\xa0comments\nResidents as young as 11 still can vote for capital projects they would like to see funded under participatory budgeting in the 27th District of Councilman Daneek Miller (D-St. Albans) and the 31st District of Councilman Donovan Richards (D-Laurelton).\nThe program allows residents to vote on how to spend $1 million for things like improvements to parks, schools, senior centers and streetscapes.\nPeople can vote online by going to the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s website at council.nyc.gov/pb/ through April 15. They also can vote at any LinkNYC kiosk.\nThe list of 12 eligible projects in Miller\xe2\x80\x99s district and their brief descriptions can be found on his official City Council website at council.nyc.gov/daneek-miller/pb/7/.\nThere also is a list of places where people still can vote in person before the deadline if they choose to do so.\nA list of projects in Richards\xe2\x80\x99 district, along with their descriptions and a list of in-person voting sites, is available on his official website at council.nyc.gov/donovan-richards/pb/7/.\nDiscuss\nPrint\nPosted in\nEastern/Southeast Queens News\non\nThursday, April 12, 2018 10:30 am.\nWelcome to the discussion.\nLog In\nSign Up\nPrint comments\nSubmit your news!\nSubmit your news! \xe4\xbf\x9d\xe6\x8a\xa4\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe6\xb0\x91\xe6\x9d\x83\xe7\x9b\x8a (\xe5\x9b\xbe)\n\xe9\xa6\x99\xe6\xb8\xaf\xe7\x88\x86\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe8\xa7\x84\xe6\xa8\xa1\xe6\xb8\xb8\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe9\xaa\x9a\xe4\xb9\xb1 \xe4\xbf\xae\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe6\x8a\xbc\xe5\x90\x8e\n\xe5\xb8\x83\xe7\xa2\x8c\xe4\xbb\x91\xe5\x8d\x8e\xe7\xad\x96\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\x81\xa5\xe5\xba\xb7\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe5\xae\xb6\xe5\xba\xad\xe6\x97\xa529\xe6\x97\xa5\xe7\x99\xbb\xe5\x9c\xba\n\xe6\xb5\x81\xe6\xb5\xaa\xe6\xb1\x89\xe5\xb8\xa6\xe8\x9d\x99\xe8\x9d\xa0\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe9\x93\x81\xe9\x97\xb9\xe4\xba\x8b \xe7\xab\x9f\xe6\x92\x9e\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe9\x80\x80\xe4\xbc\x91\xe8\xad\xa6\xe5\xae\x98\xe6\x9e\xaa\xe5\x8f\xa3\xe2\x80\xa6\n\xe5\x9b\xa0\xe6\x9a\xb4\xe9\x9b\xa8\xe5\xaf\xbc\xe8\x87\xb4\xe6\xb4\xaa\xe6\xb6\x9d \xe6\x96\xb0\xe5\xb7\x9e3\xe9\x83\xa1\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe5\x85\xa5\xe7\xb4\xa7\xe6\x80\xa5\xe7\x8a\xb6\xe6\x80\x81\n\xe4\xbe\xa8\xe6\x8a\xa5\xe7\x8b\xac\xe5\xae\xb6\xe8\xb0\x83\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe6\x8b\xa8\xe5\xbc\x80\xe9\x82\xb5\xe7\xab\xa5\xe6\xa1\x88\xe8\xbf\xb7\xe9\x9b\xbe\n\xe7\x83\xad\xe6\x92\xad\xe8\xa7\x86\xe9\xa2\x91\n1\xe5\xbc\xa0\xe6\xb8\xa9\xe5\xb8\x99\xef\xbc\x9a\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe6\xbc\x86\xe4\xb8\xba\xe5\xaa\x92\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\x89\xba\xe6\x9c\xaf\xe4\xb8\x96\xe7\x95\x8c2\xe6\x89\x93\xe5\x8d\xa1\xe7\xba\xbd\xe7\xba\xa6\xe6\x9c\x80\xe6\x96\xb0\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe6\xa0\x87\xef\xbc\x812\xe5\x88\x86\xe9\x92\x9f\xe5\xb8\xa6\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe6\x8a\xa2\xe5\x85\x88\xe7\x9c\x8b\xef\xbc\x813\xe7\x8b\xac\xe5\xae\xb6\xe4\xb8\x93\xe8\xae\xbf\xef\xbc\x9a\xe8\xb6\x85\xe7\x83\xad\xe9\x97\xa8\xe3\x80\x8a\xe4\xb8\x89\xe4\xbd\x93\xe3\x80\x8b\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe8\x80\x85\xe5\x88\x98\xe6\x85\x88\xe6\xac\xa34\xe6\xa0\xbc\xe8\x8e\xb1\xe5\xae\x9d\xe7\xbe\x8e\xe5\xad\x95\xef\xbc\x9a\xe4\xb8\x80\xe5\xb0\x81\xe7\xbb\x99\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xa5\xb3\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\x9c\x8b\xe5\x8f\x8b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbf\xa15\xe5\x8d\x8e\xe4\xba\xba\xe8\x89\xba\xe6\x9c\xaf\xe5\xae\xb6\xe8\xb0\xa2\xe6\x99\x93\xe6\xb3\xbd\xe5\x8f\x82\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe7\xbe\x8e\xe5\x9b\xbd\xe8\x89\xba\xe6\x9c\xaf\xe5\x95\x86\xe5\x8d\x8f\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe5\xba\xa6\xe8\x89\xba\xe6\x9c\xaf\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe5\xb1\x956\xe4\xb8\x80\xe8\xb5\xb7\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe4\xbe\xa8\xe6\x8a\xa5\xe5\xb0\x8f\xe8\xae\xb0\xe8\x80\x85\xe4\xbf\xb1\xe4\xb9\x90\xe9\x83\xa8\xe6\x8e\xa2\xe7\xb4\xa2\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe4\xb8\x96\xe7\x95\x8c\xe5\x90\xa7\xef\xbc\x81\n\xe5\x85\xb3\xe4\xba\x8e\xe4\xbe\xa8\xe6\x8a\xa5|\n\xe6\x8a\xa5\xe7\xba\xb8\xe5\xb9\xbf\xe5\x91\x8a|\n\xe6\x95\xb0\xe5\xad\x97\xe5\xb9\xbf\xe5\x91\x8a|\n\xe5\x85\x8d\xe8\xb4\xa3\xe5\xa3\xb0\xe6\x98\x8e|\n\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\xa3\xb0\xe6\x98\x8e|\n\xe8\x81\x94\xe7\xb3\xbb\xe6\x88\x91\xe4\xbb\xac|\n\xe6\x84\x8f\xe8\xa7\x81\xe5\xbb\xba\xe8\xae\xae|\n\xe7\xbd\x91\xe7\xab\x99\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe5\x9b\xbe|\nWAP\xe7\x89\x88\n\xe5\x8f\x8b\xe6\x83\x85\xe9\x93\xbe\xe6\x8e\xa5:\n\xe7\xbe\x8e\xe5\x9b\xbd\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\xe7\xbd\x91|\n\xe4\xbe\xa8\xe6\x8a\xa5\xe7\xbd\x91|\n58\xe5\x90\x8c\xe5\x9f\x8e\xe7\xba\xbd\xe7\xba\xa6\xe5\x8d\x8e\xe4\xba\xba\xe5\x88\x86\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe7\xbd\x91|\n\xe7\xba\xbd\xe7\xba\xa6\xe5\xa5\xbd\xe5\x90\x83\xe4\xb8\x8d\nCopyright \xe4\xbf\x9d\xe7\x95\x99\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\x88\xa9. THE CHINA PRESS All rights reserved.', b"LinkNYC kiosks showcase work by locals during National Poetry Month | am New York\nMenu\nLATEST PAPER\nSEARCH\nNews\nPolitics\nThings To Do\nEAT & DRINK\nEntertainment\nReal Estate\nTransit\nOpinion\nLATEST PAPER\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nHome\nNews\nPolitics\nElections\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nPets\nSecrets of NY\nReal Estate\nCity Living\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nStaten Island\nTransit\nSports\nOpinion\nJim Marguiles\nCartoon roundup\nWeather\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nNews\nLinkNYC kiosks showcase work by locals during National Poetry Month\nPoems were composed by those with HIV/AIDS and other conditions.\nLinkNYC kiosks are displaying work by Alliance for Positive Change's clients for\nNational Poetry Month.\nPhoto Credit: Alliance for Positive Change\nBy Lisa L. Colangelo lisa.colangelo@amny.com\n@lisalcolangelo\nUpdated April 15, 2018 4:59 PM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nWhile you are charging your phone at a LinkNYC kiosk this month, take a minute and soak in some poetry.\nThe electronic information boards will feature poems by clients of the Alliance for Positive Change, a nonprofit that helps people living with HIV/AIDS and other chronic illnesses.\nFor more than 15 years, the organization has offered creative writing classes that provide a safe and powerful outlet for people to express their life experiences.\nSome of the work has been featured in Situations, an annual literary journal and shared through live readings.\nBut this is the first time the work is being highlighted using 1,500 LinkNYC kiosks around the five boroughs through a partnership with the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications in honor of National Poetry Month.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe wanted to provide an opportunity other than support groups, something that provided intellectual stimulation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sharen Duke, executive director and CEO of the alliance. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you could utilize writing to express your fears, your trauma, your hopes, it can build self-esteem, recovery and healing.\xe2\x80\x9d\nRosa Velez, a former client, now helps facilitate the classes. Writing helped Velez deal with her deep depression and grief after her partner passed away while waiting for a liver transplant.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wanted a place where I could express what I was feeling but I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t really sure what I was feeling,\xe2\x80\x9d Velez said. \xe2\x80\x9cI was hurt and angry.\xe2\x80\x9d\nGet Breaking News emails\nThe latest about your city, as it happens.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\nHer writing group turned into a second family. And she now strives to share that support with other clients who might be intimidated by the idea of writing poetry.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe tell them to write from the heart,\xe2\x80\x9d Velez said, adding that she leaves each session with a feeling of hope.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt inspires me to come back and teach the class,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\nDuke said the writing groups, which meet weekly, have been held more than 800 times since starting in 2000 and have collectively created thousands of poems.\nShe reached out to her friend, Gerry Gomez Pearlberg, a writer and poet, to help design the class. Pearlberg trained students, such as Velez, to be leaders and carry the program forward.\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe respected the way we were feeling and always made us feel comfortable,\xe2\x80\x9d Velez said. \xe2\x80\x9cShe told us to write whatever we were feeling that day and it was OK.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSince some of the sensitive subject matter that comes up in discussions and in writing includes violence, abuse, rape and substance abuse, confidentiality is key, Velez said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever you say in the class stays in the class,\xe2\x80\x9d Velez said.\nExplaining the program to funders has sometimes been a challenge because they question how it can help with HIV prevention and other health issues, Duke said. But she is able to share examples of the program\xe2\x80\x99s positive impacts, for instance, one client proudly told Duke he spent his last dollar laminating his poem rather than purchasing a beer.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen a person feels respected, feels heard, feels good about themselves, they will be in a better place to take care of themselves,\xe2\x80\x9d Duke said.\nBy Lisa L. Colangelo lisa.colangelo@amny.com\n@lisalcolangelo\nLisa joined amNewYork as a staff writer in 2017. She previously worked at the New York Daily News and the Asbury Park Press covering politics, government and general assignment.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. All rights reserved.", b'The Week Ahead in New York Politics, April 16\nGotham Gazette\nThe Place for New York Policy and politics\nHomeNewest StoriesOpinionSubscribePodcasts\nMax & Murphy on PoliticsWhat\'s The [DATA] Point?Election Coverage\n2019 Public Advocate2018 Elections2017 Elections2016 Elections2014 ElectionsReporters\nBen MaxSamar KhurshidEthan Geringer-SamethCaitlyn RosenNoah BermanEmma WhitfordBen BrachfeldSavannah JacobsonTruman StephensAndrew MillmanColumnists\nJim BrennanCarol KellermannJessica WalkerEli ValentinDavid BloomfieldSteven ZeidmanRachael FaussCenter for an Urban FutureOtherContact UsDonate\nDeveloped in conjunction with Joomla extensions.\nConnect with usTwitterFacebook\nSTATE The Week Ahead in New York Politics, April 16April 15,\n2018 | by Ben Max & Ben Brachfeld\nTwitterIT news\nNew York City Hall\nWhat to watch for this week in New York politics:\nThe week begins with the New York political world fixated on the race for Governor after the Working Families Party endorsed Cynthia Nixon on Saturday. The WFP also endorsed City Council Member Jumaane Williams for Lieutenant Governor. Both Nixon and Williams are also running in their respective Democratic primaries, hoping to unseat Governor Andrew Cuomo and Lieutenant Governor Kathy Hochul.\nThe WFP endorsements came as the party itself was further fracturing, with Cuomo pulling labor unions from the party and the remaining progressive activists and advocacy groups sticking with the relatively small but influential group, and backing Nixon over Cuomo as she runs to the governor\xe2\x80\x99s left on virtually every issue. Nixon and Williams will now have the WFP ballot line for the general election, but the backing of the party and its members and member organizations are certain to boost their candidacies in the Democratic primary. It is unclear what further steps Cuomo and his allies will take to weaken the WFP and its chosen candidates, but the intra-Democratic party war is escalating.\nThe fallout from and analysis of these latest developments will headline at least the start of the week, also adding pressure on Democratic elected officials to choose between Cuomo and Nixon, as many have been hesitant to do so far. Added attention will come as state legislators return to Albany for three session days this week after the annual post-budget break. There are under two months until the end of the legislative session, and exactly 30 scheduled session days for legislative business in the capital. The return to session will also see the latest developments in the return of the Senate Independent Democratic Conference to the mainline Democratic fold.\nThat session will also be influenced by the outcomes of the special elections set to take place on Tuesday, April 24 -- one week from this Tuesday. There are 11 Assembly and Senate vacancies being filled, but the key race to watch is the state Senate race in Westchester.\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s clearly a great deal of intrigue in Albany and state government and politics more broadly. There will also of course be action in New York City, where there are several City Council hearings to be aware of this week, even as Speaker Corey Johnson and a delegation of Council members continues a trip to Israel -- they return this coming weekend.\nAs always, there are a variety of events to be aware of - see our day-by-day rundown below.\n***Do you have events or topics for us to include in an upcoming Week Ahead in New York Politics?e-mail Gotham Gazette editor Ben Max:\xc2\xa0This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it.***\nThe run of the week in detail:\nMondayAt the City Council on Monday:--The Committees on Health and Parks & Recreation will meet jointly at 10 a.m. to discuss a proposed law \xe2\x80\x9crequiring defibrillators at softball fields where youth leagues play.\xe2\x80\x9d--The Committee on Justice System will meet at 1 p.m. for an oversight hearing regarding \xe2\x80\x9cinvestigations and prosecutions of low wage theft.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe New York State Legislature will be in session on Monday in Albany, returning from the post-budget recess.\nAt 8:30 a.m. Monday, "NYIT, the University Transportation Research Center, NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering, Windels Marx, The City College of New York, and the New York City Council will host a symposium to discuss "Steps and Strides Towards A Sustainable Future", and the policies and evidence-based planning needed to use greener transportation. The event kicks off the week of Car Free Day which will take place on Saturday, April 21st."\nAt 10:30 a.m. Monday,\xc2\xa0city schools "Chancellor Richard A. Carranza will visit a STEAM lab and a dance class at P.S. 376 in Brooklyn." In the afternoon, he will meet with students and parents at town hall events: at 4 p.m. and at 5:30 p.m. at Brooklyn Technical High School.\nAt noon Monday, advocates and elected officials will gather on the steps of City Hall to \xe2\x80\x9cspeak out against very bad and concerning practices of the Board of Elections,\xe2\x80\x9d particularly regarding voter suppression. The rally is being led by The Black Institute.\nAt 12:30 p.m. Monday at the state Capitol in Albany, ""Seven prominent watchdog groups call for action on corruption in state government." Participants include: Citizens Budget Commission, Citizens Union, Common Cause NY, Fiscal Policy Institute, League of Women Voters NY State, New York Public Interest Group, and Reinvent Albany.\nAt 6 p.m. Monday\xc2\xa0Public Advocate Letitia James will deliver remarks at the Brooklyn Women\'s Bar Association and Brooklyn Law School Panel Discussion on Women\'s Suffrage, at Brooklyn Law School. At 7:45 p.m., James will deliver remarks at the 77th Precinct Community Council Gala, Milk River Restaurant in Brooklyn.\nAt 6:30 p.m. Monday, City Council Member Carlos Menchaca and the Consulate General of Mexico will host a welcome ceremony for new Schools Chancellor Richard Carranza at Sunset Park High School in Brooklyn.\nOn Monday, Mayor de Blasio will make his weekly appearance on NY1\xe2\x80\x99s Inside City Hall in the 7 and 11 p.m. hours.\nOn Monday \xe2\x80\x9cat 7:00 PM, Brooklyn Borough President Eric L. Adams will join the family and friends of 26-year-old Brandy Odom in marking a week since her body was discovered in Canarsie Park, having been the victim of a brutal murder. In remembrance of her life, and to keep attention on her still-unsolved slaughter, they will drape a memorial ribbon over several blocks of the park\'s fence, while urging the New York City Police Department (NYPD) to step up their efforts in apprehending her at-large killer.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTuesdayA"Governor Cuomo is in Suffolk County, Westchester County, and Albany" on Tuesday. At 10 a.m. he\'ll make an announcement at Sunken Meadow State Park in Kings Park. At noon, he\'ll make an announcement at Teamsters Local 456 in Elmsford.\nAt 1:30 p.m. Tuesday, Mayor\xc2\xa0"de Blasio will visit Bushwick Houses. Immediately after, the Mayor will make an announcement concerning rat abatement. This event is open press. There will be Q-and-A."\nAt the City Council on Tuesday:--The Subcommittee on Zoning and Franchises will meet at 9:30 a.m.--The Subcommittee on Landmarks, Public Siting, and Maritime Uses will meet at noon to discuss proposed laws relating to \xe2\x80\x9capproval of cemetery uses on land acquired in Queens before 1973\xe2\x80\x9d and to \xe2\x80\x9cauthorizing the Landmarks Preservation Commission to administer a historic preservation grant program.\xe2\x80\x9d--The Committee on Cultural Affairs will meet at 1 p.m. for an oversight hearing regarding \xe2\x80\x9c#MeToo and culture & the arts.\xe2\x80\x9d--The Subcommittee on Planning, Dispositions, and Concessions will meet at 2 p.m.\nThe New York State Legislature will be in session on Tuesday in Albany.\nAt 8 a.m. Tuesday,\xc2\xa0"By order of Mayor Bill de Blasio, NYC Parks will remove the monument to Dr. James Marion Sims. This order was given following the recommendations of the Mayoral Advisory Commission on City Art, Monuments, and Markers. Plans are being developed to commission a new work at this site. A temporary sign will be placed at the site tomorrow following removal."\nThe State Supreme Court will hold a hearing Monday on NYCHA tenants\xe2\x80\x99 demands for a preliminary injunction enforcing NYCHA to conduct new lead paint inspections. At 8:45 a.m., Danny Barber, the Chair of the Citywide Council of Presidents, Elie Hecht of At-Risk Community Services, and attorney Jim Walden will hold a press conference preceding the hearing. [Listen to Barber and Hecht explain their lawsuit and discuss issues with NYCHA on a recent episode of the Max & Murphy podcast]\n"On Tuesday, April 17, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC) will hold a public hearing on the proposed designation of the Coney Island (Riegelman) Boardwalk as a scenic landmark, and the proposed Central Harlem West 130-132nd Street Historic District."\nAt 9 a.m. Tuesday, the CUNY Graduate School of Public Health and Health Policy will host \xe2\x80\x9cNew York State Single-Payer Healthcare? Economics, Politics, and Prospects\xe2\x80\x9d at the CUNY School of Public Health, discussing the prospects of single payer healthcare in New York State. Panelists will include City Council Health Committee Chair Mark Levine, economist Gerald Friedman, Marissa Martin of Young Invincibles, and registered nurses Marva Wade and Kim Behrens.\nAt 10:30 a.m. Tuesday, the New York City Coalition for Adult Literacy will rally at Bronx Borough Hall to protest Mayor de Blasio\'s \xe2\x80\x9cproposed cuts to English and other adult literacy programs in the City Budget.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAt 10:30 a.m. Tuesday in Albany, "tenants and legislators will rally "to demand stronger rent laws." Participants will include Senator Jose Serrano, Senator Liz Kruger, Senator Gustavo Rivera, Senator Brian Benjamin, and Senator Brad Hoylman; The Real Rent Reform Campaign including Met Council on Housing, Woodside on the Move, Catholic Migration Services, Neighbors Helping Neighbors, Fifth Ave Committee, Northwest Bronx Community Clergy Coalition, Chhaya CDC. They want the senate to pass three bills: End the Preferential Rent Scam (S.6527); Repeal the Vacancy Bonus (S.1593); Repeal Vacancy Destabilization (S.3482).\nAt 11 a.m. Tuesday,\xc2\xa0outside New York State Supreme Court, "Public Advocate James will make an announcement related to the legalization of marijuana in New York. She will be joined by elected officials and advocates" including City Council Members Antonio Reynoso and Donovan Richards; Brooklyn Defenders; Drug Policy Alliance; Latino Justice; Law Enforcement Action Partnership; Legal Aid Society; National Action Network; New York Cannabis Bar Association.\nOn Tuesday at noon, "New York elected officials and three of CUNYs Latin@s Studies institutes, along with other partners, will release the "Latinos United in Action - New York Latin@s" Report and announce the second annual Summit on Latinos to be held on June 1st, 2018."\nWednesdayAt the City Council on Wednesday:--The Committees on Land Use, Finance, and Education will meet jointly at 10 a.m. for an oversight hearing reviewing the recent Council report \xe2\x80\x9cPlanning to Learn: The School Building Challenge,\xe2\x80\x9d to discuss several proposed laws relating to school sitings and land use for education, and to discuss two resolutions: the first one calling on the state to confer the city with broad design-build authority for all capital projects, and the second calling upon the School Construction Authority \xe2\x80\x9cto more clearly communicate to the general public how city residents can submit potential school sites and the guidelines used by the School Construction Authority in considering whether a suggested school site meets the evaluation standards used by the authority.\xe2\x80\x9d--The Committee on Economic Development will meet at 10 a.m. for an oversight hearing regarding \xe2\x80\x9cmodifying helicopter routes to reduce noise over residential neighborhoods,\xe2\x80\x9d to discuss a proposed law relating to \xe2\x80\x9can annual helicopter sightseeing plan,\xe2\x80\x9d and to discuss a resolution \xe2\x80\x9ccalling on the Federal Aviation Administration to amend the North Shore helicopter route to extend further west to cover Northeast Queens.\xe2\x80\x9d--The Committee on Technology will meet at 1 p.m. for an oversight hearing regarding LinkNYC.--The Committees on Justice System and Juvenile Justice will meet jointly at 1 p.m. for an oversight hearing regarding \xe2\x80\x9cNYC\xe2\x80\x99s preparedness to Raise the Age.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe New York State Legislature will be in session on Wednesday in Albany.\nBetween Wednesday and Sunday, the National Action Network and the Rev. Al Sharpton will be hosting its annual National Convention at the Sheraton Hotel in Times Square. Speakers will include numerous \xe2\x80\x9cinfluencers\xe2\x80\x9d from all walks of civic life. Speakers include U.S. Senators Bernie Sanders, Kirsten Gillibrand, Cory Booker, Kamala Harris, and Elizabeth Warren; U.S. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and other representatives; numerous advocacy leaders; local politicians such as First Lady Chirlane McCray, State Comptroller Tom DiNapoli, and City Comptroller Scott Stringer; and many others. See event website for specific days and times of appearances.\nAt 6:30 p.m. Wednesday, Mayor de Blasio will hold a town hall meeting at the Bronx School of Law, Government & Justice in Concourse Village. He will be joined by Council Member Vanessa Gibson, Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr, and Assemblymembers Michael Blake and Latoya Joyner.\nThursdayAt the City Council on Thursday:--The Committee on Land Use will meet at 11 a.m.\nAt 9 a.m. Thursday, City & State will host the \xe2\x80\x9cHealthy New York Summit\xe2\x80\x9d at the National Geographic Encounter in Midtown. The event will bring \xe2\x80\x9cinsights and perspectives from all sectors of New York\xe2\x80\x99s health care decision-making together to identify challenges and discuss solutions to improve our system.\xe2\x80\x9d Speakers will include politicians, government officials, academics, advocates, and business leaders.\nOn Thursday at 10 a.m. at City Hall, "Noting the devastating death of Saheed Vassell last week in Brooklyn, the Progressive Caucus of the New York City Council, Community Access, and Communities for Crisis Intervention Teams in NYC (CCITNYC) coalition will call on the Administration revive the Mayoral Task Force on Behavioral Health and Criminal Justice, which will be empowered to help create a sustained city-wide approach to emotionally distressed persons and the ongoing mental health crisis New York City faces. The Caucus and its allies are also calling for the City to create a new system where social workers or well-trained 911 call operators divert 911 calls to social workers or therapists or trained peers instead of police response; greatly expand mobile crisis teams who can respond within 30 minutes of a call; build a large system of co-response teams who can respond to 911 calls; and build a system where trained peers or therapist can meet police at the scene of 911 calls."\nAt 10:30 a.m. Thursday, "The City\xe2\x80\x99s Charter Revision Commission will hold its first public meeting on Thursday, April 19 \xe2\x80\x93 the first step in the Commission\xe2\x80\x99s process of reviewing the City Charter. This is an organizational meeting and does not include public testimony."\nFriday and the weekendAt 9 a.m. Friday, the New York City Board of Correction will meet at 125 Worth Street in Manhattan.\nMayor de Blasio may make his weekly appearance on WNYC\xe2\x80\x99s The Brian Lehrer Show at 10 a.m. on Friday.\nSaturday will be the annual "car free" day in New York City.\nAt 6:30 p.m. Saturday, Mayor de Blasio will appear at the 2018 Inner Circle Show at the New York Hilton Midtown. Inner Circle is a charity fundraiser comedy show hosted by the New York City press corps.\nSunday is Earth Day.\n***Have events or topics for us to include in an upcoming Week Ahead in New York Politics? Entertainment\nLegal\nPolitics\nCity\nNational\nState\nBusiness\nSports\nCyclones\nIslanders\nNets\nHistory\nNeighborhoods\nCentral Brooklyn Jazz Festival To Include Over 500 Artists\nMarch 22, 2012 Brooklyn Eagle Staff\nBROOKLYN \xe2\x80\x94 From March 30 until April 30, the Central Brooklyn Jazz Consortium (CBJC) will present the 13th Annual Central Brooklyn Jazz Festival. More than 500 artists will be performing in 40 events at venues from Coney Island to Williamsburg in Brooklyn.\nBrooklyn jazz has a rich past, and its legacy is celebrated every April. Clarence Mosley Jr., chairman of the consortium, says, \xe2\x80\x9cCBJC enters its 13th season in presenting the African-American art form jazz to the under-served populations of Brooklyn. We continue to recognize the contributions and creativity of the jazz community of Brooklyn, past and present.\xe2\x80\x9d\nInternationally recognized musicians will perform in community centers, clubs, colleges and cultural and faith-based institutions. The jazz festival is accessible to all, with 85 percent of the events free or at a cost of less than $20.\nFor information, contact CBJC at (718) 773-2252 or [email\xc2\xa0protected]\nAmong others, performers this year will include Bilal Sunni Ali, Kenyatta Beasley, Gloria Cooper, Steve Cromity, Bob Cunningham, Lou Donaldson and Eric Frazier.\nSHARE ARTICLE:\nLeave a Comment\nRelated Articles\nDemocracy vouchers stall, but they could make a comeback\nJune 21 |\nJeffery Harrell\nMeet the candidates in Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s judicial elections\nJune 21 |\nRob Abruzzese\nMore enforcement cameras coming to Brooklyn bus lanes\nJune 21 |\nScott Enman\nFBI agent was on the phone with his wife when he was shot in the back\nJune 21 |\nNoah Goldberg\nBrooklyn Today\nJune 21, 2019Jun 21, 2019 | Clouds, 77\xc2\xb0 F\nDaily Top Brooklyn News\nFollow\n@bkeagle\nContribute\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nTerms & Conditions\nContact Us\nThe Brooklyn Daily Eagle and brooklyneagle.com cover Brooklyn 24/7 online and five days a week in print with the motto, \xe2\x80\x9cAll Brooklyn All the Time.\xe2\x80\x9d With a history dating back to 1841, the Eagle is New York City\xe2\x80\x99s only daily devoted exclusively to Brooklyn.\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Everything Brooklyn Media\nDAILY TOP BROOKLYN NEWS\nNews for those who live, work and play in Brooklyn and beyond\nLeave this field empty if you're human:", b'NYC to Set Up Real-Time Monitoring for Service Availability of Public Wi-Fi and Phone Call Kiosks\nimage/svg+xml\nCONTINUE TO SITE\nThis website uses cookies in order to offer you the most relevant information.\n\xc3\x97\nLearn More\nI Accept\nMAGAZINE\nNEWSLETTERS\nEVENTS\nPAPERS\nNAVIGATOR\nSECTIONS\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL EDUCATION\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL GOVERNMENT\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nDIGITAL STATES PERFORMANCE INSTITUTE\nTOP 25\nGOVTECH 100\nSEARCH\nCybersecurity\nGovTech Biz\nEmerging Tech\nCloud\nGov Experience\nMore\nData\nNYC to Set Up Real-Time Monitoring for Service Availability of Public Wi-Fi and Phone Call Kiosks\nNew York City\'s more than 1,500 LinkNYC kiosks, which offer free public telephone calls and Wi-Fi, will get live, by-the-hour monitoring via the Internet of Things later this spring.\nby Theo Douglas\n/\nApril 18, 2018\nShutterstock\nNew York City, which is already bridging the gap for many thousands of households without broadband access, will ramp up support for its free public telephones and Wi-Fi by using technology to answer a simple question that has likely puzzled residents since the days of pay phones: Which ones work?\nThe city\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC initiative provides the ability to make free calls, charge a cellphone or smartphone, and connect to free Wi-Fi at more than 1,500 kiosks in all five boroughs. Now, with an Internet of Thing-like paradigm, it will set up a program to monitor in real time which ones aren\'t working.\nLinkNYC has good systemwide Wi-Fi and tablet service availability, at 99.8 percent and more than 95 percent uptime, respectively. But Council Member Ben Kallos, a software developer who championed then-Mayor Michael Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cReinvent Payphones\xe2\x80\x9d initiative in 2013, noticed some kiosks in his district were partially out of order, and offered Wi-Fi but not free calls.\nRELATEDNew York City Names New Chief Privacy Officer New York City to Build Nation\xe2\x80\x99s First City-Based Wireless TestbedAnne Roest Retires, NYC Hires Atlanta CIO Samir Saini as IT CommissionerDuring a conversation with interns in November as they attempted to test the Wi-Fi, Kallos told Government Technology, the idea struck him of using existing Internet protocols (IPs) such as Ping, to probe kiosk service outages in real time instead of waiting for regular, but less frequent physical inspections.\nKallos suggested the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) use IPs to improve the tracking of the free call availability, the city said in a news release.\nDoITT partnered with the New York City Council Technology Committee, chaired by Peter Koo, and with Kallos to develop a real-time monitoring system based on newly available hourly Link service information from CityBridge, the franchisee behind LinkNYC.\nThe system will intake the information into a new data set that will be available to the public in May on NYC OpenData, the city\xe2\x80\x99s open data portal, the city said.\n"This real-time, up-to-the-hour monitoring will ensure residents are able to find free phones that are working whenever they need one,"\xc2\xa0the city said in a statement.\nThe City Council\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Committee on Technology will also hear about the project in an update on LinkNYC at 1 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time on April 18.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was the genesis, going from this very 19th-century, bureaucratic format to the Internet of Things, being able to use the Internet of Things to do an audit in real time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kallos, who emphasized that he, like so many millions of residents, relies on LinkNYC kiosks to recharge his cellphone on the way home at night, and to supplant his existing data plan.\nThe council member\xe2\x80\x99s support of the issue has included advocating in 2014 for upgrading phone booths. During his re-election campaign, his campaign office was close enough to a LinkNYC kiosk to make use of its free Wi-Fi, Kallos said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think there\xe2\x80\x99s an importance about custodianship for existing products. When I care about something, I don\xe2\x80\x99t stop caring about it when it happens. I still want it to succeed,\xe2\x80\x9d Kallos said, noting that as of 2015 according the U.S. Census, more than 730,000 households in New York \xe2\x80\x94 including one-quarter of households in Brooklyn and one-third of those in the Bronx \xe2\x80\x94 did not have broadband.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaving free Wi-Fi matters. LinkNYC works,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\nOther New York City officials agreed.\xc2\xa0Samir Saini, DoITT commissioner, praised Kallos for his dedication and pointed to LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s usage by more than 3.7 million people already as proof that modern monitoring is essential.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis shows how important the program has become in a relatively short time, and why it\xe2\x80\x99s paramount that we make sure Links are operating at an optimal level. In a matter of weeks, New Yorkers are going to be able to see that for themselves when we publish a new open data set showing real-time status of all the functions of each kiosk,\xe2\x80\x9d Saini said in a statement.\nKoo, the Technology Committee chairman, highlighted the "endless potential"\xc2\xa0for LinkNYC\xc2\xa0kiosks in a statement.\n"A robust monitoring and maintenance program will ensure this innovative new program lives up to its potential,"\xc2\xa0he said, thanking Kallos, LinkNYC and DoITT.\nRuth Fasoldt, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s director of external affairs, said in a statement it is \xe2\x80\x9cproud to offer a high level of service that millions of New Yorkers rely on."\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are happy to work with DoITT and Council Member Kallos, in providing additional data for the City\'s open data portal so New Yorkers can see the status of Links throughout the city,\xe2\x80\x9d Fasoldt said.\nTheo Douglas\nStaff Writer\nTheo Douglas is a staff writer for Government Technology. His reporting experience includes covering municipal, county and state governments, business and breaking news. He has a Bachelor\'s degree in Newspaper Journalism and a Master\'s in History, both from California State University, Long Beach.\nRELATED\nNew York City Names New Chief Privacy Officer\nNew York City to Build Nation\xe2\x80\x99s First City-Based Wireless Testbed\nAnne Roest Retires, NYC Hires Atlanta CIO Samir Saini as IT Commissioner\nDISCUSS\nWe invite you to discuss and comment on this article using social media.\nMORE FROM Data\nPapers\nSPONSORED ARTICLES\nERP Modernization: How the Cloud Delivers Scalability, Security and Innovation\nThe Reality of the Local Government Cybersecurity Skill Gap\nGovernment No Longer Has to Choose Between Cybersecurity and Productivity\nNEWSLETTERS\nGovTech Today - Daily top stories\nFutureStructure - Weekly system engineering concepts\nPublic CIO - Weekly thought leadership\nNEWSLETTERS\nGOVTECH TODAY\nGOVTECH BIZ\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nPUBLIC CIO\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nK-12\nHIGHER EDUCATION\nSubscribe\nABOUT\nPRIVACY\nCONTACT\nADVERTISE\nGT Logo\n\xc2\xa9 2019 All rights reserved. e.Republic', b'The Price for Free Wi-Fi Kiosks in Seattle: A Private Company Collecting Your Data | Seattle Magazine\nJump to navigation\nMENU\nEat & Drink\nRestaurants\nBeer, Wine & Bars\nArts & Culture\nTheater\nExhibits\nDance\nLife & Style\nShopping\nHome & Garden\nNeighborhoods\nFashion\nHealth, Beauty & Fitness\nTravel & Outdoors\nHiking\nCamping\nRoad Trips\nNews\nPolitics\nTransportation\nCity Life\nBest of Seattle\nBest Neighborhoods\nBest of Beer Awards\nWashington Wine Awards\nMost Influential People\nEvents\nParty Photos\nPromotions\nTHE MAGAZINE\nCurrent Issue\nArchive\nDigital Edition\nReprints\nSubscribe\nCustomer Service\nAdvertise\nRenew\nContact\nPrivacy Policy\nTHE MAGAZINE\nCurrent Issue\nArchive\nDigital Edition\nReprints\nCustomer Service\nRenew\nGive a Gift\n| \xc2\xa0 NEWSLETTER \xc2\xa0 |\nSUBSCRIBE\nNews The Price for Free Wi-Fi Kiosks in Seattle: A Private Company Collecting Your Data\nIn the wake of Facebook\'s data collection scandal, should Seattle reconsider a proposal for free Wi-Fi at downtown bus stops?\nBY: Erica C. Barnett\n| Posted April 18, 2018\nImage Credit:\xc2\xa0IntersectionA Google-affiliated company called Intersection is in talks with the city of Seattle to provide free Wi-Fi service, phone charging ports, and real-time information about city services at bus stops throughout downtown Seattle -- but there\xe2\x80\x99s a catch.\nAccording to New York-based Intersection, which has an office in Seattle, the kiosks provide steady revenue to cities through ad-sharing agreements while remaining \xe2\x80\x9ccompletely free for cities, taxpayers, and users.\xe2\x80\x9d The concept has its fans (New York and London have signed up), but also its critics, who have raised concerns about privacy, data sharing, and visual clutter on city streets.\nThe deal, proponents say, would provide the city with badly needed funding for transportation projects, promote digital equity for Seattle residents without access to the Internet at home or through their cell-phone provider, and enhance Seattle\xe2\x80\x99s reputation as a \xe2\x80\x9cSmart City\xe2\x80\x9d that uses data to provide services more efficiently. But at a time when companies like Facebook are facing questions over their use of members\xe2\x80\x99 private information, privacy advocates are cautioning cities to pump the brakes on partnerships with big-data companies that promise something for nothing.\nRepresentatives for Intersection did not return multiple calls and emails for comment (see below for update), but according to the company\xe2\x80\x99s website, the kiosks offer advertisers a \xe2\x80\x9creal-time, localized platform\xe2\x80\x94fed by data-driven APIs\xe2\x80\x94to connect with their audiences with more relevance, in the context of their journeys throughout the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCity council member Mike O\xe2\x80\x99Brien says that when former mayor Ed Murray broached the kiosk proposal last year, the pitch was that the ad revenues could help pay for the downtown streetcar. Although the streetcar project has been\xc2\xa0put on hold\xc2\xa0because of cost overruns, the city is facing another imminent transportation funding challenge: Federal funding for the 2015 Move Seattle levy, which funds transportation projects across the city is\xc2\xa0falling short\xc2\xa0of expectations, which could lead the city to look for new revenues to offset some of the shortfall.\nMayor Jenny Durkan\xe2\x80\x99s office declined to comment on the record about the Link Seattle plan, but is reportedly reviewing the latest version of Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy and could announce something publicly in the next few months. Mafara Hobson, communications director for the Seattle Department of Transportation, says SDOT \xe2\x80\x9cis conducting an initial research and feasibility study\xe2\x80\x9d on the plan, but adds that \xe2\x80\x9cthe work remains a preliminary concept that would require executive approval and significant legislative review and requirements.\xe2\x80\x9d (SDOT is the lead agency on the proposal because the kiosks would be located in city rights-of-way).\nO\xe2\x80\x99Brien says he\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cskeptical\xe2\x80\x9d of Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s proposal, both because it would require changing the city\xe2\x80\x99s sign code to allows ads on city sidewalks\xe2\x80\x94itself a major political lift\xe2\x80\x94and because of a \xe2\x80\x9cgrowing concern about how companies are capturing our data and using it\xe2\x80\x9d without our knowledge. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you\xe2\x80\x99re realizing the stupid test you took on Facebook now is in the hands of some international conglomerate that\xe2\x80\x99s trying to influence elections,\xe2\x80\x9d O\xe2\x80\x99Brien says, it makes sense for cities to \xe2\x80\x9cbe very careful\xe2\x80\x9d about authorizing companies to collect their residents\xe2\x80\x99 private information.\nSpecifically, privacy advocates in other cities have raised alarms about how Intersection uses the data it collects.\xc2\xa0Although Intersection has said that it collects only \xe2\x80\x9canonymous, aggregated\xe2\x80\x9d information about its users, digital privacy advocates say that \xe2\x80\x9canonymous\xe2\x80\x9d information can be analyzed not only to extrapolate what type of ads a kiosk should display based on a user\xe2\x80\x99s search history, but to identify and track specific people based on their \xe2\x80\x9cdigital fingerprints\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a troubling capability in the hands of overzealous law enforcement, or immigration officials seeking to track down undocumented immigrants, or an employer who wants to know how many hours a perspective hire puts in at her current job.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe hold government to a higher standard than businesses\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99re not supposed to be profiting at the expense of the people,\xe2\x80\x9d says David Robinson, a member of the Seattle Privacy Coalition who is skeptical of Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s privacy claims. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the data is being stored somewhere, then eventually someone will abuse it, no matter what the policy is. If you really don\xe2\x80\x99t want people\xe2\x80\x99s data to be misused, then you shouldn\'t be collecting it.\xe2\x80\x9d\nShankar Narayan, policy director for the ACLU of Washington, says \xe2\x80\x9cit sounds very much as though the price of free Wi-Fi is going to be Seattleites becoming the product\xe2\x80\x94their movements, possibly the information on their cell phones, being downloaded and monetized by a company.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAlthough proponents at the city argue that free Wi-Fi levels the playing field between people who have smartphones with unlimited data plans and those who don\xe2\x80\x99t, Narayan says that\xe2\x80\x99s a Faustian bargain. \xe2\x80\x9cBasically, we\xe2\x80\x99re saying people who have the means to have an unlimited mobile plan don\xe2\x80\x99t have to sacrifice their privacy to get Wi-Fi.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAdditionally, data collection opens up the possibility of data breaches, like the one at Facebook that allowed Cambridge Analytica to gather personal information on tens of millions of Facebook users.\nDevin Glaser, the policy and political director of Upgrade Seattle, a group that advocates for municipally funded broadband service, says free Wi-Fi at bus stops does almost nothing to address the lack of digital equity in Seattle. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you picture a 12-year-old child needing an internet connection to finish their homework, the fact that they can have access while at the bus stop doesn\'t really cut it,\xe2\x80\x9d Glaser says. \xe2\x80\x9cWe need to ensure that all of Seattle\'s residents have a robust home connection, not an ad-driven boost to our Words with Friends games while we\'re waiting for the 7.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn New York City, where a consortium of companies, including Intersection, signed a 12-year contract with the city to install more than 1,000 kiosks under the brand name LinkNYC in 2016, the program has been a source of ongoing controversy. Touch-screen tablets had to be removed from the kiosks because passersby were using them to watch pornography, and privacy advocates\xc2\xa0raised questions\xc2\xa0about the company\xe2\x80\x99s retention of personal data, including browser history. Although citizen activists\xc2\xa0forced the city\xc2\xa0to revise Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy to limit how long the company would store people\xe2\x80\x99s private information, they have been unable to force the company to turn off the cameras that are located in every kiosk, recording silent video 24 hours a day. Intersection says it deletes that video every seven days unless it\xe2\x80\x99s needed \xe2\x80\x9cto investigate an incident."\nPrivacy advocates say Seattle has done a better job than most major cities, including New York, of protecting its residents from public and private surveillance. Last year, the city council passed an ordinance that gives the council some oversight over city departments\xe2\x80\x99 use of surveillance technologies\xe2\x80\x94things like the controversial \xe2\x80\x9cwireless mesh\xe2\x80\x9d system that gave Seattle police the ability to track people using wireless devices throughout the city, or the Acyclica system, which tracks travelers\xe2\x80\x99 progress through downtown using a series of devices that detect and identify people with Wi-Fi-enabled devices. (A full list of the 28 city-operated surveillance technologies identified last year is available on the city\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0website.)\nSeattle could consider beefing up its privacy ordinance to make it harder for companies to track and misuse user data. But that would require leaders to educate themselves on emerging privacy concerns proactively, the ACLU\xe2\x80\x99s Narayan says. \xe2\x80\x9cCities are not often sophisticated actors in this space\xe2\x80\x94they don\xe2\x80\x99t know when they\xe2\x80\x99re getting a bad deal.\xe2\x80\x9d Narayan says that before cities sign deals with companies like Intersection, they should take the time to understand how the technology operates and put the appropriate safeguards in place.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen automobiles first came in, there were no speed limits and no red lights, and people were getting run over and killed all the time,\xe2\x80\x9d Narayan says. \xe2\x80\x9cThe automobile didn\xe2\x80\x99t die because we invented red lights and air bags and better brakes and put bumpers on cars. The technology better and everyone got a better deal out of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\nUPDATE (4/20):\xc2\xa0When reached after the initial publication of this story, Intersection spokesman Dan Levitan said the company does not collect browsing data or track users across the city. He did not deny that the technological capability for such data collection does exist, but stressed that the privacy policy for LinkNYC requires that this activity does not take place in any capacity. Intersection says that its privacy policy agreement in New York City protects users from data collection activity. Those agreements, however, are made on a city-to-city basis, and the issues now being raised by privacy advocates in Seattle draw comparisons to those raised by the New York Civil Liberties Union last year.\nLevitan provided Seattle magazine with the following statement: "Intersection takes user privacy seriously and works closely with our city partners to craft strong privacy policies for all our Link deployments. We do not track or record the browsing activity of our users. Advertising on Link displays is never targeted at any individual, and there is no advertising inserted on mobile devices that connect to Link Wi-Fi. Cameras are only used for monitoring and maintenance of the structures and cannot be used for advertising or any other purpose. Footage is only accessible by law enforcement with a court order or lawful request. We are proud of the LinkNYC program, our partnership with the City of New York, and the of the service we provide to over 3.7 million users.\xe2\x80\x9d\nA previous version of this story incorrectly indicated that Chicago has signed up for Intersection\'s Wi-Fi service, which is not the case. A previous version also mischaracterized the manner in which Intersection\'s LinkNYC is utilizing user data. Those errors have been corrected.\nRelated Content\nThe Latest Battle Over the Showbox\nBy: Erica C. Barnett\nWhen a Seattle boy couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop playing video games, his parents came to a hard truth: Their son was addicted. And he\xe2\x80\x99s not alone. In our tech-focused city\xe2\x80\x94and the\nnation\xe2\x80\x94more people are seeking help for this condition. But there\xe2\x80\x99s no easy fix.\nEat & DrinkRestaurants\nBeer, Wine & Bars\nArts & CultureMusic\nTheater\nExhibits\nDance\nLife & StyleShopping\nHome & Garden\nNeighborhoods\nFashion\nHealth, Beauty & Fitness\nTravel & OutdoorsGetaways\nHiking\nCamping\nRoad Trips\nNewsKnute Berger Column\nPolitics\nTransportation\nCity Life\nBest of SeattleBest Restaurants\nBest Neighborhoods\nBest of Beer Awards\nWashington Wine Awards\nMost Influential People\nEventsParty Photos\nPromotions\nPopular Content\nBest Beer Destinations Around Seattle\nSeattle Drag Performer Aleksa Manila Takes Pride in Community\n150 Things Every Seattleite Must Do\nWhy Many Seattleites Now Use a Personal Concierge\nTech Addiction Is on the Rise in Seattle and Beyond\nSeattle Life\nMandarin Guide to Seattle / \xc2\xa0\xe8\xa5\xbf\xe9\x9b\x85\xe5\x9b\xbe\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\xe7\x94\x9f\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\x8d\x97\nTop Doctors 2019\nSponsored\nWhen Aspirin Isn\xe2\x80\x99t Enough: Finding a Solution to Back and Neck Pain\nMaturing Markets Look to Downsize to an Elevated Urban Lifestyle\nSpend Your Summer in the Heart of Washington Wine Country\nSummer Sips in Lake Chelan Valley\nMore Sponsored\nSpecial Advertising Sections\nHead North: 11 British Columbia Destinations to Visit this Spring\nSpecial Advertising Section: Dental Guide\n5 top Pacific Northwest spas offer stress-free gifts or stress-free treatments\nAward-winning real estate agents in greater Seattle\n7 Cannabis Products to Enjoy this Fall\n13 Craft Beverage Destinations in Sunny Yakima\n6 Marijuana Retailers In and Around Seattle\nNewsletter\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nAddress Change\nContact\nAbout\nEditors\' Bios\nJobs & Internships\nPrivacy Policy\nWriter Guidelines\n\xc2\xa9Copyright 2019 Tiger Oak Media.\xc2\xa0 All Rights Reserved.', b'City sees boom in online applications for food stamps - New York Daily News\nSkip to content\nTopics\nxml:space="preserve">\nSubscriber Services\nManage Subscription\nEZ Pay\nDelivery Issue\nSubscriber Terms\nNew York\nNYC Crime\nBronx\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nEducation\nObituaries\nWeather\nSports\nYankees\nMets\nGiants\nJets\nKnicks\nNets\nRangers\nIslanders\nFootball\nBasketball\nBaseball\nHockey\nSoccer\nMore Sports\nI\'d Click That\nOdds\nGolf\nNews\nCrime\nU.S.\nPolitics\nBill de Blasio 2020 Campaign\nWorld\nEntertainment\nMovies\nTV\nMusic\nBroadway\nGossip\nLifestyle\nHealth\nEats\nGames\nViva\nBest Reviews\nTravel Deals\nOpinion\nPhotos\nHoroscopes\nDaily\nE-Newspaper\nAutos\nCovers\nSpecial Sections\nClassifieds\nPublic Notices\nBranded Content\nPaid Partner Content\nPaid Content By Brandpoint\nTAG disclosure\nSearch\nxml:space="preserve">\nNew York\nSports\nNews\nEntertainment\nOpinion\nAdvertisement\nAdvertisement\nNew York\nCity sees boom in online applications for food stamps\nBy Jillian Jorgensen\n| NEW YORK DAILY NEWS |\nApr 23, 2018\n|\n4:00 AM\nOnline enrollment makes it easier for eligible families to receive food stamps. (Andrew Savulich/New York Daily News)\nAlmost 80% of the city\'s food stamp recipients are filing their applications online \xe2\x80\x94 one of several technological improvements officials say make it easier for the working hungry to get help.\n"During the last four years, we\'ve put in place strategies to fight hunger by making access to benefits for eligible families and individuals more readily available," city Human Resources Administration Commissioner Steven Banks told the Daily News. "In contrast, the federal government is prepared to dramatically cut back the federal role and support for preventing hunger."\nAdvertisement\nIn a city that receives about 24,000 applications a month for SNAP, formerly known as food stamps, 79% are filed online, Banks said, and more than 1 million people have signed up for accounts with HRA ACCESS online. That means less time waiting around in offices, Banks said.\n"These are critical federal benefits that are intended to prevent hunger, and the caseload includes substantial numbers of working families and individuals for whom going to our offices to get these vital benefits means a choice between missing work and eating, and potentially losing their job in the process," said Banks, a former Legal Aid attorney who recalled his own clients languishing in long lines.\nFor those who can\'t file applications from home, the city\'s also rolled out computer banks and self-service kiosks at HRA offices to allow them to fill out forms and submit applications on their own. In addition, the city\'s launched a smart phone app to allow people to file some forms by simply taking a photo and uploading them.\n"As a Legal Aid lawyer, among the most frustrating interactions between clients and staff were, \'I submitted the document,\' \'We don\'t have it,\' \'Yes I did,\' \'But we don\'t have it,\' conversations," he said. "And the mobile app allows documents to be submitted and a record to be created."\nBanks said more than 2.5 million documents have been uploaded to the app in the year it\'s been active.\nThe city\'s just as rigorous about making sure requirements are met, he said \xe2\x80\x94 but it\'s easier on both staff and clients to provide the information online. That allows the staff to focus on clients in person who struggle with technology.\n"New Yorkers transact their business online using mobile apps and using self-service tools," Banks said. "By implementing this kind of technology for our clients, we\'re making sure that eligible clients receive the federal and state assistance to which they\'re entitled, and we\'re addressing perennial challenges with staff workload," he said.\nRecertifying benefits used to require clients to wait at home or be available to take a phone call during a four-hour window, which he said led to missed appointments, cases being closed and unnecessary hearings.\nBut the city now allows people in three boroughs, Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island, to call on-demand \xe2\x80\x94 and 76% of the interviews are handled by phone at the client\'s convenience, he said. That\'s led to a 46% boost in the amount of interviews that actually get done.\nThe program will expand to Queens and the Bronx by the end of the year.\nTo boost participation, the city will launch a public information campaign about the reforms with ads in print media, on LinkNYC kiosks and in subways.\nThe benefits aren\'t just critical to those who use them \xe2\x80\x94 they also fuel the city\'s economy, he said.\n"National studies have shown that every dollar of food stamps injects a $1.70 into the local economy, so our food stamp program, our federal food stamp program provides $5.4 billion in funds to the local economy," he said. "That supports both supermarkets and the people who work in stores both large and small that sell food."\nThe advancements come while the federal government has proposed changes to SNAP that will cut benefits and eligibility for millions in the country.\ndaily news exclusives\nAdvertisement\nRecommended', b'NYC Rakes In Cash From Inmates\' Phone Calls, Advocates Say | Patch\nToggle York, NY\nBayside-Douglaston, NY\nWilliamsburg-Greenpoint, NY\nState Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\npolitics & government\nShared from New York City, NY\nNYC Rakes In Cash From Inmates\' Phone Calls, Advocates Say\nA City Council bill would bar the city from charging inmates to keep in touch with loved ones.\nBy Noah Manskar, Patch Staff\nApr 24, 2018 10:10 am ET | Updated Apr 24, 2018 10:21 am ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nNEW YORK, NY \xe2\x80\x94 People jailed on Rikers Island shouldn\'t have to line the city\'s pockets just to call their loved ones, advocates argued Monday. A City Council bill would require the Department of Correction to provide free phone calls at city jails and give up the $5 million a year that advocates say the city earns from phone fees. "People should not have to choose between making phone calls and caring for their families," said Dwayne Lee, a formerly incarcerated community leader with the activist group VOCAL-NY. Securus, the private company that provides phone services in city jails, charges inmates fees to make phone calls. A portion of the fees goes to the city\'s general fund through a revenue-sharing agreement, Timothy Farrell, the senior deputy corrections commissioner, told the Council\'s Committee on Criminal Justice on Monday. Advocates said the fees put an unnecessary burden on incarcerated people who need to keep in touch with their lawyers or family members \xe2\x80\x94 especially since the city already offers free phone calls on its LinkNYC internet kiosks. Anna Pastoressa spent thousands of dollars to stay in touch with her son during his six-year stay on Rikers Island. She wanted to hear from him every day to be sure he wasn\'t hurt in jail, she said. "It is a terrible punishment to regular working-class people and poor people, because people that have money, wealthy people, do not go through this," said Pastoressa, a member-leader with JustLeadership USA. The DOC provides three free phone calls a week to detainees and two calls a week to inmates serving sentences, Farrell said. Calls to certain specific numbers are also always free, he said. But the calls city inmates do pay for are nearly five times as expensive as calls from state prisons, said Bianca Tylek of the Corrections Accountability Project. Securus also records phone calls, a practice that violates inmates\' rights and makes it hard for attorneys to communicate confidentially with their clients, advocates said. But Farrell said the recordings help the DOC investigate incidents and prevent future violence. Inmates\' calls to their attorneys are not recorded, officials said. The DOC is open to eliminating phone call fees, but that could require changes to the city\'s contract with Securus or a new contract altogether, officials said.\n"We would like to work with the Council to figure out how to make our telephone system as fair as possible, while maintaining the necessary services and safety features the contract provides," Farrell said. (Lead image: Dwayne Lee, a formerly incarcerated activist, calls for New York City to provide free phone calls to people in city jails on Monday. Photo by Noah Manskar/Patch)Subscribe\nBack to the Forest Hills Patch\nMore from Forest HillsUp next on Forest Hills Patch\nIconic Shalimar Diner Will Be Saved From Demolition, Relocated 1d\nLancman Drops Out Of Queens DA Race, Endorses Katz 4h\nThis Dream Pillow Makes Bedtime Fun For Kids 4d\nRead more local news from Forest Hills\nWhat are Featured Events?\nFeatured Events are paid listings by users and receive priority placement on Patch, on our social pages and in our daily newsletters. Disney and Marvel worked with technology and media company Intersection to create a first of its kind out-of-home campaign that used roughly 1400 screens or 700 LinkNYC kiosks\xe2\x80\x94all of the kiosks below 125th street\xe2\x80\x94to make sure consumers were aware of the film, its showtimes and the closest theater.\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s actually an enormous amount of digital displays,\xe2\x80\x9d explained\xc2\xa0Dave Etherington, chief strategy officer at Intersection. \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC itself is the largest employment of digital displays in any city in the world so to be able to take the lion\xe2\x80\x99s share of these is pretty significant. The campaign itself was designed to drive awareness as well as ticket sales and theater visits.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The campaign kicked off last Thursday evening between 5 p.m. and 7 p.m. with ads that read, \xe2\x80\x9cSee it tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d and featured the Avengers\xe2\x80\x99 logo. The next day the ads featured an integration with Moviefone, using their proprietary API, to pull in the closest theater location to the kiosk the ad appeared on as well as the next showtime for the film so that passerby, if inspired by the ad, could easily catch the next showing.\xe2\x80\x9cOnce you\xe2\x80\x99re exposed to the creative you see the nearest theater playing and a countdown clock to the next movie screening,\xe2\x80\x9d said Etherington, who added that the geographically targeted ads work as \xe2\x80\x9ca call to action.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSharehttp://adweek.it/2HKU4FZ copy Kristina Brooklyn Home Reporter\nNews\nEvents\nNeighborhoods\nBath Beach\nBay Ridge\nBensonhurst\nCarroll Gardens\nConey Island\nDowntown Brooklyn\nDumbo\nDyker Heights\nGowanus\nGravesend\nPark Slope\nRed Reporter\nNews\nEvents\nNeighborhoods\nBath Beach\nBay Ridge\nBensonhurst\nCarroll Gardens\nConey Island\nDowntown Brooklyn\nDumbo\nDyker Heights\nGowanus\nGravesend\nPark Slope\nRed Hook\nSheepshead Bay\nSunset Park\nDigital Editions\nAdvertise\nThe structure of other researchers\xe2\x80\x99 ideas p buy cheap research papers. Reviews from High School: Business, Literature, Engineering, Medicine, Arts, History, Nursing, MBA or buy cheap research papers online. They analyze the order custom research papers cheap research papers is paramount, we urge students to find cheap research papers with your disposal all year long, you have at.\nOpinion Guest op-ed: City Hall must stop widening the digital divide, expand LinkNYC to southern Brooklyn\nBy\nadmin\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nMay 2, 2018 @ 12:52 pm\nPhoto via Flickr/LinkNYC\nA Link kiosk in New York City.\nBY COUNCILMEMBER MARK TREYGER\nFor the last few years, New Yorkers have become accustomed to hearing promises from City Hall about programs and services that all of the city\xe2\x80\x99s residents will benefit from.\nThe administration has proclaimed that many of these services are available to everyone, but in practice, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be entirely accurate. One glaring example is the case of the LinkNYC program.\nThe concept is a welcome one: Fast, free Wi-Fi, phone calls, device charging and access to city services, maps and directions offered through \xe2\x80\x98Links\xe2\x80\x99 placed at various locations around the city.\nYet these impressive services are only available in some areas of the city, while completely absent in others. There are currently 1,513 active Link locations, and another 241 that have been installed but are still waiting for internet hookups.\nHowever, here in southern Brooklyn, there are zero Link locations.\nIn fact, there are zero Links in Brooklyn south of a Flatbush Avenue location just outside the campus of Brooklyn College.\nThat means no fast or free Wi-Fi in Bensonhurst, Coney Island, Sea Gate, Gravesend, Brighton Beach, Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights, Sheepshead Bay, Borough Park, Sunset Park, Manhattan Beach, Marine Park or Midwood.\nNeighborhoods like Bedford-Stuyvesant, Bushwick, Canarsie, East New York, and Brownsville also feature little or no LinkNYC presence.\nFailing to extend the LinkNYC program to these neighborhoods is furthering the digital divide, leaving communities full of working families and immigrants behind in a world that increasingly relies on technology, mobile devices and the internet for fulfillment of job or school-related responsibilities and daily routine tasks.\nYet, as much as technology has become a driving force in our lives, for many, the cost continues to be prohibitive.\nInternet services are not cheap, and neither are internet-capable devices. Meanwhile, internet access can be critical when looking for employment, researching for academic purposes, medical services, banking or other financial services, and news and information. Many an employer requires employees to be available electronically, too.\nI believe strongly that your zip code should not be a determining factor in what opportunities are made available to you.\nYou deserve reliable, reasonable public transit options, no matter what part of the city you live in. Your children should have the same opportunities to receive a quality education as children in any other part of the city.\nAnd in 2018, in the increasingly electronic world that, more and more, we have little option but to be a part of, free Wi-Fi and mobile services should be available in all parts of the city, not just some.\nCity Councilmember Mark Treyger represents the 47th Council District in Bath Beach, Bensonhurst, Coney Island, Gravesend and Sea Gate.\nTags:bay ridgeBensonhurstBorough ParkBrighton Beachconey islandcouncilmember mark treygerDyker HeightsGravesendguest op-edlinknycmanhattan beachMarine Parkmidwoodopinionpolitics and governmentsea gateSheepshead Baysunset parkwi-fi\nLeave a Reply\nClick here to cancel reply.\nYou must be logged in to post a
