Kids\nThe Best Nightlife\nThe Best Pet Services\nThe Best Places To Stay\nThe Best Shopping\nThe Best Wellness\nShop\nThe Harlem World Collection\nDonate\nSecondary menu\nPost navigation\n\xe2\x86\x90 Previous\nNext \xe2\x86\x92\nOver 100 U.S. Mayors Join de Blasio To Defend Net Neutrality From Harlem To Hollywood\nPosted on 05/02/2018\nby\nHarlem World Magazine\n\xe2\x80\x94\nLeave a reply\nLast month, Mayors Bill de Blasio, Steve Adler, and Ted Wheeler (Portland, OR) launched the Cities Open Internet Pledge to encourage mayors to take action against the repeal of net neutrality rules. Within a week of the announcement, over 20 cities signed onto the pledge agreeing to only do business with internet and telecommunications service providers that follow strong net neutrality principles. Today, 110 mayors representing over 25 million people have signed on to use their local authority to protect net neutrality.\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday marks an important milestone in our fight against the Trump Administration\xe2\x80\x99s attempt to strip away the right to access a fair and open internet. Since New York City helped launch the pledge, over 100 cities have signed on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mayor de Blasio. \xe2\x80\x9cCities must continue to join together to protect an open internet for all of our people in the face of reckless deregulation.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTo spread awareness about the initiative, a coalition of advocacy groups led by Free Press created mayorsfornetneutrality.org. Over 79,000 people have utilized the website to ask their mayors to sign the pledge.\nIn 2017, the Federal Communications Commission voted to repeal net neutrality rules which allowed the FCC to prevent phone and cable companies from blocking, throttling and preferentially slowing access to websites and services.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe internet is a shared resource that is essential for businesses of all sizes and for people from all walks of life,\xe2\x80\x9d stated Mayor Keller of Albuquerque, New Mexico. \xe2\x80\x9cAlbuquerque residents need to know that vital information from government websites \xe2\x80\x93 and from all websites \xe2\x80\x93 is not being stalled or stopped for profit. Access to internet at workable speeds is critical to moving toward digital equity for all in our city.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs mayors, we don\xe2\x80\x99t have the luxury of inaction,\xe2\x80\x9d Mayor Sly James of Kansas City, Missouri said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have to take a stand to ensure that our residents have access to the resources they need to survive in our increasingly interconnected world and that includes an open internet.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cNet neutrality is crucial for our startup culture in Austin and around the country,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mayor Steve Adler of Austin, Texas. \xe2\x80\x9cMaking it harder for new businesses to reach their customers will stifle innovation, hurt our economy, and deeply impact our nation. It\xe2\x80\x99s critical mayors use every tool at their disposal to ensure a free and open internet.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we are to maximize entrepreneurial opportunities, grow quality jobs, and educate our youth, we must have net neutrality. We value net neutrality over profits for carriers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mayor Paul R. Soglin of Madison, Wisconsin.\nAn open internet is the foundation for a modern, democratic society and economy. Without net neutrality, service providers could determine who can access internet content based on fees paid, impacting equal access to opportunities for people to thrive. Repeal of the rules would also put a disproportional burden on small businesses and start-ups. Small businesses must be able to connect to customers online to compete in today\xe2\x80\x99s connected market. There are over 230,000 small businesses in New York City.\nThe FCC vote to repeal has sparked a national movement to restore open internet protections. In addition to the Cities Open Internet pledge, 33 states are considering legislation or resolutions to reject the FCC ruling and restore net neutrality protections. A congressional resolution of disapproval, which would void the FCC ruling, has gained hundreds of co-sponsors in the House and Senate, with a Senate vote expected in May.\nThe FCC plans to replace the existing rules with the Restoring Internet Freedom rule. By changing the classification, ISPs will no longer be treated like telecommunications companies and would therefore no longer be under FCC jurisdiction.\nThe City of New York has taken steps to preserve net neutrality: incorporating net neutrality provisions into the LinkNYC franchise and issuing a \xe2\x80\x9cTruth in Broadband\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0RFI to evaluate in real-time how carriers provide internet service to consumers and how to identify if they are engaging in anti-net neutrality practices.\nMayors who have signed onto the Cities Open Internet Pledge:\nMayor Bill de Blasio \xe2\x80\x94 New York, NY\nMayor Steve Adler \xe2\x80\x94 Austin, TX\nMayor Ted Wheeler \xe2\x80\x94 Portland, OR\nMayor Ron Nirenberg \xe2\x80\x94 San Antonio, TX\nMayor Sly James \xe2\x80\x94 Kansas City, MO\nMayor Mark Farrell \xe2\x80\x94 San Francisco, CA\nMayor Catherine E. Pugh \xe2\x80\x94 Baltimore, MD\nCounty Board of Supervisors Chair Zach Friend \xe2\x80\x94 Santa Cruz County, CA\nMayor Barney Seney \xe2\x80\x94 Putnam, CT\nMayor Paul Soglin \xe2\x80\x94 Madison, WI\nMayor Sam Liccardo \xe2\x80\x94 San Jose, CA\nMayor Jacob Frey \xe2\x80\x94 Minneapolis, MN\nMayor Ethan Strimling \xe2\x80\x94 Portland, ME\nMayor Don Boeder \xe2\x80\x94 Gaylord, MN\nMayor Tom Feldkamp \xe2\x80\x94 Bow Mar, CO\nMayor Pauline Cutter \xe2\x80\x94 San Leandro, CA\nMayor Lucy Vinis \xe2\x80\x94 Eugene, OR\nMayor Lisa Swain \xe2\x80\x94 Fair Lawn, NJ\nMayor Laura Keegan \xe2\x80\x94 Edgewater, CO\nMayor Michael Tubbs \xe2\x80\x94 Stockton, CA\nMayor Steve Schewel \xe2\x80\x94 Durham, NC\nMayor Ras Baraka \xe2\x80\x94 Newark, NJ\nMayor Steve Fulop \xe2\x80\x94 Jersey City, NJ\nMayor Andrew Ginther \xe2\x80\x94 Columbus, OH\nMayor Kim McMillan \xe2\x80\x94 Clarksville, TN\nMayor David Terrazas \xe2\x80\x94 Santa Cruz, CA\nMayor Frank Ortis \xe2\x80\x94 Pembroke Pines, FL\nMayor Lowell Hurst \xe2\x80\x94 Watsonville, CA\nMayor Shari Cantor \xe2\x80\x94 West Hartford, CT\nMayor Rick Davis \xe2\x80\x94 City of Tonawanda, NY\nMayor Sal Panto Jr \xe2\x80\x94 Easton, PA\nMayor Alex Morse \xe2\x80\x94 Holyoke, MA\nMayor Michelle Distler \xe2\x80\x94 Shawnee, KS\nMayor G. David Gillock \xe2\x80\x94 North Ridgeville, OH\nMayor Michael M Vargas \xe2\x80\x94 Perris, CA\nMayor Lyda Krewson \xe2\x80\x94 Saint Louis, MO\nMayor Bob Scott \xe2\x80\x94 Sioux City, IA\nMayor David Martin \xe2\x80\x94 Stamford, CT\nMayor Walt Maddox \xe2\x80\x94 Tuscaloosa, AL\nMayor Paul Heroux \xe2\x80\x94 Attleboro, MA\nMayor Jean (John) Mordo \xe2\x80\x94 Los Altos, CA\nMayor Debra S. DelVecchio \xe2\x80\x94 Lambertville, NJ\nMayor Adrian O. Mapp \xe2\x80\x94 Plainfield, NJ\nMayor Patrick Wojahn \xe2\x80\x94 College Park, MD\nMayor Francis M. Womack III \xe2\x80\x94 North Brunswick, NJ\nMayor Tom Butt \xe2\x80\x94 Richmond, CA\nMayor Dominic Persampiere \xe2\x80\x94 Oviedo, FL\nMayor Dan Horrigan \xe2\x80\x94 Akron, OH\nMayor Charles Lamb \xe2\x80\x94 Edmond, OK\nMayor Catherine Blakespear \xe2\x80\x94 Encinitas, CA\nMayor Peter d\xe2\x80\x99Errico \xe2\x80\x94 Leverett, MA\nMayor Heilman \xe2\x80\x94 West Hollywood, CA\nMayor Lydia E. Privacy/PolicyTheme: Catch Evolution by Catch Themes", b"Politico Pro Login\nPOLITICO Pro\nWhy Go Pro?\nLogin\nLog in to manage your account, leave comments, and sign up for newsletters.\nEmail Address\nPassword\nKeep me logged in\nSubmit\nForgot password?\nNot a member?\nFor more information about subscriptions please visit Pro's website.\nTerms of Service\nPrivacy Policy\nAbout Us\nCorrections\nSupport\n\xc2\xa9 2019 POLITICO LLC", b'Winning Participatory Budgeting Projects Across\nBrooklyn Are Announced\nNortheast\nWashington DC\nNew Jersey\nNew York\nPennsylvania\nWhat is the Black Church\xe2\x80\x99s Role in Advancing African American Wealth?\nSoutheast\nAlabama\nFlorida\nGeorgia\nMississippi\nNorth Carolina\nSouth Carolina\nVirginia\nTennessee\nLouisiana\nMidwest\nMichigan\nIllinois\nIndiana\nOhio\nWisconsin\nMinnesota\nSouthwest\nArizona\nTexas\nWest\nCalifornia\nNAACP Set to Change Tax Status to Engage Politically\nWinning Participatory Budgeting Projects Across\nBrooklyn Are Announced\nNew York\nNortheast\n/\nNew York\n1 year ago\n179 Views\nBrooklyn Borough President Eric L. Adams announced on Tuesday the impact of his $1 million capital budget investment in Fiscal Year 2019 (FY19) of participatory budgeting (PB), a democratic process in which local residents directly decide how to spend part of a public budget, which increased the number of community-driven projects funded in council districts that encompass more than 60 percent of Brooklyn. Tens of thousands of Brooklyn residents cast ballots at locations across the borough \xe2\x80\x94 including at Brooklyn Borough Hall \xe2\x80\x94 during the 2018-2019 participatory budgeting cycle voting period, which took place between Saturday, April 7th and Sunday, April 15th. Borough President Adams\xe2\x80\x99 $1 million contribution was apportioned equally to winning projects from the votes conducted by the 10 council members in the borough who are participating in PB this year.\nThis year\xe2\x80\x99s voting cycle expanded the reach to more Brooklynites as votes could be cast online at locations across the borough and at LinkNYC kiosks. Borough President Adams highlighted how the continued growth of PB in Brooklyn is helping to advance the causes of civic engagement, fiscal transparency and good government throughout the city.\n\xe2\x80\x9cParticipatory budgeting is bringing democracy back to our communities, empowering individuals to make decisions on what gets funded at the hyperlocal level,\xe2\x80\x9d said Borough President Adams. \xe2\x80\x9cI thank all of the council members participating in this year\xe2\x80\x99s process for their continued commitment to amplifying the voices of Brooklynites so our constituents have a direct say in where their taxpayer dollars get spent. From school technology to street safety, this year\xe2\x80\x99s funded projects reflect that all Brooklynites seek safer places to raise healthy children and families. Let\xe2\x80\x99s continue to advance these shared priorities and get more people involved in the PB process so that everyone has a stake in Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s future.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe $100,000 designated by Borough President Adams for PB in each participating council district expanded that council member\xe2\x80\x99s committed PB allotment, resulting in additional projects winning funding in the upcoming fiscal year:\nLaptop carts at PS/IS 157 The Benjamin Franklin Health Science Academy in Bedford-Stuyvesant, in partnership with Councilman Stephen F. Levin\nBroadband system and computer upgrades at PS 299 Thomas Warren Field School in Bushwick, in partnership with Councilman Antonio Reynoso\nAuditorium upgrades, including a new stage floor, lighting, sound system, paint, curtains and chairs at PS 9 Teunis G. Bergen in Prospect Heights, in partnership with Councilwoman Laurie A. Cumbo\nAuditorium upgrade to a public performance and community gathering space at PS 23 Carter G. Woodson Elementary School in Bedford-Stuyvesant, in partnership with Councilman Robert E. Cornegy, Jr.\nSecurity cameras at PS 94 The Henry Longfellow School in Sunset Park, in partnership with Councilman Carlos Menchaca\nReplacement of damaged and hazardous turf for the soccer field at Albermarle Playground in Kensington, in partnership with Councilman Brad Lander\nLibrary upgrade at MS 2 Parkside Preparatory Academy in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, in partnership with Councilman Mathieu Eugene\nSidewalk extensions and school safety measures near PS 134 in Kensington, in partnership with Council member Kalman Yeger\nTrench restoration along 16th Avenue in Borough Park, in partnership with Council member Kalman Yeger\nSTEAM library upgrades at PS 193 Gil Hodges in Midwood, in partnership with Councilman Jumaane D. Williams\nAuditorium upgrades and supplemental cooling system installation at IS 281 Joseph B. Cavallaro in Gravesend, in partnership with Councilman Mark Treyger.\nA map of winning projects and full voting results by district can be viewed at pbnyc.org.\nPrevious articleVanzant to the Rescue at Boys and Girls High School Complex\nNext articleKanye West, Donald Glover and the correct way to send a message\nRead more\nSource:\nOur Time Press\nPrevious post\nOnline Color Edition\nNext post\nVanzant to the Rescue at Boys and Girls High School Complex\nJust Posted\nNumber 45, AKA Donald Trump, is Not an Aberration\n20 hours ago\nThis Louisiana Parish Allowed a Quarter of Its Sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s Deputies To Work Security for a Pipeline\n21 hours ago\nCommentary: America\xe2\x80\x99s economy must better serve Black and Latino consumers\n1 day ago\nCould Regional Reparations Help the Democrats Retake the Rust Belt?\n1 day ago\nPam Confer attends ceremonial signing of Mississippi Beautiful Day by Governor Bryant\n1 day ago\nTweets by BlackNewsPortal\nTags\nHealth Matters\nPlatinum Star PR\nBE Money\nMarie Lemelle\nLos Angeles Wave Newspaper\nwealth\nfrost illustrated\nLa wave newspapers\nAmerican Cancer Society\nMayo Clinic\nReviews\nPages\nAbout Blacknewsportal\nBlack News Sources\nKUWPA\nCategories\nNortheast 3765\nSoutheast 14354\nMidwest 4579\nSouthwest 3066\nWest 2005\nFollow us\nIt may not always be good news, yet it is our news, in our voices with our narratives and perspective\nCategories\nNortheast 3765\nSoutheast 14354\nMidwest 4579\nSouthwest 3066\nWest 2005\nPages\nAbout Blacknewsportal\nBlack News Sources\nKUWPA\nTags\nHealth Matters\nPlatinum Star PR\nBE Money\nMarie Lemelle\nLos Angeles Wave Newspaper\nwealth\nfrost illustrated\nLa wave newspapers\nAmerican Cancer Society\nMayo Clinic\nTweets by BlackNewsPortal\nCopyright BlackNewsPortal \xef\xbf\xbd 2015. All Rights Reserved\nNortheast\nWashington DC\nNew Jersey\nNew York\nPennsylvania\nSoutheast\nAlabama\nFlorida\nGeorgia\nMississippi\nNorth Carolina\nSouth Carolina\nVirginia\nTennessee\nLouisiana\nMidwest\nMichigan\nIllinois\nIndiana\nOhio\nWisconsin\nMinnesota\nSouthwest\nArizona\nTexas\nWest\nCalifornia', b'New York, cos\'\xc3\xa8 LinkNYC e perch\xc3\xa9 \xc3\xa8 importante saperlo - Lettera43\nPolitica\nEconomia\nEsteri\nCronaca\nSport\nCerca\nSezioni\nCronaca\nCultura\nEconomia\nEsteri\nGreen Lab\nLettere\nMedia\nPolitica\nScienze\nSociet\xc3\xa0\nSport\nSpettacolo\nTecnologia\nViaggi\nHow To\nGuide\nTopic\nBorsa e spread\nGoverno\nMedia e Blog\nVideo\nFoto\nBlog\nCecilia Attanasio Ghezzi\nNew York, cos\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\xa8 LinkNYC e perch\xc3\xa9 \xc3\xa8 importante saperlo\nCecilia Attanasio Ghezzi\nTwitter\n12 Maggio 2018 14.00\nLike me!\nChiunque sia stato a New York nell\'ultimo anno si sar\xc3\xa0 accorto che le vecchie cabine telefoniche sono state sostituite da snelli parallelepipedi. Si chiamano LinkNYC e offrono accesso a wifi, telefonate nazionali, elettricit\xc3\xa0 per ricaricare i device e altri servizi di pubblica utilit\xc3\xa0. Il tutto gratuitamente. E, udite udite, sono a costo zero anche per la municipalit\xc3\xa0.\nMODELLO FACEBOOK. Attualmente sono oltre 1.500, ma raggiungeranno presto il numero di 10 mila unit\xc3\xa0. A Manhattan si trovano a ogni incrocio e il progetto \xc3\xa8 piaciuto tanto che si sta estendendo ad altre citt\xc3\xa0. Seattle si \xc3\xa8 detta interessata, mentre Londra ne ha gi\xc3\xa0 installati 200 (si chiamano InLinkUk). Secondo quanto si legge sul sito del progetto, non solo non sono state toccate le tasche dei cittadini, ma nell\'immediato futuro l\'utilizzo di queste "centraline" generer\xc3\xa0 mezzo miliardo di dollari perla Grande Mela. Come? Con le inserzioni pubblicitarie. Per questo, soprattutto dopo lo scandalo Cambridge Analytica, i cittadini stanno drizzando le orecchie.\nLe recenti esperienze ci hanno insegnato che in assenza di costi per gli utenti, il guadagno per le aziende hi-tech sta nei dati che raccolgono dalle nostre attivit\xc3\xa0 online. E allora vale la pena guardarli pi\xc3\xb9 da vicino questi LinkNYC, non tanto per capirne funzionamento e struttura \xe2\x80\x93 che \xc3\xa8 modulare per facilitare il ricambio e l\'aggiornamento delle varie componenti \xe2\x80\x93 ma per risalire alle aziende che li hanno inventati, a chi ci guadagna e per farsi un\'idea del vero obiettivo dell\'operazione. Ma andiamo con ordine.\nNELLA GALASSIA DI GOOGLE. Il progetto nasce dalla collaborazione della citt\xc3\xa0 di New York con CityBridge, un consorzio capitanato da Intesection, di cui una quota minoritaria \xc3\xa8 di Sidewalk Labs, azienda della galassia di Alphabet, conglomerato di Mountain View. Come dire Google? S\xc3\xac, ma c\'\xc3\xa8 un altro aspetto societario da notare. Il presidente di Intersection \xc3\xa8 Dan Doctoroff, cofondatore (assieme a Craig Nevill-Manning, ingegnere dei primordi di Google e oggi direttore tecnico di Alphabet) e amministratore delegato di Sidewalk Labs. Ma qualcosa di pi\xc3\xb9 si apprende anche dalla sua biografia.\nDA FINANZIERE A URBANISTA. Doctoroff, classe 1958, ha iniziato alla Lehman Brothers ma la sua figura \xc3\xa8 cominciata a emergere negli Anni 90 quando propose un mega progetto sportivo-immobiliare in vista della candidaura alle Olimpiadi della citt\xc3\xa0. Era cos\xc3\xac convincente che il sindaco Michael Bloomberg lo volle, dal 2001 al 2008, come suo vice per lo sviluppo economico. Il suo lavoro deve essere stato apprezzato, visto che arriv\xc3\xb2 ai vertici di Bloomberg Lp dove, dal 2008 al 2014, ha ricoperto le cariche di presidente e ad. Poi la svolta.\nMentre tutto il mondo era concentrato sulle presidenziali americane che avrebbero incoronato Donald Trump, Doctoroff ha convinto Google a finanziare \xc2\xabla quarta rivoluzione\xc2\xbb nelle infrastrutture urbane. L\'idea era quella di lavorare a una citt\xc3\xa0 intelligente che operasse su sensori, videocamere, dati, algoritmi, sistemi integrati e intelligenze artificiali per risolvere i problemi strutturali delle megalopoli.\nURBANISTICA TECNOSCIENTIFICA. \xc3\x88 il sogno di un\'urbanistica tecnoscientifica, quella che il programmatore Paul McFedries spiega cos\xc3\xac: \xc2\xabLa citt\xc3\xa0 \xc3\xa8 un computer e l\'arredo urbano la sua interfaccia. Tu sei il cursore e il tuo smartphone un interruttore. Questa \xc3\xa8 la versione bottom-up della citt\xc3\xa0-computer. Ma c\'\xc3\xa8 anche la versione top-down, che \xc3\xa8 basata sulle infrastrutture. Pensate quanto migliorerebbe l\'efficienza e l\'organizzazione se il traffico, la raccolta dei rifiuti e la distribuzione dell\'acqua fossero smart\xc2\xbb.\nSOLO UNA PARTE DEGLI INCASSI ALLA CITT\xc3\x80. Ecco. Teniamo a mente quest\'utopia tecnoscientifica e torniamo a LinkNYC. Il sistema operativo \xc3\xa8 Android, se dovessero esserci altri dubbi su quanto Google sia parte del progetto. La citt\xc3\xa0 di New York, dal canto suo, offre a Intersection e ai suoi partner l\'utilizzo degli spazi pubblici in cambio dei servizi offerti dai Link e di una parte degli incassi generati dalle inserzioni pubblicitarie.\nLa citt\xc3\xa0 \xc3\xa8 un computer e l\'arredo urbano la sua interfaccia. Tu sei il cursore e il tuo smartphone un interruttore\nI cittadini, specie quelli in difficolt\xc3\xa0 economiche, apparentemente hanno solo da guadagnarci. La fibra ottica permette addirittura di scaricare dati pi\xc3\xb9 velocemente che nella maggior parte delle case di New York e un accesso gratuito a Internet per le strade fa sempre comodo. Ma i dubbi che solleva il servizio sono tanti. Prima di tutto riguardo la privacy.\nDUBBI SULLA PRIVACY. Per accedere alla connessione pubblica \xc3\xa8 necessario registrarsi con un nome e un indirizzo email, ma se si legge attentamente l\'informativa a cui bisogna dare il consenso si capisce come CityBridge possa anche raccogliere dati sui propri device: dagli indirizzi Internet alla cronologia delle ricerche effettuate. Certo, lo fa \xc2\xabin forma anonima e aggregata\xc2\xbb, ma abbiamo gi\xc3\xa0 imparato la quantit\xc3\xa0 incredibile di informazioni personali che algoritmi ben scritti possono raccogliere attraverso i nostri metadata.\nGLI INTERESSI DI ALPHABET. E poi c\'\xc3\xa8 un altro punto. Dando per assodato che l\'analisi complessiva degli spostamenti e dei desiderata dei cittadini serve a rimodellare le nostre citt\xc3\xa0 migliorandone la rete dei mezzi pubblici e dei servizi, non dovrebbe essere la municipalit\xc3\xa0 a detenere e a gestire gli archivi? Ricordiamoci che Alphabet ha enormi interessi privati in diversi campi. Tra cui, e forse non \xc3\xa8 un caso, nell\'industria nascente delle macchine senza guidatore. Il timore \xc3\xa8 che, se il settore non verr\xc3\xa0 regolato per tempo, le smart city del futuro saranno in mano ai soliti privati. E che il mercato dei dati sostituir\xc3\xa0 ben presto quello dell\'immobiliare e della finanza nella vitalit\xc3\xa0 economica delle metropoli. O almeno, questo \xc3\xa8 quello che sta succedendo nella Grande Mela.\nbloombergcomputerfacebookgoogleinternetmichael-bloombergnew-yorksmartphone\n\xc2\xa9 RIPRODUZIONE RISERVATA\nARTICOLI CORRELATI\nCome tutelare la produzione di contenuti nell\xe2\x80\x99era digitale\nCome funziona Libra, la criptovaluta di Facebook\nL\xe2\x80\x99attesa per la criptovaluta di Facebook fa schizzare il bitcoin ai massimi da maggio 2018\nCome la protesta di Hong Kong sfida la censura Internet della Cina\nCommenti: 0\nLascia un commento Annulla risposta\nIl tuo indirizzo email non sar\xc3\xa0 pubblicato. Uptown residents voted on 11 different projects between April 7 and 15 during this year\'s participatory budgeting cycle. This year was the first in which people could cast their ballots in person, online and on LinkNYC kiosks. The Dyckman Houses in Inwood will receive investments totaling $800,000 to improve a playground in the development and for an ADA-accessible ramp for the development\'s community center. The remaining $200,000 will be spent on technology upgrades at libraries throughout Washington Heights and Inwood. City Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez said all 11 projects up for funding were "much needed investments" and he will look into securing funding for those that didn\'t win any participatory budgeting money.\nHere\'s a full list of this year\'s participatory budgeting projects (winners in bold): District Libraries Technology Upgrades: Estimated cost $200,000P.S. 173 Auditorium Technology Upgrade: Estimated cost $150,000P.S. 48 Playground Renovation: Estimated cost $500,000George Washington High School Weight Training: Estimated cost $80,000Sound System for WHEELS Auditorium: Estimated cost $150,000Dyckman Houses Building #4 Playground Renovation: Estimated cost $500,000Dyckman Houses Building #3 Park Renovation: Estimated cost $500,000Dyckman Houses New Park Game Tables: Estimated cost $350,000Dyckman Houses Community Center Outside Drainage: Estimated cost $500,000Dyckman Houses Community Center ADA Ramp: Estimated cost $850,000Northern Basketball Court Wallenberg Playground: Estimated cost $535,000Photo by ShutterstockSubscribe\nBack to the Washington Heights-Inwood Patch\nMore from Washington Heights-InwoodUp next on Washington Heights-Inwood Patch\nLegal E-Bikes Won\'t Be Allowed In NYC Bike Lanes, De Blasio Says 3h\nLong-Range Summer Forecast Released For NY 2h\nThis Dream Pillow Makes Bedtime Fun For Kids 4d\nRead more local news from Washington Heights-Inwood\nWhat are Featured Events?\nFeatured Events are paid listings by users and receive priority placement on Patch, on our social pages and in our daily newsletters. Junk call blocker YouMail is reporting the amount of pre-recorded phone messages is at an all-time high \xe2\x80\x93 and they target New York more than most states. There were 3.36 billion robocalls last month in the U.S., a whopping 34 percent higher than April 2017. New Yorkers got 207.8 million calls. Only four states got more, YouMail reported. Here\'s how that breaks down in in New York City for the month of April: Area code: 212 Total robocalls: 2.7 millionAverage calls per person: 1.6Top five robocallers last month:1: 315-533-8630GSA 5: 866-532-0424CitibankBank Debt Collection\nArea code: 646 Total robocalls: 20.5 millionAverage calls per person: 12.3Top five robocallers last month: 1: 917-728-1137Police Charity CallPolice Charity 2: 718-935-6740NYC Department of EducationEducation Services 3: 212-244-9392Chinese ConsulateSpammer 4: 888-423-0900Verizon Information LinePhone Company 5: 518-952-3396Business Loan Pre-Approved ScamBusiness Loan Scam Area code: 917 Total robocalls: 39.4 millionAverage calls per person: 16Top five robocallers last month: 1: 917-728-1137Police Charity CallPolice Charity 2: 718-935-6740NYC Department of EducationEducation Services 3: 518-952-3396Business Loan Pre-Approved ScamBusiness Loan Scam 4: 212-244-9392Chinese ConsulateSpammer 5: 888-423-0900Verizon Information LinePhone Company most, followed by Texas with 363.3 million.\nHere are the states that received the most robocalls, as well as how many they received: California, 384.4 million Texas, 363.3 million Florida, 261.1 million Georgia, 213.6 million New York, 207.8 million Illinois, 134.6 million Ohio, 115.8 million Pennsylvania, 115.4 million North Carolina, 111 million Louisiana, 97.6 millionHere are the top 10 most robocalled cities: Atlanta, GA Dallas, TX New York, NY Los Angeles, CA Chicago, IL Houston, TX Baltimore, MD Philadelphia, PA San Francisco Bay Area, CA Newark, NJ"Despite the best efforts of regulators, industry groups, service providers, and app developers, we are warning consumers to remain vigilant by not picking up any calls from unfamiliar numbers, using robocall blocking apps, and researching numbers before calling them back," YouMail CEO Alex Quilici said in a release. LEWISMay 17, 2018\nSHARE:\nNew York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications Commissioner Samir Saini is just two months into his new job, but he already has big plans for his department. In an interview with City & State, Saini described how he plans to reshape the department while continuing to meet Mayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s goal of providing broadband for all New Yorkers, from free public Wi-Fi to home broadband service. Saini also weighed in on cybersecurity in the city and his own transition from his previous role as Atlanta\xe2\x80\x99s chief information officer.C&S: How is the OneNYC initiative to bring broadband to all New Yorkers going?SS: It\xe2\x80\x99s going well. There are different parts to the program. The first part is the effort to bring broadband on our streets, which is the public Wi-Fi, the high-speed public Wi-Fi strategy. And that is largely tied to the LinkNYC kiosks. So the Link deployments, things are going very well. We just briefed the City Council on this and we have another briefing as part of a budget hearing next week on it. But we have, as of today, about 1,500 Links, active Links deployed delivering, from what I\xe2\x80\x99m getting on average, about 300-350 megabit per second up and down with a 200-foot radius range from each Link. So we have 1,500 Links deployed, scattered across the boroughs and that\xe2\x80\x99s going quite well. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s 3.5 million active subscribers using free, high-speed public Wi-Fi from the Links. And I think the other metric I just saw is we\xe2\x80\x99re seeing double-digit growth in the number of subscribers every year since we deployed the Links. So Link is going well. That\xe2\x80\x99s one piece.C&S: And the other pieces?SS: The other piece is broadband in the home. That\xe2\x80\x99s also moving forward. So broadband in the home is largely driven by DoITT\xe2\x80\x99s role to administer a set of franchise agreements. There are eight franchise agreements with cable providers. I guess the big issue there is broadband in the home, but it\xe2\x80\x99s really largely provided by two suppliers in the city: Verizon Fios and Charter/Spectrum. And what I think what you\xe2\x80\x99re going to be seeing from DoITT as part of a strategic plan we\xe2\x80\x99re going to launch very soon, before July 1, is new strategies we\xe2\x80\x99re going to deploy to help accelerate the deployment of affordable broadband in the home, and the equitable distribution of it because there are parts of the city that don\xe2\x80\x99t have broadband. The Mayor\'s Office of the Chief Technology Officer just issued a broadband report two weeks ago that\xe2\x80\x99s actually quite enlightening. Some of the highlights over here are that, No. 1, roughly 31 percent of New Yorkers don\xe2\x80\x99t have broadband in the home today, and that\xe2\x80\x99s the equivalent to the entire population of the city of Houston. So that\xe2\x80\x99s a problem. There\xe2\x80\x99s also issues around affordability for the current broadband services that are offered. And I think the obvious issue is there is a minimal level of choice for broadband. So all these things we\xe2\x80\x99re tackling, and I think you\xe2\x80\x99re going to see this in the strategic plan, ways in which we\xe2\x80\x99re going to change this game to deliver more equitable, affordable broadband to more New Yorkers to really hit the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s commitment of broadband for all New Yorkers by 2025.\nsamir-saini-headshot-submitted.jpg\nAlt Text:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiTitle Text:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiCaption:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiDescription:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiImage Credit:\xc2\xa0Submitted\nC&S: What can you tell me about ongoing difficulties with Charter/Spectrum? In what ways are they possibly violating their franchise agreement with the city?SS: There were two audits that we conducted against Spectrum. One was an audit that was financially related around evaluating how revenue was being calculated and generated. And the second audit was more on labor. And really the audits were meant to ensure and validate that Charter was in fact complying to the letter of the franchise agreement we have in place with them. So that\xe2\x80\x99s all public knowledge. On the financial audit, we asked for a bunch of financial data from Charter. They provided it ... and we\xe2\x80\x99re analyzing it. So that\xe2\x80\x99s in process. On the audit regarding whether they violated any labor issues, we made some initial findings, however there\xe2\x80\x99s other concerns from other entities around whether this is a violation of labor provisions within the franchise agreement that are still pending a final determination.C&S: You\xe2\x80\x99re fairly new to the job. What has your transition been like and what do you consider to be your most important role?SS: I\xe2\x80\x99m still two months in. But really, I\xe2\x80\x99ve broken down our core objectives into three parts. The first is going all-in into achieving digital equity for all New Yorkers. Digital equity implying equitably distributed, affordable broadband in every home, on every street, in every borough. The second one is really a focus on DoITT as a shared services provider. DoITT provides a set of IT services to serve our internal agencies. We have over 100 agencies that we support in different ways. So the first objective I\xe2\x80\x99ll have for our agency is to really transform ourselves more fully and entirely into operating like an external service company. Less a call center, internal service order taker. So it\xe2\x80\x99s a big cultural shift for us, but the idea is to really start transforming how we interact with agencies: treat them like customers, have a menu of services that are really easily understood and explainable and measurable. So it\xe2\x80\x99s really running our internal shop better than we do today and then transforming ourselves from order taker to a service management orientation.\nThe second objective is really around relooking at the services we provide to the agencies. We provide about 60 high-level services today \xe2\x80\x93 relooking at these 60, asking our customers, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat services do you want from us?\xe2\x80\x9d And then optimizing the service portfolio to align to the needs of the agencies today and what they\xe2\x80\x99ll need over the foreseeable future. This hasn\xe2\x80\x99t happened in a long time. Up to this point, DoITT has built its service portfolio based on random requests from different agencies. If you wanted a pizza, DoITT would figure out how to make a pizza and give you a pizza. If you wanted a hamburger, we\xe2\x80\x99d figure that out and give you a hamburger. If you wanted a steak, we did that. Now we have a kitchen and a bunch of chefs that can make all sorts of stuff. But the question is, should we? Or do we want to be a pizza joint? What do we actually want to be? It\xe2\x80\x99s a good problem to have because we\xe2\x80\x99ve built a lot of relationships and we have a wide menu, but it\xe2\x80\x99s now becoming a point where we want to be more strategic about what we want to put on our menu based on what really our customers want from us \xe2\x80\x93 especially if people aren\xe2\x80\x99t ordering burgers anymore.C&S: Cybersecurity has been a very large concern recently, especially with the upcoming elections. What is the city doing to shore up its defenses against cyberattacks?SS: There was a press release from the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office announcing the preliminary budget that\xe2\x80\x99s going to the City Council for review over the next few weeks. In that budget is an inclusion for over $40 million dedicated for Geoff Brown and the new cyber command unit that\xe2\x80\x99s been set up. The cyber command unit, we call C3 under the citywide (chief information security officer) Geoff Brown, reports directly into the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office, the deputy mayor of operations, not to me. And that\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing because security is such a huge world these days that it requires its own agency, its own dedicated focus and that\xe2\x80\x99s where that lives. So the biggest thing we\xe2\x80\x99ve done is put money to it, and the money is really for staff and for tools to strengthen the city\xe2\x80\x99s ability to detect, to respond, to prevent threats from happening in the first place. It also is investments to ensure that we can continuously proactively check to find holes in the environment if any exist and close them before they\xe2\x80\x99re ever exploited by a bad actor externally. And so we\xe2\x80\x99re feeling really good about it. It takes investment and the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s proposed budget provides exactly that.C&S: Is that different than other cities?SS: It is. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know of any other city that has that structure. Coming from me, I think it\xe2\x80\x99s a very good thing because New York City isn\xe2\x80\x99t like any other city. The sheer complexity of what we do and how visible we are externally warrants that cybersecurity be its own entity and have its own separate investment and funding and resources. So I think the executive order Mayor de Blasio issued to create this organization last summer was absolutely the right move. And I think New York should feel really good that we\xe2\x80\x99re not doing what other cities do. We\xe2\x80\x99re taking cybersecurity so seriously, we created a whole agency, and incremental new funding dedicated to it to ensure that we\xe2\x80\x99re safe.C&S: A couple months ago, there was a huge cyberattack that crippled Atlanta. Do you think that having a New York City approach to cybersecurity could have prevented or at minimized the damage of that attack?SS: I don\xe2\x80\x99t. I mean, the reality of what happened in Atlanta and also what\xe2\x80\x99s happening in other cities is just not being, it\xe2\x80\x99s not hitting the news unless you\xe2\x80\x99re in the CIO circuit, is that those kinds of threats, especially that one ... can\xe2\x80\x99t be prevented. (Editor\'s note: After this interview was published, the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications clarified that Saini meant\xc2\xa0that such threats are "very hard to prevent.")\xc2\xa0The key is to have an administration that prioritizes cybersecurity. I\xe2\x80\x99ll put it that way. And investments in cybersecurity in particular are really critical regardless of how it\xe2\x80\x99s structured. In Atlanta, I think Mayor (Keisha Lance) Bottoms publicly said that she had not made cybersecurity a priority. That\xe2\x80\x99s her words. But now, after the attack, it is her No. 1 priority. So I think the mayor is doing absolutely the right thing, which is way before, this is last year, before the Atlanta attack and actually several other attacks that occurred in other cities affecting critical infrastructure, public safety infrastructure, transportation infrastructure. California got affected. He saw the writing on the wall and said, \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to do this differently,\xe2\x80\x9d which is where C3 was born.C&S: You were CIO in Atlanta before coming to New York City. How different has it been to come from a place where, as you said, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t initially a priority to a place where it is?SS: Part of why I had left is first off, I\xe2\x80\x99m actually from New Jersey. So, in part, this was a move home. But the other is, there was a leadership change happening in Atlanta, there was a new mayor coming it. It was a logical time for me to depart. But also, there was minimal \xe2\x80\x93 I felt like Atlanta had hit a point where they were not investing as much as I would have wanted them to in moving on a number of areas, scaling out smart city initiatives we had, but also in the cyber space. So it was really a mixed bag of reasons, but moving here to New York, it\xe2\x80\x99s been a real blessing because I think this city and this mayor really understands and values IT. Not to say they didn\xe2\x80\x99t in Atlanta, but certainly, it\xe2\x80\x99s a big deal here. In large part I think it\xe2\x80\x99s because the operations of New York City are so complex and affect so many people that technology plays an even more critical role in the delivery of the services to the 8.7 million people that live here, less so the 500,000 people that live in Atlanta. So I think there\xe2\x80\x99s just a lot more focus and dependence on it, and a lot more investment and appreciation for IT and our services.C&S: And you said the kind of attack that happened in Atlanta isn\xe2\x80\x99t really preventable. Is it a concern that it could happen in New York City?SS: Yes. There\xe2\x80\x99s multiple types of cyberattacks that occur all the time. So I would be the first to tell you, and no one could disagree with this, no city, no state, no private sector entity is immune from any of these. Period. If anyone thinks they\xe2\x80\x99re well-protected, well, they shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t say that publicly because they\xe2\x80\x99re just going to be a target. If you talk to the cybersecurity experts out there, they\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you the same thing \xe2\x80\x93 that the game now, it\xe2\x80\x99s not about investing in services to protect yourself from ever having an attack. Everyone needs to accept that there will be an attack. It\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of when. It\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of how bad. And the question really will be, how ready are you, as a city or as a private sector company, to detect it and remediate it, and to strengthen your defenses so if it happens again, it won\xe2\x80\x99t be as bad, or that kind of attack won\xe2\x80\x99t happen again. It\xe2\x80\x99s about containment and response and then strengthening your defenses next time. No one is immune. It just so happens that Atlanta got hit, but when was the last time Atlanta was hit? Never. Because we did several other things, at least over the course of my time there, where we could have gotten hit 10 times because we had legacy infrastructure and all sorts of holes. That\xe2\x80\x99s why it\xe2\x80\x99s just one of those things where you\xe2\x80\x99re never 100 percent safe. Nobody is 100 percent safe from a cyberattack. Anyone who says they are, I would worry about.\nRelated Stories\nNew York CityA look at DoITT\'s new Text-to-911 emergency response initiativeBy GRACE SEGERS\nTechnologyThe next frontier: A Q&A with DoITT Commissioner Anne RoestBy FRANK G. McMahon is a go-to expert on budget plans and policy proposals. His organization promotes greater transparency, accountability and fiscal responsibility in state government, which often puts him at odds with lawmakers and the governor. McMahon previously worked as a journalist in Albany, as an Assembly Republican staffer and a budget adviser for almost 30 years, giving him great insight into the goings-on in the Capitol.\n20190621', All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nmenu content ends\nMenu\nGothamist\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDonate\nSearch\nSearch this site\nClose\nSearch\nSearch\nArts & Entertainment\nWhy Is A Spooky, Slowed-Down Mister Softee Jingle Blasting Through LinkNYC Kiosks?\nBy\nJake Offenhartz\nMay 24, 2018 10:42 a.m.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nEmail\nAn anthropomorphic cone head with a dented wafer face is haunting the summer streets of Manhattan, blasting his funeral march through our city\'s ubiquitous data harvesters, striking fear into nearby pedestrians, and befuddling city agencies.\nActually though, what the hell is going on here?\nHere\'s what we know: On Wednesday afternoon, LinkNYC kiosks along Third Avenue in midtown began, seemingly at once, to blast a slowed-down version of the Mister Softee theme song. No one knows why, and as far as anyone at LinkNYC can tell, it was not part of a promotion. Like many horror scenes, everything started out fine.\n"Initially I thought I had just passed two Mr. Softee trucks in a row, since I heard it from block to block," Steve Burges, a bike courier, told Gothamist. "Then I realized I was hearing it played on several consecutive blocks from the LinkNYC Kiosks, and it felt very odd."\nBut as Burges continued passing the kiosks\xe2\x80\x94nearly ten in all\xe2\x80\x94each of them "playing the same jingle seemingly in unison," the odd scene turned bloodcurdling. "Something was off because of the slow rhythmic the song, and it was really eerie," he added.\nThanks for letting us know. Our team is looking into this further. If you know what specific Links you hear this on, would you mind DMing us that information?\xe2\x80\x94 LinkNYC (@LinkNYC) May 23, 2018\nCarla Giarusso first heard the eerie jingle outside of her office on 43rd Street and 3rd Avenue, and soon noticed two more in the area. "My initial reaction when I heard the first one was wtf/laughter but then I realized it was a few more and thought either 1/ the end is nigh or 2/ we they were hacked (ha) and then of course I naturally assumed it must be the Russians," she told Gothamist.\n"Then I stopped laughing when I remembered that sonic incident in Cuba last year and figured I may as well see if the city was aware...they seemed as perplexed [as I was]."\nConcerned pedestrians who messaged LinkNYC on Twitter were told that the company is "currently looking into this," and would reboot the tablets for the time being.\nAsked about the creepy jingle, a LinkNYC spokesperson issued this statement: "LinkNYC serves New Yorkers in many important ways\xe2\x80\x94providing free wi-fi to more than 4 million users, free phone calls, device charging, and more\xe2\x80\x94but unfortunately, we don\'t serve ice cream. Once we were alerted to the Mr. Softee jingle, we immediately rebooted the tablets to end the song. Sorry if anyone wandered towards the kiosks looking for soft serve!"\nWill this reboot be enough to stave off the coming war between man and machine and ice cream? Is this the latest gambit in the increasingly hostile dessert truck turf battle? Or is it all just some sort of Pavlovian psychological experiment, a way for the city to test its powers of conditioning over New Yorkers?\nWe\'ll let you know when we find out\xe2\x80\x94in the meantime, it\'s a perfect day for a chocolate-vanilla swirl.\nReporting by Jen Chung.\n#ice cream\n#linknyc\n#midtown\n#mister softee\nDo you know the scoop? \xc2\xa0 Comment below or Send us a Tip\nFeatured in Arts & Entertainment\nRead More In:\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDashed Arrow\nBack to Top\nGothamist\nSend Us a Story Idea\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nGothamist is a website about New York City news, arts and events, and food, brought to you by New York Public Radio.\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nParty Confetti\nDashed Arrow\nSign up for our newsletter! 2020\nSign In\nJoin\nSign In\nJoin\nWhat's near me?\nBrought to you by\nDid Mister Softee Just Taunt New York City?\nAn eerie version of the jingle sharply contrasts a former attempt to silence it.\nby Paula Mejia\nMay 25, 2018\nDid Mister Softee Just Taunt New York City?\nMister Softee himself outside one of the ice cream trucks. Rjsswf8 / CC BY-SA 3.0\nEarlier this week, several New Yorkers noticed a strangely familiar noise emanating from midtown LinkNYC kiosks. Gothamist reports that as many as ten kiosks along Third Avenue, which provide free wi-fi access across the city, began all trilling simultaneously with the the iconic Mister Softee jingle. Normally the music is a happy announcement of warm weather and ice cream for sale. But it sounded off and slowed-down from the usual, twinkling song.\nAt first, onlookers thought they might be hearing distant trucks. But locals, such as bike courier Steve Burges, soon discovered that it was indeed coming from kiosks, and that \xe2\x80\x9csomething was off because of the slow rhythmics [of] the song, and it was really eerie,\xe2\x80\x9d as he described to the paper.\nThe haunting jingle doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be part of a promotion or a prank: On Twitter, LinkNYC assured people that, no, they were \xe2\x80\x9cnot hacked,\xe2\x80\x9d and they rebooted the system to stop the music. So what really happened? It\xe2\x80\x99s tough to say at this point, as no one has claimed responsibility. But it\xe2\x80\x99s curious that a city-backed infrastructure project is blasting a jingle that, a little over a decade ago, city administrators wanted to silence.\nBack in the early to mid aughts, New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought to stamp out Mister Softee\xe2\x80\x99s song once and for all. The battle against the ice cream jingle was a part of the Bloomberg administration\xe2\x80\x99s crackdown on noise in the city, dubbed Operation Silent Night. The ordinance took on stereos, construction projects, barking dogs, the hum of air conditioners, and, yes, the sound of approaching ice cream.\nIn 2004, Bloomberg cited scores of complaints rolling into the city\xe2\x80\x99s 311 hotline about the jingle. New Yorkers quickly disagreed. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d Teniqua Frontis told the New York Daily News. \xe2\x80\x9cThe jackhammers, the motorcycles, the cars. Those are the problems.\xe2\x80\x9d Mister Softee representatives protested, too, saying that silencing the call would decimate their business. Some lawmakers weren\xe2\x80\x99t totally onboard, either; one told Bloomberg that he would \xe2\x80\x9ctraumatize a lot of children in this city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nA summer classic. Alison Fayre / CC BY 2.0\nMister Softee\xe2\x80\x99s distinctive song was allowed to continue after all in 2005. The administration struck a compromise that stated the jingle must cease playing when trucks stop moving. Bloomberg continued to take shots at Mister Softee in ensuing years, but the distinctive song lives on\xe2\x80\x94spilling out of ice cream trucks and LinkNYC kiosks alike. Maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s a coincidence, or maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s a frosted middle finger to the former mayor\xe2\x80\x99s war on ice cream. But either way, the tune undeniably signals that summer is now in full swing.\nGastro Obscura covers the world\xe2\x80\x99s most wondrous food and drink.\nSign up for our email, delivered twice a week.\nice creammusicfood\nRead Next\nHow the U.S. Army Botched Feeding Its Female Soldiers in WWII\nRecent Stories\nThe Forgotten Trans History of the Wild West\nIt was a frontier in more ways than Reviews from High School: Business, Literature, Engineering, Medicine, Arts, History, Nursing, MBA or buy cheap research papers online. They analyze the order custom research papers cheap research papers is paramount, we urge students to find cheap research papers with your disposal all year long, you have at.\nNews Bensonhurst officials ask city, \xe2\x80\x98Why no free Wifi?\xe2\x80\x99\nBy\nPaula Katinas\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nMay 29, 2018 @ 2:56 pm\nNeighborhoods like Sunset Park have several LinkNYC portals while communities in Southwest Brooklyn are still waiting for the kiosks to be installed. This kiosks is located on Fourth Avenue and 33rd Street. EBrooklyn Media file photo by Paula Katinas\nThe city\xe2\x80\x99s technology revolution is passing Bensonhurst by.\nNeighborhood officials are miffed that the city\xe2\x80\x99s much-touted LinkNYC program, which makes free Wifi available to residents via sidewalk kiosks, is nowhere to be seen on local streets.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe would like to have them,\xe2\x80\x9d Community Board 11 District Manager Marne Elias-Pavia said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey would provide a valuable service to the residents of our community. Not everyone can afford to pay for high-speed internet.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn addition to free WiFi, the LinkNYC portals offer users free phone calls, easy access to the 911 and 311 systems, maps and social services platforms through a LinkNYC network. The kiosks are also equipped to serve as charging stations for people seeking to charge their cell phones and other mobile devices.\nMore than 3.5 million people have used the free WiFi since the first LinkNYC stations were installed in 2016, according to city officials. The 9.5-foot-tall kiosks contain 55-inch high-definition screens on both sides. The panels replaced the old pay telephones that used to line the sidewalks.\nThere are currently more than 1,600 LinkNYC kiosks on New York City sidewalks, including an abundance of them in trendy, upscale Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope, Brooklyn Heights and Williamsburg.\nThe city plans to install 7,500 LinkNYC kiosks over the next several years.\nIn Park Slope, the kiosks also list the arrival times of buses at local bus stops. The bus time information was installed under a pilot program.\nOther neighborhoods, like Sunset Park, have also been linked up to LinkNYC. Along a 13-block stretch of Fourth Avenue from 24th Street to 37th Street, there are six kiosks.\nResidents seeking to vote for capital budget projects in their neighborhoods as part of the City Council\xe2\x80\x99s Participatory Budgeting program could find ballots on their local LinkNYC kiosks.\nBut there is a dearth of the tall, sleek-looking technology stations in Bensonhurst and other Southwest Brooklyn communities, according to local elected officials, who are calling on the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, the agency responsible for the program, to rectify the situation.\nCouncilmember Justin Brannan posted a map of Brooklyn on his Twitter page to illustrate the lack of LinkNYC in Southwest Brooklyn.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just not fair that the wealthiest communities in New York City have an abundance of free WiFi and neighborhoods like Bensonhurst and Dyker Heights don\xe2\x80\x99t have a single LinkNYC WiFi kiosk. Going forward, LinkNYC must fulfill its franchise agreement and provide kiosks to underserved areas from Bay Ridge to Coney Island to Brownsville,\xe2\x80\x9d Brannan told this paper via email.\nOn his Twitter page, Brannan called Southwest Brooklyn \xe2\x80\x9ca WiFi-free desert.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCouncilmember Mark Treyger said he is annoyed at the absence of LinkNYC portals in his district.\nTreyger charged that the haphazard rollout of the program is turning New York into a city of technology haves and have-nots.\n\xe2\x80\x9cInternet services are not cheap, and neither are internet-capable devices. Meanwhile, internet access can be critical when looking for employment, researching for academic purposes, medical services, banking or other financial services, and news and information. Many an employer requires employees to be available electronically, too,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote in an op-ed in this newspaper. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe strongly that your zip code should not be a determining factor in what opportunities are made available to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMayor Bill de Blasio first announced a plan to bring free WiFi to New York City streets in 2014 with a promise to include all five boroughs. The city hired a consortium called CityBridge to install the kiosks.\nOfficials from the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications briefed CB 11 on the plans in 2014 and told the board they were scouting possible locations on Kings Highway, 86th Street, New Utrecht Avenue and 18th Avenue. \xe2\x80\x9cBut since that time, we have received no updates,\xe2\x80\x9d Elias-Pavia said.\nThe Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications issued a statement in response to inquiries from this paper.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC is a pioneering and successful initiative, already connecting more than 3.9 million New Yorkers and visitors to superfast WiFi, free calling, and more\xe2\x80\x94at zero cost to taxpayers. Since the public launch in 2016, more than 1,600 Links are active across all five boroughs with thousands more set to be deployed over the next few years. Link deployment follows the installation of high-speed fiber optic cables along corridors through the city. We look forward to each of the thousands more that will hit the streets in the next few years, including those in Southwest Brooklyn,\xe2\x80\x9d the statement reads.\nLeave a Reply\nClick here to cancel reply.\nYou must be logged in to post a comment.\nRelated Articles\nDime Savings Bank Serving Williamsburg Brooklyn Since 1864\nAdam Suerte Paints Urban\nBrooklyn\nBrooklyn ReporterNewsletter\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Everything Brooklyn Media\nBrooklyn Reporter', b'The missing Links as sidewalk WiFi kiosks come up short - New York Daily News\nSkip to content\nTopics\nxml:space="preserve">\nSubscriber Services\nManage Subscription\nEZ Pay\nDelivery Issue\nSubscriber Terms\nNew York\nNYC Crime\nBronx\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nEducation\nObituaries\nWeather\nSports\nYankees\nMets\nGiants\nJets\nKnicks\nNets\nRangers\nIslanders\nFootball\nBasketball\nBaseball\nHockey\nSoccer\nMore Sports\nI\'d Click That\nOdds\nGolf\nNews\nCrime\nU.S.\nPolitics\nBill de Blasio 2020 Campaign\nWorld\nEntertainment\nMovies\nTV\nMusic\nBroadway\nGossip\nLifestyle\nHealth\nEats\nGames\nViva\nBest Reviews\nTravel Deals\nOpinion\nPhotos\nHoroscopes\nDaily\nE-Newspaper\nAutos\nCovers\nSpecial Sections\nClassifieds\nPublic Notices\nBranded Content\nPaid Partner Content\nPaid Content By Brandpoint\nTAG disclosure\nSearch\nxml:space="preserve">\nNew York\nSports\nNews\nEntertainment\nOpinion\nAdvertisement\nAdvertisement\nOpinion\nThe missing Links as sidewalk WiFi kiosks come up short\nBy Editorials\n| NEW YORK DAILY NEWS |\nMay 30, 2018\n|\n4:00 AM\nNot as advertised. (Robert Sabo/New York Daily News)\n"The deal struck by Mayor de Blasio to bring free Wi-Fi to neighborhoods across the city sounds too good to be true," we wrote three and a half years ago, as a caveat on our praise of the shiny monoliths soon to dot New York\'s sidewalks.\nThe prediction turned out to be accurate. Tuesday, the consortium installing the LinkNYC kiosks where dead pay phones once stood told the city it\'s been unable to deliver what it promised.\nAdvertisement\nThe deal is getting restructured: Instead of placing 7,500 machines around the five boroughs by 2023, CityBridge will now get until 2025, with almost all of them bearing ads. It gets more time to pay the city in full, too.\nAdjustments in deals between private companies making use of public space happen \xe2\x80\x94 but why did these changes have to be rushed? The de Blasio administration gave notice of the Franchise and Concession Review Committee meeting the day before the Memorial Day weekend. A vote was scheduled for the next business day, Tuesday.\nTo get its revisions through, the city had to table one proposed revision: letting kiosks be put next to bus shelters, which have their own ads.\nLinkNYC, which once looked like a winner, is now shaping up as a mixed bag. When the kiosks work, they supply a fast, free Internet connection, via a built-in tablet and to your own device over Wi-Fi. But six months after they debuted, the on-board browsers were turned off because some folks were watching, well \xe2\x80\x94 how to put it? \xe2\x80\x94 films featuring the likes of Stormy Daniels.\nWe asked: Why not just deactivate the video function, rather than pulling the plug on the whole browser? We never got an answer.\nAdvertisement\nRecommended', b'LinkNYC Kiosks Still Possessed By Mister Softee Jingle, Still Creeping Out New Yorkers - Gothamist\nmenu content begins\nGothamist\nDonate\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nSearch this site\nSearch\nSearch\nSend us a Story Idea\nNYPR\nView All Brands\nCaret Down\n\xc2\xa9 2019 New York Public Radio. All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nmenu content ends\nMenu\nGothamist\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDonate\nSearch\nSearch this site\nClose\nSearch\nSearch\nArts & Entertainment\nLinkNYC Kiosks Still Possessed By Mister Softee Jingle, Still Creeping Out New Yorkers\nBy\nJake Offenhartz\nMay 30, 2018 3:11 p.m.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nEmail\nThat creepy-as-hell version of the Mister Softee jingle is still blaring through some LinkNYC kiosks, reminding New Yorkers in the most ominous way possible that summer is here, and that the sweet embrace of death soft-serve is coming for us all.\nWe first noted the haunting ear-worm last week, after pedestrians observed about 10 kiosks on Third Avenue in midtown blasting the inexplicably slowed-down jingle. Since then, others have encountered multiple possessed kiosks, including two near 67th Street and Broadway, which Richard Anderson spotted on his lunch break on Wednesday afternoon.\n"It was definitely creepy, even once I realized it was coming from the LinkNYC things again," Anderson told Gothamist. "It makes me wonder how LinkNYC expects people to trust their WiFi when they can\'t even keep their kiosks secure from pranksters."\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s a bunch of @LinkNYC kiosks playing that creepy, slowed down Mister Softee jingle again. Around Broadway and W. 68th. Creepy.\xe2\x80\x94 Richard J. Anderson (@sanspoint) May 30, 2018\nWhy Is A Spooky, Slowed-Down Mister Softee Jingle Blasting Through LinkNYC Kiosks?\nWho knows?? Heard it myself yesterday!!https://t.co/HNontCUcan via @Gothamist\xe2\x80\x94 Hady Mendez (@hadym) May 27, 2018\nRepresentatives for LinkNYC are adamant that this is NOT a "hack," and instead qualifies as an "old-fashioned phone prank"\xe2\x80\x94that classic gag: Is your microphone-and-camera-equipped digital tablet running? A spokesperson for the company added, "Sorry if anyone wandered towards the kiosks looking for soft serve."\nDespite their claims, critics of LinkNYC have used the opportunity to attack the controversial kiosks, which started popping up in 2014. "This is definitely someone\'s form of protest," said one member of the anti-surveillance group Rethink Link. "It\'s highlighting the dangers of the whole march to the Internet of Things."\nWhether this is a political protest, harmless prank or sweet-toothed robot takeover is, at this point, unknown. In the meantime, shoot us a line if you come across the out-of-place jingle, or happen to know the phone number we can call to hear the full remix ourselves.\n#jingle\n#linknyc\n#mister softee\n#rethink link\n#robot takeover\nDo you know the scoop? \xc2\xa0 Comment below or Send us a Tip\nFeatured in Arts & Entertainment\nRead More In:\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDashed Arrow\nBack to Top\nGothamist\nSend Us a Story Idea\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nGothamist is a website about New York City news, arts and events, and food, brought to you by New York Public Radio.\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nParty Confetti\nDashed Arrow\nSign up for our newsletter! All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy', b"Why Those LinkNYC Kiosks Keep Getting More Interesting - The Bridge\nWinner of 2018 journalism awards for local reporting, design, and commentary\n\xe2\x9c\x95\n\xc3\x97\nAll News\nIndustry\nDesign & Tech\nReal Estate\nFood & Drink\nOur Town\nFrom Day One\nWhy Those LinkNYC Kiosks Keep Getting More Interesting\nFrom super-fast Wi-Fi to free local ads for small business, the boards are making themselves useful\nBy Arden Phillips - May 29, 2018\nSHARE\nOn a Brooklyn street, a pedestrian takes advantage of such features as free device charging (Photo courtesy of LinkNYC)\nToo bright, too loud, and maybe even spying on us. Those were some of the wary reactions of New Yorkers when the first LinkNYC booths started arriving in the city two years ago, part of a sweeping plan to replace old pay phones with 7,500 kiosks offering super-fast Wi-Fi and other digital services.\nJudging by the volume of usage at more than 1,600 kiosks installed so far, however, New Yorkers have started to embrace them as communications hubs.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cSince launching, we\xe2\x80\x99ve already had more than 4 million people connect to our Wi-Fi, which is larger than the population of Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d says Ruth Fasoldt, director of external affairs at LinkNYC. \xe2\x80\x9cWe also offer free phone calls anywhere within the U.S., map functions on our tablets, access to 311, a 911 button, USB phone charging \xe2\x80\xa6 we do all of this and it\xe2\x80\x99s all paid for by the advertising on the sides of the links,\xe2\x80\x9d Fasoldt added.\nIn 2018 so far, Brooklynites have made more than 200,000 phone calls on the 236 kiosks installed in the borough so far. The most popular kiosk in Brooklyn, in terms of the number of people connecting to the Wi-Fi, has been one on Atlantic Avenue near Barclays Center. That Link, in the month of April, had more than 50,000 devices connect to it, while people across all of Brooklyn spent 32.9 million minutes on the system\xe2\x80\x99s Wi-Fi.\nWe tried it for ourselves: LinkLocal is a free ad program for small businesses and organizations (Photo by Steve Koepp)\nLinkNYC is constantly developing new programming for the eye-catching, 55-inch digital displays on both sides of the boards. Today LinkNYC and the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications\xc2\xa0 (DoITT) launched a collaboration with local artists to celebrate \xe2\x80\x9clife, beauty, and culture in New York City.\xe2\x80\x9d One of the artists involved, Julia Rothman of Brooklyn, said she\xe2\x80\x99s thrilled to see her art pop up all over the city. \xe2\x80\x9cI really like that they only appear for a short time on the screen before it flips to the next image, so it feels like you caught a quick glimpse of something special,\xe2\x80\x9d Rothman said in a press release announcing the program.\nLocal small businesses and organizations can take advantage of LinkNYC kiosks as well by signing up for a free advertising program called\xc2\xa0LinkLocal. By filling out a template online, users can request a month of rotating display time on two kiosks of their choice.\nEarlier this year, the City Council partnered with LinkNYC to launch Participatory Budgeting on the kiosks, enabling citizens another conduit for casting votes on how the city spends $1 million of the public budget. Anyone who lived in a participating district could approach a Link in any neighborhood and vote on the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s tablet.\nIn a program announced this week, artists including Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s Julia Rothman will have their work displayed on the big screens\nLinkNYC, the largest network of its kind in the world, got its start in 2014 when the de Blasio Administration put out a call for proposals to repurpose the city\xe2\x80\x99s payphone infrastructure.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cNew York knew that they had thousands of pay phones throughout the five boroughs sitting on prime real estate, not really being used by New Yorkers anymore,\xe2\x80\x9d says Fasoldt. \xe2\x80\x9cSo they wanted to find a way to really improve New Yorkers\xe2\x80\x99 lives and make this a part of their smart-cities initiative,\xe2\x80\x9d which involves deploying technology to make the city a better place.\nThe 12-year franchise was awarded to CityBridge, a consortium of experts in tech, media, and connectivity. CityBridge, which includes major tech companies like Qualcomm, is investing $200 million to install new fiber-optic cable for the Links, each of which can support hundreds of Wi-Fi users simultaneously.\nTHE BRIDGE NEWSLETTER\nSIGN UP FOR BROOKLYN BUSINESS NEWS\nLeave this field empty if you're human:\nHowever, initial ad revenues have been underwhelming.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cOver the first two years of the program, the city collected just shy of $43.4 million in payments, narrowly beating the $42.5 million minimum it was guaranteed,\xe2\x80\x9d the New York Post reported\xc2\xa0this month. Part of the problem has been a slower-than-expected rollout because of infrastructure problems encountered along the way. As a result, the administration plans to let CityBridge defer profit-sharing payments in order to allow the consortium to invest more money in the program and get the buildout completed.\nAs the hardware gets installed, LinkNYC keeps developing new content for the boards, ranging from poetry-month features to \xe2\x80\x9cThis Day in New York\xe2\x80\x9d historical facts. Says Stephanie Raphael, director of communications for the city\xe2\x80\x99s DoITT: \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re really excited about it. It just shows how Link is a very powerful tool for community engagement. You\xe2\x80\x99ll see more and more programs being rolled out.\xe2\x80\x9d\nArden Phillips is a New York-based writer and a graduate of the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University, where she received a degree in Television, Radio, and Film.\nNEXT STORY:\nBrooklyn Law School Dean Makes a Sudden Departure\nPREVIOUS STORY:\nWhy Your Brooklyn Starbucks Closed Early Today\nRELATED STORIES\nThe Pitch Contest: When Tech Startups Go Head to Head\nWhat If the Tech Boom Sputters? Entertainment\nLegal\nPolitics\nCity\nNational\nState\nBusiness\nSports\nCyclones\nIslanders\nNets\nHistory\nNeighborhoods\nCentral Brooklyn Jazz Festival To Include Over 500 Artists\nMarch 22, 2012 Brooklyn Eagle Staff\nBROOKLYN \xe2\x80\x94 From March 30 until April 30, the Central Brooklyn Jazz Consortium (CBJC) will present the 13th Annual Central Brooklyn Jazz Festival. More than 500 artists will be performing in 40 events at venues from Coney Island to Williamsburg in Brooklyn.\nBrooklyn jazz has a rich past, and its legacy is celebrated every April. Clarence Mosley Jr., chairman of the consortium, says, \xe2\x80\x9cCBJC enters its 13th season in presenting the African-American art form jazz to the under-served populations of Brooklyn. We continue to recognize the contributions and creativity of the jazz community of Brooklyn, past and present.\xe2\x80\x9d\nInternationally recognized musicians will perform in community centers, clubs, colleges and cultural and faith-based institutions. The jazz festival is accessible to all, with 85 percent of the events free or at a cost of less than $20.\nFor information, contact CBJC at (718) 773-2252 or [email\xc2\xa0protected]\nAmong others, performers this year will include Bilal Sunni Ali, Kenyatta Beasley, Gloria Cooper, Steve Cromity, Bob Cunningham, Lou Donaldson and Eric Frazier.\nSHARE ARTICLE:\nLeave a Comment\nRelated siteWATCH LIVENews 4 NY at 5The latest local news, weather and investigative stories impacting your community.LinkNYC Kiosks Are Playing a Creepy Ice Cream Truck Jingle By\nAshley SerianniPublished Jun 1, 2018 at 9:07 PM | Updated at 9:33 PM EDT on Jun 1, 2018 NEWSLETTERS Receive the latest local\nupdates in your inboxEmailPrivacy policy | More NewslettersGetty ImagesFILE (Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images)The creepy, slowed-down version of the ubiquitous Mister Softee jingle has been playing through the LinkNYC kiosks.The off-kilter ice cream truck song was first noticed last week by passersby playing out of about 10 kiosks on Third Ave in midtown. As of Wednesday, social media users were still noticing them.\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s true. All along third ave they are playing the Mr. Softee song. Was this truly not intentional? Wow. It feels like a psychological experiment. pic.twitter.com/LBJKHaWWBD\n\xe2\x80\x94 Steve Burges (@stevenatschool) May 23, 2018More have been spotted over the past week, including\xc2\xa0two around 67th and Broadway.There\xe2\x80\x99s a bunch of @LinkNYC kiosks playing that creepy, slowed down Mister Softee jingle again. Around Broadway and W. 68th. Creepy.\n\xe2\x80\x94 Richard J. Anderson (@sanspoint) May 30, 2018LinkNYC representative insist that this is not a hack of their software, and that it's simply an 'old-fashioned phone prank'.The phenomenon was first reported by Gothamist.\xc2\xa0Get the latest from NBC 4 New York anywhere, anytimeDownload the App\nAvailable for IOS and AndroidFollow NBC New York Leave Comments New York LiveNewsWeatherInvestigationsEntertainmentTrafficContact UsCommunityContestsConnect With UsWNBC Public Inspection FileEmploymentSend FeedbackTerms of servicePrivacy policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 NBCUniversal Media, LLC. All rights reserved.\nAdChoicesAdvertise with us", b'Smart cities deliver improved quality of life | Digital Signage TodayTest LinkCONTINUE TO SITE \xc2\xbb or wait 15 seconds\xc3\x97Toggle navigation\nTOPICS 3D Digital Signage4K Ultra HDAdvertisingAudience MeasurementBanks / FinancialCellular SignageCloud-Based Digital SignageContentContent ManagementCorporate CommunicationCustomer ExperienceDigital BillboardsDisplay TechnologyDistributors / ResellersDOOH AdvertisingEducation / SchoolsEntertainment VenuesHardwareHealthcare / HospitalsHotelsInstallation / IntegrationInteractive / TouchscreenLED SignsMenu BoardsMobile InteractivityOutdoor SignageRestaurantsRetailSoftwareTrends / StatisticsWayfindingView all Topic Centers \xc2\xbbSUPPLIERS Companies by NameCompanies by CategoryProducts & ServicesRequest Information from SuppliersPROJECT HELPRESOURCESNEWSWEBINARSEVENTS View Industry Event Calendar >>MORE VideosWebinarsEventsPodcastsPhotosArticlesVideosBlogsPress ReleasesJob ListingsProject HelpMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggersStore\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nSmart cities deliver improved quality of lifeJune 1, 2018 | by Bradley CooperCities around the globe are adopting smart technologies. New York City, for example, deployed Link NYC kiosks, which offer Wi-Fi services and advertisements to residents. Services such as these aren\'t just boosting Wi-Fi, they are also delivering improved quality of life.Mike Gamaroff, senior vice president of strategy, SITO Mobile, Sheldon Silverman, CEO, Smartbomb Media Group and David Pal, CEO of Ads on Top addressed how smart cities are revolutionizing city living during a panel at the Digital Signage Expo.Pal said the first concern for any smart city application is that, "it needs to answer a question." For example, if a city is trying to discover how residents move throughout the city, it should use sensors. Or if residents are unsure about city services, displays need to provide additional information."The core reason for developing smart city solutions is quality of life," Gamaroff said. He pointed out how more people from rural populations in places like China are moving to the cities than ever before. To accommodate these growing populations, smart cities need to develop solutions to handle traffic and deliver services.Silverman said cities can use sensors to see in real time how residents move throughout the city. Using this information, they can then determine if they need better transportation solutions, such as trains. Or cities could develop schedules for delivery trucks to cut down on traffic.On the customer end, smart cities can also offer key information to residents at critical times of the day. With digital signage, these cities can deliver this information easily and they can also measure the real time effects of the data.Gamaroff pointed out that if a city was opening a new park, it could advertise the opening with digital signage. It could then measure the total number of residents visiting the park to see how effective the digital signage really was.Many consumers and governments, however, are concerned about customer data and privacy, especially with recent fiascos with Facebook\'s privacy policy.\xc2\xa0The panelists said that vendors need to spend a lot of time explaining this issue with governments.Sheldon points out that governments might be concerned about collecting location-based data on residents. However, with this data, "You never need to know the name. You are forming a picture of someone who, for example, goes to a gym or QSR, then deliver ads based on that data.""We spend a lot of time with regulators that help them understand the data we do collect; the wireless, sensors (and)\xc2\xa0cameras\xc2\xa0is all aggregate data. We do not personalize that data," Gamaroff said.Smart cities, when used properly, can improve lives through more efficient services, just like in retail and restaurants.Image via Istock.comTopics: Advertising, Customer Experience, Display Technology, DOOH Advertising, Outdoor Signage, Trends / Statistics Bradley CooperBradley Cooper is a Technology Editor for DigitalSignageToday.com and BlockchainTechNews.com. His background is in information technology, advertising, and writing. wwwFollow @DigSignageTodaySponsored Links:Related ContentH&M, wayfinding claim top spots for May 2019 digital signage stories3 ways to waste your digital signage7-Eleven boosts the customer experience with menu boards7 digital transformation trends of 2019Latest ContentHow to design heavenly digital signage contentWhat\'s your biggest struggle with digital signage?Will San Francisco ban on facial recognition affect digital signage?Taco Bell claims Elevate Awards for interactive kiosksGet the latest news & insightsSubscribeLinkedIn Twitter Facebook RSSNewsComQi, AUO deliver all-in-one digital signageUpshow partners with Jukin Media for DOOH engagementInewvation deploys digital signage at Jewel Changi AirportMeridian awards recipients of 2019 scholarshipAtlona appoints Ewing-Foley to distribute products in Western US, AlaskaViewSonic intros 2 WUXGA laser projectorsAmazon, LG integrate Alexa into hotel TVsSee More \xc2\xbbResources[WEBINAR]: Critical considerations when transitioning from traditional to interactive digital signageINDOOR VS.
