(Jared McCallister/New York Daily News)\nRemembrances abound in the wake of Anthony Bourdain\xe2\x80\x99s shocking suicide last week. But one is a short story about the beloved celebrity and the fame he brought to Hilma\xe2\x80\x99s Windsor Castle, a tiny restaurant on the Dutch side of St. Maarten-St. Martin island in the Caribbean.\nMy tale is so, so Bourdain! In a 2004 food article he wrote for The New York Times, the chef-turned travel journalist gave deserving respectful admiration to the fine cuisine all across \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Maarten-St. Martin, the half-Dutch, half-French island in the West Indies,\xe2\x80\x9d but said the small roadside Hilma\xe2\x80\x99s Windsor Castle eatery was \xe2\x80\x9cmy favorite place.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAdvertisement\nAnthony Bourdain appears at the Empire State Building in 2011 for a hunger awareness event. (Bryan Smith for New York Daily News)\n\xe2\x80\x9cWindsor Castle\xe2\x80\x9d was in a small trailer parked on a long, narrow strip of land in Dutch St. Maarten with a slew of small businesses as neighbors. The likable proprietor, Hilma Harris, sold johnnycakes (traditional flat-fried or griddled cornmeal creations), patties stuffed with fish, chicken or beef, and other treats and drinks. Her breakfast and lunch clientele were island locals and tourists who came by word of mouth. But over the years, thousands more visitors, sparked by Bourdain\xe2\x80\x99s favorable 2004 review, came to Hilma\xe2\x80\x99s seeking the casual atmosphere, good food and great conversation he experienced with Harris \xe2\x80\x94 and they were not disappointed. Bourdain loved Harris and her eatery and she, and her customers, had praise for \xe2\x80\x9cTony.\xe2\x80\x9d\nUnfortunately, added to the scores of excellent online reviews for Hilma\xe2\x80\x99s Windsor Castle is a February posting about the establishment\xe2\x80\x99s destruction in last year\xe2\x80\x99s Category 5 Hurricane Irma.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSadly, Hilma\'s Windsor Castle is gone. Hurricane Irma literally carried Hilma\'s trailer off into the ocean. All that\'s left is an axle. Hilma herself is fine, but she\'s not planning to rebuild,\xe2\x80\x9d posted Beach Wanderers of Ames, Iowa.\nHeritage Month in gear\nAcross the city and country, the celebration of National Caribbean-American Heritage Month is on \xe2\x80\x94 and you can see it, honor it and taste it!\nOnce again, LinkNYC and the city Information Technology & Telecommunications Department are working with the Brooklyn-based CaribBeing cultural organization to bring Caribbean celebrities to high-tech LinkNYC kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 55-inch digital displays in the city. The regionally mimicking Caribbean comedian Majah Hype, singers Amara La Negra and Jamaica\xe2\x80\x99s Spice, and Afro-Dominican author Elizabeth Acevedo are among the featured personalities this year.\nSultry Dominican-American singer/musician Amara La Negra brings National Caribbean American Heritage Month to Manhatan\'s Times Square, appearing in the kiosk project by LinkNYC and the Caribbeing organization. (LinkNYC)\n"We are thrilled to again partner with LinkNYC to raise awareness of the many contributions of Caribbean-Americans," said CaribBeing founder Shelley Worrell. \xe2\x80\x9cThis exposure will put the spotlight on some truly inspiring artists, thinkers, writers, performers, and visionaries of Caribbean heritage.\xe2\x80\x9d\n[More New York] ICE expected to launch round up of immigrants this weekend \xc2\xbb\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City is home to one of the largest, most diverse Caribbean populations in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ruth Fasoldt, Link\xe2\x80\x99s Director of Community Affairs. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are honored to use the LinkNYC platform to celebrate Caribbean-American Heritage Month and recognize the many contributions Caribbean-Americans have made throughout history.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis month, New Yorkers will get to see some of the most influential Caribbean-American icons of the past century just by walking by a LinkNYC kiosk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Commissioner Samir Saini of the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re thrilled to collaborate with CaribBeing to showcase the Caribbean culture and heritage while shining a light on the figures who have positively impacted New York City."\nThis Instagram post shows popular comedian Majah Hype, the regionally-hilarious "King of Caribbean Comedy," as one of the celebrities on kiosks around the city during National Caribbean-American Heritage Month in a project by LinkNYC and the CaribBeing organization. (Photo by @djsupadon)\nCity Controller Scott Stringer is marking the celebration by holding a Caribbean-American Heritage Month event on Tuesday at Tropical Paradise, 1367 Utica Ave. in Brooklyn, honoring Mona-Lisa Jean-Ferrari, CEO of Ferrari and Associates; Pastor Gilford Monrose, founding president of the 67th Precinct Community Council; and DJ Norie of Power 105.1 FM radio.\n[More New York] Gutsy ex-cop says he\xe2\x80\x99s glad that scary subway confrontation with homeless man ended without violence \xc2\xbb\nTo RSVP, send email to eventsrsvp@comptroller.nyc.gov or call (212) 669-4466. For language translation services or other special accommodations, call (212) 669-4315.\nThe News Americas Now website is onboard with the celebration too \xe2\x80\x93 posting \xe2\x80\x9cCaribbean Immigrants in U.S. History\xe2\x80\x9d segments. Visit www.newsamericasnow.com.\nAre you ready for a scrumptious special occasion? Spice Isle, the upscale Caribbean fusion cuisine restaurant at 41 Mountain Blvd. in Warren, N.J., will host the \xe2\x80\x9cThe Bahamas Food Exploration,\xe2\x80\x9d a cultural dinner focused on the Bahamas on Thursday, on June 14, in honor of Caribbean-American Heritage Month and the opening of Its tasty Caribbean Food Exploration Meetup series. Visit http://bit.ly/spiceisle_bahamas or call the restaurant directly (908) 834-8864.\nSt. Lucia author debuts work\nThe New York launch of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Adventures of Wyetta,\xe2\x80\x9d by Saint Lucian children\xe2\x80\x99s author Claudette Charles takes place today (6.10) at St. Lucia House, 438 E. 49th St. in Brooklyn, at 3 p.m. There will books for sale.\nSt. Lucia\xe2\x80\x99s Children of Culture and violinist Grace Ramjeawan will perform. Call the St. Lucia Consulate at (212) 697-9360, ext. 203, or e-mail at sluconsulateny@govt.lc.\nAdvertisement\nFather\'s Day pledge returns\nFor fathers and their families, CONNECT\xe2\x80\x99s NYC Father\xe2\x80\x99s Day Pledge Against Violence takes place Thursday at noon on the steps of City Hall in Manhattan. The ninth annual event \xe2\x80\x94 co-sponsored by City Council Majority Leader Member Laurie Cumbo \xe2\x80\x94 brings together community leaders, elected officials, city activists and youth to celebrate the vital roles men and boys can play in ending and preventing violence in our homes, schools and neighborhoods. For information, contact Quentin Walcott at connectmen@connectnc.org.\nA \xe2\x80\x98Fair\xe2\x80\x99 anniversary\nA decade of community, commerce and culture will be marked on Saturday in the Bronx at the Westchester Square Business Improvement District\xe2\x80\x99s annual \xe2\x80\x9cFair @ The Square\xe2\x80\x9d at Westchester Square, from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. \xe2\x80\x94 featuring a half-mile of music, merchants, food and fun.\nThe fair\xe2\x80\x99s main stage will be E. Tremont Ave. There will be an all-day concert series hosted by Artie Rodriguez of the Diamante Show and Gene DiNapoli, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Entertainment.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Westchester Square BID\xe2\x80\x99s 10th Annual Fair @ The Square is an excellent example of BIDs\xe2\x80\x99 unique ability to build stronger neighborhoods by bringing residents and merchants together to celebrate their community,\xe2\x80\x9d said Commissioner Gregg Bishop, of the New York City Department of Small Business Services, adding that \xe2\x80\x9cEl Pavarotti de la Salsa,\xe2\x80\x9d and Tito Nieves \xe2\x80\x94 whose hits include \xe2\x80\x9cI Like it Like That,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll Always Love You\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDe Mi Enamorate\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 are among the performers.\n[More New York] Former student burned in Manhattan high school chemistry experiment says fire is burned into his memory \xc2\xbb\nFor vendor information, contact Clearview Festival Productions at (646) 230-0489. For sponsorship and Westchester Square BID Merchant opportunities, contact Yasmin Cruz, President / CEO of Image Marketing Inc. at (718) 395-1932 or email WSFair@ImageMarketingInc.com.\nAdvertisement\nRecommended', b'TVEyes Media Monitoring Suite - [Transcript]\nLog In >\nTranscript\nLog In\nTranscript Log In\nNY1\xc2\xa0-\xc2\xa0New York, NYNews All Evening\nNY1 6/13/2018 8:26:52 PM: ......\nCopyright \xc2\xa91999 - 2019\nTVEyes, Inc.\nAll rights reserved.\nQuestions, comments, or suggestions? York\nNational\nCaribbean\nSports\nEntertainment\nFeatures\nCalendar\nJune 14, 2018\n/ New\xc2\xa0York\xc2\xa0local\nLink kiosks celebrate city\xe2\x80\x99s influential Caribbean-Americans\nEnlarge this imageLinkNYCDominican-American singer Amara La Negra\xe2\x80\x99s digital billboard plays at a Link kiosk in Times Square.\nBy Alexandra Simon\nShare on TwitterTweet\nShare on Facebook\nSubscribe\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t miss our updates:\nEnlarge this image\nDoughbwoy\nComedian Majah Hype will be one of a dozen Caribbean-American highlighted in LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s campaign for Caribbean Heritage Month.\nEnlarge this image\nStephanie Ifendu\nDominican-American writer and author Elizabeth Acevedo is being highlighted in the citywide campaign, displaying notable people of Caribbean descent in all Link kiosks.\nSimilar stories\nStaten Island: City\xe2\x80\x99s digital kiosks celebrate Caribbean heritageMusic: Caribbean heritage month closes out with day long spectacular festMusic: Night at the museum Caribbean style!Manhattan: State comptroller honors congresswoman Clarke, slain officerMusic: Get into the hype with Majah HypeFood: All day feast on Jamaican Jerk favorites\nPermalink\nEmail to a friend\nYour name\nYour email address\nRecipients\xe2\x80\x99 email addresses (Up to ten, separated by commas.)\nCelebrating June as Caribbean Heritage Month, the citywide WiFi service LinkNYC is commemorating the annual observance by gracing all of their kiosks with images of influential Americans of Caribbean descent. The campaign, which highlights several notable people born or living in the city, launched last year and was created in partnership with cultural hub, Caribbeing. And its returned for another year to celebrate it, said the commissioner of the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis month, New Yorkers will get to see some of the most influential Caribbean American icons of the past century just by walking by a LinkNYC kiosk,\xe2\x80\x9d Samir Saini. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re thrilled to collaborate with Caribbeing to showcase the Caribbean culture and heritage while shining a light on the figures who have positively impacted New York City.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe honorees included are comedian Majah Hype, dancehall artists Spice, writer and author Elizabeth Acevedo, famed artist Jean Michel Basquiat, Pan-African leader Marcus Garvey, activist and leader Malcolm X, actor Winston Duke, hip-hop pioneer Grandmaster Flash, salsa singer La Lupe, award-winning actor Sidney Poitier, singer Amara La Negra, author Roxane Gay, the city\xe2\x80\x99s first Caribbean-born elected official Dr. Una Clarke, politician and first black congresswoman Shirley Chisholm, and rapper Biggie Smalls.\nAll the aforementioned are of Jamaican, Trinidadian, Dominican, Puerto Rican, Haitian, Barbadian, and Cuban descent. Many of them creating history not only for the city, but for themselves and the Caribbean Diaspora, said the service\xe2\x80\x99s director of community affairs.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaribbeing chose figures who have impacted New York City\xe2\x80\x99s culture in so many ways, from artists and authors to activists and notable politicians,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fasoldt. \xe2\x80\x9cWe were thrilled to work with Caribbeing for the second year in a row to showcase these icons and their accomplishments throughout the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWith one of the country\xe2\x80\x99s biggest concentration of Caribbean immigrants, this campaign is timely and complimenting of the city\xe2\x80\x99s Caribbean Diaspora.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City is home to one of the largest, most diverse Caribbean populations in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d added Fasoldt. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are honored to use the LinkNYC platform to celebrate Caribbean American Heritage Month and recognize the many contributions Caribbean Americans have made throughout history.\xe2\x80\x9d\nA few of the icons in the campaign are deceased, but majority of them are living and thrilled to see their likeness represented through visual billboard across the city, according to Fasoldt.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have been delighted to see some of the artists \xe2\x80\x94 including Majah Hype and Amara La Negra \xe2\x80\x94 catch themselves on Link kiosks and share the images on social media with their fans,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fasoldt.\nSaini says this campaign is one of the many ways the city is working to use technology to help educate passerby and spread knowledge.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC and the NYC Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications have worked with many local organizations to highlight the roles of both well known and un-sung figures in history and culture,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe love that our platform of 1,600 kiosks, provides the opportunity to further connect New Yorkers to their communities, and help us all learn more about each other.\xe2\x80\x9dReach reporter Alexandra Simon at (718) 260\xc3\xa2\xe2\x82\xac\xe2\x80\x9c8310 or e-mail her at asimon@cnglocal.com. Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b'Bystanders No MoreNo m\xc3\xa1s espectadores - Manhattan Times News\nTop Stories\n\xe2\x80\x9cTime could be running out\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x9cEl tiempo podr\xc3\xada estarse acabando\xe2\x80\x9d\nGo GreenVa la verde\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re only getting started\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x9cApenas estamos empezando\xe2\x80\x9d\nBragg announces campaign for Manhattan DABragg anuncia campa\xc3\xb1a para fiscal de distrito de Manhattan\nUnderstanding Gender IdentityEntendiendo la identidad de g\xc3\xa9nero\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are strong\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x9cSomos fuertes\xe2\x80\x9d\nUC Recap \xe2\x80\x93 June 10 \xe2\x80\x93 June 15\n\xe2\x80\x9cCriminalization kills my community\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x9cLa criminalizaci\xc3\xb3n mata a mi comunidad\xe2\x80\x9d\nPre-K ParityParidad en Pre-K\nLandmark deal reached for rent reformHist\xc3\xb3rico acuerdo alcanzado para la reforma de alquiler\nManhattan Times News\nHOME\nABOUT US\nSECTIONS\nLocal\nHealth\nPolitics/Government\nEducation\nGreen Living\nArts\nPublic Safety\nFood\nSports\nOpinion\nFit In The City\nY.U.M.\nUC Recap\nARCHIVES\n2010\n2011\n2012\nPublishers\xe2\x80\x99 Picks\nVIDEOS\nGET THE PAPER\nAdvertising\nCONTACT\nBystanders No MoreNo m\xc3\xa1s espectadores\nPosted by:\nPostmaster\nin\nEducation, Espa\xc3\xb1ol, Health, Local, News, Public Safety\nJune 14, 2018\n0\nEnglishEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nBystanders No More\nCampaign for hands-only CPR aims to save lives\nStory and photos by Gregg McQueen\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny CPR is better than no CPR,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dr. Holly Andersen, creator of the Hands Only CPR campaign.\nCheck. Call. Compress.\nThose are the three easy steps medical professionals say can help save a life if someone experiences sudden cardiac arrest.\nNewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and the city\xe2\x80\x99s Health Department have teamed up to teach New Yorkers how to perform Hands Only CPR, a simple technique designed to save someone undergoing cardiac arrest.\nThe Hands Only CPR campaign calls on bystanders to check on the victim for responsiveness and breathing, call 911, and compress the victim\xe2\x80\x99s chest by pushing hard and fast in the center of the chest with straight arms and interlocked hands, with two compressions per second at least two inches deep.\nDr. Holly Andersen, a cardiologist at New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center and creator of the Hands Only CPR campaign, said she started the outreach effort because of the concerns about cardiac arrest victims dying when bystanders were unsure of what to do.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomeone dies every two minutes in this country due to sudden cardiac arrest,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s about half of all cardiovascular deaths.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAndersen explained that she started the campaign to increase bystander response.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny CPR is better than no CPR,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve reduced saving a life to three easy steps.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCardiac arrest is the third leading cause of death in America \xe2\x80\x93 there are more than 356,000 out-of-hospital cardiac arrests annually in the U.S., nearly 90 percent of them fatal, according to the American Heart Association.\nOn June 6, New York-Presbyterian and the Health Department sponsored a training session at El Cata\xc3\xb1o Public Garden in East Harlem, where community members could learn the Hands Only CPR technique.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is something that anyone can do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Health Department Commissioner Dr. Mary Bassett at the event. She said that many people suffering cardiac arrest do not get the help they need, and that the chances of survival decreases by 10 percent for every minute they are not assisted.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is something that anyone can do,\xe2\x80\x9d said HealthDepartment Commissioner Dr. Mary Bassett.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe enemy of survival for them is time,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Bassett. \xe2\x80\x9cThe whole point is to start immediately and wait for help to arrive.\xe2\x80\x9d\nEast Harlem was targeted for the training effort because Health Department statistics show that rates of bystander CPR are only 18 percent in black neighborhoods, compared to nearly 47 percent in white neighborhoods, Health Department officials said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s important to connect with these communities,\xe2\x80\x9d said City Councilmember Bill Perkins, who received CPR training. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s really easy to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBassett said that many people are hesitant to do mouth-to-mouth CPR, or are afraid to intervene because they don\xe2\x80\x99t want to harm the victim more.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis doesn\xe2\x80\x99t take the place of regular CPR, but it\xe2\x80\x99s something anyone can do if they\xe2\x80\x99re not certified for that,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t need to perform mouth-to-mouth to help someone.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe worst thing you can do is nothing. You can\xe2\x80\x99t hurt someone who\xe2\x80\x99s going to die without your help,\xe2\x80\x9d added Andersen, who said that brain cells begin to die after five minutes if a cardiac arrest victim is not assisted.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a three-step process.\nShe encouraged New Yorkers to download an instructional poster from the Hands On CPR website and post it in their residential buildings or offices.\nAndersen said the Hands on CPR process has been presented to the Police Commissioner, and featured in\xc2\xa0an instructional video playing in the offices of large corporations as well as in yellow cabs. The city will also promote the three-step protocol in a citywide ad campaign on LinkNYC Wi-Fi, bus shelters, Times Square media and a program in New York City health clubs.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re starting off doing this in New York City, but we\xe2\x80\x99re looking to take this worldwide,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cThis\xc2\xa0is a\xc2\xa0global issue.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAt the East Harlem event, New York-Presbyterian volunteers showed attendees how to perform the Hands On CPR method, and provided them with cards indicating they had received training.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing to learn,\xe2\x80\x9d said local resident Raymond Bonhomme. \xe2\x80\x9cIt could save a life.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLinda Ortiz and Steven Rodr\xc3\xadguez, who work at the Health Department\xe2\x80\x99s Neighborhood Action Center on East 115th Street, said they hoped to spread the word further in the community.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was really simple to learn, about five minutes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ortiz. \xe2\x80\x9cI plan on telling a lot of others about this.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFor more information, go to www.handsonly.nyc.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny CPR is better than no CPR,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dr. Holly Andersen, creator of the Hands Only CPR campaign.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is something that anyone can do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Health Department Commissioner Dr. Mary Bassett.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a three-step process.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt could save a life,\xe2\x80\x9d said local resident Raymond Bonhomme.\nThe demo was held with community residents.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was really simply to learn, about five minutes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Linda Ortiz (right) with colleague Steven Rodr\xc3\xadguez.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s important to connect with these communities,\xe2\x80\x9d said City Councilmember Bill Perkins.\nPerkins was trained in the procedure.\nNo m\xc3\xa1s espectadores\nCampa\xc3\xb1a pr\xc3\xa1ctica de reanimaci\xc3\xb3n cardiopulmonar busca salvar vidas\nHistoria y fotos por Gregg McQueen\nLa demostraci\xc3\xb3n se llev\xc3\xb3 a cabo con residentesde la comunidad.\nVerificar. Llamar. Comprimir.\nEsos son los tres sencillos pasos que los profesionales m\xc3\xa9dicos dicen que pueden ayudar a salvar una vida si alguien experimenta un paro card\xc3\xadaco repentino.\nEl Hospital NewYork-Presbyterian y el Departamento de Salud de la ciudad se han unido para ense\xc3\xb1ar a los neoyorquinos a realizar RCP usando solo las manos, una t\xc3\xa9cnica sencilla dise\xc3\xb1ada para salvar a alguien que sufre un paro card\xc3\xadaco.\nLa campa\xc3\xb1a Hands Only CPR hace un llamado a los espectadores para verificar la capacidad de respuesta y respiraci\xc3\xb3n de la v\xc3\xadctima, llamar al 911 y comprimir el t\xc3\xb3rax de la v\xc3\xadctima presionando fuerte y r\xc3\xa1pido en el centro del pecho con los brazos rectos y las manos entrelazadas, con dos compresiones por segundo a al menos dos pulgadas de profundidad.\nLa Dra. Holly Andersen, cardi\xc3\xb3loga del New York Presbyterian/Centro M\xc3\xa9dico Weill Cornell de Nueva York y creadora de la campa\xc3\xb1a Hands Only CPR, dijo que comenz\xc3\xb3 el esfuerzo de alcance debido a las preocupaciones de que las v\xc3\xadctimas de paro card\xc3\xadaco murieran mientras los espectadores no sab\xc3\xadan qu\xc3\xa9 hacer.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlguien muere cada dos minutos en este pa\xc3\xads debido a un paro card\xc3\xadaco repentino\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo. \xe2\x80\x9cEs aproximadamente la mitad de todas las muertes cardiovasculares\xe2\x80\x9d.\nAndersen explic\xc3\xb3 que ella comenz\xc3\xb3 la campa\xc3\xb1a para aumentar la respuesta de los espectadores.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCualquier RCP es mejor que ninguna\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo. \xe2\x80\x9cHemos reducido el salvar una vida a tres sencillos pasos\xe2\x80\x9d.\nEl paro card\xc3\xadaco es la tercera causa de muerte en los Estados Unidos: hay m\xc3\xa1s de 356,000 paros card\xc3\xadacos extra hospitalarios anualmente en el pa\xc3\xads, casi el 90 por ciento de ellos son mortales, de acuerdo con la Asociaci\xc3\xb3n Estadounidense del Coraz\xc3\xb3n.\nEl 6 de junio, el New York-Presbyterian y el Departamento de Salud patrocinaron una sesi\xc3\xb3n de capacitaci\xc3\xb3n en el Jard\xc3\xadn P\xc3\xbablico El Cata\xc3\xb1o, en East Harlem, donde los miembros de la comunidad pudieron aprender la t\xc3\xa9cnica de RCP solo con manos.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsto fue muy simple de aprender, de unos cinco minutos,\xe2\x80\x9d dijo Linda Ortiz (a la derecha)con su colega Steven Rodr\xc3\xadguez.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsto es algo que cualquiera puede hacer\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo la comisionada del Departamento de Salud, la Dra. Mary Bassett, en el evento. Explic\xc3\xb3 que muchas personas que sufren un paro card\xc3\xadaco no reciben la ayuda que necesitan, y las posibilidades de supervivencia disminuyen en un 10 por ciento por cada minuto que no reciben ayuda.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEl enemigo de la supervivencia para ellos es el tiempo\xe2\x80\x9d, coment\xc3\xb3 Bassett. \xe2\x80\x9cEl objetivo es comenzar de inmediato y esperar a que llegue la ayuda\xe2\x80\x9d.\nEast Harlem fue el objetivo del esfuerzo de capacitaci\xc3\xb3n porque las estad\xc3\xadsticas del Departamento de Salud muestran que las tasas de RCP de los espectadores son solo del 18 por ciento en los barrios negros, en comparaci\xc3\xb3n con casi el 47 por ciento en los barrios blancos, dijeron funcionarios del Departamento de Salud.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEs importante conectar con estas comunidades\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo el concejal Bill Perkins, quien recibi\xc3\xb3 capacitaci\xc3\xb3n en RCP. \xe2\x80\x9cEs realmente f\xc3\xa1cil de hacer\xe2\x80\x9d.\nBassett dijo que muchas personas dudan en hacer RCP boca a boca, o tienen miedo de intervenir porque no quieren da\xc3\xb1ar m\xc3\xa1s a la v\xc3\xadctima.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEs importante conectar con estas comunidades\xe2\x80\x9d,dijo Bill Perkins, concejal de la ciudad.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsto no sustituye la RCP regular, pero es algo que cualquier persona puede hacer si no est\xc3\xa1 certificada para ello\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo. \xe2\x80\x9cNo es necesario que practicar el boca a boca para ayudar a alguien\xe2\x80\x9d.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLo peor que puedes hacer es nada. No se puede lastimar a alguien que va a morir sin ayuda\xe2\x80\x9d, agreg\xc3\xb3 Andersen, explicando que las c\xc3\xa9lulas del cerebro comienzan a morir despu\xc3\xa9s de cinco minutos si no se ayuda a una v\xc3\xadctima de un paro card\xc3\xadaco.\nAnim\xc3\xb3 a los neoyorquinos a descargar un p\xc3\xb3ster instructivo del sitio web Hands On CPR y a colocarlo en sus edificios de vivienda u oficinas residenciales.\nAndersen dijo que el proceso Hands on CPR se present\xc3\xb3 al comisionado de Polic\xc3\xada y se incluy\xc3\xb3 en un video instructivo que se reproduce en las oficinas de las grandes corporaciones y en los taxis amarillos. La ciudad tambi\xc3\xa9n promover\xc3\xa1 el protocolo de tres pasos en una campa\xc3\xb1a publicitaria en toda la ciudad en LinkNYC Wi-Fi, refugios de autobuses, medios de Times Square y un programa en los clubes de salud de la ciudad de Nueva York.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEstamos comenzando a hacer esto en la ciudad de Nueva York, pero estamos buscando llevarlo a todo el mundo\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo. \xe2\x80\x9cEste es un problema global\xe2\x80\x9d.\nEn el evento de East Harlem, los voluntarios del New York-Presbyterian mostraron a los asistentes c\xc3\xb3mo realizar el m\xc3\xa9todo RCP solo con manos y les proporcionaron tarjetas indicando que recibieron capacitaci\xc3\xb3n.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEs algo bueno de aprender\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo el residente local Raymond Bonhomme. \xe2\x80\x9cPodr\xc3\xada salvar una vida\xe2\x80\x9d.\nLinda Ortiz y Steven Rodr\xc3\xadguez, quienes trabajan en el Centro de Acci\xc3\xb3n del Vecindario del Departamento de Salud en la calle 115 este, dijeron que esperan correr la voz en la comunidad.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsto fue muy simple de aprender, unos cinco minutos\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo Ortiz. \xe2\x80\x9cPlaneo contarles a muchos otros sobre esto\xe2\x80\x9d.\nPara obtener m\xc3\xa1s informaci\xc3\xb3n, vaya a\xc2\xa0www.handsonly.nyc.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCualquier RCP es mejor que ninguna\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo la Dra. Holly Andersen, creadora de la campa\xc3\xb1a de RCP solo con manos.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsto es algo que cualquiera puede hacer\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo la comisionada del Departamento de Salud, Dra. Mary Bassett.\nEs un proceso de tres pasos.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPodr\xc3\xada salvar una vida\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo el residente local Raymond Bonhomme.\nLa demostraci\xc3\xb3n se llev\xc3\xb3 a cabo con residentes de la comunidad.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsto fue muy simple de aprender, de unos cinco minutos,\xe2\x80\x9d dijo Linda Ortiz (a la derecha) con su colega Steven Rodr\xc3\xadguez.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEs importante conectar con estas comunidades\xe2\x80\x9d, dijo Bill Perkins, concejal de la ciudad.\nPerkins recibi\xc3\xb3 capacitaci\xc3\xb3n sobre el procedimiento.\nEducation Espa\xc3\xb1ol Health | Designed by Monkey Pig Inc', b'What\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: User-Centered Research Helps Guide Code for America\xe2\x80\x99s Work in California\nimage/svg+xml\nCONTINUE TO SITE\nThis website uses cookies in order to offer you the most relevant information.\n\xc3\x97\nLearn More\nI Accept\nMAGAZINE\nNEWSLETTERS\nEVENTS\nPAPERS\nNAVIGATOR\nSECTIONS\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL EDUCATION\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL GOVERNMENT\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nDIGITAL STATES PERFORMANCE INSTITUTE\nTOP 25\nGOVTECH 100\nSEARCH\nCybersecurity\nGovTech Biz\nEmerging Tech\nCloud\nGov Experience\nMore\nGov Tech\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: User-Centered Research Helps Guide Code for America\xe2\x80\x99s Work in California\nPlus, LinkNYC kiosks celebrate city\xe2\x80\x99s famous Caribbean residents; California\xe2\x80\x99s Humboldt County enhances website accessibility; and Nashville launches new app to improve government interactions with citizens.\nby Zack Quaintance\n/\nJune 14, 2018\nA depiction of one of the proposed LinkNYC kiosks that will help deliver the gigabit-speed Wi-Fi to millions of residents and visitors across New York.\nLinkNYC\nAs part of its ongoing work on California\xe2\x80\x99s food assistance program GetCalFresh, the civic tech group Code for America (CfA) recently conducted extensive user-centric research aimed at modifying eligibility expectations.\nThis effort, which members of the nonprofit and nonpartisan group wrote about recently on medium, ties in with the overarching goal of CfA\xe2\x80\x99s work in this area \xe2\x80\x94 to make it as easy as possible for residents to apply for food assistance in California. While researching the application process, CfA found that a large number of applicants were over the income limit to qualify \xe2\x80\x94 be it because they were overlooking source of income or because the application worded its question in a way that resulted in guestimating.\nOperating with the belief that individuals unlikely to be eligible due to income should find out as quickly as possible, CfA turned to user-centric research to help it make changes to GetCalFresh, noting that getting rejected more quickly in the process would give individuals a chance to find alternative food assistance in a more timely manner.\nRELATEDWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: Bloomberg Announces $42 Million Addition to What Works Cities InitiativeWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: New Legislation in Connecticut Bolsters State\xe2\x80\x99s Open Data EffortsWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: More than 50 Services Now Available on my.indy.govTo improve in this regard, CfA is now working to improve GetCalFresh\xe2\x80\x99s application so that it provides better guidance about reporting income, specifically unearned income such as disability, veteran benefits, money received from a friend or relative, and worker\xe2\x80\x99s compensation.\nUser-centered research and design is a process in which developers extensively study the people who use services, rather than just scientifically guessing at their needs. Relatively common in the private sector in recent years, the discipline is currently being deployed by an increasing number of governmental organizations and vendors across the country.\nLinkNYC kiosks celebrate city\xe2\x80\x99s famous Caribbean residents\nTo celebrate June as Caribbean Heritage Month, LinkNYC kiosks in New York City are sporting images of influential Americans of Caribbean heritage.\nThis program first launched last year, and it is a collaboration between New York\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications and CARIBBEING, a cultural organization based in Brooklyn. The Caribbean American icons will be featured on the 55-inch digital display kiosks spread throughout the city with a goal of raising awareness about their contributions.\nWhile last year the program included figures such as artist Jean-Michel Basquiat, rapper the Notorious B.I.G., and Queen of Salsa Celia Cruz, this year\xe2\x80\x99s program will expand to feature even more visages. New this year are comedian Majah Hype, singer and musician Amara La Negra, and author Elizabeth Acevedo.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis month, New Yorkers will get to see some of the most influential Caribbean American icons of the past century just by walking by a LinkNYC kiosk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Samir Saini, New York\xe2\x80\x99s IT commissioner in a press release. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re thrilled to collaborate with Caribbeing to showcase the Caribbean culture and heritage while shining a light on the figures who have positively impacted New York City.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLinkNYC is made up of more than 1,650 individual kiosks spread throughout the city\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs. It was first launched in early 2016.\nNashville launches new app to improve government interactions with citizens\nNashville is launching a new app to accompany the hubNashville online portal the city debuted late last year, according to local news reports.\nThe new app is designed to give citizens easier access, 24 hours a day, to municipal government services. This comes in the form of everything from reporting problems about street lights to getting information about job opportunities at city hall. After a problem is reported, the app will send users updates about how that problem is being handled.\nIn addition to the app, the city has also created an online video tutorial for residents. Essentially, the app is a comprehensive mobile customer service center aimed at connecting residents for any non-emergency services, handling requests made of the Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s Office, the Metro Council Office, public works, codes and metro water services\xe2\x80\x99 stormwater division.\nAccording to the app\xe2\x80\x99s website, more departments and agencies will be added soon.\nHumboldt County, Calif., enhances website accessibility\nHumboldt County, Calif., has launched an enhanced website aimed at increasing equitable access to its services for users with disabilities, both with and without access to assistive technology devices.\nAs government services move increasingly online, there is a fear among many officials, advocates and residents that digital equity will leave some residents behind. Perhaps most frequently, this fear is framed in terms of income levels, but it also applies to the inclusion of users who suffer disabilities.\nEssentially, digitizing as many services as possible is wonderful. Agencies, however, must also work to make sure those digitized services are available to individuals with visual, hearing or other disabilities.\nThis is the situation that Humboldt County \xe2\x80\x94 home to more than 135,000 residents in Northern California, near the border with Oregon \xe2\x80\x94 has sought to remedy.\nTo make these enhancements, the county worked with Civic Plus\xe2\x80\x99 CivicEngage Website design and hosting solution, as well as with AudioEye Inc., which is CivicPlus\xe2\x80\x99 accessibility solution provider.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIT has several goals,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jim Storm, Humboldt County\xe2\x80\x99s IT division director, in a press release. \xe2\x80\x9cStrive to keep current with technology, ensure reliable systems and provide excellent customer service. With CivicPlus, our website is optimized for efficiency, and we have a collocated geographically diverse data center and 24/7/365 support. We also wanted to be a leader among California counties in Web accessibility.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAudioEye is software that monitors websites as they grow or are modified in order to automatically fix certain issues to ensure accessibility for users of assistive technology for disabilities.\nZack Quaintance\nAssistant News Editor\nZack Quaintance is the assistant news editor for Government Technology. His background includes writing for daily newspapers across the country and developing content for a software company in Austin, Texas. He is now based in Washington, D.C. He can be reached via email.\nRELATED\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: Bloomberg Announces $42 Million Addition to What Works Cities Initiative\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: New Legislation in Connecticut Bolsters State\xe2\x80\x99s Open Data Efforts\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: More than 50 Services Now Available on my.indy.gov\nDISCUSS\nWe invite you to discuss and comment on this article using social media.\nMORE FROM Gov Tech\nSPONSORED ARTICLES\nERP Modernization: How the Cloud Delivers Scalability, Security and Innovation\nThe Reality of the Local Government Cybersecurity Skill Gap\nGovernment No Longer Has to Choose Between Cybersecurity and Productivity\nNEWSLETTERS\nGovTech Today - Archpaper.com\nLinkNYC kiosks will display iconic film director\xe2\x80\x99s photos of old New York\nMenu\nAwards\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nContact\nAbout\nPrivacy Policy\nMap\nEvents\nCompetitions\nProducts\nJobs\nTopics\nRegions\nInternational\nEast\nSoutheast\nMidwest\nWest\nSouthwest\nTopics\nAN Interior\nArchitecture\nArt\nDesign\nDevelopment\nPreservation\nTransportation\nUrbanism\nNewsletters\nFacades+\nSpec Sheet\nCity Terrain\nLate Edition: East\nLate Edition: West\nLate Edition: Midwest\nLate Edition: Southwest\nConferences\nFacades+ Conference\nFacades+ AM\nTech+\nEvents\nCompetitions\nProducts\nJobs\nConferences\nConferences\nFacades+ Conferences\nTech+ Expo\nAwards\nSubscribe\nKubrick Takeover\nLinkNYC kiosks will display iconic film director\xe2\x80\x99s photos of old New York\nBy\nSelina Cheah\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nJune 19, 2018\nShare:\nBeginning this Thursday, LinkNYC kiosks around the city will feature images from the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s (MCNY) extensive photography archive.\nThe aptly named campaign, Summer in the City, is a partnership between the Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications (DoITT), LinkNYC, the city\xe2\x80\x99s free Wi-Fi kiosk system, and MCNY. Images will be displayed from the Museum\xe2\x80\x99s current exhibition, Through a Different Lens: Stanley Kubrick Photographs.\nPasserby on the street will be able to catch a glimpse of the old New York through the lens of the iconic film director. Kubrick\xe2\x80\x99s photographs highlight his formative years as a photographer (before he became a film director) for Look magazine in New York City between 1945-1950. The photographs focus on and capture the pathos of everyday life of the city, from street scenes to sporting events.\nThe LinkNYC kiosks can be found dotted all over the city. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio launched the program in 2016, more than 1,650 Links are active across all five boroughs and have replaced the old pay phones with sleek kiosks that feature free Wi-Fi, phone chargers, and digital displays for advertisements and in this case, art.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s not the first time that LinkNYC has featured art on its kiosks from MCNY. Previous \xe2\x80\x9cexhibitions\xe2\x80\x9d on the kiosks include historic photos of women who influenced New York\xe2\x80\x99s political history for Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month and \xe2\x80\x9cOn This Day in NYC History\xe2\x80\x9d information. The MCNY and LinkNYC partnership is one of many programs that disseminate New York City\xe2\x80\x99s history; others include the NYC Space/Time Directory from the New York Public Library, an app from Urban Archive that made more than 2,500 images of old New York available on-the-go, and a Civil Rights & Social Justice Map from the Greenwich Village Society.\nLinkNYC\nMCNY\nPublic Art\nRelated 21 Murray Street, 5th Floor | New York, NY 10007 | tel. 212.966.0630\nCopyright 2019, All rights reserved.", b"BT Begin Deploying 12 Ultrafast WiFi InLinkUK Kiosks in Glasgow - ISPreview UK\nMobile Menu\nHome\nISP List and Comparison\nSpeedtest\nReader Reviews\nTop 10 UK ISPs\nDiscussion Forum\nBroadband Technology\nComplaints Advice\nEditorial Articles\nContact Us\nHome\nArticles\nISP List\nReviews\nTop 10\nForum\nSpeedtest\nBroadband\nComplaints\nContact\nHome\xc2\xa0\xc2\xbb\xc2\xa0ISP News\xc2\xa0\xc2\xbb\nSponsored\nBT Begin Deploying 12 Ultrafast WiFi InLinkUK Kiosks in Glasgow\nTuesday, June 19th, 2018 (12:00 pm) - Score 2,249\nEmail | Link News\n9 Comments\nAfter deploying in London and Leeds, BT has today announced the first roll-out of 12 InLinkUK smart kiosks in Glasgow (Scotland), which claim to offer \xe2\x80\x9cultrafast\xe2\x80\x9d 1Gbps capable free public WiFi, free UK phone calls, USB device charging and a range of other digital services to help people in the vicinity.\nThe first kiosk went live on Buchanan Street and others will soon follow around the city centre. Overall a total of 150 kiosks have now been rolled out to parts of London, Leeds and Glasgow. The InLinkUK kiosks reflect a partnership between BT, Intersection (LinkNYC) and advertising company Primesight. The plan is that they will eventually replace over 1,000 pay phones in major cities across the UK. Funding for the kiosks is extracted via revenues from advertising on the large 55\xe2\x80\xb3 HD digital displays.\nNeil Scoresby, BT\xe2\x80\x99s GM for Payphones and InLinkUK, said:\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday\xe2\x80\x99s launch in Glasgow brings the fastest free public wi-fi in the UK to Scotland. Residents and visitors alike are set to benefit from this new state-of-the-art \xe2\x80\x98phone box\xe2\x80\x99, where they can also make calls for free, access local information and even charge their \xe2\x80\x98phone when out and about.\xe2\x80\x9d\nUnfortunately BT has not provided any evidence to substantiate their claim of offering the \xe2\x80\x9cfastest free public wi-fi in the UK\xe2\x80\x9d (difficult to prove). Some speed testing conducted last year (here) unsurprisingly revealed that real-world performance actually came in well below the headline claims of \xe2\x80\x98up to\xe2\x80\x99 1Gbps (sub-100Mbps is a more viable expectation).\nWireless broadband signals and network congestion are of course notoriously difficult things to tackle in a real-world environment but this shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t overshadow the fact that BT\xe2\x80\x99s kiosks still offer a useful set of features. The real speeds may struggle to hit a Gigabit but they\xe2\x80\x99re still impressively fast for a free public WiFi hotspot.\nSince the first InLink was installed in June last year, more than 100,000 people have subscribed to the service\xe2\x80\x99s free wi-fi, using \xe2\x80\x9cenough data to download the equivalent of over 12 million songs.\xe2\x80\x9d The InLinks have also \xe2\x80\x9csaved users more than \xc2\xa3352,000 in free calls, with 33,000 calls being made on average every week.\xe2\x80\x9d\nUPDATE 1:09pm\nWe understand that planning consent for more kiosks has already been approved by local councils in Birmingham, Newcastle, Southampton, Gateshead and Sheffield, as well as the London borough of Kensington & Chelsea.\nTweet\nTags: BT , Scotland , Wireless Internet\nBy Mark Jackson\nMark is a professional technology writer, IT consultant and computer engineer from Dorset (England), he also founded ISPreview in 1999 and enjoys analysing the latest telecoms and broadband developments. The nearest working phone box to me is over 4 miles away \xe2\x80\x93 the nearer ones have been decommissioned.\nMark Jackson\nJune 19, 2018 at 3:58 pm\nIn fairness, nobody really makes \xe2\x80\x9cloads of money\xe2\x80\x9d from the sort of advertising that those kiosks deliver.\nNew_Londoner\nJune 20, 2018 at 6:25 pm\nWhether or not BT deploys these new units will have no bearing on Openreach determining the attractiveness or otherwise of upgrading the broadband infrastructure serving your home.\nSteve\nJune 19, 2018 at 5:05 pm\nI would imagine the the return on investment for companies advertising on those screens is between sod all and not very much!\nMeadmodj\nJune 19, 2018 at 5:05 pm\nThis is more about brand placement.\nCurrently if you do not use the access for 30 minutes or make continuous use for 24 hours you will be cut off but can log back in. With Passport your connection is a little more secure. These will be isolated installs but will provide a known location for connectivity if you need it and I am sure enterprising residents within range can use them as a cheap broadband equivalent.\nIf abused the commercial their model will change.\nThomas Byrne\nJune 20, 2018 at 4:27 am\nWhile these boxes look good in London\xe2\x80\x99s high streets, in parts it is very noticeable that those who make best use of them are the drug users. How kind of BT to let them order their drugs from their dealers free of charge.\nGadget\nJune 20, 2018 at 8:38 am\nSurely the same could be said of any \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d WiFi service on trains, buses or underground?\nHopefully though the problem you have highlighted will therefore already be being addressed.\nMike\nJune 20, 2018 at 12:03 pm\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s wrong with BT helping in the fight against prohibition?\nRichard\nJune 20, 2018 at 5:37 pm\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s going to help BT and their\n\xc2\xa314 billion pension deficit.\nComments RSS Feed\nJavascript must be enabled to post (most browsers do this automatically)\nPrivacy Notice: Please note that news comments are anonymous, which means that we do NOT require you to enter any real personal details to post a message. Cara Joy David\nSocial Analytics\nGrosses\nBroadway Leader Board\nTheater Report\nWhat\'s Playing Around the World\nUpdate BWW\'s Database\nLinkNYC, DoITT Announce Content Partnership With The Museum Of The City Of New York\nby BWW News Desk\nBroadwayWorld.com\nJun. 19, 2018\nTweet\nShare\nLinkNYC and the Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications (DoITT) today announced a content partnership with the Museum of the City of New York, extending the Museum\'s extensive archive of photography and historic moments to the streets of New York through the Link network. A new campaign called Summer in the City to launch June 21st will feature images from the Museum\'s current exhibition, Through a Different Lens: Stanley Kubrick Photographs, which highlights the iconic film director\'s formative years in New York City as a photographer for Look magazine between 1945-1950.\n"We\'re proud to partner with MCNY to serve both residents and visitors by extending the Museum\'s rich archive of photography to the streets of New York," said Samir Saini, Commissioner for the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. "New Yorkers in all five boroughs will catch a glimpse of history, art and culture just by passing by a LinkNYC kiosk. What better way to start the summer!"\n"In addition to providing super-fast, free Wi-Fi to four million New Yorkers and visitors, LinkNYC is fundamentally changing the way information is delivered on the go. Through the content on our digital displays, we have brought useful and enriching information to the streets of New York, including in partnership with great local organizations that have made Link a beloved member of the community," said Jen Hensley, President of Link. "We are so thrilled to partner with the Museum of the City of New York, a great New York City institution, to bring their incredible content to our five-borough network."\n"Partnering with LinkNYC and DoITT is the perfect opportunity to both extend our content beyond the walls of the Museum as well as reinforce the Museum\'s mission as an institution that captures the inclusive urban experience by spotlighting relevant contemporary issues important to New Yorkers," said Whitney Donhauser, Ronay Menschel Director of the Museum of the City of New York. "The Summer in the City campaign, featuring the photography of Stanley Kubrick encompasses the rich, diverse history of the city while giving you a glimpse into the iconic director\'s future work as an artist who continues to be celebrated globally."\nLinkNYC has partnered with the Museum on multiple campaigns, ranging from highlighting historic photos of women who influenced New York political history for Women\'s History Month from the Museum\'s exhibition, Beyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics, to surfacing new \'On This Day In NYC History\' (#OTDNYC) information every day. The programs aim to increase access to city history and delight New Yorkers and visitors while on the go.\nThrough a Different Lens: Stanley Kubrick Photographs is made possible in part by Ann G. Tenenbaum and Thomas H. Lee, Nancy and Mitchell Steir, The Hilaria and Alec Baldwin Foundation, The Andrew and Marina Lewin Foundation, Daryl Brown Uber/William E. Weiss Foundation, and George A. Kellner.\nThis exhibition is organized by the Museum of the City of New York in collaboration with SK Film Archives LLC.\nDigitization of the Stanley Kubrick Photographs from the Look magazine collection was made possible in part by the Charina Endowment Fund, Bloomberg Philanthropies, Daryl Brown Uber/William E. Weiss Foundation, and other generous donors.\nDoITT is the technology core of New York City government, working with over 100 city agencies and entities to deliver the tech they need to serve and empower New Yorkers. DoITT\'s technology solutions help keep the five boroughs safe, strong, and vibrant. For more information, visit nyc.gov/DoITT or visit us on Facebook or Twitter.\nLinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\'s payphones to build the world\'s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,650 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next few years.\nMore than 4 million people - more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Phoenix, Philadelphia, Dallas, or San Diego - have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of new users joining the network each week.\nIn addition to free Wi-Fi, each Link offers free phone calls, device charging, and a tablet to access maps, 311, the social services platform Aunt Bertha, and access to 911. All of Link\'s services are 100% free for users and come at no cost to taxpayers.\nFor more information and to find a Link near you, visit link.nyc.\nFounded in 1923 as a private, nonprofit corporation, the Museum of the City of New York celebrates and interprets the city, educating the public about its distinctive character, especially its heritage of diversity, opportunity, and perpetual transformation. The Museum connects the past, present, and future of New York City, and serves the people of the city as well as visitors from around the world through exhibitions, school and public programs, publications, and collections. To connect with the Museum on social media, follow us on Instagram and Twitter at @MuseumofCityNY and visit our Facebook page at Facebook.com/MuseumofCityNY. For more information please visit www.mcny.org.\nRelated Articles\nBroadway Favorites Announced For BROADWAY LOVES SELENA GOMEZ\nVIDEO: Get to Know the Voice Behind KING KONG\nBWW TV: Get a Sneak Peek Inside the Jimmy Awards and Meet the Nominees!\nCampbell & Wendt Star in BTG\'s ROCK AND ROLL MAN\nMore Hot Stories For You\nHAMILTON Could Be Headed to Asia, Mexico, Paris, Germany, and on an Australian Tour!\nPhoto Flash: Something\'s Coming... He had previously built himself a trip planner for London Underground (a good four years prior to London launching its own planner), and at UCSF, he built his own tools to determine the most efficient transit options home after late nights of studying. This passion for tech-driven mobility solutions led Caywood to Washington, DC, where his infatuation with transportation transformed into a business.\nIn 2013, Caywood and co-founder Ryan Croft launched TransitScreen, a company that curates local, real-time mobility information \xe2\x80\x94 including bus and rail times, wait times for ride-sharing apps and the proximity of bike- and scooter-share systems \xe2\x80\x94 and displays it on screens in commercial buildings. The screens are located across more than 40 cities in the U.S. and Canada, with some even sprinkled throughout the U.K., Ireland and France.\nThe growth of TransitScreen followed a true startup trajectory, having started in Caywood\'s garage before moving to the former 1776 incubator, and eventually into its own office. Caywood describes the company as "scrappy" and touts its most strategic business decision \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0to sell to real estate clients.\nThe TransitScreen office in Washington, DC.\nKristin Musulin\n"The cities are advocates for us because we\xe2\x80\x99re helping them by providing public information that anyone, no matter who they are \xe2\x80\x94 young or old, rich or poor \xe2\x80\x94 can get,"\xc2\xa0Caywood said. "But what we do instead is work with the real estate industry and with employers to put that information into as many public and public-ish locations as possible."\nTransitScreen displays are most commonly found in commercial offices, apartment buildings, hotels, restaurants and university buildings.\n"It\'s a very different model from, say, a LinkNYC model where they have to spend hundreds of millions in capital costs to roll out their network then find a way to recoup that," Caywood explained. "We\'re able to make a very large impact on smart cities while still being a very small and lightly-funded company."\nReal-time data on the big screen\nBy offering transportation information on a public display, the TransitScreen team is aiming to preserve a valued asset of the everyday public transit user: time.\nA recent report from McKinsey Global Institute\xc2\xa0found that, by 2025, the cities that deploy smart mobility applications could reduce average commuting times by 15-20%. "When a resident looks at real-time traffic data and decides to set out at a less busy time, she avoids adding another car to the road that would worsen congestion for everyone," the report says.\xc2\xa0"Millions of individual decisions and actions add up, making the city as a whole more productive and responsive."\nTransitScreen\nCaywood said by giving city residents the option to view this real-time data right before walking out of the door, it alleviates the responsibility of looking up the information on your mobile device. And, while TransitScreen has optimized its service to be responsive to a mobile screen, Caywood said only one in every 10 public transit riders ever checks their phone for such information.\n"Most of the trips that you\xe2\x80\x99re going to make are starting at a particular location \xe2\x80\x94 your home or your work. Being able to provide the information at a glance in an efficient and easy-to-use manner, that\xe2\x80\x99s when you have the biggest impact," he said.\nOf course the company faces a lot of pressure to keep its information accurate and up-to-date as new mobility solutions enter the market. Caywood said this is a "core goal of our product," and is accomplished through active partnerships.\n"Our approach is we want to work with all of the different mobility providers to inform our audience ... about the options that are available and the choices that they can now make," he said. "So our approach to that has been to partner with them, and we\'re now seeing that as we\'ve established our presence in the space, people are kind of now coming to us with data and saying, \'What does it take to get on TransitScreen\'s platform?\'"\nEven with the influx of new electric scooter and dockless bike companies coming online, Caywood said TransitScreen is in "active conversations" with everyone in the space.\nRanking a location with MobilityScore\nIn addition to the traditional TransitScreen platform, the company has also developed MobilityScore, a tool that ranks city locations based on access to mobility services. Similar to tools like Walk Score, MobilityScore measures how easy it is to move around a city by scoring any location or address from 0 (no mobility options) to 100 (excellent mobility options).\n"It\xe2\x80\x99s based on actual data and not just schedules, so it\xe2\x80\x99s the only tool of its kind,"\xc2\xa0Caywood said. And while the tool is only in its beta phase, it has already been rolled out in most of the top 100 largest cities in North America. The company has also worked with real estates sites like Rent Jungle to optimize property and rental searches.\nCaywood called MobilityScore an "intrinsically international product" and said TransitScreen will continue to roll out the tool in new places.\xc2\xa0In a blog post,\xc2\xa0the company also called the tool "future-proof" and said it will be continuously updated with information on microtransit, autonomous vehicles and mobility-as-a-service.\nThe MobilityScore results for a location in the Dupont Circle neighborhood of Washington, DC.\nTransitScreen\nLooking forward\nFrom its active social media accounts to regular e-mail newsletters, TransitScreen is vocal about its desire to grow alongside the cities where it operates. Caywood hinted the company has a few new offerings in the works, and is continually looking for ways to "make the TransitScreen experience more relevant to the people who are viewing it and using it."\nAnd aside from internal strategies,\xc2\xa0Caywood believes the evolution of smart cities will help the company stay along a successful growth path. He said his understanding of a "smart city" is one that takes data and translates it into useful information \xe2\x80\x94 which is at the core of TransitScreen\'s business.\n"We started with this unique public information solution but we\xe2\x80\x99re really taking it to wherever people are making decisions based on mobility," he said. "There\xe2\x80\x99s a whole different side of smart cities that people don\'t even think about because we\xe2\x80\x99re so caught up in stage one, which is data collection. Stage two is where, say Waze starts changing traffic patterns and you have to start thinking what to do with it. That\xe2\x80\x99s the interesting part and that\xe2\x80\x99s sort of where the future of smart cities is going. So that\xe2\x80\x99s where we\xe2\x80\x99re pointed to.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFollow\nKristin Musulin\non\nTwitter\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nTransportation\nTech & Data\nTop image credit:\nTransitScreen\nGet smart cities news like this in your inbox daily. You can opt out anytime.', b'LinkNYC delivers better quality of life with digital signage, Wi-Fi | Digital Signage TodayTest LinkCONTINUE TO SITE \xc2\xbb or wait 15 seconds\xc3\x97Toggle navigation\nTOPICS 3D Digital Signage4K Ultra HDAdvertisingAudience MeasurementBanks / FinancialCellular SignageCloud-Based Digital SignageContentContent ManagementCorporate CommunicationCustomer ExperienceDigital BillboardsDisplay TechnologyDistributors / ResellersDOOH AdvertisingEducation / SchoolsEntertainment VenuesHardwareHealthcare / HospitalsHotelsInstallation / IntegrationInteractive / TouchscreenLED SignsMenu BoardsMobile InteractivityOutdoor SignageRestaurantsRetailSoftwareTrends / StatisticsWayfindingView all Topic Centers \xc2\xbbSUPPLIERS Companies by NameCompanies by CategoryProducts & ServicesRequest Information from SuppliersPROJECT HELPRESOURCESNEWSWEBINARSEVENTS View Industry Event Calendar >>MORE VideosWebinarsEventsPodcastsPhotosArticlesVideosBlogsPress ReleasesJob ListingsProject HelpMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggersStore\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nLinkNYC delivers better quality of life with digital signage, Wi-FiJune 22, 2018 | by Bradley CooperIn 2016, New York City went through a major smart city upgrade, as Intersection deployed multiple Link kiosks. The city replaced older phone booths with these kiosks, which offer free Wi-Fi to the public, as well as advertising and wayfinding.The kiosks also allow customers to make free nationwide calls, or report emergencies. There are now more than 1,600 kiosks in all five boroughs of the city. Digital Signage Today spoke with Ruth Fasoldt, director of community affairs for Link, to see how these devices are transforming the city and improving lives.Q. What are the main features the kiosks offer?A. LinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\'s payphones to build the world\'s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,600 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next several years.In addition to free Wi-Fi, Links offer free nationwide phone calls, a dedicated 911 button, device charging, and a tablet to access maps and city services. Link\'s services come at no cost to users or taxpayers because Link generates its own revenue through advertising on the 55-inch digital displays on the sides of kiosks.Q. How do they improve the lives of residents?A. LinkNYC provides so many benefits to New Yorkers and visitors. More than 4 million people \xe2\x80\x94 more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Phoenix, Philadelphia, Dallas\xc2\xa0or San Diego \xe2\x80\x94 have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of users joining the network each week. The network also sees more than 250,000 free phone calls made every month. Using the tablet, people can access maps and directions on the go.Along with ads that keep LinkNYC\'s services 100 percent free for users and taxpayers, the digital displays feature useful and enriching content, including community board meeting updates, real-time transit and weather information so people can make more informed decisions about their day on the go, PSAs, fun facts about NYC, historic photos\xc2\xa0and more. The screens are also used for emergency messaging, for instance, in an extreme weather event. We see tweets and Instagram posts all the time of people capturing our content and sharing it with others.Q. How does LinkNYC deal with issues such as people loitering by the kiosks or watching inappropriate content in public?A. Back in 2016, there was an issue with some kiosks having long-term users. The LinkNYC tablet is meant to be an on-the-go resource, so the web browser was removed from Link tablets in September 2016, in exchange for curated content on the tablet, and loitering complaints dropped 96 percent immediately.Q. What type of ads do the kiosks display?A. LinkNYC has a very high caliber of advertisers across categories \xe2\x80\x94 from Samsung to Delta to The Gap and The Met.Utilizing DOOH\xc2\xa0to its fullest and breaking from the norm of basic, static ads, Link kiosks offer the ability for advertisers to display unique, dynamic ads. From weather and transit, to sporting events, movie times and more, Link ads can change based on real-time information and updates, keeping advertisements relevant and consumers engaged.During the 2018 Winter Olympics in PeyongChang, for example, NBC partnered with Intersection to display Olympics content and coverage on LinkNYC screens, highlights, prime time previews, real-time medal counts, athlete bios and more. This digital OOH content campaign was the first of its kind for the U.S. Olympics broadcaster.More recently, Intersection pioneered another first-of-its-kind campaign, partnering with Disney and Marvel to promote "The Avengers: Infinity War." On the movie\'s launch weekend, LinkNYC screens displayed ads for the blockbuster, as well as the closest theater location to each kiosk and the next show time, so that passersby, if inspired by the ad, could easily catch the next showing.Q. Do the kiosks use any analytics?A. We have stats on usership, how often different services are used, the busiest Links and more. We have also made strategic use of our network capabilities like dayparting (for example, we increase transit info on our displays during peak commuting hours), geotargeting (playing historical photos in their place of original capture), and network flexibility (during Women\'s History month, we displayed facts about women\'s suffrage along the route of the women\'s march).Q. Do you think smart cities will start to pop up everywhere? Why?A.\xc2\xa0Cities around the world are looking for ways to better deliver services to residents and visitors, increase broadband connectivity, and adapt to the needs of the digital age. Many are looking to New York and LinkNYC in particular as a model. In addition to New York, a Link network is live in the U.K.\xc2\xa0We have planned expansions into Philadelphia and Newark, with many more cities on the way.Image via Link.Topics: Advertising, Audience Measurement, Content, Customer Experience, Display Technology, DOOH Advertising, Outdoor Signage Bradley CooperBradley Cooper is a Technology Editor for DigitalSignageToday.com and BlockchainTechNews.com. His background is in information technology, advertising, and writing. wwwFollow @DigSignageTodaySponsored Links:Related ContentH&M, wayfinding claim top spots for May 2019 digital signage stories3 ways to waste your digital signage7-Eleven boosts the customer experience with menu boards7 digital transformation trends of 2019Latest ContentHow to design heavenly digital signage contentWhat\'s your biggest struggle with digital signage?Will San Francisco ban on facial recognition affect digital signage?Taco Bell claims Elevate Awards for interactive kiosksGet the latest news & insightsSubscribeLinkedIn Twitter Facebook RSSNewsComQi, AUO deliver all-in-one digital signageUpshow partners with Jukin Media for DOOH engagementInewvation deploys digital signage at Jewel Changi AirportMeridian awards recipients of 2019 scholarshipAtlona appoints Ewing-Foley to distribute products in Western US, AlaskaViewSonic intros 2 WUXGA laser projectorsAmazon, LG integrate Alexa into hotel TVsSee More \xc2\xbbResources[WEBINAR]: Critical considerations when transitioning from traditional to interactive digital signageINDOOR VS. Allow from \'Notifications\' permission to enable notifications.\nSelect Allow to enable notifications.\nLove Delhi news?\nStay updated with the latest happenings.\nYes, notify Me\nDelhi\n27 Jun 2018\nDelhi takes inspiration from NY: Advanced digital interactive panels installed\nWritten by\nPallabi Chatterjee\nHave you seen about the new panel-type kiosks at Connaught Place in Delhi? Been curious?\nWonder no more! The kiosk is an interactive panel installed by New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) under its Smart City project.\nEmulating New York\'s \'LinkNYC\', they have been designed to provide people wholesome information about the capital like government department sites, railways, airlines, maps, bus services and more.\nKnow about LinkNYC, NDMC\'s inspiration for the project\nLinkNYC kiosks were started in 2015, replacing the city\'s network of 9,000-13,000 payphones. As of July 2017, there are 920 Links citywide. Eventually, there will be 7,500 Links installed in the New York metropolitan area, making the system the world\'s fastest and most expansive.\nDetails\nPanels set up in CP\'s Palika Bazar and Charkha Museum\nCredits:\nThe 9ft high, 46-inch wide panel is not just an information-provider, it also includes a mobile charging point, sensor and camera along with free WiFi.\nFor earning revenue through the panel, NDMC has kept a 75-inch LED screen for advertisements.\nAs of now, two panels have been set up in Connaught Place, one at Palika Bazar and another near Charkha Museum.\nLove Delhi news?\nStay updated with the latest happenings.\nYes, notify Me\nNDMC speaks\n50 such panels being installed throughout Delhi, may be increased\nNDMC chairman Naresh Kumar said they have procured 50 such panels to be set up in Sansad Marg, Lodhi Colony, Khan Market, Sarojini Nagar, Mandi House, Bengali Market, India Gate and Gole Market.\n"In the second phase, if the project is successful and well received by the public, we might increase the number of panels from 50 to 75," added Kumar.\n\'Transaction facility will not be available as of now\'\n"We have selected locations with high footfall and market places where these panels will be installed. The transaction facility will not be available as of now due to security issues. We are exploring possibilities for improving the services provided by these panels," he said.\nShare this timeline\nDelhi\nMunicipal Corporation Of Delhi\nTourism\n9ft\nBengali Market\nCharkha Museum\nConnaught Place\nCP\nEmulating New York\nGole Market\nIndia Gate\nKhan Market\nLED\nLinkNYC\nLodhi Colony\nMandi House\nNaresh Kumar\nNDMC\nNew Delhi Municipal Council\nNew York\nPalika Bazar\nSansad Marg\nSarojini Nagar\nSmart City\nWiFi\nShare this timeline\nAskCancel\nRelated Timelines\nDelhi\nNo relief from cold as Delhi records minimum of 3.7C\nDelhi\nDelhi shivers at 3.6 degree Celsius, lowest temperature this season\nDelhi\nDelhi\'s minimum temperature dips to 4 degrees Celsius again\nNext Timeline\nLink copied to clipboard', b'How strategic public-private partnerships are shaping up in cities | GreenBiz\nHome\nMain menuInsights\nEvents\nVideos\nSecondary menuCircular Economy\nEnergy\nTransportation\nSustainability\nSupply Chain\nCities\nBuildings\nWater\nGreenbiz on Social Media\nTwitter\nFacebook\nGoogle+\nLinkedIn\nThis site (RSS)\nSearch\nSearch\nToggle navigation\nHow strategic public-private partnerships are shaping up in citiesSue LebeckTuesday, June 26, 2018 - 1:30am\nShutterstocknaKornCreate\nThis is second in a series on the role of public-private partnerships in realizing smart, sustainable cities, systems and industries.Public-private partnerships (PPPs) fall into four key types: operating partnerships; advisory committees; project partnerships; and strategic partnerships. Of these, the most potent and long-ranging partnerships are strategic. Although they may begin with a single project, they ultimately provide a platform capable of generating new projects with the potential to achieve far-reaching impacts over time.This article describes the high-level shaping of strategic partnerships in cities \xe2\x80\x94 reviewing the organizing approaches of several successful strategic platforms, and pointing to the first key partners to turn to.Organizing models for strategic partnershipStrategic approaches to PPP development typically require the creation of a partnership organization. The platform that results effectively can become a PPP-generating machine.Envision Charlotte\xe2\x80\x99s public-private-plus collaborative formed a nonprofit organization to anchor its efforts. "We created a neutral platform to allow us to structure a win-win for everyone," executive director Amy Aussieker explained. It also offers protection. Since its founding in 2010, Charlotte has had six mayors, although this organization has persisted across mayors and even private-sector CEOs. "Though this was not the reason for forming a nonprofit, in hindsight it was a benefit," she said.\nUtilities are natural partners to cities.\nThe first-of-its-kind PPP platform for Smart City development, Envision Charlotte has become a model for others. Its first partners included local utility Duke Energy, technology company Cisco Systems and Charlotte Center City, a nonprofit that promotes the development of Charlotte\xe2\x80\x99s urban core. In its mission to improve sustainability around energy, air, water and waste, it gathered additional partners, including local banks and other businesses, technology and services company Itron, engineering firm CH2M Hill, network provider Verizon, waste-management specialist Enevo and the University of North Carolina-Charlotte. Most recently, it created a citizen-focused ECO Network to extend its sustainability goals deeper into the community.Indeed, citizen engagement is a secret sauce to help smart city evolution perform for all stakeholders.An organizing approach developed by Envision Utah has been replicated by dozens of regions around the United States. Envision Utah is a nonprofit public-private partnership that engages community stakeholders from a statewide umbrella, whose goal is "empowering people to create the communities they want." It acts as a neutral facilitator, bringing together residents, elected officials, developers, conservationists, business leaders and other interested parties to make informed decisions about how Utah should grow.This has resulted in a Quality Growth Strategy and a growth-planning toolkit designed for use by civic leaders, businesses and the public at large. These tools can be used to inform an implementation pathway for a range of multi-player partnerships.More recently, the KCMO Smart City initiative in Kansas City, Missouri, is testing a novel model for organizing a PPP: to procure a private-sector partner to join them and lead the effort. After building out an initial smart-city platform along a free downtown streetcar line (via initial PPP activity involving Cisco, Sprint and Think Big Partners), it is fielding a Request for Proposals (RFP) to recruit a lead PPP partner to expand its Smart City program.The prime partner is visualized as either a nonprofit consortium or a for-profit firm, which has demonstrated that it can build an extensive suite of capabilities and manage a partnership of public and private players, including community partners and stakeholders. This PPP-leading organization\xe2\x80\x99s scope will include the creation of new business models that can sustain the smart-city projects and sustain the PPP.Kansas City Chief Innovation Officer Bob Bennett explained: "KCMO has assets in play that we are bringing to the table: fiber and pre-coordinated access to assets. We will collaboratively build out the array of initiatives so that the city improves the lives of its people and our partner succeeds."A city\'s first partners: utilitiesSmart, sustainable cities depend on reliable and resilient energy systems. Jesse Berst, chairman of the Smart Cities Council, urges cities interested in starting a smart cities program to partner first with their local electric utility company. To that end, the council and the Edison Electric Institute formed a joint initiative, Electric Companies Advancing Cities; its task force is holding three city-utility summits in 2018, culminating with a playbook to capture best practices and case studies.\nCitizen engagement is a secret sauce to help smart city evolution perform for all stakeholders.\nAussieker of Envision Charlotte agrees that utilities are natural partners to cities. "Most cities have a public utility, which owns assets outside the city. So, if the city doesn\xe2\x80\x99t engage with that utility, how can you get to a sustainable [model]?" To illuminate the point: "Duke Energy [in Charlotte] owns the light poles while the city owns the right of way and leases the poles." In addition, "You need to partner with your utility to act on a goal of 100 percent renewable energy." Do you need to form a PPP for that? "No, but if you do you will be a lot more successful."Envision Utah is following precisely that path. Salt Lake City is in a region whose climate is warming more than twice as fast as the national average, negatively affecting water reserves and air quality. Led by the findings of Envision\xe2\x80\x99s Utah\xe2\x80\x99s citizen survey, the region is responding with urgency, and is partnering with its local utility Rocky Mountain Power. Envision has drafted a plan to acquire all the community\'s electricity from renewable sources by 2032, reducing emissions, saving water and improving air quality in the process.Communications network providers represent another potential utility partner with a natural role to play within smart cities. Partnership examples include communications projects such as New York City\xe2\x80\x99s street-facing LinkNYC, built in partnership with the CityBridge consortium (there\xe2\x80\x99s Google inside); and Huntsville, Alabama\xe2\x80\x99s unique network build-out partnership with Google Fiber. In contrast, Chattanooga\xe2\x80\x99s game-changing municipal Internet the Gig was built alone when incumbent private partners were not ready to step up their play.The lesson for utility providers: Don\xe2\x80\x99t play with the public sector at your own risk.The next article in this series will expand on the diverse roles to be played in a potent public-private partnership.Topics:\xc2\xa0Cities\nTags:\xc2\xa0partnerships\npublic-private partnerships\nPublic-Private Partnerships\nshare this article\nTwitter\nFacebook\nLinkedIn\nSue Lebeck\nApplication Manager\nCool City Challenge\nView the discussion thread.\nRelated Content\nToward a playbook for public-private partnershipsBySue Lebeck\nFrom Cape Town to Charlotte, there\'s a partner for every IndiaEnglish\xe0\xa4\xb9\xe0\xa4\xbf\xe0\xa4\xa8\xe0\xa5\x8d\xe0\xa4\xa6\xe0\xa5\x80\xe0\xa4\xae\xe0\xa4\xb0\xe0\xa4\xbe\xe0\xa4\xa0\xe0\xa5\x80\xe0\xa6\xac\xe0\xa6\xbe\xe0\xa6\x82\xe0\xa6\xb2\xe0\xa6\xbe \xe0\xaa\x97\xe0\xab\x81\xe0\xaa\x9c\xe0\xaa\xb0\xe0\xaa\xbe\xe0\xaa\xa4\xe0\xab\x80\xe0\xb2\x95\xe0\xb2\xa8\xe0\xb3\x8d\xe0\xb2\xa8\xe0\xb2\xa1\xe0\xae\xa4\xe0\xae\xae\xe0\xae\xbf\xe0\xae\xb4\xe0\xaf\x8d\xe0\xb0\xa4\xe0\xb1\x86\xe0\xb0\xb2\xe0\xb1\x81\xe0\xb0\x97\xe0\xb1\x81\xe0\xb4\xae\xe0\xb4\xb2\xe0\xb4\xaf\xe0\xb4\xbe\xe0\xb4\xb3\xe0\xb4\x82|Epaper|GadgetsNowTOITOICityWorldBusinessSportsEntertainmentTVLife
