Right now, it has the opportunity to become a national leader in fighting invasive government surveillance. Lawmakers need to hear from the people of Massachusetts to say they oppose government use of face surveillance. Face surveillance poses a threat to...\nDeeplinks Blog\nby Matthew Guariglia\n| June 18, 2019\nThe Lofgren-Amash Amendment Would Check Warrantless Surveillance\nThe NSA has used Section 702 of the FISA Amendments Act to justify collecting and storing millions of Americans\xe2\x80\x99 online communications. Now, the House of Representatives has a chance to pull the plug on funding for Section 702 unless the government agrees to limit the reach of that program...\nPress Release\n| June 12, 2019\nSocial Media Platforms Increase Transparency About Content Removal Requests, But Many Keep Users in the Dark When Their Speech Is Censored, EFF Report Shows\nSan Francisco and Tunis, Tunisia\xe2\x80\x94While social media platforms are increasingly giving users the opportunity to appeal decisions to censor their posts, very few platforms comprehensively commit to notifying users that their content has been removed in the first place, raising questions about their accountability and transparency, the Electronic...\nPress Release\n| June 10, 2019\nHearing Tuesday: EFF Will Voice Support For California Bill Reining In Law Enforcement Use of Facial Recognition\nSacramento, California\xe2\x80\x94On Tuesday, June 11, at 8:30 am, EFF Grassroots Advocacy Organizer Nathan Sheard will testify before the California Senate Public Safety Committee in support of a measure to prohibit law enforcement from using facial recognition in body cams.Following San Francisco\xe2\x80\x99s historic ban on police use of the...\nDeeplinks Blog\nby Alan Toner\n| June 3, 2019\nResearch Shows Publishers Benefit Little From Tracking Ads\nAdvertising industry lobbyists have long argued that tracking users is necessary to power a publishing industry that makes its content available to users for \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 despite a heavy privacy cost. Right now, a majority of publishers make money by working with advertisers that collect personal information about users as they...\nDeeplinks Blog\nby India McKinney\n| May 23, 2019\nDigital Advertising, Consumer Privacy and More\nDigital ads\xe2\x80\x94and control of the user data that makes them so profitable\xe2\x80\x94are the heart of the consumer privacy debate. Earlier this week, the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee held a hearing titled \xe2\x80\x9cUnderstanding the Digital Advertising Ecosystem and the Impact of Data Privacy and Competition Policy\xe2\x80\x9d to grapple with these...\nDeeplinks Blog\nby David Greene, Karen Gullo\n| May 17, 2019\nEFF Files Freedom of Information (FOIA) Request for Submissions to the White House\xe2\x80\x99s Platform Moderation Tool\nWhen social media platforms enforce their content moderation rules unfairly, it affects everyone\xe2\x80\x99s ability to speak out online. Unfair and inconsistent online censorship magnifies existing power imbalances, giving people who already have the least power in society fewer places where they are allowed a voice online.President Donald Trump...\nDeeplinks Blog\nby Dave Maass\n| May 17, 2019\nCalifornia Now Classifies Immigration Enforcement as \xe2\x80\x9cMisuse\xe2\x80\x9d of Statewide Law Enforcement Network\nIt has taken more than a year, but the California Attorney General\xe2\x80\x99s Office has implemented steps to protect immigrants from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and other agencies that abuse the state\xe2\x80\x99s public safety network, the California Law Enforcement Telecommunications System (CLETS). Following calls for reform from EFF and...\nDeeplinks Blog\nby India McKinney, Gennie Gebhart\n| May 8, 2019\nConsumer Data Privacy Advocates to Senate Committee: Here's How to Protect Consumers\nLast week, the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science & Transportation held a hearing on Consumer Perspectives: Policy Principles for a Federal Data Privacy Framework. Unlike previous hearings this year that only featured tech industry panelists, this hearing featured a panel of consumer privacy advocates, including: Helen...\nDeeplinks Blog\nby Jason Kelley\n| May 8, 2019\nShareholders Demand To Know How Northrop Grumman Will Protect Human Rights While Building Massive DHS Database\nOver the next few years, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) plans to implement an enormous biometric collection program which will endanger the rights of citizens and foreigners alike. The agency intends to collect at least seven types of biometric identifiers, including face and voice data, DNA, scars, and tattoos...\nJoin Our Newsletter!\nEmail updates on news, actions, events in your area, and more.\nEmail Address\nPostal Code (optional)\nDon't fill out this field (required)\nThanks, you're awesome! Please check your email for a confirmation link.\nOops something is broken right now, please try again later.\nShare It\nShare on Twitter\nShare on Facebook\nCopy link\nRelated IssuesPrivacyElectronic Frontier AllianceStreet-Level Surveillance\nBack to top\nFollow EFF:\ntwitter\nfacebook\ninstagram\nyoutube\nflicker\nrss\nContact\nGeneral\nLegal\nSecurity\nMembership\nPress\nAbout\nCalendar\nVolunteer\nVictories\nHistory\nInternships\nJobs\nStaff\nIssues\nFree Speech\nPrivacy\nCreativity & Innovation\nTransparency\nInternational\nSecurity\nUpdates\nBlog\nEvents\nPress Releases\nWhitepapers\nPress\nPress Contact\nDonate\nJoin or Renew Membership Online\nOne-Time Donation Online\nShop\nOther Ways to Give\nCopyright (CC BY)\nTrademark\nPrivacy Policy\nThanks\nJavaScript license information", b'10 times fiction predicted smart city advancements\n| Smart Cities Dive\nCONTINUE TO SITE \xe2\x9e\x9e\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nEnergy & Utilities\nTransportation\nBuildings & Infrastructure\nEnvironment\nResilience\nGovernance\nTech & Data\nAn article from\n10 times fiction predicted smart city advancements\nFrom data analytics to hyperloop and cutting-edge transportation methods, many smart city concepts aren\'t entirely original ideas.\nAuthor\nBy\nKatie Pyzyk\n@_PyintheSky\nPublished\nJuly 10, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nSmart city technologies might seem futuristic and exciting, but they\'re often part of the age-old chicken-and-egg argument of life imitating art, or vice versa. A number of the much-hyped current technologies made appearances in fiction \xe2\x80\x94 often science fiction \xe2\x80\x94 before their real-life debuts in smart cities.\nSmart Cities Dive has compiled a list of 10 times fiction predicted smart city advances. These examples might not be the very first known mentions of such technologies in all cases, but they are among the most prominent references.\n"Wandl the Invader" (book, 1939) \xe2\x80\x94 Predicted: Hyperloop transportation\nInnovative transportation is a frequently addressed theme in science fiction, especially considering how often the stories involve space travel. This book by Ray Cummings envisioned high-speed transportation in vacuum cylinders,\xc2\xa0\xc3\xa0 la pneumatic mail tubes.\nThis is a rudimentary example of the hyperloop, Elon Musk\'s concept for underground pod transportation inside a partial vacuum tube system. Although hyperloop has yet to officially come to fruition, preliminary construction on testing facilities has launched in France, joining those in Nevada and California. Hyperloop designs even mimic the book\'s idea of only having a few people travel in each small pod, as opposed to running an entire train through the vacuum tube system at once.\n"1984" (book, 1949) \xe2\x80\x94 Predicted: video surveillance, data collection/analytics\nElements of the dystopian novel\'s language \xe2\x80\x94 such as "Big Brother" \xe2\x80\x94 have been well integrated into modern society\'s vernacular. Although it depicts negative elements of technology, it nonetheless proved visionary in predicting future technology and related practices.\nGeorge Orwell\'s characters were monitored by "telescreens" both at home and in public that transmitted sound and video to Big Brother. Similarly, modern cities use public video surveillance for numerous purposes, including law enforcement, emergency responses and optimizing traffic flow. But cities also must strike a balance between beneficial surveillance and invading residents\' privacy, as highlighted in the book. Oakland, CA is among the municipalities moving forward with strict regulations\xc2\xa0governing the city\'s use of surveillance technology.\nThe book also delved into data collection and a primitive form of data analytics, in that residents\' personal information constantly was collected and analyzed for compliance. Those who weren\'t in compliance with the rules were punished. Interestingly, many people drew parallels between the book\'s data collection methods and the controversy surrounding the National Security Agency (NSA) when it was exposed as collecting information from U.S. citizens\' emails and phone calls; sales of 1984 spiked in 2013 during the NSA dustup.\n"Stand on Zanzibar"(book, 1969) \xe2\x80\x94 Predicted: electric cars\nThe main theme in John Brunner\'s book is that the world\'s population is growing rapidly and overpopulation brings negative consequences, some of which the book aims to predict. Notably, modern municipal leaders and planners work to avoid some of the named consequences, such as widening social divides, to prevent their city\'s de-stabilization.\nThe book envisions a world where people increasingly travel in cars powered by rechargeable electric fuel cells. Although widespread use of electric vehicles (EVs) has had several stops and starts in the United States over the past 20 years, it\'s really picking up steam now.\nSome examples include GM promising to release more EV models, Atlanta passing legislation requiring EV charging infrastructure in new buildings,\xc2\xa0the Department of Energy is funding fast EV charging research\xc2\xa0and a plethora of cities adding both public charging stations and electric battery-fueled public transportation. One main difference is that real-life EV acceptance is a bit behind the book, which was set in 2010.\n"Knight Rider" (TV show, 1982) \xe2\x80\x94 Predicted: artificial intelligence, autonomous vehicles\nThe 1980s were chock full of attention to Trans Ams, but KITT was the most coveted by people young and old. The vehicle used artificial intelligence to communicate verbally with its owner, Michael Knight. That was revolutionary considering how few cars at the time had onboard computer systems, which are standard in modern vehicles.\nKITT not only communicated with Michael, but also with its surroundings. It could operate its own systems and override human operations to become a fully autonomous vehicle. KITT\'s functions resemble in many ways the modern autonomous vehicles (AVs) being tested around the world and how they communicate with their surroundings via sensors to influence operations. However, thus far the artificial intelligence is not advanced enough to carry on full conversations with humans.\n"WarGames" (movie, 1983) \xe2\x80\x94 Predicted: cybersecurity, hacking\nNearly a decade before most people had even heard of the internet, much less used it, "War Games" exposed the dangers of a connected world, specifically that one small technical misunderstanding nearly caused a global nuclear war.\nThe main character is a hacker, which is a commonly used term today, but 35 years ago the concept was largely unknown.\xc2\xa0The movie offered,\xc2\xa0debatably, the first ever mainstream reference to the term "firewall." Although watching the movie now uncovers some discrepancies in how connectivity and hacking actually work, it did illustrate the need for cybersecurity, especially for government systems.\n"Neuromancer" (book, 1984) \xe2\x80\x94 Predicted: cyberspace, hacking\nWilliam Gibson\'s book published shortly after "War Games" was released and included a common theme: The main character, Case, is a hacker. Two years prior, Gibson released a short story that is credited as the first to coin the term "cyberspace," which he folded into Neuromancer. The novel also introduced the concept of virtual reality headsets, and artificial intelligence takes center stage throughout.\nThe internet and connectivity serve as the backbone for nearly all smart city technology, and protecting against hackers who could disrupt the entire system therefore is essential. Cities are starting to look at new, more secure developments such as blockchain-based cybersecurity to avoid large-scale hacks like the one that brought Atlanta\'s system to its proverbial knees.\n"Back to the Future Part II" (movie, 1989) \xe2\x80\x94 Predicted: Drones\nThis movie introduced a slew of iconic technologies, some of which worked out while others remain just ideas. Drones are the technology most pertinent to the smart cities space. During the portions of the movie set in the future \xe2\x80\x94 in 2015 \xe2\x80\x94 news organizations use photo- and video-capturing drones called "hovercams"\xc2\xa0to report on events and transmit live news feeds.\nBy the time 2015 rolled around in reality, drones were all the rage as a hot, new tech item. Their use expands constantly and they\'re currently employed in a variety of smart city applications including inspecting\xc2\xa0infrastructure, detecting gun shots, chasing criminals\xc2\xa0and assessing traffic accidents.\n"Total Recall" (movie, 1990)\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Predicted: artificial intelligence, autonomous taxis\nSimilar to "Knight Rider," "Total Recall" features an autonomous vehicle (AV) that communicates with human passengers. Granted, the communication with Johnny Cab, the oft-maligned and "disturbing" humanoid robot that operates the car, is far less smooth than with KITT and creates frustration.\nTotal Recall advances the AV concept and makes it applicable to areas other than just personal vehicles. A number of companies like Nissan and GM are testing autonomous taxis\xc2\xa0and AV ride-sharing services, and cities including Houston, TX and Columbus, OH\xc2\xa0recently launched pilot programs to test AV shuttles as a greater mobility option.\n"The Fifth Element"\xc2\xa0(movie, 1997)\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Predicted:\xc2\xa03D printing\nScientists in the movie use a high-tech 3D printer to construct Leeloo\'s body piece-by-piece from the inside out using recovered DNA.\n3D printers were beginning to emerge in niche markets during the 1990s, but the early models were a far cry from today\'s advanced machinery. Although real-life 3D printers thus far have not advanced to the point of creating entire living beings like in "The Fifth Element," they hold promise for constructing cities\' infrastructure including bridges, bus stops, offices and homes.\n"Minority Report" (movie, 2002)\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Predicted: predictive analytics, targeted advertising\nThe movie featured numerous futuristic technologies, but one that particularly gained notoriety for being simultaneously creepy and fascinating is the targeted advertising. Characters\' retinas are scanned when they pass billboards and various kiosks and then the technology caters the ads to each person and addresses them by name.\nMore cities are installing interactive kiosks that offer Wi-Fi and a variety of information, like maps,\xc2\xa0that could be helpful to passersby. Different cities fund the devices and their operations in different ways, and New York\'s much-celebrated LinkNYC\xc2\xa0kiosks are among those funded through advertising. But as the kiosks interact with people\'s mobile devices they also collect information, including IP addresses and mobile device type, and use the collected, anonymized\xc2\xa0data to influence advertising on the kiosks. This is similar to the technique in the "Minority Report," except that the real-life kiosks scan a person\'s phone instead of their retinas.\nFollow\nKatie Pyzyk\non\nTwitter\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nEnergy & Utilities\nTransportation\nTech & Data\nTop image credit:\nAdobe Stock\nGet smart cities news like this in your inbox daily. Please try again later.", b"Discover NYC's Never Built Architecture on the LinkNYC Kiosks | Untapped Cities\nTOURS\nPUBLIC TOURS\nPRIVATE TOURS\nINSIDERS EVENTS\nGIFT CARDS\nINSIDERS\nINSIDERS EVENTS\nBECOME AN INSIDER\nINSIDERS LOGIN\nINSIDERS ACCOUNT\nSECRETS OF NYC\nTHINGS TO DO\nTHINGS TO DO IN NYC\nNYC GETAWAYS\nTOPICS\nBEHIND THE SCENES\nARCHITECTURE\nARTS & CULTURE\nTRANSIT\nDiscover NYC\xe2\x80\x99s Never Built Architecture on the LinkNYC Kiosks\nGabrielle Showalter\n07/13/2018\nArchitecture, New York, News\nPhoto courtesy LinkNYC\nEver wondered about the New York architecture that almost was?\xc2\xa0LinkNYC, the network of kiosks around the city that supplies free wifi, free phone calls, and fun facts about the city to passerby will also be showcasing the would-be architectural endeavors that New York never built.\nLinkNYC is collaborating with authors Greg Goldin and Sam Lubell of the 2016 book\xc2\xa0Never Built New York, as well as their publisher, Metropolis Books, to highlight key architectural structures that almost became a part of the cityscape we know and love. Numerous plans were also previous featured in our column The NYC That Never Was.\nImages\xc2\xa0courtesy LinkNYC\nInformation about the structures are playing nearby to their would-be locations; for instance, the proposed 1955 Dodgers Baseball Stadium in Brooklyn, as well as the proposed 1968 Habitat housing on what is now FDR Drive.\xc2\xa0Other structures include an alternate Metropolitan Life Building (1929), ABC Office and Studio Building (1963), a completely different Museum of Modern Art (1930), a Mid-Manhattan Expressway planned by Robert Moses (1941), the Hyperboloid tower that would have replaced Grand Central (1954), as well as a $3 billion Rooftop Airport (1945)\nImages\xc2\xa0courtesy LinkNYC\nAlso check out 54 NYC Fun Facts from the LinkNYC Kiosks, a piece we did in partnership with LinkNYC! Want to learn more about the architectural \xe2\x80\x9calmosts\xe2\x80\x9d of New York? Head over to our old NYC That Never Was column to learn more.\nLinkNYC, NYC That Never Was\nRead More\nThe NYC That Never Was: 10 Outrageous Architectural Plans that Never Left the Drawing Board\n01/23/2018\n10 of NYC\xe2\x80\x99s Never Built Buildings in Downtown Manhattan\n11/01/2017\nNever Built New York: The Queens Museum Visualizes the NYC That Could Have Been\n09/19/2017\nLeave a Reply\nCancel reply\nYour email address will not be published. LinkNYC, the Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications, AN contributor Sam Lubell, writer\xc2\xa0Greg Goldin, and publisher Metropolis Books have teamed up to bring images from Never Built New York to the city\xe2\x80\x99 streets via LinkNYC kiosks.\nThe display of unbuilt megaprojects from some of the biggest names in architecture follows the release of the Never Built New York book in 2016, and the accompanying show at the Queens Museum last fall. The kiosks won\xe2\x80\x99t display the full array of weird and wild never-realized projects, but the curated images will still depict how New York could have grown into a very different city.\nA kiosk display of Howe & Lescaze\xe2\x80\x99s unbuilt Museum of Modern Art. (Courtesy LinkNYC)\nSome of the work on display includes I.M. Pei\xe2\x80\x99s proposal for the Hyperboloid, a 102-story tower proposed in 1954 that would have replaced Grand Central, and Robert Moses\xe2\x80\x99s heavily contested Mid-Manhattan Expressway. Images of the Dodger Dome, an enclosed stadium designed by Buckminster Fuller meant to keep the Dodgers in Brooklyn, and Moshe Safdie\xe2\x80\x99s tessellating Habitat New York (originally slated for the Upper East Side) have also been selected. LinkNYC will display images of each project on kiosks close to the location where they would have risen.\nA kiosk display of William Zeckendorf\xe2\x80\x99s 67-block-long Dream Airport, which would have floated in the Hudson River. (Courtesy LinkNYC)\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s 1,650 kiosks can be found all over the city following the program\xe2\x80\x99s launch in 2016. The Never Built New York\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x98exhibition\xe2\x80\x99 follows a June show that presented historical New York City photos from the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s ongoing Through a Different Lens: Stanley Kubrick Photographs exhibition.\nAbout the author\nJonathan Hilburg\n(@jhilburg)\nWeb Editor, The Architect's Newspaper\nBuckminster Fuller\nI.M. Pei\nLinkNYC\nMoshe Safdie\nNew York City\nRelated Stories\nJune 17, 2019\nColor Blind\nPlaywright Oren Safdie takes on racial tensions of national architecture\nJune 10, 2019\nSchool's In?\nFormer I.M. The other man and woman were innocent pursuers.\nThe woman had just left a work interview while the 31\n-year-old man just walked down the street with a colleague when the bullets rang out, Deputy Chief Michael Kemper\nStreet Sellers Anthony Nickns, 58, who witnessed the sidewalk shot, said that a woman "hit a man in the face" and he pulled out a gun and started firing. "\n" When she turned him, he hit the gun and started firing, "Nickns said, adding that he heard The woman shouts "did you know" before she encountered\nPaul Martinka\nAnother witness Darius Word, 44, said he stood at the corner of Fulton Street and Lawrence Street when bullets began to fly.\n"There were two girls arguing and then the guys came into it," said Word. "A guy was wearing red shorts you could say he had something he had his hand on his pocket."\n"When I looked over Here at Gap I saw a guy on the floor, "Word said.\nDuring the chaos, Word said he" froze "but that" everyone ran around me. Based off the 2016 book\xc2\xa0Never Built New York, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x94which supplies the city with free wifi\xe2\x80\x94is collaborating with curators and authors Greg Goldin and Sam Lubell to highlight some of the fantastical structures that appeared in their book, and almost graced the city\'s famous skyline.\nWhile never actualized, many of these unbuilt plans for towers, bridges and parks, hold a unique place within architectural history and its collective imagination. Memorable proposals such as Moshe Safdie\'s \'Habitat New York\', Robert Moses\' Mid-Manhattan Expressway, and I.M Pei\'s \'Hyperbloid\', are some of the works that will be on display. Placed on kiosks near the location they would have risen, the posters show what could\'ve been, reminding passersby it\'s okay to dream.\nSimilar articles on Archinect that may interest you...\n"Show audiences that it\'s okay to dream" by Kickstarting Never Built New York\nOne-to-One #45 with \'Never Built New York\' authors Greg Goldin and Sam Lubell\n"Never Built New York" catalogues alternative visions of the City\n"Unbuilt SF" showcases past and future Bay Area architecture projects\nBack to Never Land: Chicago exhibition honors remarkable never-builts\nThe NYC that could have been \xe2\x80\x93 \'Never Built New York\' to be released this fall\nTagged\nnever built new yorknever builtnew yorklinknyc\nBack to Top \xc2\xa0\xe2\x86\x91\n1 Comment\nChemex\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tHistory\xc2\xa0\xc2\xb7\xc2\xa0Contact\nI\xc2\xa0saw this today and it switched before I could read it. \xeb\xb3\xb8\xea\xb2\xa9\xed\x99\x94\n[\xed\x98\x84\xec\x9e\xa5]\xeb\x94\x94\xec\xa7\x80\xed\x84\xb8 \xec\xa0\x84\xed\x99\x98 \xec\xb5\x9c\xeb\x8c\x80 \xeb\xac\xb8\xec\xa0\x9c\xeb\x8a\x94 \xe2\x80\x98\xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb3\xb5\xec\x9c\xa0 \xeb\xb6\x80\xec\x9e\xac\xe2\x80\x99\n\xec\x88\x98\xeb\x8f\x84\xea\xb6\x8c \xec\xb2\xab \xe2\x80\x98\xea\xb0\x95\xec\x86\x8c\xec\x97\xb0\xea\xb5\xac\xea\xb0\x9c\xeb\xb0\x9c\xed\x8a\xb9\xea\xb5\xac\xe2\x80\x99\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x95\x88\xec\x82\xb0 \xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa0\x95\n[\xed\x98\x84\xec\x9e\xa5]\xea\xb8\xb0\xec\x97\x85\xec\x9a\xa9 \xec\x97\xa3\xec\xa7\x80 \xed\x98\x81\xec\x8b\xa0 \xec\x86\x94\xeb\xa3\xa8\xec\x85\x98 \xec\x84\xa0\xeb\xb4\xac\n\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x82\xac\xec\x86\x8c\xea\xb0\x9c\n\xea\xb8\xb0\xec\x82\xac\xec\xa0\x9c\xeb\xb3\xb4\n\xea\xb4\x91\xea\xb3\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x9d\x98\n\xeb\xb6\x88\xed\x8e\xb8\xec\x8b\xa0\xea\xb3\xa0\n\xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9d\xb8\xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\xb7\xa8\xea\xb8\x89\xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\xb9\xa8\n\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x86\x8c\xeb\x85\x84\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x98\xb8\xec\xa0\x95\xec\xb1\x85\n\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x9d\xbc\xeb\xac\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa8\xec\x88\x98\xec\xa7\x91\xea\xb1\xb0\xeb\xb6\x80\nRSS\n\xec\x84\x9c\xec\x9a\xb8\xed\x8a\xb9\xeb\xb3\x84\xec\x8b\x9c \xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x82\xb0\xea\xb5\xac \xed\x95\x9c\xea\xb0\x95\xeb\x8c\x80\xeb\xa1\x9c 308 (\xed\x95\x9c\xea\xb5\xad\xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x86\xb5\xec\x8b\xa0\xea\xb3\xb5\xec\x82\xac\xed\x98\x91\xed\x9a\x8c) \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x86\xb5\xec\x8b\xa0\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x82\xac\n\xeb\x8c\x80\xed\x91\x9c\xec\xa0\x84\xed\x99\x94 : 02-597-8140\n\xed\x8c\xa9\xec\x8a\xa4 : 02-597-8223\n[\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\x84\xb7 \xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8 \xeb\x93\xb1\xeb\xa1\x9d \xec\x82\xac\xed\x95\xad] \xeb\xaa\x85\xec\xb9\xad : \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x86\xb5\xec\x8b\xa0\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8\n\xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x98\xb8 : \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x86\xb5\xec\x8b\xa0\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8\n\xeb\x93\xb1\xeb\xa1\x9d\xeb\xb2\x88\xed\x98\xb8 : \xec\x84\x9c\xec\x9a\xb8 \xec\x95\x8404447\n\xeb\x93\xb1\xeb\xa1\x9d\xec\x9d\xbc : 2017-04-06\n\xeb\xb0\x9c\xed\x96\x89\xec\x9d\xbc : 2019-06-21\n\xeb\xb0\x9c\xed\x96\x89\xc2\xb7\xed\x8e\xb8\xec\xa7\x91\xec\x9d\xb8 : \xec\x9e\xa5\xec\x8a\xb9\xec\x9d\xb5\n\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x86\x8c\xeb\x85\x84\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x98\xb8\xec\xb1\x85\xec\x9e\x84\xec\x9e\x90 : \xeb\xac\xb8\xeb\xb3\x91\xeb\x82\xa8\n\xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x86\xb5\xec\x8b\xa0\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xec\xbd\x98\xed\x85\x90\xec\xb8\xa0(\xec\x98\x81\xec\x83\x81,\xea\xb8\xb0\xec\x82\xac, \xec\x82\xac\xec\xa7\x84)\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xa0\x80\xec\x9e\x91\xea\xb6\x8c\xeb\xb2\x95\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x98\xb8\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\xb0\x9b\xec\x9d\x80\xeb\xb0\x94, \xeb\xac\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa8 \xec\xa0\x84\xec\x9e\xac\xec\x99\x80 \xeb\xb3\xb5\xec\x82\xac, \xeb\xb0\xb0\xed\x8f\xac \xeb\x93\xb1\xec\x9d\x84 \xea\xb8\x88\xed\x95\xa9\xeb\x8b\x88\xeb\x8b\xa4.\n[\xed\x8a\xb9\xec\x88\x98\xec\xa3\xbc\xea\xb0\x84\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8 \xeb\x93\xb1\xeb\xa1\x9d\xec\x82\xac\xed\x95\xad] \xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x98\xb8 : \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x86\xb5\xec\x8b\xa0\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8\n\xeb\x93\xb1\xeb\xa1\x9d\xeb\xb2\x88\xed\x98\xb8 : \xec\x84\x9c\xec\x9a\xb8,. \xeb\x8b\xa406783\n\xeb\x93\xb1\xeb\xa1\x9d\xec\x9d\xbc : 2000\xeb\x85\x84 12\xec\x9b\x94 06\xec\x9d\xbc\nCopyright \xc2\xa9 2011-2019 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x86\xb5\xec\x8b\xa0\xec\x8b\xa0\xeb\xac\xb8. All rights reserved. mail to webmaster@koit.co.kr\n\xec\x9c\x84\xeb\xa1\x9c', b'How LinkNYC kiosks improve the quality of life in the Big Apple | Kiosk MarketplaceTest LinkCONTINUE TO SITE \xc2\xbb or wait 15 seconds\xc3\x97Toggle navigation\nTOPICS ATM Installation / DeploymentBill Payment KiosksCannabis KiosksCustomer ExperienceCustom KiosksDigital SignageDisplay TechnologyDVD KiosksEmployee Self-ServiceEV Charging KiosksFull Service / Turnkey ProviderGovernmentHardwareHealthcare / HospitalsHotelsICX SummitInteractive / TouchscreenKiosk BrandingKiosk DesignKiosk EnclosuresKiosk PrintersManufacturersNetworking / ConnectivityOutdoor KiosksPhoto KiosksRepair / ServiceRestaurantsRetailSelf-CheckoutSoftwareTransportation / TravelTrends / StatisticsVending KiosksWayfinding / InformationView all Topic Centers \xc2\xbbSUPPLIERS Companies by NameCompanies by CategoryProducts & ServicesRequest Information from SuppliersPROJECT HELPRESOURCESNEWSWEBINARSEVENTS View Industry Event Calendar >>MORE VideosWebinarsEventsPodcastsPhotosArticlesVideosBlogsPress ReleasesJob ListingsMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggers\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nHow LinkNYC kiosks improve the quality of life in the Big AppleJuly 18, 2018 | by Bradley CooperPhoto courtesy of Link.Editor\'s Note: An earlier version of this story ran on Digital Signage Today, a sister publication of Kiosk Marketplace.Ruth Fasoltd cites numerous benefits that the LinkNYC kiosks have provided New Yorkers.In 2016, New York City went through a major smart city upgrade, as Intersection deployed multiple Link kiosks. The city replaced older phone booths with these kiosks, which offer free Wi-Fi to the public, as well as advertising and wayfinding.The kiosks also allow customers to make free nationwide calls\xc2\xa0or report emergencies. There are now more than 1,600 kiosks in all five boroughs of the city. Digital Signage Today spoke with Ruth Fasoldt, director of community affairs for Link, to see how these devices are transforming the city and improving lives.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0What are the main features the kiosks offer?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\'s payphones to build the world\'s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,600 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next several years.In addition to free Wi-Fi, Links offer free nationwide phone calls, a dedicated 911 button, device charging, and a tablet to access maps and city services. Link\'s services come at no cost to users or taxpayers because Link generates its own revenue through advertising on the 55-inch digital displays on the sides of kiosks.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0How do they improve the lives of residents?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC provides so many benefits to New Yorkers and visitors. More than 4 million people \xe2\x80\x94 more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Phoenix, Philadelphia, Dallas\xc2\xa0or San Diego \xe2\x80\x94 have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of users joining the network each week. The network also sees more than 250,000 free phone calls made every month. Using the tablet, people can access maps and directions on the go.Along with ads that keep LinkNYC\'s services 100 percent free for users and taxpayers, the digital displays feature useful and enriching content, including community board meeting updates, real-time transit and weather information so people can make more informed decisions about their day on the go, PSAs, fun facts about NYC, historic photos\xc2\xa0and more. The screens are also used for emergency messaging, for instance, in an extreme weather event. We see tweets and Instagram posts all the time of people capturing our content and sharing it with others.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0How does LinkNYC deal with issues such as people loitering by the kiosks or watching inappropriate content in public?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0Back in 2016, there was an issue with some kiosks having long-term users. The LinkNYC tablet is meant to be an on-the-go resource, so the web browser was removed from Link tablets in September 2016, in exchange for curated content on the tablet, and loitering complaints dropped 96 percent immediately.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0What type of ads do the kiosks display?Fasoldt:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC has a very high caliber of advertisers across categories \xe2\x80\x94 from Samsung to Delta to The Gap and The Met.Utilizing DOOH\xc2\xa0to its fullest and breaking from the norm of basic, static ads, Link kiosks offer the ability for advertisers to display unique, dynamic ads. From weather and transit, to sporting events, movie times and more, Link ads can change based on real-time information and updates, keeping advertisements relevant and consumers engaged.During the 2018 Winter Olympics in PeyongChang, for example, NBC partnered with Intersection to display Olympics content and coverage on LinkNYC screens, highlights, prime time previews, real-time medal counts, athlete bios and more. This digital OOH content campaign was the first of its kind for the U.S. Olympics broadcaster.More recently, Intersection pioneered another first-of-its-kind campaign, partnering with Disney and Marvel to promote "The Avengers: Infinity War." On the movie\'s launch weekend, LinkNYC screens displayed ads for the blockbuster, as well as the closest theater location to each kiosk and the next show time, so that passersby, if inspired by the ad, could easily catch the next showing.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0Do the kiosks use any analytics?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0We have stats on usership, how often different services are used, the busiest Links and more. We have also made strategic use of our network capabilities like dayparting (for example, we increase transit info on our displays during peak commuting hours), geotargeting (playing historical photos in their place of original capture), and network flexibility (during Women\'s History month, we displayed facts about women\'s suffrage along the route of the women\'s march).Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0Do you think smart cities will start to pop up everywhere? Why?Fastold:\xc2\xa0Cities around the world are looking for ways to better deliver services to residents and visitors, increase broadband connectivity, and adapt to the needs of the digital age. Many are looking to New York and LinkNYC in particular as a model. In addition to New York, a Link network is live in the U.K.\xc2\xa0We have planned expansions into Philadelphia and Newark, with many more cities on the way.Topics: Customer Experience, Government, Interactive / Touchscreen, Outdoor Kiosks, Software, Wayfinding / Information Bradley CooperBradley Cooper is a Technology Editor for DigitalSignageToday.com and BlockchainTechNews.com. His background is in information technology, advertising, and writing. wwwFollow @DigSignageTodaySponsored Links:Related ContentKiosk Marketplace editor reviews 39 kiosk companies at National Restaurant ShowCustomers adapting to kiosks, but acceptance not uniform in all scenariosTaco Bell to install self-order kiosks in all stores in 2019 under its All Access initiativeSquare integration with Kiosk Pro app enables self-service for iPadsLatest ContentState-of-the-art testing: the first line of defense against fraudstersTexas Dairy Queen franchisee pioneers self-order kioskCashierless stores? All rights reserved.Visit Other Networld Media Group Sites:Select a siteATM MarketplaceBlockchain Tech NewsDigital Signage TodayFastCasualFood Truck OperatorKiosk MarketplaceMobile Payments TodayPizza MarketplaceQSRwebRetail Customer ExperienceWorld of MoneyBank Customer Experience (BCX) SummitCONNECT Mobile Innovation SummitFast Casual Executive SummitInteractive Customer Experience (ICX) SummitRestaurant Franchising & Innovation Summit', b'The MTA Website Leaks Private User Data Due to Basic Technical Flaw | The Indypendent\nThe Indypendent\nClose\nSearch\nNew York\nSpecial Coverage: Who Will Be Queens\xe2\x80\x99 Next DA?\nNational\nVideo\nSubscribe\nAbout Us\nIssue Archive\nDonate\nAdvertise\nDistribution\nGet Involved\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nMenu\nA Free Paper for Free People\nThe MTA Website Leaks Private User Data Due to Basic Technical Flaw\nNew York\nPhoto credit: Jens Schott Knudsen.\nFor years passwords, sexual harassment complaints and other sensitive information have been available to third parties on the internet. This article has been updated for our August print edition to reflect new developments. It was originally published on July 18 .\nJohn Bolger Jul 18, 2018\nIssue 238\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s no secret that the MTA website is as decrepit as the signals directing it\xe2\x80\x99s trains. But then again, the MTA website is not very good at keeping secrets. If you have used TripPlanner, Subway Times or Bus Times, customer service, filed a FOIL request or a sexual harassment complaint, if you have submitted personal information through any of these MTA web portals, your data \xe2\x80\x94 such as name, email address, username, password, postal address, phone number, photo uploads, text entries and travel details \xe2\x80\x94 has been exposed to countless third-parties, for many years.\nThis is because the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s website did not use encryption when transmitting your private information. As a result, any data submitted to the MTA website could have been read by third parties whose networks your private information passed through on its way to the MTA.\nIn general, the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s web offerings are all insecure at this time except for the My MTA Alerts, MTA Employment Opportunity and EasyPay portals, which all use encryption to protect visitors. After being notified of the leak, the MTA has since secured the customer service and the third-party developer portals.\nFor web traffic, secure transmission is known as \xe2\x80\x9cHTTPS.\xe2\x80\x9d Without HTTPS, there is no privacy or assurance on the web. This is because the internet is basically a network of relays between you and the physical locations of requested web servers. This means a lot of strangers handle your web requests. Without encryption, private data sent over the web can be spied upon or tampered with by any of these third parties. HTTPS thwarts these types of attacks.\nIt is impossible to count the number of third parties who have had access to your data, and it is impossible to know if any of them read or harvested your data, but a short list of these third parties includes internet service providers and phone companies (Verizon, AT&T, Time Warner Cable), WiFi providers, such as coffee shops, hotels and free providers like LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x94 even your landlord in some buildings. Also, criminal hackers and government spy agencies both foreign and domestic.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor a government agency that is sending and receiving data that has a real effect on people\xe2\x80\x99s daily lives, there\xe2\x80\x99s really no excuse for not using basic security techniques that are, at this point, absolutely bog standard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Parker Higgins, a computer security expert and director of special projects for Freedom of the Press Foundation.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor at least the last five years,\xe2\x80\x9d Higgins added, \xe2\x80\x9cmost government agencies are moving towards HTTPS everywhere. Within the federal government that\xe2\x80\x99s been an official, established standard for three years.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSwitching to HTTPS from the nonsecure transmission line \xe2\x80\x9cHTTP\xe2\x80\x9d is easy and inexpensive. HTTPS has also recently become common among local government websites. New York City\xe2\x80\x99s various web services, from traffic ticket payment to public housing requests, are all HTTPS-secured. The state government is also up to date in this sense \xe2\x80\x94 except when it comes to the MTA.\nThe MTA website itself is not a single website per se. It is a collection of unrelated web servers located around the country that perform different functions on the website but which link to each other. Since each web server uses a uniform style, the transition from one server to the other during browsing appears seamless. TripPlanner is located in Brooklyn, Subway and Bus Times are located in Virginia, Long Island Rail Road schedule lookup is on Long Island. None of these used HTTPS at press time.\nThe largest privacy violator for years was the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s web customer service portal, which is located in Chicago on a network operated by Oracle. Traffic to and from this server was unprotected until July 16, when the MTA switched it to HTTPS after being contacted for this article a few days earlier. Last month, a simple web request to this site passed through at least 12 internet relays on its way from New York City to Chicago, according to a diagnostic tool named traceroute. This means that in addition to the MTA, 12 internet operators were able to read your username and password, and any FOIL requests (including postal address), customer service requests or sexual harassment complaints (including photo uploads and phone number) you might have filed. If you re-used passwords, the MTA customer service website could have compromised every account you used the same password for.\n\xe2\x80\x9cData that you send over HTTP can be intercepted and read by anyone on your network, including internet service providers and individuals connected to the same WiFi network as you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sydney Li, a staff technologist for the Electronic Frontier Foundation. \xe2\x80\x9cSensitive data such as personally identifiable information, passwords, or sexual harassment complaints should absolutely be sent over an HTTPS connection. When you load content over HTTP, any entity responsible for routing this content can also alter or present fake content to you. This is known as a man-in-the-middle attack.\xe2\x80\x9d\nVerizon was caught doing just that, since at least 2014, according to reports from ProPublica.\xc2\xa0 In 2016, the Federal Communications Commission fined Verizon $1.35 million for injecting \xe2\x80\x9csuper-cookies\xe2\x80\x9d into the unencrypted traffic of their mobile customers, with no way to opt out. These are tracking codes that Verizon and third parties use to monitor browsing histories and build profiles on unsuspecting web users. This type of message tampering is exactly what encryption was designed to defeat. It is not possible while using HTTPS.\nSome sections of its website are managed in-house by the MTA, others are outsourced to contractors like Oracle, which conducts the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s customer service and employment opportunity portals. Oracle is one of the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s biggest technological contractors. As of May 2017, Oracle held at least $59 million in combined contracts with the MTA until 2020, according to minutes from a board meeting where the Oracle contracts to-date were consolidated into a single umbrella contract.\nThe MTA\xe2\x80\x99s customer service website is provided to the authority via a service known as RightNow, also referred to as Oracle Cloud. This contract originates from 2002, years before RightNow was purchased by Oracle. At the time, it was offered to MTA for $112,000 per year, according to a 2011 procurement report. Oracle bought RightNow in 2012 and MTA costs have ballooned since then. In July 2014, the RightNow contract was renewed under Oracle for $190,000 a year, according to minutes from a board meeting where the RightNow contract was combined with the procurement of another Oracle service, \xe2\x80\x9cSocial Relationship Management,\xe2\x80\x9d for a combined $518,000 for two years.\nCurrently, MTA still contracts Oracle for RightNow, which as of 2017 is included in the umbrella Oracle contract. This guarantees that the costs associated with RightNow will be much harder to trace going forward.\nThe MTA developer portal, for third-party app developers, was also not encrypted, meaning developers may have had their login username and password compromised or their API keys stolen. (API keys are the credentials MTA issues to third-party app developers to grant access to proprietary data feeds, such as train schedule or location services.) Visitors applying for a developer account also had their submissions leaked, which included their name, phone number and company name. The developer servers are located in Virginia.\xc2\xa0 The MTA secured this portal as of July 25.\nOn July 2, the MTA unveiled a pre-release version of its new and redesigned website, which was a vast improvement over its current website. Commendably, the homepage and the basic text pages were secured under HTTPS. Train schedule lookups have been merged into the basic website and are now secure as well. But the new website still linked to insecure areas of the old website, such as the lost and found form, which leaked name, phone numbers, email address, postal address and travel details.\nThe MTA has since secured the lost and found form.\xc2\xa0 But other parts of the old website remained unprotected at press time, such as TripPlanner and Subway Times and Bus Times.\nDespite recent progress, the MTA violated its privacy policy for years and will continue to do so until its entire website is secured under HTTPS. The privacy policy states \xe2\x80\x9cthe MTA Agencies are strongly committed to protecting personal information collected through the MTA Website against unauthorized access, use, or disclosure \xe2\x80\xa6 MTA Agencies have implemented procedures to safeguard the integrity of their information technology assets, including, but not limited to, authenticating \xe2\x80\xa6 and encrypting. Security procedures have been integrated into the design, implementation, and day-to-day operations of the MTA Website as part of our continuing commitment to the security of electronic content.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAfter the initial web publication of this report on July 18, an MTA spokesperson emailed The Indypendent the following statement: \xe2\x80\x9cThe MTA currently uses HTTPS and encryption for all ecommerce apps to protect customer data associated with financial transactions, and our technicians are working on remaining sections of the legacy website and expect to have that patched within days. There has been no evidence of data leak or breach of any information from the MTA website to date.\xe2\x80\x9d\nHowever, the nature of this type of data leak means that the mere occurrence of data transmission to the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s insecure servers is evidence itself that the leak has occurred. Since the leak occurs via the act of transmission itself, the MTA has no control over who reads or saves that leaked data. If a third party abused its access to the data, then the evidence would rest with that third party, not the MTA.\nAnd despite its assurance that technicians were patching the data breaches on its \xe2\x80\x9clegacy website,\xe2\x80\x9d many areas of the website remained leaking as The Indy went to press.\nThis is reader-supported news. \xea\xb3\xb5\xea\xb0\x84, \xec\x8b\x9d\xed\x92\x88\xec\xa0\x90 \xeb\xb0\x8f \xec\x86\x8c\xeb\xa7\xa4 \xec\x97\x85\xec\xb2\xb4 \xeb\x93\xb1 \xec\x9d\xbc\xeb\xb0\x98\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x9e\xac\xec\xa0\x95 \xeb\xac\xb8\xec\xa0\x9c\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa7\x81\xeb\xa9\xb4\xed\x95\x9c \xec\xa7\x80\xec\x97\xad \xec\x82\xac\xed\x9a\x8c \xea\xb0\x9c\xeb\xb0\x9c \xed\x88\xac\xec\x9e\x90\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0 \xec\x9c\x84\xed\x95\xb4 \xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x9e\x90\xea\xb8\x88\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4.\xc2\xa0 2001 \xeb\x85\x84 \xec\xb0\xbd\xec\xb6\x9c\xed\x95\x98\xec\x97\xac 500,000\xea\xb0\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x83\x81\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xbc\xec\x9e\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb0\xbd\xec\xb6\x9c\xed\x96\x88\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa9\xb0, 1\xec\x96\xb5 6\xec\xb2\x9c 4\xeb\xb0\xb1\xeb\xa7\x8c \xec\xa0\x9c\xea\xb3\xb1 \xed\x94\xbc\xed\x8a\xb8 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x95\xbc\xea\xb8\xb0, \xea\xb0\x80..\n\xec\x86\x8c\xed\x94\x84\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\x85\xb8 \xec\xa1\xb0\xec\x88\x98\xeb\xaf\xb8 \'\xeb\xa7\x88\xeb\x8d\x94 \xeb\x94\x94\xec\x96\xb4(Mother \xe2\x80\x98\xed\x8c\x94\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\x9a\xb0\xeb\xaf\xb811\xe2\x80\x99 \xec\xa0\x9c\xec\x9e\x91\xeb\xb0\x9c\xed\x91\x9c\xed\x9a\x8c\nEBS \xeb\x8b\xa4\xed\x81\x90\xed\x94\x84\xeb\x9d\xbc\xec\x9e\x84 \xe2\x80\x98\xec\x88\x98\xec\xbb\xb7\xeb\x93\xa4\xe2\x80\x99 2\xeb\xb6\x80\xec\x9e\x91 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x86\xa1 \xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\x85\x90 \xeb\xac\xb8\xed\x99\x94, \xeb\x82\x9800009 | \xeb\x93\xb1\xeb\xa1\x9d\xec\x9d\xbc\xec\x9e\x90 1980.12.29 | \xeb\xb0\x9c\xed\x96\x89\xec\x9d\xbc\xec\x9e\x90 1980.12.29 | Tel. 02-398-3114\n(C) Yonhapnews\n[\xeb\x8c\x80\xed\x91\x9c\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x82\xac] \xec\xa1\xb0\xec\x84\xb1\xeb\xb6\x80\n[\xed\x8e\xb8\xec\xa7\x91\xec\x9d\xb8] \xea\xb9\x80\xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x84\x9d', b'Google tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9bc \xc4\x91\xc3\xa2y v\xc3\xa0 Alphabet b\xc3\xa2y gi\xe1\xbb\x9d l\xe1\xbb\x9bn \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn c\xe1\xbb\xa1 n\xc3\xa0o?\nTh\xe1\xbb\x9di s\xe1\xbb\xb1\nX\xc3\xa3 h\xe1\xbb\x99i Gi\xc3\xa1o D\xe1\xbb\xa5c S\xe1\xbb\x91ng kh\xe1\xbb\x8fe C\xe1\xbb\x99ng \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x93ng m\xe1\xba\xa1ng\nTh\xe1\xbb\x83 thao\nB\xc3\xb3ng \xc4\x91\xc3\xa1 H\xe1\xba\xadu tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng\nGi\xe1\xba\xa3i tr\xc3\xad\n\xc3\x82m nh\xe1\xba\xa1c Phim \xe1\xba\xa3nh Nh\xc3\xa2n v\xe1\xba\xadt\nTh\xe1\xba\xbf gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi\nG\xc3\xb3c nh\xc3\xacn Qu\xc3\xa2n s\xe1\xbb\xb1 Kh\xc3\xa1m ph\xc3\xa1\nAn ninh H\xc3\xacnh s\xe1\xbb\xb1\nH\xe1\xbb\x93 s\xc6\xa1 ph\xc3\xa1 \xc3\xa1n T\xc6\xb0 V\xe1\xba\xa5n\nT\xc3\xa0i ch\xc3\xadnh - B\xe1\xba\xa5t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99ng s\xe1\xba\xa3n\nDoanh nghi\xe1\xbb\x87p B\xe1\xba\xa5t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99ng s\xe1\xba\xa3n\nTi\xc3\xaau d\xc3\xb9ng\nTh\xe1\xbb\x8b tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng ngh\xe1\xbb\x87 Xe m\xc3\xa1y\nLGBT\nMedia\nVideo \xe1\xba\xa2nh\nS\xe1\xbb\x91ng \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xb9p\n\xc4\x82n - Ch\xc6\xa1i\nNgon \xc4\x90i\xe1\xbb\x83m \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn T\xc6\xb0 v\xe1\xba\xa5n\nTin \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x8ba ph\xc6\xb0\xc6\xa1ng\nB\xe1\xba\xafc Giang H\xe1\xba\xa3i D\xc6\xb0\xc6\xa1ng Nam \xc4\x90\xe1\xbb\x8bnh \xc4\x90\xc3\xa0 N\xe1\xba\xb5ng C\xe1\xba\xa7n Th\xc6\xa1 H\xe1\xba\xa3i Ph\xc3\xb2ng \xc4\x90\xe1\xbb\x93ng Nai Qu\xe1\xba\xa3ng Ninh B\xe1\xba\xafc Ninh Hu\xe1\xba\xbf B\xc3\xacnh D\xc6\xb0\xc6\xa1ng B\xc3\xa0 R\xe1\xbb\x8ba V\xc5\xa9ng T\xc3\xa0u\nNg\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di Vi\xe1\xbb\x87t 5 ch\xc3\xa2u\nTrang ch\xe1\xbb\xa7\nXe - C\xc3\xb4ng ngh\xe1\xbb\x87\nGoogle tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9bc \xc4\x91\xc3\xa2y v\xc3\xa0 Alphabet b\xc3\xa2y gi\xe1\xbb\x9d l\xe1\xbb\x9bn \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn c\xe1\xbb\xa1 n\xc3\xa0o?\n06:28 19/07/2018\nB\xe1\xba\xa1n c\xc3\xb3 bi\xe1\xba\xbft \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn Waymo - c\xc3\xb4ng ty \xc4\x91ang chu\xe1\xba\xa9n b\xe1\xbb\x8b th\xc6\xb0\xc6\xa1ng m\xe1\xba\xa1i h\xc3\xb3a d\xc3\xb2ng xe t\xe1\xbb\xb1 l\xc3\xa1i \xe1\xbb\x9f th\xc3\xa0nh ph\xe1\xbb\x91 Phoenix c\xe1\xbb\xa7a M\xe1\xbb\xb9, hay d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n Loon thu\xe1\xbb\x99c b\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn nghi\xc3\xaan c\xe1\xbb\xa9u ph\xc3\xa1t tri\xe1\xbb\x83n X c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Alphabet, s\xe1\xba\xbd tr\xe1\xbb\x9f th\xc3\xa0nh c\xc3\xb4ng ty \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99c l\xe1\xba\xadp v\xc3\xa0o cu\xe1\xbb\x91i n\xc4\x83m nay?\nGoogle Doodle ch\xc3\xa0o m\xe1\xbb\xabng khai m\xe1\xba\xa1c World Cup 2018\nTr\xe1\xbb\xa3 l\xc3\xbd \xe1\xba\xa3o AI c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google b\xe1\xbb\x8b nh\xe1\xba\xadn x\xc3\xa9t l\xc3\xa0 \'th\xe1\xba\xadt \xc4\x91\xc3\xa1ng s\xe1\xbb\xa3\'\n\xc4\x90\xc3\xb3 l\xc3\xa0 nh\xe1\xbb\xafng g\xc3\xac \xc4\x91ang di\xe1\xbb\x85n ra sau 3 n\xc4\x83m Google t\xc3\xa1i c\xe1\xba\xa5u tr\xc3\xbac l\xe1\xba\xa1i to\xc3\xa0n b\xe1\xbb\x99 doanh nghi\xe1\xbb\x87p c\xe1\xbb\xa7a m\xc3\xacnh \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x83 th\xc3\xa0nh l\xe1\xba\xadp c\xc3\xb4ng ty m\xe1\xba\xb9 t\xc3\xaan l\xc3\xa0 Alphabet, m\xc3\xa0 theo CEO Larry Page l\xc3\xa0 gi\xc3\xbap c\xc3\xa1c b\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn t\xe1\xba\xa1i c\xc3\xb4ng ty ho\xe1\xba\xa1t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99ng hi\xe1\xbb\x87u qu\xe1\xba\xa3 h\xc6\xa1n.\nQuy m\xc3\xb4 hi\xe1\xbb\x87n t\xe1\xba\xa1i c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Alphabet c\xe1\xbb\xb1c k\xe1\xbb\xb3 l\xe1\xbb\x9bn v\xe1\xbb\x9bi nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u c\xc3\xb4ng ty, d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n ti\xe1\xbb\x81m n\xc4\x83ng nh\xc6\xb0 khinh kh\xc3\xad c\xe1\xba\xa7u k\xe1\xba\xbft n\xe1\xbb\x91i internet, xe t\xe1\xbb\xb1 l\xc3\xa1i hay n\xe1\xbb\x81n t\xe1\xba\xa3ng \xc4\x91\xc3\xa1m m\xc3\xa2y Google Cloud.\nN\xe1\xba\xbfu b\xe1\xba\xa1n ch\xc6\xb0a th\xe1\xbb\x83 h\xc3\xacnh dung c\xe1\xba\xa5u tr\xc3\xbac c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Alphabet g\xe1\xbb\x93m nh\xe1\xbb\xafng g\xc3\xac, h\xc3\xa3y \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x8dc qua nh\xe1\xbb\xafng th\xc3\xb4ng tin d\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9bi \xc4\x91\xc3\xa2y.\nGoogle ch\xc3\xadnh th\xe1\xbb\xa9c tr\xe1\xbb\x9f th\xc3\xa0nh Alphabet v\xc3\xa0o th\xc3\xa1ng 10/2015 v\xe1\xbb\x9bi hy v\xe1\xbb\x8dng gi\xc3\xbap c\xc3\xa1c \xc4\x91\xc6\xa1n v\xe1\xbb\x8b kinh doanh ho\xe1\xba\xa1t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99ng \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99c l\xe1\xba\xadp v\xc3\xa0 hi\xe1\xbb\x87u qu\xe1\xba\xa3 h\xc6\xa1n. Larry Page, \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x93ng s\xc3\xa1ng l\xe1\xba\xadp Google tr\xe1\xbb\x9f th\xc3\xa0nh CEO Alphabet\nAlphabet chia l\xc3\xa0m 2 \xc4\x91\xc6\xa1n v\xe1\xbb\x8b ch\xc3\xadnh: Google v\xc3\xa0 Other Bets. Other Bets \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c bi\xe1\xba\xbft \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u nh\xe1\xba\xa5t v\xe1\xbb\x9bi b\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn nghi\xc3\xaan c\xe1\xbb\xa9u v\xc3\xa0 ph\xc3\xa1t tri\xe1\xbb\x83n (R&D) t\xc3\xaan l\xc3\xa0 X c\xc3\xb9ng m\xe1\xbb\x99t s\xe1\xbb\x91 c\xc3\xb4ng ty con kh\xc3\xa1c\xe2\x80\xa6\n\xe2\x80\xa6 \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u ti\xc3\xaan l\xc3\xa0 Google Fiber. Ho\xe1\xba\xa1t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99ng l\xe1\xba\xa7n \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u t\xe1\xba\xa1i Kansas City v\xc3\xa0o 2012 v\xc3\xa0 m\xe1\xbb\x9f r\xe1\xbb\x99ng ra 9 th\xc3\xa0nh ph\xe1\xbb\x91 kh\xc3\xa1c c\xe1\xbb\xa7a M\xe1\xbb\xb9, Fiber cung c\xe1\xba\xa5p d\xe1\xbb\x8bch v\xe1\xbb\xa5 truy c\xe1\xba\xadp internet t\xe1\xbb\x91c \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99 c\xe1\xbb\xb1c cao (l\xc3\xaan \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn 1Gbps) v\xc3\xa0 TV. Hi\xe1\xbb\x87n Fiber c\xc3\xb3 kho\xe1\xba\xa3ng 200.000 thu\xc3\xaa bao \xc4\x91\xc4\x83ng k\xc3\xbd\nNh\xc6\xb0ng s\xe1\xbb\x91 ti\xe1\xbb\x81n m\xc3\xa0 Alphabet \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x95 v\xc3\xa0o Fiber ng\xc3\xa0y c\xc3\xa0ng \xc3\xadt \xc4\x91i. V\xe1\xbb\x9bi vi\xe1\xbb\x87c d\xe1\xbb\xabng m\xe1\xbb\x9f r\xe1\xbb\x99ng th\xe1\xbb\x8b tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng, sa th\xe1\xba\xa3i h\xc3\xa0ng tr\xc4\x83m nh\xc3\xa2n vi\xc3\xaan, nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u tin \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x93n cho r\xe1\xba\xb1ng Alphabet \xc4\x91ang chu\xe1\xba\xa9n b\xe1\xbb\x8b b\xc3\xa1n Fiber\nTi\xe1\xba\xbfp theo l\xc3\xa0 Verily chuy\xc3\xaan v\xe1\xbb\x81 ch\xc4\x83m s\xc3\xb3c s\xe1\xbb\xa9c kh\xe1\xbb\x8fe v\xe1\xbb\x9bi nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n nh\xc6\xb0 k\xc3\xadnh \xc3\xa1p tr\xc3\xb2ng th\xc3\xb4ng minh gi\xc3\xa1m s\xc3\xa1t n\xe1\xbb\x93ng \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99 glucose, d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng c\xe1\xbb\xa5 h\xe1\xbb\x97 tr\xe1\xbb\xa3 \xc4\x83n u\xe1\xbb\x91ng cho ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di gi\xc3\xa0 tay run v\xc3\xa0 m\xe1\xba\xafc b\xe1\xbb\x87nh Parkinson\nAlphabet th\xc3\xa0nh l\xe1\xba\xadp c\xc3\xb4ng ty Sidewalk Labs v\xc3\xa0o 2015. \xc4\x90\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c l\xc3\xa3nh \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa1o b\xe1\xbb\x9fi Dan Doctoroff, Sidewalk Labs gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi thi\xe1\xbb\x87u c\xc3\xa1c gi\xe1\xba\xa3i ph\xc3\xa1p gi\xc3\xbap \xc3\xa1p d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng c\xc3\xb4ng ngh\xe1\xbb\x87 v\xc3\xa0o th\xc3\xa0nh ph\xe1\xbb\x91. \xc4\x90\xc3\xa2y l\xc3\xa0 ki-\xe1\xbb\x91t truy c\xe1\xba\xadp internet \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c Sidewalk Labs h\xe1\xbb\xa3p t\xc3\xa1c v\xe1\xbb\x9bi LinkNYC l\xe1\xba\xafp \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xb7t quanh New York\nTh\xc3\xa0nh l\xe1\xba\xadp v\xc3\xa0o 2013, Calico c\xc3\xb3 m\xe1\xbb\xa5c ti\xc3\xaau \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7y tham v\xe1\xbb\x8dng: ch\xe1\xbb\xafa b\xe1\xbb\x87nh t\xe1\xbb\xad vong. Theo Business Insider, Calico \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u t\xc6\xb0 h\xc3\xa0ng tri\xe1\xbb\x87u USD \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x83 ph\xc3\xa1t tri\xe1\xbb\x83n c\xc3\xa1c lo\xe1\xba\xa1i thu\xe1\xbb\x91c ph\xc3\xb2ng ch\xe1\xbb\x91ng c\xc3\xa1c lo\xe1\xba\xa1i b\xe1\xbb\x87nh nh\xc6\xb0 ung th\xc6\xb0 hay Alzheimer nh\xe1\xba\xb1m k\xc3\xa9o d\xc3\xa0i tu\xe1\xbb\x95i th\xe1\xbb\x8d\nGV l\xc3\xa0 qu\xe1\xbb\xb9 \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u t\xc6\xb0 cho c\xc3\xa1c startup m\xe1\xbb\x9bi (early-stage) c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Alphabet, tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9bc \xc4\x91\xc3\xa2y l\xc3\xa0 Google Ventures. C\xc3\xb3 2,4 t\xe1\xbb\xb7 USD, GV \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u t\xc6\xb0 v\xc3\xa0o h\xc6\xa1n 300 c\xc3\xb4ng ty g\xe1\xbb\x93m Uber, Flatiron Health hay Slack\nGoogle Capital \xe2\x80\x93 nay l\xc3\xa0 CapitalG \xe2\x80\x93 l\xc3\xa0 m\xe1\xbb\x99t qu\xe1\xbb\xb9 \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u t\xc6\xb0 t\xc4\x83ng tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9fng. Tuy nhi\xe1\xbb\x87m v\xe1\xbb\xa5 l\xc3\xa0 ki\xe1\xba\xbfm l\xe1\xbb\xa3i nhu\xe1\xba\xadn nh\xc6\xb0ng kh\xc3\xa1c v\xe1\xbb\x9bi GV, CapitalG t\xe1\xba\xadp trung v\xc3\xa0o c\xc3\xa1c startup \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9fng th\xc3\xa0nh (later-stage) nh\xc6\xb0 Airbnb, Glassdoor hay Thumbtack\nB\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn "Think tank" \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c Alphabet t\xc3\xa1ch ra th\xc3\xa0nh c\xc3\xb4ng ty Jigsaw v\xc3\xa0o n\xc4\x83m 2016. Do Jared Cohen l\xc3\xa3nh \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa1o, Jigsaw s\xe1\xbb\xad d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng c\xc3\xb4ng ngh\xe1\xbb\x87 \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x83 gi\xe1\xba\xa3i quy\xe1\xba\xbft c\xc3\xa1c v\xe1\xba\xa5n \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x81 ch\xc3\xadnh tr\xe1\xbb\x8b nh\xc6\xb0 ki\xe1\xbb\x83m duy\xe1\xbb\x87t n\xe1\xbb\x99i dung, ch\xe1\xbb\xa7 ngh\xc4\xa9a c\xe1\xbb\xb1c \xc4\x91oan v\xc3\xa0 tuy\xc3\xaan truy\xe1\xbb\x81n ch\xe1\xbb\x91ng ph\xc3\xa1\nM\xe1\xbb\x99t c\xc3\xa1i t\xc3\xaan quen thu\xe1\xbb\x99c l\xc3\xa0 DeepMind chuy\xc3\xaan v\xe1\xbb\x81 tr\xc3\xad tu\xe1\xbb\x87 nh\xc3\xa2n t\xe1\xba\xa1o (AI). Sau khi mua l\xe1\xba\xa1i c\xc3\xa1ch \xc4\x91\xc3\xa2y 4 n\xc4\x83m v\xe1\xbb\x9bi gi\xc3\xa1 500 tri\xe1\xbb\x87u USD, nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u s\xe1\xba\xa3n ph\xe1\xba\xa9m c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 t\xc3\xadch h\xe1\xbb\xa3p c\xc3\xb4ng ngh\xe1\xbb\x87 AI c\xe1\xbb\xa7a DeepMind g\xe1\xbb\x93m b\xe1\xbb\x99 m\xc3\xa1y t\xc3\xacm ki\xe1\xba\xbfm Google Search. AI c\xe1\xbb\xa7a DeepMind c\xc5\xa9ng c\xc3\xb3 kh\xe1\xba\xa3 n\xc4\x83ng t\xe1\xbb\xb1 h\xe1\xbb\x8dc c\xc3\xa1ch ch\xc6\xa1i game \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x83 ch\xc6\xa1i v\xe1\xbb\x9bi con ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di\nC\xc3\xb3 tr\xe1\xbb\xa5 s\xe1\xbb\x9f t\xe1\xba\xa1i London (Anh), DeepMind \xc4\x91ang x\xc3\xa2y d\xe1\xbb\xb1ng \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99i ng\xc5\xa9 m\xe1\xbb\x9bi t\xe1\xba\xa1i M\xe1\xbb\xb9 \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x83 c\xc3\xb9ng l\xc3\xa0m vi\xe1\xbb\x87c hi\xe1\xbb\x87u qu\xe1\xba\xa3 h\xc6\xa1n v\xe1\xbb\x9bi Google\nXu\xe1\xba\xa5t hi\xe1\xbb\x87n t\xe1\xbb\xab 2009, Waymo l\xc3\xa0 d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n ph\xc3\xa1t tri\xe1\xbb\x83n xe t\xe1\xbb\xb1 l\xc3\xa1i thu\xe1\xbb\x99c b\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn Google X. Waymo tr\xe1\xbb\x9f th\xc3\xa0nh c\xc3\xb4ng ty \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99c l\xe1\xba\xadp v\xc3\xa0o n\xc4\x83m 2016 nh\xc6\xb0ng v\xe1\xba\xabn thu\xe1\xbb\x99c c\xc3\xb4ng ty m\xe1\xba\xb9 Alphabet\nV\xe1\xbb\x9bi \xc3\xbd ngh\xc4\xa9a "Way forward in mobility", m\xe1\xbb\xa5c ti\xc3\xaau c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Waymo l\xc3\xa0 t\xe1\xba\xa1o ra m\xc3\xb4i tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng giao th\xc3\xb4ng d\xe1\xbb\x85 d\xc3\xa0ng v\xc3\xa0 an to\xc3\xa0n cho m\xe1\xbb\x8di ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di. D\xc3\xb9 \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 th\xe1\xbb\xad nghi\xe1\xbb\x87m v\xc3\xa0 ch\xe1\xba\xa1y h\xc6\xa1n 3 tri\xe1\xbb\x87u km nh\xc6\xb0ng v\xe1\xba\xabn ch\xc6\xb0a c\xc3\xb3 s\xe1\xba\xa3n ph\xe1\xba\xa9m th\xc6\xb0\xc6\xa1ng m\xe1\xba\xa1i c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Waymo xu\xe1\xba\xa5t hi\xe1\xbb\x87n\nProject Loon, d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n "moonshot" thu\xe1\xbb\x99c ph\xc3\xb2ng th\xc3\xad nghi\xe1\xbb\x87m X nh\xc6\xb0ng \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 t\xc3\xa1ch ra th\xc3\xa0nh c\xc3\xb4ng ty \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99c l\xe1\xba\xadp. Nhi\xe1\xbb\x87m v\xe1\xbb\xa5 c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Project Loon l\xc3\xa0 mang k\xe1\xba\xbft n\xe1\xbb\x91i internet \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn 2/3 d\xc3\xa2n s\xe1\xbb\x91 th\xe1\xba\xbf gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi b\xe1\xba\xb1ng c\xc3\xa1c khinh kh\xc3\xad c\xe1\xba\xa7u bay l\xc6\xa1 l\xe1\xbb\xadng tr\xc3\xaan tr\xe1\xbb\x9di\nTh\xc3\xaam m\xe1\xbb\x99t d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n thu\xe1\xbb\x99c X l\xc3\xa0 Project Wing cung c\xe1\xba\xa5p d\xe1\xbb\x8bch v\xe1\xbb\xa5 giao h\xc3\xa0ng t\xe1\xba\xadn nh\xc3\xa0 b\xe1\xba\xb1ng drone s\xe1\xbb\xad d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng n\xc4\x83ng l\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3ng m\xe1\xba\xb7t tr\xe1\xbb\x9di. Sau nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u tranh c\xc3\xa3i v\xe1\xbb\x81 \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x81u ki\xe1\xbb\x87n l\xc3\xa0m vi\xe1\xbb\x87c, Project Wing b\xe1\xbb\x8b khai t\xe1\xbb\xad, l\xc3\xa3nh \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa1o d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n l\xc3\xa0 Dave Vos c\xc5\xa9ng r\xe1\xbb\x9di c\xc3\xb4ng ty v\xc3\xa0o th\xc3\xa1ng 10/2016\nTi\xe1\xba\xbfp t\xe1\xbb\xa5c \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn v\xe1\xbb\x9bi c\xc3\xa1c d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n "moonshot" c\xe1\xbb\xa7a X. Trong gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi c\xc3\xb4ng ngh\xe1\xbb\x87, moonshot ch\xe1\xbb\x89 c\xc3\xa1c d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7y tham v\xe1\xbb\x8dng, \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99t ph\xc3\xa1 nh\xc6\xb0ng c\xc6\xa1 h\xe1\xbb\x99i th\xc3\xa0nh c\xc3\xb4ng hay c\xc3\xb3 l\xe1\xbb\xa3i nhu\xe1\xba\xadn th\xc3\xac kh\xc3\xb4ng r\xc3\xb5 r\xc3\xa0ng. Google s\xe1\xbb\xad d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng moonshot khi n\xc3\xb3i v\xe1\xbb\x81 c\xc3\xa1c d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n s\xc3\xa1ng t\xe1\xba\xa1o, ph\xe1\xba\xa7n l\xe1\xbb\x9bn \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn t\xe1\xbb\xab b\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn Google X do Astro Teller d\xe1\xba\xabn d\xe1\xba\xaft\nTitan Aerospace \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c Google mua l\xe1\xba\xa1i n\xc4\x83m 2014 v\xc3\xa0 \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x95i t\xc3\xaan th\xc3\xa0nh Project Titan. D\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n s\xe1\xbb\xad d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng m\xc3\xa1y bay kh\xc3\xb4ng ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di l\xc3\xa1i b\xe1\xba\xb1ng n\xc4\x83ng l\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3ng m\xe1\xba\xb7t tr\xe1\xbb\x9di c\xc3\xb3 th\xe1\xbb\x83 bay trong nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u n\xc4\x83m \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x83 mang internet \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn kh\xe1\xba\xafp th\xe1\xba\xbf gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi. V\xc3\xac m\xe1\xbb\x99t s\xe1\xbb\x91 l\xc3\xbd do, Google \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 khai t\xe1\xbb\xad Project Titan c\xc3\xb9ng v\xe1\xbb\x9bi Project Wing n\xc4\x83m 2016\n\xc4\x90\xc3\xb3 l\xc3\xa0 Other Bets. Ti\xe1\xba\xbfp theo h\xc3\xa3y \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn v\xe1\xbb\x9bi ch\xc3\xadnh Google\nT\xe1\xba\xa5t c\xe1\xba\xa3 nh\xe1\xbb\xafng s\xe1\xba\xa3n ph\xe1\xba\xa9m "truy\xe1\xbb\x81n th\xe1\xbb\x91ng" c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Alphabet nh\xc6\xb0 Chrome, \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x87n tho\xe1\xba\xa1i Pixel, Google Home hay Google Play \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x81u thu\xe1\xbb\x99c \xc4\x91\xc6\xa1n v\xe1\xbb\x8b Google do Sundar Pichai l\xc3\xa0m CEO\nNest Labs \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c bi\xe1\xba\xbft \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn v\xe1\xbb\x9bi c\xc3\xa1c s\xe1\xba\xa3n ph\xe1\xba\xa9m nh\xc3\xa0 th\xc3\xb4ng minh nh\xc6\xb0 nhi\xe1\xbb\x87t k\xe1\xba\xbf hay camera gi\xc3\xa1m s\xc3\xa1t. Google mua l\xe1\xba\xa1i Nest n\xc4\x83m 2014 nh\xc6\xb0ng v\xe1\xba\xabn l\xc3\xa0 c\xc3\xb4ng ty \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99c l\xe1\xba\xadp, \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u n\xc4\x83m nay Nest m\xe1\xbb\x9bi \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c Google \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0a v\xe1\xbb\x81 m\xe1\xba\xa3ng ph\xe1\xba\xa7n c\xe1\xbb\xa9ng c\xe1\xbb\xa7a m\xc3\xacnh\nM\xe1\xba\xa3ng ph\xe1\xba\xa7n c\xe1\xbb\xa9ng c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c th\xc3\xa0nh l\xe1\xba\xadp n\xc4\x83m 2016 khi c\xc3\xb4ng ty "chi\xc3\xaau m\xe1\xbb\x99" ch\xe1\xbb\xa7 t\xe1\xbb\x8bch Motorola Rick Osterloh. M\xe1\xbb\x99t s\xe1\xbb\x91 s\xe1\xba\xa3n ph\xe1\xba\xa9m c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Osterloh v\xc3\xa0 \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99i ng\xc5\xa9 c\xe1\xbb\xa7a \xc3\xb4ng g\xe1\xbb\x93m \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x87n tho\xe1\xba\xa1i Pixel, Google Home, Chromebook hay Google Glass\nATAP, vi\xe1\xba\xbft t\xe1\xba\xaft c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Advanced Technology and Projects l\xc3\xa0 b\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn b\xc3\xad m\xe1\xba\xadt c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google v\xe1\xbb\x9bi c\xc3\xa1c d\xe1\xbb\xb1 \xc3\xa1n nh\xc6\xb0 v\xe1\xba\xa3i th\xc3\xb4ng minh Jacquard, Soli s\xe1\xbb\xad d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng s\xc3\xb3ng radar cho c\xe1\xba\xa3m \xe1\xbb\xa9ng kh\xc3\xb4ng ch\xe1\xba\xa1m hay Spotlight Stories t\xe1\xba\xa1o ra c\xc3\xa1c \xc4\x91o\xe1\xba\xa1n phim VR ng\xe1\xba\xafn. ATAP gi\xe1\xbb\x9d \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 thu\xe1\xbb\x99c v\xe1\xbb\x81 m\xe1\xba\xa3ng ph\xe1\xba\xa7n c\xe1\xbb\xa9ng c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Osterloh\n\xc4\x90\xc3\xa2y l\xc3\xa0 Diane Greene, l\xc3\xa3nh \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa1o m\xe1\xba\xa3ng doanh nghi\xe1\xbb\x87p \xc4\x91\xc3\xa1m m\xc3\xa2y v\xe1\xbb\x9bi c\xc3\xa1c d\xe1\xbb\x8bch v\xe1\xbb\xa5 nh\xc6\xb0 G Suite (tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9bc \xc4\x91\xc3\xa2y l\xc3\xa0 Google Apps for Work), Google Cloud Platform v\xc3\xa0 nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u h\xc6\xa1n n\xe1\xbb\xafa\nGoogle Cloud l\xc3\xa0 n\xe1\xbb\x81n t\xe1\xba\xa3ng \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x87n to\xc3\xa1n \xc4\x91\xc3\xa1m m\xc3\xa2y c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google c\xe1\xba\xa1nh tranh v\xe1\xbb\x9bi Amazon Web Services v\xc3\xa0 Microsoft Azure. \xc4\x90\xc3\xa2y l\xc3\xa0 ngu\xe1\xbb\x93n \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u t\xc6\xb0 ch\xc3\xadnh c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xbfn th\xe1\xbb\x9di \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x83m n\xc3\xa0y. Nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u l\xc3\xa3nh \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa1o Google tin r\xe1\xba\xb1ng Cloud s\xe1\xba\xbd s\xe1\xbb\x9bm mang v\xe1\xbb\x81 doanh thu cao h\xc6\xa1n m\xe1\xba\xa3ng qu\xe1\xba\xa3ng c\xc3\xa1o v\xc3\xa0 t\xc3\xacm ki\xe1\xba\xbfm\nG Suite g\xe1\xbb\x93m c\xc3\xa1c d\xe1\xbb\x8bch v\xe1\xbb\xa5 nh\xc6\xb0 Hangouts Meet, Calendar, Gmail, Google+, Cloud Search v\xc3\xa0 Google Drive. Theo Google, h\xc3\xa0ng tri\xe1\xbb\x87u doanh nghi\xe1\xbb\x87p \xc4\x91ang s\xe1\xbb\xad d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng G Suite\nC\xc3\xa1i t\xc3\xaan n\xe1\xbb\x95i ti\xe1\xba\xbfng kh\xc3\xa1c l\xc3\xa0 YouTube. \xc4\x90\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c Google mua l\xe1\xba\xa1i n\xc4\x83m 2006, trang chia s\xe1\xba\xbb video tr\xe1\xbb\xb1c tuy\xe1\xba\xbfn d\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9bi s\xe1\xbb\xb1 l\xc3\xa3nh \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa1o c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Susan Wojcicki \xc4\x91ang l\xc3\xa0 m\xe1\xba\xa1ng video h\xc3\xa0ng \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u th\xe1\xba\xbf gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi v\xc3\xa0 l\xc3\xa0 website truy c\xe1\xba\xadp nhi\xe1\xbb\x81u th\xe1\xbb\xa9 hai\nGoogle Search l\xc3\xa0 s\xe1\xba\xa3n ph\xe1\xba\xa9m c\xe1\xbb\x91t l\xc3\xb5i c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google. V\xe1\xbb\x9bi h\xc6\xa1n 2,3 tri\xe1\xbb\x87u l\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3t t\xc3\xacm ki\xe1\xba\xbfm m\xe1\xbb\x97i ph\xc3\xbat, \xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9bc t\xc3\xadnh c\xc3\xb3 h\xc6\xa1n 100 t\xe1\xbb\xb7 l\xe1\xba\xa7n t\xc3\xacm ki\xe1\xba\xbfm m\xe1\xbb\x97i th\xc3\xa1ng tr\xc3\xaan c\xc3\xb4ng c\xe1\xbb\xa5 n\xc3\xa0y\nC\xc5\xa9ng l\xc3\xa0 m\xe1\xbb\x99t ph\xe1\xba\xa7n quan tr\xe1\xbb\x8dng c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Google, Google Maps hi\xe1\xbb\x87n c\xc3\xb3 h\xc6\xa1n 1 t\xe1\xbb\xb7 ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di d\xc3\xb9ng m\xe1\xbb\x97i th\xc3\xa1ng\nGoogle AdSense gi\xc3\xbap nh\xc3\xa0 xu\xe1\xba\xa5t b\xe1\xba\xa3n ki\xe1\xba\xbfm ti\xe1\xbb\x81n t\xe1\xbb\xab n\xe1\xbb\x99i dung c\xe1\xbb\xa7a h\xe1\xbb\x8d b\xe1\xba\xb1ng c\xc3\xa1c qu\xe1\xba\xa3ng c\xc3\xa1o. \xc4\x90\xc3\xa2y c\xc5\xa9ng l\xc3\xa0 b\xe1\xbb\x99 ph\xe1\xba\xadn mang v\xe1\xbb\x81 doanh thu r\xe1\xba\xa5t l\xe1\xbb\x9bn cho Google\nCu\xe1\xbb\x91i c\xc3\xb9ng l\xc3\xa0 Android, h\xe1\xbb\x87 \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x81u h\xc3\xa0nh di \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99ng ph\xe1\xbb\x95 bi\xe1\xba\xbfn nh\xe1\xba\xa5t th\xe1\xba\xbf gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi. Google th\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng tung ra c\xc3\xa1c b\xe1\xba\xa3n c\xe1\xba\xadp nh\xe1\xba\xadt l\xe1\xbb\x9bn m\xe1\xbb\x97i n\xc4\x83m 1 l\xe1\xba\xa7n v\xc3\xa0 phi\xc3\xaan b\xe1\xba\xa3n m\xe1\xbb\x9bi nh\xe1\xba\xa5t hi\xe1\xbb\x87n t\xe1\xba\xa1i l\xc3\xa0 8.1 Oreo. V\xe1\xbb\x9bi Play Store, ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di d\xc3\xb9ng Android c\xc3\xb3 th\xe1\xbb\x83 t\xe1\xba\xa3i \xe1\xbb\xa9ng d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng, phim, nh\xe1\xba\xa1c v\xc3\xa0 s\xe1\xba\xa1ch.\nGoogle b\xe1\xbb\x8b t\xe1\xbb\x91 cho ph\xc3\xa9p c\xc3\xa1c nh\xc3\xa0 ph\xc3\xa1t tri\xe1\xbb\x83n \xe1\xbb\xa9ng d\xe1\xbb\xa5ng \xe2\x80\x98\xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x8dc\xe2\x80\x99 Gmail\nH\xc3\xa3ng Google v\xe1\xbb\xaba c\xc3\xb4ng b\xe1\xbb\x91 phi\xc3\xaan b\xe1\xba\xa3n Gmail c\xe1\xba\xa3i t\xe1\xbb\x95 l\xe1\xba\xa7n \xc4\x91\xe1\xba\xa7u ti\xc3\xaan k\xe1\xbb\x83 t\xe1\xbb\xab n\xc4\x83m 2013 v\xe1\xbb\x9bi c\xc3\xa1c t\xc3\xadnh n\xc4\x83ng n\xc3\xa2ng c\xe1\xba\xa5p v\xe1\xbb\x81 b\xe1\xba\xa3o m\xe1\xba\xadt v\xc3\xa0 ho\xe1\xba\xa1t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x99ng offline \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x83 c\xe1\xba\xa1nh tranh v\xe1\xbb\x9bi Microsoft Outlook.\nH\xc3\xa0ng lo\xe1\xba\xa1t b\xc3\xa0i vi\xe1\xba\xbft \'v\xe1\xba\xa1ch m\xe1\xba\xb7t\' Deaura bi\xe1\xba\xbfn m\xe1\xba\xa5t b\xc3\xad \xe1\xba\xa9n tr\xc3\xaan Google: Nghi \'chi\xc3\xaau b\xe1\xba\xa9n\' c\xe1\xbb\xa7a doanh nghi\xe1\xbb\x87p khi b\xe1\xbb\x8b \'b\xc3\xb3c m\xe1\xba\xbd\'\nM\xe1\xbb\x99t lo\xe1\xba\xa1t b\xc3\xa0i vi\xe1\xba\xbft ph\xe1\xba\xa3n \xc3\xa1nh vi\xe1\xbb\x87c kinh doanh "m\xe1\xbb\x9d \xc3\xa1m" c\xe1\xbb\xa7a C\xc3\xb4ng ty TNHH Deaura nay \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x95i t\xc3\xaan th\xc3\xa0nh Venesa tr\xc3\xb2 n\xc3\xa9 thu\xe1\xba\xbf h\xc3\xa0ng t\xe1\xbb\xb7 USD c\xe1\xbb\xa7a Apple, Facebook, Google v\xc3\xa0 Amazon\nMinh ch\xc6\xb0\xcc\x81ng Huawei se\xcc\x83 th\xc4\x83\xcc\x81ng vi\xcc\x80 h\xc3\xa0nh ri\xc3\xaang HongMeng cu\xe1\xbb\x91i n\xc4\x83m nay\nNhi\xe1\xbb\x81u ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x8dc\nL\xe1\xbb\x8bch ph\xc3\xa1t s\xc3\xb3ng phim V\xe1\xbb\x81 nh\xc3\xa0 \xc4\x91i con t\xe1\xba\xadp 49 tr\xe1\xbb\xb1c ti\xe1\xba\xbfp tr\xc3\xaan VTV1 ng\xc3\xa0y 20/6\n\xc4\x90i\xe1\xbb\x83m chu\xe1\xba\xa9n v\xc3\xa0o l\xe1\xbb\x9bp 10 n\xc4\x83m 2019 t\xe1\xba\xa5t c\xe1\xba\xa3 c\xc3\xa1c t\xe1\xbb\x89nh, c\xc3\xa1c tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng THPT [C\xe1\xba\xadp nh\xe1\xba\xadt]\nTra c\xe1\xbb\xa9u \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x83m thi tuy\xe1\xbb\x83n sinh v\xc3\xa0o l\xe1\xbb\x9bp 10 n\xc4\x83m 2019 t\xe1\xba\xa5t c\xe1\xba\xa3 c\xc3\xa1c t\xe1\xbb\x89nh, c\xc3\xa1c tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng THPT [C\xe1\xba\xadp nh\xe1\xba\xadt]\nVi\xe1\xbb\x87t Nam x\xc3\xa1c minh th\xc3\xb4ng tin t\xc3\xa0u s\xc3\xa2n bay Trung Qu\xe1\xbb\x91c \xc4\x91ang v\xc3\xa0o Bi\xe1\xbb\x83n \xc4\x90\xc3\xb4ng\n7 \xc4\x91i\xe1\xbb\x81u quy\xe1\xba\xbft \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x8bnh ph\xc3\xbac th\xe1\xbb\x8d c\xe1\xbb\xa7a m\xe1\xbb\x99t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x9di ng\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9di, b\xe1\xba\xa1n \xc4\x91\xc3\xa3 hi\xe1\xbb\x83u \xc4\x91\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\xa3c bao nhi\xc3\xaau?\nS\xe1\xbb\xb1 ki\xe1\xbb\x87n\nThi THPT qu\xe1\xbb\x91c gia 2019\nThi THPT Qu\xe1\xbb\x91c gia 2019, tin ng\xc3\xa0y 21/6: T\xe1\xbb\x89nh B\xc3\xacnh Thu\xe1\xba\xadn s\xe1\xba\xbd Th\xc3\xa1i Nguy\xc3\xaan 2019\n\xc4\x90i\xe1\xbb\x83m chu\xe1\xba\xa9n tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng \xc4\x90\xe1\xba\xa1i h\xe1\xbb\x8dc Khoa h\xe1\xbb\x8dc - tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng phi gi\xe1\xbb\x9bi t\xc3\xadnh \xc4\x91ang \'l\xc3\xa0m m\xc6\xb0a l\xc3\xa0m gi\xc3\xb3\' t\xe1\xba\xa1i Top Model Online 2019\nS\xc3\xa2n bay Arab Saudi ng\xe1\xbb\xabng ho\xe1\xba\xa1t \xc4\x91\xe1\xbb\x93ng m\xe1\xba\xa1ng\nTi\xc3\xaau d\xc3\xb9ng\nTh\xe1\xbb\x8b tr\xc6\xb0\xe1\xbb\x9dng \xc4\x90\xe1\xbb\x93 u\xe1\xbb\x91ng Th\xe1\xbb\xb1c ph\xe1\xba\xa9m Khuy\xe1\xba\xbfn Industry Event Calendar >>MORE VideosWebinarsEventsPodcastsPhotosArticlesVideosBlogsPress ReleasesJob ListingsProject HelpMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggersStore\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nTop 5 digital signage stories: June 2018July 19, 2018 | by Bradley CooperReaders of Digital Signage Today kicked off the summer by reading stories on smart cities, corporate communication and how to measure digital signage ROI.One top story last month tackled how smart cities are helping deliver improved quality of life for residents. For example, smart cities are using tools such as kiosks, digital signage and sensors to analyze traffic flows to improve services.Another story analyzed how to effectively measure digital signage ROI, by looking at engagement, experience and other objectives.You can read more on these topics by reading these top five stories for June 2018. They are posted in reverse order.5. 3 ways digital signage can deliver improved communication at the workplaceIf we are completely honest, we have to admit we regularly ignore or miss important emails. A study by The Radicati Group found that in 2015, the average employee sent and received 122 emails per day. The study also expected that number to increase to 126 emails by 2019. With so many emails flying back and forth, it's easy to see why that important email regarding a company get together or a change to the 401k can go unnoticed. Perhaps a better solution to this communication overload is to provide a more convenient source of information: digital signage. There are three key ways digital signage can boost communication in the workplace: convenience, interactivity and culture.4. Smart cities deliver improved quality of lifeCities around the globe are adopting smart technologies. New York City, for example, deployed LinkNYC kiosks, which offer Wi-Fi services and advertisements to residents. Services such as these aren't just boosting Wi-Fi, they are also delivering improved quality of life.3. 3 ways airports fly high with digital signageThrough embracing digital technologies, airports have been actively exploring the tools to further shape the delivery of their overall customer experience. With customer experience remaining the primary focus, airports are capitalizing on the opportunities to provide efficient messaging, real time information, personalized services and self-service. Airports are keen to discover what's next, as the digital revolution takes flight.2. 5 future digital signage trends of 20182017 was an innovative year for digital signage, and 2018 promises to have even more going on. Both organizations and the public have embraced the digitalization of\xe2\x80\xa6well, everything\xe2\x80\xa6and they want more.1. How to measure digital signage ROIIt is essential that you have a clear idea of what exactly you want your digital signage system to achieve. Is it to improve productivity? Increase event participation? Improve the guest experience? Boost online interactions? Your goal has to be relevant and measurable, and shouldn't be simply to give people information. Your objectives will determine both what you're going to show on digital signs and how you\xe2\x80\x99re going to judge success, so they need to be well thought out.Image via Istock.comTopics: Content, Content Management, Corporate Communication, Customer Experience, Trends / Statistics, Wayfinding Bradley CooperBradley Cooper is a Technology Editor for DigitalSignageToday.com and BlockchainTechNews.com. STREET\n\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\x99\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x88\n\xe3\x83\x97\xe3\x83\xac\xe3\x82\xbc\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x88\n\xe3\x83\x87\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xb5\xe3\x83\xb3\xe7\x9a\x84\xe3\x83\x9e\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x97\n\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\x99\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x88\xe7\x95\xaa\xe5\xa4\x96\xe7\xb7\xa8\n\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\x99\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x88\n\xef\xbe\x8c\xef\xbe\x9e\xef\xbd\xaf\xef\xbd\xb8\xef\xbe\x8f\xef\xbd\xb0\xef\xbd\xb8\n\xe3\x81\x8b\xe3\x82\x8f\xe3\x82\x89\xe7\x89\x88\n\xe3\x83\x96\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x83\x9e\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xaf\n\xef\xbd\xb8\xef\xbe\x97\xef\xbd\xbc\xef\xbe\x8c\xef\xbd\xa7\xef\xbd\xb2\xef\xbe\x84\xef\xbe\x9e\n\xe3\x81\x9d\xe3\x81\xae\xe4\xbb\x96\n\xe6\xb1\x82\xe4\xba\xba\xe6\x83\x85\xe5\xa0\xb1\n\xe4\xb8\x80\xe8\x88\xac\n\xe3\x83\xac\xe3\x82\xb9\xe3\x83\x88\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x83\xb3\n\xe6\x8e\xb2\xe7\xa4\xba\xe6\x9d\xbf\n\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n2010\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe3\x81\xae\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe6\x9c\xab\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe5\xa7\x8b\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n2011\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe3\x81\xae\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n2\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe3\x82\xb5\xe3\x83\x9e\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xad\xe3\x83\xa3\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x97\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n3\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe6\x96\xb0\xe7\x94\x9f\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n4\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe3\x83\x88\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x83\x99\xe3\x83\xab\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n6\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe3\x83\x89\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x82\xb9\xe3\x82\xbf\xe3\x83\x9f\xe3\x83\x8a\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n9\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a
