\xe8\x8a\xb1\xe7\x81\xab\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n7\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a2 \xe3\x82\xb8\xe3\x83\xa3\xe3\x83\x91\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x82\xab\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x84\n7\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a3 \xe3\x82\xb5\xe3\x83\x9e\xe3\x83\xbc\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n8\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe5\xa4\x89\xe3\x81\xaa\xe9\xa3\xb2\xe3\x81\xbf\xe7\x89\xa9\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n9\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe3\x83\x81\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xba\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n10\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xef\xbc\xae\xef\xbc\xb9\xef\xbc\xa3\xe3\x81\x8c\xe8\x88\x9e\xe5\x8f\xb0\xe3\x81\xae\xe6\x8e\xa8\xe7\x90\x86\xe3\x83\xbb\xe6\x80\xaa\xe5\xa5\x87\xe5\xb0\x8f\xe8\xaa\xac\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n11\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe3\x83\x9b\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x83\x87\xe3\x83\xbc\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n11\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe3\x83\x9b\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x83\x87\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x81\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x94\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x82\xb0\n2019\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe6\x9c\xab\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe5\xa7\x8b\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n5\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9a\xe3\x82\xb8\xe3\x83\xa3\xe3\x83\x91\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x87\xe3\x83\xbc\n\xef\xbc\x95\xe6\x9c\x88\xef\xbc\x9aBEAUTY\xe7\x89\xb9\xe9\x9b\x86\n\xe3\x82\xb3\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x83\xa0\n\xe5\xbc\x81\xe8\xad\xb7\xe5\xa3\xab\xe3\x82\xb9\xe3\x83\x86\xe3\x82\xa3\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x96\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x82\xa8\xe3\x83\x97\xe3\x82\xb9\xe3\x83\x86\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x81\xae\xe7\x9f\xa5\xe3\x81\xa3\xe3\x81\xa6\xe3\x81\xa6\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\xbf\x83!\xe3\x80\x80\xe6\xb3\x95\xe5\xbe\x8b\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\x8d\x97\n\xe7\xb4\x80\xe4\xbc\x8a\xe5\x9c\x8b\xe5\xb1\x8b\xe6\x9b\xb8\xe5\xba\x97 NY\xe6\x9c\xac\xe5\xba\x97\xe3\x83\x97\xe3\x83\xac\xe3\x82\xbc\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x84\xe2\x80\x9c\xe3\x82\x82\xe3\x81\x86\xe8\xaa\xad\xe3\x82\x93\xe3\x81\xa0\xef\xbc\x9f\xe2\x80\x9d\xe5\xa3\xb2\xe3\x82\x8c\xe7\xad\x8bBOOK\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x82\xad\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x82\xb0\nTax Specialist\xe7\xbe\xbd\xe5\xb1\xb1 \xe5\xbe\xb9\xe3\x81\xae\xe7\xa8\x8e\xe9\x87\x91\xe3\x82\x92\xe3\x81\xaf\xe3\x81\x98\xe3\x82\x81\xe3\x81\xa8\xe3\x81\x97\xe3\x81\x9f\xe3\x81\x8a\xe9\x87\x91\xe3\x81\xae\xe8\xa9\xb1\xe3\x81\x82\xe3\x82\x8c\xe3\x81\x93\xe3\x82\x8c\n\xe3\x83\x95\xe3\x82\xa1\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x82\xb7\xe3\x83\xa7\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x82\xbf\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x81\x82\xe3\x82\x84\xe3\x81\x93\xe3\x82\x93\xe3\x81\xb6\xe3\x81\xae\xe2\x80\x9c\xe3\x81\x8a\xe3\x81\x97\xe3\x82\x83\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x83\xad\xef\xbc\x81\xe2\x80\x9d\nDr. \xe7\x9f\xb3\xe8\xb0\xb7\xe4\xb8\x89\xe4\xbd\xb3\xe3\x80\x80\xe3\x81\xaa\xe3\x82\x8b\xe3\x81\xbb\xe3\x81\xa9\xef\xbc\x81\xe3\x82\xb6\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x82\xab\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\xad\nDr.\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x80\x80Dr.\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x81\xae\xe3\x83\x87\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x82\xbf\xe3\x83\xab\xe6\x97\xa5\xe8\xa8\x98\nDr.\xe3\x83\xad\xe3\x83\x90\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x88\xe3\x82\xb3\xe3\x83\xac\xe3\x82\xb9\xe3\x80\x80Dr.Bob\xe3\x81\xae\xe3\x82\xb0\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x89\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x83\x98\xe3\x83\xab\xe3\x82\xb9\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x82\xb0\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x89\xe3\x83\xbb\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\x95\nGulliver USA\xe3\x80\x80\xe8\xbb\x8a\xe3\x81\xae\xe8\xb1\x86\xe7\x9f\xa5\xe8\xad\x98\nDr.\xe9\xab\x98\xe7\x94\xb0\xe6\xb4\x8b\xe5\xb9\xb3\xe3\x80\x80FuncPhysio\xe3\x81\xae\xe6\xb0\x97\xe3\x81\xab\xe3\x81\xaa\xe3\x82\x8b\xe4\xbd\x93\xe3\x81\xae\xe3\x81\xaf\xe3\x81\xaa\xe3\x81\x97\n\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\xab\xb9\xe5\xbd\xa9\xe5\xad\x90\xef\xbc\x88\xe7\x84\xbc\xe9\x85\x8e\xef\xbc\x86\xe3\x82\xbf\xe3\x83\x91\xe3\x82\xb9 \xe5\xbd\xa9\xef\xbc\x89\xe3\x80\x80\xe3\x80\x8c\xe3\x83\x97\xe3\x83\xad\xe3\x80\x8d\xe3\x81\x8c\xe9\x81\xb8\xe3\x81\xb6\xe3\x81\x93\xe3\x81\xae\xe7\x84\xbc\xe9\x85\x8e\xe3\x80\x81\xe3\x81\x93\xe3\x81\xae\xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\x9c\xac\xef\xbc\x81\n\xe9\xa3\xaf\xe5\xb3\xb6\xe7\x9c\x9f\xe7\x94\xb1\xe7\xbe\x8e \xe5\xbc\x81\xe8\xad\xb7\xe5\xa3\xab\xe3\x80\x80Legal Cafe\nJay\xe3\x82\xb7\xe3\x82\xa7\xe3\x83\x95\xe3\x80\x80\xe3\x82\x82\xe3\x81\x86\xe4\xb8\x80\xe5\xba\xa6\xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x9d\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x80\x9c20\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe3\x81\xb6\xe3\x82\x8a\xe3\x81\xae\xe6\x97\xa5\xe6\x9c\xac\xe3\x81\xae\xe7\x94\x9f\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe3\x80\x9c\nUchida Ryuji\xe3\x80\x80Rebirth Room\xe3\x80\x80\xe3\x80\x9c\xe3\x82\xad\xe3\x83\xac\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x81\xae\xe3\x83\x92\xe3\x83\x9f\xe3\x83\x84\xe3\x80\x81\xe6\x95\x99\xe3\x81\x88\xe3\x81\xbe\xe3\x81\x99\xe3\x80\x9c\nZoni \xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\xa8\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xab\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x81\xab\xe3\x81\xaa\xe3\x82\x8b\xe3\x81\x9f\xe3\x82\x81\xe3\x81\xae\xe8\x8b\xb1\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe8\xa9\xb1\xe3\x82\xb5\xe3\x83\x97\xe3\x83\xaa\nBe Fluent NYC"\xe3\x82\x82\xe3\x81\xa3\xe3\x81\xa8Fluent\xe3\x81\xab\xe8\xa9\xb1\xe3\x81\x9d\xe3\x81\x86!"\xe8\x8b\xb1\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe8\xa9\xb1\xe3\x83\xaf\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x9d\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x88\xe3\x82\xa2\xe3\x83\x89\xe3\x83\x90\xe3\x82\xa4\xe3\x82\xb9\n\xe5\xb1\xb1\xe7\x94\xb0\xe6\x81\xb5\xe6\xaf\x94\xe5\xaf\xbf\xe3\x80\x80\xe9\x80\xa3\xe7\xb6\x9a\xe5\xb0\x8f\xe8\xaa\xac\xe3\x80\x80\xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\xa8\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x81\xae\xe7\xa5\x9e\xe6\xa7\x98\n\xe7\x99\xba\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xba\xbaJY\xe3\x81\xae\xe6\x80\x9d\xe3\x81\x84\xe5\x87\xba\xe3\x82\xb4\xe3\x83\xab\xe3\x83\x95\xe6\x97\x85\n\xe5\x81\x8f\xe6\x84\x9b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8a\x87\xe5\xa0\xb4\xe8\xab\x96\n\xe5\xb1\xb1\xe7\x94\xb0\xe9\xa0\x86\xe3\x81\xae\xe3\x80\x8c\xe9\x80\xb1\xe5\x88\x8a \xe6\x9c\xaa\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe5\x9b\xb3\xe3\x80\x8d\n\xe3\x83\x88\xe3\x83\xa9\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x83\x97\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\xb5\xb1\xe9\xa0\x98\xe3\x81\xae\xe3\x81\xa4\xe3\x81\xb6\xe3\x82\x84\xe3\x81\x8d\n\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\x9f\xb3\xe8\x82\xb2\xe5\xad\x90\xe3\x81\xae\xef\xbc\xae\xef\xbc\xb912\xe3\x81\x8b\xe6\x9c\x88\xe3\x81\xae\xe3\x83\x86\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x96\xe3\x83\xab\xe7\x89\xa9\xe8\xaa\x9e\n\xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\xa8\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x81\xab\xe3\x81\xa3\xe3\x81\xbd\xe3\x82\x93\xe4\xba\xba\xe3\x82\x82\xe3\x82\x88\xe3\x81\x86\n\xef\xbd\xb2\xef\xbe\x9d\xef\xbe\x80\xef\xbe\x8b\xef\xbe\x9e\xef\xbd\xad\xef\xbd\xb0\n\xe3\x83\xac\xe3\x83\x9d\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x88\n\xe8\xa1\x97\xe8\xa7\x92\xe3\x82\xb0\xe3\x83\xab\xe3\x83\xa1\n\xe3\x82\xb3\xe3\x83\x9f\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\x86\xe3\x82\xa3\xe3\x83\xac\xe3\x83\x9d\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x88\nNY \xe3\x82\xa6\xe3\x81\x89\xe3\x80\x9c\xe3\x81\x8b\xe3\x80\x9c\n\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x81\xa3\xe3\x81\xa8\xe3\x81\x93\xe8\xa6\x8b\xe3\x81\xa8\xe3\x81\x93\nNY\xe3\x83\x88\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x97\xe3\x82\xb7\xe3\x82\xa7\xe3\x83\x95\xe3\x81\xae\xe5\x8f\xb0\xe6\x89\x80\n\xe8\xaa\xad\xe7\x89\xa9\n\xe3\x81\xb2\xe3\x81\x9d\xe3\x81\xb2\xe3\x81\x9d\xe3\x83\x8f\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x82\xa6\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x89\xe2\x98\x85\xe3\x82\xb4\xe3\x82\xb7\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x97\nNY\xe3\x81\x93\xe3\x81\xbc\xe3\x82\x8c\xe8\xa9\xb1\n\xe3\x82\xb7\xe3\x83\xb3\xe3\x82\xb0\xe3\x83\xab\xe7\x94\xb7\xe5\xa5\xb3\xe3\x81\xae\xe4\xba\x8b\xe6\x83\x85\n\xe3\x81\xa1\xe3\x82\x87\xe3\x81\xa3\xe3\x81\xa8\xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\x81\xaf\n\xe6\xb0\x97\xe3\x81\xab\xe3\x81\xaa\xe3\x82\x8b\xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xb9\xe3\x82\x92\xe3\x83\x94\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x82\xa2\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x97\n\xe7\x99\xbe\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe9\x83\xbd\xe5\xb8\x82\xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\xa8\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x82\xaf\nNY\xe3\x82\x92\xe7\x9f\xa5\xe3\x82\x8b\n\xe6\xb0\x97\xe3\x81\xab\xe3\x81\xaa\xe3\x82\x8b\xe7\xb5\x8c\xe6\xb8\x88\n\xe5\x8c\xbb\xe7\x99\x82/\xe6\x95\x99\xe8\x82\xb2\n\xe3\x81\x82\xe3\x82\x8c\xe3\x81\x93\xe3\x82\x8cNY\xe6\x95\x99\xe8\x82\xb2\xe4\xba\x8b\xe6\x83\x85\n\xe6\x91\xa9\xe5\xa4\xa9\xe6\xa5\xbc\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x83\xaa\xe3\x83\x8b\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x82\xaf\xe3\x80\x8c\xe3\x81\x9f\xe3\x81\xa0\xe3\x81\x84\xe3\x81\xbe\xe8\xa8\xba\xe5\xaf\x9f\xe4\xb8\xad\xe3\x80\x8d\n\xe5\x85\x83\xe6\xb0\x97\xe3\x81\xae\xe9\x81\x93\xe3\x81\x97\xe3\x82\x8b\xe3\x81\xb9\n\xef\xbc\xaf\xef\xbc\xb4\xef\xbc\xa3101 \xe3\x83\x95\xe3\x82\xa1\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x9e\xe3\x82\xb7\xe3\x83\xbc\xe6\x8e\xa2\xe8\xa8\xaa with \xe3\x81\xb2\xe3\x81\x90\xe3\x81\xa1\xe5\x85\x88\xe7\x94\x9f\nMy \xe9\xa4\x8a\xe7\x94\x9f\xe3\x83\xbb\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe9\xa4\x8a\xe7\x94\x9f\n\xe3\x83\x9a\xe3\x83\x83\xe3\x83\x88\n\xe3\x82\x8f\xe3\x81\x9f\xe3\x81\x97\xe3\x81\xae\xe5\xae\xb6\xe6\x97\x8f\nSave A Life\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Daily Sun New York. All rights reserved.', b"The Future Of Cities: Tapping The Transformative Power Of Exponential Technologies\nVideo\nWebinars\nStart A Business\nSubscribe\nBooks\nMy Account\nEntrepreneur Insider\nSaved Content\nMy Account\nSign Out\nVideo\nPodcasts\nArticles\nStart A Business\nStore\nBooks\nWomen Entrepreneur\nGreen Entrepreneur\nAsk An Expert\nShop Entrepreneur\nFranchise\nFranchise Home\nFranchise 500 Ranking\nBusiness Opportunities List\nFranchises For Sale\nProducts\nNetwork\nPodcasts\nBooks\nConnect\nEntrepreneur Insurance\nEvents\nSpotlight\nTopics\nLeadership\nInspiration\nGrowth Strategies\nMarketing\nTechnology\nSocial Media\nFinance\nEntrepreneurs\nStarting a Business\nFranchise\nMagazine\nIssues\nSubscribe\nGift Subscription\nSubscription Services\nNewsletter\nSubscribe\nEditions\nUnited States\nIndia\nAsia Pacific\nMiddle East\nEurope\nSouth Africa\nEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nGeorgia\nPhilippines\nOther\nContact\nAdvertise\nReprints & Licensing\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nCookies Policy\nSite Map\nMy Queue\nArticles\nVideos\nPodcasts\nAuthors\nThere are no Videos in your queue.\nClick on the Add to next to any video to save to your queue.\nSee Latest Videos\nThere are no Articles in your queue.\nClick on the Add to next to any article to save to your queue.\nSee Latest Articles\nThere are no Podcasts in your queue.\nClick on the Add to next to any podcast episode to save to your queue.\nSee Latest Podcasts\nYou're not following any authors.\nClick the Follow button on any author page to keep up with the latest content from your favorite authors.\nSmart City\nThe Future Of Cities: Tapping The Transformative Power Of Exponential Technologies\nNext Article\n--shares\nAdd to Queue\nImage credit:\ngraphicstock\nDr. Peter H. Diamandis\nCo-founder and Executive Chairman at Singularity University\nJuly\n22, 2018\n7 min read\nOpinions expressed by Entrepreneur contributors are their own.\nYou're reading Entrepreneur Middle East, an international franchise of Entrepreneur Media.\nIf you could build a city from the ground up using first principles, how would you do it? What would it look like? By 2050, two-thirds of the population, more than six billion people, are expected to live in urbanized areas. Exponential technologies will radically change the way we build and organize our cities in the future. In this article, I will cover mass urbanization trends, building future cities, and exponential technology implications.Considering the transformative power of exponential technologies, is it better to take a top-down approach when designing cities, or a bottom-up approach? Let\xe2\x80\x99s dive in.Mass urbanization Cities currently house over 50% of the world\xe2\x80\x99s population, and generate 80% of the world\xe2\x80\x99s GDP. The UN estimates that continuing urbanization and population growth will add 2.5 billion people to the world\xe2\x80\x99s urban population by 2050, with nearly 90% of the increase concentrated in Asia and Africa. While the city population is growing dramatically, the footprint of the city (the number of square kilometers it covers) will grow at a faster rate, ultimately causing the city densities (people per square kilometer) to decline. The expected increase in urban land during the first three decades of the 21st century will be greater than the cumulative urban expansion in all of human history.This poses a unique challenge for sustainability endeavors, as low-density cities tend to produce higher carbon emissions than higher-density cities of a similar population size. By 2050, the UN projects that demand for water and energy will increase by 55%. By 2035, the demand for energy will increase by 33%. As people migrate to cities, existing infrastructure will need to be improved, or we will face significant shortages. Technology has the potential to dramatically reduce the downsides of urbanization. With big data, ubiquitous sensors, computer intelligence, and transportation technology (autonomous cars, flying cars, Hyperloop, and so on), we can imagine central systems that are far more efficient and offer far greater performance than the ones around today.Building future citiesFour recent projects in this area have caught my eye:1. Sidewalk labsSidewalk Labs is Alphabet\xe2\x80\x99s urban development organization that seeks to imagine what cities would look like if they were built \xe2\x80\x9cfrom the internet up.\xe2\x80\x9d In 2012, Sidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s subsidiary Intersection began converting old payphones into free, technologically advanced access points, complete with video call capability and screamingfast Wi-Fi. Over the next several years, 7,500 \xe2\x80\x9clinks\xe2\x80\x9d will be installed throughout New York City. In October 2017, Sidewalk announced its plans to build a tech-centered neighborhood southeast of downtown Toronto called Quayside. Waterfront Toronto, Sidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s partner in the project, said that the city will be \xe2\x80\x9ca testbed for emerging technologies, materials and processes that will address these challenges and advance solutions that can be replicated in cities worldwide.\xe2\x80\x9d2. Bill Gates & Belmont Partners Bill Gates recently announced his commitment of US$80 million to build a \xe2\x80\x9csmart city\xe2\x80\x9d just outside of Phoenix, Arizona with the help of Belmont Partners, a real estate investing group. In a press release, the company described the city as a \xe2\x80\x9cforward-thinking community with a communication and infrastructure spine that embraces cutting-edge technology, designed around high-speed digital networks, data centers, new manufacturing technologies and distribution models, autonomous vehicles and autonomous logistics hubs.\xe2\x80\x9d Unlike Sidewalk\xe2\x80\x99s project in Toronto, this city would literally be built from the ground up\xe2\x80\x93 currently, the 24,800-acre site is a patch of empty land in the desert. Grady Gammage, a spokesperson for the Belmont Partners, argues that this fact gives the company a unique advantage: \xe2\x80\x9cEnvisioning future infrastructure from scratch is far easier and more cost efficient than retrofitting an existing urban fabric.\xe2\x80\x9d Eventually, the city (currently called Belmont) will boast 80,000 homes, 3,800 acres of industrial, office, and retail space, and 470 acres for public schools.3. Dubai's 'Smart Dubai 2021' PlanOver the next decade, Dubai will look more and more like it came from a sci-fi movie.The city has laid out 2021 goals that include: - 3D-printing 25% of the city\xe2\x80\x99s buildings- Making 25% of transportation trips automated and driverless- Installing hundreds of artificial trees that use solar power to provide the city with free Wi-Fi, screens with mapping information, and ports for charging phones- Integrating passenger drones that can carry individuals into their public transportation system- Becoming one of the top 10 sustainable cities by 2020- Becoming the happiest city on Earth With this top-down approach, Dubai is setting a prime example for other governments around the world to follow. As other nations see Dubai\xe2\x80\x99s tourism and efficiency exponentially increase, I\xe2\x80\x99m confident that other cities will follow suit.\xc2\xa0And, as cities begin to intelligently incorporate big data into their infrastructure, they will become more efficient, sustainable and prosperous.4. Kingdom of Saudi Arabia's Neom Project Saudi Arabia is also redesigning the ideal future city with NEOM, a $500 billion independent economic zone currently under construction in a 26,500 sq. km. area in Tabuk. This tech utopia, part of the Saudi Vision 2030 plan, will be powered solely by sustainable energy. Economic incentives in nine sectors aim to reduce regional dependence on oil, while an open source approach invites global data scientists and entrepreneurs to catalyze urban innovation. Other goals in the NEOM road map:- Automate and democratize access to government services- Free highest-speed Internet and free online continuous education for residents- Net-zero carbon footprint on all buildings- A transportation system built in anticipation of future mobility platforms, with a layout equally suitable for pedestrians, cyclists and commutersSaudi Arabia is already demonstrating how legacy regulations and linear systems must adapt to our exponential future. In November 2017, Saudi Arabia granted the first citizenship to Sophia, a humanoid robot by Hanson Robotics. In June 2018, many Saudi women drove for the first time, as a decades-old ban was lifted by royal decree. How will futuristic, open source, utopian cities like NEOM and Dubai interface with linear, slow-moving governments? How will the rise of such global innovation hotbeds rebalance economic activity and investments?Implications and big questionsThe implications of exponential technology on cities are vast. In our lifetimes, we will see exciting developments that blur the lines between science fiction and reality. If I was starting a city from scratch, here are the questions I would ask and think about. What about you?- Would you begin with a Massively Transformative Purpose (MTP) for the city?- Would you incorporate a city-wide Token/Coin and do an ICO for city services?- Would you make human driven cars illegal?- Would all-autonomous cars allow the elimination of all parking lots, parking garages and street parking?- Do you need traffic lights?- Would you make the city and all transportation 100% renewable electric, with maximum solar penetration?- Would you put a Hyperloop station at the center of the city plan?- How would you leverage AR & VR for creating citizen avatars that potentially disrupt transportation even further?- Would you require vertical farming to generate 50% of the food supply?- Would you offer wireless gigabit services for free within the city footprint?- How would you enable movement of human capital to encourage innovation?- How would you deliver education? (Wait for my next article for my thoughts on this.) We must ask all these questions as we adapt to large and fast-growing city populations.Some cities, like the ones I\xe2\x80\x99ve mentioned above, have a head start on this with their proxy MTP announcements. Will they attract better talent, or dominate future trade? How will these implications change the geopolitics in an oil-based region like the Middle East? To me, one thing is crystal clear: the future of cities is an exciting place for innovation and disruption.This is the first in a four-part series by Peter H. Diamandis, M.D., co-founder and Executive Chairman at Singularity University, on how exponential technologies will create abundance and opportunities for entrepreneurs and governments alike. Dr. Diamandis will be in Dubai on Oct 29-30, 2018. Contact team@a360dubai.com with comments or feedback.Related:\xc2\xa0The Future Of (Public) Innovation Labs\nMore from Entrepreneur\nKathleen, Founder and CEO of Grayce & Co, a media and marketing consultancy, can help you develop a brand strategy, build marketing campaigns and learn how to balance work and life.\nBook Your Session\nJumpstart Your Business. Do you have critical gaps in your coverage? Dr. Aisha Bin Bishr On Smart Dubai Office's Citywide Blockchain Implementation\nHabits\nBill and Melinda Gates Just Gave Us New Insight Into Their Evening Routine and, of Course, It's Genius", b'50 Years of Armstrong Rapid Manufacturing - TCT Magazine\nSkip to main content\nSearch\nfacebook\ntwitter\nyoutube\ngoogle_plus\nlinkedin\nMenu\nNews\nImaging\nSoftware\nServices\nEvents\nTCT Show\nTCT Awards\nTCT Asia\nRAPID + TCT\nTCT Conference @ Formnext\nBlogs\nDaniel O\'Connor\'s Blog\nLaura Griffiths\' Blog\nSam Davies\' Blog\nThe Todd Grimm Column\nJim Woodcock\'s Blog\nDuncan Wood\'s Blog\nGuest Blogs\nAwards\nTCT Hall of Fame\nWebinars\nDirectory\nSubscribe\nMag\nHome Services 50 Years of Armstrong Rapid Manufacturing\n50 Years of Armstrong Rapid Manufacturing\n"We like to think of ourselves as a fine blend of the 14th and 21st Centuries."\nby\nLaura Griffiths\n23 July 2018\n14:35\nBack to Search Results\nRSS\nPrint\n\xc3\x97\nExpand\nThe last 50 years have seen many technological milestones. In 1968, man was yet to walk on the moon, computers were enormous, and the plastics industry was about to boom. For a family business in Syracuse, NY, 1968 would mark the beginning of legacy as a leading manufacturing supplier to some of the biggest companies in the world.\nFounded by John and Betty Armstrong, who came to the U.S. from Coventry, UK, where John started out as a Wood and Metal Pattern Maker apprentice, Armstrong RM began with modest dreams of building a small firm of five. Today, as the company celebrates its 50th anniversary, Armstrong employs over 150 people, headed up by the family\xe2\x80\x99s next generation.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was 9-years-old and with my dad at the plant when the first equipment was delivered,\xe2\x80\x9d Peter Armstrong, President of Armstrong RM recalls. \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t have a clue what it was. Today, decades later, I still see some of that original equipment as I walk around our plant.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWhen Armstrong started out, the company intended to make cast moulds for plastic moulding, but soon got into the RIM (Reaction Injection Moulding) process when a customer problem turned into an opportunity. A clothing designer came to Armstrong to produce a mannequin mould but soon struggled to find anyone to run the body forms. A short conversation with a local material supplier later and a 50-piece order for RIM polyurethane was made.\nAfter a few successful years, it was decided that getting into the casting business, where John had started off at Sims Castings in the early 60s, would be the way to go when a sales rep showed up at the Armstrong home in Minoa with 37 aluminium casting jobs to quote for technology giant, IBM. The team can still remember the meeting in the Armstrong family living room going on until the early hours when what was thought to be an initial order for a handful of the most suitable parts ended with IBM ordering quantities of all 37.\n\xc3\x97\nExpand\nArmstrong production facility.\nDuring the 1970s, the company expanded, leasing a new facility and ramping its team up to around 75 employees. Throughout the next decade, rapid growth continued as Armstrong became a primary supplier to companies at the beginning of the telecomm technology explosion. Additional locations were sought, and a machine shop was added.\nArmstrong currently boasts a state-of-the-art 100,000 square ft. manufacturing facility featuring numerous casting, moulding, machining and rapid prototyping processes for prototypes and low volume metal or plastic production, along with a recently acquired space in Hingham, MA. TCT paid a visit to the new office last year where examples of handcrafted wooden models and plastic prototypes provided a clear view of how the company has evolved over the years.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe try to utilise any technology that helps us fulfil our mission,\xe2\x80\x9d Paul Armstrong, Director of Marketing told TCT. \xe2\x80\x9cWe find that many time-tested older methods like casting aluminium can provide the best path to manufacture a part especially if taking advantage of more 21st century technology in the process such as AM models, CMM inspection or CNC Machining. We like to think of ourselves as a fine blend of the 14th and 21st Centuries.\xe2\x80\x9d\nArmstrong has always been about embracing old school craftsmanship with modern technologies. In 1994, the company was the first manufacturer in New York State to purchase and utilise a 3D Systems stereolithography machine. Being an early adopter meant Armstrong spent much of the decade focussing on its rapid prototyping business, creating models for manufacturing cast injection moulds in a variety of consumer related applications from Black and Decker to Whirlpool, and McDonalds.\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstalling 3D Systems equipment was significant as it was new, exciting technology that our customers were just learning about,\xe2\x80\x9d Peter explained. \xe2\x80\x9cIt positioned us as an early technology leader, pulled in a lot of customer interest and was a significant advancement to improve our services and reduce lead times.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xc3\x97\nExpand\nArmstrong was an early adopter of SLA technology.\nNowadays you would be hard pressed to find an area within which Armstrong hasn\xe2\x80\x99t made some form of model or part, whether it\xe2\x80\x99s in space on the NASA shuttle; protecting the homeland under oceans on submarines; or cast hubcaps for President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s inaugural limo.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver the years, we have made so many interesting parts for the cutting-edge technology of the time,\xe2\x80\x9d Paul added. \xe2\x80\x9cMost recently we have been working with Rethink Robotics of Boston in developing and launching the Sawyer robot, we worked with Civiq Cityscapes on the Link NYC kiosks all over greater New York City. My favourite part we made in the early days was a cast aluminium guitar body for a local guitar maker named Jim Brunet. He gave one of his first guitars to Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones who used it that night at their concert at the Carrier Dome in front of 50,000 fans.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBy the end of the 90s, Armstrong had grown to 240 employees with sales over 20 million USD but technological shifts and major events in U.S. history, meant that by the early 2000s, the industry landscape looked very different. As Armstrong describes, \xe2\x80\x9cthe honeymoon in manufacturing was over.\xe2\x80\x9d But the lean period - \xe2\x80\x9clean\xe2\x80\x9d still meaning 150 employees - was by no means the end and as the country started to get its mojo back, so did Armstrong. The company carved itself a reputation within a highly competitive, technology driven market, which saw huge orders from those initial blue-chip customers like IBM. By 2008, Armstrong reached a high-water mark with sales close to 30 million USD.\n\xc3\x97\nExpand\nHandcrafted wooden pattern.\nToday, customers include the likes of Uber, Rethink Robotics, Medtronic and Boeing, still comprising that old school mentality with modern solutions whether making one or 1,000 parts. The company has grown from a \xe2\x80\x9cmom and pop\xe2\x80\x9d shop into a modern manufacturing facility, but there are still new challenges, particularly in exciting the next generation to get involved in manufacturing and engineering.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSkilled labour is much scarcer as manufacturing has been perceived as a declining career path when in fact with the advent of all the new advanced manufacturing technologies the high skilled opportunities are endless,\xe2\x80\x9d Paul commented.\nArmstrong\xe2\x80\x99s motto is, \xe2\x80\x9ca strong future stands behind us.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s a history of experience, knowledge and of course, mistakes made, but Armstrong is by no means resting on its laurels. It can\xe2\x80\x99t, the manufacturing industry is constantly changing and in the current age of automation and new processes coming in at a rapid rate, the team is not afraid of getting stuck into the latest technology or opportunity.\nPaul concludes: \xe2\x80\x9cAll of that drives us forward, to keep providing high quality castings and moulded plastics parts as we head into our next 50 years.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTags\n3D Printing\nAdditive Manufacturing\nArmstrong Mold\n3D Printing News\nby\nLaura Griffiths\n23 July 2018\n14:35\nLatest\nView more\nAccept Cookies?YesWaitLeave\nNews\nImaging\nSoftware\nServices\nEvents\nTCT Show\nTCT Awards\nTCT Asia\nRAPID + TCT\nTCT Conference @ Formnext\nBlogs\nDaniel O\'Connor\'s Blog\nLaura Griffiths\' Blog\nSam Davies\' Blog\nThe Todd Grimm Column\nJim Woodcock\'s Blog\nDuncan Wood\'s Blog\nGuest Blogs\nAwards\nTCT Hall of Fame\nWebinars\nDirectory\nSubscribe\nMag\nAbout Us\nAdvertise with TCT\nContact Us\nPartners\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms & Conditions\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Rapid News Publications Ltd. A Rapid News Communications Group Company. All Rights Reserved\nBuilt with Metro Publisher\xe2\x84\xa2', b"Smart Cities Are Coming, and They'll Need Data Centers \xe2\x80\xa2 Data Center Frontier\nAbout Us\nSponsorship Opportunities\nPrivacy Policy\nData Center FrontierCharting the future of data centers and cloud computing.\nHome\nEnergy\nDesign\nServers\nStorage\nNetwork\nCooling\nCloud\nHyperscale\nTechnology\nInternet of Things\nAI & Machine Learning\nEdge Computing\nVirtual Reality\nAutonomous Cars\n5G Wireless\nColo\nSite Selection\nVoices\nWhite Papers\nResources\nEvents\nNewsletter\nCompanies\nData Center 101\nJobs\nYou are here: Home / 5G Wireless / Smart Cities Are Coming, and They\xe2\x80\x99ll Need Data Centers\nSmart Cities Are Coming, and They\xe2\x80\x99ll Need Data Centers\nBy Rich Miller - July 23, 2018 1 Comment Smart cities technologies seek to bring intelligence into urban landscapes with networks of sensors and data analytics. (Photo of Hong Kong via Pixabay)\nLinkedinTwitterFacebookSubscribeMail\nThe street light may not look like technology. But many technologists believe the humble street light will illuminate the future of smart cities.\nThese new smart street lights come equipped with energy-efficient LED bulbs, which last longer and use less power than traditional street lights. But there\xe2\x80\x99s more: these light poles can also include built-in wireless connectivity (Bluetooth and wifi), high-definition digital cameras, and sensors to monitor weather and air quality. Most smart street lights come with a control network that can connect a city-wide array of sensors, and analytics packages.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe real killer app for smart cities is smart street lighting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sean Tippett, the Director of Smart Cities and IoT at Silver Spring Networks, which specializes in Internet of Things (IoT) solutions for business. \xe2\x80\x9cIt pays for itself, and then you have an IoT network in place.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSmart street lights are the leading edge of an ambitious vision for smart cities, with the IoT bringing intelligence to everything from trash cans to park benches to dedicated ad-supported wifi kiosks like the LinkNYC or CIVIQ SmartScapes. The goal is to allow cities to use sensors and data analysis to bring intelligence to urban environments, and improve the quality of life for residents.\n\xe2\x80\x9cA smart city harnesses the power of its data to run more efficiently,\xe2\x80\x9d said Melvin Greer, Chief Data Scientist at Intel Corp. \xe2\x80\x9cEvery company and every city is now data-centric.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a vision that will arrive slowly, and in phases. The first phase involves deploying networks of sensors to collect data.\nThe trajectory of smart cities has been further transformed by the rise of autonomous vehicles, which have the potential to bring transformational changes in how cities are designed and function. Futurists and smart cities advocates foresee a future in which self-driving cars communicate with one another and the infrastructure around them. Imagine an urban landscape in which cars communicate with streetlights to improve traffic flow, and use sensors to locate empty parking spaces \xe2\x80\x93 and naturally, park themselves.\nThe realization of data flowing from vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) could be decades away. But it underscores the disruptive potential of combining the Internet of Things and autonomous cars.\nA New Role for Data Centers\nSmart cities are a key component of our digital future, bringing together the Internet of Things, BigData, artificial intelligence and self-driving cars to change the way we live and do business in major urban centers.\nData centers will be major beneficiaries of the emergence of smart cities, which will require lots of connectivity, data storage and compute power for analytics to crunch all that data. How big is this opportunity, and when will it arrive?\nFree Resource from Data Center Frontier White Paper Library\nSlow Provisioning Derails IT Transformation Efforts\nIn this report, 451 Research analyst Christian Perry underscores the negative impact slow provisioning can have on your IT transformation efforts using results from their recent Voice of the Enterprise survey of over 500 enterprises. Download the new white paper from Cyxtera that contends it's time for groundbreaking innovation in data center colocation that overcomes slow provisioning.\nDownload\nTo answer these questions, Data Center Frontier has spent the past 18\xc2\xa0 months speaking with leading technologists, vendors and public officials to understand how the evolution of smart cities may change the data center landscape. We\xe2\x80\x99ve attended conferences like the Industry of Things World and Internet of Things World, along with data center industry events.\nThe bottom line: True smart cities will arrive slowly, and face challenges in gaining funding and political support. But early adopters are already deploying networks of sensors and devices to lay the groundwork for more ambitious smart infrastructure ahead.\n\xe2\x80\x9cData centers that support smart cities can\xe2\x80\x99t be designed on power and real estate concerns,\xe2\x80\x9d said Intel\xe2\x80\x99s Greer. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll be designed in a much smaller footprint and focused on a much more concentrated series of concerns. In the smart cities of the future, the data will be more important than the center.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBeyond the Hype: Making Smart Cities Real\nThe smart city is an urban development that integrates information technology and the Internet of things (IoT) into the fabric of city life, using analytics and sensors to better manage cities and make urban ife safer, more efficient and sustainable. It\xe2\x80\x99s just one more expression of how next-generation technologies are remaking the American landscape.\nAs with most new technologies, the smart cities movement has generated excitement about the possibilities.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople want their pizza delivered in two minutes, by a drone\xe2\x80\x9d said Lou Lutostanski, Vice President for Internet of Things at Avnet. \xe2\x80\x9cTechnology is no longer a limiter. Our imagination is the only limitation.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLinkNYC kiosks are deployed at 7,500 locations across Manhattan, replacing payphones with ad-supported wifi and services. (Photo: Rich Miller)\nBut it\xe2\x80\x99s easier to imagine technology than build it and pay for it. So it will be with smart cities, which will emerge gradually.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think we\xe2\x80\x99re at approximately the peak of the hype cycle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sharelynn Moore, VP of Global Marketing at Itron, a leading vendor in the IoT and smart cities sector. \xe2\x80\x9cBut there is real business to be had here. There\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of really amazing things coming. The cost and power of the technology has come down enough to make it work.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you get the infrastructure overlay, these applications will appear,\xe2\x80\x9d Moore added. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are on-ramps that can get you started. But we are just getting started on innovation.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSilver Spring\xe2\x80\x99s Tippett says smart city strategies will serve as an economic development tool.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe see very progressive, forward-looking cities seeing this as an innovation point and a differentiator, using early investments to attract developers and businesses,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tippett.\nLeading With Lighting\nA lot of those early investments are in smart lighting projects, which can piggyback on a larger trend to convert legacy streetlights to LED to reduce energy costs.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe do a lot of work in the connected lighting sector, and we\xe2\x80\x99re seeing it continue to grow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tippett, who sees an opportunity in providing monitoring and management to cities, which often don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do it themselves. As connected things proliferate, it\xe2\x80\x99s not a small job.\nEarly projects have been promising. In 2014, San Diego installed a network of 3,000 smart streetlights from GE, which is now saving the city about $250,000 annually in electricity and maintenance costs (since outages are reported electronically, allowing targeted truck rolls for repairs during daylight hours).\nOther cities are beginning to install these systems at scale. Officials in Edinburgh, Scotland are deploying a network of 64,000 smart street lights from Telensa, complete with wireless nodes to provide wifi for residents.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf all of our vision for the IoT comes to pass, there will be a lot of devices out there, and scalability becomes important,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tippett. \xe2\x80\x9cThere needs to be a very strong emphasis on security. The technology provider has a responsibility to ensure that the solution is secure and can scale.\xe2\x80\x9d\nClearing the Confusion on the Tech & the Opportunity\nThe expo hall at Internet of Things World stretches across much of the Santa Clara Convention Center. As you walk past booth after booth of connected things, it\xe2\x80\x99s a dazzling array of IoT tech. Some of it is super cool, while some leaves you scratching your head.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re really trying to grapple with all this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jon Walton, CIO of San Mateo County. \xe2\x80\x9cSo much of the stuff we see on the expo floor is so new. We don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\xe2\x80\x99s really going to be around. The IoT is actually far ahead of where government wants to engage.\xe2\x80\x9d\nKitra RushUp is an Internet of Things platform based on Samsung\xe2\x80\x99s ARTIK technology that uses sensors to manage lighting and security and provide data on weather and environmental emissions, as seen in this demo overlay of data collection in San Francisco. (Photo: Rich Miller)\nOn a panel of municipal officials, Walton said that learning curve is a challenge for cities seeking to evangelize a smart cities strategy.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need executive sponsorship and strong leaders,\xe2\x80\x9d said Walton. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have to make IoT tangible. IT in government has always been seen as an expense. The conversation we\xe2\x80\x99re having now is \xe2\x80\x98are some of these a service?\xe2\x80\x99 If we\xe2\x80\x99re not going to try to monetize IoT, maybe we focus on providing a benefit, rather than advertising or business models.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWalton and San Mateo County have developed a \xe2\x80\x9cSmart Region Model\xe2\x80\x9d to focus on agencies working together to use shared technology resources to solve regional problems. The concept brings together\xc2\xa0smart parking solutions, smart street lights, waste management, energy management and asset tracking.\nFinding the Funding, and the Business Model\nIn an era of tight budgets for cities and counties, a key question is how governments will fund their investment in smart city initiatives.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the ROI (return on investment) on public wifi versus affordable housing?\xe2\x80\x9d Walton said. The key selling point will initially be financial efficiency \xe2\x80\x93 finding better and cheaper ways to provide services. Some IOT-driven services may provide opportunities for monetization through public-private partnerships (PPPs) that offer a public benefit while providing a financial incentive for the business partner.\nOne option is creating wired innovation districts that can attract startups and other connected businesses. Many early monetization strategies focus on the sale or exchange of data gathered through sensor networks, which raises privacy questions.\nDavid Tolson of DBT-DATA.\nDave Tolson of DBT Data has a unique perspective on the smart cities discussion. For many years, Tolson built upscale housing in urban markets, before shifting his focus to data center development. Building truly smart cities will require serious investment in infrastructure, Tolson said, which is not an area where government has a strong track record \xe2\x80\x93 with the exception of cities preparing for the Olympics or Super Bowls.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the federal, state and local level, there\xe2\x80\x99s not enough money to update infrastructure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tolson. \xe2\x80\x9cThe return would be phenomenal. It\xe2\x80\x99s intelligent and profitable to do. But where is the money going to come from? It can\xe2\x80\x99t come completely from the private sector.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a little skeptical,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe opportunity is currently very limited.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe Evolving Role of the Data Center\nWhat does this mean for data center economics? A number of developers and service providers are positioning themselves to benefit from demand for urban IT infrastructure. Smart cities are a particular flavor of edge computing, with the accompanying focus on right sizing the data center form factor.\nWhen it comes to data center infrastructure, smart cities will mix the old and the new, creating opportunities for traditional \xe2\x80\x9ccore\xe2\x80\x9d connectivity hubs as well as smaller data centers\xc2\xa0 optimized for edge computing.\nMulti-tenant carrier hotels\xc2\xa0have been\xc2\xa0cornerstones of the Internet economy since the 1990s, and are some of the most successful properties in the colocation industry. Typically located in the central business district of major cities, buildings like One Wilshire (LA) and 60 Hudson Street (New York) and the Dallas Infomart, these buildings house meet-me rooms, a common area where providers can make physical connections between their networks.\nExecutives at Netrality, which owns carrier hotels in five U.S. markets, say its facilities are positioned to benefit as smart city technologies are deployed.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll these applications are highly-dependent on low-latency connectivity,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gerald Marshall, President and CEO of Netrality. We\xe2\x80\x99re starting to see the infrastructure to support these initiatives in our properties.\xe2\x80\x9d\nA Hangar drone hovering in front of the Vapor Edge Module. (Image: Hangar)\nAt the other end of the spectrum are micro data centers that will help deploy infrastructure for 5G wireless connectivity\xc2\xa0and low-latency applications.\nEdge computing specialist Vapor IO\xc2\xa0has begun deploying unmanned \xe2\x80\x9clights-out\xe2\x80\x9d data center modules\xc2\xa0 in downtown Chicago, including a test site that serves as a launchpad for drone startup Hangar.\xc2\xa0 In an early example of infrastructure for a robot-powered smart city, the two companies are creating an edge computing network to manage drones as they fly missions to collect and analyze oceans of business data.\nThe companies see the collaboration as the first step towards a larger network to manage an automated society.\xc2\xa0Hangar\xe2\x80\x99s real-time tracking system is currently focused on drones, but can also be used to support autonomous cars.\nIntel\xe2\x80\x99s Greer said data center modules are part of an exploding ecosystem of devices and vehicles that will comprise the smart cities to come.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSmart cities are going to disrupt this idea of the huge, monolithic data center,\xe2\x80\x9d said Greer. \xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The iPhone X isn\xe2\x80\x99t a smartphone. It\xe2\x80\x99s an artificial intelligence device. The (car) key is a sensor. It knows when you are in proximity to your vehicle. This is the future.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLinkedinTwitterFacebookSubscribeMail\nTagged With: Netrality, smart cities, Vapor IO\nStay informed: Get our news updates!\n* indicates required\nEmail Address\n*\nFirst Name\nLast Name\nAre you a new reader? Follow Data Center Frontier on Twitter or Facebook.\nAbout Rich MillerI write about the places where the Internet lives, telling the story of data centers and the people who build them. I founded Data Center Knowledge, the data center industry's leading news site. Now I'm exploring the future of cloud computing at Data Center Frontier.\nComments\nJohn Laban says\nJuly 27, 2018 at 12:26 pm\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s very exciting watching the Telecommunications Service Providers creating\nEdge Data Centres at such huge scale in the world\xe2\x80\x99s cities (see http://www.opencord.org). The tens of thousands of Open Edge CORD Data Centres dwarf all other Edge Data Centres combined.\nReply\nLeave a Reply Cancel reply\nYour email address will not be published. Required fields are marked *Comment Name *\nEmail *\nWebsite\nFacebookGoogle+LinkedInPinterestTwitter\nVoices of the Industry\nPublic Sector & Government Data Center Trends: IT Modernization Initiatives\nAs innovation and demand for information technology continues to increase, IT departments of all sizes are facing incredible pressure to finish building a new way of delivering services. \xc2\xa0Isaac Negusse, Director, Federal Data Center Practice at Iron Mountain, discusses IT modernization initiatives in the public sector.\nDCF Spotlight\nNorthern Virginia Data Center Market: The Focal Point for Cloud Growth\nThe Northern Virginia data center market is seeing a surge in supply and an even bigger surge in demand. Data Center Frontier explores trends, stats and future expectations for the No. 1 data center market in the country.\nEdge Computing is Poised to Remake the Data Center Landscape\nData center leaders are investing in edge computing and edge solutions and actively looking at new ways to deploy edge capacity to support evolving business and user requirements.\nSee More Spotlight Features\nWhite Papers\nData Center Evaluation Checklist Makes Comparison Easy\nThe use of colocation services has continued to increase, rapidly becoming the solution of choice for organizations requiring an efficient, secure and cost-effective way to manage their IT infrastructure. Colocation providers deliver a stable foundation upon which you can support your core business and execute on your IT strategy \xe2\x80\x93 but not all data center service providers are created equal.\xc2\xa0Download the new white paper from Cyxtera that provides a data center checklist to ensure you cover all selection criteria as you tour various facilities.\nDownload\nSee More White Papers \xc2\xbb\nGet the Latest News from DCF\nFirst Name:\nLast Name:\nEmail address:\nLeave this field empty if you're human:\nJob Listings\nJob Openings | Peter Kazella and Associates, Inc\nElectrical Commissioning Engineer - New York, NYData Center Construction Project Manager - Longmont, COMechanical Engineer - New York, NYUPS Field Service Technician - Phoenix, AZFacility Manager - Los Angeles, CA\nSee More Jobs\nData Center 101\nData Center 101: Mastering the Basics of the Data Center IndustryData Center Frontier, in partnership with Open Spectrum, brings our readers a series that provides an introductory guidebook to the ins and outs of the data center and colocation industry. UsContact UsAdvertiseTerms and ConditionsCommenting GuidelinesSitemap\nFollow Metro on\nFacebook\nTwitter\nGoogle Plus\nInstagram\nLinkedIn\nContact Us Email\nNew York\nThis New York Fortnite tournament will have $10,000 in prizes\nWhy pwn noobs on your sofa when you can dish it out in person to win prizes at New York's Fortnite In the Heights tournament?\nBy Eva Kis\nPublished : July 23, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nMore\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsapp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\nYou don't need to be NFL Player Donte Deayon to participate in New York's Fortnite In The Heights\xc2\xa0Tournament.\nJerritt Clark, Getty Images\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nFortnite is, to put it mildly, everywhere. Got skills? Why pwn the noobs from your couch when you could do it in front of an audience of hundreds at New York\xe2\x80\x99s first-ever Fortnite In The Heights Tournament?\nComing on Saturday, Aug. 11 to the Armory New Balance Track & Field Center in Washington Heights, Fortnite In The Heights invites all gamers to bring their iOS device or Nintendo Switch to battle it out for a prize pool of $10,000. Tickets are $15, and anyone can sign up to play (limited only by the Armory\xe2\x80\x99s capacity).\nOrganized by Silicon Harlem, The Armory Foundation, iHeartRadio and LinkNYC, the tournament will be livestreamed on The Armory\xe2\x80\x99s Jumbotron and on Twitch. Doors open at 11 a.m., which also starts the clock on the two-hour preliminary round of games to qualify for the tournament. The top 400 players will move forward, with the winner decided at 5 p.m.\nRecommended Slideshows\n40 PicturesPHOTOS: Blues dump Bruins to win Stanley Cup after agonizing 52-year wait40 Pictures\n8 PicturesPHOTOS: This Pakistani waiter looks just like Peter Dinklage8 Pictures\n36 PicturesAll of these celebrities have had their nudes leaked36 PicturesMore picture galleries\n16 PicturesThese photos of Trump and Ivanka will make you deeply uncomfortable\n16 Pictures\n4 PicturesCuba Gooding Jr. charged in Manhattan groping incident, police say4 Pictures\n2 Pictures4 fun things to do in the Lehigh Valley2 Pictures\nThere is no age limit to participate, but players younger than 18 must have a parent or guardian accompany them or a permission slip allowing them to play. Spectator tickets are $15; a DJ and emcee will provide entertainment, and \xe2\x80\x9chealthy snacks\xe2\x80\x9d will be available for purchase.\nEpic Games\xe2\x80\x99 free-to-play video game Fortnite has become a global sensation, making $223 million in March alone. The premise of the game is simple: 100 players are dropped on an island and must fight to be the last man (or woman, but mostly teenage boy) standing.\nThe idea behind the event is at least in part to encourage taking part in what can legitimately be called sports here in the real world (which is reeling a bit because of Fortnite, ironically). Fortnite In The Heights is a \xe2\x80\x9ccommunity-driven, family-friendly event, is designed to combine gaming, technology, and fitness for all,\xe2\x80\x9d according to the organizers. Early arrivals can even opt to run a few laps around the Armory track.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith more than 180,000 athlete visits each year to The Armory, many of whom are also eSports players, this will be a social competition for them,\xe2\x80\x9d says Armory Foundation Co-President Jonathan Schindel in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cThe seating configuration and technology at The Armory are ideal for eSports, and I expect we will also convert some of the gamers into trying out track and field.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLoading...\nLatest From ...\nNews\nShare Now\nShare this 1007.728,78-0,12%\nPublicidad\npulsos de mercado\nINDICES\n22:13\nWall Street sube un 2% en la semana y se queda cerca de m\xc3\xa1ximos hist\xc3\xb3ricos\n22:01\nEl petr\xc3\xb3leo extiende su rally se confirme\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Ver todos los pulsos \xe2\x80\xa2\nEl Centro Regional de la Ciudad de Nueva York anuncia la entrega tarjetas verdes permanentes y para ciudadanos mexicanos\n|\n|\nPR News\n|\n23 jul, 2018\n17:00\nEl Centro Regional de la Ciudad de Nueva York anuncia la entrega tarjetas verdes permanentes y para ciudadanos mexicanos\nEl Centro Regional de la Ciudad de Nueva York anuncia la entrega tarjetas verdes permanentes y para ciudadanos mexicanos Los primeros 6 ciudadanos mexicanos en ofertas de proyectos EB-5 del NYCRC reciben la residencia permanente en los Estados Unidos PR Newswire NUEVA YORK, 23 de julio de 2018 NUEVA YORK, 23 de julio de 2018 /PRNewswire/ --\xc2\xa0El Centro Regional de la Ciudad de Nueva York ("NYCRC", por sus siglas en ingl\xc3\xa9s) se complace en anunciar que los primeros 6 ciudadanos mexicanos en ofertas de proyectos EB-5 del NYCRC recibieron la residencia permanente en los Estados Unidos. Dichos ciudadanos mexicanos son parte de las m\xc3\xa1s de 4,650 personas de todo el mundo que obtuvieron tarjetas verdes permanentes a trav\xc3\xa9s de ofertas de proyectos del NYCRC hasta la fecha.\nLa residencia permanente permite a los inversionistas EB-5 residir y trabajar en cualquier lugar de los Estados Unidos y contar con la protecci\xc3\xb3n de las leyes de dicho pa\xc3\xads. Los c\xc3\xb3nyuges y los hijos menores de 21 a\xc3\xb1os de edad de los inversionistas EB-5 tambi\xc3\xa9n cuentan con autorizaci\xc3\xb3n para residir, trabajar y asistir a entidades educativas en cualquier lugar de los Estados unidos. Asimismo, los tres inversionistas EB-5 iniciales de M\xc3\xa9xico que invirtieron en las dos primeras ofertas de proyectos del NYCRC recibieron el amortizaci\xc3\xb3n completo de su inversi\xc3\xb3n EB-5 de $500,000. Ya tuvo lugar el amortizaci\xc3\xb3n de un total de $125 millones a 250 inversionistas EB-5 en todo el mundo en el marco de las dos ofertas de proyectos iniciales del NYCRC.\n"Nos complace enormemente que nuestros inversionistas mexicanos y los miembros de sus familias tengan \xc3\xa9xito con las ofertas de proyectos del NYCRC", sostuvo Paul Levinsohn, el Director de Administraci\xc3\xb3n del NYCRC. "El NYCRC se toma muy en serio su funci\xc3\xb3n de fomentar la creaci\xc3\xb3n de puestos de trabajo y el desarrollo econ\xc3\xb3mico, adem\xc3\xa1s de su responsabilidad de ayudar a nuestros inversionistas EB-5 y sus familias a lograr sus objetivos inmigratorios".\n"Se trata de un logro muy importante para el NYCRC y, por supuesto, para nuestros inversionistas EB-5 de M\xc3\xa9xico", sostuvo Gregg Hayden, el Director de Mercados Globales del NYCRC. "Quedamos a la espera de la oportunidad de ayudar a m\xc3\xa1s ciudadanos mexicanos en el futuro". Acerca del Centro Regional de la Ciudad de Nueva York El NYCRC fue aprobado por el Servicio de Ciudadan\xc3\xada e Inmigraci\xc3\xb3n de los Estados Unidos en 2008 con el objeto de obtener inversiones extranjeras para proyectos inmobiliarios y de infraestructura, de conformidad con el Programa para Inmigrantes Inversionistas EB-5. La compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xada fue el primer centro regional EB-5 aprobado en la ciudad de Nueva York. Hasta la fecha, el NYCRC obtuvo m\xc3\xa1s de $1.5 mil millones de capital para 21 proyectos de desarrollo econ\xc3\xb3mico en Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan y el Bronx. Entre los ejemplos de proyectos que utilizan pr\xc3\xa9stamos proporcionados por fondos administrados por el NYCRC podemos mencionar los siguientes:\nEl redesarrollo de la Estaci\xc3\xb3n de Autob\xc3\xbas del Puente George Washington en Washington Heights; La construcci\xc3\xb3n de una red de infraestructura inal\xc3\xa1mbrica en las estaciones de metro de la ciudad de Nueva York; El redesarrollo de un nuevo centro de carga en el Aeropuerto Internacional JFK; El redesarrollo de Brooklyn Navy Yard, el m\xc3\xa1s grande parque industrial de la ciudad de Nueva York; La construcci\xc3\xb3n del nuevo centro de procesamiento y distribuci\xc3\xb3n de alimentos de Fresh Direct en South Bronx; La ampliaci\xc3\xb3n de los Estudios Steiner, el m\xc3\xa1s grande estudio de cine y televisi\xc3\xb3n de la ciudad de Nueva York; La construcci\xc3\xb3n del desarrollo de City Point en el centro de Brooklyn; La construcci\xc3\xb3n de un hotel y complejo de consultorios m\xc3\xa9dicos en Washington Heights; La construcci\xc3\xb3n de los componentes clave del redesarrollo de Atlantic Yards en Brooklyn; La ampliaci\xc3\xb3n del Centro Hutchinson Metro en el Bronx; La construcci\xc3\xb3n de LinkNYC, la iniciativa p\xc3\xbablico-privada para llevar la m\xc3\xa1s grande y r\xc3\xa1pida red de infraestructura de Wi-Fi p\xc3\xbablico del pa\xc3\xads a las calles de la ciudad de Nueva York.\nAdem\xc3\xa1s de fomentar el desarrollo econ\xc3\xb3mico, las ofertas del NYCRC hicieron posible que m\xc3\xa1s de 4,650 personas se conviertan en residentes permanentes de los Estados Unidos y que 5,778 personas se conviertan en residentes permanentes condicionales a trav\xc3\xa9s del Programa para Inmigrantes Inversionistas EB-5.\nPara obtener mayor informaci\xc3\xb3n sobre el NYCRC, visite\xc2\xa0www.nycrc.com. Logo - http://mma.prnewswire.com/media/599057/NYCRC_logo_060112__R_Logo.jpg\nFUENTE The New York City Regional Center\nPublicidad\nLo m\xc3\xa1s le\xc3\xaddo\nNoticias\nMercados\nConsultorio de an\xc3\xa1lisis t\xc3\xa9cnico: Telef\xc3\xb3nica, Inditex, Naturgy, Repsol, Oryzon y tres t\xc3\xadtulos m\xc3\xa1s\nWall Street sube un 2% en la semana y se queda cerca de m\xc3\xa1ximos hist\xc3\xb3ricos\nEl petr\xc3\xb3leo extiende su rally al calor de una posible guerra EEUU-Ir\xc3\xa1n\nIbex 35: necesitamos de los bancos para que la figura de vuelta se confirme\nArcelorMittal se aproxima a la l\xc3\xadnea clavicular del gran \'cabeza y hombros\'\nM\xc3\xa1sM\xc3\xb3vil no levanta cabeza desde que se confirm\xc3\xb3 su entrada en el Ibex\nEl Ibex salva la semana al subir un 0,2% el viernes pese a la banca y el petr\xc3\xb3leo\nEnce protagoniza un fuerte rebote del 6% "dentro del oc\xc3\xa9ano bajista del t\xc3\xadtulo"\n\xc2\xbfA\xc3\xban no sabes qu\xc3\xa9 es la \'cu\xc3\xa1druple hora bruja\'? Este viernes es la segunda del a\xc3\xb1o\nAlarma en el petr\xc3\xb3leo: el mercado anticipa un enfrentamiento armado EEUU-Ir\xc3\xa1n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Vea el listado completo \xe2\x80\xa2\nConsultorio de an\xc3\xa1lisis t\xc3\xa9cnico: Telef\xc3\xb3nica, Inditex, Naturgy, Repsol, Oryzon y tres t\xc3\xadtulos m\xc3\xa1s\nWall Street sube un 2% en la semana y se queda cerca de m\xc3\xa1ximos hist\xc3\xb3ricos\nEl petr\xc3\xb3leo extiende su rally al calor de una posible guerra EEUU-Ir\xc3\xa1n\nIbex 35: necesitamos de los bancos para que la figura de vuelta se confirme\nArcelorMittal se aproxima a la l\xc3\xadnea clavicular del gran \'cabeza y hombros\'\nM\xc3\xa1sM\xc3\xb3vil no levanta cabeza desde que se confirm\xc3\xb3 su entrada en el Ibex\nEl Ibex salva la semana al subir un 0,2% el viernes pese a la banca y el petr\xc3\xb3leo\nEnce protagoniza un fuerte rebote del 6% "dentro del oc\xc3\xa9ano bajista del t\xc3\xadtulo"\n\xc2\xbfA\xc3\xban no sabes qu\xc3\xa9 es la \'cu\xc3\xa1druple hora bruja\'? Los casos en los que tenerlo contratado no sirve de nadaEn muchas ocasiones, los usuarios desconocen las coberturas de los seguros de autom\xc3\xb3viles. Son varias las situaciones que, salvo contadas excepciones, siempre est\xc3\xa1n excluidas, aunque tener contratado una p\xc3\xb3liza a todo riesgo lleve a pensar lo contrario.\nSuscr\xc3\xadbase The city replaced older phone booths with these kiosks, which offer free Wi-Fi to the public, as well as advertising and wayfinding.The kiosks also allow customers to make free nationwide calls\xc2\xa0or report emergencies. There are now more than 1,600 kiosks in all five boroughs of the city. Digital Signage Today spoke with Ruth Fasoldt, director of community affairs for Link, to see how these devices are transforming the city and improving lives.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0What are the main features the kiosks offer?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\'s payphones to build the world\'s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,600 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next several years.In addition to free Wi-Fi, Links offer free nationwide phone calls, a dedicated 911 button, device charging, and a tablet to access maps and city services. Link\'s services come at no cost to users or taxpayers because Link generates its own revenue through advertising on the 55-inch digital displays on the sides of kiosks.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0How do they improve the lives of residents?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC provides so many benefits to New Yorkers and visitors. More than 4 million people \xe2\x80\x94 more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Phoenix, Philadelphia, Dallas\xc2\xa0or San Diego \xe2\x80\x94 have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of users joining the network each week. The network also sees more than 250,000 free phone calls made every month. Using the tablet, people can access maps and directions on the go.Along with ads that keep LinkNYC\'s services 100 percent free for users and taxpayers, the digital displays feature useful and enriching content, including community board meeting updates, real-time transit and weather information so people can make more informed decisions about their day on the go, PSAs, fun facts about NYC, historic photos\xc2\xa0and more. The screens are also used for emergency messaging, for instance, in an extreme weather event. We see tweets and Instagram posts all the time of people capturing our content and sharing it with others.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0How does LinkNYC deal with issues such as people loitering by the kiosks or watching inappropriate content in public?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0Back in 2016, there was an issue with some kiosks having long-term users. The LinkNYC tablet is meant to be an on-the-go resource, so the web browser was removed from Link tablets in September 2016, in exchange for curated content on the tablet, and loitering complaints dropped 96 percent immediately.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0What type of ads do the kiosks display?Fasoldt:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC has a very high caliber of advertisers across categories \xe2\x80\x94 from Samsung to Delta to The Gap and The Met.Utilizing DOOH\xc2\xa0to its fullest and breaking from the norm of basic, static ads, Link kiosks offer the ability for advertisers to display unique, dynamic ads. From weather and transit, to sporting events, movie times and more, Link ads can change based on real-time information and updates, keeping advertisements relevant and consumers engaged.During the 2018 Winter Olympics in PeyongChang, for example, NBC partnered with Intersection to display Olympics content and coverage on LinkNYC screens, highlights, prime time previews, real-time medal counts, athlete bios and more. This digital OOH content campaign was the first of its kind for the U.S. Olympics broadcaster.More recently, Intersection pioneered another first-of-its-kind campaign, partnering with Disney and Marvel to promote "The Avengers: Infinity War." On the movie\'s launch weekend, LinkNYC screens displayed ads for the blockbuster, as well as the closest theater location to each kiosk and the next show time, so that passersby, if inspired by the ad, could easily catch the next showing.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0Do the kiosks use any analytics?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0We have stats on usership, how often different services are used, the busiest Links and more. We have also made strategic use of our network capabilities like dayparting (for example, we increase transit info on our displays during peak commuting hours), geotargeting (playing historical photos in their place of original capture), and network flexibility (during Women\'s History month, we displayed facts about women\'s suffrage along the route of the women\'s march).Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0Do you think smart cities will start to pop up everywhere? Why?Fastold:\xc2\xa0Cities around the world are looking for ways to better deliver services to residents and visitors, increase broadband connectivity, and adapt to the needs of the digital age. Many are looking to New York and LinkNYC in particular as a model. In addition to New York, a Link network is live in the U.K.\xc2\xa0We have planned expansions into Philadelphia and Newark, with many more cities on the way.Topics: Kiosk Branding, Kiosk ROI, Kiosks, Kiosks / Self-Service, Technology Bradley CooperBradley Cooper is a Technology Editor for DigitalSignageToday.com and BlockchainTechNews.com. His background is in information technology, advertising, and writing. wwwFollow @DigSignageTodaySponsored Links:Related ContentUrban Air CEO: Retail success is all about loving the customerGetting customers to return: Customer experience success storiesBrick-and-mortar retail isn\'t dead, it\'s just evolvingWhat revived legacy retail brands need to do to surviveLatest ContentCreating an experience beyond shoppingFor high-velocity retail business, mind the data gapCashierless stores? The ability to have complete control of your assets without depending ...\nLoading...\nRecent News\nPlease enable JavaScript!Bitte aktiviere JavaScript!S\'il vous pla\xc3\xaet activer JavaScript!Por favor,activa el JavaScript!antiblock.org\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\nStarlink Blog', b'Why Peer-to-Peer Networks Are The Key To Global WiFi Accessibility \xe2\x80\x93 CryptoNinjas\nFriday, June 21, 2019\nNews\nBlockchain Technology\nCrypto Exchanges\nVendor Technology\nWallets\nCapital Raising\nCrypto Payments\nToken Updates\nMarket Data\nCrypto Links\nConferences\nResources\nBitcoin ATM Map\nBitcoin Merchant Payments\nBlockchain Government Policy\nDecentralized Applications\nSmart Contracts\nCryptonite by MetaCert\nNo Result\nView All Result\nSubscribe\nNo Result\nView All Result\nHome\nToken Offerings, Listings, Technology\nWhy Peer-to-Peer Networks Are The Key To Global WiFi Accessibility\nJuly 30, 2018\nThe next time you\xe2\x80\x99re waiting at a transit stop, in line at the grocery store, or out at a coffee shop, look around and take note of how many people are staring at their smartphones. It\xe2\x80\x99s safe to say that at any given moment, the majority of the people in your surrounding area are either accessing the web or trying to access the internet with their devices.\nWe live and breathe by our smartphones; they are the gateway to the outside world, the source of our daily communications, and the keys to our personal and financial data. Yet, when we are away from our homes or offices, accessing the web is like pulling teeth. For all the technological advancements we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen in 2018, global WiFi is still just a fantasy.\nWhy is global WiFi challenging?\nIt seems like the fix to our WiFi woes should be straightforward\xe2\x80\x93but it\xe2\x80\x99s not. The lack of wifi is only going to grow more inconvenient as the number of smartphone users increases. In fact, by 2019, there will be an estimated 2.5 billion smartphone owners across the globe, and each one of them will depend on their devices to access the web at any given time and location.\nWe take Internet accessibility for granted, but this service is not free. A global, accessible, free (and fast) WiFi system requires service providers to take a financial hit. There is a long history of companies stepping up to provide more accessible WiFi, but these solutions are far from perfect. Consider LinkNYC, a project dedicated to bringing wireless internet access to the city\xe2\x80\x99s residents. Through the installation of thousands of Kiosks across the city\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs, LinkNYC saw an opportunity to place free high-speed routers at specific locations to bring the dream of ubiquitous WiFi to fruition.\nAs explored in this 2016 U.S. News coverage of LinkNYC, the \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d description of this project is slightly misleading. Yes, New Yorkers do not have to pay in monetary terms, however, by using routers to access the Internet, they have to provide an email address.\nAt a time when people are more attuned than ever regarding the risk of losing ownership of personal data, the data exchange the LINKNYC model requires does little to build security and privacy confidence in consumers.\nPeer-to-peer exchanges on the blockchain are the future of accessibility.\nUnfortunately, high-speed, secure WiFi cannot exist without the exchange of some form of payment; this payment is usually a financial transaction or personal data. But through building an open network of Wi-Fi hotspots on a blockchain-backed network, people can access the web without having to worry about who is seeing their data or dealing with the frustration of sending payments at every log-in.\nThanks to the rise of the blockchain, there may be another way people can utilize hotspots on-the-go without paying by the minute or relinquishing all of their private data rights.\nSmartphone users are always plugged into the web. Even the most intelligent smartphone user faces daily frustrations in not being able to access sites or apps while on the go. \xc2\xa0Despite being almost permanently online, the majority of smartphone users do not come anywhere close to using up their data allowance for each month. In fact, a survey conducted by OPP Open Wi-Fi found that 68% of participants did not use their entire data allowances each month. This admission indicates that there is wasted data that could be utilized for helping other individuals access the internet free of charge and without the exchange of personal information.\nOPP Open WiFi is one company looking at peer-to-peer data exchanges to solve the issue of WiFi shortages. The organization recognizes that unused data allowance is global and is a significant untapped resource. OPP Open WiFi\xe2\x80\x99s approach relies on a network of WiFi hosts, who, essentially, open the door to their unused data. Through logging onto OPPs application, hosts can turn their devices into hotspots that individuals passing by can utilize in exchange for a cryptocurrency payment.\nOur lives may run on smartphone devices, but WiFi access is the fuel. In addition to merely browsing, more people across the global workforce need unlimited internet access anywhere and at any time; the rise of the freelancer economy has transformed the call to universal WiFi from a wish to a demand. New organizations are finding ways to use blockchain\xe2\x80\x99s decentralization to power a new solution and build a world devoid of digital borders.\nShare453Tweet\nRelated Posts\nBlockTower Capital launches competition to recruit crypto asset analyst\nJune 20, 2019\nEU crypto asset platform Coinhouse integrates Ledger\xe2\x80\x99s wallet solution\nJune 20, 2019\nBlockchain network Elrond prepares token sale on Binance Launchpad\nJune 20, 2019\nPlatON\xe2\x80\x99s blockchain-based network to power China\xe2\x80\x99s largest smart city project\nJune 20, 2019\nIOTA\xe2\x80\x99s Tangle DLT to ensure allergen food safety for Primority\nJune 20, 2019\nFuzeX and XTOCK launch new crypto cold wallet custody service\nJune 20, 2019\nAdd comment\nName*\nE-mail*\nE-mail is already registered on the site.
