Statement \xe2\x80\x93 Resolution\n9/17 Waterfront, Parks & Resiliency Committee \xe2\x80\x93 6:00 PM\nLocation:\xc2\xa0Community Board 1 \xe2\x80\x93 Conference Room, 1 Centre Street, Room 2202A-North\n1) Brooklyn Bridge Beach/Esplanade \xe2\x80\x93 Update and possible resolution (tentative)\n2) Barnett Newman Triangle \xe2\x80\x93 Update by DDG (tentative)\nBarnett Newman Triangle is the strip of land between Church and Sixth, across from 100 Franklin (whose developer, DDG, is also redoing the pedestrian island). Rendering below.\n3) Hudson River Park \xe2\x80\x93 Update by Madelyn Wils, President & CEO, Hudson River Park Trust (Tentative)\n9/20 Quality of Life & Service Delivery Committee \xe2\x80\x93 6:00 PM\nLocation: Manhattan Borough President\xe2\x80\x99s Office, 1 Centre Street, 19th Floor \xe2\x80\x93 Southside\n1) Special Event: Spotlight on Seniors \xe2\x80\x93 Presentation by Councilmember Margaret Chin, New York City Council Committee on Aging, Chair\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s not as if she has more important things to do.\n9/24 Executive Committee \xe2\x80\x93 6:00 PM\nLocation:\xc2\xa0Community Board 1 \xe2\x80\x93 Conference Room, 1 Centre Street, Room 2202A-North\n1) Discussion of FY 2020 District Needs Statement and budget priorities\n2) Committee reports\n9/25 CB 1 Monthly Meeting \xe2\x80\x93 6:00 PM\nLocation: The Peck Slip School, 1 Peck Slip\nAll documents relating to the above agenda items are on file at the Community Board 1 office and are available for viewing by the public upon written request to man01@cb.nyc.gov. At all meetings, additional items may be raised as \xe2\x80\x9cNew Business.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTags: 100 Franklin, 119 Hudson, 134 W. Broadway, 205 Hudson, 39-41 Worth, 416 Washington, 50 Varick, 51 White, 71 Worth, 80 Centre, 92 Laight, Atera, Augustine, Barnett Newman Triangle, Brookdale Battery Park, Chefscape, Community Board 1, Cut by Wolfgang Puck, DDG, Howard Hughes Corporation, Hudson River Park, Issey Miyake Tribeca, Margaret Chin, Seaport District, Spring, Spring Studios, Zutto\nComment:\nCancel Reply\nName\n(required)\nEmail\n(required; not published)\nMedium rectangle #1 (top)\nSubscribe\nSubscribe to the TC Newsletter\nRight column rectangle ads\nPopular posts\nPopular Posts\nCity will phase out parking placards\nGhost Town: The 2018 Retail Vacancy Report\nWhere to Order Thai Food in Tribeca\nWhere to Order Chinese Food in Tribeca\nMega rectangle\nRestaurant guide iconMedium rectangle #2 (middle slot)\nInstagram\nTribeca Citizen on Instagram\nShopping Guide icon\nOld Tribeca Scrapbook house ad\nAbout\nAbout Tribeca Citizen\nContact\nAdvertise\nPress\nShop\nConnect\nTwitter\nFacebook\nInstagram\nEmail Newsletter\nGuides\nRestaurant Guide\nShopping Guide\nTribeca Visitor's Guide\nLegal\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Tribeca Citizen\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Design by Jackie Blue\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Additional development by Soren Technology Consulting", b"In smart cities, advertisers will rule | CityMetric\nMenu\nSite Menu\nHousing\nIn Theory\nMidlands Engine\nTube maps\nBusiness\nTransport\nPolitics\nFabric\nHorizons\nAbout CityMetric\nContact us\nSkylines\nPrivacy Policy\nClose\nSearch\nSearch\nTweet\nTweet\nThe Skylines Podcast\nData Tools\nAbout CityMetric\nContact us\nClose\nHorizons\nSmart Cities\nSeptember 4, 2018\nIn smart cities, advertisers will rule\nBy Martin Greenacre\nA LinkNYC kiosk in New York City. Image: Getty.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re not paying for it, you\xe2\x80\x99re the product.\xe2\x80\x9d The phrase was coined in the 1970s to talk about television advertising, but has since become the internet\xe2\x80\x99s whole business model: we get nice services, for free or for very little, and in return, our attention is sold to advertisers.\nBut what if that logic dominated everyday life? With the rise of the smart city, it\xe2\x80\x99s becoming a reality. And local authorities should be both upfront and cautious about the risks.\nSous les pav\xc3\xa9s, la pub\nIn a time of disappearing budgets, it is understandable that councils will jump at any opportunity to improve their cities without spending a penny. Companies like JCDecaux and Clear Channel provide cities with street furniture such as bus stops and bicycles, in return for advertising space.\nOccasionally, though, the public service aspect is all but forgotten. In 2015, JCDecaux replaced Paris\xe2\x80\x99s 2,000 bus shelters with a new model. With their sleek design, the new shelters had USB ports for charging your phone, and large, digital advertising screens. The only problem? They didn\xe2\x80\x99t actually provide shelter from the rain and had to be changed.\nOther times, public utility is just an excuse for brand promotion, as with the \xe2\x80\x9ctrackable water refill stations\xe2\x80\x9d recently installed in London by Canary Wharf Group \xe2\x80\x93 narcissistic water fountains with a screen that tracks the number of plastic bottles saved.\nWith cities desperate for innovation yet strapped for cash, advertisers have been emboldened to set their own rules. A recent report from the Outdoor Advertising Association of America talks about how the knowledge that a bus passenger is taking a specific route towards a specific destination could be used for hyper-targeted messages: \xe2\x80\x9cThe information might include: an upcoming destination; reminders about previous purchases; points-of-interest along the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThis mixing of public and private usages is one way advertisers are cementing their urban domination. As one advertising CEO puts it, \xe2\x80\x9cThe serendipitous confluence of municipal poverty and secular change in marketing practices presents a unique opportunity for a new breed of public-private partnerships.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn reality, \xe2\x80\x9cpublic-private partnerships\xe2\x80\x9d often means public data being used for private ends. The best example of this took place via Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s digital kiosks in New York, the LinkNYC. These kiosks were designed to replace the city\xe2\x80\x99s payphones, and they feature HD screens for accessing maps, services and video calls, a phone, and USB charging ports. The \xe2\x80\x9cLinks\xe2\x80\x9d are owned and operated by the CityBridge consortium, and are funded by advertising on the large screens. Last year, \xe2\x80\x9cInLinks\xe2\x80\x9d launched in the UK.\nIntersection turned public data into private ad dollars last year, when it helped the beer brewing company MillerCoors run an advertising campaign in partnership with the Metropolitan Transit Authority (MTA). MillerCoors used MTA data to detect when there were delays on certain train lines, and subsequently relayed this information alongside the slogan, \xe2\x80\x9cYour commute can wait\xe2\x80\x9d and an invitation to stop off for a beer.\nProtecting data in smart cities\nSo where is our personal data in all of that? The future of outdoor advertising lies in the combination of two inherent features of the internet \xe2\x80\x93 free, advertiser-subsidised services, and targeted ads. And the latter means large-scale data collection. As Le Monde reports, the screens that companies like JCDecaux are fitting on public infrastructure \xe2\x80\x9cuse cameras and detection systems to identify with remarkable precision the sex, age, height, weight, and geographical origins of passers-by\xe2\x80\x9d. In some cases, cameras even use \xe2\x80\x9cemotion detection\xe2\x80\x9d, to check if people are responding positively to the message.\nThe marketing possibilities are so enticing that Philippe Baudillon, president of the French branch of Clear Channel Outdoor, just published a book about smart cities, R\xc3\xa9inventer la Street Experience. In his reimagined city, we are all connected, all the time; the street becomes a \xe2\x80\x9creal-life hyperlink\xe2\x80\x9d, sending people towards websites and social media campaigns.\nThe book explains that Clear Channel has also developed a tool called Consumer Audience Smart Tracking, which uses \xe2\x80\x9cmore than 2,000 socio-behavioural criteria taken from anonymised data\xe2\x80\x9d to analyse consumers passing in front of a screen, \xe2\x80\x9cmaking it possible to identify not only the number of people who walk by, but also their lifestyle and consumption habits\xe2\x80\x9d.\nBaudillon stresses that the data is used to identify and target large groups, not individuals: we don\xe2\x80\x99t have to worry about the bus shelter revealing our internet history just yet. Still, with smart street furniture linked to your smartphone\xe2\x80\x99s Wi-Fi, and bourgeoning facial recognition technology, hyper-targeted outdoor advertising is increasingly plausible.\nPublic authorities have, however, shown that they are willing to uphold privacy laws. In 2013, the company Renew London trialled recycling bins which featured LCD advertising screens, and which tracked Wi-Fi signals from pedestrians\xe2\x80\x99 phones. Renew said it collected data from media access control (MAC) addresses simply to measure footfall. But after campaigners raised privacy concerns, the City of London Corporation asked Renew to halt its trial.\nThe French Data Protection Authority (CNIL) denied JCDecaux authorisation to collect similar data. The device would have gathered data from any smartphone users within a 25 radius of their advertising screens, meaning not everybody was likely to have seen the A4 sign notifying them of their rights, according to Osborne Clarke\xe2\x80\x99s marketing law blog.\nThe European Union\xe2\x80\x99s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which came into effect in May, should give citizens even more power in such cases. Businesses are now required to share what kind of information they collect, and individuals must be able to withdraw their consent.\nBut this is much more complicated in a physical, public space than it is online, as the CNIL\xe2\x80\x99s decision recognises. That is why the public should be consulted before projects are finalised. While free technology is always enticing, cities mustn\xe2\x80\x99t forget whom they are supposed to serve, before the next big data scandal hits the streets.\nRelated Articles\nEngland needs to close the north-south divide in higher education, too\nCanada\xe2\x80\x99s gay neighbourhoods are struggling. Can queer pop-ups plug the gap?\nWhat do the songs of Bruce Springsteen tell us about the American city?\nTweet\nShare\nPin\nTransport\nLondon\n9 hours ago\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s why it\xe2\x80\x99s actually good that London has so many rail terminals\nBy Claude Lynch\nEuston. Eugh. Image: Getty.\nThere are 14 railway terminals in London. That sounds like a lot, even by the standards of London\xe2\x80\x99s 8 million strong population. For context, Beijing has just six terminals between its 21 million people. So if you decide where to live based on the obscure metric of \xe2\x80\x9cnumber of railway terminals per million people\xe2\x80\x9d, London is doing really, really well.\nBut it\xe2\x80\x99s such a bother, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? Making the inconvenient, interchange-laden journey from Liverpool Street to London Bridge, for example, is the price we pay to travel cross-country; changing in Central London is the norm for many a journey, even though it\xe2\x80\x99s expensive, inefficient, and adds to the footfall at stations that are already stereotypically congested.\nIn fact, as is so often the case, there\xe2\x80\x99s actually a pretty sensible explanation for why London ended up with so many railway stations, even by European standards. As pioneers of the industrial revolution, Britain was the first country to build serious railway infrastructure. But in the hyper-entrepreneurial petit-bourgeois era of early industrialisation, there was no centralised transport system; like Aretha Franklin\xe2\x80\x99s sisters, railway companies were doing it for themselves. (Sorry.)\nBecause London has been the overwhelming economic centre of England since they knocked up the Bayeux Tapestry, all railway services tended to radiate from it. But the great railway boom of the 1830s and \xe2\x80\x9840s predated the arrival of the first underground railway, the Metropolitan Line, in 1863. And the difficulty and expense of demolishing existing suburbs meant that the new railways tended to terminate on the edge of the built up area. The result was separate stations, run by different companies, all around today\xe2\x80\x99s city centre.\nIn any case, I\xe2\x80\x99m inclined to believe that having all these railway terminals, strewn around London like a contorted hula hoop, is actually a good thing. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to demonise Birmingham, which is fast outgrowing its ugly duckling stereotype \xe2\x80\x93 but Birmingham New Street serves as a good example of the problem with terminals whose trains go straight through the city.\nThere, the trains run north to south, services reaching both London and Manchester, with easy connections to Moor Street and Snow Hill stations. The choice to run tracks through the station makes the area immediately around it \xe2\x80\x93 in other words, central Birmingham \xe2\x80\x93 less navigable. The interlocking railway infrastructure strangles the city.\nIf the same had happened in London, in the absence of a precarious, hyperbolically ambitious cut-and-cover scheme, we\xe2\x80\x99d lose the precious, contiguous urban core that runs all the way from Paddington to Fenchurch Street.\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s another benefit to all these terminals; it means fewer areas end up being cut in half. Urban policy wonks have spent the longest time discussing how arterial roads split communities, but we rarely stop to think about how a railway line could divide one area from another, too. Yes, they're much quieter than, say, the M1, but they're just as hard to cross \xe2\x80\x93 and dividing lines that are mildly problematic in King's Cross Central could've been overwhelming in areas in central London proper.\nThe suburban railways running through outer London are testament to this point. In Islington, the North London Line sharply divides the well-to-do N1 postcode from the more mixed area of N7, and the East Coast Main Line makes the Arsenal Stadium feel miles away even if you live just to the north on Tollington Road, simply because there\xe2\x80\x99s no road crossing for a mile. Imagine if those divides existed in Central London, cutting you off from St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s because you lived on the wrong side of the tracks.\nThe takeaway here might seem obvious: all this infrastructure would be much better off underground. Well yes, it would, and that\xe2\x80\x99s what Thameslink and, hopefully, maybe, one day in the far flung future, Crossrail try to achieve, as do London\xe2\x80\x99s subsurface Tube lines.\nBut it\xe2\x80\x99s worth mentioning that when the Metropolitan and District railways were built, they lay on the urban fringe, which reduced disruption. Thameslink and Crossrail have been fare more costly (and indeed extremely delayed) because they\xe2\x80\x99re now in the midst of a dense urban area. Also, if we wanted to connect, say, Liverpool Street and London Bridge underground, the tunnels would need to skirt around other underground lines. Shy of Brunel\xe2\x80\x99s second coming, this is just too much to ask.\nSo, we should appreciate the ubiquity of railway terminals in London for what they\xe2\x80\x99re worth. Their existence is testament to a tangential, tentative Victorian past where we stumbled through industrialisation, building great railway terminals as we went (and useless Cannon Street too).\nChanging between railway terminals in London is a London experience in itself. At the risk of sounding sentimental, it\xe2\x80\x99s an inconvenience with a history behind it. Unlike Crossrail delays. That stuff is beyond romanticising.\nRelated Articles\nAn official and objective ranking of London\xe2\x80\x99s 14 major rail terminals\nLeeds is still haunted by its pledge to be the \xe2\x80\x9cMotorway City of the Seventies\xe2\x80\x9d\nTransport for London just cut its bus services. You probably didn\xe2\x80\x99t notice.\nTweet\nShare\nPin\nMore content\nEditor's Pick\nFantasy metro maps: West Yorkshire edition\nTransport\nFantasy metro maps\nJune 10, 2019\nPodcast: After Grenfell and advanced Sheffield\nSkylines\nPodcast\nJune 6, 2019\nLocal council wards are really very interesting, actually\nPolitics\nMaps\nJune 6, 2019\nMost Popular\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s why it\xe2\x80\x99s actually good that London has so many rail terminals\nTransport\nLondon\n9 hours ago\nWhere are the largest cities in Britain?\nFabric\nDemographics\nSeptember 16, 2015\nAn official and objective ranking of London\xe2\x80\x99s 14 major rail terminals\nTransport\nRail\nAugust 7, 2018\nEngland needs to close the north-south divide in higher education, too\nHorizons\nEducation\nJune 20, 2019\nLeeds is still haunted by its pledge to be the \xe2\x80\x9cMotorway City of the Seventies\xe2\x80\x9d\nTransport\nRoads\nJune 19, 2019\nLatest\nPodcast: A Short history of council housing\nSkylines\nPodcast\n10 hours ago\nBritain\xe2\x80\x99s housing policy must \xe2\x80\x9cditch its relentless numbers game\xe2\x80\x9d\nFabric\nHousing\nJune 20, 2019\nCanada\xe2\x80\x99s gay neighbourhoods are struggling. Microsoft puts rival app on internal list of \xe2\x80\x98prohibited and discouraged\xe2\x80\x99 software\nTrending: Isilon co-founder Sujal Patel building mysterious biotech startup, backed by Andreessen Horowitz\nWhy Seattle\xe2\x80\x99s plan to bring Intersection WiFi kiosks and bus stop makeovers stalled\nby Monica Nickelsburg on September 5, 2018 at 6:00 amSeptember 5, 2018 at 10:54 am\nComments\nShare\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa028\nTweet\nShare\nReddit\nEmail\nThe Playbook: 6/26 Get tickets now!\nA Link kiosk in New York City. (Intersection Photo)\nFast-growing cities, like Seattle, are looking for opportunities to embrace technology to become more efficient, mobile, and equitable. But working with the private sector to implement innovations can be tricky, as a jammed-up partnership between Seattle and the transit advertising company Intersection proves.\nIntersection is a New York-based company that operates digital ads on public transit and free WiFi information kiosks in London and New York. It is a spinout of Sidewalk Labs, the urban planning-focused sister company of Google under the Alphabet umbrella.\nUntil late last year, Intersection planned to give Seattle bus stops a high-tech makeover and deploy its Link kiosks, miniature billboards that provide free WiFi and other amenities, throughout the urban core. The partnership appeared to be speeding ahead until it hit a roadblock. Now, Seattle \xe2\x80\x9cis not actively negotiating on the proposed electronic kiosks,\xe2\x80\x9d according to the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office. City officials indicated that privacy concerns are the main reason talks aren\xe2\x80\x99t moving forward.\nIn 2016, the Seattle Department of Transportation told Intersection the company\xe2\x80\x99s bid would be selected for a new \xe2\x80\x9cstreet furniture\xe2\x80\x9d program intended to update bus stops and other amenities on public streets. Intersection says the arrangement would have included \xe2\x80\x9cnew bus shelters and digital kiosks to the city, providing hundreds of thousands of residents and visitors with secure and super-fast Wi-Fi, access to free phone calls, maps, transit updates, and local information.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAccording to Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s proposal, obtained by The Urbanist, the company offered to pay Seattle between $97 million and $167 million over 20 years in exchange for exclusive rights to operate the kiosks and bus stations. Intersection would have also paid the city a share of the revenue from ads served on the kiosks and bus stops. The ad revenue was estimated to make an additional $100 million or more for the city over 20 years.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll of these free services would come at no cost to taxpayers and would generate significant new revenue for the city to invest in transit and other public priorities,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jen Hensley, president of Link at Intersection, in a statement to GeekWire.\nIn late 2017, representatives from Intersection shared their plans for Seattle with the regional Chamber of Commerce at a private event. But sometime in the months that followed, Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan had a change of heart.\nMayor Durkan had significant concerns with both the privacy and data policies \xe2\x80\x94 specifically what data was collected, how it was stored, what tracking was possible, and how ads were targeted.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the initial proposal, Mayor Durkan had significant concerns with both the privacy and data policies \xe2\x80\x94 specifically what data was collected, how it was stored, what tracking was possible, and how ads were targeted,\xe2\x80\x9d said\xc2\xa0Stephanie Formas, the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s communications director.\nIntersection works with each city to draft bespoke privacy policies for its Link kiosks. All Link devices are equipped with security cameras. In New York, the footage is deleted after seven days, unless it is needed to investigate an incident. Link devices collect email addresses when users log into the WiFi network for the first time but don\xe2\x80\x99t ask for any additional personal information. Intersection does not engage in targeted advertising, according to the company\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy.\nA Link Kiosk (Intersection Image)\n\xe2\x80\x9cIntersection\xe2\x80\x99s Link product is a proven solution for expanding access to broadband connectivity, promoting community-based organizations and local businesses, and providing new opportunities for civic engagement,\xe2\x80\x9d Hensley said. \xe2\x80\x9cLink also comes with our strong commitment to user privacy and security.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOne of two companies that eventually joined to form Intersection did land in hot water in New York over privacy concerns back in 2014. The company then known as Titan Outdoor\xc2\xa0controlled advertising displays on New York phone booths.\xc2\xa0BuzzFeed discovered\xc2\xa0that the booths contained beacons that could be used to track the movements of passersby and push ads to mobile phones. New York had the beacons removed as a result of BuzzFeed\xe2\x80\x99s coverage.\nIn 2015, Sidewalk Labs bought Titan Outdoors and another company called Control Group, merging them together to form Intersection as an independent startup.\nLast year, Intersection announced\xc2\xa0revised privacy policies\xc2\xa0for LinkNYC after the New York Civil Liberties Union sent a letter to the city warning about the company\xe2\x80\x99s data collection practices. Under the revised privacy policy, Intersection stopped collecting information about the websites that users visited when logged into Link free WiFi.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause of her background working on privacy issues from decades, Mayor Durkan strongly believes that any proposals using city right-of-way must adequately protect users\xe2\x80\x99 privacy and data and uphold net neutrality principles while ensuring that any such program advances equity for communities throughout Seattle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Formas. \xe2\x80\x9cIn addition, she believes there needs to be a fair return to taxpayers for use of city land and true engagement with the diverse neighborhoods throughout Seattle.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIntersection\xc2\xa0already operates rail and bus ads in Seattle and the Eastside through partnerships with King County Metro and Sound Transit. Intersection also has an existing office in downtown Seattle.\nIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t clear whether the street furniture discussions will be renewed, but Intersection appears optimistic. If the talks start up again, the plan would still require the city to change its sign code to allow ads on public sidewalks.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe look forward to continuing our conversations with city stakeholders about bringing these public benefits to the streets of Seattle,\xe2\x80\x9d Hensley said.\nMonica Nickelsburg is GeekWire\xe2\x80\x99s Civic Editor, covering technology-driven solutions to urban challenges and the intersection of tech and politics. Before joining GeekWire, she worked for The Week, Forbes, and NBC. Monica holds a BA in journalism and history from New York University. Follow her @mnickelsburg\nComments\nShare\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa028\nTweet\nShare\nReddit\nEmail\nPrevious StoryCrowdsourcing efforts save digital ghosts of artifacts lost in Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s museum fire\nNext StoryBorn inside RealNetworks, Scener is a new Twitch-like commentary platform for streaming media\nFiled Under: Civic Innovation\xc2\xa0 Tagged With: cities \xe2\x80\xa2 Internet \xe2\x80\xa2 intersection \xe2\x80\xa2 link \xe2\x80\xa2 Seattle \xe2\x80\xa2 Sidewalk Labs \xe2\x80\xa2 Smart Cities\nGeekWire Newsletters\nSubscribe to GeekWire's free newsletters to catch every headline\nEmail address\nSubscribe\nGeekWire Daily - Top headlines daily\nGeekWire Weekly - Most-read stories of the week, delivered Sunday\nGeekWire Space & Science - Weekly headlines from Alan Boyle, award-winning aerospace and science editor\nGeekWire Podcasts \xe2\x80\x94 Weekly update with our latest audio episodes\nGeekWire Cloud Tech Weekly \xe2\x80\x94 Cloud and developer technology, delivered weekly\nGeekWire Mid-week Update \xe2\x80\x94 Most-read stories so far this week, delivered Wednesday\nGeekWire Local Deals \xe2\x80\x94 Special offers for Pacific Northwest area readers\nSend Us a Tip\nHave a scoop that you'd like GeekWire to cover? All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nmenu content ends\nMenu\nGothamist\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDonate\nSearch\nSearch this site\nClose\nSearch\nSearch\nArts & Entertainment\nSummer Is Fading But Creepy Mister Softee LinkNYC Haunting Continues\nBy\nClaire Lampen\nSept. 5, 2018 3:30 p.m.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nEmail\nI SCREAM, YOU SCREAM, WE ALL SCREAM DOWN HERE (Silva/Flickr)\nPicture this: New York City is suddenly set upon by a bloodthirsty Conehead in a bowtie who lures his prey with the call of his friendly, familiar jingle. The victims detect the tune, slowed to an unnerving molasses pace, churning from\xe2\x80\x94where is that? The sewer? Or could it be that public WiFi hotspot on the corner? Yes, it calls to them, and just as they connect their phones to the jingling LinkNYC with a glowing USB cord, all goes black. Exactly 24 hours later, authorities find them slashed to ribbons in their apartments, "The World\'s Best" smeared on the wall in melted soft serve.\nThis scenario may sound far-fetched, but it\'s the most likely outcome of the extended Mister Softee mystery/nightmare New Yorkers have been living these past four months. As far as I know, none of the poor souls who\'ve heard the notorious ice cream truck\'s creepy tones floating from LinkNYC kiosks have perished\xe2\x80\x94yet. But the jingle haunting continues, and none of us are safe.\nTwitter user Scott Ethier captured LinkNYC stations near Broadway and 33rd Street in Astoria, Queens on September 2nd cranking out the "slo-mo Mr. Softee" death knell mixed with some very scary air sirens, why the hell not??\n@LinkNYC @Gothamist @BrianLehrer LinkNYC stations around B\'way & 33rd St in Astoria are all playing slow-mo Mr Softee music accompanied by an air raid siren.\n#LinkNYCApocalypse pic.twitter.com/w14Y8YfYe2\xe2\x80\x94 Scott Ethier (@ScottEthier) September 2, 2018\nGothamist has been investigating this creepy mystery since May, when the first strains of Mr. Softee\'s warped jingle drifted from LinkNYC kiosks on Third Avenue in Midtown. Initially, the free WiFi service apologized for inadvertently confusing passersby. "LinkNYC serves New Yorkers in many important ways\xe2\x80\x94providing free wi-fi to more than 4 million users, free phone calls, device charging, and more\xe2\x80\x94but unfortunately, we don\'t serve ice cream," the company said in a statement. "Once we were alerted to the Mr. Softee jingle, we immediately rebooted the tablets to end the song. Sorry if anyone wandered towards the kiosks looking for soft serve!"\nHa ha that was just the beginning: Throughout the summer, reports rolled in from Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Queens, where residents continued to hear the ominous tones blaring from Link stations into July and August. Some speculated that the kiosks, which can harvest user data, may have been hacked. Although LinkNYC attempted to assuage our fears with assurances that this string of jinglings was "just an old-fashioned phone prank," many passersby remain unclear on what, exactly, that means.\nCan you clarify what the phrase "old-fashioned phone prank" means in the context of a public WiFi hotspot/data collection point/tablet-driven advertising monolith? pic.twitter.com/L1SC8gt7ia\xe2\x80\x94 Scott Ethier (@ScottEthier) September 4, 2018\nEXACT SAME QUESTION.\nSpeaking to NY1, LinkNYC explained its reasoning. Someone must be "dialing a number that for some odd reason, plays the jingle, and they leave it on speaker," the company posited. In response to our inquiry into the nature of these alleged old-timey hijinks, a LinkNYC spokesperson acknowledged that not everyone will use the company\'s free services responsibly. Some people will, apparently, call a phone number playing this theme and then leave it blasting from the station\'s speaker after they\'ve fled the scene. LinkNYC has put in place a mechanism that automatically ends calls after 10 minutes if no one taps the screen to confirm their presence. It\'s working to block the offending numbers.\nUnfortunately, though, blocking accounts on any platform often feels like chopping heads of a hydra\xe2\x80\x94which means we\'ll probably be screaming for ice cream for months to come. So please keep us posted on any possessed kiosks you may encounter around the city. Summer may be coming to a close, but this chilling case remains wide open.\n#jingle\n#linknyc\n#mister softee\n#mystery\n#screams\nDo you know the scoop? \xc2\xa0 Comment below or Send us a Tip\nFeatured in Arts & Entertainment\nRead More In:\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDashed Arrow\nBack to Top\nGothamist\nSend Us a Story Idea\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nGothamist is a website about New York City news, arts and events, and food, brought to you by New York Public Radio.\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nParty Confetti\nDashed Arrow\nSign up for our newsletter! All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy', b"View in Browser |\nAdd\nnytdirect@nytimes.com to your address book.\nThursday, September 6, 2018\nNYTimes.com \xc2\xbb\nWho Will Be the Next Attorney General?\nBy ALEXANDRA S. LEVINE AND JONATHAN WOLFE\nFrom left, Letitia James, Sean Patrick Maloney, Leecia Eve and Zephyr Teachout, the Democratic candidates for attorney general. Holly Pickett for The New York Times\nGood morning.\nThe clock to the primary is ticking: We\xe2\x80\x99re exactly one week out.\nAnd with that, four candidates\xc2\xa0to be\xc2\xa0New York\xe2\x80\x99s next attorney general \xe2\x80\x94 all of whom you\xe2\x80\x99ll see on the ballot\xc2\xa0next Thursday,\xc2\xa0Sept. 13 \xe2\x80\x94 will\xc2\xa0face off\xc2\xa0tonight\xc2\xa0in their\xc2\xa0final\xc2\xa0debate.\nOur Albany bureau chief,\xc2\xa0Jesse McKinley, gave us the rundown of\xc2\xa0what\xe2\x80\x99s at stake in the race and why the post is so vital \xe2\x80\x94 particularly now.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe traditional purpose of the attorney general is to defend the state in the legal arena,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. McKinley told us. \xe2\x80\x9cAs we\xe2\x80\x99ve crept into modernity, that mandate has broadened with the political ambitions of whoever has held that office.\xe2\x80\x9d\n(Eliot Spitzer used the power to prosecute cases on Wall Street, for example;\xc2\xa0Eric T. Schneiderman\xc2\xa0opted to\xc2\xa0dig into the activities of President Trump.)\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it can really be a way of investigating almost anything that touches on New York,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. McKinley added. \xe2\x80\x9cWhoever is chosen will have their own viewpoint on what the office is supposed to do and what it can do \xe2\x80\x94 it really is a litmus test as to the interest of the attorney general.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe Democratic contenders are\xc2\xa0Letitia James, the New York City public advocate,\xc2\xa0who was endorsed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and is backed by the Democratic Party in New York;\xc2\xa0Zephyr Teachout, a lawyer who was endorsed by\xc2\xa0The New York Times\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Chirlane McCray;\xc2\xa0Sean Patrick Maloney, a congressman from the Hudson Valley; and\xc2\xa0Leecia Eve, a former top aide to Mrs. Clinton and\xc2\xa0Mr. Cuomo.\n(Barbara Underwood, who was appointed attorney general in May after Mr. Schneiderman resigned\xc2\xa0over\xc2\xa0accusations that he physically abused several women, is not running.)\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll really be a test of how powerful insurgent candidates can be,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. McKinley said. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no question that Tish is the establishment, and no question that Zephyr has run way to the left of her and is banking on progressives, die-hards, \xe2\x80\x98Berniecrats\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x94 however you want to put it \xe2\x80\x94 coming out in droves to put her over the top.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOne shared target, however, is\xc2\xa0Mr.\xc2\xa0Trump. Each of the candidates has\xc2\xa0pledged\xc2\xa0to\xc2\xa0follow Mr.\xc2\xa0Schneiderman\xe2\x80\x99s lead in taking on\xc2\xa0the Trump\xc2\xa0administration,\xc2\xa0giving\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0New York race\xc2\xa0heightened relevance nationwide.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the legal sense,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. McKinley said, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s important because ongoing cases against the Trump administration, and against Donald Trump personally, in some cases mirror and in some cases are ancillary to investigations that are underway on a federal level as well.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMr. Trump can grant pardons only for federal crimes.\nThe winner of the Democratic primary will face the Republican\xc2\xa0candidate,\xc2\xa0Keith Wofford,\xc2\xa0in the Nov. 6\xc2\xa0general election. A victory\xc2\xa0in November\xc2\xa0by Ms. James, Ms. Teachout or Ms. Eve would mark the first time a woman\xc2\xa0was\xc2\xa0elected to the position.\nTonight\xe2\x80\x99s debate\xc2\xa0at the Cooper Union in the East Village will be moderated by\xc2\xa0Preet Bharara, the former United States attorney in Manhattan, and WNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Brian Lehrer.\nThe event is sold out but will be broadcast live on\xc2\xa0WNYC\xc2\xa0(93.9 FM and AM 820) and livestreamed on the Cooper Union\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Facebook page\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0YouTube page, and on\xc2\xa0CAFE.com.\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s what else is happening:\nADVERTISEMENT\nIn the News\nSince pleading guilty last month to federal charges, Michael D. Cohen has remained isolated and politically toxic. Mary Altaffer/Associated Press\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Michael Cohen, President Trump\xe2\x80\x99s former lawyer and longtime fixer, has become increasingly isolated since his guilty plea. [New York Times]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Scrutiny of Julia Salazar\xe2\x80\x99s background has revealed several inconsistencies that threaten to derail her candidacy for\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0New York State Senate. [New York Times]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0After the Parkland, Fla.,\xc2\xa0massacre, school districts across the U.S. added new layers of security to their buildings. New York City is experimenting with a different approach. [New York Times]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0The authorities are investigating an Emirates Airline flight that landed at\xc2\xa0Kennedy\xc2\xa0Airport after numerous people appeared to become ill. [New York Times]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0When it comes to the ticket of Cynthia Nixon and Jumaane D. Williams, who have endorsed each other in their bids for governor and lieutenant governor, the relationship may be mutually beneficial. [New York Times]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0At Friends Seminary, an elite private school in Manhattan, a teacher made a Hitler joke. It tore the school apart, opening a proxy battle in a larger war over values.\xc2\xa0[New York Times]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0An investigation by the city\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Department of\xc2\xa0Consumer\xc2\xa0Affairs found that many home health care workers have been mistreated in a number of ways, including being shorted on wages. [Gothamist]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Many New Yorkers are annoyed by the loud jingles coming from ice cream trucks around the city. Have you ever wondered which neighborhoods complained the most? [Bklyner]\nComing Up Today\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cNew York State, Reproductive Justice, and the Midterm Elections,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0a discussion\xc2\xa0at the Brooklyn Historical Society in Brooklyn Heights. 6:30 p.m. [$5]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Practice\xc2\xa0yoga during sunset\xc2\xa0on the waterfront at\xc2\xa0Hunters Point\xc2\xa0South Park in Long Island City, Queens. 7 p.m. [Free]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0An evening of jazz with\xc2\xa0sound artists and improvisational vocalists\xc2\xa0at\xc2\xa0the Issue Project Room in Downtown Brooklyn. 8 p.m. [$25]\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Alternate-side parking remains\xc2\xa0in effect\xc2\xa0until Sept. 10.\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0For more events, see The New York Times\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Arts & Entertainment guide.\nMetropolitan Diary\nAll-Natural Nails\nDear Diary:\nOn a recent trip home to the city, I was on an uptown No. 3 train with my best friend when what looked like three generations of one family got on at Times Square.\nThey were tourists and were discussing their day so far and their next stop. I heard one member of the family speak.\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to a woman standing near us on the jam-packed subway car. \xe2\x80\x9cHow long have you been growing your nails?\xe2\x80\x9d\nI looked down and saw that the woman she was talking to had nails that were at least six inches long, painted bright gold and curled around in a way that acrylic nails wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\nI hadn\xe2\x80\x99t even noticed them. Plus, it was a question most New Yorkers wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t ask. We\xe2\x80\x99ve trained ourselves to avert our eyes and mind our own business on the subway.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince 1982,\xe2\x80\x9d the woman with the long nails said with a smile.\nThe first woman returned the smile and complimented her on her nails.\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you, too,\xe2\x80\x9d the woman with the long nails said.\nI spent the rest of the ride wondering how she had completed some of life\xe2\x80\x99s most basic tasks for the past few decades.\n\xe2\x80\x94 Katie Adrian\nAnd Finally ...\nSidewalk facts. John Taggart/Bloomberg, via Getty Images\nDid you know that on a clear day you can see five states from the Empire State Building observatories?\nNeither did we, until we read it on a\xc2\xa0LinkNYC kiosk.\nThe LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x9cfun facts\xe2\x80\x9d series is perhaps our favorite feature of the kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 aside from the free internet access they provide.\nSo we reached out to the folks at LinkNYC for a few tidbits about our city. Did you know:\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0About 1 in every 38 people living in the United\xc2\xa0States\xc2\xa0resides in New York City.\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Based on capacity, 18 percent of New York\xe2\x80\x99s adult population could be safely suspended in elevators at the same time.\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0New York City gets more inches of rain\xc2\xa0each\xc2\xa0year than Seattle.\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Most Broadway theaters skip Row\xc2\xa0I\xc2\xa0to avoid disappointing people who might think they\xe2\x80\x99ll be\xc2\xa0sitting in\xc2\xa0Row 1.\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s estimated that fewer than 40 people live above 800 feet in the city.\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0The narrowest townhouse in the city is\xc2\xa0about\xc2\xa09 feet wide\xc2\xa0(9 feet\xc2\xa06 inches,\xc2\xa0to be exact).\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0New York City\xc2\xa0homeowners\xc2\xa0can request that a tree be planted\xc2\xa0outside their homes for free.\n\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0And one of our favorites:\xc2\xa0Runners discard\xc2\xa0about 26 tons of clothing\xc2\xa0within the first few miles of the New York City Marathon.\nNew York Today is a weekday roundup that publishes at 6 a.m. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email\xc2\xa0here.\nFor updates throughout the day,\xc2\xa0like us on Facebook.\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Post a comment,\xc2\xa0email us at nytoday@nytimes.com, or reach us via Twitter using\xc2\xa0#NYToday.\nFollow the New York Today columnists,\xc2\xa0Alexandra Levine\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Jonathan Wolfe,\xc2\xa0on Twitter.\nYou can find the latest New York Today at\xc2\xa0nytoday.com.\nADVERTISEMENT\nFOLLOW NEW YORK TODAY\nFACEBOOK\n@NYTMetro\nNYTimes\nPinterest\nGet more NYTimes.com newsletters \xc2\xbb\n|\nGet unlimited access to NYTimes.com and our NYTimes apps for just $0.99.\xc2\xa0Subscribe \xc2\xbb\nABOUT THIS EMAIL\nYou received this message because you signed up for NYTimes.com's New York Today newsletter.\nUnsubscribe |\nManage Subscriptions |\nChange Your Email |\nPrivacy Policy |\nContact |\nAdvertise\nCopyright 2018 The New York Times Company 620 Eighth Avenue New York, NY 10018", b'These NYC Neighborhoods Have The Most Maddening Ice Cream Truck Noise - Gothamist\nmenu content begins\nGothamist\nDonate\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nSearch this site\nSearch\nSearch\nSend us a Story Idea\nNYPR\nView All Brands\nCaret Down\n\xc2\xa9 2019 New York Public Radio. All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nmenu content ends\nMenu\nGothamist\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDonate\nSearch\nSearch this site\nClose\nSearch\nSearch\nFood\nThese NYC Neighborhoods Have The Most Maddening Ice Cream Truck Noise\nBy\nAndres O\'Hara\nSept. 6, 2018 10:47 a.m.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nEmail\n(Robert S/ flickr)\nThe creepy Mister Softee songs mysteriously emanating from LinkNYC kiosks have gotten a lot of attention lately, but let\'s not forget that the original source of that ominous melody is still out there, prowling the streets and parking right outside your apartment for hours and hours and hours until you\'re hearing it jingle jangle into your dreams/nightmares.\nCity regulations state that ice cream trucks can only play music while moving, but the ice cream biz is notoriously lawless. In 2014, Gothamist reported that New Yorkers have lodged over 7,000 noise complaints since 2010, which averages out to almost five a day, 365 days a year.\nLocalize.city has updated the stats, and found that people may simply be learning to love the jingle (it is less creepy than the LinkNYC version?) and there has been a 20 percent reduction in noise complaints in the last 12 months. There were nearly 1,279 noise complaints about ice cream trucks filed during the last 12 months, through August 15th, 2018. Manhattan had a 47 percent decline in complaints, Brooklyn had a 25 percent decline, the Bronx has a 7 percent decline, while in Queens there was an 11 percent increase in complaints.\nThe areas that had the most complaints include Captain Tilly Park in Jamaica, Van Cortland Park in the Bronx, and the area between Madison Park and Union Square.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause these trucks are mobile, the local hot spots might vary year-to-year, but it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that there remain corridors where residents are persistently annoyed by the song and trying to do something about it,\xe2\x80\x9d Localize.city data analyst Daniel Slutsky said. "For example, last year saw a steep rise in complaints in the north part of Kingsbridge, near Van Cortlandt Park. Not far away though in Norwood, south of the Williamsbridge Oval, there was a drop in complaints compared to previous years. Perhaps, the ice cream truck routes changed \xe2\x80\x94 or the persistent complainers moved away."\nMany complainers, however, remain. As one rapidly unraveling Kingsbridge woman wrote on Facebook in April: \xe2\x80\x9cYOUR A***** DRIVER IS STILL PARKED ON VAN CORTLANDT PARK SOUTH AND BLASTING NOISE. YOU, MISTER SOFTEE, HAVE BEEN THERE FOR MORE THAN AN HOUR. DO NOT COME TO MY NEIGHBORHOOD.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThese are the top areas with the most ice cream song related complaints, according to Localize.city\nJamaica, around Captain Tilly Park\nFlatiron/Union Square, around Union Square Park and Madison Square Park\nKingsbridge, around Bailey Playground, Fort Independence Playground and Van Cortlandt Park\nSunset Park, around Rainbow Playground, Brizzi Playground and Sunset Park\nElmhurst/Corona, around Newtown Playground\nEast Harlem, around Rev. Linnette C Williamson Memorial Park, Martin Luther King Jr. Playground, Morningside Park, Marcus Garvey Park, TRUCE Garden and Playground One Twenty Five CXXV\nNorwood, around Whalen Park\nBedford-Stuyvesant, around John Hancock Playground, Herbert Von King Park, Hattie Carthan Community Garden, Banneker Playground and Tranquility Farm\nBoerum Hill/Fort Greene, around Nicholas Naquan Heyward Jr. Park, Boerum Park, North Pacific Playground, Fort Greene Park; Oracle Playground\nSoundview, around Soundview Park\nManhattanville/West Harlem, around Annunciation Playground, Jacob H. Schiff Playground, Montefiore Square, Alexander Hamilton Playground, Frank White Memorial Garden, Carmansville Park and Jackie Robinson Park\nInwood, around Inwood Hill Park, Fort Tryon Park, Dyckman House Museum and Isham Park\nIf you don\'t live in one of these neighborhoods, YouTube has you covered:\n#311\n#ice cream trucks\n#mister softee\n#noise complaints\nDo you know the scoop? \xc2\xa0 Comment below or Send us a Tip\nFeatured in Food\nRead More In:\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDashed Arrow\nBack to Top\nGothamist\nSend Us a Story Idea\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nGothamist is a website about New York City news, arts and events, and food, brought to you by New York Public Radio.\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nParty Confetti\nDashed Arrow\nSign up for our newsletter! All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy', b'Shining light on dark fiber, other broadband networks\nTopics\nWeek\'s top\nLatest news\nUnread news\nSubscribe\nScience X Account\nRemember me\nSign In\nClick here to sign in with\nor\nForget Password?\nNot a member?\nSign up\nLearn more\nNanotechnology\nPhysics\nEarth\nAstronomy & Space\nTechnology\nChemistry\nBiology\nOther Sciences\nshare this!\n2\n3\nShare\nEmail\nHome\nTechnology\nInternet\nHome\nTechnology\nTelecom\nSeptember 6, 2018\nShining light on dark fiber, other broadband networks\nby Rick Hellman,\nUniversity of Kansas\nA LinkNYC kiosk in Manhattan, shortly after its 2016 debut. Credit: Epicgenius, via Wikimedia Commons\nOnly a couple of months after they were installed in 2016, New York City decided to cut off internet access to a series of "smart city" kiosks it built to replace old telephone booths after homeless people monopolized them with such socially unpleasant activities as watching pornography and listening to loud music.\nAccording to a new paper co-authored by Associate Professor of Film & Media Studies Germaine Halegoua, skirmishes like those over LInkNYC "configure how the internet and the city street are and are not public, who is and is not supposed to be using these utilities, and who gets to decide their use." They write that this sort of failure of imagination plagues planners of both the visible parts of the internet infrastructure, like the kiosks, as well as the unseen and publicly unmapped expanses of "dark fiber" backbone network that are buried throughout America.\nIn an article published in June in the journal New Media & Society, Halegoua and her co-author, University of Pennsylvania Assistant Professor Jessa Lingel, write that during the 1990s, when much of the current internet infrastructure was built, network operators overestimated the rate at which demand for connectivity would grow. Thus they laid many thousands of miles of glass fibers in underground conduits that have remained unused, or "unlit," all these years later. That capacity is buried, out of sight and out of the public mind.\nIn contrast, some recent so-called smart-city efforts to distribute internet access through kiosks, wireless and fiber networks strive for visibility and public access.\nThe authors say their study "interrogates the social and material decisions about where networks are, who they are for and how they are accessed." Its title is "Lit up and left dark: Failures of imagination in urban broadband networks."\nFor the portion of the study involving the LinkNYC kiosks, Lingel walked around the three New York City boroughs where they had been installed and asked people what they thought about the kiosks, which the authors liken to "a Swiss Army knife of digital technology support, all free of charge."\nThe authors write that the Links, as they were called, "originally provided four key functions: a USB charger, a Wi-Fi hotspot, phone calls (provided by Vonage) and a web browser."\nLingel asked users who they thought had installed the Links and for what purpose. In fact, LinkNYC was a partnership between the city and companies including Qualcomm and Google.\nHalegoua\'s portion of the study was even trickier to tease out.\n"Maps of dark fiber are generally not available," she said. "That\'s private, corporate information."\nSo Halegoua used grant money from the Urban Communication Foundation and International Communication Association to pay for some of the maps she consulted for the study.\nThat information was compared to the map of LinkNYC kiosks to create a synthesis of the seen and unseen parts of the internet above and below the streets of the city.\nAs for why there is so much dark fiber honeycombing America today, Halegoua blames it, in part, on overbuilding spurred by turn-of-the-millennium exuberance. Like the LinkNYC creators, the builders of the dark-fiber networks failed to consider a wider range of populations living in rural and inner-city regions who would incorporate internet access into their daily lives.\n"It was a failure to imagine future uses and users and also to imagine simultaneous technological developments that disrupted their idea of what a fiber network and public internet access was," she said. "Today, we have other ways of connecting," with smartphones served by satellites and cell towers probably the most relevant.\nWith commercial imperatives having led broadband companies, by and large, to ignore poor communities, "smart cities" looking to improve access "need to expand the imagination of who might use those services and how," Haleguoa said. "If loud music is a problem, you might design the system differently."\nSome cities, including Lawrence, invested in fiber networks that wound up remaining largely dark. Urban planners and communities should try to learn from these histories, Halegoua said, and she hopes her paper can provide "recommendations \xe2\x80\xa6 for policymakers who want to build an urban broadband network that is more equitable or socially just."\nHalegoua is continuing her research on dark-fiber networks, with plans to write a book on the subject next year.\nExplore further\nNYC to pull plug on sidewalk internet after porn complaints\nMore information:\nGermaine R Halegoua et al. Lit up and left dark: Failures of imagination in urban broadband networks, New Media & Society (2018). DOI: 10.1177/1461444818779593\nProvided by\nUniversity of Kansas\nCitation:\nShining light on dark fiber, other broadband networks (2018, September\n6)\nretrieved 21 June 2019\nfrom https://phys.org/news/2018-09-dark-fiber-broadband-networks.html\nThis document is subject to copyright. Apart from any fair dealing for the purpose of private study or research, no\npart may be reproduced without the written permission.
