What are the consequences?\n\xc3\x97', b'Are LinkNYC Internet Kiosks Tracking Your Movements?\nTheIntercept_EnglishPortugu\xc3\xaasPoliticsJusticeNational SecurityWorldTechnologyEnvironmentSpecial InvestigationsVoicesPodcastsVideosDocumentsAboutEditorial PoliciesBecome a SourceJoin NewsletterBecome A MemberThe Intercept is a First Look Media Company.\xc2\xa9 First Look Media. All rights reservedTerms of usePrivacySitemapTheIntercept_Photo illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesPhoto illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesAre New York\xe2\x80\x99s Free LinkNYC Internet Kiosks Tracking Your Movements?Ava KofmanAva KofmanSeptember 8 2018, 1:00\xc2\xa0p.m.Photo illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesPhoto illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesLinkNYC kiosks have become a familiar eyesore to New Yorkers. Over 1,600 of these towering, nine-and-a-half-foot monoliths \xe2\x80\x94 their double-sided screens\xc2\xa0festooned with ads and fun facts \xe2\x80\x94 have been installed across the city since early 2016. Mayor Bill de Blasio has celebrated their ability to provide \xe2\x80\x9cthe fastest and largest municipal Wi-Fi network in the world\xe2\x80\x9d as \xe2\x80\x9ca critical step toward a more equal, open, and connected city for every New Yorker, in every borough.\xe2\x80\x9d Anyone can use the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 Android tablets to search for directions and services; they are also equipped with charging stations, 911 buttons, and phones for free domestic calls.\nBut even as the kiosks have provided important services to connect New Yorkers, they\xc2\xa0may\xc2\xa0also\xc2\xa0represent\xc2\xa0a troubling expansion of the city\xe2\x80\x99s surveillance network,\xc2\xa0potentially connecting every borough to a new level of invasive monitoring. Each kiosk has three cameras,\xc2\xa030 sensors, and heightened sight lines for viewing above crowds.\nSince plans for LinkNYC were first unveiled, journalists, residents, and civil liberties experts have raised concerns that\xc2\xa0the internet kiosks might be storing sensitive data about its users and possibly tracking their movements. For the last two years, the American Civil Liberties Union, Electronic Frontier Foundation, and a small but vocal group of activists \xe2\x80\x94 including ReThink LinkNYC, a grassroots anti-surveillance group, and the anonymous Stop LinkNYC coalition \xe2\x80\x94 have highlighted the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s potential to track locations, collect personal information, and fuel mass surveillance.\nNow an undergraduate researcher has discovered indications in LinkNYC code\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 accidentally made public on the internet\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0that LinkNYC may be actively planning to track users\xe2\x80\x99 locations.\nMayor Bill de Blasio speaks at\xc2\xa0a press conference next to\xc2\xa0a LinkNYC public internet\xc2\xa0kiosk on Feb 18, 2016.\nPhoto: Albin Lohr-Jones/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re the Product\nPlans to replace the city\xe2\x80\x99s payphone booth network with Wi-Fi-enabled kiosks were first announced by de Blasio in 2014. Less than a year later, the city awarded a contract to a chameleon-like consortium of private companies known as CityBridge. It was an attractive deal: LinkNYC kiosks, at no cost to the city, would provide free internet coverage to anyone walking by. CityBridge, in turn, would be responsible for the installation, ownership, and construction of the devices, with plans to earn back its expenses through advertising. The twin 55-inch displays will eventually carry targeted ads derived from the information collected about kiosk users.\nThese terms raised alarms among internet researchers and privacy experts, who were quick to point out that nothing in life is truly free. \xe2\x80\x9cAs we know,\xe2\x80\x9d Benjamin Dean, a technology policy analyst, told attendees at a New York hacking conference in 2016, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you\xe2\x80\x99re not paying, you\xe2\x80\x99re not the customer \xe2\x80\x94 you\xe2\x80\x99re the product.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe key player in CityBridge is known as Intersection, and one of Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s largest investors is Sidewalk Labs, with whom it also shares the same offices and staff. Sidewalk Labs CEO Daniel Doctoroff is the chair of Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s board. Sidewalk Labs is owned by Google\xe2\x80\x99s holding company, Alphabet Inc. In other words, the\xc2\xa0plan to blanket New York City with 7,500 camera-equipped obelisks has been largely underwritten by the company formerly known as Google \xe2\x80\x94 a corporation whose business model depends on selling your personal information to advertisers. As Doctoroff, who was also the city\xe2\x80\x99s former deputy mayor of economic development, has said of the kiosks: \xe2\x80\x9cBy having access to the browsing activity of people using the Wi-Fi \xe2\x80\x94 all anonymized and aggregated \xe2\x80\x94 we can actually then target ads to people in proximity and then obviously over time, track them through lots of different things, like beacons and location services, as well as their browsing activity. So in effect, what we\xe2\x80\x99re doing is replicating the digital experience in physical space.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn March 2016, the New York Civil Liberties Union raised multiple concerns with the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office about LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s vast and indefinite data retention and the possibilities for unwarranted NYPD surveillance. The NYCLU asked whether environmental sensors and cameras would be hooked up to NYPD systems, including the Domain Awareness System (built by Microsoft). LinkNYC has since updated its policy to state that it will take reasonable efforts to notify users if their information is being shared with law enforcement.\nIn May of this year, Charles Meyers, an undergraduate at New York City College of Technology, came across folders in LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s public library on GitHub, a platform for managing files and software, that appear to raise further questions about location tracking and the platform\xe2\x80\x99s protection of its users\xe2\x80\x99 data. Meyers made copies of the codebases in question \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC Mobile Observation\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRxLocation\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and shared both folders with The Intercept.\nAccording to Meyers, the \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC Mobile Observation\xe2\x80\x9d code collects the user\xe2\x80\x99s longitude and latitude, as well as the user\xe2\x80\x99s browser type, operating system, device type, device identifiers, and full URL clickstreams (including date and time) and aggregates this information into a database. In Meyers\xe2\x80\x99s view, this code \xe2\x80\x94 along with the functions of the \xe2\x80\x9cRxLocation\xe2\x80\x9d codebase \xe2\x80\x94 suggests that the company is interested in tracking the locations of Wi-Fi users in real time.\xc2\xa0If such code were run on a mobile app or kiosk, he said, the company would be able\xc2\xa0to make advertisements available in real time based on where and who someone was, and that this would constitute a potential violation of the company\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy.\xc2\xa0In 2016, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy made it clear that it did not collect information about users\xe2\x80\x99 precise locations. \xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d it states, \xe2\x80\x9cwe know where we provide WiFi services, so when you use the services we can determine your general location.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLinkNYC disputes these speculations. David Mitchell, Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s chief technology officer, told the Intercept that the code was never intended to be released and was part of a longer-term research and development process. \xe2\x80\x9cIn this instance,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained over email, \xe2\x80\x9cIntersection was prototyping and testing some ideas internally, using employee data only, and mistakenly made source code public on Github. This code is not in use on the LinkNYC network.\xe2\x80\x9d An Intersection spokesperson added that LinkNYC does not collect users\xe2\x80\x99 clickstream data or browsing history, and that it has not used the \xe2\x80\x9cRxLocation\xe2\x80\x9d codebase to collect user data. LinkNYC did not respond to repeated questions about the function or purpose of the code.\nThe Intercept asked four technologists, including a computer forensics investigator and an expert on Wi-Fi location tracking, to independently review the code. Each confirmed that the code could execute commands as Meyers had described, but they emphasized that it was not possible to determine the purpose of the code and whether it was actually running on any kiosks or devices\xc2\xa0based on the information given. They concluded that it was unlikely that\xc2\xa0the code\xc2\xa0was currently in use, as its unfinished security features pointed to the fact that\xc2\xa0it appeared to be in progress, possibly for a mobile product. \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t know why it exists, but the fact that it exists is creepy,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Surya Mattu, a research scientist and artist. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no way properly to interrogate this further as a third party.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFor many researchers and privacy experts, this lack of third party oversight represents the\xc2\xa0most significant issue. Privacy experts told The Intercept that the lack of clarity surrounding LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s leaked code points to the larger lack of transparency surrounding the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s operations. Despite their omnipresence in the city\xe2\x80\x99s major public spaces, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s pervasive data collection is not constrained by any auditing mechanisms, explained Daniel Schwarz, a technology fellow at the NYCLU. \xe2\x80\x9cWithout transparency and external auditing of the source code, as well as what data is collected, for what purpose, and how it is being monetized by the company,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is no way to verify whether the privacy policy is working to protect users\xe2\x80\x99 data.\xe2\x80\x9d\nA few hours after The Intercept contacted LinkNYC for comment, the company demanded that Github remove Meyer\xe2\x80\x99s copy of its code due to copyright violations.\nPedestrians pass one of the new Wi-Fi kiosks that offer free web surfing, phone calls and a charging station on August 24, 2016 in New York City.\nPhoto: Spencer Platt/Getty Images\nConnecting \xe2\x80\x94 and Controlling \xe2\x80\x94 Communities\nAs LinkNYC expands across the globe \xe2\x80\x94 Intersection has unveiled plans for kiosks in Philadelphia, Toronto, and the U.K. \xe2\x80\x94 so too does the scope of the concerns surrounding it. Shahid Buttar, the EFF\xe2\x80\x99s director of grassroots advocacy, has warned of the possibility of mission creep \xe2\x80\x94 that is, the expansion of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s uses beyond its stated purpose to provide free Wi-Fi. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no reason to presume that a current statement of policy will constrain the consortium of the future,\xe2\x80\x9d Buttar said.\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s current privacy policy already shows that the company sweeps up enormous amounts of sensitive data\xc2\xa0from all users, such as \xe2\x80\x9cMAC address (anonymized), IP address, browser type and version, time zone setting, browser plug-in types and versions, operating system and platform, device type, and device identifiers.\xe2\x80\x9d LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy classifies this information as technical, rather than personal, data.\xc2\xa0It may occasionally \xe2\x80\x9csupplement anonymized Technical Information we collect from you with information collected by third parties. Third parties may include advertising partners or other providers that help us understand our users.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThis distinction, privacy experts say, ignores the fact that device identifiers \xe2\x80\x94 even when anonymized \xe2\x80\x94 provide more than enough information to tell advertisers, law enforcement, or malefactors who we are, since most phones and computers are used by the individuals who own them. Knowing\xc2\xa0that a device has been in multiple locations, along with\xc2\xa0the history of the Wi-Fi networks it has visited,\xc2\xa0can provide enough information for someone to find out where individuals live, work, commute, shop, and so on.\xc2\xa0A recent Associated Press investigation found that many Google services for Android devices and iPhones were storing location data even if when users had turned on a privacy setting to prevent Google from doing so.\nAccording to privacy watchdogs, the rollout of the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s cameras have shown how the mission has already expanded beyond its initial purview. In 2016, LinkNYC disclosed that the kiosks \xe2\x80\x9cmay\xe2\x80\x9d contain cameras; by 2017, the cameras were operational. LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy states that cameras do not keep video records for more than seven days and that the camera footage is used to \xe2\x80\x9cimprove the services.\xe2\x80\x9d But opting out is not an option: Just by walking down the block, it is possible to be swept into its audio or video feeds, which can capture a nearly 360-degree view of their surroundings. Civil liberties experts have concerns about the circumstances under which CityBridge will share its ongoing taping with law enforcement. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, according to documents obtained by ReCode, Sidewalk Labs is selling kiosks to other cities that will be able to \xe2\x80\x9cmonitor pedestrian, bike and car traffic, track passing wireless devices, listen to street noise and use the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 built-in video cameras to identify abandoned packages.\xe2\x80\x9d Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s chief innovation officer told MIT Tech Review that it was considering upgrading kiosks to support augmented reality and autonomous vehicles.Join Our NewsletterOriginal reporting. Fearless journalism. Delivered to you.I\xe2\x80\x99m inThe NYCLU and EFF stated that the ambiguity surrounding Meyer\xe2\x80\x99s discovery of the code underscores the need for community-driven initiatives to protect the privacy and civil liberties of users. As EFF has noted, there are no means for New Yorkers to participate in decisions about how data from LinkNYC kiosks will be used, with whom they will be shared, for how long they will be retained, or whether the parameters under which they\xc2\xa0are initially collected might expand in the future. In response to Meyer\xe2\x80\x99s findings, ReThink LinkNYC is calling for third-party oversight to confirm that the company\xe2\x80\x99s software does what it says it does.\nThe New York City Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s Office did not respond to a request for comment on the calls for auditing and stronger oversight. Samir Saini, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT),\xc2\xa0wrote in an email to The Intercept following the publication of the story that \xe2\x80\x9cas a public project, LinkNYC can only exist if it conforms to the City\xe2\x80\x99s unambiguous commitment to user privacy. That means the City does not, and will never, allow the network operator \xe2\x80\x94 CityBridge \xe2\x80\x94 to exploit individual identifiers or precise location of LinkNYC users. If, at any time during our careful oversight of CityBridge, we discover practices that violate the Privacy Policy, we will direct CityBridge to immediately cease and desist from that practice. It is unfortunate that CityBridge inadvertently posted code on Github for an R&D project they were working on. CityBridge is not permitted to use code that tracks the precise location of users on the LinkNYC network.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn a follow-up email to The Intercept, Saini explained that city\xe2\x80\x99s audits will be \xe2\x80\x9ctriggered when DoITT feels that an investigation of specific franchisee practices is necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d \xc2\xa0At present there are no regular audits of the CityBridge agreement to determine whether LinkNYC is violating users\xe2\x80\x99 privacy.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t know if it\xe2\x80\x99s being held to its standards because there is so much opacity and not enough transparency surrounding the system,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Buttar. \xe2\x80\x9cThere needs to be some designated processes with public accountability and participation before the kiosk system and private organizations that constitute the consortium can propose changes unilaterally on millions of users.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCorrection: September 18, 2018\nThis article has been updated with comments from Samir Saini, commissioner\xc2\xa0of the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, who contacted The Intercept after publication. Saini clarified the LinkNYC privacy policy and explained that CityBridge does not retain the right to collect information about the specific websites users visit on their own devices.\nUpdate: September 10, 2018\nCharles Meyers filed a counter notice with Github, challenging LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s takedown demand, and he has made the code he found available again here.We depend on the support of readers like you to help keep our nonprofit newsroom strong and independent. Join\xc2\xa0Us\xc2\xa0Contact the author:Ava Kofman[email\xc2\xa0protected]\xe2\x80\x8bgmail.com@eyywa\nLeave a commentTheIntercept_Join Our NewsletterBecome a MemberWeekly editor\xe2\x80\x99s picksBreaking stories and exclusives2020 election coverageEmail list managed by MailChimp\nFilters SVG', b'CUOMO\xe2\x80\x99s terrible, no-good, very bad weekend \xe2\x80\x94 SIENA POLL shows CUOMO beating NIXON 63-22 \xe2\x80\x94 AG\xe2\x80\x99s race tightens, with MALONEY taking the lead \xe2\x80\x94 Why CUOMO won\xe2\x80\x99t ride the subway - POLITICO\nSkip to Main Content\nPOLITICO\nMagazine\nThe Agenda\nPro\nSearch\nSearch\nSECTIONS\nThe Agenda\nMagazine\nCongress\nWhite House\nElection 2020\nElection Results 2018\nVideo\nPodcasts\nNEWSLETTERS\nPlaybook\nPlaybook PM\nHuddle\nAll Newsletters\nSERIES\nThe Deciders\nThe Agenda: The Future of Prosperity\nWhat Works Next\nWomen Rule\nPOLITICO LIVE\nLive Home\nUpcoming Events\nPrevious Events\nAbout POLITICO Live\nCOLUMNS & CARTOONS\nJosh Gerstein\nRich Lowry\nJack Shafer\nMatt Wuerker\nCartoon Carousel\nPOLICY\nAgriculture\nCybersecurity\nDefense\nEducation\neHealth\nEmployment & Immigration\nEnergy & Environment\nFinance & Tax\nHealth Care\nSpace\nTechnology\nTrade\nTransportation\nEDITIONS\nCalifornia\nCanada\nChina\nEurope\nFlorida\nNew Jersey\nNew York\nPro\nFollow us\nTwitter\nInstagram\nFacebook\nMy Account\nLog InLog Out\nPolitico\nNew York Playbook\nNick Niedzwiadek and Erin Durkin\'s must-read briefing informing the daily conversation among knowledgeable New Yorkers\nGet the New York Playbook Newsletter\nEmail\nSign Up\nBy signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nCUOMO\xe2\x80\x99s terrible, no-good, very bad weekend \xe2\x80\x94 SIENA POLL shows CUOMO beating NIXON 63-22 \xe2\x80\x94 AG\xe2\x80\x99s race tightens, with MALONEY taking the lead \xe2\x80\x94 Why CUOMO won\xe2\x80\x99t ride the subway\n09/10/2018 07:22 AM EDT\nPresented by PhRMA\nBy Laura Nahmias in Manhattan, with Daniel LippmanIt was all going so well. After a string of early campaign gaffes \xe2\x80\x94 a surrogate referring to his challenger Cynthia Nixon as an \xe2\x80\x9cunqualified lesbian\xe2\x80\x9d and a bizarre remark about how Jews lack rhythm, among other things \xe2\x80\x94 Gov. Andrew Cuomo seemed to be finding his stride in the final weeks leading up to Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s Democratic primary election. Past polling has shown him winning handily, and a new Siena poll out this morning shows him beating Nixon by a 41-point margin. Then came the last 72 hours.Gov. Andrew Cuomo insisted Friday there was nothing political about his decision to hold a massive campaign-style event, and to invite Hillary Clinton, for the opening of the new Mario Cuomo bridge a week before the primary. By Friday night, it appeared that announcement was too hasty: the new span was closed again, after contractors working on the bridge realized the old Tappan Zee Bridge could collapse and endanger its new counterpart. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s opponents accused him of risking lives for the sake of having the bridge opening as a campaign backdrop. Hours later, reporters and politicians were learning about a mailer insinuating Cynthia Nixon is \xe2\x80\x9canti-semitic\xe2\x80\x9d being sent to voters by the State Democratic Party; among other things, it raised new questions about why the party is targeting a specific primary opponent before its members have had a chance to vote.Adopting a tactic he has used to distance himself from the troubled subway system that he runs, Cuomo tried to absolve himself of responsibility in both cases: Cuomo insisted that the State Democratic Party, which he effectively controls, sent out the Nixon mailer to thousands of homes without his approval. (Never mind the fact he\xe2\x80\x99s used the party as a vessel for his political ambitions since he took office 8 years ago.) And at a press conference he convened Sunday, he denied responsibility for the Tappan Zee Bridge problems.. "I have no authority in this situation," he said Sunday. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is not our bridge\xe2\x80\x9d...When the Second Avenue Subway opened last year, the governor poured champagne at its inaugural ride. Months later, he said that the state had no control over the subway system. On Friday, he drove FDR\'s car over the new span of the bridge he\'d pushed to be renamed after his own late father. But when government showed its cracks, literally, the buck stopped somewhere else.IT\xe2\x80\x99S MONDAY. L\xe2\x80\x99Shanah Tovah. Got tips, suggestions or thoughts? Let us know ... By email: LNahmias@politico.com, and daniel@politico.com, or on Twitter: @nahmias, and @dlippman.WHERE\xe2\x80\x99S ANDREW? Gov. Andrew Cuomo has not released a public schedule.WHERE\xe2\x80\x99S BILL? Mayor Bill de Blasio is visiting the Elmcor Senior Center, the 82nd Street\xe2\x80\x94Jackson Heights Subway station and in the evening, appearing live on NY1\xe2\x80\x99s Inside City HallWHERE\xe2\x80\x99S CYNTHIA? Democratic gubernatorial candidate Cynthia Nixon is appearing live on BuzzFeed\xe2\x80\x99s AM2DM morning showWHERE\xe2\x80\x99S MARC? In White Plains, criticizing Gov. Cuomo. Today\xe2\x80\x99s Tabloids: \xe2\x80\x94 Daily News: \xe2\x80\x9c9/11 FUND DEATH SPIRAL\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 New York Post: \xe2\x80\x9cLESS MOONVES\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 See them here and here: \xe2\x80\x94 Newsday: \xe2\x80\x9cCLOSING FOR REPAIRS\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 El Diario New York: \xe2\x80\x9cNo bajan la guardia\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 Translation: \xe2\x80\x9cThey do not lower their guard\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94See ThemThe Free Papers:\xe2\x80\x94 Metro New York: \xe2\x80\x9cRUFF REALTY\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 AM New York: \xe2\x80\x9cBURGER BATTLE\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 See ThemThe Broadsheets: \xe2\x80\x94 New York Times: \xe2\x80\x94 1 col., above the fold: \xe2\x80\x9cCBS CHIEF IS OUT AS MORE WOMEN CITE MISCONDUCT\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 4 col., above the fold: \xe2\x80\x9cA Turncoat Spy Went Free. Putin Never Forgave Him\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 1 col., above the fold: \xe2\x80\x9cDRONE MISSIONS CURBED BY OBAMA EXPAND IN AFRICA\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 Wall Street Journal: \xe2\x80\x94 5 col., above the fold: \xe2\x80\x9cMoonves Out as CBS Settles Suit\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 1 col., above the fold: \xe2\x80\x9cAssad Is Planning Chlorine Attack, U.S. Says\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 See ThemQuote of the Day: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you found a toad in your breakfast cereal you, would have it humanely removed. There happens to be a toad representing you in the state Senate. We need to vote (him or her) out of office.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 Language on mailers going out to voters from the Jim Owles Liberal Democratic Club, describing former members of the IDC as \xe2\x80\x9ctoads\xe2\x80\x9d and urging voters to vote them out. New Poll NumbersSiena Poll of Likely Democratic Primary Voters headline: "Cuomo widens lead over Nixon, 63-22 AG race: Sean Patrick Maloney leads the pack, barelyMaloney 25%, James 24%, Teachout 18%, Eve 3%Hochul Widens Lead Over Williams for LG 43-21%; 35% Remain Undecided"THE UPSHOT: \xe2\x80\x9cCuomo has massive leads among some of the groups that Nixon has hoped would oppose him. Cuomo leads 68-18 among New York City voters, despite Nixon\xe2\x80\x99s constant criticism of his handling of the subways. He has a 66-18 edge among women, and a 59-28 advantage among voters younger than 35.Nixon, in other words, is left with only two paths to victory. One entails a complete collapse by Cuomo, and she argues that this already has begun \xe2\x80\x94 a delay in the opening of a replacement for the Tappan Zee Bridge and the uproar over a mailer linking Nixon to anti-Semitism caused \xe2\x80\x9ca game changing weekend,\xe2\x80\x9d her campaign said in a statement on Sunday night. The other path would be that every poll conducted on the race to date has come nowhere close to capturing reality.\xe2\x80\x9d [POLITICO\xe2\x80\x99s Bill Mahoney]HE CONTROLS THE SUBWAY BUT HE DOESN\'T RIDE THEM \xe2\x80\x94 Step One: Take the train. Step Two: Get photographed taking the train. Step Three: Tweet out the photo (or rely on passers-by to do same). Would-be governor Cynthia Nixon does straphanger photo-ops. Council Speaker Corey Johnson does them, too. So occasionally does avowed motorist Mayor Bill de Blasio. Across the Hudson, Gov. Phil Murphy does it, on the foundering NJ Transit. In fact, perhaps the only major local politician who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do it is the one who controls New York\xe2\x80\x99s crisis-ridden subway system. That would be Gov. Andrew Cuomo. It\'s not like his advisers haven\'t tried to persuade him to give it a try. They\'ve urged Cuomo, who is running for a third term, to ride the subway on more than one occasion, according to two knowledgeable sources. The governor has demurred. One explanation has it that the image of a \xe2\x80\x9cpassive straphanger\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\'t align with the governor\xe2\x80\x99s can-do persona. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t enable him to don a windbreaker or grapple with machinery alongside predictably deferential transit workers. [Dana Rubinstein]\xe2\x80\x94 Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s Bridgegate, Flashback: July 9, 2018 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cTappan Zee Bridge document requests show staff in the dark about opening...The announcement that the first of the Gov. Mario M. Cuomo Bridge\'s two spans would open overnight Aug. 25 \xe2\x80\x94 the weekend before Labor Day \xe2\x80\x94 was made July 27 after nearly two years of a vague \xe2\x80\x98spring or summer 2017\xe2\x80\x99 deadline. Rather than a keen bit of planning, the decision appears to have been made by Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s office, rather than those working the $3.9 billion project day-to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d [Westchester Journal News\xe2\x80\x99s Matt Coyne]\xe2\x80\x94 View from the Left: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you believe Andrew Cuomo will govern as a progressive after 8 years of doing the opposite, I have a bridge collapsing on top of another bridge to sell you\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 [@DavidKlion] \xe2\x80\x94 Mailergate Fallout: \xe2\x80\x9cSource says mailer from @nydems accusing @CynthiaNixon of anti-semitism went out to about 7000 households and cost roughly $11,300. @geoffberman has promised to send out a mailer on behalf of Nixon campaign, but highly unlikely that could get done before Thursday primary.\xe2\x80\x9d [NY1\xe2\x80\x99s Zack Fink]\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cA state Democratic party mailer hitting gubernatorial primary foe Cynthia Nixon on Jewish issues is just the latest unforced error during a sloppy campaign by Gov. Cuomo that is still very much his to lose, insiders say.\xe2\x80\x9d [Daily News\xe2\x80\x99s Ken Lovett]\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the lowest form of politics, and the most dangerous, exploiting the festering wounds and fears along ethnic and religious lines.\xe2\x80\x9d [NYT Editorial Board]\nA message from PhRMA:\n86% of AARP members support the administration\xe2\x80\x99s proposed rule to reform the rebate system in Medicare Part D, according to a nationwide Morning Consult survey. However, AARP gets $4.5B from health insurance companies and is lobbying against this policy. If their members support this proposed rule, who is AARP really fighting for?\nWHAT ALBANY IS READING:\xe2\x80\x94 Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s campaign manager, the energy lobbyist \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cCuomo hired a lobbyist for a natural-gas pipeline company to run his re-election campaign at the same time his administration was throwing a potential lifeline to the company\xe2\x80\x99s controversial New Jersey-New York pipeline project. Less than three months before the administration postponed a decision on the project, The Williams Companies also donated $100,000 to a Democratic Party governors\xe2\x80\x99 organization that supports Cuomo...Cuomo spokesperson Rich Azzopardi asserted that there was no link between the lobbying, the donations and the administration\xe2\x80\x99s pipeline decisions.\xe2\x80\x9d [David Sirota and Chase Woodruff in WNYC]\xe2\x80\x94 Nixon\xe2\x80\x99s Digital Team Talks Strategy: \xe2\x80\x9cCuomo, a second-term Democrat, has used millions... on pricey television ads showcasing his accomplishments and sniping at his opponent, Nixon\'s scrappy digital team says they are taking a cue from other insurgent Democratic campaigns that are winning elections with small budgets and by creating big social-media buzz around the country..[her] campaign says it has poured more than $1 million into a comprehensive digital strategy, primarily on email, Facebook, Instagram and Twitter ad buys. A cursory view of the Facebook\'s newly launched political ad archive...shows that the Andrew Cuomo page has released 670 ads over the course of the campaign, while the Cynthia for New York page has put out 1300. \xe2\x80\x98The running joke around here is Cuomo is running the best campaign a 1990s candidate could buy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Nixon spokeswoman Lauren Hitt.\xe2\x80\x9d [Times Union\xe2\x80\x99s Rachel Silberstein]\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cJaw-dropping expenses at Finger Lakes Welcome Center\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9c... Records show taxpayers spent $9,900 for a road map area, $12,225 for four small signs pointing visitors to restrooms and the community room and $13,153 for a \'selfie\' wall that appears to be glorified wallpaper. Governor Andrew Cuomo jokingly took credit for some of the design during the building\'s ribbon-cutting ceremony. \xe2\x80\x98The truth is it was all me,\xe2\x80\x99 Governor Cuomo said. \xe2\x80\x98Upside down canoe light fixtures, when I first said it, they mocked me. Look how well they work.\xe2\x80\x99 The governor was referring to 4 canoes that were donated by a local boat museum. They were turned into dazzling lights; however, the cost for the rigging and lighting cost almost $50,000. A 10"x10" stainless steel frame to acknowledge that canoe donation cost $1,014.\xe2\x80\x9d [WGRZ]\xe2\x80\x94 Newsday endorsed Cuomo. \xe2\x80\x94 The governor scheduled a fundraiser for the week after the primary. WHAT CITY HALL IS READING: \xe2\x80\x94 Ritchie Torres Backs Jumaane Williams: Council Member and Progressive Caucus prodigal son Ritchie Torres will endorse fellow member Jumaane Williams for lieutenant governor Monday, splitting his ballot between his colleague and Gov. Andrew Cuomo \xe2\x80\x94 who is running on an opposing ticket. [POLITICO\xe2\x80\x99s Rosa Goldensohn]\xe2\x80\x94 New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said Saturday he will not make an endorsement in next week\xe2\x80\x99s marquee gubernatorial primary matchup between his longtime ally Cynthia Nixon and his frequent rival Gov. Andrew Cuomo, hinting that taking sides against the governor could have negative consequences for the city he governs. De Blasio, who for weeks has declined to publicly weigh in on the race now only days away, said in a statement he would keep his vote private in order to protect his relationship with whoever wins the Democratic primary. The mayor and governor have been in a years-long feud of unknown origin, but Nixon has intimated in recent weeks that she did not anticipate de Blasio\'s backing, citing the governor\'s penchant for retribution. [POLITICO\xe2\x80\x99s Gloria Pazmino]\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cYears of politicking, complaining, traveling to Iowa, trying to shape the \xe2\x80\x9cprogressive agenda.\xe2\x80\x9d And he stays out of the most important race in his home state.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 Washington Post\xe2\x80\x99s Josh Dawsey, @jdawsey1THE PANOPTICON \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAre New York\xe2\x80\x99s Free LinkNYC Internet Kiosks Tracking Your Movements?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9can undergraduate researcher has discovered indications in LinkNYC code \xe2\x80\x94 accidentally made public on the internet \xe2\x80\x94 that LinkNYC may be actively planning to track users\xe2\x80\x99 locations. [The Intercept\xe2\x80\x99s Ava Kofman]FOR YOUR RADAR -- The Republican Main Street Caucus, led by Rep. John Katko (R-N.Y.), has sent a letter to Speaker Ryan urging him to bring to the House floor a bipartisan reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA). Per a tipster: \xe2\x80\x9cVAWA is currently set to expire on September 30, 2018, creating uncertainty and a lapse in authorization for critical programs nationwide. ... There are 46 signers.\xe2\x80\x9dThe letter2018Attorney General Race: LEECIA EVE SAYS JAMES URGED HER TO DROP BID \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9dMs. Eve says that she received a call from Ms. James just 48 hours after Mr. Schneiderman\xe2\x80\x99s resignation. When she told Ms. James that she planned to run, Ms. Eve said Ms. James said she had hoped they could \xe2\x80\x98work something out.\xe2\x80\x99 Ms. Eve took that as an effort to persuade her to not enter the race, on the premise that two black women candidates would take votes from one another.\xe2\x80\x98How dare someone suggest there could be only one woman or one woman of color,\xe2\x80\x99 Ms. Eve said. \xe2\x80\x98Nobody raises these issues when two, three, four or 15 white men are running against each other.\xe2\x80\x99 Ms. James\xe2\x80\x99s camp said both women said they were running during the phone call and that they had wished one another luck. Delaney Kempner, a spokeswoman for Ms. James, denied that Ms. James asked Ms. Eve to drop out and said \xe2\x80\x98she is pleased to be running with such a diverse group of candidates.\xe2\x80\x99 [New York Times\xe2\x80\x99s Jeffery C. Mays]State Senate Races: \xe2\x80\x94 Specialized High School Test Plays Big in Avella/Liu Fight: Asian students, families, advocates and alumni associations for the schools have blasted Mayor Bill de Blasio\'s proposal to scrap an admissions test, arguing it would lead to a decline in academic rigor and discrimination against Asian students, who make up the majority of the students at the schools. The battle over the test, and the larger question of admitting more black and brown students to the specialized schools, has become a political football in the 11th state Senate District, where Liu, the former city comptroller and first Asian-American to be elected to citywide office, is trying to unseat Avella, a former member of the now defunct Independent Democratic Conference. [POLITICO\xe2\x80\x99s Madina Toure]\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cBrooklyn state Sen. Martin Dilan failed to report thousands of dollars in donations \xe2\x80\x94 in violation of state campaign finance law \xe2\x80\x94 dating back to 2016, the Daily News has learned.\xe2\x80\x9d [Ken Lovett]\xe2\x80\x94 32BJ SEIU, which has more than 160,000 members, is spending heavily on behalf of Alessandra Biaggi as she tries to unseat Democratic state Senator Jeff Klein, an advantage that \xe2\x80\x9ccould put Biaggi over the top in what is increasingly being viewed, despite Klein\xe2\x80\x99s significant advantages, as an unpredictable race given broader trends and recent upsets, Biaggi\xe2\x80\x99s strengths as a campaigner, and the activism behind her bid.\xe2\x80\x9d [Gotham Gazette\xe2\x80\x99s Samar Khurshid]REAL ESTATE, with POLITICO New York\xe2\x80\x99s Sally Goldenberg and Janaki Chadha:Johnson Floats Idea of City Subway Takeover: "New York City Council Speaker Corey Johnson on Friday floated the idea of a city takeover of the subways, \'since New Yorkers are the ones that are most invested in its success.\'...Johnson said that he did not have a plan developed for municipal rule, but envisioned the possibility of the state Legislature \'breaking New York City Transit off from the MTA umbrella.\' \'I mean, I don\'t know why they want the headache, honestly,\' he said of the state. \'They should want to give it to us. ... They would kind of be able to say, \xe2\x80\x98it\'s the city\'s fault, stop yelling at us about it.\'\xe2\x80\x9d POLITICO\'s Rosa Goldensohn and Dana Rubinstein\xe2\x80\x9cWhy one fifth of Manhattan storefronts are vacant:\xe2\x80\x9d Despite a boom in development and tourism, life for NYC\xe2\x80\x99s retailers is getting worse and worse. Douglas Elliman\xe2\x80\x99s head of retail leasing, Faith Hope Consolo, goes so far as to call it \xe2\x80\x98the most challenging retail landscape in my 25 years in real estate\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x99Elliman\xe2\x80\x99s recent survey of Manhattan found that 20 percent of storefronts were vacant, compared with the brokerage\xe2\x80\x99s 2016 results that found 7 percent vacancy. Borough president Gale Brewer conducted a study last year that found 188 empty stores along Broadway Avenue alone. [The Real Deal]NYCHA NEWS: "A Brooklyn NYCHA development located next to land that\'s been tainted by dry cleaning and petroleum spills recently registered alarming levels of chemicals in indoor air, the Daily News has learned.\xe2\x80\x9d [Daily News\' Greg B. Smith] You can find the free version of Sally and Janaki\xe2\x80\x99s real estate newsletter here: http://politi.co/2a1DgJkSOCIAL DATA: WEEKEND WEDDINGS \xe2\x80\x93 \xe2\x80\x9cAlexander Crohn, Salvador Trinidad\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 N.Y. Ebony Meeks Laidley \xe2\x80\xa6 journalist David Freedlander \xe2\x80\xa6 Lauren Hackett, SVP of global communications at The Economist \xe2\x80\xa6 (was Saturday): Emily Walsh, COS for NYC Council Member Keith PowersAROUND NEW YORK:\xe2\x80\x94 The Cortlandt Street Subway station, closed for 17 years after the 9/11 attacks, has finally reopened. \xe2\x80\x94 Former Gov. David Paterson told radio host John Catsimatidis that he is siding with President Donald Trump regarding the anonymous New York Times op-ed published this week. [The Hill]\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cThis Cynthia Nixon T-shirt won over the crowd at Christian Siriano\'s NYFW show\xe2\x80\x9d [USA TODAY]THE HOME TEAMS \xe2\x80\x94 Howard Megdal:Mets 6, Phillies 4: While the Mets still mull over whether to let franchise icon David Wright back on the field or risk angering their fans and the insurance company that covers Wright\'s contract further, Corey Oswalt helped dim the postseason hopes of the Phillies.Mariners 3, Yankees 2: Mitch Haniger\'s athleticism\xe2\x80\x94on the basepaths, in the field\xe2\x80\x94reduced the Yankees\' lead in the wild card race to just 2.5 games over Oakland.Jaguars 20, Giants 15: It\'s just one game, and Saquan Barkley looked good in his debut, but between the stagnant offense and Eli Manning interceptions, it felt a lot like last season\'s 3-13.Ravens 47, Bills 3: Nathan Peterman, Josh Allen: I\'m just not sure it matters who the quarterback is.The day ahead: The Mets host the Marlins. The ads encourage immigrants to contact 311 and ask about the NYCitizenship program which provides free legal help and financial consulting to eligible applicants.\nThe mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office said about 54 percent of the city\xe2\x80\x99s 3.1 million immigrants are naturalized U.S. citizens. Roughly 660,000 New York City immigrants who are lawful permanent residents, such as green card holders, are eligible to naturalize, the office said.\nLast year, 800 naturalization applications were filed through NYCitizenship, according to a representative from the office.\nAs of Sunday, there were 1,735 operational LinkNYC kiosks throughout the five boroughs. The city aims to ultimately install 7,500 kiosks, replacing old pay phone stations.\nCorrection: An earlier version of this story should have noted there are no plans to run the ads in print publications.\nGet Breaking News emails\nThe latest about your city, as it happens.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\nBy Ivan Pereira ivan.pereira@amny.com\n@IvanPer4\nIvan has been a staff reporter with amNewYork since May 2012 and covers breaking news, politics and enterprise stories.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nMore on this topic\nLinkNYC kiosks showcase writing for National Poetry MonthPoems were composed by those with HIV/AIDS and other conditions.\nCouncilman aims for LinkNYCs to include bus timesThe city and LinkNYC's operators, however, said the request is not feasible at this time.\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. All rights reserved.", b'We\'re Getting Closer To Cracking The Creepy Mister Softee LinkNYC Jingle Mystery - Gothamist\nmenu content begins\nGothamist\nDonate\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nSearch this site\nSearch\nSearch\nSend us a Story Idea\nNYPR\nView All Brands\nCaret Down\n\xc2\xa9 2019 New York Public Radio. All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nmenu content ends\nMenu\nGothamist\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDonate\nSearch\nSearch this site\nClose\nSearch\nSearch\nArts & Entertainment\nWe\'re Getting Closer To Cracking The Creepy Mister Softee LinkNYC Jingle Mystery\nBy\nJake Offenhartz\nSept. 17, 2018 1:57 p.m.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nReddit\nEmail\n(Drew Dies / Flickr)\nFor several months now, a hair-raising, inscrutable mystery has played out on the streets of New York: Why the hell is the Mister Softee jingle creepily blasting at half-speed from some of the city\'s LinkNYC kiosks? Is it a hack or an "old-fashioned phone prank"? A guerrilla commentary on the invasive nature of these data-siphoning obelisks that seem to be sprouting from the pavement each day? Or just another ice cream scam? Is it weird that we\'re hungry and frightened at the same time?\nSome answers to our questions remain elusive, but others are beginning to snap into focus. Over the weekend, tipster Jason Eppink encountered one of the singing kiosks at 35th Avenue and 37th Street in Astoria, and managed to jot down a phone number from the tablet\'s screen.\nApparently, someone\xe2\x80\x94something?\xe2\x80\x94is using the public WiFi hotspots to dial an answering machine in Iowa, which is, or at least was, connected to a recording of the latest version of the slowed-down jingle. That number is 563-999-1308, and up until last night, you could call it and hear an even stranger variant on the soundscape. In this iteration, the slowed-down ice cream jingle is remixed with some cryptic mutterings\xe2\x80\x94"There are 47 airplanes in the underground hospital, airplane #17 is performing stomach surgery on airplane #7," followed by a string of numbers.\nWe don\'t know, either, but go ahead and listen for yourselves:\nEppink\xe2\x80\x94who has his own history of public pranks, but swears he\'s not the culprit\xe2\x80\x94says he heard the dramatic song on both Saturday and Sunday this past weekend. He noted the active call had been going on for about 5 minutes (the calls are programmed to time out after 10 minutes), and says he\'s unsure whether it\'s "the original provocateur or someone building on their success."\nThe latest remix comes after some New Yorkers noticed the creepy theme song accompanied by an air raid siren in Astoria earlier this month.\n@LinkNYC @Gothamist @BrianLehrer LinkNYC stations around B\'way & 33rd St in Astoria are all playing slow-mo Mr Softee music accompanied by an air raid siren.\n#LinkNYCApocalypse pic.twitter.com/w14Y8YfYe2\xe2\x80\x94 Scott Ethier (@ScottEthier) September 2, 2018\nThe first slowed-down jingles\xe2\x80\x94sans air horns or hypnotic airplane mumblings\xe2\x80\x94were first heard in May of this year, and have since been spotted all over the city. There\'s also another LinkNYC kiosk in Astoria that, according to Eppink, has been known to play a call-in show focused on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We\'re not sure what to make of that, either.\n#astoria\n#linknyc\n#mister softee\nDo you know the scoop? \xc2\xa0 Comment below or Send us a Tip\nFeatured in Arts & Entertainment\nRead More In:\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nPopular\nDashed Arrow\nBack to Top\nGothamist\nSend Us a Story Idea\nFollow Us\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nGothamist is a website about New York City news, arts and events, and food, brought to you by New York Public Radio.\nAdvertising\nContact Us\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nParty Confetti\nDashed Arrow\nSign up for our newsletter! Share your email address to get our top stories each day.\nDashed Arrow\nSubmit email\nBy submitting your information, you\'re agreeing to receive communications from New York Public Radio in accordance with our Terms.\nNYPR\nView All Brands\nCaret Down\n\xc2\xa9 2019 New York Public Radio. All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy', b'Government wireless networks desperately need an upgrade -- GCN\nThe Technology that Drives Government IT\nAI & AutomationCybersecurityCloud & InfrastructureData & AnalyticsSmart Cities & IoTEmerging TechState & LocalMoreEventsResourcesNewslettersContactAdvertiseReprintsList Rental\nINDUSTRY INSIGHT\nGovernment wireless networks desperately need an upgrade\nBy Chris "CT" ThomasSep 17, 2018\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s government IT networks are at a crossroads. For too long, these networks have been locked into old technology, and agencies have not had the budget to innovate. Current systems are delivering a poor experience \xe2\x80\x93 for both end users and IT teams \xe2\x80\x93 and prevent new technologies from enabling agency missions.\nWhile government IT has stagnated, private-sector IT has raced forward, roughly doubling performance and capacity every five years. Technology giants such as Google and Amazon have leveraged new technologies to unlock gigantic value and productivity, creating new consumer experiences. They have dramatically raised expectations of what IT can accomplish and how it should be provided.\nWireless is the new network onramp for accomplishing the mission. Industry partners with both traditional Ethernet and wireless expertise can provide government agencies with an IT infrastructure on par with the leading tech giants of today. This will enable agencies to meet modernization goals and improve the IT experience for both internal and external users.\nThe time to upgrade is now, because the government wireless onramp needs a lot of repair. Two recent polls conducted by The Government Business Council highlight the need for immediate action.\nThe first survey asked government employees about the state of their agency\xe2\x80\x99s wireless or Wi-Fi networks. The results were sobering:\n50 percent rated their work network poor or very poor.\n63 percent said that their workday wireless experience was worse than what they encounter elsewhere.\n49 percent said the poor wireless experience hindered their productivity in fulfilling the mission.\nThe results from the second poll highlight employee dissatisfaction with current policies and the poor user experience relating to federal wireless networks:\nOnly 23 percent of respondents were satisfied with their agency\xe2\x80\x99s bring-your-own-device policy.\n22 percent were not allowed to use their personal devices at all, and 40 percent of those that can reported having to jump through onerous IT policy hoops.\nOver 61 percent felt that security concerns trump and interfere with workplace efficiency.\nNew wireless technology allows agencies to meet these challenges in a far more efficient and economical way. Wireless local-area networks have made dramatic leaps in performance over the past few years. And a better end-user experience is just the beginning of the benefits. Performance can be enhanced while improving security and lightening the load on the IT department.\nNewer software-as-a-service platforms make certificate-based solutions easier to implement as front ends to existing Network Access Control (NAC) solutions, enabling new customization features that reduce administrative overhead and complexity. These new certificate solutions are agnostic -- they can integrate into any network and can be deployed via the cloud or on-premises. Users register their devices one time, and from then on, connectivity is seamless.\xc2\xa0 Certificates are fully customizable to the specific workflow of the agency, and the IT team retains granular policy control over data access.\nCertificates leverage a public key infrastructure, a well-established method for the secure transfer of electronic information. Email clients, servers and smartphones have PKI support built in, and multiple certificate sources can be accommodated. Wireless network connections are protected with WPA-2 Enterprise, while also mitigating WPA-2\xe2\x80\x99s vulnerability to KRACK attacks. And many of the new solutions are much less expensive because they are priced per user not per device, which is the current pricing model for government NAC solutions.\nWith new technology, cities and bases can be made \xe2\x80\x9csmart\xe2\x80\x9d via wireless networks with a speed and efficiency unheard of just a few years ago, even in environments traditionally inhospitable to wireless connectivity, like inside steel buildings or across rural communities. These smart systems are advanced and future-proofed, ready to evolve and deliver whatever performance the towns need moving forward.\nWhen updating a wireless government network, it\xe2\x80\x99s important to remember that the network of the future requires a heterogeneous environment. Agencies must ensure that they work with best-of-breed partners for all elements of their network -- especially the edge. With technology advancing so quickly, agencies should not put all their IT eggs in one contractor\xe2\x80\x99s basket.\nAgencies can\xe2\x80\x99t continue to ask employees to accept an inferior user experience every time they log in at work. Specific smart city initiatives such as New York City\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC have demonstrated a better way forward, with clearly established best practices. By leveraging the latest technology, agencies can improve the user experience, simplify management and reduce costs.\nMuch like many of our country\xe2\x80\x99s roads and bridges, the government wireless onramp is in desperate need of maintenance. The good news is the right technology can give agencies a wireless network worthy to the mission, both quickly and economically.\nAbout the Author\nChris "CT" Thomas is senior systems engineer with Ruckus Networks.\nE-Mail this page\nPrintable Format\nRelated Articles\nThis year, cellular changes forever\nDon\'t panic: Nationwide test of emergency alert system set for Nov. 9\nDate set for first national test of alert system\nNavy recruits know technology, but they\'re not IT experts\nNavy to increase broadband speed tenfold\nGCN\nAdvanced Search\nStay Connected\nSign up for our ReleasesJob ListingsMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggers\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nLinkNYC kiosks to promote citizenship services for immigrantsSept. 17, 2018LinkNYC kiosks in New York City will run ads sponsored by the Mayor's Office of Immigrant Affairs that explain how to\xc2\xa0apply\xc2\xa0for citizenship. The campaign begins today, Citizenship Day, according to amny.com.The ads, which are also running in print publications, advise immigrants to call 311 to learn about a city-sponsored U.S.\xc2\xa0citizenship program, which includes free legal assistance and financial consulting services for eligible individuals.Topics: Government, Outdoor Kiosks, Wayfinding / InformationCompanies: LinkNYCSponsored Links:Related ContentKiosk Marketplace editor reviews 39 kiosk companies at National Restaurant ShowCustomers adapting to kiosks, but acceptance not uniform in all scenariosTaco Bell to install self-order kiosks in all stores in 2019 under its All Access initiativeSquare integration with Kiosk Pro app enables self-service for iPadsLatest ContentState-of-the-art testing: the first line of defense against fraudstersTexas Dairy Queen franchisee pioneers self-order kioskCashierless stores? appointment\xe3\x80\x8d\xe5\x8d\xb3\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\xbd\x89\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\xb0\x88\xe5\x93\xa1\xe3\x80\x82\n\xe6\xad\xa4\xe5\xa4\x96\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x99\xbd\xe6\x80\x9d\xe8\xb1\xaa\xe9\xbc\x93\xe5\x8b\xb5\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe5\xb1\x85\xe6\xb0\x91\xe9\x83\xbd\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x8f\x83\xe8\x88\x87\xe6\xb0\x91\xe4\xb8\xbb\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8c\x85\xe6\x8b\xac\xe5\x85\xac\xe6\xb0\x91\xe8\xa6\x81\xe7\x99\xbb\xe8\xa8\x98\xe9\x81\xb8\xe6\xb0\x91\xe3\x80\x81\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe6\x8a\x95\xe7\xa5\xa8\xe6\xac\x8a\xef\xbc\x9b\xe5\xb8\x82\xe9\x95\xb7\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe6\xb0\x91\xe4\xba\x8b\xe5\x8b\x99\xe8\xbe\xa6\xe5\x85\xac\xe5\xae\xa4\xe6\xad\xa4\xe6\xac\xa1\xe9\x82\x84\xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\xb8\x82\xe9\x81\xb8\xe8\x88\x89\xe8\xb2\xa1\xe5\x8b\x99\xe5\xa7\x94\xe5\x93\xa1\xe6\x9c\x83(Campaign Board)\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe3\x80\x8c\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe5\xb8\x82\xe6\xb0\x91\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe3\x80\x8d(DemocracyNYC)\xe9\xa0\x85\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\x90\x88\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe6\x8e\xa8\xe5\x87\xba\xe6\x96\xb0\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe5\x8d\xa1\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe8\xaa\x9e\xe7\xa8\xae\xe5\x90\x91\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe6\xb0\x91\xe7\xa4\xbe\xe5\x8d\x80\xe6\x99\xae\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe8\xaa\xb0\xe8\x83\xbd\xe6\x8a\x95\xe7\xa5\xa8\xe3\x80\x81\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe7\x99\xbb\xe8\xa8\x98\xe9\x81\xb8\xe6\xb0\x91\xe7\xad\x89\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb0\x87\xe6\x96\xbc\xe8\xbf\x91\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe7\x99\xbc\xe6\x94\xbe\xe7\xb5\xa6\xe5\xb8\x82\xe6\xb0\x91\xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\xa4\xbe\xe5\x8d\x80\xe6\xa9\x9f\xe6\xa7\x8b\xe3\x80\x82\n\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe5\x8d\xa1\xe9\x82\x84\xe5\xb0\x87\xe4\xbb\x8b\xe7\xb4\xb9\xe5\xb1\x85\xe6\xb0\x91\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe8\xab\x96\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe6\xb0\x91\xe8\xba\xab\xe5\x88\x86\xe7\x82\xba\xe4\xbd\x95\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x83\xbd\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe5\x8f\x83\xe8\x88\x87\xe6\xb0\x91\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe9\x80\xb2\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x80\x94\xe5\xbe\x91\xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\xb9\xb3\xe5\x8f\xb0\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8c\x85\xe6\x8b\xac\xe7\x95\xb6\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe7\xa4\xbe\xe5\x8d\x80\xe5\xa7\x94\xe5\x93\xa1\xe6\x9c\x83\xe5\x92\x8c\xe6\x95\x99\xe8\x82\xb2\xe7\x90\x86\xe4\xba\x8b\xe6\x9c\x83\xe3\x80\x81\xe5\x8f\x83\xe8\x88\x87\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe9\xa0\x90\xe7\xae\x97(participatory budgeting)\xe3\x80\x81\xe7\xa4\xbe\xe5\x8d\x80\xe7\xbe\xa9\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe3\x80\x81\xe6\x94\xbf\xe6\xb2\xbb\xe7\xab\xb6\xe9\x81\xb8\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8b\x99\xe7\xad\x89\xe3\x80\x82\n\xe5\xb8\x82\xe9\x95\xb7\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe6\xb0\x91\xe4\xba\x8b\xe5\x8b\x99\xe8\xbe\xa6\xe5\x85\xac\xe5\xae\xa4\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe6\x91\xa9\xe6\x96\xaf\xe6\x89\x98\xe8\x8f\xb2(Bitta Mostofi)\xe8\xa1\xa8\xe7\xa4\xba\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe6\xb0\x91\xe7\x82\xba\xe7\xb6\x93\xe6\xbf\x9f\xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\xa4\xbe\xe5\x8d\x80\xe7\x99\xbc\xe5\xb1\x95\xe6\xb3\xa8\xe5\x85\xa5\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe5\x8a\x9b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x84\xa1\xe8\xab\x96\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe6\xb0\x91\xe8\xba\xab\xe5\x88\x86\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe5\xae\xa2\xe9\x83\xbd\xe5\xb0\x87\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x9c\xaa\xe4\xbe\x86\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x9f\x8e\xe5\xb8\x82\xe5\xbb\xba\xe8\xa8\xad\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x99\xbc\xe6\x8f\xae\xe9\x97\x9c\xe9\x8d\xb5\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe7\x94\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xae\x93\xe5\x9f\x8e\xe5\xb8\x82\xe8\xae\x8a\xe5\xbe\x97\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe7\xbe\x8e\xe5\xa5\xbd\xef\xbc\x9b\xe3\x80\x8c\xe9\x80\x99\xe5\x80\x8b\xe5\x85\xac\xe6\xb0\x91\xe6\x97\xa5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x91\xe5\x80\x91\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x9b\xae\xe6\xa8\x99\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\x8a\xa9\xe5\x8a\x9b\xe9\x82\xa3\xe4\xba\x9b\xe6\xb8\xb4\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe6\x88\x90\xe7\x82\xba\xe5\x85\xac\xe6\xb0\x91\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xba\xba\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xb8\xa6\xe7\x82\xba\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe5\xae\xa2\xe6\x8f\x90\xe4\xbe\x9b\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe5\x8f\x83\xe8\x88\x87\xe6\xb0\x91\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe3\x80\x8d\xe3\x80\x82\n4\xe6\x88\x90\xe7\xb6\xb2\xe7\xb4\x84\xe8\xbb\x8a\xe7\x82\xba\xe7\xa7\x9f\xe8\xb3\x83 ...\xe5\x85\xa8\xe5\xb8\x82\xe9\xab\x98\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x8d\x9a\xe8\xa6\xbd\xe6\x9c\x83 \xe4\xbb\x8a\xe5\xb9\xb4 ...\n\xe8\xb6\x85\xe4\xba\xba\xe6\xb0\xa3\xe6\x96\xb0\xe8\x81\x9e\n5\xe7\xa7\x92\xe5\x89\x9d\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe8\x92\x9c \xe7\xb6\xb2\xe8\xb7\xaf\xe7\xa5\x9e\xe6\x8b\x9b \xe6\x93\x8a\xe8\x90\xbd\xe7\xbe\x8e\xe8\xbb\x8d\xe7\x84\xa1\xe4\xba\xba\xe6\xa9\x9f \xe7\xbe\x8e\xe6\xac\xb2\xe9\x96\x8b\xe6\x88\xb0 \xe8\xad\xa6\xe7\xb1\xb2\xe6\xb0\x91\xe7\x9c\xbe\xe5\x8d\x94\xe5\xb0\x8b\n\xe5\xba\xb7\xe5\xb0\xbc\xe7\xbe\x8e\xe4\xba\xba\xe9\xad\x9a\xe9\x81\x8a\xe8\xa1\x8c 22\xe6\x97\xa5\xe7\x99\xbb\xe5\xa0\xb4\n\xe5\x8b\x9e\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe3\x80\x81\xe7\x92\xb0\xe5\xa2\x83\xe5\x95\x8f\xe9\xa1\x8c\xe5\xa4\x9a \xe4\xba\x9e\xe6\xb4\xb2\xe5\x8d\x94\xe6\x9c\x83\xef\xbc\x9a\xe4\xb8\x80\xe5\xb8\xb6\xe4\xb8\x80\xe8\xb7\xaf\xe6\x87\x89\xe5\xa2\x9e\xe9\x80\x8f\xe6\x98\x8e\xe5\xba\xa6\n8\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe9\x81\x93\xe8\xbb\x8a\xe7\xa6\x8d \xe8\x8f\xaf\xe7\x94\xb7\xe9\xa8\x8e\xe8\x87\xaa\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe8\xbb\x8a\xe5\x8f\x97\xe8\xbc\x95\xe5\x82\xb7\n112\xe5\x88\x86\xe5\xb1\x80\xe8\xad\xa6\xe6\xb0\x91\xe6\x9c\x83 \xe8\xad\xa6\xe7\xb1\xb2\xe9\x96\x80\xe7\xaa\x97\xe6\x87\x89\xe7\xb7\x8a\xe9\x8e\x96\n\xe9\x95\xb7\xe6\xa6\xae\xe8\x88\xaa\xe7\xa9\xba\xe7\xbd\xb7\xe5\xb7\xa5 \xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe5\x91\xa8\xe5\x85\xad\xe8\x88\xaa\xe7\x8f\xad\xe5\x8f\x96\xe6\xb6\x88\n\xe7\xa6\x81\xe6\xad\xa2\xe5\x88\x87\xe9\x99\xa4\xe8\xb2\x93\xe7\x88\xaa\xe2\x80\xa6\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe5\xb7\x9e\xe9\xa6\x96\xe5\x85\x88\xe5\xaf\xa6\xe6\x96\xbd \xe5\x8f\x8d\xe5\xb0\x8d\xe6\xb4\xbe\xe6\x89\xb9\xe6\xb2\xbb\xe6\xa8\x99\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe6\xb2\xbb\xe6\x9c\xac\n\xe7\x9a\x87\xe5\x90\x8e\xe5\x8d\x80\xe5\x82\x91\xe5\x85\x8b\xe6\xa3\xae\xe9\xab\x98\xe5\x9c\xb084\xe8\xa1\x97\xe4\xba\xba\xe5\xad\x94\xe7\x99\xbc\xe7\x94\x9f\xe7\x88\x86\xe7\x82\xb8 \xe7\x81\xab\xe5\x8b\xa2\xe4\xbb\x8d\xe6\x9c\xaa\xe8\xa2\xab\xe6\x92\xb2\xe6\xbb\x85\n\xe5\x9b\xa0\xe7\x88\xad\xe5\x9f\xb7\xe6\x8b\xbf\xe8\xb5\xb7\xe9\x85\x92\xe6\x9d\xaf\xe5\x82\xb7\xe4\xba\xba \xe5\xb8\x83\xe7\xa2\x8c\xe5\xb4\x99\xe7\x94\xb7\xe5\xad\x90\xe9\x81\xad\xe8\xad\xa6\xe9\x80\x9a\xe7\xb7\x9d\n\xe3\x80\x8c\xe8\xa3\xbd\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe9\x9f\xb3\xe6\xa8\x82\xe7\xaf\x80\xe3\x80\x8d\xe5\x91\xa8\xe4\xba\x94\xe6\x8f\xad\xe5\xb9\x95 \xe5\xb8\x83\xe7\xa2\x8c\xe5\xb4\x99\xe5\xa5\xbd\xe6\x88\xb2\xe9\x80\xa3\xe5\x8f\xb0\n\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\xa4\x9a >\n;\n\xef\xbb\xbf\n\xe9\x97\x9c\xe6\x96\xbc\xe4\xb8\x96\xe5\xa0\xb1\n\xe9\x97\x9c\xe6\x96\xbc\xe6\x88\x91\xe5\x80\x91\n\xe8\x88\x87\xe6\x88\x91\xe5\x80\x91\xe8\x81\xaf\xe7\xb5\xa1\n\xe5\xbb\xa3\xe5\x91\x8a\xe5\x83\xb9\xe7\x9b\xae: \xe5\xa0\xb1\xe7\xb4\x99\n\xe5\xbb\xa3\xe5\x91\x8a\xe5\x83\xb9\xe7\x9b\xae: \xe7\xb6\xb2\xe8\xb7\xaf\n\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe6\xa9\x9f\xe6\x9c\x83\n\xe5\xae\xa2\xe6\x88\xb6\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8b\x99\n\xe8\xa8\x82\xe5\xa0\xb1\n\xe6\x8a\x95\xe7\xa8\xbf\n\xe9\x9b\xbb\xe5\xad\x90\xe5\xa0\xb1 ePaper\n\xe9\x9b\xbb\xe9\x83\xb5\xe5\xa0\xb1 eNews\n\xe4\xb8\x96\xe7\x95\x8c\xe9\xbb\x83\xe9\xa0\x81\xe7\xb6\xb2\n\xe4\xb8\x96\xe7\x95\x8c\xe5\x88\x86\xe9\xa1\x9e\xe7\xb6\xb2\n\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe5\x8b\x95\n\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe5\x8b\x95\xe9\x83\xa8\n\xe6\xb4\x9b\xe6\x9d\x89\xe7\xa3\xaf\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe5\x8b\x95\n\xe8\x88\x8a\xe9\x87\x91\xe5\xb1\xb1\xe6\xb4\xbb\xe5\x8b\x95\n\xe7\xa4\xbe\xe7\xbe\xa4\n\xe5\xbe\xae\xe4\xbf\xa1\n\xe8\x87\x89\xe6\x9b\xb8\n\xe5\xbe\xae\xe5\x8d\x9a\n\xe5\xb0\x88\xe5\x88\x8a\n\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe5\x95\x86\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8b\x99\xe9\x83\xa8\n\xe6\xb4\x9b\xe6\x9d\x89\xe7\xa3\xaf\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe5\x95\x86\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8b\x99\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xbf\x83\n\xe8\x88\x8a\xe9\x87\x91\xe5\xb1\xb1\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe5\x95\x86\xe6\x9c\x8d\xe5\x8b\x99\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xbf\x83\nWorld MovePersonalisationPR StuntsPremier LeagueProgrammaticRadioSainsburysShazam ChartSingaporeSnapchatSports MarketingSpotifySuper BowlTVTwitterUFCValentines DayVice MediaVodafoneWieden+KennedyWPPYouTubeNewsCarvana\xe2\x80\x99s New York market launch holds true to its unconventional car buying methodsCreative Works\nBy Kyle O'Brien-20 September 2018 14:17pm\nCarvana delivers cars to New York City\nResidents in New York City can order just about anything online and get it delivered to their front door, and now that includes a car, thanks to Carvana. The ecommerce platform for buying, financing and selling used cars has now launched as-soon-as-next-day vehicle delivery in the Big Apple.To celebrate entering its largest market to date, Carvana is maximizing its marketing presence in Manhattan with a one-day integrated campaign today (September 20) to tell New Yorkers about the company\xe2\x80\x99s way of buying a car. Carvana will actually parade its services through New York with a caravan of five signature Carvana car haulers carrying vehicles. Partnering with a production artist, Carvana designed three car-sized takeout bags for NYC-style delivery, emphasizing that you can now order a car online and have it delivered to your doorstep. The parade will cross the Manhattan Bridge from Brooklyn and tour through the city, passing signature areas like SoHo, Columbus Circle, Midtown and Washington Square Park.Throughout the day, more than 250 digital on-street LinkNYC units will display Carvana advertising along the parade route, as well as a live social feed of those using the campaign hashtag #TheNYCWayToBuyACar. Those who spot the parade are encouraged to snap a photo and post to their social handles using the hashtags #TheNYCWayToBuyACar and #sweepstakes for a chance to win a year of free Postmates (up to $5,000).\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City is the largest market we\xe2\x80\x99ve launched to date, so it\xe2\x80\x99s fitting we give it our largest celebration\xe2\x80\x9d said Ernie Garcia, founder and chief executive of Carvana. \xe2\x80\x9cNew Yorkers are known for being mobile-first, so we\xe2\x80\x99re proud to be the first to give them a fully start-to-finish mobile car buying experience; a service they\xe2\x80\x99ve become accustomed to for much of their purchasing decisions.\xe2\x80\x9dCarvana now offers as-soon-as-next-day vehicle delivery in nearly 80 markets across the US. Carvana customers shop for and purchase their next vehicle entirely online, saving a trip to the dealer along with time and money. Along with high-definition, 360-degree photos, every Carvana vehicle comes with a seven-day return policy so the customer has time to ensure the vehicle fits their life.\nCustomers can shop more than 10,000 vehicles on Carvana.com, finance, purchase, and even sell their current vehicle to Carvana, then schedule as-soon-as-next-day delivery to their home or office in as little as 10 minutes.Building campaigns from the insideCarvana was founded in the digital age, in 2012 in Phoenix, with a mission to change the way people buy cars. They also changed the way auto sales marketing is done, pulling their creative teams in house to make for a vertically integrated experience, from campaign ideation to the final sale.Paul Keister, Carvana\xe2\x80\x99s chief creative officer, was a former agency creative, and executive director at his agency, Goodness Mfg, when he started working with the upstart Carvana. After working on his first project with the company and Carvana\xe2\x80\x99s co-founder and chief brand officer, Ryan Keeton, they knew it was a good fit and Keister came over to run the in-house team.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re vertically integrated, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve made a decision to build versus buy to be able to control that whole chain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Keeton. \xe2\x80\x9cWe outsource a small amount of things here or there \xe2\x80\x93 PR, and media planning and buying, we work with Horizon Media. Everything else, from social, creative to design to digital marketing, to quantitative analytics\xe2\x80\xa6 people with PhDs in astrophysics building out models for our marketing \xe2\x80\x93 that\xe2\x80\x99s all in house. We made that choice because we believe you\xe2\x80\x99re able to focus really deeply. We needed to build the capability ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9dThe in-house agency covers roughly 30 people in Phoenix and in Venice, California. Being internal means that the creatives can spend their time focusing on brand solutions and producing new creative, rather than pitching new business.\xe2\x80\x9cWe take the best of what makes an agency tick and focus there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Keister, adding that they make identify the business priority, then write a brief. After that, they find the \xe2\x80\x9cideas we like, flesh them out, build them, make sure they\xe2\x80\x99re hitting the key objectives, and produce them. It\xe2\x80\x99s much more streamlined (than agencies). We still provide hearty discussions and checks and balances with each other.\xe2\x80\x9dNot Carvana\xe2\x80\x99s first stuntThe campaigns at Carvana started with one that still has legs, one that started when Keister was at Goodness, called the Wavy Guy.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the story of the lovable Wavy character at the dealership that has been silent witness to all the things that have happened over time. He gets fed up when he punches the clock and goes home (to his Wavy family) and decides to use Carvana. That helped get traction. Wavy Guy was effective to our growth. That single campaign has had a long shelf live,\xe2\x80\x9d said Keeton.\nHe added that television has been an effective advertising medium for the company, due to its national reach. Other campaigns have included \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t Play the Game\xe2\x80\x99 where people had to play ridiculous dealer games only to lose money, and a New Way to Buy a Car Smell, which spoofed cologne commercials by adding silly ingredients, including a \xe2\x80\x9csingle tear of a car salesman.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSocial media has helped grow the company as well, and one of the main catalysts for that is the life-sized Carvana car vending machine.\xe2\x80\x9cIf you look at the key performance indicators, the ultimate one is someone buying a car. We\xe2\x80\x99ve had customers directly reference that vending machine experience as their first point of contact with Carvana. That shows it was provocative enough for them to learn more about us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Keister.\nCarvana vending machine\nAdded Keeton: \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s an asset that we developed to use in markets to build awareness. We\xe2\x80\x99ve taken it on tours. Not only is it a physical element, it\xe2\x80\x99s got an interactivity to it. People love taking a picture using it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, adding that those pics are often shared on social media.The two added that the car business is a noisy one, and they use their marketing tactics to show people that Carvana is a very different way to buy.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not a marketplace. With us you don\xe2\x80\x99t have to deal with the hassle of dealers, of a salesperson. We don\xe2\x80\x99t have overhead. Once folks start to understand and dig in\xe2\x80\xa6 doing it all from home makes a big difference,\xe2\x80\x9d said Keeton.\nCarvana Car Delivery\nAdded 20 September 2018\nOverall Rating\n5/5\nVote\nThis article is about: North America, Automotive, Advertising, Creative, Marketing, BrandShare to TwitterShare to LinkedInShare to FacebookGet The Drum NewsletterBuild your marketing knowledge by choosing from daily news bulletins or a weekly special.RelatedOpen MicRecommended ReportsFrom our Network\nThe Drum articles suggested by\nHelping publishers increase engagement, improve monetization and drive new audiences.\nRead moreMore Must WatchOn The SceneTalking HeadsDrum DocumentariesEverything You Need To KnowFuture Stars Of DigitalBrand LoveVideoThe CMO Swap: Britvic x TribeVideoRosie Arnold looks back on her career and explains why she never wanted to start her own agencyVideoFearless Girl statue disappears from New York's streetsVideoEverything you need to know: Programmatic 2.0 The value of the middle pathVideoIs this the era of social media reckoning? The campaign begins today, Citizenship Day, according to amny.com.The ads, which are also running in print publications, advise immigrants to call 311 to learn about a city-sponsored U.S.\xc2\xa0citizenship program, which includes free legal assistance and financial consulting services for eligible individuals.Topics: Content, Government, Interactive / Touchscreen, Outdoor SignageSponsored Links:Related ContentMenu boards deliver upgraded restaurant experiences3 ways to waste your digital signageH&M, wayfinding claim top spots for May 2019 digital signage storiesHow to do digital wayfinding rightLatest ContentHong Kong celebrates art with AR gamesHow to design heavenly digital signage contentWhat's your biggest struggle with digital signage?Will San Francisco ban on facial recognition affect digital signage?Get the latest news & insightsSubscribeLinkedIn Twitter Facebook RSSNewsComQi, AUO deliver all-in-one digital signageUpshow partners with Jukin Media for DOOH engagementInewvation deploys digital signage at Jewel Changi AirportMeridian awards recipients of 2019 scholarshipAtlona appoints Ewing-Foley to distribute products in Western US, AlaskaViewSonic intros 2 WUXGA laser projectorsAmazon, LG integrate Alexa into hotel TVsSee More \xc2\xbbResources[WEBINAR]: Critical considerations when transitioning from traditional to interactive digital signageINDOOR VS. Then remaining mainly cloudy. Thunder possible. Low 56F. Winds ESE at 10 to 20 mph. Chance of rain 80%..\nTonight\nRain ending early. Then remaining mainly cloudy. Thunder possible. Low 56F. Winds ESE at 10 to 20 mph. Chance of rain 80%.\nUpdated: June 21, 2019 @ 4:26 pm\nFull Forecast\nHome\nLife\nTravel\nClose\nA traveler uses a power, Wi-Fi and information kiosk while visiting the Big Apple. (LinkNYC Kiosk photo courtesy of CityBridge)\nLinkNYC Kiosk/CityBridge\nFacebook\nTwitter\nSMS\nEmail\nPrint\nSave\nSavvy ways to stay charged on the road\nMyscha Theriault\nTribune News Service\nSep 21, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nSMS\nEmail\nSubscribe: Only 33 cents a day\nA traveler uses a power, Wi-Fi and information kiosk while visiting the Big Apple. (LinkNYC Kiosk photo courtesy of CityBridge)\nLinkNYC Kiosk/CityBridge\nFacebook\nTwitter\nSMS\nEmail\nPrint\nSave\nJuggling appointments, project deadlines and video conferencing from the road with a constant ticking clock on battery power is problematic to say the least. Factor in a GPS misfire, a flat tire or even an unexpectedly long meeting, and the situation is amplified significantly. During the past year, a few new options have floated across my radar for fighting this dilemma with as little frustration as possible. Following are my favorite strategies for keeping battery woes at bay.Combos: Carrying a separate battery backup and charging cable to keep your phone topped off can be a real drag when you are already running short of space in your gear bag. Finding a spot to plug in both devices along with your laptop at a crowded airport gate can be a frustrating feat as well. Recently, my husband and I discovered the existence of battery cases for our smartphones.Since the battery is located inside the protective case you place on your mobile anyway, you receive additional functionality out of an item you were already using. No extra storage space necessary. There's also no extra charging cord required since using the same attachment port you would normally use to charge your phone through your phone case charges both items at once. For less than $20 a pop, we ordered one for each of us and never looked back. We receive more than double the charge time and our equipment takes up as little space as possible. Ours are from a company called Accerzone, which makes cases to fit our particular phones, but prices are comparable for equivalent products to suit other models.\nSize: As with the cases mentioned above, the size of any piece of technical travel equipment is of specific concern. Bulky gear is always a bore, but portable battery rechargers can be exceptionally frustrating when it comes to finding luggage room. This is why my husband and I were so excited to find a miniature one by Nuon on the Batteries Plus website recently. Previously, we always switched between regular and rechargeable batteries whenever we transitioned between fast-paced travel to stationary periods where we slow down to work on more time-consuming projects. For 30 bucks, we now have a space-efficient option for recharging the batteries we use most often on the road for things such as specialized astronomy binoculars and red light headlamps.Another go-to piece of charging equipment for our household is a world power travel adapter by Targus. While the $20 price we paid was certainly right for our budget, what we really love most about it is the fact it all fits in a compact tube shape that's easy to pack. So many similar products can be enormous by comparison, and make working while abroad more frustrating than it needs to be, particularly on days when we need to change locations with all of our bags in tow. We've been using this power adapter for several years now, and it continues to work seamlessly whenever we need it.Infrastructure: Any digital nomad who routinely uses fast food establishments and bookstore coffee shops to crank out some work between highway stops can attest to one highly inconvenient truth. Free Wi-Fi doesn't necessarily mean free electrical access to go with it. For those living out of a carry-on bag with limited space, one multi-plug adapter and a single extension cord will only get you so far, particularly if you need to go for long stretches of time between traditional charging options. In addition to in-flight power ports and more charging stations showing up at airports these days, some interesting new options are starting to show up in major cities.LinkNYC, for example, offers power charging and internet access at free-to-use kiosks throughout the Big Apple. Visitors needing to charge their mobile device can do so via a USB port connected only to power for security purposes, while still accessing the internet via a touch screen and keypad for free calls and information searching as they wait to power up. Residents and tourists alike can utilize these free stations as they search out eateries, transportation, polling locations and more. The kiosks even have ports to plug in your headphones so you can have privacy for any calls you need to make while you await a full charge. These same types of kiosks are also available throughout the U.K. in England, Wales and Scotland. Similar devices are coming soon to both Philly and Newark, N.J.Making your life work from the road can be challenging, but not impossible. With a few precision product purchases, planned access to infrastructure and a commitment to pay attention to power-hogging background apps, you can remain as charged as necessary for most situations.\nWhat's your reaction?\nLove\n0\nFunny\n0\nWow\n0\nSad\n0\nAngry\n0\nFacebook\nTwitter\nSMS\nEmail\nPrint\nSave\nTags\nCharging\nElectricity\nElectrotechnics\nPhone\nKiosk\nDeadline\nDevice\nBattery\nExtension Cord\nMore Headlines\nIn the Kansas town that was home, the astonishing story of Eisenhower lives on\nWhat to do when you lose your passport overseas\nA wine country weekend close to home: Southwest Michigan\xe2\x80\x99s vineyards boast variety \xe2\x80\x94 and a cute new B&B\nCruise lines give refunds for some Cuba cruises on first day of US ban\nMultimedia\nPhotos: Rochester FC, FC Minneapolis soccer\nPhotos: International Yoga Day on Peace Plaza\nPhotos: Honkers, Bismarck baseball\nPhotos: Safe City Nights at George W.
