New Yorkers, she said, have been very receptive.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy now, New Yorkers have understood it\xe2\x80\x99s important what you put into your bodies and how you treat them . . . I think the natural extension of that is laundry and home care products that you need to take a closer look at as well,\xe2\x80\x9d Williams said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe environmental component of our business has always been very important . . . In the end it\xe2\x80\x99s up to all of us. It needs to start somewhere, and the smallest entity is the individual.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCelsious is one of several city businesses highlighting ways to lower environmental impacts in time for Climate Week NYC\xe2\x80\x99s kickoff on Monday. And in celebration of the summit\xe2\x80\x99s 10th year, organizers are encouraging New Yorkers to make both small and large changes to live more sustainably with their #10things campaign.\nThere are more than 150 events planned during the summit, including discussions, museum tours and documentary screenings.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think one of the reasons why Climate Week NYC is so important is because it brings together some of the most influential people from business and government, alongside those who make up one of the largest cities in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d Helen Clarkson, CEO of The Climate Group, said in an emailed statement. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom cutting down on plastic, to reducing our reliance on fossil fuel powered vehicles, Climate Week NYC is proving to be a powerful force to encourage those in positions of power to do the right thing, so that we can all make the personal choices needed to tackle climate change.\xe2\x80\x9d\nChanges can include turning off water while brushing your teeth, eating a more plant-based diet and eliminating single-use plastic.\nRestaurateur Ravi DeRossi owns several vegan restaurants participating in Climate Week, including Avant Garden, and said factory farming is having a hugely negative impact on the planet.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur consumption of meat, the way we eat is completely changing the world and it\xe2\x80\x99s awful,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, adding: \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody in the world is seeing that more vegan restaurants are popping up right and left . . . Right now, every day counts because don\xe2\x80\x99t have a lot of time left. Fortunately, people are waking up.\xe2\x80\x9d\nDeRossi said he has also removed plastic straws from his restaurants, instead opting for things such as paper or bamboo straws. He\xe2\x80\x99s exploring other alternatives as well.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople have that attitude of \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m just one person using one straw a day.\xe2\x80\x99 Its hard to imagine that one person can make a difference, but its true,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf everybody works together and thinks as a whole as opposed to individual we can have an impact massively.\xe2\x80\x9d\nJeff LaPadula, who co-owns participating vegan eateries P.S. Kichen and Terri, said choosing vegan or vegetarian food makes a direct impact on climate change.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor us, we really want people to realize that climate change and helping the environment really begins with each person,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt all kind of begins with us, with your knife and fork . . . A little drip of water can start a flood, it\xe2\x80\x99s kind of that idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFor travelers, things like bringing your own water bottle or choosing public transportation are easy changes, suggested Fred Dixon, the president and CEO of NYC & Company, which has promoted the Climate Week NYC campaign through bus shelters, LinkNYC, social media, and in taxis. He added it\xe2\x80\x99s also more important than ever to highlight the city\xe2\x80\x99s environmentally friendly attributes.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York itself is quite a green city already in many ways, compared to other cities,\xe2\x80\x9d Dixon said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe know going forward as a destination, it\xe2\x80\x99s important for us to be seen to be taking the climate change issue seriously. It\xe2\x80\x99s about just igniting new conversations.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBy Alison Fox alison.fox@amny.com\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. Learn more and share your input.\nMost popular\nWhat to know before watching the Central Park 5 series 'Mrs. Maisel' giving out free Midge-approved lunches MTA touts 7 train performance as it fights for funding Senate, Assembly pass\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill A look at where the Central Park 5 are now\nTop Things to Do stories\nThe Shed's summer programming has arrived\nWhat to know about this year\xe2\x80\x99s Mermaid Parade\nWatch the Democratic presidential debates at these parties\n'Whitney's Collection' to reimagine iconic artwork\nHow to fight injustice after watching Central Park 5 series\nPublic health and Brooklyn, examined through history\nThings to Do Photos & Videos\nDon't just march, celebrate at these Pride parties\nHow to celebrate the start of summer\nMarch as a mermaid & more to do this weekend\nCentral Park puts finishing touches on Belvedere Castle\nOur freebie guide to the city\nLearn to climb, catch free music and more to do this week\nQuick Links\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s paper\nNewsletters\nSecrets of New York\nEvents this week\nWeekend Best Bets\nStaff & Bios\nSitemap\nPartners\nNewsday\nNews 12\nNewsday Homes\nNewsday Jobs\nNewsday Connect\nHometown Shopper\nNews12 Varsity\nSections\nNews\nTransit\nPolitics\nElections\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nContact us | Jobs at amnewyork | PRIVACY\nPOLICY | TERMS OF SERVICE\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\n240 W 35TH ST., 9TH FLOOR NY, NY 10001 646.293.9499 FAX: 212.239.2828 | Newsday. All rights reserved.", b'Carvana parades cars wrapped in takeout bags around NYC to promote auto delivery\n| Marketing Dive\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nTech\nCreative\nSocial Media\nVideo\nAnalytics\nExecutive News\nMobile\nAn article from\nBrief\nCarvana parades cars wrapped in takeout bags around NYC to promote auto delivery\nAuthor\nBy\nErica Sweeney\nPublished\nSept. 24, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nDive Brief:\nE-commerce auto-buying and selling platform Carvana launched "as-soon-as-next-day" vehicle delivery in New York City and debuted a one-day integrated campaign to promote its offering around the city, according to news provided to Marketing Dive.\nCarvana\xc2\xa0deployed a caravan of five signature car haulers that paraded through New York City on Sept. 20. Three of the haulers carried vehicles inside giant takeout delivery bags to highlight its new delivery option. They included a "receipt"\xc2\xa0attached to the back that read, "Buy your car online and get it delivered. Just like everything else in New York."\nMore than 250 digital on-street LinkNYC displays featured Carvana ads and a live feed of people using the campaign hashtag #TheNYCWayToBuyACar. People who saw the parade of vehicles were encouraged to take photos and post them on social media using the campaign hashtag and #sweepstakes for a chance to win a year of free Postmates up to $5,000.\nDive Insight:\nCarvana\'s\xc2\xa0interactive campaign could help the company reach younger consumers as it enters its biggest market to date.\xc2\xa0Parading cars wrapped in takeout bags around New York City was an attention-grabber, and also provided opportunities to engage with social media-savvy generations. Encouraging passersby to snap, post and hashtag photos \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0which in turn were placed on large digital displays \xe2\x80\x94 might have helped boost social media traffic for the brand. .\nMarketers continue to invest in out-of-home (OOH) marketing \xe2\x80\x94 like Carvana\'s\xc2\xa0use of LinkNYC\xc2\xa0displays \xe2\x80\x94 to drive awareness and reach consumers in unique ways at key points throughout their busy day-to-day lives. Brands that dedicate 15% or more of their media budgets to OOH had a 24% increase in brand trust, 106% increase in perception of brand quality and a 275% increase in customer loyalty, according to a recent survey by Rapport, IPG Mediabrands\' OOH division.\nIf successful, the campaign could help automakers reach a demographic that has been less inclined than older generations to buy cars. While consumers generally want to purchase vehicles online, many millennials in particular do not even want to own their own cars. In addition, Gen Z\'s conversations around auto brands have also dropped off significantly, as most prefer walkable areas and ride-hailing services, a recent Engagement Labs study\xc2\xa0found.\nRecommended Reading:\nMarketing Dive\nOut-of-home ads can boost customer loyalty by 275%, study finds\nMarketing Dive\nGen Zers drop destination retail, auto brands from the conversation, study finds\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nCreative\nSocial Media\nTop image credit:\nCarvana\nGet the Newsletter\nSubscribe to Marketing Dive to get the must-read news & insights in your inbox.\nEmail:\nMarketing Dive\nTopics covered: social media, mobile, advertising, marketing tech, content marketing, and more.\nDaily\nview sample\nSign up\nA valid email address is required.\nPlease select at least one newsletter.\nBy signing up you agree to our privacy policy. You can opt out anytime.', b"LinkNYC's 5 million users make 500,000 phone calls each month | VentureBeat\nCHANNELS l\nl\nCHANNELS\nGamesBeat\nAI\nAR/VR\nBig BOARD\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nCHANNELS\n\xe2\x80\xba\nCHANNELS\nGamesBeat\nEntrepreneur\nAI\nEsports\nAR/VR\nMarketing\nBig Data\nMedia\nBusiness\nMobile\nCloud\nPC BOARD\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nVENTUREBEAT\n\xe2\x80\xba\nAbout\nAdvertise\nCareers\nContact\nGot a news tip?\nPress Releases\nVB Lab\nWebinars\nPrivacy Policy\nMOBILE\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s 5 million users make 500,000 phone calls each month\nKyle Wiggers@Kyle_L_Wiggers September 29, 2018 4:15 AM\nImage Credit: LinkNYC\nMOST READ\nNokia reveals 5G-ready lithium nanotube battery with 2.5X run time\nSpiketrap: Cyberpunk 2077 was the fan favorite game of E3 2019\nT-Mobile blasts AT&T and Verizon for \xe2\x80\x98outright lies about 5G\xe2\x80\x99\nSlack IPO starts trading at $38.50 for $23 billion valuation\nDead by Daylight scares its way to mobile\nIn 2014, in a bid to replace the more than 11,000 aging payphones scattered across New York City\xe2\x80\x99s pedestrian walkways with more functional fixtures, Mayor Bill de Blasio launched a competition \xe2\x80\x94 the Reinvent Payphones initiative \xe2\x80\x94 calling on private enterprises, residents, and nonprofits to submit designs for replacements.\nIn the end, LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x94 a plan proposed by consortium CityBridge \xe2\x80\x94 secured a contract from the city, beating out competing proposals with electricity-generating piezoelectric pressure plates and EV charging stations. The plan was to spend $200 million installing as many as 10,000 kiosks, or Links, that would supply free, encrypted gigabit Wi-Fi to passers-by within 150 feet. They would have buttons that link directly to 911 and New York\xe2\x80\x99s 311 service and free USB charging stations for smartphones, plus wired handsets that would allow free calls to all 50 states and Washington, D.C. And perhaps best of all, they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t cost the city a dime; advertising would subsidize expansion and ongoing maintenance.\nThe\xc2\xa0Links wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t just get urbanites\xc2\xa0online and let them juice their phones, though. The idea was to engage users, too, principally with twin 55-inch high-definition displays and tethered Android tablets with map functions. Mike Gamaroff, head of innovation at Kinetic, characterized the Links in 2016 as \xe2\x80\x9cfirst and foremost a utility for the people of the city, that also doubles up as an advertising network.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTwo years after the deployment of prototypical kiosks in Manhattan, Intersection \xe2\x80\x94 a part of the aforementioned CityBridge, which with Qualcomm and CIVIQ Smartscapes manages the kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 is ready to declare them a success. The roughly 1,600 Links recently hit three milestones: 1 billion sessions, 5 million users, and 500,000 phone calls a month.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have an opportunity to communicate with people as they navigate their day,\xe2\x80\x9d Intersection senior consumer marketing manager Amanda Giddon told VentureBeat in a phone interview. \xe2\x80\x9cMy mandate is to help make Link a part of the community through content and content strategy \xe2\x80\x94 really, anything that [makes] New Yorkers feel like tourists in their own city [or] even help tourists feel like New Yorkers through useful, actionable information.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCreative content\nAt any given time, the Link kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 screens host news headlines from the Associated Press, comics, weather info, real-time alerts from the Office of Emergency Management, and creative from a mix of roughly 50 other campaigns. Also on tap are hundreds of hyperlocal factoids\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cNYC Fun Facts\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThis Day in New York\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 about people (\xe2\x80\x9cMartin Hildebrandt opened the United States\xe2\x80\x99 first tattoo business in New York City in 1870\xe2\x80\x9d), places (\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a superhero supply store in Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x9d), and things (\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City gets 15 times more snow than the South Pole each year\xe2\x80\x9d). There are close to 400 trivia tidbits in all, with new ones joining the collection each week.\nGibbon researches the facts herself, typically spending a few hours a week\xc2\xa0poring through a range of sources, including Broadway.org, Grow NYC, Time Magazine, FiveThirtyEight, and the\xc2\xa0National History Museum. She dutifully fact-checks them and copies them to a master spreadsheet before deciding which ones will make the cut.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s been really great to see people writing in about the content they see.\xc2\xa0We\xe2\x80\x99ve created some moments of awe for people, and if I can create a moment of awe for someone on a daily basis, then I\xe2\x80\x99m doing my job right,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Giddon said.\nWhen the kiosks aren\xe2\x80\x99t alerting pedestrians to, say, the percentage of New Yorkers riding elevators at any time, they display real-time bus arrivals and local maps. But the bulk of their programming consists of rotating regular, seasonal, and limited-time content collaborations with organizations, publications, and government agencies.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe survey our users quite frequently [for ideas] \xe2\x80\xa6 and we go to great lengths to make sure our [content] is contextually relevant,\xe2\x80\x9d said Giddon. \xe2\x80\x9c[We\xe2\x80\x99re] pioneering this publishing approach and public space and are really eager to get feedback and adjust as we continue to expand.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOne recent example is a partnership with the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) that showcased the work of local artists. Another is \xe2\x80\x9cPopular Places Near You,\xe2\x80\x9d a Foursquare-powered feature that shows top restaurants and entertainment hubs within walking distance.\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s just the tip of the iceberg. Intersection worked with the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s Beyond Suffrage exhibit to feature NYC women in politics, with the NYC Department of Records to curate historical photography (localized at a neighborhood level), and with Silicon Harlem and Global Kids to showcase legendary\xc2\xa0African Americans\xc2\xa0during Black History Month.\nSocial services\nIntersection\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0also leveraging the kiosks to promote civic engagement.\nIn April, it teamed up with the New York City Council to roll out Participatory Budgeting New York City, which let residents as young as 11 vote via the kiosk tablets on how the city will allocate its $40 million public budget. And it launched an awareness campaign to get New Yorkers registered to vote in advance of the November 2018 general elections. (The latter integrated with the city\xe2\x80\x99s voter registration data to show a real-time count of the number of people signed up.) It also posts Community Board meeting notices and local road closures and through its LinkLocal program lets small businesses advertise for free on select kiosks around the city.\nIntersection has experimented with social services, too. In January, users were able to browse and enroll in health plans through New York State of Health insurance marketplace.\nFor some New Yorkers, the Link hubs aren\xe2\x80\x99t just a convenience \xe2\x80\x94 they\xe2\x80\x99re a lifeline. A 2014 study by the Office of the New York City Comptroller found that 27 percent of NYC residents surveyed \xe2\x80\x94 40 percent of whom had less than a high school education \xe2\x80\x94 lacked broadband internet at home.\nWithout a reliable internet connection, students can\xe2\x80\x99t access online classroom resources, out-of-work adults can\xe2\x80\x99t submit job applications, and families struggling to make ends meet can\xe2\x80\x99t take advantage of social services. As the New York Times wrote in August 2016:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIn urban areas, rural areas, and everywhere in between, students who lack internet service at home have difficulty doing their nightly schoolwork. Many of them cobble together whatever connectivity they can, picking up free Wi-Fi signals in front of libraries, in school parking lots, and at fast-food restaurants.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFour years ago, De Blasio\xc2\xa0touted the Links as a sign of progress in the fight for unimpeded internet access. \xe2\x80\x9c[They\xe2\x80\x99re] the fastest and largest municipal Wi-Fi network in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0he said, \xe2\x80\x9c[and] a critical step toward a more equal, open, and connected city for every New Yorker, in every borough.\xe2\x80\x9d\nControversy\nBut the accolades tend to ignore the fact that LinkNYC isn\xe2\x80\x99t strictly a philanthropic effort. Advertisements that run alongside Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s programming were expected to generate between $500 million and a billion dollars over the next 12 years. (CityBridge and the city split the ad revenue equally.)\nAnd the kiosks themselves aren\xe2\x80\x99t without controversy.\nThe connected tablets initially had an internet browser, but Intersection disabled it in response to complaints about users browsing pornographic material. It also added vision-assistance tools after the National Federation of the Blind sued the City of New York and LinkNYC, arguing that the tablets lacked basic accessibility features.\nRevenue, meanwhile, has missed expectations.\xc2\xa0Over the first two years, the city collected $43.4 million in payments, narrowly beating the $42.5 million minimum CityBridge guaranteed. Under an amended deal, CityBridge will delay paying the city its share of revenues (above the minimum payments) until the last year of the contract, when they\xe2\x80\x99ll be due with 10 percent interest.\nAnd as The Intercept recently pointed out, consumer advocacy groups and activists, including the American Civil Liberties Union, Electronic Frontier Foundation, Stop LinkNYC, and ReThink LinkNYC, have brought attention to the hubs\xe2\x80\x99 potential for mass surveillance.\nEach hub is equipped with three cameras and sensors capable of, among other things, \xe2\x80\x9cmonitor[ing] pedestrian, bike, and car traffic; track[ing] passing wireless devices; listen[ing] to street noise; and \xe2\x80\xa6 identify[ing] abandoned packages.\xe2\x80\x9d\nNone of this has scared away investors, who extended $150 million in financing to Intersection last year.\nIntersection makes clear in its privacy policy that it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t collect information about users\xe2\x80\x99 precise locations. And in response to recent allegations that it intends to track Wi-Fi users\xe2\x80\x99 real-time positions, it said it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\xc2\xa0collect their clickstream data or browsing history.\nAs Intersection and CityBridge eye expansion to new markets, Giddon said, they\xe2\x80\x99ll take into account feedback they\xe2\x80\x99ve received so far.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99ll definitely be a combination of lessons learned and ensuring we add a little local flavor [to our programing],\xe2\x80\x9d Giddon said.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cWe have research teams in New York and Philadelphia who\xe2\x80\x99ve conducted some preliminary focus group testing to understand how to best serve the community. We\xe2\x80\x99re really open to feedback, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve done a lot of work here and look forward to seeing how it\xe2\x80\x99s received.\nIntersection hopes to install 7,500 Link kiosks by 2026, when its contract with the city expires. In June, it launched InLinkUK, a partnership with telecom provider BT and outdoor advertising agency Primesight to replace over 1,000 pay phones in major U.K. cities with kiosks. In September, 100 kiosks\xc2\xa0hit the sidewalks of Philadelphia as part of its LinkPHL program. And by the end of this year, 45 will come to Newark.", b"New York City's Wi-Fi kiosks have over 5 million users - PhoneArena\nLog in\nMenu\nHome\nNews\nReviews\nPhone finder\nSpecs comparison\nSize comparison\nCamera comparison\nBest phones\nBenchmarks\nCarriers\nVerizon\nAT&T\nT-Mobile\nSprint\nU.S. Cellular\nView all\nBrands\nApple\nSamsung\nGoogle\nLG\nMotorola\nSony\nHuawei\nView all\nHome\nNews\nReviews\nPhone finder\nSpecs comparison\nSize comparison\nCamera comparison\nBest phones\nBenchmarks\nTools\nSpecs comparison\nSize comparison\nCamera comparison\nBest phones\nBenchmarks\nLog in\nCarriers:\nVerizon\nAT&T\nT-Mobile\nSprint\nU.S. Cellular\nsearch\nBrands:\nApple\nSamsung\nGoogle\nLG\nMotorola\nSony\nHuawei\nHome\nNews\nYou are here\nWireless service\nNew York City's Wi-Fi kiosks have over 5 million users\nby\nAlan Friedman\n/\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Sep 30, 2018,\n8:52 PM\nBack in 2014, we told you about New York City's plans to get rid of 10,000 pay phones that were still dotting the Big Apple's landscape. The plan was to replace the pay phones with\xc2\xa0 Wi-Fi kiosks that would offer free Wi-Fi at speeds up to 1Gbps, and include charging stations and an Android tablet. And ads would be sold to help fund the project, eventually making it self-sufficient.\nNearly four years later, there are 1,700 kiosks in the five boroughs, and more than five million people are registered to access the free Wi-Fi connectivity, with 20 million Wi-Fi sessions taking place each week, along with 500,000 free phone calls. Because each LinkNYC kiosk uses fiber optics, it provides data speeds up to 100 times faster that public Wi-Fi. Each kiosk can support hundreds of Wi-Fi users simultaneously, standing within 150 feet of the unit.Through the tablet on the kiosk, those in the city can make free phone calls to anywhere in the U.S., including calls to 311,411 or 911. International calls can be placed with the use of a calling card. And in case users do need to call 911, each kiosk features a red button that can be pressed to call for emergency help. Since navigating the city can be difficult, the tablet can also provide maps and directions to users. Each LinkNYC kiosk is equipped with two free USB charging ports. And both are connected to a power supply only, so the data stored by a mobile device is safe and sound.The LinkNYC kiosks are built to withstand just about anything that can happen in New York outside of King Kong terrorizing the city. They are protected from the elements, flooding, earthquakes, vandalism and theft. They also are equipped with multiple cameras and sensors that can monitor foot, bike, and car traffic. Eack kiosk can also track passing mobile phones and tablets, listen to street noise and identify packages left by individuals.While it all sounds great, there have been some issues. The browser on the tablet had to be disabled because the kiosks originally attracted porn-starved New Yorkers without their own internet connection. And ad revenue has fallen short of estimates. This has forced the consortium behind the project to delay paying New York City its 50% share of ad revenue until the last year of the contract, which is in 2026. 10% interest will be added. By then, the plan is to have 7,500 LinkNYC kiosks up and running.\nFeatures available on the LinkNYC kiosksource: LinkNYC via VentureBeat\nFEATURED VIDEO\nOptions\n4\nComments\nReply\nReport\n1.\nFerneyZan\nPosts: 113; Member since: Jul 21, 2010\nInteresting for sure..\nThis is something that should be in the plans for other cities as well, not just NYC..\nposted on Sep 30, 2018,\n9:21 PM\n2\nReply\nReport\n2.\ngamehead unregistered\nI don't believe I ever used one of these\nposted on Sep 30, 2018, 10:31 PM\n0\nReply\nReport\n3.\nrsiders\nPosts: 1889; Member since: Nov 17, 2011\nI'm not one of those conspiracy theorist types but I do believe in too much technology and potential privacy risks. Visit https://www.parsintl.com/ for samples and additional information.", b"New York City's WiFi kiosks have over 5 million users\nEngadget\nLogin\nHome\nGear\nGaming\nEntertainment\nTomorrow\nBuyer's Guide\n2019 Camera Guide\nParenting and Tech\nBest of CES 2019\nPhones\nLaptops\nView All\nVideo\nReviews\nLog in\nSign up\nShow More Results\nEngadget\n3 related articles\nLogin\nYouTube tests moving comments to a separate window on mobile\nA new tool detects deepfakes with 96 percent accuracy\nHold the phone: Chevy owners can order Domino's with their car\nLatest in Gear\nYouTube tests moving comments to a separate window on mobile\n1h ago\nView\nFEMA's presidential alerts are an easy target for spoofing attacks\n1h ago\nView\nA new tool detects deepfakes with 96 percent accuracy\n2h ago\nView\nNew York Senate passes ban on Elon Musk's Not-A-Flamethrower\n2h ago\nView\nImage credit: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg via Getty Images\nsave\nSave\nshare\nNew York City's WiFi kiosks have over 5 million users\nIt turns out that people want fast internet access on the street.\nJon Fingas, @jonfingas\n09.30.18\nin Internet\nComments\n441\nShares\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nSave\nSponsored Links\nMichael Nagle/Bloomberg via Getty Images\nNew York City's high-speed WiFi kiosks have been around for a while, but just how many people are using them? Quite a few, in fact. The LinkNYC team has revealed that there were over 5 million registered WiFi users as of September 2018, with over a billion sessions spread across the 1,700-plus units in the city. People make over 500,000 calls every month, too, although it's not clear how many of those were ice cream truck pranksters. You can safely presume that there's plenty of demand.\nAs VentureBeat reported, though, these kiosks haven't been without their share of concerns. They're ad-subsidized, but they've barely earned enough to meet the CityBridge consortium's minimum guarantee. The group also removed the kiosks' web browsers after complains of people surfing porn sites or hogging the machines. There's also the concerns about privacy given the presences of cameras and sensors on every kiosk, although Intersection (a part of CityBridge) has stressed that it doesn't collect sensitive info like exact locations or browser history.The kiosks are likely to have a long life, as Intersection's LinkNYC contract lasts until 2026. Whether or not they continue to see healthy adoption is another story. Now that mobile 5G is on the horizon, many New Yorkers could have gigabit-class (or at least, close enough) speeds in their pockets within the next few years. They'll likely have their uses, particularly for visitors, but they might not be as alluring as personal internet access catches up.\nVia:\nVentureBeat\nSource:\nLinkNYC\nIn this article:\ncitybridge,\ngear,\ninternet,\nkiosk,\nlinknyc,\nnewyorkcity,\nwi-fi,\nwifi\nAll products recommended by Engadget are selected by our editorial team, independent of our parent company. Some of our stories include affiliate links. If you buy something through one of these links, we may earn an affiliate commission.\n441\nShares\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nSave\nComments\nSign In\n1h\n1h ago in\nMobile\nYouTube tests moving comments to a separate window on mobile\nUsers would have to willingly seek out the comment section.\nBy\nC. Fisher,\n1h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n1h\n1h ago in\nSecurity\nFEMA's presidential alerts are an easy target for spoofing attacks\nFake alerts could be sent to nearly all cellphones nationwide.\nBy\nC. Fisher,\n1h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n1h\n1h ago in\nBusiness\nSpotify claims it 'overpaid' songwriters and wants its money back\nSpotify said the money can be paid back before the end of 2019.\nBy\nA. Dellinger,\n1h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n2h\n2h ago in\nServices\nA new tool detects deepfakes with 96 percent accuracy\nIt focuses on subtle head movements to identify manipulated videos.\nBy\nA. Dellinger,\n2h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n2h\n2h ago in\nAV\n'Sea of Solitude' looks like a brilliant, emotional horror show\nAnd I can't wait to play it.\nBy\nJ. Conditt,\n2h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\nMore Stories\nFrom around the web\nAbout\nAbout Engadget\nAbout Our Ads\nAdvertise\nBrand Kit\nBuyers Guide\nContact Us\nRSS Feed\nSections\nReviews\nGear\nGaming\nEntertainment\nTomorrow\nThe Buyer's Guide\nVideo\nPodcasts\nDeals\nContribute\nComment Guidelines\nSend us a tip!\nSupport\nInternational\n\xe7\xb9\x81\xe9\xab\x94\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe7\xae\x80\xe4\xbd\x93\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe6\x97\xa5\xe6\x9c\xac\xe7\x89\x88\nJoin Our Newsletter\nSubscribe\nFollow Us\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Verizon Media. All rights reserved.\nAbout Verizon Media\nReprints and Permissions\nSuggestions\nPrivacy Policy (Updated)\nTerms of Service (Updated)\nTrademarks\nAdvertise\nPage 1Page 1ear iconeye iconFill 23text filevr", b'Recode Daily: With the SEC off his back, Elon Musk can return his focus to Tesla - Vox\nSkip to main content\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nRecode Daily: With the SEC off his back, Elon Musk can return his focus to Tesla\nPlus, the FBI forced a man to open his iPhone X with his face; California restores net neutrality, and the Trump administration immediately sues California; beyond the man cave: The showroom garage.\nBy\nRecode Staff\nOct\n1, 2018,\n8:44am EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nRecode Daily: With the SEC off his back, Elon Musk can return his focus to Tesla\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nElon Musk, CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, speaks at a press conference at SpaceX headquarters where he announced the Japanese billionaire chosen by the company to fly around the moon, on Sept. 17, 2018 in Hawthorne, Calif. If the project is successful Yusaka Maezawa would become the first private citizen to fly around the moon.\nMario Tama / Getty Images\nThis story is part of a group of stories called\nUncovering and explaining how our digital world is changing \xe2\x80\x94 and changing us.\nTesla CEO Elon Musk will step down as chairman of the electric carmaker for at least three years as part of a settlement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission over a security fraud charge stemming from a series of tweets that the SEC believes misled investors. Musk and Tesla will also each pay $20 million fines as part of the settlement, but did not have to admit any wrongdoing related to the Aug. 7 tweets. (That\xe2\x80\x99s when Musk alleged that he had \xe2\x80\x9cfunding secured\xe2\x80\x9d to take Tesla private at a $420 per-share price.) Meanwhile, tomorrow, Tesla will turn in a critical production report that will show investors whether the company can sustain and surpass its long-promised target of building 5,000 Model 3s per week. And Tesla still needs to find a No. 2 exec like Musk\xe2\x80\x99s right-hand woman at SpaceX, Gwynne Shotwell. [Jason Del Rey / Recode]\n[Want to get the Recode Daily in your inbox? Subscribe here.]\nIt happened again: Facebook announced on Friday that, thanks to a security \xe2\x80\x9cvulnerability,\xe2\x80\x9d hackers were able to access the personal accounts of some 50 million users. In this latest breach \xe2\x80\x94 the third security issue Facebook has disclosed since June \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cthe attackers could use the account as if they are the account holder.\xe2\x80\x9d Here\xe2\x80\x99s how the breach worked and what information may have been accessed. For a company that wants to be the digital connective tissue for all of your personal relationships \xe2\x80\x94 including your romantic connections \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s past time to think hard about this question: Why should people continue to trust Facebook with their personal information? [Kurt Wagner / Recode]\nNet neutrality was restored in California, as Governor Jerry Brown signed legislation into law, setting up a legal showdown pitting his state against internet service providers and the Federal Communications Commission. [Jon Brodkin / Ars Technica]\nThe use of digital technology in the U.S. has seen a two-year plateau after years of rapid growth. The shares of U.S. adults who say they use the internet, use social media, or own a smartphone or a tablet computer are all nearly identical to the number who said so in 2016.[Paul Hitlins / Pew Research Center]\nChart of the Day: Netflix is driving the original-content boom\nThe U.S. FBI forced an Apple iPhone X owner to unlock the device with his face. A child abuse investigation unearthed by Forbes includes the first-known case in the world in which law enforcement used Apple Face ID facial recognition technology to open a suspect\xe2\x80\x99s iPhone. The case marks another significant moment in the ongoing battle between law enforcement and tech providers, with the former trying to break the myriad security protections put in place by the latter. [Thomas Brewster / Forbes]\nManhattan\xe2\x80\x99s 1,600 LinkNYC kiosks, which replaced 11,000 aging city pay phones and provide free Wi-Fi and U.S. phone calls, are seeing five million users and 500,000 phone calls a month. Two years after they were deployed, the sidewalk kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 screens display real-time bus arrivals and local maps, plus news headlines from the Associated Press, comics, weather info, real-time alerts from the Office of Emergency Management, and creative content from a mix of roughly 50 other campaigns. Advertising that runs alongside programming on the kiosks is expected to generate between $500 million and a billion dollars over the next 12 years. [Kyle Wiggers / VentureBeat]\nIs Bytedance the world\xe2\x80\x99s most valuable startup? An unknown software engineer created a news aggregation app powered by artificial intelligence. Today, 35-year-old Zhang Yiming\xe2\x80\x99s company, Bytedance, is on its way to a more than $75 billion valuation \xe2\x80\x94 surpassing Uber as the No. 1 startup. SoftBank is said to be planning to invest about $1.5 billion in the Chinese company, joining KKR, General Atlantic and Sequoia as backers. Much of Bytedance\xe2\x80\x99s lofty valuation stems from its creation of an internet experience that\xe2\x80\x99s a cross between Google and Facebook. [Lulu Yilun Chen and Mark Bergen / Bloomberg]\nELON WATCH: \xe2\x80\x9cNaughty by Nature\xe2\x80\x9d TRUMP WATCH: \xe2\x80\x9cCongratulations to Mexico and Canada!\xe2\x80\x9d KANYE WATCH: A bizarre Sunday.\nTop stories from Recode\nAmazon has failed as a destination for \xe2\x80\x9cdiscovery\xe2\x80\x9d shopping \xe2\x80\x94 so it built a physical store to try it the old-fashioned way.\nThe new Amazon 4-star store is an admission of past missteps but also a worthy experiment. [Jason Del Rey / Recode]\nNetflix and Hulu go in for comedies while Amazon sticks to drama: A look at the original content boom.\nSci-fi is very popular among video services, too. All Rights Reserved', b"GlobalReach Technology Appoints Wi-Fi Industry Veteran to Lead Innovation in Hospitality Sector Solutions | Hospitality Technology\nSkip to main content\nHome\nCustomer Experience\nPoint of Sale\nOperations\nEvents\nRestaurant Technology Network (RTN)\nData & Analytics\nResearch & Reports\nMagazine\nBuyer's Guide\nContact Us\nSubscribe\nSUBSCRIBE\nPress enter to search\nCustomer Experience\nPoint of Sale\nOperations\nEvents\nRestaurant Technology Network (RTN)\nData & Analytics\nResearch & Reports\nMagazine\nBuyer's Guide\nContact Us\nGlobalReach Technology Appoints Wi-Fi Industry Veteran to Lead Innovation in Hospitality Sector Solutions\nPress enter to search\nGlobalReach Technology Appoints Wi-Fi Industry Veteran to Lead Innovation in Hospitality Sector Solutions\n10/01/2018\nGlobalReach Technology, a global provider of high-performance Wi-Fi solutions, service\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0analytics, said it appointed Chris Bruce as Managing Director.\nChris has more than 20 years in executive roles at British Telecom (BT) in its Wi-Fi, hospitality technology and international telecoms businesses. He previously served as CEO of BT Openzone Wi-Fi, where he led the rapid growth of its HISA (High Speed\xc2\xa0Internet Access) business with leading international hotel brands. Prior to that, he held the position of VP of Internet Hosting for Europe, as well Director of International Sales & Consulting, BT Global Services, where he led executive relationships across the U.S., Middle East, Africa\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Asia.\nThroughout his career, Chris has fostered relationships with some of the largest brands in the international hospitality sector, including Hilton, Guoman Thistle\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Starbucks, and successfully delivered a strategically significant and profitable business growth strategy.\nChris also brings many years of international carrier experience, as Chair and Co-chair of the Wireless Broadband Alliance, driving the development of a seamless and secure user experience (Hotspot 2.0) and more recently, the convergence of services over 5G and Next Generation Wi-Fi (802.11ax).\nGlobalReach provides a highly-configurable, scalable and globally distributed technology platform that enables telecommunication providers and enterprises to deliver, manage and monetize Wi-Fi services and solutions.\nBuilt on its own\xc2\xa0industry leading\xc2\xa0technology, its award-winning captive portal, cloud-RADIUS / AAA wireless platform delivers robust public Wi-Fi services, including those for a major national coffee shop chain across the USA, the London Underground, large-scale municipal networks like LinkNYC, San Francisco and San Jose, in-flight Wi-Fi for pan-continental airlines, and carrier SMB services, allowing seamless connectivity for users.\nIts clients include Vodafone Group, BT, Virgin Media, CenturyLink, Proximus, Telekom Malaysia, Cisco, HP Aruba\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Ruckus Wireless. The platform supports billions of authentications, supporting hundreds of various devices and operating systems.\nRELATED TOPICS\nNetworking\nHotels\nSHARE\nMore Bulletins\nGuestroom / In-room\nAEi Communications Announces New Partnership with Percipia\n06/21/2019\nHotels\nSiteMinder Partners with Charme & Caract\xc3\xa8re H\xc3\xb4tels to Elevate Guest Experiences Across the World\n06/21/2019\nPOS\nPAR Technology Announces API Integration with SpeedETab and Brink POS Software\n06/21/2019\nLoyalty\nCheetah Digital, Sabre Partner on Airline Loyalty Program\n06/21/2019\nGet the Newsletter Subscribe\nGet the Magazine Subscribe\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nYouTube\nFooter\nContact Us\nAbout Us\nMedia Kit\n\xc2\xa9 2019 EnsembleIQ, All Rights Reserved", b'How New York City Tells the Story of Its Open Data Work\nimage/svg+xml\nCONTINUE TO SITE\nThis website uses cookies in order to offer you the most relevant information.\n\xc3\x83\xe2\x80\x94\nLearn More\nI Accept\nMAGAZINE\nNEWSLETTERS\nEVENTS\nPAPERS\nNAVIGATOR\nSECTIONS\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL EDUCATION\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL GOVERNMENT\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nDIGITAL STATES PERFORMANCE INSTITUTE\nTOP 25\nGOVTECH 100\nSEARCH\nCybersecurity\nGovTech Biz\nEmerging Tech\nCloud\nGov Experience\nMore\nData\nHow New York City Tells the Story of Its Open Data Work\nAs open data work and availability continue to evolve, local governments are rolling out new ways to spread awareness.\nby Zack Quaintance\n/\nOctober 3, 2018\nLink.nyc\nNew York City these days is dotted with high-tech hot spots, kiosks that are part of a program called LinkNYC. Thousands upon thousands of visitors and residents of the city walk past these screens, using them for everything from public Wi-Fi access to charging devices to getting info about city services.\nThis September, however, users of the more than 1,700 active LinkNYC kiosks throughout the city might have noticed something new on the screens: brightly colored blue and yellow features, almost like testimonials for open data. These testimonials are simple, featuring the faces of real people, their job titles or affiliations, and a quick list of what they accomplished with open data as well as the data sets they used.\nFor example, one screen says: \xe2\x80\x9cRentlogic, Yale Fox\xe2\x80\xa6 I used NYC OpenData to bring transparency to the rental market. Data used: open HPD violations, DOB violations, DOB ECB Violations.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s a picture of Fox, and a second note, reading: \xe2\x80\x9cI am an entrepreneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s it. Simple, clear, easy to read and understand.\nRELATEDDesigners Are Driving Culture Change in City HallWhat Is Human-Centric Design?The Importance of Celebrating Data WinsOther featured stories include civic technologists who used New York open data to bring more transparency to community projects, a data scientist who used it to predict the lifespan of New York street trees and an environmental planner who showed how the city\xe2\x80\x99s sewer system works among others.\nCraig Campbell, a special advisor to the Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s Office of Data Analytics \xe2\x80\x94 which is the primary municipal agency behind the city\xe2\x80\x99s open data work \xe2\x80\x94 recently spoke with Government Technology about this storytelling campaign.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s to give people a sense of what is possible using open data,\xe2\x80\x9d Campbell explained. \xe2\x80\x9cEveryone need not use open data, but everyone should have the opportunity to use open data. This storytelling campaign is designed to get the word out about the resources that exist.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTo date, New York City has published more than 2,000 data sets, with an ongoing release of more. This has led to more than a million users accessing New York City open data, many of whom create projects like the ones described above.\nThis storytelling effort in New York City dates back years, spanning more than just the vignettes on the kiosks. The local government\xe2\x80\x99s open data efforts, however, date back even further. In 2012, the city passed a law requiring an annual open data report available to the public that outlines information such as what data has been released, or which sets are running behind schedule. Essentially, the report details all aspects of what the city government is doing to comply with its open data law.\nIn the past two years, part of the focus of that report, Campbell said, has become to \xe2\x80\x9cmake the data seem more real by telling real stories about the people behind the data.\xe2\x80\x9d This effort has taken a wide range of forms, from videos to updates on the city\xe2\x80\x99s open data portal. Campbell also noted the work in its current form would not be possible without Reboot Inc., a design firm with which the city has partnered, or the work of Al Webber, the city\xe2\x80\x99s director of open data.\nAnd New York City is far from alone in its use of such storytelling to share its municipal tech and innovation work. This discipline has become a priority for jurisdictions across the country, with many of the foremost experts in the field preaching the value of celebrating data wins.\nEssentially, the public needs to understand what data is available, why it matters and how it\xe2\x80\x99s being used \xe2\x80\x94 both within local government and by civic tech groups \xe2\x80\x94 to improve quality of life, if open data is to become a valued and important part of our society moving forward. Detroit has even gone so far as to create a position in its city hall for a chief storyteller. Meanwhile, many city halls across the country are turning to design philosophies to bolster efficiency and help create human-centered products that are easy to access and use for constituents.\nSo, while these bright screens on New York City kiosks may be novel now, odds are good that this project \xe2\x80\x94 or others like it \xe2\x80\x94 will spread rapidly. Campbell described it as a way to \xe2\x80\x9copen up the hood, pull back the curtain\xe2\x80\x9d on not only the logistics but also the importance of open data work in municipal government.\nZack Quaintance\nAssistant News Editor\nZack Quaintance is the assistant news editor for Government Technology. His background includes writing for daily newspapers across the country and developing content for a software company in Austin, Texas. He is now based in Washington, D.C. He can be reached via email.\nRELATED\nDesigners Are Driving Culture Change in City Hall\nWhat Is Human-Centric Design?\nThe Importance of Celebrating Data Wins\nDISCUSS\nWe invite you to discuss and comment on this article using social media.\nMORE FROM Data\nPapers\nSPONSORED ARTICLES\nERP Modernization: How the Cloud Delivers Scalability, Security and Innovation\nThe Reality of the Local Government Cybersecurity Skill Gap\nGovernment No Longer Has to Choose Between Cybersecurity and Productivity\nNEWSLETTERS\nGovTech Today - Daily top stories\nFutureStructure - Weekly system engineering concepts\nPublic CIO - Weekly thought leadership\nNEWSLETTERS\nGOVTECH TODAY\nGOVTECH BIZ\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nPUBLIC CIO\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nK-12\nHIGHER EDUCATION\nSubscribe\nABOUT\nPRIVACY\nCONTACT\nADVERTISE\nGT Logo\n\xc2\xa9 2019 All rights reserved. e.Republic', b'NYC launches full-court cyber press -- GCN\nThe Technology that Drives Government IT\nAI & AutomationCybersecurityCloud & InfrastructureData & AnalyticsSmart Cities & IoTEmerging TechState & LocalMoreEventsResourcesNewslettersContactAdvertiseReprintsList Rental\nNYC launches full-court cyber press\nBy Susan MillerOct 03, 2018\nNew York City is taking several steps to grow its own cybersecurity resources.\nOn Oct. 2, the NYC Economic Development Council (NYCEDC) announced plans to cultivate its cybersecurity sector with the Cyber NYC initiative. That effort will include a Global Cyber Center, an innovation hub for startups, initiatives to fuel commercialization and research, and new cybersecurity talent pipelines.\nAiming to address the cybersecurity needs of New York\'s signature industries -- finance, healthcare, retail and media \xe2\x80\x93 Cyber NYC also plans "catalyze" the growth of 10,000 cybersecurity jobs over the next decade, according to NYCEDC officials.\nCyber NYC is powered by a $30 million city investment and will leverage up to an additional $70 million from private funding from companies including Goldman Sachs, PricewaterhouseCoopers, MasterCard and Facebook.\nThe initiative includes the following efforts:\nA 15,000-square-foot Global Cyber Center will offer a cyber range, a virtual testing ground to run simulations and coworking space for startups. \xc2\xa0Developed by Israeli corporate innovation expert SOSA, the center will also offer structured programming for companies and industry-specific events to encourage investments, commercialization and implementation of cyber technologies in NYC\xe2\x80\x99s leading corporations.\nNYCEDC tapped international venture capital firm Jerusalem Venture Partners to establish Hub.NYC, an \xc2\xa0international cybersecurity investment hub to support growth-stage startups and facilitate their access to clients. It will also offer business support and investment, with the objective of growing startups into major, NYC-based cybersecurity firms.\nColumbia University\'s Inventors to Founders program will connect academic cybersecurity researchers with experienced entrepreneurial talent to commercialize the technology and launch new cybersecurity companies through mentorship, training and validation capital.\nFor the Applied Learning Initiative, the City University of New York, New York University, Columbia, Cornell Tech, and iQ4, a cloud-based virtual collaboration platform provider, will build a cyber talent pipeline. The partners will offer city residents certification and degree programs and provide degree-seeking students with real-world, case-method education about cybersecurity and facilitate job placements.\nFullstack Academy, a software development school, and CUNY\xe2\x80\x99s LaGuardia Community College will develop a Cyber Boot Camp to prepare New Yorkers for cybersecurity jobs.\n"Today\'s cybersecurity environment is more intricate and complex than ever before, and presents itself to companies, organizations and individuals alike," said Sean Joyce, cybersecurity and privacy leader at PricewaterhouseCoopers, one of the Cyber NYC partners. "To combat this ever-evolving threat landscape, it\'s important that we invest in developing skilled professionals, innovative approaches, and build collaboration across the public and private sector to thwart potential attacks and build stronger resiliency."\nMobile cybersecurity for city residents\nTo help NYC residents better protect themselves from mobile cyber threats, the NYC Cyber Command launched a free app that alerts mobile users to threats on their iOS or Android devices or on the Wi-Fi networks they are accessing.\nThe New York City-funded NYC Secure mobile app warns users about threats on their mobile devices, such as unsafe apps, a potentially unsecure Wi-Fi network or unsafe settings and activity. It can detect elevation-of-privileges attacks, rogue access points, and unenabled encryption.\xc2\xa0 After identifying potential issues, NYC Secure offers recommendations on how to address the threats. The app does not require an internet connection to detect a threat, so alerts are immediate.\nNeither the city nor the app\'s developer, Zimperium, collect or use any personal information.\nThe app was first announced in March as a part of Mayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s larger NYC Secure initiative, aimed at protecting New Yorkers online that also included securing the city\'s public Wi-Fi networks. \xc2\xa0The Quad9 automated security platform the city deployed blocks access to known malicious sites by checking IP addresses against IBM X-Force threat intelligence, which includes daily monitoring of \xc2\xa0more than 40 billion web pages and images and 17 million spam and phishing attacks.\nNYC Cyber Command mandated the deployment of the technology on the city\'s internal networks by the end of 2018. It will also be deployed on the LinkNYC network, whose 1,400 kiosks offer free high-speed Wi-Fi around the city\'s five boroughs.\nAbout the Author\nSusan Miller is executive editor at GCN.\nOver a career spent in tech media, Miller has worked in editorial, print production and online, starting on the copy desk at IDG\xe2\x80\x99s ComputerWorld, moving to print production for Federal Computer Week and later helping launch websites and email newsletter delivery for FCW. After a turn at Virginia\xe2\x80\x99s Center for Innovative Technology, where she worked to promote technology-based economic development, she rejoined what was to become 1105 Media in 2004, eventually managing content and production for all the company\'s government-focused websites. Miller shifted back to editorial in 2012, when she began working with GCN.\nMiller has a BA and MA from West Chester University and did Ph.D. work in English at the University of Delaware.\nConnect with Susan at smiller@gcn.com or @sjaymiller.\nE-Mail this page\nPrintable Format\nRelated Articles\nThe National Guard\'s cyber escape room\nThe downside of drones\nChina-U.S. tech supply chain how can other cities across the world find the funds to follow its lead?\nFacebookTwitterLinkedinemailThe scramble for technology to create cleaner, safer, richer cities has intensified as funding models have started to take root. The fashion for smart city pilot tests has finished. The technology works, we are told. The last challenge is how to pay for them, when so many of their benefits are hard to calculate financially.\nHow do you make money from sensors in car parks, really? How much, exactly, is information about air pollution worth?\nIn a new report, Navigant Research has looked at the smart city market, and identified the five key funding models that have started to make it tick. Here, we consider each, as means to solve 21 century urban challenges, and ask obliquely if any of them will bring intelligence to cities, beyond just a few noisy outliers\n1 | PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS (PPPs / 3Ps)\nA public-private partnership, declined as PPP in Europe and 3P / P3 in North America, is a cooperative arrangement between two or more public and private sector entities, where the financial risk is loaded on one side of the deal, typically towards private enterprise.\nPPP / 3P deals have been employed as a standard financing instrument by governments across the globe, particularly as a way to fund major public infrastructure projects during the last 30 years. The structure of the model, and the allocation of risk, varies considerably, depending on partners and applications.\nIn the smart cities space, it is the most common and, as yet, most effective tool for governments and suppliers to push forward with their projects. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are all over the place, in many smart-city application areas, and they come in many different flavours,\xe2\x80\x9d says Ryan Citron, senior research analyst at Navigant Research.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is essentially just a contract between a public authority and private supplier that defines a way to work together, but the definition is pretty loose.\xe2\x80\x9d The financial risk is largely assumed by the private sector, he notes, so tax payers \xe2\x80\x9caren\xe2\x80\x99t on the hook\xe2\x80\x9d if something goes wrong.\nIn smart city deployments in the US, the financial burden assumed by the private sector has been greater, simply as state funding has been less. In Europe, most smart city projects have retained a stream of funding from the European Union, typically via its Horizon 2020 programme, pushing research and innovation in the region through to 2020.\nThe upside for the private sector is the chance to secure major regional and national infrastructure deals, only with the sting of bank-rolling such projects through their formative years. Key incentives are built into PPP / 3P deals by governments in order to justify the investment for the private sector.\n\xe2\x80\x9cGovernments typically guarantees some level of service, or offers subsidies, grants or tax breaks,\xe2\x80\x9d notes Citron.\nPPP / 3P arrangements have helped many smart city technologies take root. However, they require a clear business case with a reliable return-on-investment. The problem for the smart city movement, and vendors pushing novel solutions in the space, is so many of the applications and use cases are either completely untested, or else they only offer a kind of \xe2\x80\x98soft\xe2\x80\x99 ROI.\nIn the end, the financial risk for both sides is too high. \xe2\x80\x9cFor many smart-city applications, the return is less clear for investors,\xe2\x80\x9d comments Citron.\n2 | ENERGY SAVINGS PERFORMANCE CONTRACTS (ESPCs),\nAs discussed above, PPP / 3P models are hugely varied; at one extreme, they effectively result \xe2\x80\x98energy savings performance contracts\xe2\x80\x99 (ESPCs), where the financial incentives are effectively swapped for a share of the energy savings achieved by the tech upgrade.\nIn the smart city space, ESPCs have become the default tool for getting smart buildings and smart street-lighting projects off the ground. The model works so buildings are retro-fitted with energy control and management systems, and whole cities are afforded brand new lighting infrastructure, without making any capital investment.\nInstead, they relinquish their energy savings until the supplier recovers their own costs. \xe2\x80\x9cIt uses the future energy savings to fund the investment. Once the energy savings pay off the initial fee, the city starts to reap the benefits,\xe2\x80\x9d explains Citron.\nFor street lighting, vendors reckon cities can save 70 per cent of their energy and maintenance costs by combing connected LED lights and control systems, and make the money back in a few years.\nCitron explains: \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of companies are telling cities they don\xe2\x80\x99t have to pay anything. They\xe2\x80\x99re saying: \xe2\x80\x99Your paying $10 million per year in electricity costs for lighting; put our system in and save $7 million. You can have it paid off in three years, and save a tonne of money every year after that.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe ESPC model has effectively made street-lighting the poster child for smart city applications. Cities like the model, too, because the supplier is the one penalised if targets are not met, removing risk almost completely.\nBut, like with PPP / 3P master deals, ESPCs work because the ROI is well understood. The energy savings from other smart city applications \xe2\x80\x93 including even popular point solutions, like connected waste bins, weather sensors, and parking systems \xe2\x80\x93 are murkier, and riskier for investors.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe challenge with all of these models is how to apply them to other smart city applications,\xe2\x80\x9d says Citron.\n3 | AS-A-SERVICE OFFERINGS (aaS)\nSubscription-based models offer another way for cities to avoid making upfront payments for tech infrastructure and service offerings. They appear to cities rather like ESPCs, insofar as the cost is spread over a set period. The difference is the outcome for the city is not written into the bargain at the start.\nTypically it is attached to more conventional service offerings, rather than infrastructure projects. Certain lighting companies, for example, require cities to pay a subscription to make use of their control and management functions. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s good model \xe2\x80\x93 the city doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have to pay upfront; just on an ongoing basis. It makes it easier to bear,\xe2\x80\x9d says Citron.\nIncreasingly, smart city providers are aspiring to get their capital costs down to the point they can also offer as-a-service schemes. Street parking, says Citron, has been expensively rolled out in cities like Los Angeles, with every single space fitted with a sensor to create a parking map for drivers.\nBut the sheer cost of such an exercise has stopped cities from copying, and suppliers from pushing. Instead, they are seeking to redesign their tech and rewrite their algorithms to make the service more affordable, if also more approximate, and to eke out a subscription model for partners,\nDespite increasing interest and adoption, however, as-a-service models are hard to offer when material costs are high in the first place. The five models are discussed here are less popular, by degrees, as we go through them. Subscription based offerings have found less traction than standard PPP / 3P models or energy savings contracts. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not very common, at this point.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCitron explains: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s hard in some realms for companies to come in and provide the service without charging upfront for some of the tech.\xe2\x80\x9d\n4 | INVESTMENT RECOVERY THROUGH ADVERTISING / MARKETING\nFrom here, we are scraping the barrel. The idea cities and enterprises will be able to monetise the data gathered on their city streets remains just that \xe2\x80\x93 an idea, locked in pilot mode in most cases. The idea an open data platform, in a smart-city control centre, will spark a new economy of local innovators is appealing, but hard to grasp.\nEither way, these more expansive smart city concepts invariably hinge on the a hard ROI, probably realised by upgrading the street lights. Most experiments in the market only exist because the business case for street lights is so clear.\nThere is one alternative, however; the well-trailed LinkNYC project in the US, which is seeking to convert 7,500 old pay-phone booths across the five boroughs of New York City into digital kiosks. The plan was to spend $200 million. City Hall did not have to pay a dime. The cost \xe2\x80\x93 and then some \xe2\x80\x93 would be recovered through advertising, to the tune of $500 million over 12 years. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s paying for the project,\xe2\x80\x9d says Citron.\nAround 1,600 kiosks are in operation, offering free, fast and secure (gigabit) Wi-Fi to passers-by, push-button connections to emergency services, free USB charging, tethered Android handsets for free calls, and touchscreen access to city info and services. Five million people have stepped into the kiosks so far, reckons CityBridge, the consortium behind the project.\nThe payback for the city is connectivity and accessibility. The model has been picked up by electric vehicle (EV) charging companies, too, notes Citron, offering advertising space on their charging stations to be able to make a return and offer free charging.\n5 | SOCIAL IMPACT BONDS (SIBs)\nA recent phenomenon, social impact bonds (SIBs), also known as pay-for-with the pay-out contingent on agreed social outcomes. Issued by the public sector and funded by private sector, while they operate over a fixed period of time, they do not offer a fixed rate of return.\nThe first social impact bond was announced by the UK government in 2010 to finance a prisoner rehabilitation programme, bringing together innovators to generate idea to develop social action. In a smart-city context, it has been used here and there for healthcare projects, and other applications related to the criminal justice system\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s an interesting model. It hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been used much. The contracting arrangements can be kind of complex, and difficult to finance. But it really targets social oriented investors, and people interested in alternative measures of financial performance,\xe2\x80\x9d comments Citron.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not going to be a major model, but it\xe2\x80\x99s innovative and a little different \xe2\x80\x93 and it does focus on improved social outcomes, which is really the goal of most smart city projects. It could be used in transportation a bit more, for instance.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThis article is a forerunner to a report and webinar, titled How to buy / sell a smart city \xe2\x80\x93 procurement models to make every city smart, to be published on November 5. Sign up to the Enterprise IoT Insights newsletter here to get updates about the report, and related news. Register for the webinar here to hear from speakers from AT&T, the City of Cardiff, Cisco, Cradlepoint and Navigant.\nRelated\nRelated\nTags:3Pas-a-servicebondsenergy saving contractsESPCfundingPPPprocurementSIBssmart cities\nPrevious post\nPlatform provider Particle intros new IoT developer kits, Microsoft IoT coding studio\nNext post\nSoftBank completes key connection tests for NIDD technology\nThe Author\nAll posts\nJames Blackman\nJames Blackman has been writing about the technology and telecoms sectors for over a decade. He has edited and contributed to a number of European news outlets and trade titles. He has also worked at telecoms company Huawei, leading media activity for its devices business in Western Europe. Transparency\nTwitter\nFacebook\nInstagram\nCivicist Twitter\nRSS\nCivicist\nCivic Tech News & Analysis from Civic Hall\nFirst Post\nBig Hacks\nTiny chips from China found in devices used by nearly 30 U.S. companies; a record 800,000 people registered to vote on National Voter Registration Day; and more.\nBy: Micah L. Sifry\nOct 4, 2018\nThis is civic tech: More than 800,000 people registered to vote last week on National Voter Registration Day, a record that surpassed the 2016 total of 771,000 and far more than organizers expected, Katie Reilly reports for Time magazine. Of those, 486,966 came in thru Democracy.works\xe2\x80\x99 Turbovote platform, which worked with dozens of major tech partners. This is one more sign that turnout in the 2018 election may reach the levels typically seen in presidential years.Related: Say hello to Ayirini Fonseca-Sabune, New York City\xe2\x80\x99s first chief democracy officer.Zack Quaintance of GovTech reports on how New York City is using its LinkNYC kiosks to tell the story of how civic hackers are using the city\xe2\x80\x99s open data to improve life in the city.The AP\xe2\x80\x99s Rob Gilles reports on the ongoing controversy dogging Sidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99 Toronto project.Goodbye Sesame Street and hello Chu-Chu TV! If you are a parent of young kids, you probably know about this phenomenon already. 1.5 billion views! For context, Alexis Madrigal of the Atlantic explains the fascinating world of YouTube-powered children\xe2\x80\x99s video makers.Tech and politics: Google\xe2\x80\x99s former head of public relations, Jessica Powell, has written a satirical novel called The Big Disruption, and judging from this letter from her on Medium (which has published the novel) and interview with Kara Swisher of Recode, it\xe2\x80\x99s one of those cases where only fiction can really get at the truth. (And yes, we learn that Brian Chesky of Airbnb once really did try to claim during a keynote talk that his company would cause the world to have less wars.)The ACLU\xe2\x80\x99s Neema Singh Guliani writes in the Washington Post that big tech companies sudden interest in consumer privacy legislation is \xe2\x80\x9cin fact, an effort to enlist the Trump administration and Congress in companies\xe2\x80\x99 efforts to weaken state-level consumer privacy protections.\xe2\x80\x9dRelated: Columbia professor Tim Wu writes in the New York Times that the Justice Department\xe2\x80\x99s announcement that it will sue California for imposing strong net neutrality rules is \xe2\x80\x9cbut one of a series of similar invasions of states\xe2\x80\x99 rights undertaken in the name of corporate sovereignty, which, in the age of a new nationalism, has been elevated above state law.\xe2\x80\x9dTechnosociologist Zeynep Tufekci opines in the New York Times that while Russian meddling in the other countries\xe2\x80\x99 elections is a real concern, we should be paying more attention to the core of Silicon Valley\xe2\x80\x99s business model of profiting from micro-targeting and elevating polarizing content because it drives user engagement.Life in Facebookistan: Singapore is poised to pass a new law that would force tech platforms to stop the spread of fake news within hours of its being posted, a crackdown that Craig Silverman of Buzzfeed says would be the \xe2\x80\x9cmost far-reaching\xe2\x80\x9d effort by any government in the world to regulate misinformation online.You can now look up \xe2\x80\x9cgroup history\xe2\x80\x9d on Facebook, and The New York Times\xe2\x80\x99 Kevin Roose has already turned up some doozies, like the \xe2\x80\x9cWe Support Brett Kavanaugh (SCOTUS)\xe2\x80\x9d group that used to be \xe2\x80\x9cIsis Support Group\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cWho Farted !!!\xe2\x80\x9dCyberwar, continued: The UK has formally accused Russia of four major cyber-attacks, Matt Burgess reports for Wired UK, \xe2\x80\x9can attack between July and August 2015 where the emails of a small UK TV station were stolen; the hack against the Democratic National Committee (DNC) in 2016; leaking of athlete data from the World Anti-Doping Agency, and the BadRabbit ransomware that spread in October 2017.\xe2\x80\x9d While observers have long assumed the connection, the attribution is significant, he writes.Tiny chips inserted during the computer manufacturing process in China by a unit of the People\xe2\x80\x99s Liberation Army have been found in devices used by nearly 30 companies in the United States, including a major bank, government contractors, Amazon and Apple, Jordan Robertson and Michael Riley report in a major story for Bloomberg BusinessWeek called \xe2\x80\x9cThe Big Hack.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cChina\xe2\x80\x99s goal was long-term access to high-value corporate secrets and sensitive government networks,\xe2\x80\x9d they write. \xe2\x80\x9cNo consumer data is known to have been stolen.\xe2\x80\x9dIf you didn\xe2\x80\x99t get the emergency presidential alert text that was sent out to millions of Americans yesterday, not to worry, explains Emily Dreyfuss for Wired. After all, it was a test of the system.End times: A timely reminder why politicians should never appear in front of monochrome backgrounds.Program note: Next week I\xe2\x80\x99ll be in Bucharest for the Code for All Global Summit, so First Post will be on hiatus. See you the following week.\nBy: Micah L. Sifry\nOct 4, 2018\nShare\nShare on Twitter\nShare on Facebook\nShare by Email\nTopics\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0First Post\nSponsors\nCraig Newmark Philanthropies\nMicrosoft\nLuminate\nGoogle\nSee all Sponsors, Partners, and Organizational\nMembers\nCivic Hall\n118 W22ND STREET, 12FL NEW YORK, NY 10011\nHours: Mon to Fri, 8:30 a.m. to 7 p.m.\ninfo@civichall.org\n@CivicHall on Twitter\nWhy privacy matters, Facebook's new currency, KidTube; and much more on the #FirstPost, a digest of news and analys\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/R4wqLyRXHU\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @EngineerEmily: A Timeline of Civic Tech Tells a Data-Driven Story of the Field https://t.co/Mgsg6HSpvv @CivicHall https://t.co/S2yvyCskaU\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @motaword: This month, MotaWord's content creator @marcosd attended New York Tech Meetup (powered by @CivicHall):\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/jhE4uLKjwq\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @booksoncallnyc: We\xe2\x80\x99re so pleased to be @CivicHall this evening, handling book sales for @josephmenn and \xe2\x80\x9cCult of the Dead Cow: How\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/Xrdyj0bndW\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @LeeTomson: Lunch and Learn with @PBProject in advance of their Forum @CivicHall on June 24! https://t.co/RDXA7sTb4M\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nRT @Shari_Davis1: Can't wait to kick off our #DemocracyBeyondElections conversation later this month with @CivicHall.\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/ofL2ULMtmR\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nCivic tech and your taxes; BreadTube vs alt-right; and so much more on the #FirstPost, a digest of news and analysi\xe2\x80\xa6 https://t.co/dRwTCWnmvO\n\xe2\x80\xa2Follow Us\nWe had a blast as well! All Rights Reserved.\nContact\nData Use Policy\nTerms of Service\nPress Contact", b'Public-Private Partnerships Empower Cities with Dexterity in Emerging Tech | StateTech Magazine\nSkip to main content\nBecome a StateTech Insider\nSign up today to receive premium content!\nSign Up\nMENU\nLog in\nMobile menu\nTopics\nStates\nTips & Tactics\nVoices\nFeatures\nVideo\nIT Blogs\nMore\nNews\nEvents\nWhite Papers\nMust Read IT Blogs\nCITizen\nSmart Cities\nAbout Insider\nSearch\nSearch\nMain menu\nTopics\nStates\nTips & Tactics\nVoices\nFeatures\nVideo\nIT Blogs\nMore\nNews\nEvents\nWhite Papers\nMust Read IT Blogs\nCITizen\nSmart Cities\nAbout Insider\nSearch\nEnergy & Utilities\nEnterprise\nFinancial Services\nLegal\nManufacturing\nNonprofit\nRetail\nSmall Business\nSports & Entertainment\nStartups\nTrending Now\nEnterprise\nWhat Is IoT\xe2\x80\x99s New Security Threat? It\xe2\x80\x99s Called Hajime.\nBusiness Intelligence\nCloud\nData Center\nDigital Workspace\nHardware\nInternet\nManagement\nNetworking\nSecurity\nSoftware\nTrending Now\nPublic Safety\nDispatch Centers Upgrade 911 Systems in the Face of Cyberthreats\nCloud\n3 Benefits of Effective Government Cloud Management\nNetworking\nSmart Cities 3.0: 5G, Edge Computing and Citizen Engagement\n30 Must-Read State and Local IT Blogs 2018\nOct 31 2018\nFollow these blogs to stay current on the latest news and trends for state government, smart cities, first responders, public libraries, courts and more.\nStateTech Magazine\nCurrent Issue | Archive\nStateTech E-Newsletter\nCurrent Issue | Archive\nTwitter\nfeed\nHome\xc2\xbbNetworking\nNetworking\nPublic-Private Partnerships Empower Cities with Dexterity in Emerging Tech\nMunicipalities find flexibility, innovation and competencies in public-private partnerships supporting smart cities.\nby\nAdam Stone\nAdam Stone writes on technology trends from Annapolis, Md., with a focus on government IT, military and first-responder technologies.\nTechnology moves fast; government procurement moves slow. Public-private partnerships can help bridge the gap. State and local governments increasingly are looking to leverage the agility of the private sector through creative affiliations, while also trimming the cost of innovative projects.\nThree examples help to show how PPPs can help civic officials get to a desired IT endpoint faster and more effectively.\nLink NYC Rolls Out Free Wi-Fi Kiosks in New York City\nNow in the fourth year of a projected 12-year rollout, Link NYC aims to install more than 7,500 free public Wi-Fi kiosks. The effort brings together the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications and CityBridge, a consortium of IT firms including Intersection, Qualcomm and CIVIQ Smartscapes.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe third-party franchisee, CityBridge, was in a position to provide cutting-edge expertise in selling advertising, as well as the ability to build out the private network,\xe2\x80\x9d says Andrew Manshel, assistant commissioner of franchise administration\xc2\xa0for the New York City IT department.\nMore to the point, the franchisee and the tech partners bear the cost of the project. \xe2\x80\x9cWe didn\xe2\x80\x99t have to use the limited capital funds that the city has available in order to do this,\xe2\x80\x9d Manshel says.\nWith 1,800 kiosks already installed, Manshel says the secret to a successful PPP lies in both sides understanding their respective roles. \xe2\x80\x9cThe city steers and the private-sector partner rows,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cThat means we set the high standards for the partner to meet, and they execute on those standards. We went in with clear standards for these kiosks, both aesthetic and technological.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMORE FROM STATETECH: Find out why these eight smart cities are ones to watch!\nKentucky Residents Breathe Easier with AIR Louisville\nThe city of Louisville, Ky., has a reputation for lousy air quality, with a high incidence of asthma and respiratory distress. With help from a private tech supplier and funding from a national nonprofit, a city-led PPP is looking to change that.\nWith $750,000 in funding from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, medical device maker Propeller Health supplies \xe2\x80\x9csmart\xe2\x80\x9d asthma inhalers that correlate to location, building a localized database of air quality and health risk. The Institute for Healthy Air, Water and Soil, part of the University of Louisville, helps to analyze the data, with an eye toward identifying high-risk locations and trends around the city.\nIt took city-sized muscle to bring all the players together. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is the power of working in the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office. We could take people who were normally in different silos, all these disparate players, and present them with this shared problem,\xe2\x80\x9d says Grace Simrall, Louisville\xe2\x80\x99s chief of civic innovation and technology.\nA PPP also offered a unique vehicle for solving a civic problem without spending tax revenues on untried technologies.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs an innovation office, we are looking for true breakthroughs, which often means using brand-new methods and brand-new data sources. Given that, we don\xe2\x80\x99t want to experiment using the public dollar,\xe2\x80\x9d Simrall says.\nAt the same time, the PPP brought to the table a level of experience the city couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have accessed in-house. \xe2\x80\x9cGovernment should not be expected to have core competencies in everything,\xe2\x80\x9d Simrall says. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you have emerging technologies, we need to rely on private partners. We don\xe2\x80\x99t want to develop a smart medical device when there are companies out there who have done that.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMORE FROM STATETECH: Get practical IT governance advice from former smart city leaders!\nCommuters Travel Smart with Water Street Tampa\nIn Tampa, Fla., Smart Mobility Manager Vik Bhide would like to leverage the expanding Internet of Things to deliver smart traffic lights, enhanced signage and maybe even autonomous vehicles.\nHe sees the emerging Water Street Tampa development as an opportunity to do all that. The city is partnering with developer Strategic Property Partners on the $2 billion to $3 billion project, which has backing from Bill Gates\xe2\x80\x99s Cascade Investment. The city also is teaming with the Tampa Hillsborough Expressway Authority to help execute a $21 million grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation to study connected vehicle technology.\nThe partners all come together via the recently formed Tampa Bay Smart Cities Alliance.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith smart cities, most solutions delivered to the end user pass through several entities, and it helps to have a place where these entities can coordinate with one another,\xe2\x80\x9d Bhide says. \xe2\x80\x9cHaving an alliance that incorporates most of these entities \xe2\x80\x94 the city, the utilities, the major developers \xe2\x80\x94 allows us to streamline services and to bring new solutions to market sooner.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAs envisioned, Water Street will have 9 million square feet of hotel space, along with 3,500 residential units, 1 million square feet of cultural and retail space, and 2 million square feet of office space in 18 different buildings.\nUltimately, Bhide describes the PPP as the logical expression of the interconnected realities underlying smart city technology. \xe2\x80\x9cThe reason we need the partnerships is because the end user straddles everybody\xe2\x80\x99s business in consuming these newer smart-city services,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cThe partnership creates a circular value proposition, using public infrastructure and private data to deliver a better service.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLinkNYC/Twitter\nMore On\nInnovation\nInvestment\nIT Governance\nReturn on Investment\nInternet of Things\nSmart Cities\nWi-Fi\nRelated As of September,\xc2\xa0the company reported having more than 5 million registered users who have conducted\xc2\xa01\xc2\xa0billion sessions at the city's\xc2\xa01,700-plus units, according to msn.com. Users are making more than 500,000 visits a month.The kiosks, which display\xc2\xa0paid advertising, have barely delivered the minimum payments guaranteed to the city by CityBridge, the consortium that operates the kiosks.Topics: Government, Outdoor Kiosks, Wayfinding / InformationSponsored Links:Related ContentKiosk Marketplace editor reviews 39 kiosk companies at National Restaurant ShowCustomers adapting to kiosks, but acceptance not uniform in all scenariosTaco Bell to install self-order kiosks in all stores in 2019 under its All Access initiativeSquare integration with Kiosk Pro app enables self-service for iPadsLatest ContentState-of-the-art testing: the first line of defense against fraudstersTexas Dairy Queen franchisee pioneers self-order kioskCashierless stores?
