Additionally, LinkNYC kiosks are currently running two campaigns to remind New Yorkers of the looming registration deadline displaying a countdown clock until the voter registration deadline and stats showing how many people in the surrounding district of the LinksNYC kiosk have registered to vote.\xc2\xa0And New Yorkers concerned about entering personal information into the kiosk can rest assured: Your privacy stays protected thanks to an encrypted private WiFi network, any information you enter is anonymized.Those\xc2\xa0hoping to sign up should have their New York State driver\xe2\x80\x99s license, permit or non-driver ID handy. To register to vote in New York City, you must be a U.S. citizen, a New York City resident for at least 30 days and 18 years of age on Election day.\xc2\xa0Photo credit: Jovana RizzoTo learn more about how to register to vote or to check if you are already registered, go here.\xc2\xa0Launched in 2014, LinkNYC the first-of-its-kind communications network created to replace the city\xe2\x80\x99s payphones and to build the world\xe2\x80\x99s fastest and largest free public wi-fi network. Currently, there are more than 1,700 Links live throughout the five boroughs, and so far, five million people have used the free wi-fi service.Equipped with advanced communication technology, LinkNYC can be used for more than just phone calls and free wi-fi. Each kiosk offers services such as device charging, a tablet to access maps, the social services platform Aunt Bertha and access to 311 and 911. All of Links\xe2\x80\x99 services are 100 percent free for users.To find a Link near you, visit this map.So, Brooklynites, no excuses \xe2\x80\x94 everything you need to get your registration started is readily available at your nearest LinkNYC kiosk.Tags: bk readerLinkNYC kioskmidterm election 2018voter registration ShareTweetSend\nDid you enjoy this story? Please help us continue to bring you Brooklyn's latest local news for free by donating $1 here!\nRelated Posts\nNY State Legislators Pass Bill Decriminalizing Marijuana June 21, 2019\nEvolution in Motion: Sidra Bell Dance Debuts New Work on Identity and Womanhood June 21, 2019\nEast NY Dads Unleash Their Inner Artist at Father\xe2\x80\x99s Day Paint \xe2\x80\x98n\xe2\x80\x99 Sip\xe2\x80\x99 Party June 21, 2019\nCouncilman Reynoso Launches Bid for Borough President June 21, 2019\nLoad More\nNext Post\nNo Building, No Permits - How a Brownsville Charter School Found a Home\nComments 1\nstupid-city says:\n8 months ago \xe2\x80\x9ceverything you need to register is readily available at your nearest LinkNYC kiosk.\xe2\x80\x9dThat is not true. You can *start* registering to vote via curbside LinkNYC kiosks but you cannot finish the process without heading to a local library, or your home PC, or other primary resources.Why would anyone use a LinkNYC kiosk to get \xc2\xbd way through the voter registration process except to prove they can? Same thing about registering for health coverage through the NY State of Health via LinkNYC. It is physically impossible to upload proof of income and ID and the like from a LinkNYC tablet, but headlines make it look like all kinds of New Yorkers are doing this when no one possibly can.ReplyLeave a Reply Cancel replyYour email address will not be published. But what did that have to do with the price of tea in China? I Agree", b'Voter registration push as deadline draws near |\nNew York Amsterdam News: The new Black view\nFri, June 21st\nClassifieds\nContact\nEvents\nAbout\nMedia Kit\nSubscribe\nSign in\nSearch\nHome\nNews\nEducation\nHealth\nInternational\xc2\xbb\nCaribbean Connection\nImmigration Korner\nLocal\nNational\nPolitics Noir\nReligion\xc2\xbb\nThought from Pastor Mike\nObituaries\nUnion Matters\xc2\xbb\n1199\n32BJ\nCOBA\nDC37\nTeamsters\nPopular Topics\nActivism\nHousing\nJustice\nOpinion\nBlogs\nEditorials\nLetters to the Editor\nOp-Eds\nArts & Entertainment\nArt\nBooks\nCelebrities\nFashion\nFilm/TV\nFood\nTheater\nTravel\nMusic\nColumnists\xc2\xbb\nAfrica Sings\nCaribbean Lingo\nDifferent Stages\nGo with the Flo\nHarlem Arts Alliance\nImhoteps Guide\nNightlife\nSChop\nSuite Sounds\nJazz Notes\nHealth\nColumnists\xc2\xbb\nHouse Calls\nSports\nHarlem Focus\nBlack Experience\nVoter registration push as deadline draws near\nCYRIL JOSH BARKER |\n10/11/2018, 12:31 a.m.\nPolling station voters sign\nNia Sanders\nAcross the nation, advocates are making their final push to get people registered to vote in time for the upcoming November midterm election. The deadline in New York is this Friday, Oct. 12, for both online and in-person registration.\nFrom Democrats, Republicans, progressives and conservatives, every angle of the political spectrum is scrambling to make sure eligible voters are registered to flood the polls. In the wake of the recent confirmation of now Supreme Court Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh, all sides are energizing their bases for victories in November.\nOne example is in an email sent out Wednesday by the New York Progressive Action Political Action Committee urging citizens with the message \xe2\x80\x9cDemocracy is dying.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur message to you today is simple and clear,\xe2\x80\x9d the email said. \xe2\x80\x9cOur democracy is in a state of peril. Any unregistered person who does not register to vote by Friday will be silenced by the powers that be Nov. 6.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe NAACP unveiled a strategy to maximize the Black vote by targeting low and moderate propensity voters. The civil rights organization worked with GSSA, LLC, a Colorado data analytics group and partner in the initiative, to map out metrics for the Black community to have an impact on the elections and identify parity in registration and turnout of Black voters in battleground states.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn order to become a potent political force, the Black community must build a political infrastructure that will vote in both presidential and non-presidential elections and at all levels of the ballot,\xe2\x80\x9d said NAACP President and CEO Derrick Johnson. \xe2\x80\x9cIf all eligible members of the community rise to the challenge and vote, we control the fate and future of our community. Stated more directly, we must vote in far greater numbers because our lives, our very existence depends on it.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe NAACP is also enlisting the support and partnership of members and of allied organizations, including the faith community, Pan-Hellenic organizations and issue-advocacy groups. So far, more than two dozen memoranda of understanding have been executed with partner organizations.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the current social, political and policy environment, change will only happen in our democracy through voting our interests and our conscience,\xe2\x80\x9d said Johnson. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Black community can only improve its political and economic situation in America by becoming a potent political force.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThis week in the city, reminders were all around along city streets as LinkNYC kiosks flashed messages about registering to vote along with a countdown clock to Friday. Information was also flashed about the number of voters in particular districts.\nHowever, even those who feel confident they are registered are being urged to double-check before the Oct. 12 deadline. The New York Civil Liberties Union reports that many showed up during the September primary only to find out their names were missing from voter rolls. Among those missing from the roll was Mayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s own son, Dante.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe suffer from confusing registration deadlines and outmoded poll books that cause errors, delays, and long lines,\xe2\x80\x9d the NYCLU said in statement. \xe2\x80\x9cTo make matters worse, due to decades of partisan gerrymandering, New Yorkers cannot be sure they receive equal representation even when they cast their ballots.\xe2\x80\x9d\nVoters are being urged to check their status by going to voterlookup.elections.ny.gov, where they can enter their name, date of birth, county and ZIP code. If no match is found or the voter\xe2\x80\x99s status is not listed as active, the voter should contact the Board of Elections.\nAt the end of September on National Voter Registration Day, more than 800,000 eligible voters updated their registration or registering for the first time. The registration drive surpassed the previous record of 771,321 set during the 2016 presidential campaign.\nAlso of interest\nYour vote...voices of wisdom\nStill fighting for voters\' rights\nOfficials cry foul over proposed closure of polling sites in Black Georgia county\nNAACP announces \'This is My Vote\'\nMost Recent\nAlvin Bragg announces run for Manhattan D.A.\nHoroscopes with Ashley\xe2\x80\x99s Aquarian Age, June 20 - June 26\nRemembering our ancestors who didn\xe2\x80\x99t survive the voyage\nReady for a Harlem summer\nTalking SCHOP!\nA birthday first in Canada, b'LinkNYC\xe7\xb6\xb2\xe7\xb5\xa1\xe4\xba\xad\xe2\x80\x82\xe9\x81\x8a\xe6\xb0\x91\xe6\xbb\x8b\xe6\x93\xbe\xe5\x9a\xb4\xe9\x87\x8d\n2019\xe5\xb9\xb406\xe6\x9c\x8821\xe6\x97\xa5 22:35\n\xe7\xb4\x90\xe7\xb4\x84\nLinkNYC\xe7\xb6\xb2\xe7\xb5\xa1\xe4\xba\xad\xe2\x80\x82\xe9\x81\x8a\xe6\xb0\x91\xe6\xbb\x8b\xe6\x93\xbe\xe5\x9a\xb4\xe9\x87\x8d\n\xe5\xb7\x9e\xe8\xad\xb0\xe6\x9c\x83\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe5\xbc\xb7\xe5\x8f\x8d\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\xa8\xb7\xe6\x93\xbe 11\xe9\x81\x8a\xe5\xae\xa2\xe5\x8c\x85\xe6\x8b\xac4\xe8\x8f\xaf\xe4\xba\xba\xe6\x80\xa5\xe9\x99\x8d\xe6\xb2\x99\xe6\xbc\xa0\n\xe5\x9f\x83\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe7\x99\xbc\xe7\x94\x9f\xe7\x86\xb1\xe6\xb0\xa3\xe7\x90\x83\xe4\xba\x8b\xe6\x95\x85\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x95\xb6\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe6\x99\x82\xe9\x96\x936\xe6\x9c\x8820\xe6\x97\xa5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\x9f\x83\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe5\x8d\x97\xe9\x83\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x9b\xa7\xe5\x85\x8b\xe7\xb4\xa2\xe7\x9c\x81\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xb8\x80\xe7\x86\xb1\xe6\xb0\xa3\xe7\x90\x83\xe5\x9c\xa8 ...\n\xe4\xbb\x8a\xe6\x97\xa5\xe7\xb2\xbe\xe5\xbd\xa9\xe5\x85\xa7\xe5\xae\xb9\n\xe5\xb7\x9e\xe8\xad\xb0\xe6\x9c\x83\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe5\xbc\xb7\xe5\x8f\x8d\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\xa8\xb7\xe6\x93\xbe \xe6\xb3\x95\xe6\xa1\x88\xe9\x81\x8e\xe9\x97\x9c\xe5\xbe\x85\xe6\x9f\xaf\xe8\xac\xa8\xe7\xb0\xbd\xe7\xbd\xb2\n\xe6\x9c\xac\xe5\xa0\xb1\xe8\xa8\x8a \xc2\xa0 \xe5\x9c\xa8\xe9\x81\x8e\xe5\x8e\xbb\xe5\xb9\xbe\xe5\x8d\x81\xe5\xb9\xb4\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbe\x86\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\xa8\xb7\xe6\x93\xbe\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\xb7\x9e\xe8\xad\xb0\xe6\x9c\x83\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe5\xbb\x88\xe6\x9c\x80\xe7\xa6\x81\xe5\xbf\x8c\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xad\xb0\xe9\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82 ...\n\xe5\x85\x92\xe5\xad\x90\xe6\xb6\x89\xe5\x88\xa9\xe7\x9b\x8a\xe8\xa1\x9d\xe7\xaa\x81\xe5\xbc\x95\xe9\x97\x9c\xe6\xb3\xa8 \xe6\x8b\x9c\xe7\x99\xbb\xe6\x89\xbf\xe8\xab\xbe\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe7\xab\x8b\xe5\x8d\xb3\xe8\x99\x95\xe7\x90\x86\n\xe6\x9c\xac\xe5\xa0\xb1\xe8\xa8\x8a \xc2\xa0 \xe5\x89\x8d\xe5\x89\xaf\xe7\xb8\xbd\xe7\xb5\xb1\xe6\x8b\x9c\xe7\x99\xbb\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x85\x92\xe5\xad\x90\xe8\xa2\xab\xe6\x8f\xad\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x8b\x9c\xe7\x99\xbb\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe5\x89\xaf\xe7\xb8\xbd\xe7\xb5\xb1\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe9\x96\x93\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe5\x85\xa5\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x9c\x8b\xe5\x8f\x8a ...\n\xe5\xb8\x8c\xe5\x85\x8b\xe6\x96\xaf\xe8\xb5\xb4\xe5\x9c\x8b\xe6\x9c\x83\xe9\x96\x89\xe9\x96\x80\xe8\x81\xbd\xe8\xad\x89 \xe7\x99\xbd\xe5\xae\xae\xe7\xa5\xad\xe8\xb1\x81\xe5\x85\x8d\xe6\xac\x8a\xe9\x98\xbb\xe6\xad\xa2\xe5\x95\x8f\xe7\xad\x94\n\xe9\x99\xb8\xe7\xa5\x9d\xe6\x98\x8e\xe7\xb7\xa8\xe8\xad\xaf \xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9c\x97\xe6\x99\xae\xe5\x89\x8d\xe5\x8a\xa9\xe7\x90\x86\xe5\xb8\x8c\xe5\x85\x8b\xe6\x96\xaf\xef\xbc\x88Hope Hicks\xef\xbc\x8919\xe6\x97\xa5\xe5\x87\xba\xe5\xb8\xad\xe5\x9c\x8b\xe6\x9c\x83\xe8\x88\x89\xe8\xa1\x8c ...\n\xe8\x81\xaf\xe7\xb5\xa1\xe6\x88\x91\xe5\x80\x91\n\xe7\xb8\xbd\xe6\xa9\x9f\xef\xbc\x9a\n212-699-3800\ninfo@nysingtao.com\n\xe5\xbb\xa3\xe5\x91\x8a\xe9\x83\xa8\xef\xbc\x9a\n212-699-3800\xe6\x8c\x89106\xe6\x88\x96107\nsales@nysingtao.com\n\xe5\x88\x86\xe9\xa1\x9e\xe5\xbb\xa3\xe5\x91\x8a\xef\xbc\x9a\n212-699-3808\nclassified@nysingtao.com\n\xe7\x99\xbc\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe9\x83\xa8:\n212-699-3800\xe6\x8c\x89162\xe6\x88\x96164\ncir@nysingtao.com\n\xe5\xb8\x82\xe5\xa0\xb4\xe6\x8e\xa8\xe5\xbb\xa3\xe9\x83\xa8\xef\xbc\x9a\n212-699-3800\xe6\x8c\x89111\nmarketing@nysingtao.com\n\xe6\x98\x9f\xe5\xb3\xb6\xe6\x97\xa5\xe5\xa0\xb1Apps\nIOS\nAndroid\n\xe9\x97\x9c\xe6\xb3\xa8\xe6\x88\x91\xe5\x80\x91\n\xe8\xa8\x82\xe9\x96\xb1\xe6\x98\x9f\xe5\xb3\xb6\xe6\x97\xa5\xe5\xa0\xb1\n\xe9\x9b\xb6\xe5\x94\xae\xe7\x89\x88\n\xe9\x9b\xbb\xe5\xad\x90\xe7\x89\x88\n\xe7\xa7\x81\xe9\x9a\xb1\xe6\x94\xbf\xe7\xad\x96\xe8\x81\xb2\xe6\x98\x8e\n\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\xa2\x9d\xe6\xac\xbe\n\xe7\x89\x88\xe6\xac\x8a\xe5\x91\x8a\xe7\xa4\xba\nCopyright All rights reserved.', b'TVEyes Media Monitoring Suite - [Transcript]\nLog In >\nTranscript\nLog In\nTranscript Log In\nNY1\xc2\xa0-\xc2\xa0New York, NYInside City Hall\nNY1 10/11/2018 10:20:35 PM: ......\nCopyright \xc2\xa91999 - 2019\nTVEyes, Inc.\nAll rights reserved.\nQuestions, comments, or suggestions? Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b"5G street fight | E&ampT Magazine\nIET sites\nThe IET\nE&T Jobs\nE&T Magazine\nIET Connect\nIET Digital Library\nWiring Regs digital\nIET Electrical\nIET Faraday\nIET Venues\nIET.tv\nEngineering Communities\nWelcome\nYour IET account\nOther IET sites\nThe IET\nE&T Jobs\nE&T Magazine\nIET Connect\nIET Digital Library\nWiring Regs Digital\nIET Electrical\nIET Faraday\nIET Venues\nIET.tv\nToggle navigation\nMenu\nHome\nE&T News email\nLatest issue\nWebinars\nWhitepapers\nE&T jobs\n5G street fight\nImage credit: Image Source\nBy Mark Ballard\nPublished Friday, October 12, 2018\nPublic and private interests are vying to control comms infrastructure on city streets, so they can profit when next-gen mobile arrives.\nWhen the payphone business started collapsing around the turn of the millennium, New York City had to act. It had grown accustomed to making money by licensing call box operators and taking a share of their income, but mobile phones were becoming popular. And payphones were going bust.\nThe City authority instructed phone booth operators to sell advertising space on their call boxes and give it a share of that revenue, too.\nIt earned $26m that way in 2000. In the following decade, as 75 per cent of payphones in the US were scrapped, NYC kept its payphone income near $20m. A decade on, its ad income started going up, while its income from phone calls fell to near zero, and half again of all payphones in New York were scrapped.\nNYC decided it was time to reinvent the payphone, to make it more of an advertising hoarding with a phone attached. And that is how the next-generation phone kiosk was born. The City would make $500m from call box adverts over the 12-year life of its next licence contract, Mayor Bill de Blasio said in 2014, shortly before awarding it to a consortium that dreamed up a next-gen phone kiosk called LinkNYC.\nIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all about money, though. LinkNYC had been patched together from a medley of visionary designs submitted to a public competition the City held to \xe2\x80\x9creinvent the payphone\xe2\x80\x9d in 2013. It embodied the public ethos as well, and ideas NYC had been pushing for around decade: a comms kiosk with a touchscreen web interface and local guides and services. Competition concept drawings imagined 10ft digital panels displaying not ads but sci-fi info-schematics.\nHurricane Sandy clinched the deal in October 2012, shortly after NYC officials defined how the payphone should be reinvented, and ahead of the last payphone contracts reaching the end of their 15-year terms. The old ones had been defamed, since it seemed no-one but vagrants used them anymore. Then Sandy knocked out all but the public phone network and people turned to payphones in their emergency. The reinvented ones would be free, high-speed wireless internet beacons as well, with emergency buttons. And, as de Blasio put it, all at no cost to taxpayers.\nNYC could cover the cost with advertising and still take a larger cut. It cited a deal where it allowed a billboard firm to put adverts on municipal street furniture and took half the income. The phone deal it did in 1999 had got a\xc2\xa0third, and just a dime in every dollar spent on calls.\nNYC told potential suppliers in 2012 what a next-gen phone kiosk should be: a slim panel like other street ad hoardings. Switching these with chunky phone boxes, NYC would declutter its streets, make them look smarter, and ease pedestrian flow.\nThis contrivance of public and private purpose was reflected in the consortium of companies that formed to produce the LinkNYC kiosk. At their heart was Intersection, a corporation formed from the merger of Titan, the largest US billboard operator, and Control Group, a tech studio that had designed public information kiosks for the New York subway. A sister of ad-funded tech giant Google put up money. Qualcomm, the comms equipment maker, along with other tech firms, contributed specialisms.\nIt was the same kiosk they brought to BT in the UK in 2017. But the business model was not the same at all. Public authorities didn\xe2\x80\x99t control phone boxes in the UK, so they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t make any money out of them. Many have consequently opposed the scheme.\nBT had taken call fees from the UK\xe2\x80\x99s classic red phone boxes when it was the national telecoms operator in the latter part of the last century, retaining the right after it was privatised in 1984. Laws held that phone boxes were a public good, so BT should ensure there were enough to meet public need.\nThat need declined so much last decade that Ofcom, the UK communications regulator, revised the rules to help local public authorities (LAs) stop BT and other operators scrapping phone boxes in places where, for example, poverty was so prevalent that people might depend on them.\nEverything had changed by 2017 and LAs found cause to oppose the kiosk produced by NYC.\nSmartphones had overloaded mobile phone networks in city centres with high demands for capacity. Comms firms proposed small cells: transmitters distributed along city streets to take strain off major mobile networks. Yet they would need favour from local planning authorities, and a network infrastructure.\nComms companies did deals with LAs to rent spaces on street furniture, such as lamp posts and CCTV columns, already linked with cable ducts. They offered to square public good with private greed in the New York model. LAs would get a cut of the money mobile operators paid to use the network infrastructure. Spare capacity would supply a free public Wi-Fi service, which LAs claimed would bridge the digital divide by ensuring anyone could get internet access, even if they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford it. Wi-Fi would be basic and time-limited. Those who wanted more and faster would pay, and LAs would take a cut of that as well.\nLAs hoped to make a lot of money. The London Borough of Camden \xe2\x80\x93 one of the first to act \xe2\x80\x93 was expected to earn \xc2\xa33.5m from a 10-year deal it signed in 2011 with Arqiva, a comms infrastructure firm that subsequently did most such deals. Sixteen other London boroughs joined on its terms. Camden valued the deal at \xc2\xa340m. The group estimated it would raise \xc2\xa320m.\nMichael Snaith, a consultant at Regional Network Solutions, who helped engineer the \xe2\x80\x98concession\xe2\x80\x99 contract model the LA deals followed, with his colleague Callum Knowles, said they advised on more than 40.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe aspiration was public Wi-Fi,\xe2\x80\x9d he says, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the driver was: \xe2\x80\x98We have these assets \xe2\x80\x93 how much can you pay for them?\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIt became a problem, he said, that LAs thought it would be a \xe2\x80\x9cmajor income earner\xe2\x80\x9d, while the contractors promised too much. Camden\xe2\x80\x99s income projection for its 2011 deal had become \xe2\x80\x9cunachievable\xe2\x80\x9d, it said last year, \xe2\x80\x9cdue to the rising prevalence of other sources of free Wi-Fi and the availability of 4G\xe2\x80\x9d.\nOfficials in London\xe2\x80\x99s Hammersmith & Fulham borough said in February they were renegotiating the 2013 Wi-Fi deal they did with Arqiva because it had underachieved. Another deal to rent council cable ducts for networking might be abandoned.\nSouthampton City Council cancelled its 2013 Arqiva concession, according to a director who asks not to be named. \xe2\x80\x9cIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t delivering what we hoped. Take-up was almost nil. There was too much contention in the area. You have to stand extremely close to a transmitter if you are to avoid competing signals from surrounding shops and mobile,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. That contention was from Wi-Fi in places such as coffee shops.\nOther LAs had similar problems. \xe2\x80\x9cThe old market square is a very congested radio environment, with multiple Wi-Fi services being pushed out by shops,\xe2\x80\x9d says John Connelly, digital infrastructure manager at Nottingham City Council, which agreed a concession with BT in 2015.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen BT did the initial survey, they told us there are lots of signals competing. And when signals compete, they knock each other out. With the contention, if you have 50 people near an access point, all trying to get on the system, it\xe2\x80\x99s more difficult for the cell.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt depends on the number of access points you have. The more you have, the better the service,\xe2\x80\x9d says Connelly.\nBT addressed this in plans to install Wi-Fi in Glasgow, according to documents held by the City Council. It showed how LAs could spread uninterrupted Wi-Fi over central streets if they combined transmitters in phone kiosks with those BT put on lamp and CCTV posts under a concession it agreed with Glasgow in 2014.\nWhere neighbouring transmitters do not collaborate they contest, say public officials. David Oliver, solution architect for a Wi-Fi service Sheffield City Council set up last year under a 10-year concession, says it will not deliver a seamless service with InLinks BT is installing in the city as well. People would either log in to one or the other, or their phones might switch between them if they were subscribed to both, depending on which had the stronger signal.\nSheffield\xe2\x80\x99s Wi-Fi signal has a 30Mbit/s capacity with blanket coverage, says Oliver. He has tried to find out from other LAs what is the typical speed of free public Wi-Fi, and thinks it is probably less than 10Mbit/s.\nPaul Neville, digital director at Waltham Forest, says its concession delivers 4Mbit/s\xc2\xa0 Wi-Fi, but the authority is working with Arqiva to double it.\nCapacity makes all the difference when facing contention, and the underlying network determines the capacity, according to Nottingham\xe2\x80\x99s Connelly.\nBT has claimed InLinks deliver free Wi-Fi at 1Gbit/s speeds, based on a fibre network it puts in when it installs them in choice spots on its old payphone network, with the cost of the rollout covered by advertising.\nLAs, government and concessionaires have all been striving to build fibre networks. Tower Hamlets, another London borough, made fibre a condition of the concession it sought to establish this year, with the cost to be covered by mobile phone operators who paid to use the network. It reckoned on making \xc2\xa33.5m on the deal.\nLAs did not give up on concessions after the first deals failed. Nor did they abandon the idea of making money from them.\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s not a failure. It\xe2\x80\x99s an evolution. Because local authorities have released the assets, they have played an enabling role in the digital agenda.\xe2\x80\x99\nMichael Snaith, Regional Network Solutions\nThe City of London, authority for the financial district, reckoned it would make \xc2\xa318.5m from a concession it let last year to Cornerstone, a firm joint-owned by mobile operators Telefonica O2 and Vodafone.\nMobile operators\xe2\x80\x99 demand for small cells is reportedly uncertain. Their 4G services were notoriously late rolling out. But the delivery of 5G mobile broadband phones in 2020 is planned initially for city centres where it could be economically viable to distribute the small cells required to support them.\nWestminster City Council reckons it will make \xc2\xa322m from a 10-year deal it struck this year with Ontix Ltd, an unknown start-up.\nOther LAs setting up similar deals in the last 12 months include Liverpool, Coventry, Kingston and Hackney. Most of them opposed BT\xe2\x80\x99s InLink rollout by refusing all planning applications it made to install them. Whereas those LAs that had no such deal or had not recently reset them typically granted every InLink BT requested. Others, such as Southwark and Lambeth, have opposed significant numbers of InLinks while setting up deals of their own.\nBy examining records of 45 LAs where BT\xc2\xa0sought to install InLinks, and others significant by their concession deals or their being London boroughs, E&T found a confluence between self-interest and opposition to InLink.\nE&T viewed the records of more than 1,000 InLink planning decisions, as well as contract records, elected council proceedings and cabinet and committee papers where public authorities set out multi-million-pound deals with comms companies. Most of them kept the financial details from public view.\nTheir opposition was based on legitimate reasons under planning law, according to their own records. UK planning rules give comms companies special rights to install network equipment on the basis of there being a great public need for it. They must still make applications for each bit of equipment. LAs can oppose only the particular places where comms companies seek to put it, so they have some say over where it goes and how it looks, but the law forbids them blocking a network installation.\nIt forbade them blocking the BT rollout, yet many claimed InLinks were impractical in every location BT proposed, forcing BT to pursue its rollout in appeals before the planning ombudsman.\nWestminster took its opposition to the High Court in August, claiming phone boxes were such a nuisance that it should have power to refuse them. It chose for its contention an application by New World Payphones, another next-gen phone kiosk company previously owned by Arqiva.\nThe latter created coverage in Camden by combining access points on its kiosks with those on municipal furniture. Phone kiosks were likewise part of a concession bid it made in Waltham Forest last year.\nYet Camden wrote a public letter last month to Kit Malthouse, the government minister for housing and planning, asking for power to refuse kiosks when it believed there was no need. InLink UK, on the other hand, lobbied the London Mayor in March, begging power to stop LAs blocking its rollout because it had plans to put 5G cells in them.\nBristol City Council, which has licensed use of its street furniture to its \xe2\x80\x98Bristol is Open\xe2\x80\x99 joint venture with the University of Bristol, refused all 25 InLink applications this year. It has put \xc2\xa325.3m of government funding into the deal. Then last year it agreed a \xc2\xa35m street-advertising concession with JCDecaux, granting it spots on main roads where both ad-based kiosks and small-cell contractors vie for space. That is another form of concession LAs pursue. Camden had proposed forbidding its own concessionaire from displaying advertisements in order to protect revenue from its street advertising concessions.\nSouthwark said last year it might do a deal for JCDecaux to upgrade its billboards with Wi-Fi, while it prepared to put 5G small cells in street furniture. Islington was putting hotspots in benches. LAs up and down the country have been drawing up \xe2\x80\x98smart city\xe2\x80\x99 plans for networked street furniture and small-cell concessions. The reinvented phone kiosk has not appeared in their plans.\nSnaith says LAs were losing interest in free Wi-Fi, while some contractors believe their concessions have been a waste of time.\nReflecting on the generation of concession deals that LAs did on the NYC model, which Camden took up in 2012, Snaith insists they did not fail.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome people would say they were a failure,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not a failure. It\xe2\x80\x99s an evolution. Because local authorities released the assets, they have played an enabling role in the digital agenda.\xe2\x80\x9d\nRead more: Cities block 5G kiosks after doing rival deals\nImage credit: E&T\nImage IET cookies and how to control them\nYes I agree", b"NYC will roll out thousands more kiosks offering free public Wi-Fi\nGo to the content\nGo to the footer\nClose\nNew York\nChange city\nNew Look out for your first newsletter in your inbox soon!\nMy Account\nMy Profile\nSign out\nMy Account\nSearch\nicon-search\nTickets\nEvents\nThings to Do\nTime Out Market\nRestaurants\nBars\nMovies\nTheater\nKids\nArt\nNews\nAttractions\nVideo\nHotels\nTravel\nMusic\nTO Book\nClasses\nMuseums\nShopping\nNightlife\nComedy\nDance\nLGBT\nSex & Dating\nBooks\nCity Guide\nNeighborhoods\nMagazine\nSweepstakes\nVenue Rental\nMore\nWorldwide\nicon-chevron-right\nNorth America\nicon-chevron-right\nUnited States\nicon-chevron-right\nNew York State\nicon-chevron-right\nNew York\nicon-chevron-right\nNYC will roll out thousands more kiosks offering free public Wi-Fi\nNews\n/ City Life\nNYC will roll out thousands more kiosks offering free public Wi-Fi\nShare\nTweet\nBy Will Gleason. Brought to you by Microsoft\nPosted: Monday October 15 2018, 12:53pm\nPhotograph: Courtesy LinkNYC\nWhen the sleek, black LinkNYC kiosks began popping up around New York in 2016, it felt sort of like the opening scene of 2001: A Space Odyssey. Technologically advanced monoliths from the future had suddenly materialized to drag us all into the future. Two years later, the internet-connected sidewalk kiosks\xe2\x80\x94which offer free Wi-Fi, free calling and USB ports to charge devices\xe2\x80\x94can boast\xc2\xa0more than 5 million registered Wi-Fi users who log an average of 20 million free sessions a week. Additionally, 500,000 phone calls are made on the kiosks every month.\nSo can we look forward to a sunny future where we can all cancel our private internet plans and log onto a free public network that blankets the city?\xc2\xa0Unfortunately, no. \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC kiosks are primarily designed for commercial corridors,\xe2\x80\x9d explains Kate Blumm, Assistant Commissioner at the NYC Department of Information Technology. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just one piece of the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s larger plan to bring affordable high-speed internet to every New Yorker by 2025.\xe2\x80\x9d Additionally, the 1,700 kiosks that have been installed across the five boroughs (of a planned 7,500) only offer a Wi-Fi range of about 150 feet.\nWhen NYC originally conceptualized the project that eventually became LinkNYC, it was looking for a modern replacement for the city\xe2\x80\x99s aging payphone infrastructure. The winning proposal, from CityBridge, envisioned futuristic metal totems spread out across all five boroughs with giant, high-res screens on either side. Advertisements shown on the screens would then cover the cost of the kiosks themselves, and the city would be gifted with free, fast Wi-Fi infrastructure. To date, however, some of the most compelling uses of the kiosks have come from those screens rather than the Wi-Fi.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe were surprised by how many people have been using them to make calls when everyone has cell phone, but a big part of the kiosks has been the content we display on the screens,\xe2\x80\x9d says Jennifer Hensley, the president of Link. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re able to provided curated content to help people make the most of their city through partnerships with local government and cultural institutions.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s ranged from a recent initiative where New Yorkers could literally register to vote using the kiosks to information on good restaurants to hit up in the area, fun facts about the city and details on upcoming local events that those passing by might want to attend.\nOne of the criticisms of the kiosks from privacy advocates has been the inclusion of two cameras above the displays (along with a third camera above the tablet which could possibly be used for video calling in the future). Hensley insists, however, that the cameras above the New York devices are primarily for monitoring the structures themselves. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re expensive pieces of hardware out on the streets so we want to make sure they\xe2\x80\x99re safe,\xe2\x80\x9d she says.\nAlong with the addition of thousands of more kiosks in the coming years, Hensley predicts that the devices will play a large part in coming years with helping New Yorkers have all the information they need to be counted in the 2020 census. However, by that time, Link will be helping more than just New Yorkers. The company has plans to expand into Newark this\xc2\xa0week\xc2\xa0and will soon spread to Philadelphia by the end of the year.\nAdvertising\nAdvertising\nShare\nTweet\nGuest blogger\nBy Will Gleason. Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b"LinkNWK launches in Brick City - NJBIZ\nLOG INSubscribe\nPrint, Digital & Data Subscriptions\n8 Weeks Free Trial Subscription\nSign Up For Daily And Other Newsletters\nEvents\nLatest Headlines\nDigital Editions\nVanguard Series\nExecutive Moves\nPic Page\nPower 100\n2019 Power 100\n2018 Power 100\n2017 Power 100\n2016 Power 100\n2015 Power 100\n2014 Power 100\nLists\nLists and Directories\nComplete a Survey\nLogin Subscribe\nPrint, Digital & Data Subscriptions8 Weeks Free Trial SubscriptionSign Up For Daily And Other Newsletters\nMy Account\nManage Your Print or Online SubscriptionManage Your Email Subscription\nContact USAdvertise\nEducation\nEnergy\nFood & Hospitality\nGovernment\nHealth Care\nLaw\nManufacturing\nMoney\nReal Estate\nRetail\nTechnology\nTransportation\nEducation\nEnergy\nFood & Hospitality\nGovernment\nHealth Care\nLaw\nManufacturing\nMoney\nReal Estate\nRetail\nTechnology\nTransportation\nPrint\nLinkNWK launches in Brick City\nBy:\nJessica Perry\nOctober 17, 2018\n7:50 am\nFrom left, Aisha Glover, president and CEO, Newark Community Economic Development Corp.; Joel Bloom, president, NJIT; Jen Hensley, president, Link at Intersection; and Newark Mayor Ras Baraka at a LinkNWK kiosk.-(CITY OF NEWARK PRESS OFFICE)\nNewark has bolstered its tech credentials further with the official launch of LinkNWK, a series of kiosks serving users with secure Wi-Fi and other features.Collaborators on the endeavor \xe2\x80\x94 the City of Newark, Newark Community Economic Development Corp., New Jersey Institute of Technology and Intersection, the company behind the \xe2\x80\x9csmart cities\xe2\x80\x9d technology \xe2\x80\x94 were all on hand Tuesday for the activation of the first kiosks.\nIntersection will install 45 kiosks throughout the city, including in each of the city\xe2\x80\x99s five wards.\nThe kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 construction, installation, maintenance and upgrades are supported through display advertising making them free for users and with no expense to taxpayers. Profits generated through advertising are also expected to fund additional infrastructure programs for NCEDC.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re excited to continue to build upon Newark\xe2\x80\x99s reputation as a tech hub. With major anchors and corporations like NJIT, Audible, Panasonic and Newark Venture Partners, as well as robust data infrastructure, we continue to bring Newark and its residents to the forefront of innovation,\xe2\x80\x9d Aisha Glover, president and CEO of NCEDC, said at the event. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are equally excited that LinkNWK is another feather in our tech cap.\xe2\x80\x9d\nNJIT will work with Intersection to explore new uses for LinkNWK\xe2\x80\x99s kiosks, including integrating them with apps.\nIn addition to Wi-Fi, Link kiosks offer mobile device charging; the ability to make phone calls within the U.S.; community content produced with local partners; and access to municipal services, maps and directions.\nNewark joins New York City, London, and other cities in the U.K. in its use of Link. Newark is the first city to launch with the Link Wi-Fi App, which provides users with a secure, encrypted connection to the LinkNWK network.\n7:50 am Wed, October 17, 2018\nNJBIZ Jessica Perry\nClick to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)\nClick to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)\nClick to share on LinkedIn (Opens in new window)\nClick to share on Email (Opens in new window)\nClick to print (Opens in new window)\nJessica Perry\nfollow jessperry_nj\nJessica is the Web Editor for NJBIZ.\nNJBIZ Business Events\nEnergy Panel Discussion - Presented by NJBIZ\nTuesday, June 25, 2019\nIcon Honors Awards\nTuesday, August 20, 2019\nForty Under 40\nWednesday, September 18, 2019\nCFO of the Year Awards\nTuesday, October 22, 2019\nView All\nLatest News\nMost Read\n\xc3\x98rsted\xe2\x80\x99s Ocean Wind Project wins BPU nod\nNY, NJ Legislatures approve commission to oversee Gateway tunnel project\nSponsored Content\nAn Energy Reality Check\nNarcan hand outs top 32,000 free doses during one-day program (updated)\nMore Latest Headlines\nMurphy vows to cut millions in 'pork' without millionaire's tax\nThe milky fray\nSenate, Assembly approve tax break extension measure\nParamount assets relocates headquarters to downtown Newark\nHackensack Meridian Health mourns the passing of Joseph Simunovich\nSubscriber Content\nJune 17, 2019\nJune 17, 2019 Edition of NJBIZ\nThe milky frayGap yearsMaking wavesProtecting patient data\nMore from This Week's Issue\nNJBIZ.Com\nLatest Headlines\nNJBIZ In Print\nSubscribe To Print\nDigital Editions\nEvents\nAdvertising With NJBIZ\nMedia Kit\nAdvertise in Print\nAdvertise Online\nEvent Sponsorships\nProduction Information\nCustomer Service\nContact NJBIZ\nHelp & FAQ\nAbout NJBIZ\nNJBIZ Staff\nDirections\nTerms and Conditions\nPrivacy Policy\nResources\nArchive Search\nBusiness Lists\nServices\nEmployee Engagement Surveys\nSubscribe to NJBIZ\nFollow Us\n\xc2\xa9 2019 BridgeTower Media. Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b'LinkNWK activates first kiosks -- GCN\nThe Technology that Drives Government IT\nAI & AutomationCybersecurityCloud & InfrastructureData & AnalyticsSmart Cities & IoTEmerging TechState & LocalMoreEventsResourcesNewslettersContactAdvertiseReprintsList Rental\nPulse\nBy GCN Staff\nBlog archive\nLinkNWK activates first kiosks\nThe first two LinkNWK kiosks in Newark, N.J., have been activated.\nPlans to place 45 kiosks offering free gigabit Wi-Fi, mobile-device charging and other services on sidewalks across the five wards of city were first announced in April.\nThe kiosks are made by Intersection, a smart city technology firm that has created similar networks in New York and London. Newark, however, will be the first city to offer the Link Wi-Fi app that provides an encrypted connection between the a user\'s device and the network provided by the kiosks. This is designed to prevent devices from connecting to \xe2\x80\x9cevil twin\xe2\x80\x9d networks that can allow hackers to view and steal user information.\nThe New Jersey Institute of Technology plans to partner with Intersection to find innovative use cases. "We envision possibilities that will improve transportation, community health, education, public safety, real estate development, and many other aspects of business and life throughout our city\'s downtown and its wards,\xe2\x80\x9d NJIT President Joel S. Bloom said in a statement.\nPosted by Matt Leonard on Oct 17, 2018 at 6:00 PM\nE-Mail this page\nPrintable Format\nFeatured\nCybersecurity\nWith defense contractors in the crosshairs, NIST rolls out new cyber guidelines\nForeign countries are targeting and compromising U.S. contractors so frequently that the Department of Defense asked NIST to develop custom security guidance.\nGovernment government credentials\nAn updated credentialing policy from the White House aims to make PIV cards interoperable across agencies and tap federal identifiers like Social Security numbers to secure getting plenty of use. As of September,\xc2\xa0the company reported having more than 5 million registered users who have conducted\xc2\xa01\xc2\xa0billion sessions at the city\'s\xc2\xa01,700-plus units, according to msn.com. Users are making more than 500,000 visits a month.The kiosks, which display\xc2\xa0paid advertising, have barely delivered the minimum payments guaranteed to the city by CityBridge, the consortium that operates the kiosks.Sponsored Links:Related ContentUrban Air CEO: Retail success is all about loving the customerGetting customers to return: Customer experience success storiesBrick-and-mortar retail isn\'t dead, it\'s just evolvingWhat revived legacy retail brands need to do to surviveLatest ContentCreating an experience beyond shoppingFor high-velocity retail business, mind the data gapCashierless stores? Send us\nfeedback.\nPrivacy Policy', b'Newark brings free Wi-Fi kiosks to city streets |\nNew York Amsterdam News: The new Black view\nFri, June 21st\nClassifieds\nContact\nEvents\nAbout\nMedia Kit\nSubscribe\nSign in\nSearch\nHome\nNews\nEducation\nHealth\nInternational\xc2\xbb\nCaribbean Connection\nImmigration Korner\nLocal\nNational\nPolitics Noir\nReligion\xc2\xbb\nThought from Pastor Mike\nObituaries\nUnion Matters\xc2\xbb\n1199\n32BJ\nCOBA\nDC37\nTeamsters\nPopular Topics\nActivism\nHousing\nJustice\nOpinion\nBlogs\nEditorials\nLetters to the Editor\nOp-Eds\nArts & Entertainment\nArt\nBooks\nCelebrities\nFashion\nFilm/TV\nFood\nTheater\nTravel\nMusic\nColumnists\xc2\xbb\nAfrica Sings\nCaribbean Lingo\nDifferent Stages\nGo with the Flo\nHarlem Arts Alliance\nImhoteps Guide\nNightlife\nSChop\nSuite Sounds\nJazz Notes\nHealth\nColumnists\xc2\xbb\nHouse Calls\nSports\nHarlem Focus\nBlack Experience\nNewark brings free Wi-Fi kiosks to city streets\nCyril Josh Barker |\n10/18/2018, 11:38 a.m.\nNewark, N.J.\nLinkNWK activated this week in Newark\xe2\x80\x99s first Link kiosks that are delivering free Wi-Fi and other services at no cost to users.\nMayor Ras J. Baraka, Newark Community Economic Development Corporation President and CEO Aisha Glover, the New Jersey Institute of Technology and Intersection, a cities technology and media company, came together to install the kiosks.\nSimilar to LinkNYC, each Link kiosk offers free mobile device charging, phone calls to anywhere in the U.S., access to municipal services, maps and directions and community content produced in conjunction with local partners.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese kiosks will enable residents and visitors alike to gain immediate information about Newark, ranging from upcoming cultural events to emergency service response,\xe2\x80\x9d said Baraka. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are the only city in the entire state and the second in the nation to provide these services, and every person who uses one of these kiosks will not only gain the services they need, but learn something more important: Newark is a world-class urban leader.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIntersection will install 45 LinkNWK kiosks throughout Newark, encompassing areas around Newark Penn Station and the Prudential Center, and along Broad Street, Market Street, Martin Luther King Boulevard and Irvine Turner Boulevard. Link kiosks will also be installed on neighborhood corridors such as Clinton Avenue, Ferry Street, South Orange Avenue and Bloomfield Avenue and will be placed in every one of Newark\xe2\x80\x99s five wards.\nAlso of interest\nNewark Mayor Ras Baraka speaks on Amazon HQ2\nLinkNYC teams up with Silicon Harlem to celebrate Black History Month\nHoward University students spend spring break cleaning up Newark\nMayor Ras Baraka, Savion Glover discuss strengthening Newark\xe2\x80\x99s arts and culture industry\n48th anniversary of Newark Rebellion commemorated\nMost Recent\nAlvin Bragg announces run for Manhattan D.A.\nHoroscopes with Ashley\xe2\x80\x99s Aquarian Age, June 20 - June 26\nRemembering our ancestors who didn\xe2\x80\x99t survive the voyage\nReady for a Harlem summer\nTalking Oct. 16, 2018. (Courtesy: City of Newark)\nBy Karen Yi | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com\nNew digital kiosks with 55-inch screens have\xc2\xa0sprouted across the city of Newark\xc2\xa0that will allow passers-by to make free phone calls, connect to public Wifi or charge their mobile devices.Newark is the first in New Jersey to\xc2\xa0launch the LinkNWK sidewalk\xc2\xa0kiosks\xc2\xa0created by\xc2\xa0Intersection, a New York-based technology company. New York City was the first to roll out the technology in 2016 and Philadelphia will install the kiosks later this fall.\nOn Tuesday, officials debuted\xc2\xa0the newly-installed\xc2\xa0kiosks across from the\xc2\xa0Prudential Center on Broad Street. A\xc2\xa0total of 45 kiosks will be in operation in the city -- with at least one in every ward. So far, two are up and running."Newark is once again defining itself to the state, nation, and world as a cutting-edge, high-tech city," Mayor Ras Baraka said. "These kiosks will enable residents and visitors alike to gain immediate information about Newark, ranging from upcoming cultural events to emergency service response."The kiosks, which Intersection installed at no cost to the city, display information on city services, fun facts about Newark, upcoming events and advertisements.The ad revenue will go to the company and be shared with the city as well.Representatives at\xc2\xa0Intersection said this time, the kiosks will not allow internet browsing. When the devices were first installed in New York City people used the kiosks to watch pornography, according to reports at the time.\nLinkNWK kiosk on Broad Street. Oct. 16, 2018. (Courtesy: City of Newark)\nThe company has not announced plans to install kiosks in any other New Jersey cities.The Newark kiosks will be the first to roll out with a Wifi app that allows users to connect to the LinkNWK network and pull up a map to find the nearest kiosk.\nNJIT has also partnered with Intersection\xc2\xa0to find creative ways of using the devices to benefit the community."Newark is a rising star in the tech economy, and we are proud that LinkNWK will only add to this momentum," said Jen Hensley, President of Link at Intersection.A minority investor in Intersection is Sidewalk Labs, which was created by Alphabet, the parent company of Google. Karen Yi may be reached at\xc2\xa0kyi@njadvancemedia.com. Follow her\xc2\xa0on Twitter at\xc2\xa0@karen_yi\xc2\xa0or on\xc2\xa0Facebook.\nView Comments\nFooter Navigation\nDisclaimer\nRegistration on or use of this site constitutes acceptance of our User Agreement and Privacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 New Jersey On-Line LLC. Community Rules apply to all content you upload or otherwise submit to this site.\nAd Choices', b"Kiosks herald Newark's high-tech hub surge | Video | NJTV News\nWatch\nTopics\nPolitics & Government\nArts & Entertainment\nBusiness & Economy\nEducation\nElections\nEnvironment\nHealth\nLaw & Public Safety\nTransportation\nWeather\nScience & Technology\nAbout\nTeam\nWhere to Watch\nContent Partners\nContact\nSEARCH\nDONATE\nSEARCH\nDONATE\nSCIENCE &AMP TECHNOLOGY Kiosks herald Newark\xe2\x80\x99s high-tech hub surge\nBY David Cruz, Senior Correspondent | \t\t\tOctober 18, 2018, 4PM EST\nSHARE:\n701157011570115Kiosks herald Newark's high-tech hub surgeConnectivity, interactivity and links to services are planned for new kiosks that will be located around Newark.2018-10-16 10:48 amdisabled30173885316fIWybCYCWktrue\nLet\xe2\x80\x99s say you\xe2\x80\x99re a big city mayor and you\xe2\x80\x99re in the middle of a news conference and demo of a new high-tech street kiosk that connects you to a hot spot, and city services, and traffic and transit info, and offers free phone calls across the U.S. You\xe2\x80\x99re hungry, but you\xe2\x80\x99re also late for your next event. Clearly, this is a job for a LinkNWK kiosk.\nThe mayor was at Military Park downtown surrounded by a crowd of tech-looking hipsters, or hip-looking techsters, demonstrating the new advertiser-supported kiosks from the New York-based Intersection, which has deployed thousands of kiosks in London and New York.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese links here in Newark are special,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jen Hensley, president of LINK at Intersection. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re unique in the whole world because they\xe2\x80\x99re connected by municipal fiber. The city had the foresight to really invest in infrastructure, and today what you\xe2\x80\x99re seeing is a manifestation of that in the form of services being offered for free to all of the residents, workers and visitors here.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe city\xe2\x80\x99s 26-mile superfast fiber optic network is now powering the city\xe2\x80\x99s rebranding, which includes a major push for the new Amazon HQ2. The first of these kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 there will be 45 in all at various commercial centers around the city \xe2\x80\x94 will be at Military Park, around which a transformation has already begun.\n\xe2\x80\x9cMilitary Park is kind of a center of gravity in this section, gathering space, there\xe2\x80\x99s a ton of festivals, events, people come out, they eat here, so it\xe2\x80\x99s just been a game changer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Newark Community Economic Development Corporation CEO Aisha Glover. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was kind of a hole in the doughnut here and it really sparked a lot of development. You know, Halsey is booming, a lot more restaurants are moving in, so it really changed the dynamic.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBut if you\xe2\x80\x99re one of those people who fears \xe2\x80\x94 as an out of town reporter did \xe2\x80\x94 that the kiosks will attract some of the city\xe2\x80\x99s less affluent denizens, the mayor made it clear that serving them was part of this initiative.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe technology has to be used to help everybody in society,\xe2\x80\x9d responded the mayor. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not just for the people across the street at Prudential. For somebody right there, sleeping in the park that uses that and finds a home, hell yeah that\xe2\x80\x99s something that we want to use the kiosks for.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLocations and timelines are subject to city approvals but the first two kiosks, like all those signs of the city\xe2\x80\x99s comeback, have already arrived.\nDavid Cruz\nSenior CorrespondentSenior Correspondent David Cruz is an award-winning journalist with a 25-year career in television, radio and newspapers. He began as a correspondent on North Hudson News, a nightly newscast covering Hudson County.\nRead Full Bio\nFollow @CruzNJTV\nTOPIC: SCIENCE &AMP TECHNOLOGYTAGS: LINKNWK LINK WIFI CITY SERVICES HOMELESS NEWARK HIGH-TECH HOTSPOT AMAZON HQ2 TECHNOLOGY LINK AT INTERSECTION\nMORE FROM SCIENCE &AMP TECHNOLOGY\n03:00Aviation research park hailed as \xe2\x80\x98silicon valley of the future\xe2\x80\x99\n03:30NJ hospital provides targeted radiation therapy, reducing side effects\n02:44Atlantic City betting on new data center to spur development\nPrevious Story\nWATCH WEEKNIGHTS\n6PM, 7:30PM, 11PM\nWHERE TO WATCH\nJoin the Conversation\nNJ COMMUNITY EVENTS\nMAJOR FUNDING PROVIDED BY\nADDITIONAL SUPPORT\nCONTENT PARTNERS\nAbout\nTeam\nContact\nNJTV ONLINE:\nNJTVONLINE.ORG\nPrograms\nKids\nSchedule\nFaq\nDonate\nAbout\nPrivacy Policy\nClosed Captioning\nCareers\nPressroom\nContact\n\xc2\xa9 2019 PUBLIC MEDIA NJ, INC. Support for arts programming is made possible in part by the Jean Dubinsky Appleton Estate.", b'LinkNWK network debuts in Newark with Wi-Fi kiosks - ROI-NJ\nAbout\nEducation\nFinance\nHealth Care\nIndustry\nLaw\nLifestyle\nOpinion\nPolitics\nReal Estate\nTech\nB2B Center\nLists\nSubscribe\nAbout\nEducation\nFinance\nHealth Care\nIndustry\nLaw\nLifestyle\nOpinion\nPolitics\nReal Estate\nTech\nB2B Center\nLists\nInforming and connecting businesses in New Jersey\nLinkNWK network debuts in Newark with Wi-Fi kiosks\nBy ROI-NJ Staff Newark |\nOct 19, 2018 at 11:56 am\nCity of Newark An illustration of what a LinkNWK kiosk looks like on a Newark street.\nThe LinkNWK network formally launched in Newark this week with the activation of special Link kiosks that will deliver Wi-Fi and other services to city residents and other users.\nNewark Mayor Ras Baraka, the Newark Community Economic Development Corp., New Jersey Institute of Technology and Intersection, the technology and media company behind the initiative, officially debuted the kiosks Tuesday, making Newark the second city in the U.S. with the service, after New York.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNewark is once again defining itself to the state, nation and world as a cutting-edge, high-tech city,\xe2\x80\x9d Baraka said in a prepared statement. \xe2\x80\x9cThese kiosks will enable residents and visitors alike to gain immediate information about Newark, ranging from upcoming cultural events to emergency service response.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are the only city in the entire state and the second in the nation to provide these services, and every person who uses one of these kiosks will not only gain the services they need, but learn something more important: Newark is a world-class urban leader.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWith the aid of the Newark Fiber program, Link kiosks offer Wi-Fi, charging, phone calls and access to municipal services and content.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re excited to continue to build upon Newark\xe2\x80\x99s reputation as a tech hub,\xe2\x80\x9d Aisha Glover, CEO and president of Newark CEDC, said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cWith major anchors and corporations like NJIT, Audible, Panasonic and Newark Venture Partners, as well as robust data infrastructure, we continue to bring Newark and its residents to the forefront of innovation. We are equally excited that LinkNWK is another feather in our tech cap.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIntersection will install 45 kiosks throughout the city, both in areas around Newark Penn Station and the Prudential Center and in heavily trafficked neighborhood corridors like Broad Street, Martin Luther King Boulevard and Clinton Avenue.\nRead more from ROI-NJ:\nNewark to get 45 Wi-Fi kiosks, special app as part of LinkNWK, city announces\nIntersection chairman: LinkNWK, a free public Wi-Fi platform, is about the future\nNewark to become fourth city in world to implement Link, a free network of advanced Wi-Fi services\nRelated\nROI-NJ Staff | editorial@roi-nj.com |\n@ROINJNews\nRead more from ROI-NJ\nAhead of debate, poll finds N.J. voters still favor Murphy\nPlatkin to be named Murphy\xe2\x80\x99s chief counsel\nEducational Testing Services inks former Md., Del. education official\nChristie as A.G.: Why former associates think it would be a great move\nGSAM PRE, Madison Marquette acquire retail center in Newark\nMore By ROI-NJ Staff\nWhat they\xe2\x80\x99re saying about Murphy on inauguration day\nThe Ammon Foundation: Company-sponsored and addiction-focused\nHF Planners bolsters design team\n$15/hour in N.J. isn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x98fair\xe2\x80\x99 if no one wins\nMorristown-based Berkley One expands in Midwest\nAlso in Tech\nIntertrust N.V. acquires Somerset-based Viteos for $330M\nCognizant to acquire Zenith Technologies\nBusinesses must notify customers of breach involving certain personal data \xe2\x80\x94 but N.J. has changed what that is\nDun & Bradstreet to acquire AI customer data platform\nCarolan, Ciano, Riccio earn Hall of Fame honor from NJ Tech Council\nGet a return on your information. All rights reserved', b'Facial recognition becoming a major public space issue - Curbed\nSkip to main content\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nSubscribe\nLog In or Sign Up\nLog In\nSign Up\nCities\nTopics\nHandbook\nShopping\nPodcast\nMore\nCities\nAtlanta\nAustin\nBoston\nChicago\nDetroit\nLos Angeles\nNew Orleans\nNew York\nPhiladelphia\nSan Francisco\nSeattle\nWashington DC\nTopics\nNews\nArchitecture\nHome Tech\nCampers and RVs\nInterior Design\nHouse Calls\nFor Sale\nLongform\nMaps\nHandbook\nShopping\nPodcast\n\xe2\x9c\x95\nFiled under:\nOpinion\nFacial recognition is becoming one of the 21st century\xe2\x80\x99s biggest public space issues\nNew,\n8\ncomments\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s about civil rights and the erosion of privacy in the public realm\nBy\nDiana Budds\nOct 19, 2018, 12:00pm EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nFacial recognition is becoming one of the 21st century\xe2\x80\x99s biggest public space issues\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nCorbis via Getty Images\nAutomation and artificial intelligence (AI) are often marketed as wondrous and futuristic technologies that will help us live more convenient lives. But beyond the idealistic marketing hype the reality is far more malignant.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAI\xe2\x80\x9d isn\xe2\x80\x99t just asking Siri for directions or telling Alexa to turn on your lights; it\xe2\x80\x99s already being used\xe2\x80\x94and has been used for decades\xe2\x80\x94to decide who receives medical care, who attends which schools, and who receives housing assistance.\nIt can also be used to identify people and people and make predictions about their behavior, a type of AI known as facial recognition.\nFacial recognition software is already widespread. Customs and Border Protection uses it to screen non-U.S. residents on international flights and TSA plans to expand this to all international travelers. The New Orleans police department, in partnership with Palantir, was using facial recognition in its predictive policing program for six years before the public knew about it. It\xe2\x80\x99s estimated that half of all American adults are in some sort of facial recognition database.\nAnd at AI Now\xe2\x80\x94a symposium held October 16 about the intersection of artificial intelligence, ethics, organizing and accountability, presented by an NYU research institute of the same name\xe2\x80\x94panelists warned that facial-recognition technology has troubling implications for civil rights, especially amid current debates about who has access to public space.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe should be deeply worried about the impact of AI face recognition on civil rights,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sherrilyn Ifill, president and director-counsel of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. \xe2\x80\x9cSo much of this implicates public space, contested public space, who can step into it, and what happens to us when we do.\xe2\x80\x9d\nNew York City\xe2\x80\x99s Domain Awareness system continually monitors people. This year, it was revealed that NYPD partnered with IBM to create facial recognition technology that can identity people by race.\nGetty Images\nThe rise of mass surveillance and biometric analysis in public space\nSince 9/11, mass surveillance has become the norm for law enforcement, which uses a variety of tactics to monitor people. Body cameras have become more common and security cameras are already ubiquitous. What\xe2\x80\x99s changing today isn\xe2\x80\x99t that we are being watched, it\xe2\x80\x99s who\xe2\x80\x99s doing the watching: computers.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAutonomous facial recognition\xe2\x80\x9d is a system that uses computer vision to look at images. Snapchat\xe2\x80\x99s filters and Apple\xe2\x80\x99s FaceID use computer vision, for example. Then, an algorithm\xe2\x80\x94designed by human programmers and data scientists\xe2\x80\x94processes those images and uses machine learning to analyze them by cross referencing the image to other data sources.\nThe facial recognition software technology companies are developing can identify a person in a crowd in real time, track someone\xe2\x80\x99s movements, detect emotions, and predict behavior. In a highly controversial study, one AI researcher claimed he could use facial recognition to predict someone\xe2\x80\x99s sexuality. IBM used NYPD footage to create software that lets police search for people by their skin color.\nThere are, of course, huge caveats with facial recognition technology: it\xe2\x80\x99s notorious for being highly inaccurate. Amazon\xe2\x80\x99s face-recognition software\xe2\x80\x94which analyzes facial attributes like gender and emotions\xe2\x80\x94wrongly identified 28 members of Congress as people who have been charged with a crime. Facial recognition software used by the Metropolitan Police, law enforcement in London, had an embarrassingly high rate of false-positive identifications: 98 percent.\nSherrilyn Ifill (left), Timnit Gebru (center), and Nicole Ozer (right) discussed the implications of facial recognition technology at AI Now\xe2\x80\x99s 2018 symposium.\nAndrew Federman courtesy AI Now\nWhy facial recognition is a Civil Rights issue\nDuring the AI Now panel, Nicole Ozer, the technology and civil liberties director of the ACLU\xe2\x80\x99s California chapter, called facial recognition technology a \xe2\x80\x9cgrave threat\xe2\x80\x9d that \xe2\x80\x9cfeeds off and exacerbates bias in society.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIf facial recognition systems sound a lot like souped-up versions of phrenology\xe2\x80\x99s quack science, it\xe2\x80\x99s because they are. Can someone look like a criminal? Look like they\xe2\x80\x99re about to cause harm? Appear to be a risk? Who decides that these traits actually signify criminality or risk? Or what a neutral expression is? This isn\xe2\x80\x99t much different than the stereotyping and profiling that happens today, which disproportionately affects people of color.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not just recognizing a face; it\xe2\x80\x99s evaluating a person,\xe2\x80\x9d Ifill said of the technology.\nFacial recognition technology accelerates such judgments, makes them at a larger scale, and does so with a greater level of opacity. Then \xe2\x80\x9cwe deposit this tech into institutions that are unable to address inequality, and drop it into a period of racial profiling and Stop and Frisk,\xe2\x80\x9d Ifill said.\nTake New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Gang Database, which currently lists between 17,000 and 20,000 individuals. It\xe2\x80\x99s only one-percent white\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s not entirely clear how someone is added to the list or removed, which has potentially damaging effects if someone is labeled a gang member when they have no affiliations.\nIn December 2017 and February 2018, NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund and the Center for Constitutional Rights filed a Freedom of Information Law request to understand how the NYPD builds, maintains, and and audits the database but didn\xe2\x80\x99t receive the documents it requested. In August, the advocacy groups sued the NYPD for failure to disclose its practices.\nAt its 2018 symposium, AI Now documented key moments in artificial intelligence news. Many of them relate to the use of facial recognition, including\nMicrosoft\xe2\x80\x99s partnership with ICE, in January; Palantir\xe2\x80\x99s deployment of predictive policing, in New Orleans, in February; an Amazon shareholder call for a moratorium of sales of face recognition tech to law enforcement revealed in June; Microsoft calling for federal regulation of facial recognition tech in July; and IBM and NYPD\xe2\x80\x99s partnership in September.\nAI Now\nWhy public space is a civil rights issue\nThe civil-rights implications of facial recognition become particularly clear in public space. What\xe2\x80\x99s troubling about this tech\xe2\x80\x94and data collection in general\xe2\x80\x94entering the public realm at a rapid clip is that they erode our constitutional rights to privacy, free speech, freedom of assembly, and due process. Meanwhile, our current political climate is becoming more hostile to these rights in public space. It\xe2\x80\x99s not too far of a stretch to see how facial recognition could make it worse.\nThe Trump Administration is actively trying to restrict access to public space that\xe2\x80\x99s popular with protesters. Would fewer people attend demonstrations if they knew their image could end up in a database just by attending? Police departments are already scanning crowds and protests to find and arrest people with outstanding warrants by cross referencing footage with social media profiles.\nFacial recognition adds fuel to the fire by making it impossible to move through public space freely. As Ifill said during the panel: \xe2\x80\x9cThe Civil Rights movement was about dignity in public space.\xe2\x80\x9d Facial recognition has the potential to strip dignity, all behind the scenes, and all surreptitiously.\nIfill draws parallels to the 1958 Supreme Court Case NAACP v. Alabama. In an attempt to intimidate Civil Rights activists, Alabama subpoenaed the NAACP\xe2\x80\x99s membership list, which the organization declined to do. The Supreme Court ruled that identifying who was in the NAACP would infringe on the right to privacy and free association.\nIn Wales, the human rights organization Liberty sued South Wales police for using facial recognition technology and told the Guardian, \xe2\x80\x9cThe police\xe2\x80\x99s creeping rollout of facial recognition into our streets and public spaces is a poisonous cocktail\xe2\x80\x94it shows a disregard for democratic scrutiny, an indifference to discrimination, and a rejection of the public\xe2\x80\x99s fundamental rights to privacy and free expression.\xe2\x80\x9d\nPublic space, in its lowest common denominator, is space that\xe2\x80\x99s open and accessible to all people regardless of race, age, income, sex/gender, or economic background. With facial recognition software in widespread use, you essentially lose privacy as soon as you enter the public realm. And public space ceases to be public if people can\xe2\x80\x99t freely use it\xe2\x80\x94including using it free of fear that they will be inaccurately profiled by humans or autonomous systems.\nPowerful technology with virtually no oversight\nThis summer, a group of Amazon employees called on Jeff Bezos to stop selling its face-recognition technology\xe2\x80\x94called Amazon Web Services Rekognition\xe2\x80\x94to law enforcement, citing concerns about violating human rights, especially considering the targeting of black activists by law enforcement and ICE\xe2\x80\x99s mistreatment of migrants and refugees. Just this week, Jeff Bezos essentially washed his hands of any culpability to civil or human rights violations related to Rekognition, saying that society\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cimmune response\xe2\x80\x9d will eventually fix biased tech.\nThis week, an anonymous Amazon employee wrote a Medium post which discusses how law enforcement around the country\xe2\x80\x94specifically Orlando, Florida, and and unnamed Oregon sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s department\xe2\x80\x94is testing facial recognition software with live video feeds and mugshot databases with virtually no public oversight.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s not just law enforcement that\xe2\x80\x99s playing into mass surveillance. Cities are using machine learning and computer vision to \xe2\x80\x9coptimize\xe2\x80\x9d their operations and redesign their systems. Sidewalk Labs is building a data-driven \xe2\x80\x9csmart city\xe2\x80\x9d in Toronto. Consumer brands are latching onto facial recognition software to target advertising in public space.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe only know the tip of the iceberg on how the government is ramping up face surveillance and how companies are using it,\xe2\x80\x9d Ozer said.\nMore public oversight of facial recognition may be coming. This summer, the ACLU asked Congress to institute a moratorium on the use of facial recognition by government agencies. Microsoft also urged Congress to regulate the technology. New York City created an \xe2\x80\x9cAutomated Decision Systems Task Force\xe2\x80\x9d to create recommendations on how AI should be regulated and monitored. This summer, 20 experts in civil rights and artificial intelligence authored a letter to the task force with preliminary suggestions about what policy could look like. In Toronto, Sidewalk Labs is proposing a \xe2\x80\x9cCivic Data Trust\xe2\x80\x9d to oversee the information it will eventually collect.\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s a chilling game: count how many security cameras you pass on your way to work. I tried it yesterday and passed 85 on a trip that included about six blocks of walking in Brooklyn and Manhattan and passing through two subway stations. Some were private (the ones outside my apartment building and in its hallways, the cameras in front of shops and bodegas, and security cameras in and around my office building). Thirty-seven were associated with New York City governance (the NYPD cameras on light poles and service vehicles, security cameras in LinkNYC kiosks, cameras in MTA stations).\nWhat was troubling to me is that I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, off the top of my head, what the privacy policies are for any of these companies, how long footage is stored, who has deals to share data, or how secure any of the data is. Was I being profiled? By leaving my apartment, did my image enter some sort of database? I would have no idea, just like everyone else who ventures outside. (I looked into it and learned that some of the MTA\xe2\x80\x99s cameras feed into NYPD\xe2\x80\x99s Domain Awareness System, which uses facial recognition. According to a LinkNYC spokesperson, the company has a provision banning the use of facial recognition technology and does not send footage to the NYPD unless it is subpoenaed.)\nIn her opening statement to the symposium, AI Now co-founder Kate Crawford said a few words that stuck with me: \xe2\x80\x9cAI isn\xe2\x80\x99t tech; it\xe2\x80\x99s power, politics, and culture.\xe2\x80\x9d Right now, our political climate is hostile to our civil liberties, it\xe2\x80\x99s using its power to restrict access to public space, and we live in a culture of fear. What good is a public space if people are too anxious to use it?\nSign up for the\nCurbed Daily Newsletter\nA daily dose of design and real estate news, intel, and eye candy\nEmail (required)\nSubscribe\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy and European users agree to the data transfer policy.\nMost Read\nAmazon is selling a $1,200 geodesic dome kit for your backyard\nThe Garden Dome Igloo is a 12-foot dome kit that can work as a backyard retreat, glamping tent, or kids play area.\nDo you hear marbles rolling in your apartment? The sidebar size is long.\nLoading comments...\nThe Latest\nIn the Maldives, MIT experiment fights rising sea levels with nature\nThe Growing Islands project harnesses natural wave forces to build underwater sand buffers.\nBy\nLiz Stinson\nOur cities are getting hotter\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s killing people\nHeat waves are causing more deaths in U.S. cities than all other disasters combined.\nBy\nAlissa Walker\n19\ncomments\n/\nnew\nGlass-and-brick midcentury gem on Lake Michigan asks $2.5M\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re a midcentury lover dreaming of a lake getaway, this three-bedroom, two-bath home might be your answer.\nBy\nMegan Barber\n1\ncomment\n/\nnew\nCan coworking companies sell inclusive communities?\nMeasuring the impact of The Wing, WeWork, the Coven, and other spaces selling a better workspace.\nBy\nPatrick Sisson\nCome for the pizza, stay for the \xe2\x80\x99gram at this pink Formica eatery\nHumble Pizza is modeled after London\xe2\x80\x99s Formica cafes of the 1950s.\nBy\nLiz Stinson\nOne of America\xe2\x80\x99s most popular furniture styles was invented by a celibate religious sect\nAll Shaker furniture is symbolic of the values of the utopian spiritual sect that designed it and gave the style its name\xe2\x80\x94values that are overdue for a comeback today.\nBy\nDiana Budds\n1\ncomment\n/\nnew\nChorus\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nGDPR Commitment\nCommunications Preferences\nContact\nSend Us a Tip\nCommunity Guidelines\nMasthead\nAbout Curbed\nNewsletters\nEditorial Ethics and Guidelines\nAll Systems Operational\nCheck out our status page for more details.\nVox Media\nAdvertise with us\nJobs @ Vox Media\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Vox Media, Inc. All Rights Reserved\ntweet\nshare', b"Ooredoo & Netgear launch Wi-Fi 6, 10+ Gbps mmWave Wi-Fi by Qualcomm, and LinkNYC tops 5 million users | Wi-Fi NOW Events\nWi-Fi NOW EventsAbout usAbout Wi-Fi NOWMANIFESTOOur ratingsOur credentialsMeet the teamContact usEventsCurrent EventsDownload Show GuideBuy Wi-Fi NOW presentations & videos2019 Washington DC2019 Shanghai2018 Johannesburg2018 Berlin2018 San FranciscoPrevious EventsExpoAwardsAbout awardsThe AwardsWhy enter?How to enterJudgesHall of FameSelection criteriaMediaNewsTVOoredoo & Netgear launch Wi-Fi 6, 10+ Gbps mmWave Wi-Fi by Qualcomm, and LinkNYC tops 5 million users [Weekly News Brief] by Claus Hetting | October 20, 2018By Claus Hetting, Wi-Fi NOW CEO & ChairmanAnother eventful week in the world of Wi-Fi included multiple new product launches related to Wi-Fi 6 and 60 GHz Wi-Fi \xe2\x80\x93 not to mention new numbers from the world\xe2\x80\x99s flagship City Wi-Fi network in New York City. Here are the week\xe2\x80\x99s most important Wi-Fi news items:Ooredoo & Netgear announce world\xe2\x80\x99s first Wi-Fi 6 consumer productThe Gulf Times reports that Qatar\xe2\x80\x99s Ooredoo is \xe2\x80\x98planning to introduce\xe2\x80\x99 the Netgear Nighthawk AX12 Wi-Fi router to its customers as part of its fibre-based broadband offering. The announcement comes even before Netgear themselves have made any statement about their new Wi-Fi 6 product. With the launch, Ooredoo would become the first EMEA-region operator to deploy a Wi-Fi 6 solution.The Netgear AX12 is also the first consumer-grade Wi-Fi 6 product that we know of.\xe2\x80\x9cNighthawk AX12 offers Gigabit Internet up to 6 Gbps Wi-Fi speeds and WPA3, the latest Wi-Fi security standard designed for enhanced security in public and private networks. An ultra-fast 2.2GHz quad-core processor ensures speed and performance for more Wi-Fi devices and high-speed applications,\xe2\x80\x9d the news report says.The photo of the Nighthawk AX12 rendered here to the left (courtesy Gulf Times) is the first photo we have seen of such a device. Reputable sources tell us that the new Netgear 12-stream device is powered by Qualcomm chips. Qualcomm is right now one of two chipset companies that we know of offering a 12-stream solution (the second company is\xc2\xa0Quantenna). The 12 streams are a consequence of 8 streams of 5 GHz plus four 2.4 GHz streams.Note: The above has been corrected since first published to reflect that both Qualcomm and Quantenna currently offer 12-stream Wi-Fi 6 chipset solutions. We apologise for previous inaccuracies.\xc2\xa0Qualcomm launches 10+ Gbps mmWave Wi-FiQualcomm is arguably the early front runner in the race to commercialise Wi-Fi 6 but the company is also not pulling any punches in getting to market first with new unlicensed millimetre wave gear. Last week Qualcomm launched its bid to dominate the 60 GHz chipset market with a family of products supporting the 802.11ay standard.The 802.11ay standard is essentially a souped-up (meaning bandwidth aggregated) and hence extremely fast version of 802.11ad-based 60 GHz Wi-Fi. The AY chips \xe2\x80\x93 now available for both infrastructure and mobile devices \xe2\x80\x93 bond several 60 GHz channels together to deliver speeds of more than 10 Gbps Wi-Fi, \xe2\x80\x9cextending Wi-Fi experiences to the 5G era,\xe2\x80\x9d the company says.As examples of how 60 GHz Wi-Fi is being used today, Qualcomm cites\xc2\xa0Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Terragraph and smartphone vendor Asus, who launched the world\xe2\x80\x99s first 60 GHz capable device last year. Only a small handful of consumer-grade routers support the 802.11ad standard as of today.Qualcomm\xe2\x80\x99s launch also kind of begs the question as to what naming conventions may eventually be adopted for 802.11ad and 802.11ay products now that the Wi-Fi Alliance has announced new names for generations of 802.11-based products, most notably Wi-Fi 6. Qualcomm for the time being seems to have settled for \xe2\x80\x9960 GHz Wi-Fi\xe2\x80\x99 as at least the interim name for what used to be called WiGig.LinkNYC tops 5 million usersThe world\xe2\x80\x99s undisputed flagship City Wi-Fi project \xe2\x80\x93 LinkNYC of New York City \xe2\x80\x93 last month announced new user and network numbers. We kind of missed that but here they are for reference now: LinkNYC now tops 5 million users and some 20 million Wi-Fi sessions per week. The company also says more than 1700 kiosk units have been installed across the Big Apple.LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s younger sister-project in the UK is called InLinkUK and is operated by BT. InLinkUK last week was shortlisted for a Wi-Fi NOW 2018 Affordable Connectivity award./Claus.\nWi-Fi Industry NewsJune 20, 2019 [Regulation & Policy]Europe\xe2\x80\x99s process to release 6 GHz spectrum to Wi-Fi on track, expert saysJune 18, 2019 [Breaking News]Emergency \xe2\x80\x98Ducklink\xe2\x80\x99 Wi-Fi to save lives during disastersJune 17, 2019 [Breaking News]Facebook takes on
