Worth supporting. Subscribe today for $1.00\nA traveler uses a power, Wi-Fi and information kiosk while visiting the Big Apple. (LinkNYC Kiosk photo courtesy of CityBridge)\nSavvy ways to stay charged on the road\nTravel\nBy\nMyscha Theriault, Tribune News Service\nJuggling appointments, project deadlines and video conferencing from the road with a constant ticking clock on battery power is problematic to say the least. Factor in a GPS misfire, a flat tire or even an unexpectedly long meeting, and the situation is amplified significantly. During the past year, a few new options have floated across my radar for fighting this dilemma with as little frustration as possible. Following are my favorite strategies for keeping battery woes at bay.\nCombos: Carrying a separate battery backup and charging cable to keep your phone topped off can be a real drag when you are already running short of space in your gear bag. Finding a spot to plug in both devices along with your laptop at a crowded airport gate can be a frustrating feat as well. Recently, my husband and I discovered the existence of battery cases for our smartphones.\nSince the battery is located inside the protective case you place on your mobile anyway, you receive additional functionality out of an item you were already using. No extra storage space necessary. There\xe2\x80\x99s also no extra charging cord required since using the same attachment port you would normally use to charge your phone through your phone case charges both items at once. For less than $20 a pop, we ordered one for each of us and never looked back. We receive more than double the charge time and our equipment takes up as little space as possible. Ours are from a company called Accerzone, which makes cases to fit our particular phones, but prices are comparable for equivalent products to suit other models.\nSize: As with the cases mentioned above, the size of any piece of technical travel equipment is of specific concern. Bulky gear is always a bore, but portable battery rechargers can be exceptionally frustrating when it comes to finding luggage room. This is why my husband and I were so excited to find a miniature one by Nuon on the Batteries Plus website recently. Previously, we always switched between regular and rechargeable batteries whenever we transitioned between fast-paced travel to stationary periods where we slow down to work on more time-consuming projects. For 30 bucks, we now have a space-efficient option for recharging the batteries we use most often on the road for things such as specialized astronomy binoculars and red light headlamps.Another go-to piece of charging equipment for our household is a world power travel adapter by Targus. While the $20 price we paid was certainly right for our budget, what we really love most about it is the fact it all fits in a compact tube shape that\xe2\x80\x99s easy to pack. So many similar products can be enormous by comparison, and make working while abroad more frustrating than it needs to be, particularly on days when we need to change locations with all of our bags in tow. We\xe2\x80\x99ve been using this power adapter for several years now, and it continues to work seamlessly whenever we need it.\nInfrastructure: Any digital nomad who routinely uses fast food establishments and bookstore coffee shops to crank out some work between highway stops can attest to one highly inconvenient truth. Free Wi-Fi doesn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily mean free electrical access to go with it. For those living out of a carry-on bag with limited space, one multi-plug adapter and a single extension cord will only get you so far, particularly if you need to go for long stretches of time between traditional charging options. In addition to in-flight power ports and more charging stations showing up at airports these days, some interesting new options are starting to show up in major cities.\nLinkNYC, for example, offers power charging and internet access at free-to-use kiosks throughout the Big Apple. Visitors needing to charge their mobile device can do so via a USB port connected only to power for security purposes, while still accessing the internet via a touch screen and keypad for free calls and information searching as they wait to power up. Residents and tourists alike can utilize these free stations as they search out eateries, transportation, polling locations and more. The kiosks even have ports to plug in your headphones so you can have privacy for any calls you need to make while you await a full charge. These same types of kiosks are also available throughout the U.K. in England, Wales and Scotland. Similar devices are coming soon to both Philly and Newark, N.J.Making your life work from the road can be challenging, but not impossible. With a few precision product purchases, planned access to infrastructure and a commitment to pay attention to power-hogging background apps, you can remain as charged as necessary for most situations.\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94(Lifestyle and travel expert Myscha Theriault blends thrift and luxury to live well for less around the world. She has sold her home, all her furniture and most of her other belongings to travel the world full time with her husband. You can follow her adventures on Instagram via @MyschaTheriault.)\nSupport real journalism. Support local journalism. Subscribe to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution today.\nSee offers.\nYour subscription to the Atlanta Journal-Constitution funds in-depth reporting and investigations that keep you informed. City and Puerto Rico to promotion tourism between the two.Post to FacebookLin-Manuel Miranda announces partnership between NYC and Puerto Rico\nFilm and theater star Lin-Manuel Miranda announced a partnership between New York City and Puerto Rico to promotion tourism between the two.\nCheck out this story on floridatoday.com: https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/2018/10/23/lin-manuel-miranda-new-york-and-puerto-rico-team-up-promote-travel/1740849002/CancelSendSent!A link has been sent to your friend\'s email Join the ConversationTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQsComments\nThis conversation is moderated according to USA TODAY\'s\ncommunity rules.\nPlease read the rules before joining the discussion.\nLin-Manuel Miranda announces partnership between NYC and Puerto RicoNancy Trejos, USA TODAY\nPublished 4:15 p.m. ET Oct. 23, 2018 | Updated 8:51 a.m. ET Oct. 24, 2018CLOSENYC & Company, New York City\'s official destination marketing organization, and Discover Puerto Rico have partnered in a campaign to promote tourism between the two destinations. These new ads will appear on bus stop shelters and LinkNYC screens across New York City.(Photo: USA TODAY/ Nancy Trejos)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREThe tourism marketing organizations for New York City and Puerto Rico have announced a first-ever partnership to encourage travel between the two destinations.NYC & Company and Discover Puerto Rico signed the official alliance at an event hosted by award-winning film and theater star Lin-Manuel Miranda at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan on Tuesday. Miranda\xe2\x80\x99s Broadway hit "Hamilton"\xc2\xa0will have a limited engagement in Puerto Rico in January, with Miranda reprising his role as Alexander Hamilton.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m here to tell you that Puerto Rico is waiting for you,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0said Miranda, whose parents were born in Puerto Rico. \xe2\x80\x9cThey need your money, they need your visits, they need your support. They need as many voices as possible.\xe2\x80\x9dHurricane Maria one year later: Puerto Rico is \'eager to welcome visitors\'The two organizations will swap marketing and advertising assets, valued at $300,800. Starting Nov. 19 for three months, New York City advertisements will be featured on select billboards throughout San Juan, the capital of the U.S. territory.Puerto Rico ads will appear on bus stop shelters across New York City\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs from Nov. 19 to Jan. 13. They will also be displayed on LinkNYC screens, a communications network offering free public Wi-Fi, phone calls, device charging and a tablet to access city information that is replacing more than 7,500 pay phones.The ads will include a new tagline: \xe2\x80\x9cFamous Original, New York City. Always here for you.\xe2\x80\x9d The tagline will also appear in Spanish.\xe2\x80\x9cThis messaging is intended to remind Puerto Ricans that New York City will always welcome them,\xe2\x80\x9d says Charles Flateman, vice chairman of the NYC & Company Board of Directors. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re here to help Puerto Rico any way we can to position themselves as a must visit now destination and showcase their open for business messaging.\xe2\x80\x9dThe partnership comes just over a year after Hurricane Maria pummeled the island, causing at least $100 billion in damage. Recovery has been slow, with electricity being restored to the entire island on Aug. 14. The government of Puerto Rico has declared the official loss of life to have reached 2,975 people.The tourism industry has been bouncing back over the past year. There are now about 26 flights between the New York City area and Puerto Rico daily.\xe2\x80\x9cThis comes at a particularly important time when we can use the transformative power of travel to lift the prosperity of the island to accelerate the economic recovery,\xe2\x80\x9d says Brad Dean, CEO of the recently created Discover Puerto Rico. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are eager to welcome visitors to the island. We hope New Yorkers will take the opportunity to contribute to the acceleration of the economic development.\xe2\x80\x9d \xc2\xa0Lin-Manuel Miranda launches multimillion-dollar arts fund for Puerto RicoMiranda has been actively lobbying for hurricane recovery efforts. Over the summer, he partnered with the nonprofit Flamboyant Foundation to create a multi-million dollar fund to boost the arts."Hamilton," the Broadway hit he wrote, will head to Puerto Rico from Jan. 8 to 27 at Teatro UPR on the University of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s main campus in San Juan. All proceeds from the engagement will go to the arts fund.\xe2\x80\x9cThis relationship between New York and Puerto Rico is not just a campaign,\xe2\x80\x9d Miranda says. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a life-long, generations-long thing and it is so wonderful to ratify it and declare that Puerto Rico is open for business.\xe2\x80\x9dMiranda recalled regularly visiting his grandparents in Vega Alta, on the northern coast of the island.\xe2\x80\x9cTo have that connection be a tangible thing, there\xe2\x80\x99s no price you can put on that,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing is better for your soul than to visit Puerto Rico.\xe2\x80\x9dFacebookTwitterGoogle+LinkedInPuerto Rico one year after Hurricane Maria: Before and after photos\xc2\xa0FullscreenPost to FacebookPosted!A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. All Rights Reserved.\nWeather Alert\n1 Weather Alert\nPhoto by: USA TODAY/ Nancy Trejos\nNYC & Company, New York City\'s official destination marketing organization, and Discover Puerto Rico have partnered in a campaign to promote tourism between the two destinations. These new ads will appear on bus stop shelters and LinkNYC screens across New York City.\nNATION-NOW\nLin-Manuel Miranda announces partnership between NYC and Puerto Rico\nNYC and Puerto Rico team up to promote tourism\nAuthor:\nNancy Trejos, USA TODAY\nPublished:\n12:07 PM MDT October 23, 2018\nUpdated:\n6:51 AM MDT October 24, 2018\nThe tourism marketing organizations for New York City and Puerto Rico have announced a first-ever partnership to encourage travel between the two destinations.NYC & Company and Discover Puerto Rico signed the official alliance at an event hosted by award-winning film and theater star Lin-Manuel Miranda at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan on Tuesday. Miranda\xe2\x80\x99s Broadway hit "Hamilton"\xc2\xa0will have a limited engagement in Puerto Rico in January, with Miranda reprising his role as Alexander Hamilton.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m here to tell you that Puerto Rico is waiting for you,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0said Miranda, whose parents were born in Puerto Rico. \xe2\x80\x9cThey need your money, they need your visits, they need your support. They need as many voices as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOne year after Hurricane Maria, Puerto Rico wants tourists back\nThe two organizations will swap marketing and advertising assets, valued at $300,800. Starting Nov. 19 for three months, New York City advertisements will be featured on select billboards throughout San Juan, the capital of the U.S. territory.Puerto Rico ads will appear on bus stop shelters across New York City\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs from Nov. 19 to Jan. 13. They will also be displayed on LinkNYC screens, a communications network offering free public Wi-Fi, phone calls, device charging and a tablet to access city information that is replacing more than 7,500 pay phones.The ads will include a new tagline: \xe2\x80\x9cFamous Original, New York City. Always here for you.\xe2\x80\x9d The tagline will also appear in Spanish.\xe2\x80\x9cThis messaging is intended to remind Puerto Ricans that New York City will always welcome them,\xe2\x80\x9d says Charles Flateman, vice chairman of the NYC & Company Board of Directors. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re here to help Puerto Rico any way we can to position themselves as a must visit now destination and showcase their open for business messaging.\xe2\x80\x9dThe partnership comes just over a year after Hurricane Maria pummeled the island, causing at least $100 billion in damage. Recovery has been slow, with electricity being restored to the entire island on Aug. 14. The government of Puerto Rico has declared the official loss of life to have reached 2,975 people.\nThe tourism industry has been bouncing back over the past year. There are now about 26 flights between the New York City area and Puerto Rico daily.\xe2\x80\x9cThis comes at a particularly important time when we can use the transformative power of travel to lift the prosperity of the island to accelerate the economic recovery,\xe2\x80\x9d says Brad Dean, CEO of the recently created Discover Puerto Rico. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are eager to welcome visitors to the island. We hope New Yorkers will take the opportunity to contribute to the acceleration of the economic development.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLin-Manuel Miranda starts Puerto Rico arts fund\nMiranda has been actively lobbying for hurricane recovery efforts. Over the summer, he partnered with the nonprofit Flamboyant Foundation to create a multi-million dollar fund to boost the arts."Hamilton," the Broadway hit he wrote, will head to Puerto Rico from Jan. 8 to 27 at Teatro UPR on the University of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s main campus in San Juan. All proceeds from the engagement will go to the arts fund.\xe2\x80\x9cThis relationship between New York and Puerto Rico is not just a campaign,\xe2\x80\x9d Miranda says. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a life-long, generations-long thing and it is so wonderful to ratify it and declare that Puerto Rico is open for business.\xe2\x80\x9dMiranda recalled regularly visiting his grandparents in Vega Alta, on the northern coast of the island.\xe2\x80\x9cTo have that connection be a tangible thing, there\xe2\x80\x99s no price you can put on that,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing is better for your soul than to visit Puerto Rico.\xe2\x80\x9d\nPuerto Rico one year after Hurricane Maria: Before and after photos\nThis is Old San Juan after Hurricane Maria. The area recovered quickly, unlike other parts of the island.\nThis was Old San Juan right after Hurricane Maria made landfall.\nSanturce is the most populated district in San Juan, the capital of Puerto Rico. This is Santurce now.\nThis is Santurce right after Hurricane Maria. Santurce is the most populated district in San Juan, known for its restaurants and nightlife.\nThis is Bahia de San Juan rebuilt after Hurricane Maria.\nThis is Bahia de San Juan destroyed after Hurricane Maria.\nThis is Humacao Restaurant, now recovered from the flooding caused by Hurricane Maria last year.\nThis is Humacao Restaurant flooded by Hurricane Maria.\n01\n/\n08\nThis is Old San Juan after Hurricane Maria. The area recovered quickly, unlike other parts of the island.\n02\n/\n08\nThis was Old San Juan right after Hurricane Maria made landfall.\n03\n/\n08\nSanturce is the most populated district in San Juan, the capital of Puerto Rico. This is Santurce now.\n04\n/\n08\nThis is Santurce right after Hurricane Maria. Santurce is the most populated district in San Juan, known for its restaurants and nightlife.\n05\n/\n08\nThis is Bahia de San Juan rebuilt after Hurricane Maria.\n06\n/\n08\nThis is Bahia de San Juan destroyed after Hurricane Maria.\n07\n/\n08\nThis is Humacao Restaurant, now recovered from the flooding caused by Hurricane Maria last year.\n08\n/\n08\nThis is Humacao Restaurant flooded by Hurricane Maria.\nJobs\nTerms of Service\nPrivacy Notice\nYour California Privacy Notice\nAd Choices\nEEO Public File Report\nFCC Online Public Inspection File\nClosed Caption Procedures\n\xc2\xa9 2019 KTVB-TV. All Rights Reserved.', b'Lin-Manuel Miranda announces New York City, Puerto Rico tourism partnership | abc7ny.com\nBREAKING NEWSAt least 8 hurt when SUV jumps curb, overturns in the BronxFull StoryBREAKING NEWSVOTE | Field Forecast: Who will hit more home runs this season - Pete Alonso or Gary Sanchez?Full StoryBREAKING NEWSEx-classmate gets life in prison for Sarah Stern murderFull StoryBREAKING NEWSYouTube star missing, fans concerned after recent videoFull StoryWATCH LIVENew York CityNew JerseyLong IslandNorthern SuburbsConnecticutEDITLog InWatchPhotosLocal News New York CityNew JerseyLong IslandNorthern SuburbsConnecticutCategories WeatherTrafficLocalish7 On Your Side7 On Your Side InvestigatesU.S. & WorldPoliticsSportsWeatherEntertainmentBackstage with Sandy KenyonNeighborhood EatsNeighborhood TreatsIn Our BackyardGlam LabStation Info About ABC 7Meet the News TeamABC 7 In Your CommunitySweepstakes and RulesTV ListingsJobsshows Live with Kelly and RyanABC 7 Shows & SpecialsLive Well NetworkFollow Us:Welcome, Your AccountLog OutShareTweetEmailTravelLin-Manuel Miranda unveils New York City, Puerto Rico tourism partnershipShare:ShareTweetEmailShare:ShareTweetEmailWABC NEW YORK CITY (WABC) -- NYC & Company and Discover Puerto Rico have announced a first-ever official partnership aimed at boosting tourism between New York City and Puerto Rico.New York City\'s official destination marketing organization and Puerto Rico\'s newly established destination marketing organization formalized the new one-year alliance at a press conference hosted by Lin-Manuel Miranda at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan Tuesday morning."This partnership is deeply personal for me as it formally bridges two of the most fundamental parts of my identity," Miranda said. "As a first generation New Yorker with parents from Puerto Rico and family on the island, I\'ve always felt a special connection not only to my life in upper Manhattan but with my roots and summers spent in Vega Alta, Puerto Rico. I do not exist without both or either. Today\'s public commitment and bond between these two places that I hold so dear could not be more meaningful."The alliance includes a collaboration agreement between Puerto Rico and New York City, the exchange of marketing assets to boost reciprocal travel, the sharing of best practices in tourism marketing, and continued support of Puerto Rico\'s successful recovery following Hurricane Maria.The city-to-island partnership includes a swap of marketing and advertising assets, valued at more than $300,000. New York City campaign advertisements will be featured on select billboards throughout San Juan, Puerto Rico, beginning November 19, 2018, for three months. Puerto Rico advertisements will appear on bus stop shelters and LinkNYC screens across New York City\'s five boroughs from November 19, 2018, through January 13, 2019.New York City has created a unique tagline for promotions in Puerto Rico, "Famous Original, New York City. Always here for you." or "Famous Original, New York City. \xc2\xa1Siempre aqu\xc3\xad para ti!" This messaging is intended to remind Puerto Ricans that New York City will always welcome them.Currently, there are approximately 26 flights between the New York City area and Puerto Rico daily. As part of the one-year agreement, New York City and Puerto Rico will share best practices in tourism marketing and management to increase visitation in the year ahead.----------* More New York City news* Send us a news tip* Download the abc7NY app for breaking news alerts * Follow us on YouTube\nReport a correction or typo\nRelated topics:travelnew york citytraveltourismpuerto ricolin manuel mirandaShare:ShareTweetEmailCopyright \xc2\xa9 2019 WABC-TV. All Rights Reserved.', b'Hamilton Star On Hand as Puerto Rico, New York City Enter Tourism Partnership\nHome\nNews\nWeather\nEntertainment\nSports\nMoney\nMore >\nLifestyle\nHealth & Fitness\nFood & Drink\nTravel\nAutos\nVideo\nKids\ncauses\nlifestyle\nYou are using an older browser version. Please use a supported version for the best MSN experience.\nHamilton Star On Hand as Puerto Rico, New York City Enter Tourism Partnership\nTravelPulse\n10/23/2018\nJoe Pike\n\xc2\xa9 Travalliancemedia Owned Media (Staff Photo)\nHamilton star Lin-Manuel Miranda speaks during a press conference to announce a new tourism-related partnership between New York City and Puerto Rico. (Photo by Joe Pike)\n"Hamilton: An American Musical" star Lin-Manuel Miranda was the host for a press conference Tuesday to announce a new partnership between destination marketing organizations in New York City and Puerto Rico.And TravelPulse was in the room where it happened.\xe2\x80\x9c[Puerto Rico needs] your money, your visit, your support,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miranda at the event held at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing is better for your soul than visiting Puerto Rico.\xe2\x80\x9dNYC & Company signed a first-ever partnership with Discover Puerto Rico to boost tourism between the two destinations. The new, one-year alliance includes a collaboration agreement between Puerto Rico and New York City, the exchange of marketing assets to boost reciprocal travel, the sharing of best practices in tourism marketing and continued support of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s successful recovery following Hurricane Maria.Brad Dean, CEO of Discover Puerto Rico, said since both New York City and Puerto Rico have gone through \xe2\x80\x9cunimaginable\xe2\x80\x9d events in the past, an apparent reference to the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, the partnership just made sense.\xe2\x80\x9cWe are showing the bond of resilience,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dean. \xe2\x80\x9cNew York understands what it is like to go through something unimaginable. Both destinations have gone through unimaginable circumstances and came out bright and ready to shine.\xe2\x80\x9dSo, what is the connection to the Tony Award winner?Miranda, whose parents are from Puerto Rico, will reprise his role as Alexander Hamilton for a three-week run of the Broadway smash hit play in Puerto Rico. "Hamilton: An American Musical" will run in Puerto Rico from January 8 - 27 at Teatro UPR, located at the heart of the University of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s main campus in San Juan.\xe2\x80\x9cHamilton will be great, but that will be for three weeks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miranda. \xe2\x80\x9cThe relationship between Puerto Rico and New York will be a much longer relationship.\xe2\x80\x9dNew York City campaign advertisements will be featured on select billboards throughout San Juan for three months, beginning November 19. Puerto Rico advertisements will appear at bus stops and LinkNYC screens across New York City\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs from Nov. 19 to January 13.\xe2\x80\x9cPuerto Rico and New York City have so much in common," said Charles Flateman, board vice chairman of NYC & Company. "Both destinations are rich in design, cuisine and so much more. We wanted to stand together to promote tourism for some time and what better time than today? Puerto Rico is open for business and ready to welcome all.\xe2\x80\x9dThe city-island partnership includes a swap of marketing and advertising assets, valued at roughly $300,800.Flateman said the official tagline for the partnership is, \xe2\x80\x9cFamous Original, New York City. Always Here for you,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cFamous Original, New York City. Siempre Aqui para ti!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x9cThis story does not end with Maria," said Dean.\nGo to MSN Home\nAdChoices\nAdChoices\nMore from TravelPulse\nNYC & Company Announces New Outpost in Singapore\nTravelPulse\nRegistration Open for IGLTA 2019 Convention in NYC\nTravelPulse\nPuerto Rico: One Year After Maria\nTravelPulse\nTravelPulse\nVisit the Full Site\nHome\nNews\nWeather\nEntertainment\nSports\nMoney\nLifestyle\nHealth & Fitness\nFood & Drink\nTravel\nAutos\nVideo\nKids\ncauses\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Microsoft\nPrivacy & Cookies\nTerms of use\nAbout our Ads\nFeedback\nHelp\nMSN Worldwide\nNewsletter\nMSN Blog\nAbout Us', b"Lin-Manuel Miranda Touts Tourist Partnership Between NYC, Puerto Rico | WCBS Newsradio 880\nSkip to main content\nListen\nMusic\nnews\nsports\nGet Our Newsletter\nFOLLOW US\nMenu\nClose\nOn Air\nAudio\nNews\nTraffic\nWeather\nContests\nSearch our Website\nShowsPat Farnack\nSteve Scott and Michael Wallace\nThe CBS Evening News\nWayne Cabot and Paul Murnane\nComplete Schedule\nOn DemandAudio on Demand\nPodcasts\nVideo\nNewsLocal\nNational\nPolitics\nWorld\nBusiness\nHealth\nEntertainment\n1 Thing Sustainability\nNew York Mets\nWeather\nTraffic\nSmall Business Spotlight\nSweet Spot\nStories From Main Street\nContestsContest Rules\nContests\nGalleries\nListen\nLiveOn DemandPodcastsONLINE STREAMNever miss a story or breaking news alert! Advertising at bus stop shelters and LinkNYC screens across the five boroughs begins Nov. 19 and will run through mid-January.Charles Flateman, of the city\xe2\x80\x99s tourism organization NYC and Company, wants to help send a message to residents of the city.\xe2\x80\x9cWe want all New Yorkers to know that Puerto Rico is open for business and ready to welcome us all,\xe2\x80\x9d Flateman said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey need your money. They need your visit. They need your support.\xe2\x80\x9dNew York City tourism ads will also be displayed in San Juan.You only have 6 more days to enter our #Ham4PR Prizeo contest for a chance to win a trip to attend the opening night of @HamiltonMusical in Puerto Rico! Find out more details and enter by Sunday, Oct 28: https://t.co/ZU5eCU2n8X pic.twitter.com/klhWGQObkG\xe2\x80\x94 Hamilton (@HamiltonMusical) October 23, 2018 Miranda says he hopes the campaign will raise money for arts organizations in Puerto Rico and reinforce the long-lasting relationship between the two locations, which are more than 1,500 miles apart.\xe2\x80\x9cThis relationship between New York and Puerto Rico is not just a campaign. It is a lifelong, generations-long thing. And it is so wonderful to ratify that,\xe2\x80\x9d Miranda said.Miranda, who created the wildly popular musical \xe2\x80\x9cHamilton,\xe2\x80\x9d is also hoping to attract visitors to Puerto Rico by retaking the lead role in the show next year. He\xe2\x80\x99ll star in it for three weeks in January.\nTags:\nLin-Manuel Miranda\nPuerto Rico\nNew York City\nHamilton\nBroadway\nAll Local\nFOLLOW US\nPhone: 877-987-WCBS\nWhen texting this station, message & data rates apply. All rights reserved.", b'Nueva York y Puerto Rico se promover\xc3\xa1n mutuamente como destinos tur\xc3\xadsticos - Hoy\nNueva York y Puerto Rico se promover\xc3\xa1n mutuamente como destinos tur\xc3\xadsticos\nFotograf\xc3\xada sin fecha cedida por Discover Puerto Rico donde aparece el detalle de un edificio en el Viejo San Juan (Puerto Rico). EFE/Discover Puerto Rico/SOLO USO EDITORIAL/NO VENTAS\nFotograf\xc3\xada sin fecha cedida por Discover Puerto Rico donde aparece el detalle de un edificio en el Viejo San Juan (Puerto Rico). EFE/Discover Puerto Rico/SOLO USO EDITORIAL/NO VENTAS\nEFE\nLa ciudad de Nueva York y\nPuerto Rico\nfirmaron hoy un acuerdo de cooperaci\xc3\xb3n para impulsar el turismo entre ambas partes, que beneficiar\xc3\xa1 a la isla caribe\xc3\xb1a en su recuperaci\xc3\xb3n, a un a\xc3\xb1o del destructor paso del hurac\xc3\xa1n Mar\xc3\xada.La "NYC & Company", la organizaci\xc3\xb3n oficial de promoci\xc3\xb3n de turismo de Nueva York, y "Discover Puerto Rico", la reci\xc3\xa9n establecida organizaci\xc3\xb3n de negocio de destinos de esa isla, firmaron hoy el primer acuerdo de cooperaci\xc3\xb3n, en un evento en el Museo del Barrio. "Al tiempo que Puerto Rico contin\xc3\xbaa con su recuperaci\xc3\xb3n, NYC & Company, se complace en formar parte de este esfuerzo para impulsar la industria del turismo hacia la isla", se\xc3\xb1al\xc3\xb3 el vicepresidente y director de NYC & Company, Charles Flateman, de acuerdo con un comunicado."Ahora m\xc3\xa1s que nunca necesitamos apoyar y celebrar la isla, mientras creamos impacto econ\xc3\xb3mico", comunicando que la isla "est\xc3\xa1 abierta para los negocios y para los turistas", agreg\xc3\xb3.\nPor su parte, Brad Dean, director ejecutivo de "Discover Puerto Rico" destac\xc3\xb3 que la asociaci\xc3\xb3n con la compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xada de turismo de esta ciudad "no tiene precedentes y nos ayudar\xc3\xa1 a llevar nuestros esfuerzos de turismo estrat\xc3\xa9gico al siguiente nivel".Asegur\xc3\xb3 que la isla, que se recupera del azote del hurac\xc3\xa1n en septiembre del a\xc3\xb1o pasado, est\xc3\xa1 lista para hacer negocios "y ansiosa por compartir su rica y diversa cultura", festivales, eventos, atracciones y bellezas naturales con los visitantes.Como parte del acuerdo de cooperaci\xc3\xb3n, en Puerto Rico se realizar\xc3\xa1 una campa\xc3\xb1a de promoci\xc3\xb3n de Nueva York, cuyos destinos mostrar\xc3\xa1 durante tres meses en vallas publicitarias en San Juan, capital de la isla, desde el 19 de noviembre.Mientras que los anuncios de Puerto Rico aparecer\xc3\xa1n en las marquesinas de las paradas de autobuses de la ciudad y en las pantallas en los cinco condados de la red de comunicaciones LinkNYC que provee WiFi gratis a neoyorquinos, a partir tambi\xc3\xa9n del 19 de noviembre, cuando se conmemora el descubrimiento de la isla, y hasta el 13 de enero del 2019.Durante la conferencia de prensa en que se hizo el anuncio, que tuvo como anfitri\xc3\xb3n a la estrella de Broadway, creador del exitoso musical "Hamilton",\nLin-Manuel Miranda\n, de origen puertorrique\xc3\xb1o, se dio a conocer adem\xc3\xa1s que Nueva York se promover\xc3\xa1 en la isla con el eslogan "Famous Original, New York City. Always here for you." O "Famous Original, New York City. ?Siempre aqu\xc3\xad para ti!".La isla animar\xc3\xa1 por su parte a los neoyorquinos a visitarle con el mensaje de "estamos listos para celebrar", que estar\xc3\xa1 acompa\xc3\xb1ado de im\xc3\xa1genes de San Juan y otros destinos en Puerto Rico."Esta alianza que tiende puentes entre dos partes fundamentales de mi identidad, es profundamente personal para m\xc3\xad", afirm\xc3\xb3 Miranda, quien llevar\xc3\xa1 a la isla su famoso musical "Hamilton", que presentar\xc3\xa1 en el teatro de la Universidad de Puerto Rico, del 8 al 27 de enero.Miranda repetir\xc3\xa1 su papel como Alexander Hamilton \xc3\xbanicamente durante las tres semanas que duran las funciones exclusivas en Puerto Rico.\n"Como una primera generaci\xc3\xb3n de neoyorquinos con mis padres provenientes de Puerto Rico y familia en la isla, siempre he sentido una especial conexi\xc3\xb3n, no s\xc3\xb3lo con mi vida en el Alto Manhattan, sino tambi\xc3\xa9n con mis ra\xc3\xadces y los veranos" en la isla, record\xc3\xb3 para asegurar que "no podr\xc3\xada existir sin los dos o sin uno de los dos".\nCopyright\n\xc2\xa9 2019, Hoy Los Angeles, una publicaci\xc3\xb3n de Los Angeles Times Media Group\nLA TIMESHoy DigitalCuriosidadesEspect\xc3\xa1culosDeportesDatos y mapasJUEGOSAn\xc3\xbancieseAutos71\xc2\xb0', b'Puerto Rico, New York City partner for tourism support | Hotel Management\nSkip to main content\nLinkedIn\nFacebook\nTwitter\nSearch\nEnclose phrases in quotes. Use a + to require a term in results and - to\nexclude terms.Example: +water -Europe\nTop Menu\nMR&H\nLearn\nAttend an Event\nNewsletters\nSubscribe\nLatest Issue\nMain navigation\nOwn\nOperate\nTech\nDesign\nProcure\nHotel ROI\nMain navigation - Mobile\nOwn\nOperate\nTech\nDesign\nProcure\nHotel ROI\nOwn\nPuerto Rico, New York City partner for tourism support\nby Jena Tesse Fox |\nOct 23, 2018 4:23pm\nBrad Dean, Lin-Manuel Miranda and Charles Flateman at the ceremony. Photo credit: Julienne Schaer\nNEW YORK \xe2\x80\x93 A unique partnership was officially formed Oct. 23\xc2\xa0at New York City\'s Museo del Barrio, where NYC & Company, the city\xe2\x80\x99s official destination marketing organization, and Discover Puerto Rico, Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s newly established destination marketing organization, signed an agreement aimed at boosting tourism between The Big Apple and the island.\nThe announcement and signing was hosted by Tony- and Pulitzer Prize-winning artist Lin-Manuel Miranda, who has used his fame to draw attention to Puerto Rico\'s needs, and will be bringing his hit musical "Hamilton" to San Juan for a three-week run next year.\nThe\xc2\xa0one-year alliance, the first-ever city-to-island partnership, includes\xc2\xa0the exchange of marketing assets to boost reciprocal travel, the sharing of best practices in tourism marketing and continued support of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s successful recovery following Hurricane Maria. NYC & Company board of directors vice chairman Charles Flateman and Discover Puerto Rico CEO Brad Dean signed the agreement.\nFREE DAILY NEWSLETTER\nLike this story? Subscribe to IHIF!\nThe hospitality industry turns to IHIF International Hotel Investment News as the must-read source for investment and development coverage worldwide. Sign up today to get inside the deal with the latest transactions, openings, financing, and more delivered to your inbox and read on the go.\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs Puerto Rico continues its recovery, NYC & Company is pleased to do its part to further encourage visitation from New York City to Puerto Rico,\xe2\x80\x9d said Flateman. \xe2\x80\x9cNow more than ever, we need to support and celebrate the island while also creating economic impact for the destination.\xe2\x80\x9d Noting\xc2\xa0the two destinations share "so much" in common, Flatemen said\xc2\xa0NYC & Company is "determined" to stand together with Puerto Rico to promote tourism.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur partnership with NYC & Company is unprecedented and will help take our strategic tourism efforts to the next level,\xe2\x80\x9d said\xc2\xa0Dean. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are working aggressively to elevate Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s brand and make it visible to the world as a premier travel destination. Puerto Rico is open for business and eager to share its rich and diverse culture with visitors.\xe2\x80\x9d\nDean said New York City and Puerto Rico "share a bond of resiliency" in the wake of "unimaginable circumstances." For example, Puerto Rico has 132 hotels open now and four historic hotels are scheduled to reopen in the coming months,\xc2\xa0he added. Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s hotel sector, particularly near the airport and San Juan, has fared better than expected by some estimations, and according to Steve Smith, managing director, CBRE Hotels, it remains an active process.\nPartnership Details\nAs part of the one-year agreement, New York City and Puerto Rico will share best practices in tourism marketing and management to increase visitation in the year ahead. The city-to-island partnership includes a swap of marketing and advertising assets, valued at $300,800. New York City campaign advertisements will be featured on select billboards throughout San Juan beginning Nov. 19, for three months. Puerto Rico advertisements will appear on bus stop shelters and LinkNYC screens across NYC\'s five boroughs from Nov.\xc2\xa019 through Jan.\xc2\xa013.\nThe campaign will encourage Puerto Ricans to visit Gotham with the tagline \xe2\x80\x9cFamous Original, New York City. Always here for you,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cFamous Original, New York City. \xc2\xa1Siempre aqu\xc3\xad para ti!\xe2\x80\x9d New York City is promoting visits for the upcoming holiday season and into next year as NYC & Company\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c2019: A Monumental Year\xe2\x80\x9d messaging unfolds.\nPuerto Rico, in turn, is encouraging New Yorkers to visit the island for the holiday season, promoting the traditional Three Kings\'\xc2\xa0Day celebration and the San Sebastian street festival. The new campaign features images from San Juan and other areas.\nMiranda called the partnership \xe2\x80\x9cdeeply personal\xe2\x80\x9d as it bridges his family\'s homeland and his own hometown. \xe2\x80\x9cAs a first-generation New Yorker with parents from Puerto Rico and family on the island, I\xe2\x80\x99ve always felt a special connection not only to my life in upper Manhattan but with my roots and summers spent in Vega Alta, Puerto Rico,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. He noted during the ceremony that his personal Discover Puerto Rico campaign began in childhood when his parents sent him from New York City to spend a month with his grandparents. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not exist without both or either. Today\xe2\x80\x99s public commitment and bond between these two places that I hold so dear could not be more meaningful.\xe2\x80\x9d The Caribbean island, he added, needs "as many voices as possible" in order to rebuild.\nThe Puerto Rico engagement of Hamilton will run Jan. 8 to 27\xc2\xa0at Teatro UPR, on the University of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s main campus in San Juan. Miranda will reprise his role as Alexander Hamilton exclusively for the\xc2\xa0engagement.\nWhile the musical will run for three weeks and the advertisements will be seen around San Juan and New York City for three months, Miranda added\xc2\xa0the connection between the two destinations is meant to last for generations.\nRead more on\nMarketing Promotions Tourism Puerto Rico New York City\nSuggested Articles\nTech AVIXA expands commitment to hospitality with HM, Questex Following Hotel Management\'s first-ever\xc2\xa0hotel track at InfoComm 2019, the AV association\xc2\xa0is partnering again with Questex Hospitality Group. by Stefani C. O\'Connor Jun 21, 2019 12:55pm\nDevelopment Four Seasons under construction in Nashville Co-owners The Congress Group and AECOM Capital will develop the Four Seasons Hotel and Private Residences Nashville. by Chuck Dobrosielski Jun 21, 2019 10:30am\nFinancing Advantage Hotels CEO talks Vista, Select Inn buy\nThe newly formed Advantage Hotels has acquired Advantis Hospitality Alliance\xe2\x80\x99s midscale and economy brands Vista and Select Inn. by Chuck Dobrosielski Jun 21, 2019 9:40am\nAbout the Author\nJena Tesse Fox\nAssociate Editor\n[email\xc2\xa0protected]\nhttps://twitter.com/jenafox\nhttps://www.linkedin.com/in/jenatessefox\nhttps://www.instagram.com/jenatesse/\nGENERAL\nHome\nPrivacy\nTerms of Use\nRSS\nCONTACT\nAdvertise\nAbout Us\nNEWSLETTERS\nNewsletters\nPrint/Digital\nConnect\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Questex LLC. Know it all.\nMeeting News\nHome / News / Destinations\nEast\nDiscover Puerto Rico and NYC & Company Launch City-to-Island Partnership\nThe effort, announced by Lin-Manuel Miranda, includes exchange of marketing assets valued at more than $300,000\nshare\nshare\nby Alex Palmer |\nOctober 23, 2018\nWhile New Yorkers have long been visiting Puerto Rico and vice versa, for the first time there is now a formal marketing effort to boost tourism between the two destinations. Announced by the destinations\' official marketing organizations, Discover Puerto Rico\xc2\xa0and NYC & Company, at an event hosted by Broadway star Lin-Manuel Miranda, the City-to-Island Partnership will urge travel between both U.S. destinations over the holiday season and beyond.\n"Puerto Rico and New York City share so much in common," said Charles Flateman, board vice chairman of NYC & Company, during the event, which was held in Manhattan\'s El Museo del Barrio. "Both are tourism destinations rich in design, in cuisine, culture, innovation and so much more -- and clearly there is a long and special affinity between these two destinations."\nThe partnership will include an exchange of marketing and advertising assets valued at more than $300,000 over a three-month period, beginning Nov. 19, 2018. Select billboards will be placed throughout San Juan, Puerto Rico, with the tagline "Famous Original, New York City. Always here for you," in English and Spanish, while Puerto Rico will promote its offerings on bus stop shelters and LinkNYC screens throughout New York City\'s five boroughs with the tagline "We\'re Ready to Celebrate."\nThe partnership, aimed at meetings and business events as well as individual leisure travelers, is rolling out as Discover Puerto Rico emphasizes that the destination has significantly recovered from the devastation of last year\'s hurricane season. Discover Puerto Rico CEO Brad Dean said they were, "not just simply open for business, but we are eager to welcome visitors back to the island" and that "we hope New Yorkers will take this opportunity to help accelerate the economic recovery.\nThe campaign is rolling out in time for the holiday season in both destinations, whether the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree in New York or the Three Kings Day in Puerto Rico. But Dean emphasized that in addition to the 132 hotels and many other offerings already available to visitors, this winter will see the opening of four more historic properties: Caribe Hilton; El San Juan Hotel, Curio Collection;\xc2\xa0Dorado Beach, a Ritz-Carlton Reserve; and the St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort. It will also see the Puerto Rico engagement of the Broadway smash Hamilton, running Jan. 8-27, 2019, in which Miranda will reprise his role as Alexander Hamilton for a three-week run at the University of Puerto Rico\'s main campus in San Juan.\n"Nothing is better for your soul than to go visit Puerto Rico," said Miranda, in his remarks emphasizing his own personal connection to the island, going there every summer to visit his grandparents and having his grandparents come to Yankee games in New York City. "This relationship between New York and Puerto Rico is not just a decade. It is a lifelong, generations-long thing and it is so wonderful to ratify that and declare Puerto Rico is open for business."\nPlease enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.\ncomments powered by Disqus\nNewsletters\nMeeting News\nHow-To\nTop 10 Newsletter\nTech Insider\nMeeting Deals\nSign Up for More ENLs\nMost Popular\nmost read\nHow to Win Employees Over When You\'re a New Leader\nHow to Start Your Day Off on the Right Foot\n5 Ways to Incorporate Wellness Into Corporate Events\nHow to Stay Hydrated So You Sleep Better\nHow to Make Your R\xc3\xa9sum\xc3\xa9 Feel Current\nHow to Respond When an Employee Tenders His/Her Resignation\nsmall meetings cvbs dmos destinations webcast\nWellness Tips Corporate Events Washington Duke Inn\nTop Women Speakers Motivation Inspiration\nCreative Ways Incorporate Golf Meetings\naustin-texas-meetings-group-activities\nTips Creating Perfect Lighting Look Meetings Events\nsponsored video\nVegas Is The Place To Meet\nVegas is equipped with meeting spaces alongside top-notch hospitality and amenities, all located within minutes of the airport.\nrelated\nDestinations\nSan Francisco Goes Big on MeetingsPark City\'s Stunning OfferingsLong Beach Keeps Meetings FreshHawaii\'s Island Meetings Attractions3 Days In\xe2\x80\xa6San AntonioCosta Rica\'s Rich Meetings OfferingsSouth Florida Woos MeetingsMichigan Meetings Update\nf\nl\ni\nHome\nStrategy\nNews\nResources\nEvents\nSupplied Content\nfind or a post a job\nHome\nStrategy\nNews\nResources\nEvents\nSupplied Content\nf\nl\ni\nAbout Us\nSubscribe\nNewsletter\nContact Us\nAdvertise With Us\nEditorial Calendar\nPrivacy\nTerms\nNorthstar Travel Media Sites\nTravelAge West\nTravel Weekly\ntravel42\nHotel & Travel Index\nOfficial Hotel Guide\nOfficial Cruise Guide\nThe Beat\nPhoCusWright\nStar Service Online\nBusiness Travel Planner\nIntelliguide\nIncentive\nMeetings & Conventions\nBusiness Travel News\nSports Travel\nCopyright \xc2\xa9 2019 by Northstar Travel Media LLC. Make sure you like us on Facebook for even more updates.\nMy sqft House Tours\nWhere I Work\nNYC Guides\nThe Urban Lens\nCelebrities\nArchitecture\nHistory\nSearch 6sqft\nToggle navigation\nMy sqft House Tours\nWhere I Work\nNYC Guides\nThe Urban Lens\nCelebrities\nArchitecture\nHistory\nVIEW PHOTO IN GALLERY\nCity Living, Policy\nLin-Manuel Miranda joins effort to encourage travel between NYC and Puerto Rico\nPosted On Wed, October 24, 2018\nBy Devin Gannon\nIn City Living, Policy\nVIEW PHOTO IN GALLERY\nPosted On Wed, October 24, 2018\nBy Devin Gannon\nIn City Living, Policy\nLa Perla in San Juan; photo courtesy of Discover Puerto Rico\nThe tourism agencies of New York City and Puerto Rico are teaming up to boost travel between the two places. At an\xc2\xa0event on Tuesday hosted by Lin-Manuel Miranda, NYC & Company and Discover Puerto Rico signed a one-year alliance to encourage \xe2\x80\x9creciprocal travel,\xe2\x80\x9d with a new advertising campaign and\xc2\xa0swapping of marketing tips. Miranda is also bringing his award-winning show \xe2\x80\x9cHamilton\xe2\x80\x9d to the island from January 8 to January 27 at the Univesity of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s San Juan campus. All proceeds from the engagement\xc2\xa0will go toward an art fund on the island\xc2\xa0founded by Miranda.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs a first generation New Yorker with parents from Puerto Rico and family on the island, I\xe2\x80\x99ve always felt a special connection not only to my life in upper Manhattan but with my roots and summers spent in Vega Alta, Puerto Rico,\xe2\x80\x9d Miranda said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not exist without both or either. Today\xe2\x80\x99s public commitment and bond between these two places that I hold so dear could not be more meaningful.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe dual campaign will cost $308,000 and run between November 19 and January 13. The promotion includes ads for the Big Apple on billboards in San Juan and ads promoting the island on bus stop shelters and Link NYC screens across the five boroughs.\nThe new tagline \xe2\x80\x9cFamous Original, New York City. Always here for you.,\xe2\x80\x9d which will also be written in Spanish, will be featured in the promotions. Through this message, the agency hopes to remind Puerto Ricans that they are always welcome to NYC.\nPuerto Rico\xc2\xa0will encourage New Yorkers to visit the island over the holidays, with a marketing campaign bosting \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re Ready to Celebrate,\xe2\x80\x9d which shows off their classic Three King\xe2\x80\x99s Day celebration and the San Sebastian street festival.\nThe partnership comes just over a year after Hurricane Maria, a\xc2\xa0damaging storm that took\xc2\xa0nearly 3,000 lives. New York City, which has the largest number of Puerto Rican residents in the mainland of the U.S, will soon be home to a permanent Hurricane Maria Memorial; Gov. Andrew Cuomo last month established a\xc2\xa0commission to provide recommendations on its site and design.\nCurrently, there are about 26 flights daily between the NYC area and Puerto Rico.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City and Puerto Rico share a diverse culture and vibrancy that cultivates a unique affinity between the two destinations, and there could not be a better time for us to align our efforts,\xe2\x80\x9d Fred Dixon, the president of NYC & Company, said.\nRELATED:\nCuomo will bring a Hurricane Maria Memorial to Battery Park City\nTo boost travel from Southeast Asia, NYC tourism agency opens new office in Singapore\nLatin in Manhattan: A look at early Hispanic New York\nTags :\nHurricane Maria, NYC & Company\nPrevious Post\nNext Post\nJoin the discussion when you sign in with one of the following methods:\nfacebook Sign In\nSign In\n[userpro template=login force_redirect_uri=1 login_button_secondary='' login_button_primary='Sign In Now' login_side='' login_heading='' ]\t\t\tForgot Password?\nDon't have an account? BrandVoice: 3 Ways To Future-Proof Your Business\nTech MD\nUnisys BrandVoice: Blueprint for 10 Billion: How Businesses Can Transform to Thrive In A More Populous World\nVanguard BrandVoice: The Future Of Work\nHamilton Star Lin-Manuel Miranda: Amazing Adventure Partners New York City And Puerto Rico\nLaura Manske\nContributor\nOpinions expressed by Forbes Contributors are their own.\nTravel\nFalling in love with travel every day.\nShare to facebook\nShare to twitter\nShare to linkedin\nFlag of Puerto Rico on the beach at Coney Island, Brooklyn, New York City. \xc2\xa9 Getty\nIt is both\xc2\xa0a brilliant love match\xc2\xa0and a business brainstorm. The partnership\xc2\xa0announced this week by Broadway genius\xc2\xa0Lin-Manuel Miranda of\xc2\xa0"Hamilton: An American Musical" is certainly worthy of standing ovation applause \xe2\x80\x94 as\xc2\xa0NYC & Company,\xc2\xa0the Big Apple\'s official destination marketing organization, and Discover Puerto Rico, the Island of Enchantment\'s newly\xc2\xa0founded destination marketing organization\xc2\xa0join hands and hearts to launch a campaign\xc2\xa0set to\xc2\xa0inspire travel\xc2\xa0between New York City and Puerto Rico.\xc2\xa0This smiles-across-the-miles alliance,\xc2\xa0heralded at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan, kicks off a one-year targeted collaboration between the two tourism hotspots, an especially cool support\xc2\xa0for Puerto Rico\'s continued successful recovery from the devastation of Hurricane Maria.\nTony Award-winner Lin-Manuel Miranda talking about his passion for New York City and Puerto Rico.\n\xc2\xa9 Julienne Schaer\nSays theater-and-film star Miranda:\xc2\xa0"This partnership is deeply personal for me as it formally bridges two of the most fundamental parts of my identity. As a first generation New Yorker with parents from Puerto Rico and family on the island, I\xe2\x80\x99ve always felt a special connection not only to my life in Upper Manhattan but with my roots and summers spent in Vega Alta, Puerto Rico. I do not exist without both or either. Today\xe2\x80\x99s public commitment and bond between these two places that I hold so dear could not be more meaningful."\nNew York City shines. \xc2\xa9 Getty\n"We are showing the bond of resilience," explains\xc2\xa0Brad Dean, CEO of Discover Puerto Rico. "New York understands what it is like to go through something unimaginable. Both destinations have gone through unimaginable circumstances and came out bright and ready to shine." Adds\xc2\xa0Charles Flateman, board vice chairman of NYC & Company and senior vice president of the Shubert Organization: "Now more than ever, we need to support and celebrate the island while also creating economic impact for the destination. We are honored to work alongside Discover Puerto Rico to communicate that it is open for business and welcoming travelers."\xc2\xa0Puerto Rico needs "your money, your visit, your support," continues Miranda. It "needs as many voices as possible. Nothing is better for your soul than visiting Puerto Rico."\nPuerto Rico sparkles. \xc2\xa9 Getty\nSharing marketing skills and resources, the city-to-island ad campaign, beginning November 19th and valued at $300,800, will\xc2\xa0pitch (in English and Spanish) on billboards throughout San Juan, Puerto Rico: "Famous Original, New York City. Always here for you."\xc2\xa0In New York City, ads on bus-stop shelters and Link NYC screens\xc2\xa0will encourage New Yorkers and its visitors to\xc2\xa0vacation in the Caribbean island, a\xc2\xa0USA Territory,\xc2\xa0this winter: "We\xe2\x80\x99re Ready to Celebrate." Images from Puerto Rico\xc2\xa0will spotlight the island\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0uplifting experiences: music, cuisine, nature, beauty, festivals.\xc2\xa0"New York City and Puerto Rico share a diverse culture and vibrancy that cultivates a unique affinity between the two destinations, and there could not be a better time for us to align our efforts," says\xc2\xa0Fred Dixon,\xc2\xa0NYC & Company president and CEO. This "is a remarkable representation of the unity between New York City and Puerto Rico, and we look forward to a productive year ahead."\nHistoric Castillo San Felipe del Morro in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico, with jet ski riders. \xc2\xa9Getty\nAdds\xc2\xa0Brad Dean: "We are working aggressively to elevate Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s brand and make it visible to the world as a premier travel destination.\xc2\xa0Puerto Rico is open for business, and eager to share its rich and diverse culture with visitors. Our entire island is brimming with festivals, events, attractions and natural beauty that are waiting to be discovered this holiday season. Puerto Rico is ready to celebrate." There are currently 26 daily flights between New York City and Puerto Rico.\nLin-Manuel Miranda appears at the curtain call following the opening night performance of "Hamilton" at the Richard Rodgers Theatre in New York City. \xc2\xa9 Charles Sykes/Invision/AP File\nThe Tony Award winner\xc2\xa0will reprise his role as Alexander Hamilton for a three-week run (January 8 - 27) at Teatro UPR on the University of Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s campus in San Juan.\nFor more travel ideas and tips: NYC & Company and Discover Puerto Rico.\nFollow me on\nTwitter\nor\nLinkedIn.\nLaura Manske\nContributor\nBased in NYC, Manske has been an on-staff editor at many top magazines, as well as a freelance journalist. She has been called a trend-spotter, culture connoisseur and i...\nRead More\nPrint\nSite Feedback\nTips\nCorrections\nReprints & Permissions\nTerms\nPrivacy\n\xc2\xa92019 Forbes Media LLC. All Rights Reserved.\nAdChoices', b"Newark, N.J., Installs Multipurpose Kiosks Loaded with Free Services\nimage/svg+xml\nCONTINUE TO SITE\nThis website uses cookies in order to offer you the most relevant information.\n\xc3\x97\nLearn More\nI Accept\nMAGAZINE\nNEWSLETTERS\nEVENTS\nPAPERS\nNAVIGATOR\nSECTIONS\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL EDUCATION\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL GOVERNMENT\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nDIGITAL STATES PERFORMANCE INSTITUTE\nTOP 25\nGOVTECH 100\nSEARCH\nCybersecurity\nGovTech Biz\nEmerging Tech\nCloud\nGov Experience\nMore\nNetwork\nNewark, N.J., Installs Multipurpose Kiosks Loaded with Free Services\nThe kiosks provide free international phone calls, as well as Wi-Fi connectivity, and can charge cellphones.\nby Skip Descant\n/\nOctober 25, 2018\nPedestrians in Newark, N.J., walk past a newly installed LinkNWK kiosk adjacent to Military Park and across the street from the Prudential Center in mid-October 2018.\nSkip Descant/Government Technology\nInternational phone calls are expensive. But in Newark, N.J., you can make them for free. All you need to do is walk over to one of the city's newly installed kiosks in neighborhoods across the city.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFree is pretty good,\xe2\x80\x9d quipped Martin O\xe2\x80\x99Malley, the former mayor of Baltimore and governor of Maryland, as he moderated a panel discussion in mid-October at the 2018 MetroLab Network Summit on the campus of the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) in Newark.\nThe project, known as LinkNWK (pronounced \xe2\x80\x9cLink Newark\xe2\x80\x9d), launched Oct. 16, 2018, and is a partnership between the city, the Newark Community Economic Development Corporation, NJIT and Intersection, a maker of kiosks and the supporting software technology. Intersection will install up to 45 of the kiosks all across the city in the coming weeks.\nRELATEDAurora, Ill., Eyes Downtown Smart KiosksAustin's Solar-Powered Kiosk Charges Phones, E-Bikes and Cars KC Kiosks Avoid LinkNYC's Porn Troubles, Rollout Going Smoothly\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNewark is incredible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mayor Ras J. Baraka, speaking during the mayoral panel at the Summit. \xe2\x80\x9cIt allows people to make phone calls anyplace in the world they want to. It allows people to charge their cellphone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Baraka, adding that the kiosks also provide city maps, information about local events and more. In addition, the kiosks act as free Wi-Fi hot spots around the city.\nThe kiosks on Newark streets join other similar units in New York, London and other cities in the United Kingdom. Intersection is set to launch LinkPHL in Philadelphia in the coming weeks.\nSome of the other information provided by the kiosks includes news and weather, information about cultural programs, opportunities for civic engagement, local photography and more.\nLike many smart city projects in Newark, they are supported by Newark Fiber, a program to bring affordable gigabit-speed Internet service to Newark. The network spans some 26 miles, said Baraka. \xe2\x80\x9cSome of it is being used, particularly in the downtown area and some of the parks,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cMillions of people in New York and London have enjoyed Link\xe2\x80\x99s free, super-fast Wi-Fi, useful information, and other free services,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jen Hensley, president of Link at Intersection, in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cNewark is a rising star in the tech economy, and we are proud that LinkNWK will only add to this momentum.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe kiosk services are free and are supported through advertising, similar to how kiosks are funded in other cities like Kansas City, Mo., or New York City.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs a company, we believe it\xe2\x80\x99s important to provide continual support to an area where so many of our customers and employees live, work and visit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mark Krolick, vice president of marketing at United Airlines, a sponsor of the LinkNWK project, in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cThese new kiosks are another example of connecting Newark with the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\nEditor's note: An earlier version of this story stated all 45 kiosks have been installed. The kiosks project is partially deployed, and more will come online in the coming weeks.\nSkip Descant\nStaff Writer\nSkip Descant writes about smart cities, the Internet of Things, transportation and other areas. He spent more than 12 years reporting for daily newspapers in Mississippi, Arkansas, Louisiana and California. He lives in downtown Sacramento.\nRELATED\nKiosks: Today\xe2\x80\x99s Elegant and Simple Smart City Program\nNewark, N.J., Names Former State CIO Emanuel as IT Chief\nSacramento, Verizon Push Pause on Kiosk Deal\nDISCUSS\nWe invite you to discuss and comment on this article using social media.\nMORE FROM Network\nThis collection of Government Technology\xe2\x80\x99s top networking stories shows how states and localities are implementing intelligent and connected technologies to improve the lives of their constituents and better their communities. NJ\nMaplewood, NJ\nWest Orange, NJ\nBloomfield, NJ\nBelleville-Nutley, NJ\nJersey City, NJ\nMillburn-Short Hills, NJ\nSpringfield, NJ\nCranford, NJ\nState Edition\nNew Jersey\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\npolitics & government\n\'I\'ll Have The Tacos\': Newark Mayor Launches Free Wi-Fi Kiosks\nVIDEO: They\'re sure to go down as the most famous tacos in the city\'s history. Welcome to the era of free wi-fi in Newark.\nBy Eric Kiefer, Patch Staff\nOct 26, 2018 7:00 am ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nNEWARK, NJ \xe2\x80\x94 With cameras rolling and flashes popping, Newark Mayor Ras Baraka leaned into the high-tech kiosk at Military Park, placing his phone call with a feigned casualness, as if he was ordering a pizza at home in his living room. "Hi, this is Mayor Baraka\xe2\x80\xa6 how y\'all doing today?" he asked the worker on the other end of the line. "I\'m trying to order something to pick up." After hearing the restaurant\'s menu, Baraka decided on an order of tacos. "I\'m going to send somebody to get \'em," he said. "I\'ll see y\'all in a minute." And with that symbolic order of food, Newark took a flying leap into a new era of technology. Last week, Baraka, city officials and several community leaders gathered in Military Park for the activation of Newark\'s first LinkNWK kiosks, which deliver free wi-fi, offer mobile device charging, make phone calls to anywhere in the U.S. and allow access to a plethora of municipal services, maps and directions. The kiosks \xe2\x80\x93 which are run by tech company Intersection \xe2\x80\x93 make use of Newark Fiber, the city\'s public-private gigabit data network. Eventually, Intersection will install 45 LinkNWK kiosks throughout the city\'s five wards, including: Newark Penn StationPrudential CenterBroad Street, Market Street, Martin Luther King Blvd. and Irvine Turner Blvd."Neighborhood corridors" such as Clinton Avenue, Ferry Street, South Orange Avenue and Bloomfield AvenueA collaboration between Intersection, the City of Newark, the Newark Community Economic Development Corporation (NCEDC) and New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT), the kiosks are expected to help Newark cement a rising reputation as a "cutting-edge, high-tech city," Baraka stated. See related article: Newark Is 1st In N.J. To Use High-Tech Kiosks"We are the only city in the entire state and the second in the nation to provide these services, and every person who uses one of these kiosks will not only gain the services they need, but learn something more important: Newark is a world-class urban leader," Baraka said. According to municipal officials, the kiosks operate at no cost to taxpayers or users. Instead, they\'ll be supported by advertising revenue, some of which will also help fund other "smart infrastructure" programs in the Brick City through contributions to the NCEDC. Initial advertisers on the kiosks include United Airlines, which operates a hub out of Newark Airport.\nDon\'t forget to visit the Patch Newark Facebook page here. Learn more about posting announcements or events to your local Patch site here. All Rights Reserved.\nSwipe for more from Patch \xc2\xbb\nFind out what\'s happening in Newark with free, real-time updates from Patch.\nSuccess! You\'re now signed up for local updates.\nDaily Newsletter The latest Newark news delivered to your inbox every morning.\nBreaking News Alerts Real-time updates on breaking stories in Newark.\nLet\'s go!\nNot in Newark?', b"Urban Brand Utility: Impact Branding for the Urbanising Century -\nSustainable Brands\nUrban Brand Utility: Impact Branding for the Urbanising Century\nNews & Views\nSB'19 Detroit Highlights\nLatest News\nAll Channels\nCorporate Member News\nAll Press Releases\nGlobal Events\nSB Insights\nParticipate\nAbout SB\nNews & Views\nGlobal Events\nSB Insights\nParticipate\nAbout SB\nSB'19 Detroit Highlights\nLatest News\nAll Channels\nCorporate Member News\nAll Press Releases\nMarketing and Comms\nUrban Brand Utility:Impact Branding for the Urbanising Century\nS\xc3\xa9rgio Brodsky\nPublished 7 months ago.\nAbout a 8 minute read.\nThe brand communications crisis is not an urban legend, albeit just as scary\nBetween 2001 and 2002, Brazil went through its largest energy crisis. The lack of infrastructure planning combined with economic growth forced the Government to ration the energy supply from its main urban centres, for intermittent periods of time. Back then, as a student living in S\xc3\xa3o Paulo, I remember streets darkening as the sun went down. In one of those evenings, walking back home from university, two men driving a motorcycle stopped right in front of me. One of them jumped off the bike and before I knew it, he hit me on the head with the back of his gun and stole my backpack.\nS\xc3\xa3o Paulo is one of the many existing (and emerging) megacities feeling its \xe2\x80\x98growing pains\xe2\x80\x99 due to an increased demand for ever more comfortable lifestyles. From a strategic standpoint, although cities only occupy 2 percent of the earth\xe2\x80\x99s landmass, they are where 75 percent of resource consumption and most brand communications are concentrated.\nMoreover, the global media and advertising footprint also comes with a hefty environmental toll. In the UK, for instance, advertising is responsible for two million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions annually, equivalent to heating 50 percent of London\xe2\x80\x99s social housing, according to CarbonTrack.\nMarkets, choice and competition are not just a consumers\xe2\x80\x99 best friend, but their political representation. Brands able to broaden their audiences from customers to citizens and their revenue model from sales to the creation of shared value will be the game-changers driving our industry forward. This is the type of thinking required to embrace Urban Brand Utility (UBU), an approach to brand communications I conceived and have been advocating for.\nWhat Urban Brand Utility should look (and be) like: Useful, profitable and impactful\nUBU is about using brands\xe2\x80\x99 touch points as more than mere messengers to supplementing public utility services and minimising carbon dioxide emissions.\nSuch logic can turn brand communications into a regenerative force for cities, where the promotion of goods and services is not only more profitable, but also environmentally enriching and socially virtuous.\nIn Moscow, for example, Sberbank was approached by major Russian real estate developers to collaborate on better infrastructure planning in residential areas. People\xe2\x80\x99s opinions on local needs fuelled targeted campaigns, promoting loans for small businesses. The \xe2\x80\x98Neighbourhoods\xe2\x80\x99 campaign generated nine times as many small business responses than traditional loan advertising.\nIn other words, people had their needs addressed as neighbourhoods became more attractive. The city increases tax collection from the new businesses being set up, which also reduces the cost related from having to deal with derelict areas. As the biggest Russian bank, caring about citizens is not just a nice thing to do but an effective way for Sberbank to positively impact its bottom line.\nCitizen-consumers are important players in enabling business to tackle the issues that matter most. As important as it is to reduce the number of clicks on a consumer journey, improving our life journeys will often result in superior returns.\nAware that potholes, cracks and bumps in the road can cause irreversible damage to people\xe2\x80\x99s pizzas during the drive home, Domino\xe2\x80\x99s decided to pave towns across the US (using its branding) and save their customers\xe2\x80\x99 pizzas from the bad roads. Obviously, not only Domino\xe2\x80\x99s customers benefited from this effort, but every single driver going through the few selected roads.\nThis may sound silly, but according to the National Surface Transportation Policy and Revenue Study Commission of the U.S. Congress, the annual investment required by all levels of government to simply maintain the nation\xe2\x80\x99s highways, roads and bridges is now an estimated $185 billion per year for the next 50 years. Today, the nation annually invests about $68 billion.\nMayors and city managers from the municipalities where \xe2\x80\x9cPaving for Pizza\xe2\x80\x9d has taken place have acknowledged the creation of shared value.\nFor Eric Norenberg, the city manager of Milford, DE: \xe2\x80\x9cWe appreciated the extra Paving for Pizza funds to stretch our street repair budget as we addressed more potholes than usual.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTowards new revenue models underpinned by creative urban resilience\nAdvertising is the soul of the capitalist system and the best incentive to upgrade it is to create new revenue streams. For one, a brand that shows itself relevant and useful is more likely to cut through the noise and increase sales. But there\xe2\x80\x99s also a bigger commercial model to be explored. First, by definition, UBU programs have three core objectives:\nEnabling savings or new earnings for cities\nCreating shared value for the cities\xe2\x80\x99 inhabitants, and\nDelivering superior return on media investment (ROMI).\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s a hypothetical situation. Let\xe2\x80\x99s assume that Domino\xe2\x80\x99s Paving for Pizza program generates a $10 million surplus to the city of Bartonville by minimising the costs from dealing with potholes. Rather than treating this as a one-off campaign, smart mayors would try and create a virtuous cycle, where 50 percent of the surplus is retained by the city, 25 percent is returned to the advertiser and 25 percent to the agency and media owner \xe2\x80\x94 a value only unlocked by repeating the approach.\nThe more advertisers communicate their messages in a way that benefits brand, people and city, the cheaper it becomes to do more of it \xe2\x80\x94 and, the more cities encourage such an approach, the faster societal problems will be addressed. In other words, UBU programs become a catalyst, igniting brand love, smartening cities and improving their economies, as shown on the model below.\nAs with the idea of a circular economy, where the life cycle of products and services goes beyond end users, UBU looks at brand communications as closed loops by designing a system bigger than fixed campaign periods, target audiences and business-as-usual KPIs. This way, marketing budgets are effectively turned into investment funds with returns in the form of brand cut-through, happier customers, social impact and more effective city management \xe2\x80\x94 as Heineken is aiming to achieve through its Cities Project, for example.\nMaking a brand\xe2\x80\x99s touchpoints become the new Agoras\nTo make the model scalable, however, a digitised mechanism would be required. An interesting case of civic engagement enabled by outdoor media has recently gone live in New York City.\nThe Participatory Budgeting campaign invited New Yorkers to decide how to spend US$1 million of the public budget through digital panels spread across the city. This means that the same touch point used to communicate is also used to enable the action it asks audiences to undertake \xe2\x80\x94 a paradigm shift where advertising can finally walk its talk.\nThe company behind the \xe2\x80\x98voting outdoor panels,\xe2\x80\x99 Intersection, started up by repurposing New York City\xe2\x80\x99s now-obsolete pay phones as totems offering free broadband Wi-Fi connectivity to residents and visitors, and media space for advertisers.\nBesides supplementing New York\xe2\x80\x99s broadband network and now enhancing civic life, the LinkNYC totems have projected an incremental US$500 million in ad revenue for the city as part of a 12-year contract, by unlocking new value from underutilised assets.\nJust like the Ancient Greek public squares \xe2\x80\x94 the Agoras \xe2\x80\x94 where direct democracy was born, this emerging participatory media can effectively collect complaints and suggestions for cities\xe2\x80\x99 improvement, in real time. The next step for this could then be the matching of brands that align with specific urban challenges.\nThis way, instead of top-down public-private contracts, issues are identified by local constituents informing future UBU programs, as wanted by the people and enabled by advertising media.\nThis can be done by following six strategic imperatives:\nTranslate the big idea that defines your brand into a big utility that can operationalise its impact.\nReplace interruptive interactions with enhancing ones by delivering a public utility service.\nTurn any existing utility of a communications effort from a stunt into a sustained practice.\nShift your business focus from short-term sales results to longer-term profitability.\nBroaden your audiences from customers to citizens, expanding paths-to-purchase into life journeys.\nDiversify revenue from sales to the creation of shared value.\nAs a comparison, Magna Global estimated that in 2018, global media spending in brand communications will reach US$551 billion; but, according to the Pike Institute, by 2020 investment in smart city infrastructure will not surpass US$108 billion \xe2\x80\x94 an approximate 5:1 ratio, respectively.\nThrough the UBU approach the current US$ 551 billion could merge into the much larger pie of Global Welfare & Security spend of US$ 40.5 trillion, a figure obtained by dividing Gross World Product (GWP) by the 30 percent global average spent on welfare and security, as per the International Monetary Fund (IMF).\nThe above, at least in theory, would be plausible as advertisers would then become key players in public-private-partnerships.\nMedia and advertising have powered a linear economy that is now facing severe challenges. Conversely, urbanisation has fuelled population growth that went from a sign of prosperity to one of alarm. The strategic opportunity is to bend the line and turn the existing real estate and brand communication infrastructure into a network of creative urban resilience that benefits all parties involved and educates everyone in the value chain.\nAs we've noted, markets, choice and competition are not just consumers\xe2\x80\x99 best friend, but their civic representation. After all, as one of the tribunes asks the crowd in Shakespeare\xe2\x80\x99s Coriolanus: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the city but the people?\xe2\x80\x9d\nPublished Oct 26, 2018 10am EDT / 7am PDT / 3pm BST / 4pm CEST\nS\xc3\xa9rgio Brodsky\nThe\nMarketing and Comms\nchannel is sponsored by\nAdvertisement\nMore Stories About:\nHeineken Sberbank Domino's Intersection Marketing and Comms Marketing and Comms They also provide municipal services, maps and directions, according to a\xc2\xa0report\xc2\xa0by The Patch.The kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 a collaborative effort by Intersection, the City of Newark, the Newark Community Economic Development Corp. and New Jersey Institute of Technology \xe2\x80\x94 will be installed in in high-traffic locations and "neighborhood corridors" around the city.\xc2\xa0Newark will have a total of 45 of the kiosks when the project is complete.Topics: Advertising, Customer Experience, Hardware, Installation/Integration, Interactive / Touchscreen, Networking / Connectivity, Trends / StatisticsSponsored Links:Related ContentKiosk Marketplace editor reviews 39 kiosk companies at National Restaurant ShowTaco Bell to install self-order kiosks in all stores in 2019 under its All Access initiativeSquare integration with Kiosk Pro app enables self-service for iPadsTaco Bell, Bell Canada Smart City Kiosks grab Elevate AwardsLatest ContentState-of-the-art testing: the first line of defense against fraudstersTexas Dairy Queen franchisee pioneers self-order kioskCashierless stores?
