Theaters\nVenues\nWriters\nWebsites\nStagehands\nABOUT US\nSocial Media\nContact Info\nWrite For Us\nJobs\nInternships\nRadio Station\nMagazine\nOur Sponsors\nADVERTISE\nAd Rates\nBanner Ads\nFor great Jersey music and much more, tune into our radio station at AsburyMusic.com\nLinkNWK Reminds Voters To Head To The Polls On November 6th\noriginally published: 11/05/2018\n(NEWARK, NJ) -- LinkNWK has been broadcasting reminders and poll site hours on Link\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x99s 55\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9d displays in Newark since November 1st, and will also host poll site locators on the Link tablets to provide voters with actionable information on the go.\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9cLink has transformed the way information is delivered on city streets, and supporting civic engagement has become a core part of our mission. With thousands of screens encouraging New Jersey residents to vote, and offering helpful resources for voters on the go, we hope to support a strong showing of democracy this Election Day,\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9d said Ruth Fasoldt, Link's Director of External Affairs.\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9cThis initiative by LinkNWK will enable people in Newark to find out vital information about voting locations, hours, and procedures at the touch of a computer screen,\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9d\xc3\x82\xc2\xa0Newark Mayor Ras J. Baraka\xc3\x82\xc2\xa0said. \xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9cI am extremely pleased that LinkNWK has partnered with us to use 21st-century technology to enable us to help people to vote.\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9dThe campaign is Link\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x99s third initiative this election cycle to promote voter awareness, engagement, and turnout. In New York, Links recently promoted New York State\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x99s primary election in September, which saw record voter turnout in the city, through reminders and local poll site information. Leading up to New York\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x99s voter registration deadline of October 12th, Link kiosks ran two campaigns encouraging New Yorkers to register to vote. The initiative consisted of a countdown clock up until the registration deadline as well as local statistics about how many people had registered to vote in each election district. Link also provided the ability for New Yorkers to register through the Link tablet in 2016 and 2018.The general election campaign represents the first civic engagement initiative for LinkNWK, which launched in Newark on October 16. Philadelphia will become the next city to launch a Link network later this year.The article continues after this ad\xc2\xa0 \xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9cNewark is once again defining itself to the state, nation, and world as a cutting-edge, high-tech city. These kiosks will enable residents and visitors alike to gain immediate information about Newark, ranging from upcoming cultural events to emergency service response,\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9d said Mayor Baraka. \xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9cWe are the only city in the entire state and the second in the nation to provide these services, and every person who uses one of these kiosks will not only gain the services they need, but learn something more important: Newark is a world-class urban leader.\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x9dLinkNWK is the result of a collaboration between The City of Newark, The Newark Community Economic Development Corporation (NCEDC), the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) and Intersection to enable city residents to benefit from Newark Fiber \xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x93 a program designed to bring affordable gigabit internet to the city. LinkNWK, Newark Fiber, and the city\xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x99s famed research universities, tech-savvy workforce, and proximity to New York City, are all making Newark a robust technology center.LinkNWK is a new communications network brining free, super fast Wi-Fi, national phone calls, maps and directions, device charging, access to city and emergency services, and local information to the streets of Newark. The program is the result of a collaboration between The City of Newark, The Newark Community Economic Development Corporation (NCEDC), the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) and Intersection to enable city residents to benefit from Newark Fiber \xc3\xa2\xc2\x80\xc2\x93 a program designed to bring affordable gigabit internet to the city.\nMore Articles You Might Like\nNew Jersey Hall of Fame Sets October 27 As Date For 11th Annual Gala Ceremony\nPrudential Center Presents Jurassic World Live\nThe Arts Go Live at Avenel Performing Arts Center\nUCPAC Receives $10,000 Grant from Northfield Bank Foundation\nState Theatre's Benefit Gala Hits A High Note With The Roaring Twenties\nA Look At MPAC's 25th Anniversary Season\nEvent calendarFriday, Jun 21, 2019\nMUSIC\n21 KINGS @ The Saint, Asbury Park - 7:30pm\nHappy Together Tour 2019 @ The Paramount Theatre (Asbury Park), Asbury Park - 7:00pm\nJackie June at The Asbury @ The Asbury Hotel, Asbury Park - 8:30pm\nMatt O'Ree Band @ The Stone Pony, Asbury Park - 7:00pm\nSAVED BY THE 90s @ Asbury Lanes, Asbury Park - 8:00pm\nIyanla Vanzant: Acts of Faith Remix Tour @ Prudential Hall @ New Jersey Performing Arts Center (NJPAC), Newark - 7:30pm\nTHEATRE\nAuditions: Zorro! If there is a problem with the rights to any image, please contact us and we will look into the matter.", b"LinkNYC kiosks join get out the vote effort around city\nCategories\nArts & Entertainment\nBrooklyn Bookbeat\nBusiness\nCourts and Law\nCrime\nEducation & Kids\nCollege\nContinuing Education\nJunior High / High School\nPre-K and Elementary\nHealth\nHistory\nMarket Place\nNews\nOpinions\nPolitics\nCity\nNational\nState\nReal Estate\nReligion\nScholastic and Amateur\nSports\nCyclones\nIslanders\nNets\nStreetbeat\nNeighborhoods\nAtlantic Yards\nBath Beach\nBay Ridge\nBedford-Stuyvesant\nBensonhurst\nBergen Beach\nBoerum Hill\nBorough Park\nBrighton Beach\nBrooklyn Boro\nBrooklyn Heights\nBrownsville\nBushwick\nCanarsie\nCarroll Gardens\nClinton Hill\nCobble Hill\nColumbia Waterfront\nConey Island\nCrown Heights\nCypress Hills\nDitmas Park\nDowntown\nDUMBO\nDyker Heights\nEast Flatbush\nEast New York\nEastern Brooklyn\nFlatbush\nFlatlands\nFort Greene\nFort Hamilton\nGeorgetown\nGerritsen Beach\nGowanus\nGravesend\nGreenpoint\nGreenwood Heights\nKensington\nManhattan Beach\nMapleton\nMarine Park\nMidwood\nMill Basin\nNavy Yard\nNew York City\nNorthern Brooklyn\nOcean Hill\nOther Brooklyns\nPark Slope\nProspect Heights\nProspect Park\nProspect Park South\nProspect-Lefferts\nRed Hook\nSea Gate\nSheepshead Bay\nSouthern Brooklyn\nStarrett City\nSunset Park\nVinegar Hill\nWestern Brooklyn\nWilliamsburg\nWindsor Terrace\nCalendar\nStreetbeat\nLog In\nLog In\nNews\nReal Estate\nArts & Entertainment\nLegal\nPolitics\nCity\nNational\nState\nBusiness\nSports\nCyclones\nIslanders\nNets\nHistory\nNeighborhoods\nNews\nBrooklyn Boro\nLinkNYC kiosks join get out the vote effort around city\nNovember 6, 2018 By Paula Katinas Brooklyn Daily Eagle\nImage courtesy of LinkNYC\nDuring this election season, the LinkNYC kiosks that dot the city\xe2\x80\x99s landscape are proving themselves to be good for much more than just charging iPhones and using Wi-Fi, according to officials. The sidewalk technology stations were part of a major Get Out the Vote effort by flashing constant reminders for residents to vote.\nIn the days leading up to Election Day, the 55-inch screens on LinkNYC kiosks displayed reminders to vote, along with information on polling site hours. Residents could also find their polling sites by using the Link tablet.\nThe idea is to offer busy New Yorkers information on the go, officials said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLink has transformed the way information is delivered on city streets, and supporting civic engagement has become a core part of our mission. With thousands of screens encouraging New Yorkers to vote, and offering helpful resources for voters on the go, we hope to support a strong showing of democracy this Election Day,\xe2\x80\x9d Ruth Fasoldt, Link\xe2\x80\x99s director of external affairs, told this newspaper via email.\nThe kiosks were put to good use during the primary season in September by reminding residents to vote on Sept. 13. And as the city\xe2\x80\x99s Oct. 12 voter registration deadline approached, the technology stations flashed messages reminding people that they had to register by that date in order to be eligible to vote on Nov. 6.\nFor statistics fans, the screens displayed information on how many people had registered to vote in each election district.\nThere are more than 1,700 LinkNYC kiosks around the city, including hundreds in Brooklyn.\nThe kiosks are part of an ambitious technology initiative launched by Mayor Bill de Blasio and the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications in 2016. A total of 7,500 of the kiosks is expected to be installed over the next decade.\nDAILY TOP BROOKLYN NEWS\nNews for those who live, work and play in Brooklyn and beyond\nLeave this field empty if you're human:\nThe kiosks replaced the old pay telephones that used to line city sidewalks.\nThe stations offer free Wi-Fi, free phone calls, easy access to the city\xe2\x80\x99s 911 and 311 systems, maps and the social services platform Aunt Bertha through a LinkNYC network, officials said.\nThe kiosks are also equipped to serve as charging stations for residents seeking to charge their phones and other mobile devices.\nA consortium called CityBridge is in charge of the LinkNYC program.\nSince 2016, more than five million people have used the LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s free Wi-Fi service, according to officials, who said 500,000 phone calls are made every month from the technology stations.\nSHARE ARTICLE:\nLeave a Comment\nRelated Articles\nNYC Council speaker asks Board of Elections director to resign\nNovember 6 |\nBy Paula Katinas\nBrooklyn Today\nJune 21, 2019Jun 21, 2019 | Clouds, 78\xc2\xb0 F\nDaily Top Brooklyn News\nBrooklyn Boro\nView More\nNew York City\xe2\x80\x99s most populous borough, Brooklyn, is home to nearly 2.6 million residents.\xc2\xa0If Brooklyn were an independent city it would be the fourth largest city in the United States. While Brooklyn has become the epitome of \xe2\x80\x98cool and hip\xe2\x80\x99 in recent years, for those that were born here, raised families here and improved communities over the years, Brooklyn has never been \xe2\x80\x98uncool\xe2\x80\x99.\nFollow\n@bkeagle\nContribute\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nTerms & Conditions\nContact Us\nThe Brooklyn Daily Eagle and brooklyneagle.com cover Brooklyn 24/7 online and five days a week in print with the motto, \xe2\x80\x9cAll Brooklyn All the Time.\xe2\x80\x9d With a history dating back to 1841, the Eagle is New York City\xe2\x80\x99s only daily devoted exclusively to Brooklyn.\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Everything Brooklyn Media\nDAILY TOP BROOKLYN NEWS\nNews for those who live, work and play in Brooklyn and beyond\nLeave this field empty if you're human:", b'Top 5 out-of-home advertising trends\n| Marketing Dive\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nTech\nCreative\nSocial Media\nVideo\nAnalytics\nExecutive News\nMobile\nAn article from\nTop 5 out-of-home advertising trends\nWhile printed signs still dominate, growth in digital out-of-home inventory lets advertisers be more timely, creative and targeted, Geopath\'s CEO Kym Frank says.\nAuthor\nBy\nDianna Christe\nPublished\nNov. 12, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nThe static billboards of the past are increasingly being replaced by dynamic digital signs that update in real time and are activated by mobile devices or connected cars, pointing to how the integration of digital technology with out-of-home (OOH) advertising unlocks interesting opportunities for marketers.\nDelta Airlines and Equinox Fitness showcased how digital is changing billboard advertising with a campaign this summer that used real-time flight data to encourage international travelers arriving at Los Angeles International Airport to "sweat away" their jet lag. Dynamic opportunities like this are helping drive channel growth, as OOH ad spend rose 1.2% last year compared to 2016, accounting for $7.7 billion, according to the Outdoor Advertising Association of America (OAAA). By 2021,\xc2\xa0a MAGNA Intelligence study predicts OOH spend will reach $33 billion.\nOther changes are also evident as OOH advertising evolves. Trade organization Traffic Audit Bureau for Media Measurement, which has audited the circulation of OOH media in the U.S. since 1933, changed its name to Geopath in 2016 and is now embracing data, technology and media research to measure and analyze how consumers engage with OOH ads. In an interview with Marketing Dive, Geopath CEO Kym Frank discussed some of the changes taking place in the space and highlighted key trends impacting marketers.\nDynamic creative and custom triggers\nWhile printed signs still dominate, digital OOH inventory is taking new shape and presenting advertisers with the potential to deliver more dynamic creative and custom triggers. Jukeboxes in bars, large format digital signs lining highways, digital bus shelters and signage in malls and restaurants across America are spurring marketers to experiment with the channel. In the past, such deployments were often considered experimental or a one-off test, but nowadays dynamic creative in OOH is becoming more scalable, Frank said.\nFor instance, advertisers can now change the creative based on the speed of traffic going past a digital billboard. If traffic is flowing at 60 miles an hour, drivers may only have time to read 10 words or so on a billboard. But if traffic is congested or at a standstill, drivers may be able to read up to 150 words. Messaging and creative can be instantly adjusted to match these conditions and better capture consumers\' attention.\n"Digital is allowing advertisers to be more reactive and serve dynamic creative often based on custom triggers," Frank said.\nIntegration of mobile into OOH\nAdvertisers can also dynamically trigger ads based on the types of mobile devices near the OOH channel, meaning an iPhone owner might see a different ad than an Android user.\xc2\xa0Advertisers are also geofencing their digital billboards so after drivers who have seen the ad leave the area, they can be retargeted with a personalized ad on their mobile device.\xc2\xa0For example, if searches for flu medication are peaking in the area, a billboard ad for a pharmacy might adjust the creative to promote certain products at the pharmacy and then the retailer can send passersby an offer.\n"Advertisers are getting very creative in how to use the medium, now we are seeing weather triggers, search query triggers, and even messaging based on what is currently playing on a radio station served to a billboard as you drive by," Frank said.\nData improves measurement\nThe OOH industry has made big investments in measurement systems to glean the kinds of metrics typically associated with digital channels, according to Frank. As a result, brands now have the ability to look at who has been exposed to an ad campaign on a digital billboard and track the behavior of the consumer afterward. While in the past marketers would have had to survey people and ask if they recalled seeing a billboard, now marketers know what consumers passed OOH ads and whether the marketing message contributed to an online search or purchase.\n"This is a massive technology data ecosystem that we didn\'t have access to 10 years ago and suddenly we have so many new toys to play with as an industry."\nKym Frank\nCEO, Geopath\nUsing data from connected cars, marketers can also perform more granular segmentation and targeting of audiences.\n"So rather than just looking at standard demographics, we can now look at people in the market for a new car or people who are planning to go to a college or university within the next year," Frank said.\nThe rise of automation\nAutomation and programmatic trading have reached the OOH industry. The buying and selling of OOH ad space was once a cumbersome process that involved negotiating pricing between the advertiser or the agency and the media seller and sending the creative off to a printer. Someone would then have to go out, take a photo of the unit and send that to the advertiser. These days, the process has become far more automated and efficient.\nSome programmatic platforms allow advertisers to buy both mobile ads and OOH units directly through the same interface, enabling more integrated location-based strategies. With automated platforms, it\'s also easier for advertisers to upload files and for installers to snap digital photos during installation to deliver proof of deployment to the advertiser and agency in real time.\nDigital OOH units can also be tracked throughout the day, similar to any other digital ad, delivering analytics results much faster than traditional methods allowed.\n"This applies to anything from roadside billboards to jukeboxes in a bar," Frank said. "It spans the gamut of sizing."\nSmart cities stimulate growth\nCities are becoming more connected than ever before, offering interactive digital kiosks with maps, free Wi-Fi and local destinations. These city-run services are a great opportunity for advertisers to connect with audiences. New York\'s LinkNYC and other projects in the works in New Rochelle, New York, and Austin, Texas, highlight that it\'s not necessarily just OOH companies putting ad inventory into the marketplace.\n"Eventually these city projects become ad-supported and become part of the out-of-home ecosystem, and we expect that to become more and more prevalent," Frank said. "Who is running them will be interesting to see. Sometimes it is out-of-home companies, sometimes it is digital companies and sometimes, it is the cities themselves. This is a massive technology data ecosystem that we didn\'t have access to 10 years ago and suddenly we have so many new toys to play with as an industry."\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nMarketing Tech\nCreative\nAnalytics\nMobile\nTop image credit:\nLamar Advertising\nGet marketing news like this in your inbox daily. You can opt out anytime.', b"Smart City Approaches in the Real World | IoT For All\nTechAgricultureAI & MLAR, VR, & MRAsset TrackingBlockchainBuilding AutomationConnectivityBluetoothCellularLPWANData & AnalyticsDevices & SensorsDigital TransformationEdge & Cloud ComputingEnergy & UtilitiesFinance & InsuranceIndustrial IoTIoT PlatformsMedical & HealthcareRetailSecuritySmart CitySmart HomeTransport & Supply ChainUI & UXVoice InteractionIoT ExplainedIntro CourseQ&ASimple ExplanationsTutorialPodcastNewsContributeBecome a ContributorSubmit a Press ReleaseMoreTeamAboutNewsletterEvent PartnersFree eBooks\nSearch\nIoT For All TechAllAgriculture (24) AI & ML (146) AR, VR, & MR (66) Asset Tracking (55) Blockchain (21) Building Automation (42) Connectivity (152) Bluetooth (12) Cellular (38) LPWAN (38) Data & Analytics (138) Devices & Sensors (182) Digital Transformation (197) Edge & Cloud Computing (55) Energy & Utilities (43) Finance & Insurance (10) Industrial IoT (107) IoT Platforms (82) Medical & Healthcare (47) Retail (30) Security (142) Smart City (90) Smart Home (95) Transport & Supply Chain (60) UI & UX (39) Voice Interaction (33)\nInternet of ThingsIndustrial Augmented Reality (AR) Boosts Equipment Maintenance, Field Service and Staff\xe2\x80\xa6 #askIoTFive Problems That Can Sink an IoT Certification Project #askIoTHow to Plan Your IIoT Solution for Long-Term Scalability Data & AnalyticsToward a New Model of Data OwnershipIoT ExplainedAllIntro Course (28) Q&A (81) Simple Explanations (86) Tutorial (46)\n#askIoTFive Problems That Can Sink an IoT Certification Project #askIoTHow to Plan Your IIoT Solution for Long-Term Scalability #askIoTWhat Is a Smart Building? #askIoT5 AI Use Cases for Enterprise Resources Planning (ERP)PodcastNewsContributeBecome a ContributorSubmit a Press ReleaseMoreTeamAboutNewsletterEvent PartnersFree eBooksHome\nInsightsLIKE28InsightsInternet of ThingsSmart CitySmart City Approaches in the Real WorldIn the second installment of IoT For All's Smart City Series, Marc Bielas argues that by learning from the real world smart city approaches behind New York City, Barcelona, and Tallinn, we can collaboratively build a better urban future.By Marc Bielas - November 13, 20185582TweetShareShareEmailIf you\xe2\x80\x99re coming from my previous article, What is a Smart City, you might be wondering what smart city developments and technologies look like in the real world. Specific technologies such as distributed sensing, public data, and modular electricity infrastructure are paramount to smart city projects. Diving right into the details of these technologies without contextualizing them in real cities, however, would further the dangerous approach of solutions-first thinking. Individual cities, much like people, are all unique. Looking at specific technologies prior to understanding a city\xe2\x80\x99s needs is a bit like handing a surfer an umbrella or giving a newborn baby a copy of Infinite Jest.In order to manifest the intentions behind a smart city\xe2\x80\x94to make individual aspects of urban life better\xe2\x80\x94those interested in the field must start with context. Only after understanding it fully can they introduce solutions.To manifest the intentions behind a #SmartCity\xe2\x80\x94to make #Urban life better\xe2\x80\x94stakeholders must start with context. Only after understanding it fully can they introduce solutions. || #IoTForAll @MarcBielas Click To TweetRather than focusing on a single technology, this article will introduce a series of smart city strategies as they pertain to leading cities in the field. These strategies represent different but equally important approaches to urban innovation: investments in distributed sensing, infrastructural improvements, and e-Governance. By diving into the work done in New York, Barcelona, and Tallinn, this post will give you a better understanding of the broad range of available methodologies and technologies in the smart city industry.Sensors and Data:\xc2\xa0New York City, U.S.A.Population: 8.6 millionImage Credit: LinkNYCNew York City is a leader in successful sensor deployment and public data access, having incorporated sensing across many city functions including water metering and transportation. In 2009, the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Environmental Protection, which delivers 1 billion gallons of water a day to 8.6 million residents, developed an advanced meter reading system consisting of 817,000 individual water meters across the city\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs. By regularly sending water readings to the department\xe2\x80\x99s operational center, these sensors provide citizens and the government with real-time access to water usage monitoring and easy billing.By eliminating the need for manual metering, the city decreased tax expenditure by $3 million dollars annually. Additionally, the system reduced the need to estimate water usage from 17% to 3% of buildings, meaning that citizens are now more likely to pay for actual usage as opposed to estimated amounts. This reduction caused billing disputes to drop by 56%, developing secondary economic benefits. Furthermore, nothing stops the city from continuously analyzing water data and developing new tools on top of simple metering. One such tool for leak notification has saved users hundreds of millions of dollars since it was rolled out in 2011.New York City faces a host of issues related to moving people across the city. It has the highest public transit ridership in North America\xe2\x80\x941.73 billion riders in 2017. With an aging transportation infrastructure, the city has taken multiple approaches to modernization. Buses, which support the movement of 2.5 million passengers every weekday, are largely unreliable due to traffic.In order to improve bus service and further incentivize its use, NYC\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Transportation (DOT) and Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) developed a system called Transit Signal Priority (TSP) to decrease the amount of time buses spend at red lights from the historic average of 20%. Since 2008, TSP has used GPS trackers built into public buses and data integration into the city\xe2\x80\x99s traffic lights either to trigger early green lights or to extend a green light when a bus nears an intersection. Since this entire system is digital, the city can continue to decrease bus commute times by tuning specific variables. By 2017, TSP was already deployed in 260 locations and five bus routes throughout the city. Moreover, it had reduced bus delays by about 20%, increasing the viability of aboveground public transit. As this solution expands to more intersections and routes, the city will be able to capture the environmental and economic benefits of even higher transit ridership.\xc2\xa0With sensors becoming ubiquitous, the amount of data available for analysis is growing rapidly. The NYC government and other cities already produce more data than they know what to do with. These datasets, when combined and analyzed, could continuously reveal potential opportunities for innovation. Key findings might lead to viable business models.\xe2\x80\x9cOpen Data\xe2\x80\x9d has become a popular idea in the smart city field. Today, NYC provides more than 1,000 open datasets through its public OpenData platform. Citizens and corporations alike can use the available data to discover new ways of improving the urban experience. An example of this was the analysis of more than 150 million taxi trips by MIT, GE, and Audi in 2014. That project revealed that the total number of taxi trips could be easily decreased by 40% if taxi-sharing services existed. These findings and others provide key insights into highly effective routes to minimizing traffic and increasing urban efficiency. Moreover, since they rely heavily on real information as opposed to general urban theory, they may be more likely to succeed.Smart Infrastructure: Barcelona, SpainPopulation: 1.6 millionImage Credit: Business InsiderBarcelona is an economic and cultural powerhouse in Europe. Believe it or not, the city has been building smart city infrastructure for over 150 years. In 1854, Madrid\xe2\x80\x99s government mandated the destruction of Barcelona\xe2\x80\x99s city walls and sought to expand the city\xe2\x80\x99s rapidly growing population. Ildefons Cerda, an urban planner and civil engineer, heeded the call for expansion. He developed one of most prominent smart urban plans in history: the superblock.Serving as an octagonal mold for urban fabric, the superblock prioritizes large interior courtyards, wide streets, and buildings that recede from intersections to increase the amount of light entering the city\xe2\x80\x94a stark contrast to the dark and tightly interwoven streets of Barcelona\xe2\x80\x99s historical center. Additionally, by standardizing larger urban forms but allowing for differences in individual building design, the superblock has created a unique identity for Barcelona, allowing it to be visually interesting but not confusingly read as a cohesive whole.Jumping ahead, today\xe2\x80\x99s Barcelona has continued its legacy of infrastructural innovation. Building on top of the superblock network, which consists of horizontal and vertical grids intersected by multiple diagonal boulevards, Barcelona has recently deployed an orthogonal bus network. Highly-efficient\xc2\xa0hybrid buses repeatedly follow straight paths so that the network can allow passengers to minimize the complexity of their routes. Each rider can\xc2\xa0reach any destination with only one transfer.In 2002, Barcelona rolled out another key innovation that has minimized resource use. Districlima\xc2\xa0is an urban network of district-wide heating and cooling systems. It\xe2\x80\x99s similar to what is in use at many American college campuses, albeit\xc2\xa0at a smaller scale. By providing steam as well as hot and cold water at a city-wide level, Districlima is able to implement environmental best practices such as using waste heat from industrial processes to create steam and leveraging plentiful sea-water for cooling. Districlima saves more than 17,500 tons of C02 annually and reduces fossil fuel consumption by 60%.Barcelona\xe2\x80\x99s neighborhoods have also begun to experiment with another important infrastructural pursuit: smart waste management. Some neighborhoods have constructed large subterranean vacuum networks to minimize both the stench of overflowing dumpsters and the sound of trash collection vehicles. Other neighborhoods have partnered with companies to develop specialized sensors that alert waste management services when trash bins fill to a preset level. Those partnerships actively minimize the need for trash collection crews to waste resources by emptying trash bins that still have capacity. By allowing for exploration through small pilots in different neighborhoods, Barcelona will build an understanding of best practices that it can deploy across the larger population.Smart Governance:Tallinn, EstoniaPopulation: 426,500Image Credit: Wikimedia CommonsWhen the Soviet Union imploded in 1991, Estonia regained its independence and was forced to reboot as a country with few resources. Estonia hoped to jumpstart the process of rebuilding by piggybacking on the internet boom in 1996. The nation quickly invested in a project called \xe2\x80\x9cTiger\xe2\x80\x99s Leap,\xe2\x80\x9d which rolled out computers with internet access to all schools and universities. In 2000, armed with a computationally savvy populace, Estonia\xe2\x80\x99s government led the world by declaring internet access a basic human right. The government began rolling out \xe2\x80\x9ce-Estonia\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94a suite of tools that would fully digitize the country\xe2\x80\x99s government.Anchored by X-Road\xe2\x80\x94an interoperable data service that allows the nation\xe2\x80\x99s e-service databases to link up harmoniously with private citizens and companies\xe2\x80\x94e-Estonia positions the nation at the forefront of digital governance. Since 2001, Estonians have been able to file their taxes online. 95% of the country does so today. In 2002, Estonia introduced high-tech e-ID cards paired with digital identities. These identities allow the government to authenticate citizens without physical contact, allowing for online voting, schooling, and protection as well as higher security banking. Since it began its reboot in 1991, Estonia has managed to put 99% of its government services online. (Marriage, divorce, and real estate transactions are still handled in person.)Digitization has enabled the Estonian government to operate 24 hours a day while maximizing the efficiency of taxpayer dollars. To keep citizen data safe, e-Estonia has become an early adopter of blockchain, which the government is integrating across its entire suite of tools. The government already authenticates property registries, business licenses, and judicial actions through blockchain technology.\xc2\xa0Given the level of personal data protection the government offers, Estonians can also have full access to their health data online without fear. They can seamlessly transfer between doctors and access digital prescriptions. World leaders like the USA lag far behind such a deep integration of useful technology into government practice.In the age of cyber-warfare, Estonia has also embarked on a mission to create the world\xe2\x80\x99s first \xe2\x80\x9cData Embassy,\xe2\x80\x9d which will contain a complete backup of the country\xe2\x80\x99s citizens and data in Luxembourg. For a small country of only 1.3 million people (including e-Citizens), Estonia has managed to successfully prepare itself for our rapidly changing times. Since data privacy and e-Services were designed and built from the ground up\xe2\x80\x94instead of through piecemeal replacement of pre-existing infrastructures\xe2\x80\x94Estonia is better positioned to adopt developing technologies than most other nations.While individual smart city deployments will (hopefully) be tailored to their specific contexts, the general frameworks and methods used when developing smart city solutions are highly transferable. Industrial, governmental, and\xc2\xa0public stakeholders alike will benefit from sharing learnings and best practices across cities and nations. Together, we can collaboratively push each other toward a better iteration of modern urban life.TweetShareShareEmailTAGSbig datadatadigital transformationinternet of thingsiotmarc bielasp3pppsmart buildingsmart citysmart city seriessmart energysmart homessmart meterssmart officeMarc Bielashttp://marcbielas.com/Marc Bielas is a Product Manager at Leverege. He focuses on deploying dynamic enterprise IoT solutions. He also writes about smart cities for IoT For All. He recently graduated from Yale University, majoring in Computing and the Arts (CS & Architecture) and Energy Technology.\nMore Insights Breaking Down Barriers as a Woman in IoT April 17, 2019Welcome to the Co-Economy\xe2\x80\x94Brought to You by Generation IoT December 15, 2017Should I Use an IoT Platform? \xe2\x80\x93 Reduce Cost and Boost... July 15, 20175 Keys to Designing User Experience for IoT Products March 30, 2018Industrial Augmented Reality (AR) Boosts Equipment Maintenance, Field Service and Staff Training\nSofteq Development Corporation -\nJune 21, 2019 Five Problems That Can Sink an IoT Certification Project\nGuest Writer -\nJune 21, 2019 How to Plan Your IIoT Solution for Long-Term Scalability\nCory Williamson -\nJune 20, 2019 Toward a New Model of Data Ownership Data & Analytics JC Gaillard -\nJune 20, 2019 Data is today\xe2\x80\x99s most used currency. The business model developed by big tech firms over the past decade, by which consumers pay for services with their personal data instead of money, is being undermined by long-term social trends toward greater care for privacy. Do you own your personal data? Could you sell it instead of giving it away? How can trust be built in that type of transaction?Podcast E031 | How to Effectively Handle the Digital Transformation Journey | Sean Parham,... Sean also discusses how the biggest changes throughout that transformation aren't found in the technology but enabled by it.Smart City Data: Digital Identity Meets Critical Infrastructure Internet of Things Susan Morrow -\nJune 19, 2019 Tying our (digital) identities to IoT devices creates a critical smart city infrastructure complicates privacy and security.5 Common Questions About the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) Internet of Things Digital Lumens -\nJune 19, 2019 Industrial IoT (IIoT) adds unprecedented efficiency to businesses. CTRL + SPACE for auto-complete.", b"New Public Spaces Are Supposed to Be for All. The Reality Is More Complicated. - The New York Times\nSectionsSEARCHSkip to contentSkip to site indexNew YorkSubscribeLog InLog InToday\xe2\x80\x99s PaperNew York|New Public Spaces Are Supposed to Be for All. The Reality Is More Complicated.AdvertisementSupported byNew Public Spaces Are Supposed to Be for All. The Reality Is More Complicated.ImageA worker power-washing the pedestrian plaza along Broadway in Manhattan\xe2\x80\x99s garment district. Trash, used needles and feces there have drawn complaints.CreditCreditJeenah Moon for The New York TimesBy Winnie HuNov. 13, 2018Office workers sip coffee beside men sleeping in chairs pulled together. Tourists park their shopping bags where people shoot up heroin, or drink until they pass out. Panhandlers go table to table seeking handouts. Piles of trash, used needles and worse (human feces) have drawn complaints.This is a scene from the heart of Manhattan, where a painstaking effort to ban cars and carve a public plaza out of one of New York City\xe2\x80\x99s most famous streets \xe2\x80\x94 with birch trees, cafe-style tables and original artwork \xe2\x80\x94 has collided with stark socioeconomic realities.An opioid epidemic has left some addicted and desperate. Others with mental illnesses are not getting the help they need. And of the more than 60,000 homeless people in New York, at least 3,000 live on the streets.The plaza along Broadway, a few blocks south of Times Square, has become a haven for people struggling with all of those issues.What is happening in Midtown Manhattan underscores the challenges in New York and many other American cities of creating public spaces that, by definition, are open to all and a cornerstone of urban life, especially in space-starved communities. From pocket-size parks to plazas on reclaimed roadways to sidewalks dressed up with sleek benches and kiosks, the spaces make concrete-and-asphalt grids more inviting.But as these public spaces have proliferated, they have also become testing grounds for what is acceptable \xe2\x80\x94 and unacceptable \xe2\x80\x94 public behavior. Cities including Honolulu, San Francisco, Colorado Springs and Charleston, S.C., have passed laws or regulations against sitting or lying down on sidewalks. Some cities have banned people from camping or even sleeping in public spaces.\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a big issue for the people who manage public spaces in virtually every city in the country, and depending on what the rules and laws are, it\xe2\x80\x99s an almost intractable problem in most cases,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adrian Benepe, a senior vice president for the Trust for Public Land, and a former New York City parks commissioner.Many city and business leaders say setting basic rules of conduct helps ensure that public spaces can be enjoyed by everyone and addresses public health and safety concerns. Advocates for the homeless counter that such measures are unconstitutional, target the homeless and keep out people who have nowhere else to go.\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going to tell me I can\xe2\x80\x99t use a public space because I don\xe2\x80\x99t have a home?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99 said Jason Flores, 30, who moved to New York from Philadelphia and sleeps in public areas because he has no money.Mr. Benepe said that behavior in public spaces has to be regulated, but that cities \xe2\x80\x9ccan\xe2\x80\x99t criminalize homelessness and it\xe2\x80\x99s a fine line.\xe2\x80\x9dIn a 2016 survey of 187 cities, the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, a nonprofit advocacy group, found that 88 cities had passed laws or regulations that restricted sitting or lying down in public places, up from 58 cities a decade earlier. Similar bans restricted sleeping in public spaces in 84 cities and begging in public spaces in 164 cities. It is unclear, however, how much these are enforced.\xe2\x80\x9cThis is being driven by the growth of homelessness and the increasing public presence of people who are poor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maria Foscarinis, the center\xe2\x80\x99s executive director, who added that some laws have been successfully challenged in the courts.ImagePlazas, including this one in Union Square in Manhattan, have proliferated across New York as officials have tried to make streets more welcoming to pedestrians.CreditYana Paskova for The New York TimesLaws trying to dictate behavior in public spaces, Ms. Foscarinis said, are a \xe2\x80\x9ckneejerk political reaction\xe2\x80\x9d that fail to address the underlying causes. She cited research showing that it would be more effective and less expensive to create affordable housing and provide social services than to enforce such laws.Jerold S. Kayden, an urban planning professor at the Harvard University Graduate School of Design, said that as long as there have been public spaces, there have been tensions over who used them, and how. The agora in ancient Greece \xe2\x80\x94 a space for assembly celebrated for its debates \xe2\x80\x94 was originally only open to \xe2\x80\x9ccitizens,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Kayden said, in effect excluding \xe2\x80\x9cpeople not considered worthy of public space.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x9cPublic space has always been part of being human,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cBut that\xe2\x80\x99s the challenge: What expression of humanity is acceptable?\xe2\x80\x9dMr. Flores said security officers and others wake him up \xe2\x80\x94 sometimes three or four times a night \xe2\x80\x94 and tell him to move on. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s like being kicked when you\xe2\x80\x99re down,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not fair.\xe2\x80\x9dBut also unfair, others said, is having public spaces taken over by those seeking a place to sleep or making it harder for others to use.Constantine Obelenus, 65, a messenger, recalled not having a place to sit with a cup of coffee in a park near his home in Elmhurst, Queens, because the benches were taken by people sleeping. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the space for?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody.\xe2\x80\x9dSidewalks have become contentious as well. In Manhattan, residents of a Chelsea apartment building have cleaned mounds of trash, rotting food, urine in juice bottles, feces and used needles left outside their door by people who camp out on the pavement.Mark Goldey, 49, a lawyer who lives in the building, said the LinkNYC kiosks, which offer free internet access, at either end of his block are another problem because people sprawl out around them with their stuff and block foot traffic.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s hard to get around,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt feels unsafe.\xe2\x80\x9d[How New York City has taken streets away from cars to turn into pedestrian plazas]New York City has long had rules for how public spaces are to be used. Some of the most stringent apply to city parks and playgrounds, where more than three dozen rules prohibit a range of conduct, such as disorderly behavior, urinating, defecating, fighting, spitting, lying down on benches, camping without a permit and not picking up after dogs.Park officers handed out 1,820 tickets for all violations through August, compared with 1,850 all of last year.Other public spaces resort to creative ways of curbing unwanted behavior. Metal dividers are added to benches to keep people from lying down. Bryant Park in Midtown Manhattan is \xe2\x80\x9cprogrammed within an inch of its life\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 festivals, readings, ice-skating \xe2\x80\x94 to bring in crowds that leave little room for illicit uses, said Dan Biederman, the president of the Bryant Park Corporation, which manages the park.But sidewalks and streets were never intended as gathering places. That changed when pedestrian plazas were carved out of streets. In 2016, New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Transportation adopted rules for its pedestrian plazas \xe2\x80\x94 59 are open, 18 more are on the way \xe2\x80\x94 after complaints of costumed Elmos and other vendors aggressively seeking tips in the Times Square plaza.ImageJason Flores, 30, said he sleeps in public areas in Manhattan because he has no money.CreditJeenah Moon for The New York TimesThe rules are now posted in every plaza, but are often ignored or flouted, according to plaza managers and others. Because plazas \xe2\x80\x94 unlike parks \xe2\x80\x94 never close, they can be an open invitation for misconduct and there are no dedicated officers to enforce the rules, they said. The police have to be called.After a sprawling Bronx plaza opened in 2016, homeless people and others sought refuge there, bringing mattresses and suitcases. Drug use is also common there.\xe2\x80\x9cYou just have this open space inviting people to do whatever they want,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilma Alonso, the executive director of the Fordham Road Business Improvement District. \xe2\x80\x9cIt has so much potential that when it\xe2\x80\x99s empty and underutilized, it hurts.\xe2\x80\x9dJust south of there, in a popular South Bronx shopping district known as the Hub, at least 50 people at any time \xe2\x80\x94 or more than three times as many as a year ago \xe2\x80\x94 sleep or camp out in public spaces, including a recently opened plaza, said Michael Brady, the executive director of the Third Avenue Business Improvement District. Mr. Brady said his staff and local business owners have learned to give a nasal spray used to treat overdoses.Under state law, homeless people cannot be forcibly removed from the streets unless they pose a threat to themselves or others. City officials said they have significantly expanded outreach efforts and programs for the homeless. They said they have helped nearly 2,000 people voluntarily leave the streets for shelters and permanent housing since 2016.The Broadway plaza is the largest public space in Manhattan\xe2\x80\x99s garment district, a dense neighborhood where factories have been replaced with offices, restaurants, hotels and apartments. At night, as many as two dozen people sleep on the plaza where festive white lights will soon be strung for the holidays and silver tables and chairs offer \xe2\x80\x94 weather permitting \xe2\x80\x94 al fresco dining amid skyscrapers.Several men said they felt safe there, with the huge planters of juniper and Japanese holly offering shelter from the cold. J.R., 36, who declined to give his full name, said he was homeless and slept there only at night when office workers were not around.In the daytime, he said, he tried not to bother anyone. \xe2\x80\x9cEveryone should try to be fair with each other,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have to share the space.\xe2\x80\x9dBut other people argue and fight in the plaza, according to workers for the Garment District Alliance, which maintains the plaza. These workers say they have seen people use and sell drugs, and urinate on the plants. One rowdy group recently pelted passers-by with batteries, they said.Min Park, the manager of Cook Eatery, said some people from the plaza have grabbed food from the deli\xe2\x80\x99s buffet table without paying. Or they have asked customers for money. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m constantly chasing them out,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.Barbara A. Blair, the alliance\xe2\x80\x99s president, has stationed security guards around the plaza to try to keep the peace. She once posted signs asking people not to give money to panhandlers on the plaza. The signs were ripped down. She got emails accusing her of being heartless.At 5 a.m. on a recent day, Ms. Blair accompanied security officers as they woke people sleeping on the plaza to tell them that it was being cleaned. Outreach workers with Urban Pathways, a nonprofit, offered support services and a place for them to stay. Then six cleaners came with power hoses and disinfectant.\xe2\x80\x9cWe love our plaza,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Blair said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut we\xe2\x80\x99re struggling with homelessness and antisocial behavior in these public spaces.\xe2\x80\x9dA version of this article appears in print on , on Page A22 of the New York edition with the headline: Havens in Cramped Cities Test the Concept of Public Space for All. CompanyContact UsWork with usAdvertiseYour Ad ChoicesPrivacyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapHelpHelpSubscriptions", b'Google\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSmart City\xe2\x80\x9d in Toronto Faces New Resistance\nTheIntercept_EnglishPortugu\xc3\xaasPoliticsJusticeNational SecurityWorldTechnologyEnvironmentSpecial InvestigationsVoicesPodcastsVideosDocumentsAboutEditorial PoliciesBecome a SourceJoin NewsletterBecome A MemberThe Intercept is a First Look Media Company.\xc2\xa9 First Look Media. All rights reservedTerms of usePrivacySitemapTheIntercept_Illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesIllustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesGoogle\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSmart City of Surveillance\xe2\x80\x9d Faces New Resistance in TorontoAva KofmanAva KofmanNovember 13 2018, 5:03\xc2\xa0p.m.Illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesIllustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesThe world\xe2\x80\x99s most ambitious \xe2\x80\x9csmart city,\xe2\x80\x9d known as Quayside, in Toronto, has faced fierce public criticism since last fall, when the plans to build a neighborhood \xe2\x80\x9cfrom the internet up\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0were first revealed. Quayside represents a joint effort by the Canadian government agency Waterfront Toronto and Sidewalk Labs, which is owned by Google\xe2\x80\x99s parent company Alphabet Inc., to develop\xc2\xa012 acres of the valuable waterfront just southeast of downtown Toronto.\nIn keeping with the utopian rhetoric that fuels the development of so much digital infrastructure, Sidewalk Labs has pitched Quayside as the solution to everything from traffic congestion and rising housing prices to environmental pollution. The proposal for Quayside includes a centralized identity management system, through which \xe2\x80\x9ceach resident accesses public services\xe2\x80\x9d such as library cards and health care. An applicant for a position at Sidewalk Labs in Toronto was shocked when he was\xc2\xa0asked in an interview to imagine how, in a smart city, \xe2\x80\x9cvoting might be different in the future.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOther, comparatively quaint plans include driverless cars, \xe2\x80\x9cmixed-use\xe2\x80\x9d spaces that change according to the market\xe2\x80\x99s demands, heated streets, and \xe2\x80\x9csensor-enabled waste separation.\xe2\x80\x9d The eventual aim of Sidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99s estimated billion-dollar investment is to bring these innovations to scale \xe2\x80\x94 first to more than 800 acres on the city\xe2\x80\x99s eastern waterfront, and then to the world at large. \xe2\x80\x9cThe genesis of the thinking for Sidewalk Labs came from Google\xe2\x80\x99s founders getting excited thinking of \xe2\x80\x98all the things you could do if someone would just give us a city and put us in charge,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d explained Eric Schmidt, Google\xe2\x80\x99s former executive chair, when Quayside was first announced.\nFrom the start, activists, technology researchers, and some government officials have been skeptical about the idea of putting Google, or one of its sister companies, in charge of a city. Their suspicions about turning part of Toronto into a corporate test bed were triggered, at first, by the company\xe2\x80\x99s history of unethical corporate practices and surreptitious data collection. They have since been borne out by Quayside\xe2\x80\x99s secret and undemocratic development process, which has been plagued by a lack of public input \xe2\x80\x94 what one critic has called \xe2\x80\x9ca colonizing experiment in surveillance capitalism attempting to bulldoze important urban, civic and political issues.\xe2\x80\x9d In recent months, a series of prominent resignations from advisory board members, along with organized resistance from concerned residents, have added to the growing public backlash against the project.\nA few weeks ago, Ann Cavoukian, one of Canada\xe2\x80\x99s leading privacy experts and Ontario\xe2\x80\x99s former privacy commissioner, became the latest stakeholder to resign from the project. Cavoukian was brought on by Sidewalk Toronto (as the collaboration between Waterfront Toronto and Google-sibling Sidewalk Labs is known) as a consultant to help institute a proactive, \xe2\x80\x9cprivacy by design\xe2\x80\x9d framework. She was initially told that all data collected from residents would be deleted and rendered unidentifiable. Cavoukian learned last month, however, that third parties would be able to access identifiable information gathered at Quayside. \xe2\x80\x9cI imagined us creating a Smart City of Privacy, as opposed to a Smart City of Surveillance,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Cavoukian\xc2\xa0wrote\xc2\xa0in her resignation letter. Her concerns echoed those of residents who have long pointed to the privacy implications of handing over streets to the world\xe2\x80\x99s most profitable data hoover.\nIn response to questions from The Intercept about Cavoukian\xe2\x80\x99s resignation, a spokesperson for Sidewalk Labs said,\xc2\xa0 \xe2\x80\x9cSidewalk Labs has committed to implement, as a company, the principles of Privacy by Design. Though that question is settled, the question of whether other companies involved in the Quayside project would be required to do so is unlikely to be worked out soon, and may be out of Sidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99 hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\nNow, in an effort to get ahead of\xc2\xa0Quayside\xe2\x80\x99s development before it\xe2\x80\x99s too late, a coalition of experts and residents have launched a Toronto Open Smart Cities Forum. The group represents the latest and largest effort by Torontonians to start having the kinds of public conversations, teach-ins, and debates that should have \xe2\x80\x9ctaken place last year, when this project was first announced,\xe2\x80\x9d according to Bianca Wylie, co-founder of Tech Reset Canada and one of the lead organizers of the opposition to Sidewalk Toronto. \xe2\x80\x9cThe process Sidewalk Toronto has started has been so anti-democratic that the only way to participate is to be proactive in framing the topic,\xe2\x80\x9d Wylie continued.\nToronto Open Smart Cities Forum is taking the lead in the local fight against the commodification of its city\xe2\x80\x99s data. The group\xe2\x80\x99s struggle is one that urban residents around the world have been watching closely. Even those who never set foot in Canada may soon be subject to the products, norms, and techniques produced by Sidewalk Toronto, simply by virtue of using Google\xe2\x80\x99s earth-spanning services. \xe2\x80\x9cThis isn\xe2\x80\x99t just about data being sold,\xe2\x80\x9d Wylie said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s also about how is this data being used with other kinds of data in other products. You can move a lot of information around within Alphabet without having to sell it, and we need to talk about that.\xe2\x80\x9d The outcome of Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s ability to rein in the Google affiliate, in other words, has ramifications not just for Canadians, but also for the future of who controls our civic life.\nConceptual image of Sidewalk Toronto.\nImage: Sidewalk Toronto\nA City of Surveillance\nSidewalk Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s ongoing controversies may serve as the latest warning sign for cities who are considering signing over public spaces to major tech companies. Cavoukian\xe2\x80\x99s decision to quit represents only the most recent resignation in a series of departures that Wylie has referred to as an \xe2\x80\x9congoing bulldozing of stakeholders.\xe2\x80\x9d In addition to Cavoukian, a Waterfront Toronto\xc2\xa0board member and two Waterfront Toronto\xc2\xa0digital\xc2\xa0advisers have also resigned in the last five months. Three more digital advisers have also\xc2\xa0threatened to resign unless major changes are made to the project\xe2\x80\x99s planning process.\nIn anticipation of the negative press, Sidewalk Labs has allocated $11 million of its initial $50 million budget to \xe2\x80\x9ccommunications/engagement/and public relations.\xe2\x80\x9d This includes a strategy of building influencers \xe2\x80\x9cto ensure support for the Master Innovation and Development Plan among key constituents in Toronto.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Last week, iPolitics\xc2\xa0reported that Sidewalk Labs has begun lobbying at least\xc2\xa019 federal departments, including the prime minister\xe2\x80\x99s office, Environment and Climate Change Canada, the Public Health Agency of Canada, and the Treasury Board, among others. The meetings all took place days after the resignation of Cavoukian, the former Ontario privacy commissioner.\nBut so far, the project has been losing allies more quickly than it\xe2\x80\x99s been making them. When Saadia Muzaffar, a prominent technologist and the founder of TechGirls Canada, resigned from Waterfront Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s Digital Strategy Advisory Panel in October, it was due in part to the partnership\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cblatant disregard for resident concerns about data and digital infrastructure.\xe2\x80\x9d In her viral letter of resignation, Muzaffar criticized Sidewalk Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s dishonest negotiations process: \xe2\x80\x9cThere is nothing innovative about city-building that disenfranchises its residents in insidious ways and robs valuable earnings out of public budgets, or commits scarce public funds to the ongoing maintenance of technology that city leadership has not even declared a need for.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIf Google\xe2\x80\x99s other global projects are any indication, Sidewalk Lab\xe2\x80\x99s venture in Canada\xc2\xa0may hew closely to the Silicon Valley model of offering free services in exchange for the right to virtually limitless data collection. Sidewalk Labs-associated LinkNYC and InLinkUK kiosks have already been installed in New York and London. The kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 which include three cameras,\xc2\xa030 sensors, and Bluetooth beacons \xe2\x80\x94 aggregate anonymized data for advertising purposes in exchange for providing passersby with free Wi-Fi services.\nGiven that there is no genuine way to opt out of public space, Torontonians have been asking questions about what meaningful consent would look like. In the case of Quayside, the terms of any agreement\xc2\xa0wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t just cover Wi-Fi but could also extend to basic government services. Julie Di Lorenzo, a real estate developer who left Waterfront\xe2\x80\x99s board in July, explained to the AP that questions she had asked about residents who might not consent to share data had gone unanswered. She wanted to know if those who didn\xe2\x80\x99t opt-in to the city would be told that they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t live there. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s one thing to willingly install Alexa in your home,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Toronto journalist Brian Barth. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s another when publicly owned infrastructure \xe2\x80\x94 streets, bridges, parks and plazas \xe2\x80\x94 is Alexa, so to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAdding to these concerns is the fact that Sidewalk Labs has asked potential local consultants to hand over all of their intellectual property, according to a recent Globe and Mail investigation. As Jim Balsillie, the former CEO of Blackberry, recently pointed out in an\xc2\xa0op-ed, Waterfront Toronto has left the ownership of intellectual property\xc2\xa0and data unresolved in its latest agreement; this means that it would default to Sidewalk Labs, giving the company a gross market advantage. Indeed, in an\xc2\xa0announcement last year, Schmidt went as far as to thank Canadian taxpayers for creating some of Alphabet\xe2\x80\x99s key artificial intelligence technology, the\xc2\xa0intellectual property of which the company now owns. Balsillie noted that what happens in Toronto will \xe2\x80\x9chave profound and permanent impacts on the digital rights and prosperity of all Canadians because IP [intellectual property] and data \xe2\x80\x94 our century\xe2\x80\x99s most valuable extractive resources \xe2\x80\x94 spread seamlessly.\xe2\x80\x9d This is why current and former stakeholders in Waterfront Toronto have called for the public to receive financial benefits from the project, emphasizing that Canada\xe2\x80\x99s largest city should not simply be seen as a U.S. company\xe2\x80\x99s urban laboratory.\nThe Sidewalk Labs spokesperson said that\xc2\xa0the company\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9crelationship with its contractors does not impact its agreements with Waterfront Toronto in any way, including its commitment to the process laid out in the PDA,\xc2\xa0which says that in the future Waterfront Toronto may have rights to certain Sidewalk Labs IP. Of course, if Sidewalk Labs does not own the IP created by the planning process, it would not have the power to share or convey that IP to Waterfront Toronto or anyone else.\xe2\x80\x9dJoin Our NewsletterOriginal reporting. Fearless journalism. Delivered to you.I\xe2\x80\x99m inYet until recently, Sidewalk Labs refused to say who will own data produced by Quayside\xe2\x80\x99s visitors, workers, and residents in what it calls \xe2\x80\x9cthe most measurable community in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d Nor had the company clarified, despite facing pointed questions at public town hall-style meetings, whether or how the information streaming in from sensors in park benches, traffic lights, and dumpsters would be monetized. (The writer Evgeny Morozov has summed up Google\xe2\x80\x99s strategy as \xe2\x80\x9cNow everything is permitted \xe2\x80\x93 unless somebody complains.\xe2\x80\x9d)\nIn an apparent response to the mounting public pressure against the project, Sidewalk Labs recently released its first proposal for the digital governance of its collected data. Most significant among these plans was the suggestion that all data be placed in a \xe2\x80\x9ccivic data trust.\xe2\x80\x9d On the company\xe2\x80\x99s blog, Alyssa Harvey Dawson, Sidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99 Head of Data Governance, explained that with the proposed creation of a civic data trust, no one would have the \xe2\x80\x9cright to own information collected from Quayside\xe2\x80\x99s physical environment \xe2\x80\x94 including Sidewalk Labs.\xe2\x80\x9d This would represent, she wrote, \xe2\x80\x9ca new standard for responsible data use that protects personal privacy and the public interest while enabling companies, researchers, innovators, governments, and civic organizations to improve urban life using urban data.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAccording to experts who have been following the project closely, the details of how this trust might be implemented are vague and at times contradictory. On one hand, the proposal states that Sidewalk Labs would get no\xc2\xa0preferential\xc2\xa0access to any data that is collected. On the other, as Sean McDonald points out, \xe2\x80\x9cthe proposed trust would grant licenses to collect and use data \xe2\x80\x94 and the more sensitive the data, the more proprietary it would be.\xe2\x80\x9d There is also the question of just how\xc2\xa0anonymous certain data would be, and whether such\xc2\xa0anonymity would be reversible when it came to sharing information with law enforcement. Some residents are opposed to Sidewalk Labs having any involvement with this data proposal. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is as if Uber were to propose regulations on ride-sharing, or Airbnb were to tell city council how to govern short-term rentals. By definition, there is a conflict of interest,\xe2\x80\x9d writes Nabeel Ahmed, a smart city expert and member of the Toronto Open Smart Cities Forum.\nPart of the mission of the new Toronto Open Smart Cities Forum is to shift the public conversation away from debating the latest minutiae of the company\xe2\x80\x99s proposed terms and toward a broader consideration of whether the project should move forward under any terms at all. This conversation, Wylie emphasizes, should be taking place between residents and the government; Sidewalk Labs should not be the only voice setting the terms and advancing the agenda. \xe2\x80\x9cWe need to state clearly and unambiguously that this infrastructure is public,\xe2\x80\x9d Wylie said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can say in March, \xe2\x80\x98This data isn\xe2\x80\x99t being collected,\xe2\x80\x99 but then in July, it\xe2\x80\x99s updated to do something else. This infrastructure creates plausible surveillance so long as you always keep the door open to what\xe2\x80\x99s possible.\xe2\x80\x9dWe depend on the support of readers like you to help keep our nonprofit newsroom strong and independent. Squint hard enough to see the Manhattan skyline from your barely affordable studio apartment an hour into the outer boroughs, and you can just make out one last act of shameless groveling on the horizon:In celebration [of the winning bid for Amazon\xe2\x80\x99s HQ2 competition], several key New York City buildings, including the Empire State Building and One World Trade Center, along with electronic billboards and CityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC screens will light up in \xe2\x80\x9cAmazon Orange\xe2\x80\x9d tonight at 8:00 PM.AdvertisementNew York is projected to give up 4 million square feet of prime waterfront property and close to $3 billion in state and city subsidies and incentives to one of the most valuable companies on Earth in exchange for 25,000 jobs that are likely to drive up rents and choke mass transit.
