We are working to restore service.", b'3 Key Strategies for Successful Civic Engagement Using Technology\nTwitter\nRSS\nSubscribe and follow:\nAbout Us Events\n\xee\x80\xa5All upcoming events\nWebinars\nMeetups\nWorkshops\nPartner Events\nSummits\nPast Events\n\xee\x80\xa3The Next Urban FutureOctober 3, 2019\nEvent Overview\nWho\xe2\x80\x99s Coming?\nSponsors\nVenue\n\xee\x80\xa3Meeting of the Minds Annual Summit PhoenixFebruary 19-21, 2020\nEvent Overview\nWho\xe2\x80\x99s Coming?\nSponsors\nVenue and Lodging\n\xee\x80\xa3Stratford Mobility SummitMay 20, 2020\nEvent Overview\nWho\xe2\x80\x99s coming?\nSponsors\nVenue and Lodging\nBlog\nlMeeting of the Minds BlogThe Meeting of the Minds Blog features the writings of over 450 urban sustainability experts. The content is curated, edited, and published by the Meeting of the Minds staff, but rarely written by us. This is a place for urban practitioners to share their knowledge with others involved or interested in this important work.\nRecent Posts\nAnnouncements\nWriting Guidelines\nmFocus Areas\nEnvironment\nEconomy\nGovernance\nInfrastructure\nMobility\nResources\nSociety\nTechnology\n\xee\x80\x96Article Series\nThe Future of Cities Project\nBehavior Change Blog Series\nGlobal Mobility Research\nClimate Resiliency\nThe Future of Mobility in the Boston Region\nThe Future of Smart Cities\nDear 2050\nArchives\nPast Webinars\nPast Talks\nSelect Page\n3 Key Strategies for Successful Civic Engagement Using Technology\nBy Sandra RichterSandra Y. Richter is the CEO and Co-Founder of Soofa. While at MIT, she worked with municipalities in South Africa, Japan, China and Europe on smart transportation systems in collaboration with companies like Volkswagen, Lockheed Martin, and Verizon to define smart city strategies and evaluate business models. She co-founded Soofa in 2014 to deploy smart, social, and sustainable city technology in neighborhoods all around the world\nNov 14, 2018 | Governance, Technology | 1 comment\nI challenge you to become a great smart city catalyst. To transform your community by democratizing access to technology, adapting to your communities\xe2\x80\x99 needs, and learning from your mistakes. Cities are investing in housing, business, transportation, and technology to turn our urban centers into smart places that can cope with unprecedented growth. But there\xe2\x80\x99s one element at the heart of great urban leadership that is often overlooked: driving civic engagement. At Soofa, we think that the result of successful civic engagement is the betterment of the quality of life for all people in all communities in a city. This happens not necessarily through political processes, rather; through regular, two way communication between city leaders and citizens. For over a decade, I have worked with leaders in government, real estate, and business. Soofa has installed smart urban devices in over 120 cities around the world, and along the way we\xe2\x80\x99ve met countless people and have seen the diverse neighborhoods they build.\xc2\xa0I have travelled from Europe to the US, worked in China, Japan, and Africa, and have always followed the MIT Media Labs\xe2\x80\x99 principles, which guide our vision at Soofa and have shaped our own principles to enhance civic engagement. The challenge of creating a culture of civic engagement can be daunting. Our strategy to overcome this challenge has been crystalized in a number of design principles for success\xe2\x80\x94among them a flexible engagement platform that everyone, in every neighborhood, can access. Here are the key elements that define Soofa\xe2\x80\x99s approach to successful civic engagement using technology. \xc2\xa0 1. Make it Easy to Engage Constituents: Provide a Democratized, Easy, and Fun Way for Humans to Promote the Quality of Life in their Community Online and Offline. Giving a voice to a city, its people, and its businesses is what makes a smart city catalyst truly great and their city fully engaged. Studies show when community members are involved, contributing to the discourse, and acting as owners of change, their community thrives. We need to make it easy to engage online and offline and support catalysts from all neighborhoods, regardless of demographic or socioeconomic status. For a long time, \xe2\x80\x9ccivic engagement\xe2\x80\x9d meant going to community meetings: meetings with long agendas and few action items taking place in the middle of the day. Having participated in many of these meetings, I noticed the attendees are rarely representative of the community, and in particular, my generation of younger people is underrepresented. Some community leaders reacted to the lack of millennial involvement by sharing information and seeking public opinion on social networks, like sponsoring surveys on Facebook, engaging in dialogue on Twitter, or promoting specialized websites like CoUrbanize\xc2\xa0to facilitate community discussions and encourage democratized decision-making and action. Public engagement and influence have gone from personal, door-to-door interactions and neighborhood gatherings in a rec center or library to television advertisements to social media. The next generation engages in neighborhood politics with 280 characters and an emoji. While new platforms make it easy to participate, they also make it easy to tune out, and community members who aren\xe2\x80\x99t tech savvy or don\xe2\x80\x99t have access to the Internet are left out. This means we still face the same problems with new technology as we do with community meetings\xe2\x80\x94not everyone is heard and not everyone can engage. Good city leaders know this and communicate across multiple platforms online and offline. Posters and bulletin board ads, when well-designed, do capture my attention\xe2\x80\x94but more often than not, I\xe2\x80\x99ll get excited about the message only to realize it\xe2\x80\x99s for an event that has already happened. With the rise of social media and the ability to easily create event ads online, our public communication surfaces are not kept up-to-date\xe2\x80\x94and while accessible to all, flyers taped to every telephone pole litter our cities. The right mix of communications that link to citizens\xe2\x80\x99 daily lives to the futures they wish to create is key in a smart city. This includes both real people speaking to the community as well as mass communication on- and offline that can still be personalized and relevant for diverse audiences. As we think through city-wide communication strategy, we need to embrace and demand more digital surfaces in our cities, because they have the potential to reach and engage all citizens in the moment with the right message. Let\xe2\x80\x99s get serious about communication and marketing at the city level and invest in multi-channel civic engagement. Let\xe2\x80\x99s take back the billboards at our bus stops and use them to share messages about our neighborhoods. Let\xe2\x80\x99s regain a sense of ownership of the information we see when we wait for the subway and take advantage of the time our citizens are most engaged and captive\xe2\x80\x94sharing with them relevant, civically engaging content instead of one advertisement after the next.\nLearn more about bringing the Soofa Sign to your community.\nMore info\n2. Adapt to the Neighborhood: \xc2\xa0Be Humble, Listen, and Understand That There is No Cookie-Cutter Solution. The idea of multi-channel civic engagement and the role of the grassroots community marketer is being implemented by forward-thinking smart city leaders who understand the \xc2\xa0importance\xe2\x80\x94and economic benefits\xe2\x80\x94of giving their constituents a voice. More investments are being made into digital systems that reach and engage the public. Services like 311 are now app store-ready (like we see in Atlanta), amber alerts are pushed to all smart phones across the nation, and civic messages engaging the public are being pushed through new offline digital display networks. These systems are expensive to build, implement, and maintain. In the spirit of scalability and cost optimization\xe2\x80\x94both key features of a successful, sustainable smart city\xe2\x80\x94the digital infrastructure both for real-world and cloud-based applications is being standardized. The same is true for messaging when resources are tight. This is problematic for diverse communities and urban landscapes where the vibe and demographic composition changes from block to block. The installation of LinkNYC (digital kiosks) in New York City was a success in some neighborhoods, but was received with skepticism in others. Millions of dollars were spent to give citizens access to information, WiFi, and a voice\xe2\x80\x94but instead, they got a loud, bright platform reserved for national advertisers and misused services. As much as it was hoped that the content would be different for every neighborhood, relevant to the audience it was being served to, it often has ended up that broad messages and irrelevant advertisements blanketed the network. Not everywhere is Times Square, but often every neighborhood is seeing the same content being shown there. Soofa designs low-cost systems that are simple to deploy and have few, yet highly-demanded features. This is true for applications we build as well as for our technology-enabled infrastructure. We take a neighborhood-by-neighborhood or group-by-group approach and make time to listen to and implement feedback, allowing for the true customization our communities need. \xc2\xa0 3. Prototype, Learn from your Mistakes, and Think Through the Long-Term Financial Impact. This is more than a principle; it should be a pledge by all city leaders, industry partners, and everyone involved in making great cities around the world. Share experiences and learn from each other. Don\xe2\x80\x99t overthink, don\xe2\x80\x99t overbuild, always test, and iterate quickly. Great smart city leaders might have a grand vision, but they must work collaboratively and bring their community along for the journey. This creates supporters who feel empowered and leaders who are trusted to make the change we want to see and experience. I am often shocked by the budgets for planning civic engagement processes that are often years long and result in a thousand-page report that gets filed away in the dark recesses of city hall storage cabinets. Reports and plans play well with the risk aversion that is often found in city halls, but if when we don\xe2\x80\x99t act, these reports and plans live and die with a single administration. When adding tech into the equation, we think easy and cheap. But a good social media strategy that reaches everyone takes talent, time, iterative development, and lots of funding. Civic apps like 311 need to be maintained, and large kiosks are in the hundred thousand-dollar range for a single unit. Who is going to pay for that? Too often the answer is advertisers and sponsors. Advertisement and sponsorship can be a great way to support the public, but we need to be aware of the advertisers\xe2\x80\x99 intentions and remember to finance low-income neighborhood engagement as well as the bustling downtown streets and squares. The digital divide will only be worsened if we focus on social media strategy for those who have Internet access and advertising-supported digital outdoor platforms that are attractive in neighborhoods where the demographics and traffic volume appeal to advertisers. This is where a platform like the Soofa Sign\xe2\x80\x94solar-powered, affordable, and flexible\xe2\x80\x94meets the needs of cities large and small and benefits everyone from the most affluent neighborhoods to those in transition. As smart city leaders and changemakers, I ask you to always remember\xc2\xa0to put people first and technology second. Citizen engagement is always evolving; there are always new tools and methods. First and foremost, though, smart cities need stewardship and maintenance. They need leaders who work hard to understand the needs of all people and build trust through collaboration and iteration. Someone needs to pay to make even the simplest of smart city visions real, and we need a sustainable business model that can scale to meet the grandest vision. Our cities deserve less paperwork, less bureaucracy, and more courage.\nDiscussion Leave your comment below, or reply to others.\n1 Comment\nAndrew M Manshel\non November 14, 2018 at 7:52 am\nHappy to chat with you over coffee any time. Andy Manshel. New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. Reply\nSubmit a Comment Cancel reply\nYour email address will not be published. Required fields are marked *Comment Name *\nEmail *\nWebsite\nNotify me of followup comments via e-mail. You can also subscribe without commenting.Submit Comment\nThis site uses Akismet to reduce spam. Learn how your comment data is processed.\nRead more from the Meeting of the Minds Blog Spotlighting innovations in urban sustainability and connected technology\nDowntown Revitalization Efforts Create a Market for Contractors by Mary Scott Nabers A recent study by the International Downtown Association reports that vibrant downtowns contain around 3% of citywide land, but contain 14% of all citywide retail and food and beverage businesses, and 35% of all hotel rooms. This results in $53 million in sales tax per square mile, compared to the citywide average of $5 million. Not to mention that downtown residential buildings also add to the tax base. In the 24 cities included in the study, residential growth in these downtowns outpaced the rest of the city by 400% between 2010 and 2016. Partnerships between city officials and contractors result in new and visionary downtown destinations. Along with large vertical construction projects, there are opportunities for countless other projects, including parking structures, enhanced Wi-Fi, landscaping, pedestrian and biking paths, and traffic improvements.\nThe Future of Cities\nby Dr. Nikos A. Salingaros Ordered city geometry that is built today is meaningless for energy cycles. Resilient networks contain inherent diversity and redundancy, with optimal cooperation among their subsystems, yet they avoid optimization (maximum efficiency) for any single process. They require continuous input of energy in order to function, with energy cycles running simultaneously on many different scales. Short-term urban fixes only wish to perpetuate the extractive model of cities, not to correct its underlying long-term fragility!\nShowing Results Will Win More Funding for Transit Projects\nby Paul Mackie TDM, when employed, works. TDM agencies around the country use a treasure\xe2\x80\x99s trove of strategies to get people out of cars and onto trains, buses, and bikes, which is something that has to happen if we don\xe2\x80\x99t want our roads to become unusable due to traffic and environmental congestion. But one major problem with the practice of TDM is that it has had a hard time making the case that it is a cost-effective alternative or at least add-on to big infrastructure projects. It seems pretty obvious that teaching people, educating them, about how to use our systems will make those systems run more smoothly. But there has never been a great way to back up that assumption with hard numbers.\nMeeting of the Minds is made possible by the generous support of these organizations.\nJoin our email list to keep up-to-date with our events and resources.We bring\xc2\xa0together leaders from multiple sectors and diverse geographies to share ideas and work together to shape a common urban agenda. Events include monthly webinars, workshops, pop-up events and an annual summit held each fall.\nSubscribe\nYou have successfully subscribed.\nMeet the smart people building smart cities.Quick LinksContact Us Blog Writing Guidelines Media Inquiries Privacy Policy Downloads2019-2020 Prospectus Logo and Company Bio Annual Reports The Annual Magazine ApplicationsScholarship Application Volunteer Application Job Openings\nTwitter\nRSS\nShare This\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nreddit', b"Delivery Service Hyper-Targets Hungry Office Workers In LinkNYC Campaign - Sixteen:Nine\nSkip to content\nMenu\nABOUT 16:9\nCONSULTING\nSPEAKING\n16:9 PODCAST\nCONTACT\nALL DIGITAL SIGNAGE, SOME SNARK\nSearch\nMenu\nPODCAST\nTECHNOLOGY\nCREATIVE\nPROJECTS\nBUSINESS\nSearch\nDelivery Service Hyper-Targets Hungry Office Workers In LinkNYC Campaign\nNovember 14, 2018 by Dave Haynes\nThis is simple example of geo-targeting for a Digital OOH ad campaign \xe2\x80\x93 with contextual spots for the food delivery service delivery.com zeroed down to the neighborhood and time of day.\nThe hyperlocal campaign is running on Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC network, which is big 55-inch back-to-back screens on monolithic sidewalk fixtures. The targeting tactics are based around things like calls to action for delivery, around lunchtime, near office towers.\nNo real revelation here, but the ease of doing this is in many respects tied to how much data a network has about the specific screen location, and what\xe2\x80\x99s around it. With the right rules-based scheduling engine, the targeting could get a lot more granular than this.\nBioTwitterLinkedInLatest Posts\nDave HaynesEditor/Founder at Sixteen:NineDave Haynes is the founder and editor of Sixteen:Nine, an online publication that has followed the digital signage industry for more than 12 years. Dave does strategic advisory consulting work for many end-users and vendors, and also writes for many of them. He's based near Halifax, Nova Scotia.\n@sixteennine13-year-old blog & podcast about digital signage & related tech, written by consultant, analyst & BS filter Dave Haynes. DNA test - 90% Celt/10% Viking. \xf0\x9f\x98\x8f\xf0\x9f\x98\x9c\xf0\x9f\x8d\xba.@DPAAorg Study Suggests Awareness, Understanding And Use Of #DOOH All On Rise https://t.co/1ssd0FpD9E https://t.co/A5tSloupWL - 3 hours agoFollow @sixteennine\nLatest posts by Dave Haynes (see all)\nDPAA Study: Awareness, Understanding And Use Of DOOH All On Rise - June 21, 2019\nComQi, AUO Team Up On Swappable, Upgradeable Smart Digital Signage Displays - June 21, 2019\nDebacle On 34th Street: One Very Big, Very Out Fine Pitch LED - June 20, 2019\nShare this:TwitterLinkedInEmailPrintMoreReddit\nCategories CREATIVE, Digital OOH, IoT, TECHNOLOGYTags advertising, delivery.com, Digital OOH, Intersection, LinkNYC, New York\nPost navigation\nIntel Adds More Data, Capabilities To Its Real Sense Depth-Sensing CamerasMall Research Suggests Targeted Digital OOH Ads Can Drive Double-Digit Store Sales\n1 thought on \xe2\x80\x9cDelivery Service Hyper-Targets Hungry Office Workers In LinkNYC Campaign\xe2\x80\x9d\nbeth\nNovember 14, 2018 at 7:27 PM\ngreat to know \xe2\x80\x93 is there a mobile component that can \xe2\x80\x9ccatch\xe2\x80\x9d a message, alert or call to action for those in the immediate vicinity?\notherwise, it\xe2\x80\x99s a great example and something Dominos and Taco\nabel might appreciate seeing a use case\nComments are closed.\n16:9 Sponsors\nAbout Sixteen:Nine SIXTEEN:NINE is an online news and analysis publication focused on the digital signage industry \xe2\x80\x93 vendors and end-users. We filter the BS. We ignore most press releases. We celebrate great work. And we point out stupidity. There are 6,700+ articles here, and the count grows daily. Tracing back to early 2006, 16:9 is in many ways a running history of the digital signage industry. Founding Editor Dave Haynes has built and run companies in this business, and he\xe2\x80\x99s consulted for scores of companies. In other words, he knows his stuff.\nSixteen:Nine Podcast \xe2\x80\x93 more than 150 episodes and counting\nTwitter: @sixteennine\nSubscribe to Blog via Email\nEnter your email address to subscribe to this blog and receive notifications of new posts by email.\nEmail Address\nAbout 16:9 Sixteen:Nine has been covering the digital signage industry daily since Feb. 2006. They were given these certifications for 2017. Now for the first time, What Works Cities has published its certification criteria for 2018, doing so in a\xc2\xa0post on medium.\nIn addition to laying out a ton of specific and useful information for cities, the post also notes that \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Works Cities Certification is the standard of excellence for data-driven local government. The program\xe2\x80\x99s 45 criteria outline the people, processes, and policies foundational to a well-managed city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nRELATEDWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: Can Alaska Help Solve Climate Change?What\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: Civic Technologists Work to Educate, Mobilize VotersWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: New Directory Maps the Top Civic Innovation LabsThe relevant criteria are grouped into eight foundational practices, including data governance, evaluations, general management, open data, performance and analytics, repurposing, results-driven contracting, and stakeholder engagement.\nThis year\xe2\x80\x99s criteria is a revised and updated version of last year\xe2\x80\x99s. In 2017, more than 230 cities applied for this benchmarking program. To be eligible for 2018 certification, local governments must submit their assessments by Dec. 31, 2018. Click here for more information about What Works Cities Certification.\nNew York City Uses Kiosks to Showcase Historic Photos\nNew York City has launched a new program aimed at sharing more of its historic photographs with residents and visitors through a collaborative effort between its LinkNYC kiosks program and its Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT). The program is called Historic NYC and it brings historic photographs of New York\xe2\x80\x99s world-famous landmarks and streets to the Link kiosks spread throughout all five boroughs.\nAlso partnering on this program are the Museum of the City of New York (MCNY) and Urban Archive. The photos are being provided by the museum while Urban Archive\xe2\x80\x99s mapping technology is making the location-based displaying possible within a couple hundred feet of where the individual photographs were first taken.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome of the new photography includes Staten Island\xe2\x80\x99s Richmond Club in 1895, the Forest Hills Inn in Queens from 1916, the Williamsburgh Savings Bank tower in Brooklyn in 1929, and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx from 1937. Links will feature the exact address at which the photo was taken, the distance from the Link showing the photo, as well as the photographer and the year the photograph was taken,\xe2\x80\x9d the city said in a press release.\nThis is a pretty noteworthy campaign, in that it expresses a truth about such kiosk programs, which have become popular in other major cities as well, and that truth is that there are many new and creative uses for this tech that have yet to be explored.\nClick here to see some of the photos.\nTrio of Major World Cities Form Coalition for Digital Rights\nIn other New York City news, the jurisdiction is teaming with Amsterdam and Barcelona to form a new coalition for digital rights.\nThe three cities have launched an effort dubbed Cities Coalition for Digital Rights, an initiative aimed at both promoting and tracking progress they are making toward better protecting the digital rights of residents of and visitors to their cities.\nThe idea is for this new coalition to help with the creation of things like policies, tools and resources that can advance burgeoning digital rights efforts. The group\xe2\x80\x99s work will also align with the Charter for Human Rights and Principles for the Internet, which was established by the UN\xe2\x80\x99s Internet Governance Forum.\nIn a press release this week, the cities noted this is the first time that cities have come together to protect digital rights on a global scale.\nThere are five shared principles at work, and organizers say they expect them to help set the agenda for policy discussions as well as with other cities in the future. The five principles are as follows:\nUniversal and equal access to the Internet, and digital literacy\nPrivacy, data protection and security\nTransparency, accountability, and non-discrimination of data, content and algorithm\nParticipatory democracy, diversity and inclusion\nOpen and ethical digital service standards\nFull details about all of this are available at https://citiesfordigitalrights.org.\nA Weekly Chicago Civic Tech Meetup Has Evolved into a Membership-based Nonprofit\nChi Hack Night, the prolific weekly Chicago-based civic tech meetup, has evolved into a membership-based nonprofit organization, the group has announced on its website.\nChi Hack Night co-founder Derek Eder detailed the changes in the post, noting that \xe2\x80\x9cin December 2018, Chi Hack Night will incorporate as an independent, membership-driven 501(c)3 non-profit organization. We will invite attendees to become voting members and elect who will serve on our Board of Directors. And on December 11th, we will hold a town hall feedback session about these changes at Chi Hack Night.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThis marks a major evolution for Chi Hack Night, which has been running every Tuesday night in the city for roughly six and a half years, attracting notable attendees who have ranged from candidates for governor to employees of the city\xe2\x80\x99s tech and innovation department. In fact, before leaving city service, then-Chief Data Officer Tom Schenk attended all of the group\xe2\x80\x99s meetings.\nThe format for Chi Hack Night features food, speakers and time to invest in civic tech projects in various stages of completion. The group has a long resume of projects it has helped complete, with notable examples ranging from a website that provides easy access to lobbying data to a visualization of vacant buildings to an online snowplow tracker. Chi Hack Night has drawn interest from all levels of government, been featured in the Chicago Tribune and inspired copycat efforts as far away as Toronto.\nIncorporating as a nonprofit will essentially formalize the group moving from an ad hoc setup to one wherein decisions are made democratically by a more diverse leadership structure.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been running Chi Hack Night for almost seven years,\xe2\x80\x9d Eder wrote in his announcement. \xe2\x80\x9cIt has grown beyond me. In order for Chi Hack Night to grow and sustain itself, I need to give up some of my power and distribute it to others. By spreading this power around, Chi Hack Night will become stronger and better equipped to inspire and promote civic engagement and technology.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOther Civic Tech News This Week:\nWhy Chicago Added a Design Office to City Hall\nBismarck, N.D.'s Mobile App Goes Live\nAccessibility a Key Focus of Lima, Ohio\xe2\x80\x99s New Website\nCity Council Defers to Feds, Tabling Drone Ordinance\nCalifornia Students Teach Coding to Kids in Shelters\nZack Quaintance\nAssistant News Editor\nZack Quaintance is the assistant news editor for Government Technology. His background includes writing for daily newspapers across the country and developing content for a software company in Austin, Texas. He is now based in Washington, D.C. He can be reached via email.\nRELATED\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: Can Alaska Help Solve Climate Change?\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s New in Civic Tech: Civic Technologists Work to Educate, Mobilize Center\nNetscout Video Resource Center\nThe 5G Exchange\nAutomation Exchange\nWhite Papers\nUpcoming Webinars\nWebinar Archives\n5G Webinars\nLiveLearning Webinars\nMobile / Carrier WiFi\nLinkNYC Kiosks Could Become a Launch Pad for City 5G\nNews AnalysisDan Jones, Mobile Editor11/19/2018Comment (0)Login50%50%\nTweet\nIs this the future home for 5G connectivity in cities like New York?\nA LinkNYC WiFi kiosk.\nIt could be, as the president of Link explained at last Thursday\'s Future of Cable Business Services event in midtown Manhattan. Talking to Light Reading after her appearance, she explained that the company is well aware of the possibility of using its public WiFi kiosks as street mountings for 5G small cells or repeaters. (See Bright Lights, Smart City: A \'Street Furniture\' Exploration.)\nJen Hensley, president of LinkNYC, describes the kiosks as "an endpoint that is going to be increasingly valuable over time," with 5G deployments a definite possibility in the future. The company is already talking with partners about the 5G prospects, she said. "We\'ve been at it a couple of years," she noted.\nQuestions about who would control any 5G small cells are still in play, while the city of New York would still have design rights over the "street furniture" to be deployed on the nine-and-a-half-foot tall kiosks.\nNonetheless, using the LinkNYC kiosks as 5G hosts would make sense for deployments in dense urban locales such as Manhattan. Each kiosk is served via a gigabit fiber connection already and the small cell could be powered at the source.\nThe kiosks could help address the range limitations of high-band 28GHz millimeter 5G, which operators have been testing at ranges of 1,000 to 2,000 feet for gigabit connectivity. (See 5G: The Density Question .)\nIn areas like midtown Manhattan, operators already use the kiosks to deploy at every block in many areas. LinkNYC is currently due to roll out 7,500 kiosks across the five boroughs, about five times the number deployed so far.\nLink President Jen Hensley discusses city connectivity with Light Reading\'s Alan Breznick.\nLinkNYC is backed by Google\n(Nasdaq: GOOG)\'s Intersection unit, Qualcomm Inc.\n(Nasdaq: QCOM) and QMX Smartscapes. Qualcomm has already announced plans to make mmWave small cell chipsets, expected to be available in commercial devices sometime around late 2020. (See Qualcomm & Samsung to Work on 5G Small Cells and Qualcomm Spills LinkNYC\'s Guts.).)\nLink is also expanding its footprint. As well as NYC, the operation is deploying kiosks in parts of Newark, NJ, and elsewhere. "We\'ve just started in Philly," Hensley noted. It also has 300 units deployed in the UK as LinkLondon. (See\nLinkNYC Now Live in All 5 Boroughs.)\n\xe2\x80\x94 Dan Jones, Mobile Editor, Light Reading\nLike what we have to say? this box]', b'LinkNYC helps residents learn about borough through photos\nHomeCreate AccountLog InGoHome\nPrint\nLinkNYC helps residents learn about borough through photos\nPosted:\nMonday, November 19, 2018 7:49 PM EST\nUpdated:\nTuesday, November 20, 2018 9:46 AM EST\nTHE BRONX -\nLinkNYC is helping residents learn about the history of the borough through photographs.LinkNYC, which has been connecting New Yorkers using free calling and Wi-Fi services, is incorporating photos into its more than 1,700 kiosks.The photos of New York streetscapes, buildings and scenes from everyday life were taken from the Museum of the City of New York.VIDEO: LinkNYC uses buildings and scenes from Museum of the City of New YorkThey will join the rotating slideshow of bus and subway arrival times, New York City fun facts, and advertisements - which the city says pays for the links.Critics of the links point out its potential for mass surveillance because of its Bluetooth capabilities and outward facing cameras.Others argue it adds color to an otherwise bland commute.LinkNYC hopes to install over 7,500 more platforms over the next several years.LinkNYC says the kiosks do\xc2\xa0not collect personal information and that the company has a strong privacy policy that forbids the collection of personal data.\nTop StoriesMore>>Man approaches police for help after being stabbed in University site', b'Small Business Saturday campaigns call for New Yorkers to shop local | am New York\nMenu\nLATEST PAPER\nSEARCH\nNews\nPolitics\nThings To Do\nEAT & DRINK\nEntertainment\nReal Estate\nTransit\nOpinion\nLATEST PAPER\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nHome\nNews\nPolitics\nElections\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nPets\nSecrets of NY\nReal Estate\nCity Living\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nStaten Island\nTransit\nSports\nOpinion\nJim Marguiles\nCartoon roundup\nWeather\n76\xc2\xb0\n6/21/2019\nGood Evening\nNews\nSmall Business Saturday campaigns call for New Yorkers to shop local\nEvents include a crawl in Astoria.\nNicole Panettieri, owner of The Brass Owl boutique, organizes the Small Business Saturday Retail Crawl in Astoria.\nPhoto Credit: The Brass Owl\nBy Alison Fox alison.fox@amny.com\nUpdated November 20, 2018 11:25 AM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nWhen the family meals are put away and the pies have all been eaten on Thanksgiving weekend, many\xc2\xa0people reach for their credit cards. All across New York City, small businesses are hoping to get a piece of the action.\nWhile Black Friday conjures up images of long lines outside big-box stores and people fighting over televisions, local shops\xc2\xa0are working to get customers through the doors both on the big day, as well as Small Business Saturday.\n"This really kicks off the holiday season for us and it is usually one of our busiest days of the year," said\xc2\xa0Lexi Beach, who owns Astoria Bookshop, of Saturday. The mom-and-pop bookstore is participating in the neighborhood\'s Small Business Saturday Retail Crawl, in which customers get "passport" stamps for each participating store they visit and \xe2\x80\x94 if they collect five or more \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0can enter to win gift cards worth $450.\n"It\'s really festive," Beach said. "We\'ve found it to be really successful, and we love seeing the excitement of people who just love supporting local businesses."\nNicole Panettieri, owner The Brass Owl, a boutique in Astoria,\xc2\xa0organizes the retail crawl, now in its fourth year. Last year, more than 250 people turned in their "passports," she said. Eighteen businesses are participating in this year\'s crawl.\n"There\'s that nostalgic mentality for New Yorkers having mom-and-pop shops. People really love supporting the local businesses," Panettieri said. "All the owners here, because we live here, we really keep the neighborhood\'s best interest in mind when we\'re curating the shops."\nIn Brooklyn, the Atlantic Avenue Business Improvement District is doing a monthlong\xc2\xa0photo campaign running on a dozen LinkNYC kiosks in the borough\xc2\xa0starting Saturday, hoping to emphasize the personalities and faces behind some of the area\'s locally-owned shops.\n"It\'s not just about shopping for gifts. But the reason people go to these places and go back to them is the wonderful relationships people have, and we want to celebrate that," said\xc2\xa0Sara Nordmann, the executive director of the Atlantic Avenue BID. "I\xc2\xa0realize that shopping online has its appeals \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0it\'s convenient. You can\'t reason people out of it. [But] if they want to have a nice place to live with active street life, with people to say hello to, with something interesting to see .\xe2\x80\x82.\xe2\x80\x82. they need to make a commitment to brick-and-mortar and to the people behind it."\nGet Breaking News emails\nThe latest about your city, as it happens.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\nKaren Zebulon, of the children\'s store Gumbo, is participating in the Atlantic Avenue BID\'s Small Business Saturday campaign. Photo Credit: Photomuse / Kristin Reimer\nEva Dayton, the founder of Consignment Brooklyn on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, hopes Friday and Saturday will be a big family shopping weekend. She is planning on giving away essential oil candles with a $100 purchase\xc2\xa0and was thinking of serving a hot cocktail \xe2\x80\x94 "just something to make it a little more cozy," she said.\n"I think it will draw in more family people in the neighborhood as opposed to just regular shoppers. I\xc2\xa0feel like people stay around this neighborhood for Thanksgiving," she said. "It\'s nice to just do a little something."\nGregg Bishop, the city\'s Department of Small Business Services commissioner,\xc2\xa0said the agency tries to prepare small businesses for the big shopping weekend \xe2\x80\x94 and the holiday season that follows \xe2\x80\x94 with workshops and marketing tips, as well as\xc2\xa0pushing out the message to shop small on social media and through radio advertisements. SBS is also participating in a lighting ceremony at the Empire State Building on Nov. 21 in celebration of Small Business Saturday.\nBishop\xc2\xa0said smaller shops can actually have a few advantages over the bigger ones.\n"You don\'t have the crowds, all the negative stuff that you see," he said. "You have the flexibility of knowing you can walk into a store\xc2\xa0and find something unique."\nStill, Karen Zebulon, who owns the Boerum Hill children\'s store\xc2\xa0Gumbo, said Black Friday and Small Business Saturday are not very busy for her. Instead, the last couple of weeks before Christmas are when business really picks up.\n"I always think of Black Friday as a big-box store, people are running to get the big technology items. They\'re not really going into the small stores as much on Friday," she said, adding she wishes Small Business Saturday was not the same weekend as Black Friday. "People have gone out, they\'ve spent huge amounts of money. I\xc2\xa0just feel like it overpowers Small Business Saturday. It\'s hard for people to even focus on it or recognize it."\nBy Alison Fox alison.fox@amny.com\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe\'re revamping our Comments section. Learn more and share your input.\nMost popular\nWhat to know before watching the Central Park 5 series \'Mrs. Maisel\' giving out free Midge-approved lunches MTA touts 7 train performance as it fights for funding Senate, Assembly pass\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill A look at where the Central Park 5 are now\nTop News stories\nHere\'s what\'s in the NY\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill\nYour guide to next week\'s primary elections\nHALT solitary confinement fails, but lawmakers strike a deal\nSenate, Assembly pass\xc2\xa0marijuana decriminalization bill\nWatch the Democratic presidential debates at these parties\nMan who spray-painted\xc2\xa0anti-Muslim messages\xc2\xa0arrested: Cops\nNews photos & videos\nDon\'t just march, celebrate at these Pride parties\nStonewall\'s resident bartender Tree recalls riots ahead of 50th anniversary\nHow does a guide dog train in NYC?\nCentral Park puts finishing touches on Belvedere Castle\nThe best places to view the July Fourth fireworks\nSee scenes from this year\'s Puerto Rican Day Parade\nQuick Links\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s paper\nNewsletters\nSecrets of New York\nEvents this week\nWeekend Best Bets\nStaff & Bios\nSitemap\nPartners\nNewsday\nNews 12\nNewsday Homes\nNewsday Jobs\nNewsday Connect\nHometown Shopper\nNews12 Varsity\nSections\nNews\nTransit\nPolitics\nElections\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nContact us | Jobs at amnewyork | PRIVACY\nPOLICY | TERMS OF SERVICE\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\n240 W 35TH ST., 9TH FLOOR NY, NY 10001 646.293.9499 FAX: 212.239.2828 | Newsday. All rights reserved.', b'LinkNYC, DoITT, the Museum of the City of New York and Urban Archive Launch\xc2\xa0Historic NYC: Photography from NYC History Displayed on Links Across the City - The Bronx Chronicle\nFollow Us\nFacebookTwitterRSS FeedEmail us a tipYoutube\nABOUT\nContact\nJoin Our Team!\nBULLETIN BOARD\nFriday, June 21, 2019\nNews\nLocal News\nDomestic News\nWorld News\nEditorials\nSports\nPartners\nVideo\nFeatures\nSections\nPolitics\nFood & Restaurants\nVeterans\nCultures\nPersonal Finance\nEducation News\nScience\nAnimal Issues\nPhotos\nAll Sections\nBronx Landmarks\nLinkNYC, DoITT, the Museum of the City of New York and Urban Archive Launch\xc2\xa0Historic NYC: Photography from NYC History Displayed on Links Across the City\nNovember 24, 2018 2:01 PM\xc2\xb7\nLinkNYC, DoITT, the Museum of the City of New York and Urban Archive Launch\xc2\xa0Historic NYC: Photography from NYC History Displayed on Links Across the City\nThe Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s historic photos showcased on Links in all five boroughs\nNEW YORK \xe2\x80\x93\xc2\xa0LinkNYC and the Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications (DoITT) today launched Historic NYC, which brings historic photography of New York City landmarks and streets to all Links across the five boroughs. In partnership with the Museum of the City of New York (MCNY) and Urban Archive, historic photos from the MCNY archive will be featured on the Links\xe2\x80\x99 55-inch digital displays within a couple hundred feet of the photo\xe2\x80\x99s location of capture, which is made possible by Urban Archive\xe2\x80\x99s mapping technology. This dynamic campaign will highlight MCNY\xe2\x80\x99s rich collection of historic photos and surface thousands of them across the entire Link network.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith an expansive five-borough network, LinkNYC is giving New Yorkers and visitors alike the ability to travel back in time with historic photography of the neighborhoods where we live, work and visit. Thanks to the rich archive and mapping technology from the Museum of the City of New York and Urban Archive, we are providing a way for all of us to feel more connected to the city and its history,\xe2\x80\x9d said\xc2\xa0Ruth Fasoldt, Link\xe2\x80\x99s Director of External Affairs.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis mapping technology creates an exciting new way for New Yorkers and visitors to see historic photography of the streets they\xe2\x80\x99re walking on just by passing a LinkNYC kiosk,\xe2\x80\x9d said\xc2\xa0Samir Saini, Commissioner of the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are thrilled to partner with MCNY to demonstrate the value of data visualization through this unique experience that everyone walking down the street can enjoy.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur expansive collection of more than 750,000 objects, including photography, documents New York City\xe2\x80\x99s history dating back to the 17th\xc2\xa0Century,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0said Whitney Donhauser,\xc2\xa0Ronay Menschel Director\xc2\xa0and President, Museum of the City of New York. \xe2\x80\x9cWorking with LinkNYC, DoITT, and Urban Archive enables us to provide content beyond the walls of the Museum while creating unique experiences for New Yorkers and tourists alike.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur partnership with LinkNYC and MCNY is a perfect example of what can be done when technology, open city data and history are combined. The LinkNYC integration showcases MCNY\xe2\x80\x99s digital collections in relevant locations while encouraging the exploration of city history,\xe2\x80\x9d said\xc2\xa0Tim Bradley, Urban Archive\xe2\x80\x99s Director.\nSome of the new photography includes Staten Island\xe2\x80\x99s Richmond Club in 1895, the Forest Hills Inn in Queens from 1916, the Williamsburgh Savings Bank tower in Brooklyn in 1929, and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx from 1937. Links will feature the exact address at which the photo was taken, the distance from the Link showing the photo, as well as the photographer and the year the photograph was taken.\nAbout LinkNYC\nLinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\xe2\x80\x99s payphones to build the world\xe2\x80\x99s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,700 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next few years.\nLinkNYC provides important tools to communities to access connectivity and social services. More than 5 million people \xe2\x80\x93 more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Los Angeles, and Houston \xe2\x80\x93 have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of new users joining the network each week. The system sees 500,000 phone calls made every month, and the most commonly dialed number is for the NY State EBT customer service line, which helps families connect to food stamps and other assistance. Tens of thousands of New Yorkers access 311 and Aunt Bertha, a platform to connect with local nonprofits and services, via Link tablets every month to access housing and other resources.\nAll of Link\xe2\x80\x99s services are 100% free for users and come at no cost to taxpayers.\nFor more information and to find a Link near you,visit\xc2\xa0link.nyc.\nAbout the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT)\nDoITT is the technology core of New York City government, working with over 100 city agencies and entities to deliver the IT products and services they need to serve and empower New Yorkers and keep our five boroughs safe, strong, and vibrant. For more information, visitnyc.gov/DoITT\xc2\xa0or visit us on\xc2\xa0Facebook\xc2\xa0or\xc2\xa0Twitter.\nAbout the Museum of the City of New York\nThe Museum of the City of New York fosters understanding of the distinctive nature of urban life in the world\xe2\x80\x99s most influential metropolis. It engages visitors by celebrating, documenting, and interpreting the city\xe2\x80\x99s past, present, and future. The Museum serves the people of the city as well as visitors from around the world through exhibitions, school and public programs, publications, and collections. To connect with the Museum on social media, follow us on Instagram and Twitter at @MuseumofCityNY and visit our Facebook page atFacebook.com/MuseumofCityNY. For more information please visit\xc2\xa0www.mcny.org.\nAbout Urban Archive\nUrban Archive is a technology nonprofit that creates new connections between people, places, and cultural institutions in New York City. We develop fun and informative applications that bring together the digital collections of the city\xe2\x80\x99s museums, archives, and libraries in an easy-to-use resource built for discovery. Our mission is to inspire learning that\xe2\x80\x99s rooted in what\xe2\x80\x99s local \xe2\x80\x93 the architecture, culture, and unique stories of New York City.\nTo connect with Urban Archive, follow @UrbanArchiveNY on\xc2\xa0Instagram\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Twitter\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0download the Urban Archive app, available for free in the App Store. For more information please visit\xc2\xa0urbanarchive.nyc.\nYou Should Read:\nNothing yet!\nTweet\nAuthor: The Bronx Chronicle\nSUPPORTING YOUR FELLOW CITIZENS\nCopyright \xc2\xa9 2019 \xe2\x80\x94 The Bronx Chronicle. 5:04 pm\nHadas Kuznits | KYW Newsradio\nCategories:\nLocal News\nPHILADELPHIA (KYW Newsradio) -- The first of 100 kiosks for free phone charging, WiFi, phone calls and information have been unveiled on the sidewalk at 1835 Market Street.\xc2\xa0Jen Hensley, President of Link at Intersection, explains the LinkPHL kiosks are secure WiFi hotspots that provide super fast service.\xc2\xa0"We don\'t have passwords associated with our information," Hensley said. "It\'s a WiFi connection that you can download through an app on your phone, and that provides fully encrypted WiFi connectivity, and you\'re connected automatically any time you\'re within the range of a LinkPHL kiosk."\xc2\xa0The kiosks are paid for by advertising displayed on the 55-inch kiosk screens. They also have USB ports for phone charging and more.\xc2\xa0"We have an integrated tablet where you can make free phone calls anywhere in the United States," Hensley said. "You can access information, city services, social services, weather and transit information. There\'s also a maps feature. So people should just play around with the tablet. There\'s no login required and we don\'t take any personal information from using the tablets."\xc2\xa0We sure have come a long way from public payphones.\xc2\xa0"It\'s true. It is the payphone of the future, but way cooler," Hensley said. "And free. No quarters needed."\nFirst of many free phone charging and WiFi kiosks unveiled in Center City\nTags:\nHadas Kuznits\nLinkPHL\nWiFi\nPhiladelphia Free Wifi\nFree Wifi\nWifi Kiosks\nFOLLOW US\nPhone: 855-KYW-NEWS (599-6397)\nWhen texting this station, message & data rates apply. Message frequency is recurring and varies. Reply STOP to cancel. Benefits\nSearch\n* Subscriber Services\nAccount Center\nCarrier Portal\nBuy Our Photos\nShare This\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nClose\n1 of 5\nCaption +\nThis payphone in Uintah Gardens works.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nAn empty hole is all that remains of this pay phone on South Hancock Avenue.\nCOURTESY photo\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nPart of the receiver is missing on this payphone at Galley Road and Academy Boulevard.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nThe payphone outside the bus terminal is missing from its holder.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nThis payphone in the Teller County Courthouse was turned off last year due to lack of use. Photo by Debbie Kelley\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nShow MoreShow Less\nDon't write the pay-phone eulogy yet\nBy: Debbie Kelley\nDebbie Kelley\nReporter\nDec 9, 2018\nComments\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nCaption +\nThis payphone in Uintah Gardens works.\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nAn empty hole is all that remains of this pay phone on South Hancock Avenue.\nCOURTESY photo\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nPart of the receiver is missing on this payphone at Galley Road and Academy Boulevard.\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nThe payphone outside the bus terminal is missing from its holder.\nShow MoreShow Less\nCaption +\nThis payphone in the Teller County Courthouse was turned off last year due to lack of use. Photo by Debbie Kelley\nShow MoreShow Less\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nWhile it\xe2\x80\x99s nowhere near the lifeline it used to be, the pay phone isn\xe2\x80\x99t extinct yet. It is, however, on the endangered list and hanging by a thin cord.About 99,800 public pay phones still operate in the U.S., down from 2.1 million in 1999, according to the Federal Communications Commission, which regulates operations. New York has the most of any state, about one-fifth of the remaining pay phones, and North Dakota has the fewest, about 100.Colorado had 1,246 usable pay phones as of March 2016, the latest data available.\nNot many remain in Colorado Springs. Those prime locations in front of convenience stores now are occupied by Redbox movie-rental machines, and the phones have been removed from city and El Paso County buildings, including jails.\n'New' Westside Community Garden is looking for a few green thumbsDefunct pay phones with torn wires, missing receivers, graffiti or other vandalism can be found here and there, outside the Greyhound bus station downtown, in the parking lot of a Native Roots grass and gas station on Academy Boulevard and near a 7-Eleven in the Hillside neighborhood, for instance.But a few still work, including one at Uintah Gardens on West Uintah Avenue.A weathered phone book dangles beneath it. The cost to start a conversation: 50 cents. Prepaid phone cards and credit cards are accepted, and it has a local directory assistance feature.Do many people use it?\xe2\x80\x9cOff and on,\xe2\x80\x9d a clerk at a nearby gas station replies. \xe2\x80\x9cBut not very much.\xe2\x80\x9dLack of use prompted the pay phone to be turned off last year in the Teller County Courthouse lobby in Cripple Creek.Another sign of the technological times.\xe2\x80\x9cIn this day and age, everybody uses cellphones,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lynn Fenn, administrative assistant.Many people don\xe2\x80\x99t even notice the pay phone near the metal detector in the historical 1904 courthouse.It\xe2\x80\x99s become as much of a fixture as the sign where jurors check in, which says: \xe2\x80\x9cNo claim jumping. Respect women, mules and the law.\xe2\x80\x9d\n14 regional franchises Colorado Springs residents wish we had\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s funny, when we questioned people in the building, \xe2\x80\x98Do you ever see anybody use the pay phone?\xe2\x80\x99 many said, \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a pay phone?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Fenn said. \xe2\x80\x9cA few people knew \xe2\x80\x94 those who\xe2\x80\x99ve worked here for many years.\xe2\x80\x9dAnyone who needs to make a call but doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have a cellphone can use an office phone in the lobby, she said.Mobile phones are a primary reason for the pay phone\xe2\x80\x99s demise, said Mark Thomas, who in 1995 started cataloging pay-phone locations as an art project. He was inspired, in part, by comedian David Letterman, who would call pay-phone numbers on his \xe2\x80\x9cLate Night\xe2\x80\x9d talk show to see if anyone would answer.Thomas, a concert pianist from Queens, N.Y., created a website, The Payphone Project, which lists pay phone numbers, locations and industry news.He traces the pay phone\xe2\x80\x99s fall from relevance to the Lifeline program, which gives free phones to the poor, a reliable pay-phone customer base.\xe2\x80\x9cLifeline seemed like it was created to target all that was left of the business,\xe2\x80\x9d Thomas said.Nowadays, people seek out pay phones when they lose their cellphone, forget it at home or the battery runs out, he said.\xe2\x80\x9cI still encounter an occasional Luddite who will not carry a cellphone,\xe2\x80\x9d Thomas said. And, \xe2\x80\x9cI still see a lot of travelers using calling cards to call home from pay phones.\xe2\x80\x9dMore interesting, he said, are the cases of people who use pay phones so their call cannot be traced.\xe2\x80\x9cIt was reported that in some cities, there had been increases in 911 calls made from pay phones because people calling to report crimes did not want to be associated with them,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is intended to be impossible to hide your cellphone or landline number from 911, so some who call 911 don\xe2\x80\x99t want any chance of their number being involved in a criminal investigation. They look for a pay phone.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTo help keep the industry viable, the FCC lifted audit requirements in February, saying they were \xe2\x80\x9cno longer justified as payphone revenues have plummeted due to a changing communications marketplace.\xe2\x80\x9dThe expensive audits became \xe2\x80\x9cunnecessary to ensure that the few remaining providers are compensated fairly,\xe2\x80\x9d an FCC news release says.But pay-phone eulogies are premature, Thomas said.\xe2\x80\x9cThere will always be a need for communication access that is available to the lowest common denominator,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think all public pay phones should be free for local calls, and government subsidies could keep the dial tone alive in remote areas, national parks and poor neighborhoods. \xe2\x80\x9dMore evidence that pay phones have not outlived their usefulness: In October, officials from the U.S. Forest Service and Washington state\xe2\x80\x99s Snohomish County installed a new pay phone in Verlot, Wash., a scenic area where cellphone service is unreliable and the need for communication was seen as a public safety issue.Thomas has been tracking the \xe2\x80\x9cpay phone of the future,\xe2\x80\x9d called the LinkNYC kiosk, which he says have been \xe2\x80\x9cpopping up like mushrooms all over New York.\xe2\x80\x9dThe program converts old pay phones into Wi-Fi hotspots where free calls can be made to all 50 states and Washington, D.C.The 9\xc2\xbd-foot-tall \xe2\x80\x9cLinks\xe2\x80\x9d also provide Android tablet computers to access city maps, get directions and make video calls, plus two free USB-charging stations for smartphones, the ability to use calling cards to make international calls and a 911 button.Thomas said he tries not to wax nostalgic about how, back in the day, neighborhood pay phones were society\xe2\x80\x99s communications bedrock, and the phone booth provided privacy not only for telephone calls, but also for Clark Kent to transform into Superman.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not lost on me that there was something to be said for a time when pay-phone calls were important, and the pay-as-you-go motif made every minute and finish-line-second count,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\xe2\x80\x9cI would miss the rugged but comfortable call quality of a working landline pay phone. Call quality is so far superior to those LinkNYC machines that there\xe2\x80\x99s no comparison.\xe2\x80\x9dContact the writer: 719-476-1656.\nContact the writer: 719-476-1656.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nTags\nColorado Springs\nLife\nPay Phones\nDebbie Kelley\nReporter\nStaff reporter, education and general news and features\nFollow Debbie Kelley\nClose\nGet email notifications on {{subject}} daily!\nYour notification has been saved.\nThere was a problem saving your notification.\n{{description}}\nEmail notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items.\nSave\nManage followed notifications\nClose\nFollowed notifications\nPlease log in to use this feature\nLog In\nDon't have an account? Sign Up Today\nLoad comments\nsponsored\nInnovative jewelry designer to appear at Johannes Hunter Jewelers showcase, July 18-20\nInnovative jewelry designer to appear at Johannes Hunter Jewelers showcase, July 18-20\nsponsored\nNew La-Z-Boy store now open for business at First & Main Town Center\nNew La-Z-Boy store now open for business at First & Main Town Center\nMost Read\nA-Basin extends season two more weekends with summer snow possible this weekend\nColorado baseball brawl a symptom of toxic culture in youth sports, officials say\nLETTERS: A very, very bad idea in Colorado Springs; please heed these words\nColorado Springs police search for missing at-risk adult\nMonument police chief retires abruptly; unclear who is running department\nGet the Newsletter\nThe latest breaking news, delivered straight to your email! Subscribe\nFollow our Facebook\nGet real time news updates\nFollow\nGazette.com Coloradosprings.com Gazettepreps.com Best of the Springs OutThereColorado.com\nPrivacy Policy Terms of Service \xc2\xa9 2019 Produced by Colorado Springs Gazette", b'Link kiosks expand to downtown Philadelphia\n| Smart Cities Dive\nCONTINUE TO SITE \xe2\x9e\x9e\nDeep Dive\nOpinion\nLibrary\nEvents\nJobs\nTopics\nMenu\nSign Up\nSearch\nSearch\nx\nEnergy & Utilities\nTransportation\nBuildings & Infrastructure\nEnvironment\nResilience\nGovernance\nTech & Data\nAn article from\nBrief\nLink kiosks expand to downtown Philadelphia\nAuthor\nBy\nChris Teale\n@chris_teale\nPublished\nDec. 10, 2018\nShare it\npost\nshare\ntweet\nDive Brief:\nThe City of Philadelphia has officially activated its first Link kiosks, known as LinkPHL, in its downtown area.\nThe kiosks from smart cities technology and media company Intersection will provide free Wi-Fi, mobile device charging and phone calls, as well as access to city services, information and advertising. The company expects to deploy 100 throughout the city.\n"I expect that Philadelphians and visitors to our great City will use and love all that LinkPHL has to offer. It is exciting to finally see the kiosks launch today in Center City,"\xc2\xa0Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney said in a statement. "LinkPHL\xe2\x80\x99s many amenities support our SmartCityPHL goal of creating a modern infrastructure that will benefit Philadelphia for many years to come."\nHave you heard of #LinkPHL? The new kiosks provide free secure wifi, phone calls, wayfinding, device charging, access to City services, and community info \xe2\x80\x94 and they\'re completely free to use! Learn more about the program and how you can use the kiosks \xe2\x9e\xa1\xef\xb8\x8f https://t.co/WW1BWDaj1C pic.twitter.com/Qg3HD27PgU\n\xe2\x80\x94 City of Philadelphia (@PhiladelphiaGov) December 7, 2018\nDive Insight:\nSince rolling out in 2016, Link\xe2\x80\x99s kiosks have become a popular amenity\xc2\xa0in cities like New York and Newark, NJ.\xc2\xa0In an interview with Smart Cities Dive in September, Amanda Giddon, Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s senior consumer marketing manager, said more than 5 million people have connected to the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 Wi-Fi, showing that while they have helped provide information to residents, they are also helping more people get online.\nThe initiative has also generated millions of dollars in revenue for New York City through advertising, and has created new jobs.\xc2\xa0Some report that retail business near the kiosks has experienced an uptick.\nAnd Giddon said the evolution in content on Link kiosks is well underway, including what she called a "moment-based campaign,"\xc2\xa0which in New York City has included historical information about marches in the lead-up to the Women\xe2\x80\x99s March and voter registration drives before elections. She said to expect similar efforts in Philadelphia, including an expansion of its #ArtOnLink program, which showcases the work of local artists on the 55-inch displays. "It\'s been a fun exercise to think about how to localize this at scale,"\xc2\xa0Giddon said.\nThe company has its eye on cautious expansion to other U.S. cities, and with this move has expanded its footprint outside of the Greater New York region. (Intersection also has deployed Link kiosks in London through the InLinkUK initiative.)\xc2\xa0If all goes well, and the company\'s information on transit, weather, local services and news mixes well with more off-beat and whimsical content, it could continue to move outward, especially as cities look to use technology like this to close the digital divide.\nGiddon said the company plans to make the kiosks a "beloved member of the community it serves,"\xc2\xa0especially by monitoring its content and making sure it keeps up with people\xe2\x80\x99s needs. "We are definitely evolving every day from a content perspective, but we\'ve done pretty extensive user research to ask what people want to see,"\xc2\xa0she said. "We definitely have lessons learned and will look to add that local flair in our new Link markets."\nRecommended Reading:\nCity of Philadelphia\nPhiladelphia Launches LinkPHL\nFollow\nChris Teale\non\nTwitter\nshare\ntweet\npost\nemail\nprint\nFiled Under:\nBuildings & Infrastructure\nTech & Data\nTop image credit:\nIntersection\nGet the Newsletter\nSubscribe to Smart Cities Dive to get the must-read news & insights in your inbox.\nEmail:\nSmart Cities Dive\nTopics covered: energy, green building, transportation, waste solutions, connectivity, policy and more.\nDaily\nSign up\nA valid email address is required.\nPlease select at least one newsletter.\nBy signing up you agree to our privacy policy. You can opt out anytime.', b"TP-Link's new Wi-Fi 6 routers, LinkNYC lands in Philly, and Nokia inks first home Wi-Fi deal | Wi-Fi NOW Events\nWi-Fi NOW EventsAbout usAbout Wi-Fi NOWMANIFESTOOur ratingsOur credentialsMeet the teamContact usEventsCurrent EventsDownload Show GuideBuy Wi-Fi NOW presentations & videos2019 Washington DC2019 Shanghai2018 Johannesburg2018 Berlin2018 San FranciscoPrevious EventsExpoAwardsAbout awardsThe AwardsWhy enter?How to enterJudgesHall of FameSelection criteriaMediaNewsTVTP-Link\xe2\x80\x99s new Wi-Fi 6 routers, LinkNYC lands in Philly, and Nokia inks first home Wi-Fi deal [Weekly News Brief] by Claus Hetting | December 12, 2018Wi-Fi 6 is perfect for gamers, says TP-LinkOn December 10 Taiwan-based consumer-grade Wi-Fi leader TP-Link launched not one but two futuristic-looking new Wi-Fi 6 routers dubbed Archer AX6000 and Archer\xc2\xa0AX11000. TP-Link is touting a total tri-band speed of nearly 11 Gbps for the larger of the two units (AX11000 \xe2\x80\x93 which is presumably the logic behind its name) and says that the new router will deliver \xe2\x80\x98great network performance for your gaming experience\xe2\x80\x99. Clearly the design is meant for the gaming room.Above: TP-Link\xe2\x80\x99s new Archer AX11000 Wi-Fi 6 gaming routerTP-Link does not inform us of the configuration but with eight fairly obvious antennas protruding from its case, we think 8\xc3\x978 (or 4\xc3\x974) MU-MIMO could be a good guess. Following the Netgear announcement last month, and D-Links launch early this year, TP-Link is only the third consumer-grade Wi-Fi vendor (that we know of) to launch a Wi-Fi 6 product. At least five enterprise Wi-Fi solution vendors have already launched Wi-Fi access point products. No device-side Wi-Fi 6 clients have thus far been launched but the first are expected during 1H2019.The Archer AX6000 unit will retail at $350 USD while the larger AX11000 will retail at $450 USD. Unfortunately, shipments will only start in January \xe2\x80\x93 so there won\xe2\x80\x99t be Wi-Fi 6-capable Archers under the Christmas trees this year.\xc2\xa0First five LinkNYC-style free Wi-Fi kiosk up and running in PhillyAbove: An InLinkUK kiosk installed in LondonThe first five of a planned one hundred LinkNYC-style free Wi-Fi electronic billboards is now up and running in the city of Philadelphia, USA. The project is aptly called LinkPHL (pronounced \xe2\x80\x98Link Philly\xe2\x80\x99) and this is the fourth project of its type following the original LinkNYC in New York City, LinkNWK (pronounced \xe2\x80\x98Linked Newark\xe2\x80\x99), and InLinkUK in the United Kingdom. In the US the three projects are operated by Intersection, while in the UK Intersection is partnering with BT for operations. For an impressive overview of the wide extent of the UK project, see a map of current InLinkUK locations, see this link.The schemes are funded by electronic billboard advertising. The city of Philadelphia and Intersection will evenly split advertising revenues guaranteeing the city a revenue of $450,000 per year, said the Philadelphia Enquirer earlier this year.\xc2\xa0LinkNYC currently serves 5 million users and some 20 million Wi-Fi sessions per week, says Intersection. Earlier this year, InLinkUK was shortlisted for the Wi-Fi NOW Affordable Connectivity award.Editors note: The above section on Link free Wi-Fi projects has been corrected 12.14.2018.Nokia inks first Wi-Fi mesh service provider dealNokia has been conspicuously late (and nearly absent) in addressing the burgeoning and lucrative home Wi-Fi mesh business opportunity. But a couple of weeks ago, the company finally managed to secure their first major home Wi-Fi win: The customer is AIS Fibre in Thailand, who as of February this year reported that it serves around half a million households with fibre-based broadband.According to the press release\xc2\xa0AIS Fibre customers in Thailand \xe2\x80\x9cwill be eligible to receive the Nokia WiFi Beacon 3 duo-pack for a special price.\xe2\x80\x9d Conceptually, the Nokia mesh solution \xe2\x80\x93 called \xe2\x80\x98Nokia Beacon\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x93 looks similar to many of its brethren although Nokia says the solution also detects and mitigates \xe2\x80\x98non-Wi-Fi\xe2\x80\x99 interference sources./Claus.\nWi-Fi Industry NewsJune 20, 2019 [Regulation & Policy]Europe\xe2\x80\x99s process to release 6 GHz spectrum to Wi-Fi on track, expert saysJune 18, 2019 [Breaking News]Emergency \xe2\x80\x98Ducklink\xe2\x80\x99 Wi-Fi to save lives during disastersJune 17, 2019 [Breaking News]Facebook takes on leadership role to improve Wi-FiJune 16, 2019 [News Exclusive]South Africa: Vast Networks\xe2\x80\x99 Wi-Fi offload trial with Vodacom \xe2\x80\x98faster than cellular\xe2\x80\x99June 13, 2019 [Breaking News]World\xe2\x80\x99s biggest Wi-Fi 6 trial tees off at US Open with Cisco & USGAJune 12, 2019 [Weekly News Brief]Wi-Fi news roundup: Aruba, Marvell, Quantenna, Newracom, and moreJune 12, 2019 [Breaking News]Greece to start building nationwide free public Wi-Fi networkMay 30, 2019 [Breaking News]Cuba to legalise private Wi-Fi networks by end JulyMay 30, 2019 [Breaking News]Wi-Fi 6 enters steep growth phase far outpacing 5G, says IDCMay 30, 2019 [CHIPSET NEWS]Wi-Fi HaLow IoT startup Morse Micro lands US$17M in Series A financingSubscribe to our newsletterSubscribe to Wi-Fi NOW
